Title: O’Neill claims government took another K1 billion loan
Content: IALIBU-Pangia MP Peter O’Neill claims that the Government has taken on another K1 billion in new loans, only weeks after withdrawing more than K1 billion in dividends from Kumul Minerals Holdings Limited. O’Neill, in a statement yesterday, said the latest borrowings include K600 million for the “politically convenient” Connect PNG programme from local banks and K400 million from the Asian Development Bank for general budget support. “That’s K2 billion raised in just a couple of weeks – but still no medicines,” O’Neill said. “The prime minister insensitively told medical workers last Friday to ‘do more with less’, admitting that there is a serious cash shortage and that he cannot release funds to buy essential medicines.” A comment was sought from Prime Minister James Marape yesterday but no response was received when this edition went to press. O’Neill claimed that Marape told doctors and nurses to stop complaining about the lack of funding and to focus on patient outcomes. “Real patriotism is shown when professionals work for the good of the country, not just for pay checks. Health workers must be efficient and resourceful in how they use what is available,” O’Neill said. “Marape’s comments contradict what he said only three weeks earlier when he criticised the 22 governors and provincial health authorities (PHA), claiming that the medicine budget had been spent and that PHAs were at fault for the shortages. “Fast-forward three weeks, and now he is blaming doctors and nurses, while admitting there is no money left to buy medicines. “The public is frustrated by chronic shortages affecting hospitals nationwide and blames Marape and his Pangu Government for the pain, suffering and unnecessary deaths due to the medicine drought. “People want answers on why billions of Kina continue to be committed elsewhere while essential drugs remain out of stock. “It is simply not acceptable for Papua New Guineans to be left without medicines while another K2 billion flows into what many see as a Waigani slush fund.”

Title: Treasurer: Country needs better return from resources
Content: TREASURER Ian Ling- Stuckey says the country needs a better return from its resources. “International studies clearly indicate that Papua New Guinea is benefiting less from its resource wealth than most other developing countries,” he said in a statement. “The Government’s work to get a fairer share is being attacked again by the Opposition. “In a recent statement, he (former prime minister Peter O’Neill) attacked the Government’s work to get payments from the Kumul resource companies.” O’Neill said recently that he had credible information that the Kumul Mineral Holdings had been instructed to pay K1 billion in advanced dividend before the end of the financial year. He said: “Kumul Minerals earns most of its revenues from the Ok Tedi mine. The mine is 100 per cent owned by the people of PNG since 2013 when it was nationalised under my government. We never interfered and the mine ran independently. Now it is being pushed around as the cash-cow. Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) has been instructed to pay K900 million in dividends in 2025.” Ling-Stuckey said that as required by responsible financial management, “the Government is expecting the Kumul Holding companies to pay dividends in line with Government policies”. “The Government, and our international partners, have become more and more concerned about the lack of payments from our Kumuls,” he said. “When the PNGLNG project was being designed, the expectation was that 100 per cent of all the dividends would come to the budget, either directly, or through a Sovereign Wealth Fund.” Ling-Stuckey claimed that O’Neill changed the original approach, and “gave the Kumuls the flexibility to decide how much of the people’s dividends should be paid to the people”. “He was so confused he actually set up a private company but owned by the people of PNG. Worse, it was the only company in the world, where workers decided how much of profits are given back to owners. The people’s budget share was reduced to less than half,” he said. “But even then, the Kumuls have not met this much lower share.  Estimates are that Kumul Petroleum Holdings has K3,299 million in outstanding dividends. “Why then is O’Neill trying to protect Kumul Petroleum from paying their fair share of dividends to help pay for teachers and nurses and police? “The 2025 Budget set out that Kumul Mineral Holdings (KMH) was expected to pay K921 million. Mid-year, only K121 million has been paid. This is unsatisfactory. Any responsible government would go to the Kumuls and instruct them to pay according to the Government’s NEC endorsed dividend policy. “Treasury has not issued demands to Ok Tedi to buy government bills. KMH made an offer to buy extra government bills instead of paying dividends, but this was rejected by Treasury. “Treasury Bills have already been very well supported by investors this year. If KMH has the cash to invest in Treasury Bills, they have the cash to make dividend payments to the Government. We want tax revenues from the resource sector, not just more debt.” Parliament will reconvene tomorrow (Nov 18) for a two-week session dedicated to passing the 2026 National Budget.

Title: Budget to be tabled on Thursday
Content: THE 2026 national budget is expected to be tabled in Parliament on Thursday. Secretary for Treasury Andrew Oaeke, in a paid advertisement on Friday, said the budget lock-up would be at the Parliament state function room on Thursday starting at 9am. This will be followed by the tabling of the budget in parliament by Treasurer Ian-Ling Stuckey. Prime Minister James Marape last month said that the budget would continue to focus on growth, maintaining the debt level and primary service delivery. The discussions may include anticipated revenue sources, allocations for public service and potential economic initiatives. Marape on returning from the Brazil Cop30 last Tuesday, emphasised the importance of a fiscal restraint on the belief that funding was adequate to accommodate the 2027 General Elections. He said this would include an oversight by both Government and Opposition MPs for transparency.

Title: Sir Tiong’s passing a great loss: Duma
Content: STATE Enterprises Minister William Duma has described the passing of the late Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King, the founder of the Rimbunan Hijau (RH) Group of Companies, as a “big loss to PNG”. Duma in a statement said Tiong had started small and became very successful in everything he did. “He contributed heavily in the development of the PNG logging industry to what it is today, as well as in ensuring that the skyline of Port Moresby was improved by both the ground-breaking Vision City Mega Mall and the Stanley Hotel and Suites projects,” Duma said. “These are billion kina projects which he pushed for when not many foreign investors were prepared to invest in PNG,” he said. “In the media and communications industry, he provided competition by establishingThe Nationalnewspaper, and that has contributed immensely to communication in PNG.” Tiong passed away last Tuesday in Malaysia.

Title: 30 female students evacuated from Rabaul
Content: A ROYAL Australian Air Force evacuated 30 female students of the Sonoma Adventist College in East New Britain to Lae because of on-going fights between students and locals. Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso confirmed that the 30 female students were evacuated because of the violence. He said that of the 30, 11 would travel to Goroka, two students to Madang and the rest were from Morobe. They landed at Nadzab Tomodachi International Airport yesterday. Rosso, the Lae MP who was behind the evacuation exercise, thanked the Australia Defence Force and Canberra for their assistance to airlift the students to Lae. Similar arrangements were organized by Rosso for University of Goroka students from East Sepik and West New Britain currently in Lae.

Title: Jokema wins award for business
Content: MUSICIAN Honlly Isaac, known across Papua New Guinea as Jokema, has been honoured with the 2025 MoniPlus Sir Bernard Chan Entrepreneur with a Disability Award. Isaac received the award during the Ela Motors SME Awards in Port Moresby last week. The surprise announcement was made after Isaac just finished his performance and had spoken candidly about the importance of building additional pathways for sustainability. “This award is not about me but for all people living with disabilities and doing their hardest to live normal lives to work, to be with our families and make a contribution to our communities,” Isaac said after receiving the award. “Just because someone cannot walk or see or hear does not mean they have nothing to offer society. “My disability does not hold me back as I continue to make music, to appear on stage, run business operations and make my contribution to community development.” Isaac became a paraplegic after a car accident in 2018, and has since transformed adversity into a platform for leadership, inspiration and nation-building. He runs multiple businesses, including the Jokema Inn, Jump Enterprises, Oil Palm Trucking, The Fixers, ZenX Security and the newly-established Spinal Cord Injury Foundation. “God has a path for everyone and I believe that He put me in this wheelchair for a reason. “I went from the highest point in my musical career to the lowest moment of my life when I lost the use of my legs. “But I realised that with focus, discipline and positivity I could rebuild my life. “My purpose now is to look after my people in Morobe, empower young musicians, farmers, SMEs and be an advocate for those living like me.” The award was presented to Jokema after he had taken part in a question and answer session where he discussed how musicians and entrepreneurs should diversify, create and build long term livelihoods. Moments later, Sir Bernard Chan took the stage and presented him with the award, praising his exceptional courage, innovation and unwavering commitment to the community. “To be honoured with this award by such a great and outstanding man of the stature of Sir Bernard Chan is a great honour,” Jokema said. The Ela Motors SME Awards once again recognised excellence, resilience and the spirit of innovation – values Honlly Isaac embodies daily.

Title: Yafai appeals conviction
Content: THE Supreme Court heard an appeal against conviction by former deputy Finance secretary Jacob Yafai and adjourned the case to next month for directions hearing. Yafai, from Yangoru’s Karapia village in East Sepik, was jailed 22 years last month by Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika for misappropriating K41.8 million of State money. He filed this appeal against conviction through his lawyer Edward Sasingian of Sasingian Lawyers. Justice David Cannings, who presided in the matter in a one-man bench in Waigani on Friday, heard the appeal and adjourned it to Dec 11 for further directions. Sasingian informed the court that Yafai’s appeal book was ready but asked the court to give a date in February for the appeal to be heard properly. The court heard that Yafai filed the Supreme Court application without leave to review the decision of Chief Justice Sir Gibbs made on Aug 19, which convicted him on four counts of misappropriation and one count of abuse of office. Yafai argued among other grounds that Sir Gibbs had erred in law and fact when he had him convicted and has sought orders to uphold the appeal, and have the whole of the judgement of Aug 19 quashed. He is also arguing in the appeal that Sir Gibbs had made an error of convicting him on the finding that he was directed by the former Finance secretary the late Steven Gibson to verify the claim by Paul Paraka and that when he had failed to do so, he was acting dishonestly when the evidence before the court said otherwise. On another ground of appeal, Yafai argued that Sir Gibbs erred in mixed facts and law, when he accepted the evidence of the former Finance Minister James Marape that was given against him in court, when it was unreliable and contradicted State exhibit, indicating bias. Yafai further claims that the trial judge erred in law in convicting him on abuse of office, for directing the payment of K41.8 million to Paraka Lawyers when the evidence before the court did not support the element of the charge. He also sought an order to alternatively have the matter remitted back to the National Court for a retrial before another judge.

Title: UN, Australian Border Force help PNG Customs
Content: THE United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), with funding support from the Australian Border Force, has donated six sets of IT equipment and 15 sets of drug and precursor test kits to the Papua New Guinea Customs Service (PNGCS). Chief Commissioner of Customs David Towe said these resources were designated for the Passenger and Cargo Control Programme (PCCP) at Port Control Units in PNG. “We appreciate UNODC’s unwavering support through ongoing capacity building training initiatives and now through the donation of the IT equipment and drug test kits,” he said. The handover took place during the closing ceremony of the UNODC-WCO-INTERPOL PCCP Law Enforcement Assistance Programme (LEAP) training on combating deforestation and illicit timber trafficking last month. Towe expressed gratitude for the continued partnership with UNODC. “We appreciate UNODC’s unwavering support through ongoing capacity building training initiatives and now through the donation of the IT equipment and drug test kits,” he said. “These tools will significantly leverage our ability to secure our borders, combat drug trafficking and other illicit activities, and safeguard our communities and the economy.” The week-long training provided theoretical and practical knowledge of forest crime prevention and timber trafficking, including topics such as impacts of deforestation, timber supply chain analysis, risk profiling and indicators, international trade documentation, physical inspection procedures, crime scene management, evidence collection, global forestry crime trends and concealment methods. Commissioner Border Security and Regional Operations Benjamin Sine acknowledged UNODC’s ongoing support in strengthening PNGCS border security. “These trainings strengthen our enforcement capabilities and collaboration between PNGCS and UNODC in advancing border security efforts. Our focus remains on building internal capacity to ensure sustainable capacity development in future,” he said. The training was facilitated by PNG Customs officers Leslie Malo and Jerry Abraham, alongside PCCP deputy regional coordinator Topan Caesar Renyaan and programme assistant Jadetayakom Luythong. Sine said there were 16 Customs officers from respective divisions including, regional operations, enforcement, post clearance audit (PCA), intelligence and targeting, and Trade Excise and Valuation participated in the training. “It is encouraging to see our own trainers leading these sessions and I urge all participants to make full use of the knowledge gained,” Sine said.

Title: PM commends peaceful elections
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has commended the people of Hela, including those in his own district of Tari-Pori, for a peaceful completion of the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections. Marape said the peaceful conclusion across the province was an achievement for Hela, marking a clear shift from past challenges and instability that often disrupted the election process. “Today, I am proud to say that 99 per cent of the council elections in Tari-Pori have been completed, with people voting freely and peacefully, free of intimidation or violence,” he said. “There were no law and order issues reported. From where we have come from to where we are today, in just 13 years since we became a province, this is an extraordinary transformation.” He thanked the people of Hela, including candidates, community leaders and supporters, for respecting the democratic process and working together to ensure a peaceful outcome. “I commend all the candidates who contested these elections. Even for those who did not make it through, you remain an important part of your communities,” Marape said. “Our district, in partnership with the Hela government, will ensure that everyone continues to play a part in local leadership – through ward committees and community-based teams – to maintain peace, stability and progress across our province. “I want to commend the provincial election manager for once again delivering a credible and orderly election outcome when many thought it would not be possible. “Despite limited police and defence personnel due to manpower shortages, our communities rallied together to uphold peace and order. This shows that when people take responsibility and work together, things can be settled much better.” Marape also thanked Hela Governor Philip Undialu for his leadership and commitment in conducting the elections.

Title: Jail project needs urgent funding
Content: A CRITICAL restoration of the Mukrumanda jail project in Enga has not started despite a K8 million allocation from the National Government, says an official. Correctional Services Minister Joe Kuli said this funding was to ensure prisons were built to accommodate law offenders from the escalating law and order problems in Enga. “The Correctional Services facilitates the prison areas and allocations for prisons rest with the provincial government. “For a complete rehabilitation of all 21 prisons around the country, it would take K32 million in total, but so far, the allocation to CS has only been at K2 million for prison rehabilitations and other works. “This is insufficient given there are 21 prisons and the functions of each prisons defer,” he said. He said law offenders were being diverted to Baisu Prison in the Western Highlands which had far exceeded its capacity of more than 1,000 persons. In September, Prime Minister James Marape when visiting Wabag said a K8 million was allocated and this was to ensure some effort was made to curb the escalating law and order problems in the province. Marape had stressed that Mukrumanda was a critical project and encouraged the provincial government to get the project off the ground as soon as possible. CS acting Commissioner Bernard Nepo said Mukrumanda was a project that had legacy issues. “With the support from Finance and EPG, we are trying to sort this out so that law and order issues can be resolved not in a big way but at least to contain those that are brought to our custody. “At this stage, the project is yet to be completed. A few weeks back the prime minister made an undertaking that K8 million should be injected to the project and so we are in the process of finding that money from Finance.

Title: 240 reservists passout from training centre
Content: ABOUT 241 police reservists have passed out in the first intake of the National Reservist Training for East New Britain on Friday. Governor Michael Marum congratulated the reservists at Kokopo during a parade witnessed by Police Commissioner David Manning. “It is a significant milestone for the province, marking a renewed commitment to strengthening law and order and addressing manpower gaps within the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary,” he said. Marum also thanked the Government, the Ministry of Police and the Department of Police for the initiative and support to the reservist programme, stating its importance in complementing regular police operations, especially in rural and high-demand areas. “I would also acknowledge the support and technical cooperation of the Australian Federal Police personnel based in Kokopo,” he said. Marum challenged the reservists to wear their uniform with pride and purpose, reminding them that many before them had upheld the values and discipline of the constabulary. “The uniform is a symbol of service, sacrifice and respect for the people they serve,” he told the reservists,” Marum said. He also appealed to the people of ENB for their respect and support for the new reservists. “They are here to serve you so allow them to do their jobs with the greatest respect by working with them,” he said. “When the public and the police cooperate, we build safer communities together.” Marum also extended his appreciation and support to ENB MPs; Dr Allan Marat, Jelta Wong, Eremas ToBaining, Elias Kapavore and the provincial administration for their contributions to the successful implementation of the programme.
People: Allan Marat, Elias Kapavore, Jelta Wong

Title: Marape backs Australia to host Cop31
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has expressed his strong support for Australia’s bid to host the 31st Conference of the Parties (Cop31) climate summit next year. Marape, in a statement on Thursday, said PNG’s support would elevate the collective voice of the pacific and Oceania region on Global Climate Action. Marape confirmed that he had discussed the matter with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and that Papua New Guinea, alongside other Pacific Island nations, fully supported Australia’s candidature to host the summit. “The Australian bid to host Cop31 is not just an Australian initiative – it is a regional bid, one that carries the full backing of the 15 Pacific Island Forum nations,” Marape said. “We in the Pacific collectively believe that after Brazil hosted Cop30 this year as a forest nation, it is proper and timely for the Oceania region – home of the world’s largest ocean – to host Cop31.” Marape said this proposal represented a continuation of the global conversation linking the “Forest Nations” and “Ocean Nations”, two essential nature-based solutions to climate change. “With due respect to our friends in Turkey, this is nothing personal,” he said. “Turkey and its president are highly respected.” Marape underscored that the Pacific and rainforest nations carry rare moral authority to speak on both mitigation and adaptation, given their vulnerability to the worsening impacts of climate change and their stewardship over vital global carbon sinks. “The Pacific Ocean is the largest on Earth, and our Island Nations are among those most affected by rising sea levels, coastal erosion and changing weather patterns,” he said. “We experience the harshest realities of climate change first hand, yet we also offer some of the most powerful solutions – our forests and our oceans, which absorb massive amounts of carbon and host immense biodiversity.” Marape emphasised that Cop 31 in Australia would not only give voice to the Pacific’s climate concerns but also demonstrate regional solidarity and leadership in driving global transition towards clean, green energy. “The industrialised nations have not yet fully transitioned from fossil fuels to renewable energy,” he said. “As the world works toward this transformation, the Pacific and the rainforest nations – those in the Amazon, the Congo Basin, and here in Southeast Asia – stand as critical partners through our stewardship of forests and oceans.” He added: “From Belém in Brazil to Australia in Oceania, there is a natural sequence – a continuation of the climate dialogue – linking the forest nations and ocean nations. This transition of host venues symbolically connects nature-based solutions to global climate action.”

Title: MP urges Marape to concentrate on internal climate change issues
Content: HIRI-KOIARI MP Keith Iduhu says Prime Minister James Marape and his government should concentrate on internal climate change problems so that the country can properly benefit from climate funding. He said this on Friday after Marape addressed the World Leaders Climate Action Summit at the 30th Conference of the Parties (Cop30) in Belem, Brazil. “I agree in principle with Marape that PNG deserves conservation financing, however, the Government’s failure to address ingrained and systematic corruption and its failure to strengthen dangerously weak institutions will, in my view, ultimately prevent funds from benefiting the people,” Iduhu said. “His government must crack down on illegal logging.” Marape, when addressing the world leaders at Cop30, reaffirmed PNG’s commitment to global climate action and sustainable development. Iduhu said: “He wants PNG to have fair access to the Green Climate Fund, which is a large international fund that helps developing countries pay for projects related to climate change. “He (Marape) also wants clear and honest rules for carbon market systems, which is a way for countries to trade ‘carbon credits’ as outlined in the global Paris climate agreement. “This ensures that money from protecting forests goes to the right people. “They must safeguard the rights of landowners with sufficient law enforcement support to ensure they do not come into conflict with illegal loggers. “Most importantly, Marape and his government must ensure police are resourced to protect and serve the people.”

Title: Paita to continue partnership
Content: MOROBE Governor Rainbo Paita will continue the partnership between the provincial government, Katim Tasol Organisation (KTO) and Manalos Aviation to establish portable clinics in rural areas. Paita said health was one of the major sectors that his government would be looking at during this remaining 15 months of his regime. He said the bigger population of Morobe was living in rural areas. The portable clinic is the Bush Clinic project of the KTO, a non-governmental organisation with the mission of bringing quality health to every rural community in line with the Government health plan 2021-2030. The provincial government, in partnership with Manalos Aviation, supported the NGO to install two portable clinics at Indagen in Kabwum last year. “We are going to pick more than five sites that are unable to get quality health services,” Paita said. “We will partner with them and fund them to run the programme in the rural areas.” KTO is working in partnership with the Lutheran Health Services, Mama Foundation (Manalos Aviation) and the Morobe health authority to provide treatment for common healthcare problems. The features included in the modular are a mini operating theatre for obstetric and minor surgical procedures, treatment for babies, including neonatal resuscitation, pediatric infusion pumps and phototherapy, stabilising critical patients with intensive care monitoring and adaptive airway management. Diagnostic unit integrated: Important diagnostic tests can be done on-site. This partnership was established under the leadership of the late governor Luther Wenge, and Paita promised to continue because it would benefit the rural population of Morobe.

Title: Rosso urges unity among politicians
Content: THERE has to be unity and collaboration among Morobe politicians for the benefit of the greater Morobe, says Lae MP, John Rosso. Rosso made the remarks after the election of the new Governor, Rainbo Paita, and stated that politics will not benefit Morobe, if there was division among the MPs. As a senior politician and the Deputy Prime Minister, Rosso, congratulated Paita, stating that the vacancy has been filled and Paita would chair the Tutumang (provincial assembly) for the next 15 months. “We have the ability to change Morobe through this house,” he added. “Put people first in every decision that we will make.” After cautioning the MPs, Rosso, pledged to work in collaboration with Paita, stating that Morobe is a big province with many resources and challenges, and if they work together, then they could deliver. Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jr shared the same sentiment and said that there had to be an equal benefit sharing agreement established under the new governor. “People in the rural area are still suffering,” he added. “More money should be funded into the airlines company to assist the rural areas that are not connected to a road link.” Basil then stated that party politics must not be played at the provincial level, but there had to be equality in benefit sharing and be fair. Tewae-Siassi MP Dr. Kobby Bomareo told Paita that there had to be restoration of the budget for all the provincial roads in the next budget. “People of Morobe and leaders must not take sides,” he said. “Let us unite and be positive for going way forward. “If we divide, then we can’t achieve the goals and deliver the services people need. “The chairman (governor) must work together with the provincial executive council and the MPs to serve the interests of rural Morobe.” Bomareo then congratulated Paita and urged the 10 MPs and the People’s Executive Council to work together for the interest of the rural Morobe.
People: John Rosso, Kobby Bomareo, Rainbo Paita, Sam Basil

Title: K7.4 million park to attract tourists
Content: THE redeveloped Konebada recreational facility at Gabutu, constructed at a cost of K7.4 million, is expected to not only serve the local community but be also a tourist attraction. National Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop said at the opening on Friday that Port Moresby has three main beaches, Ela Beach, Konebada and Taurama. “It has the potential to be reclaimed and to have that part of our seafront enjoyed by residents and visitors but that’s another challenge and story,” he said. “We want the city to look attractive to tourists and business people. “With the NRL franchise, we need to look at how to improve standards in the city like the car parks at our stadiums.” Prime Minister James Marape said the Government was working on a policy and by next year, they would announce a learning programme that would be attached to traditional land across the country. “We started something at Tuhava estate,” he said. “This would allow traditional landowners to have titles and earn money instead of losing land forever. Marape said the other agenda they were looking at was boosting tourism within the country and internationally apart from gold, copper and others. Marape said the city had to be a better place to set an example to other provinces because it was the central stopover for tourists and other visitors. Meanwhile, local MP Justin Tkatchenko said that last year they advertised for Motu-Koitabu companies or interested persons to manage and run the facility, knowing that many years before it was traditional Motu-Koitabu land. “We had 12 applicants from Vabukori who are the main village and from there they were selected from merit and ability to maintain, operate and have these facilities properly coordinated for the benefit of the public and to set the new direction for the electorate,” he said. The NCD Commission board committed K6.4 million for the project with an additional K1 million from the district services improvement programme.
People: James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko, Powes Parkop

Title: PM pays tribute to RH founder
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has thanked the late Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King, the founder of the Rimbunan Hijau (RH) Group of Companies, for his work and contributions to Papua New Guinea. “I pass on our condolences to the family, relatives and the staff of all RH companies on the passing of Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King,” Marape said in a statement. “We appreciate his work and contributions to our country in the creation of a business conglomerate that has covered everything from forestry to supermarkets to hotels and real estate, to the media. “These companies have employed thousands of Papua New Guineans over the years, and through them put food on the table, send children to school, and meet basic needs.” Tiong passed away on Tuesday in Malaysia. Marape acknowledged his contributions to industries such as oil palm, forestry, aviation, supermarket chains, real estate, tourism and hospitality, andThe Nationalnewspaper. “I acknowledge Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King’s work and thank him for his choice to invest heavily in our country and opening up opportunities to many of our people. We thank him. May his soul rest in peace.”

Title: Ela Motors donates bus for education programme
Content: ELA Motors has donated a bus to the Port Moresby Nature Park to be used for its education programme. Ela Motors chief executive officer Masaru Mikami said the artwork, by Japanese artist Kensuke Miyazaki, reflected the spirit of Papua New Guinea through themes of cultural pride, innovation and community collaboration. “It stands as a symbol of our shared journey and enduring commitment to unity and progress,” Mikami said. He said renowned artist Miyazaki was best known as the project leader of the Over the Wall initiative. Miyazaki said that the project had provided vibrant murals to nine countries including Kenya, Timor-Leste, Ukraine, Ecuador, Haiti, Pakistan, Benin, Palau and the Netherlands. “Papua New Guinea becomes the 10th, as part of a global mission to create super-happy murals with local communities and brighten the world through art,” he said. In celebrating PNG’s 50th Independence anniversary, Miyazaki and his team also created commemorative murals for Kokopo, Goroka and Port Moresby. Prime Minister James Marape thanked Ela Motors and Japan for being good corporate partners in the development of the country.

Title: Public service holiday dates set
Content: PUBLIC servants will take a break for Christmas from Thursday, Dec 25 to Friday, Jan 2, according to the Department of Personnel Management. Department Secretary Taies Sansan in a statement said: “The shutdown period allows public servants the opportunity to rest and spend quality time with their families during the festive season.” “However, essential and emergency services such as hospitals, police, defence, correctional services, and public utilities will continue operations to ensure services to our people are not disrupted during this time.” The three paid shutdown days are Monday, Dec 29, Tuesday, Dec 30, and Wednesday, Dec 31. Sansan added that public servants rostered to work during the shutdown would be compensated with a paid day off at a later date. “Departments and agencies are encouraged to plan accordingly so that critical functions continue smoothly while allowing as many staff as possible to enjoy the festive break,” she said. She said that the department’s payroll division, in collaboration with Finance, would maintain normal operations, plus the Immigration and Citizenship Services Authority. “I wish all our public servants and their families a safe and blessed Christmas and a prosperous New Year 2026.”

Title: All process followed in election of governor, says deputy clerk
Content: THE election of the new Morobe governor followed due processes, says Deputy Clerk to Parliament Basil Kambuliagen. Kambuliagen presided over a Tutumang (provincial assembly) special sitting yesterday to elect a new governor to replace the late Luther Wenge. The special sitting was supposed to start at 10am but delayed to 11am. “Even though there was a slight delay, it was for them to manage themselves. “We cannot force them as they are mandated leaders,” Kambuliagen said. “We are satisfied with everything because no constitutional amendments were made. “The process has been perfectly followed, which means there will be no complaints.” Deputy governor Willie Simbisi called for the nomination of candidates at 11.42am. Kambuliagen said democratic processes were followed, guided by the standing orders, in nominating and electing Rainbo Paita as the Governor of Morobe for the next 15 months. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP, John Rosso, said the vacancy created by the passing away of Luther Wenge on Sept 13, had been filled  yesterday, Nov 13. Rosso called for unity among the MPs and the provincial executive council to deliver services in the rural areas of Morobe.
People: John Rosso, Luther Wenge, Rainbo Paita

Title: Menyamya students urged to stay active during forced break
Content: MENYAMYA students attending the University of Goroka have been encouraged to spend their early school break in productive activities like awareness and advocacy in the district. The 60 student were among the group of Morobe students from the institution who were repatriated to Lae and accommodated at Bugandi Secondary School on Tuesday night. Menyamya MP Solen Loifa and administrator Fidelis Harrisol met with the students yesterday to transport them back to the district which is located over 100 kilometres southwest of the provincial capital. “When you’re back in the district, don’t get involved in politics or any violence,” Harrisol said. “Rest your mind, be productive. If you want to carry out awareness on certain issues, advice the district and we’ll support you with resources.” Loifa said what happened was an unfortunate situation and sympathised with the students for the disruption to their academic year. He was in Goroka with other Morobe leaders yesterday to facilitate the movement. He thanked the Morobe administration and fellow MPs from the province’s nine districts for their concerted efforts in ensuring their children’s safe return home. Harrisol confirmed that no Menyamya student was injured during the fight between UOG students and Goroka landowners. “You students are our human resource, we at the district respect you and must make sure you reunite with your parents and give them comfort,” he said. The final group in Lae are the East Sepik Students body, currently accommodated at the Lae Secondary School. Morobe administration met with them to arrange for their movement to Bugandi Secondary, awaiting further arrangements for their return to respective provinces. A total of 45 buses and vehicles convoyed from Goroka, Eastern Highlands to Lae, bringing more than 1,000 students from the Mamose region.

Title: Reckless driving still high
Content: MORE THAN 50 road accidents have occurred over the past five months in the National Capital District (NCD). In July, police reported that these accidents were due to high speed and alcohol related, causing deaths of at least 10 people.“With the festive season coming up and while it is a time to be joyful to celebrate the birth of our Lord and saviour, there’s a lot of things that happens during this time,” Police Commissioner David Manning said. Manning urged motorists to take extra precautions and be mindful of pedestrians and other road users. Recent accidents in the city included the Konedobu incident that claimed three lives on Tuesday, one at 5-Mile where a contractor lost his life and two other accidents the same nigh but no deaths. Meanwhile, NCD Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab said traffic police were investigating the Konedobu accident. “There were about four traffic accidents reported to police because people are still driving recklessly around the city,” he said. “Our traffic officers are making arrests, people are being convicted, but we still have ignorant individuals who do not think about other road users and the people they carry.” Simatab said they were trying their best to ensure some accidents were avoided by conducting random police stop-and-search operations, setting up roadblocks and doing motor patrols to show police presence. When drivers see police, they tend to drive with care. “Police will not always be at locations where you are involved in an accident; look after yourself, passengers and others on the road,” Simatab said. He also called on the relatives of the deceased to work with police to hasten investigations.

Title: Bodies of two women found
Content: POLICE in the National Capital District and Central this week discovered bodies of two unidentified women and warned young girls and women to be extra careful. One of the bodies was found along the Hiritano Highway and the other at 12-Mile outside the Ilimo Farm. NCD Metropolitan Supt Warrick Simatab had said women and girls should feel safe walking on streets, going to school or to work. “We want to build a city where women and girls walk freely, without fear,” he said. Police have warned girls to inform their families of their whereabouts in case anything happens they can reach you. “A quick response by the police saved a young woman last week from being raped by a man. The man has been arrested and detained,” police said. “Always inform others where you are going. For the two females who are currently in the morgue, please advise the police of any missing female family members so we can work to identify them.” Forensic members from NCD and Central police units attended to the scene at 12-Mile and transported the body to the morgue. Police are now working to identify the deceased.

Title: Power lies with parliament to ratify referendum result
Content: PARLIAMENT is the final decision-making authority to ratify the 2019 Bougainville referendum results for independence, says Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville Matters chairman Dr Allan Marat. He said this as the committee completed its final round of public consultations on the referendum results and post-referendum developments in Arawa yesterday. He said a report compiled from their regional consultations, which began in Goroka last month followed by Lae, Kokopo then Port Moresby, would be presented to Parliament during this month’s sitting for debate. “These consultative forums are of importance for dialogue, consensus-building and democratic participation on Bougainville’s Referendum,” he said. “Bougainvilleans have already spoken through the referendum with the 97.7 per cent vote for independence, while the rest voted for greater autonomy. “From these consultations, the committee will report to Parliament its findings and recommendations, as Parliament has the final decision-making authority on the referendum results.” Marat said that the consultations were an important part of the Melanesian Agreement which was signed by Prime Minister James Marape and Bougainville President Ishmael Toroama on June 26. Among other provisions, it states that the Bougainville Referendum and the Joint Consultation Report be presented to the 11th Parliament, including the committee’s report from its consultations. “According to our terms of reference, the committee shall oversee the implementation of the Bougainville Peace Agreement as stipulated in the Constitution,” Marat said. “The committee shall report to Parliament bi-annually, or as and when required on updates of work in progress on the implementation of the peace agreement. “After these consultations, we will present the first report to Parliament for members to debate.” He said the Melanesian Agreement provided the means by which the referendum results would be brought to Parliament. He said these, among others, were important provisions of the agreement between the Government and the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG):

Title: Pariwa gives K100,000 to business association
Content: MADANG Governor Ramsey Pariwa has committed K100,000 to members of a newly established business association called the Begesin-Girawa Resources Landowners Association, to support them. Pariwa committed the funding on Tuesday when he officiated at the launching of the association and its 43 business arms. He said that he was pleased to help local associations because they had taken the first step in organising themselves through the registration of their businesses and for attending literacy training. Pariwa also acknowledged a local consultant Erich Hansin for sacrificing his time and effort in formulating the policy documentations of the 43 business arms. Association chairman Mek Orip said: “Your intervention in helping us goes to show that you have the heart to see changes and developments taking place in rural settings of Madang and we are so grateful for such a commitment.” Pariwa challenged people of Begesin-Girawa constituency and Usino LLG to get their acts together and apply for loans under the Madang SME credit scheme which was launched in April this year. He said Madang had surpassed other provinces in the country by investing K5 million which was now parked at the National Development Bank for indigenous people to acquire loans. Meanwhile, Pariwa also announced another commitment of K350,000 for the maintenance of the road from Negeri junction to Manipur station in Usino LLG.

Title: Women join Enga PHA board
Content: TWO women were among seven who were sworn-in as members in the new Enga Provincial Health Authority Board yesterday. Karo Maha, the country manager of New Porgera Limited and Barrick Limited, said she volunteered to be on the board while her colleague Jennifer Kaeyo, said she did not hesitate when the offer was made. Kaeyo is one of the deputy directors of the PNG Fire and Rescue Services. She works in the policy division. The board was sworn in by Wabag District Magistrate Lisandra Kot-Ipata. Enga Governor Sir Peter Ipatas witnessed the event.

Title: Rural hospital gets new bus
Content: THE Warangoi Rural Hospital which caters for more than 15,000 people in Pomio’s Sinivit local level government area of East New Britain have received a new hospital bus and medical equipment. The donation was a joint effort between the East New Britain Provincial Government (ENBPG) and the East New Britain Provincial Health Authority (ENBPHA). ENBPHA acting director of corporate affairs, Carol Malisa, commended the Warangoi Rural Hospital team and said the new vehicle would complement the hospital’s only ambulance. “The medical equipment and vehicle commissioned today will strengthen the hospital’s capacity to deliver quality care for communities in Sinivit,” Malisa said. Warangoi Rural Hospital serves a population of more than 15,000 people and has faced operational challenges in recent years, including disruptions caused by law and order issues between 2022 and 2025. Hospital administrator and health extension officer, Sylvanus Ariija thanked the ENBPG and ENBPHA for their ongoing support and highlighted staff housing as one of the hospital’s biggest challenges. “We currently have 40 staff but only seven houses and that continues to be a major issue for a Level 3 hospital like ours,” Aiija said. “We appeal to the authorities to address this housing shortage so we can better serve our people.” Ariija added that the hospital is in need of proper fencing. “At the same time we have security issues and have also submitted some requests to the higher authorities seeking funding for perimeter fencing,” he said. “This will help protect our workforce on the ground.” Meanwhile, ENB Governor Michael Marum acknowledged the difficulties faced by the Sinivit LLG area, particularly issues related to law and order. “I’m in constant contact with Pomio MP regarding these issues. The construction of the police post up the road is one way we’re addressing law and order concerns,” he said. He noted that Warangoi Rural Hospital serves communities across both the Pomio and Gazelle districts and said the hospital’s housing concerns would be raised with the provincial health authority and administration. Marum also commended the hospital staff for their continued commitment to providing health services despite limited resources and rural challenges.

Title: PM: Economy on solid path
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says Papua New Guinea’s economy remains on a solid path, with consistent Budget performance exceeding 90 per cent implementation each year since 2019. On his return from COP30 in Brazil, the Marape outlined the Government’s progress in restoring fiscal discipline, reducing deficits and preparing for a balanced Budget by 2027. “From 2019 to 2024, we have closed our Budgets above 90 per cent — despite global shocks like the Covid-19,” he said. “Our government has been disciplined, transparent and consistent in meeting our economic commitments.” Marape urged citizens, policymakers and commentators to consult the Treasury website, where the final budget outcomes and mid-year economic and fiscal outlook reports are publicly available for scrutiny. “Don’t listen to political noise,” he said. “The facts are there. “Compare every administration from 2010 to now and you will see that this Pangu-led government has delivered strong, honest Budgets.” Marape said PNG was steadily reducing its deficit from a high of nearly nine per cent in 2020 to more sustainable levels. “The target remains to achieve the first balanced budget since 2010 by 2027,” he said. Marape attributed the country’s resilience to reforms in revenue collection, improved project delivery and responsible borrowing for development. “We are managing our economy prudently,” he said. “Our goal is not just growth, but inclusive growth — ensuring every Kina invested brings services to our people, from infrastructure to health and education.” The 2026 Budget will be framed to maintain fiscal discipline while positioning PNG for a fair, credible and well-funded 2027 National Election, with oversight from both Government and Opposition committees to ensure transparency. “Democracy thrives on fairness. “We will fund the 2027 elections properly and allow every political party and citizen to participate freely.” He urged citizens to engage constructively and vote responsibly in 2027: “Vote with purpose. “Choose leaders who can govern, not just talk. “If you want a certain leader as prime minister, then vote for his party’s candidates. “That’s how democracy works.”

Title: ESP students evacuated
Content: EAST Sepik Governor Allan Bird says the decision to evacuate the East Sepik students attending the University of Goroka was not political but necessary. Bird said contrary to what many commentators were saying, this was not political for the East Sepik government. “This is about the responsibility of a local government to its people. It would be irresponsible of my government to not act with haste,” he said. “I don’t enjoy wasting scarce public funds. Especially since ESPG has experienced a K104mil funding cut by the national government. ESPG simply does not have any money for any luxurious spending. “But we have to spare funds to move our children safely home.” Bird added that the government had failed to provide security that citizens deserved, and such incident was a reflection of the government’s “incapacity” at all national levels. “I have long lamented our inability as a State to protect our citizens,” he said. “This incident, unfortunately, sadly, is further confirmation. “The situation in Goroka is no different to Wewak. “All services provided by the government are failing in my province as well. We are only surviving by the goodwill of our people. “I hope all the perpetrators at UoG are identified, charged and prosecuted but chances of that are slim to none.” Meanwhile, Bird thanked the Morobe government and Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso for the hospitality provided to students from other centres who are being cared for by Lae secondary schools. He confirmed that a representative from the ESPG was travelling to Lae to coordinate moving the students safely home. “What has happened at UoG is a tragedy and is deeply regrettable,” Bird reiterated. “As a provincial government, we are only responding to requests from our students and their parents who are rightly concerned about the safety of their children. “Forty-five students were injured during a fight that lasted many hours. “We were extremely lucky there were not more casualties. “While this may well be an isolated incident, there is little doubt that serious tensions existed long before this incident erupted. “Until then, the primary responsibility of the ESPG is to remove as many of our constituents as possible out of harm’s way.”

Title: Community should be supportive of university, says VC
Content: THE University of Goroka (UoG) has spent close to K40 million each year for goods and services in Eastern Highlands, Vice-Chancellor Dr Teng Waninga says. He said with that amount going into the economy of Goroka as spinoff, the community should be supportive of the university as the premier teacher training institution in the country. Waninga, early this week was emotional about the way neighbouring community attacked the university and the students on Sunday in a fight that was reported to have lasted for eight hours. He said for rentals alone, the non-residential students pay between K80 and K200, depending on the quality of the building, and the distance from the rental accommodation to the university. For the residential students, the university pays in excess of K5,000 per fortnight to rental accommodation owners, he said. Since 2022, when a major earthquake destabilised the foundation of the dormitory structures, some students have been forced to seek alternative accommodation in communities. He said for the surrounding communities to receive direct benefits from the university, they can be smart enough to re-invest that money in sustainable livelihood activities. “For 20 years, I have paid that much – K37 million in goods and services,” he said. “Yet, the community cannot understand that and caused disturbances to the campus.” Waninga said the Government also funded K200 million for the construction of the five-storey central administration and student forum building, which will be opened by the end of the year. He said another K20 million for two new dormitories to be constructed soon to cater for student accommodation. “This is what the university can offer to Eastern Highlands as the host province of the premier learning institution,” he added. The recent fight was rooted to locals drinking beer on Saturday night, and demanding money from a student, he added. Former Eastern Highlands Governor Peter Mumu on social media expressed his dissatisfaction on the conduct of the people of Okiufa and Asaroufa towards the university. Mumu said the university has contributed to the development of Eastern Highlands since its establishment.

Title: Establishing an assembly is way forward, says Masatt
Content: THE establishment of the Bougainville Constituent Assembly (BCA) paves the path toward managing the final constitution-making process that leads to independence, Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) Attorney-General Ezikiel Masatt says. The Bca comprises 45 elected members of the House of Representatives and Speaker (Simon Pentanu) who serves as chairman, including appointed members representing the Bougainville Constitutional Planning Commission. Masatt said the BCA, which had its members sworn-in this week, was the mandated body to steer the final stages of Bougainville’s constitution-making process. “The role of the Bca is to manage the final stages of the constitutional making process, leading to independence. The fundamental duty of the Bca is to discuss, debate the draft independent constitution and adopt the independence constitution,” he said. “Because the constitution came directly from the people. “I urge the Bca members to seek a careful balance. “While the Bca has the legal right to amend or reject the draft, members must avoid making ‘wholesale changes’ to the constitution. Masatt reminded members that the assembly carries the sole constitutional authority to set Bougainville’s official independence date once the constitution is adopted. “The responsibility for setting the independence date rests solely with the (Bca) and nobody else,” he said. “While the Leaders Consultative Forum has recommended Sept 1, 2027, this date must be reviewed and decided upon by the members sitting in the assembly today.” Masatt reiterated the three pathways to achieving independence, one of which was through the constitution-making process itself. He said the preferred pathway to independence remains grounded in the Bougainville Peace Agreement, reflecting on Bougainville’s fulfilment of its obligations under the Bpa, from weapons disposal to the withdrawal of security forces, leading to the constitutional guarantee that enabled the 2019 referendum.

Title: Schools to receive tablets
Content: THE Government has supported the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) through a digital transformation initiative to provide more than 150 digital tablets for seven schools in the region. The digital tablets, preloaded with teaching resources, e-learning content,and classroom management tools, will be sent to Hutjena Secondary, Tarlena (Bishop Wade) Secondary, Asitavi Secondary, Arawa Secondary, Buin Secondary, Tonu Secondary, and Bana High School. Chief Secretary Ivan Pomaleu said the initiative symbolises a shared commitment to equip Bougainville’s next generation with modern tools for learning. “Today’s tablet presentation reflects our shared vision to transform Bougainville’s education through technology and sustainability,” he said. “The future of our classrooms depends on how well we connect learning to modern tools and clean energy. “Through these tablets, our teachers gain the capacity to deliver lessons efficiently, manage classrooms effectively, and connect our schools to the digital world.” ABG Education Minister Robin Wilson said that the initiative was a vital turning point in how Bougainville prepares its students for the modern world. He also emphasised the role of schools and teachers in promoting responsible digital use for students. “Technology is here to stay, we have to embrace it and we have to work with it so we are not left behind,” he said. “I believe that with the schools taking charge of using technology they can also put some ethics into the use of technology at school-aged children, especially with the use of social media today.” Wilson also commended MP Peter Tsiamalili Jr for his leadership and ongoing commitment to improving education in Bougainville. He said that such local-driven initiatives would pave the way for a sustainable and digitally connected education system in the region.

Title: Counting for Karkar LLGs progressing smoothly
Content: COUNTING for the presidents’ seats of the North Karkar and South Karkar local level governments (LLGs) in Madang has started with the process progressing smoothly under tight security, an official says. North Karkar acting returning officer Ezra Tapasu said counting started on Wednesday and has continued on schedule without much trouble. “I can confirm that the counting process has gone very well without any disruptions,” he said. “The counting area is under heavy security, guarded by police personnel and auxiliaries to maintain the integrity of the process.” Tapasup said counting teams for North Karkar have progressed to the fourth count, tallying first preference votes. He said the team would proceed with exclusion counts as part of the next phase of the process. He added that North Karkar has a total of six ballot boxes, while South Karkar has seven, and both teams were on track to complete counting and proceed to final declarations before the end of the week. “Counting officials are working efficiently,” he said “The day’s session concluded at 6pm and resume early tomorrow (Friday) morning for exclusion counting.” Meanwhile, Madang police commander Supt Robert Baim said despite a lack of resources, they have ensured a peaceful election period. He urged people to abide by the law and work closely with police. Writs are scheduled to be returned next Friday.

Title: Sir Bob acknowledges PNG’s contributions to Tonga
Content: GOVERNOR-General Sir Bob Dadae expressed his delight and pride at seeing Papua New Guineans contribute their skills and expertise to the development of Tonga. Sir Bob said this during a function organised by King Tupou VI of Tonga for Sir Bob and the PNG community. “I am delighted to meet youall and proud to learn about your involvement in the various industries here in Tonga,” he said. “Yes, we do have our High Commissioner (Sakias Tameo, PNG High Commissioner to New Zealand accredited to Tonga) present with us today. “He represents our country at a higher diplomatic level, but you also as Papua New Guineans residing in Tonga, are representatives of our country. “In how you conduct yourself personally and, in your service conduct yourselves with the highest standard that will reflect well on you personally and our country PNG.” High Commissioner Tameo urged the PNG community to form an association that will better serve the interests of Papua New Guineans living in Tonga and in close consultation with the PNG High Commission in New Zealand.

Title: State-owned enterprises to join march to end violence on women and girls
Content: ALL State-owned enterprises will join the “End Violence Against Women and Girls” campaign march on Nov 31 in Port Moresby. This was decided on Wednesday in a meeting among all the heads of State-owned Enterprises and National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop. Kumul Consolidated Holdings Ltd managing director Prof David Kavanamur said the country’s poverty rate has increased over the last 20 years, aiding violence in the country. He said that as state enterprises, they have an obligation to the country to help in some ways to address the GBV issue and all other forms of violence. “It (violence) has gone up over the last decades and it has a direct impact on the socio-economic growth of our country,” he said. “It is something we can no longer turn a blind eye to and something that needs all of government and private sector approach.” In a meeting with all the heads of State enterprises yesterday in Port Moresby, Parkop revealed that between 1986 and 2025, GBVs had increased by 210 per cent. Today, one in 10 girls is abused every second. More than 3.5 million women and girls experience violence in PNG in a year, according to UN Women report presented yesterday. Parkop, who is spear-heading the campaign, said those statistics were not just numbers but actually human beings who had come to report their cases. “The scary thing is that out of 30,000 GBVs reported to police last year (2024), only 1,004 arrests were made,” he said. “That means the perpetrators are out there in the communities and in our workplace. “As government and state agencies, we must play our part to flush out these perpetrators and come up with a zero-tolerance for such people.”

Title: Water union gives Government 10 days to settle K250 million debt
Content: MEMBERS of the Water PNG Workers Union have given the Government 10 days to pay an outstanding water arrears of K250 million, or have their supply cut off. Union general secretary Andrew Waine said workers had started shutting down water supply to Government agencies and departments such as the Correctional Service, Defence Force, Police, and Government departments and agencies. He said a nationwide strike would be the next step if there was no response from the Government. Water PNG workers in Port Moresby had planned a strike on Monday for outstanding Consumer Price Index pay adjustments and other employee benefits overdue from 2022. But management then explained the outstanding K250 million which was pushing Water PNG to insolvency. “The employees’ resolution is to put pressure on the Treasury department to release the money,” Waine said. “The union talked with management but there is no money because we only rely on water rates as our source of income. In the past four years, there had been no salary upgrades, no CPI, no appraisal payments.” He said that workers had been told by Water PNG that they might not be paid on Pay 26 “because our financial position is bad”. “Water PNG’s source of income is the water bills and they have to pay up,” he said. There are over 800 employees nationwide, with 400 based in Port Moresby. Water PNG chief executive officer James Young in a statement on Monday said they were under severe liquidity stress as the Government arrears of K250 million had affected cash flow. He forecast a significant loss this year and could not meet the CPI pay adjustment for staff.

Title: PNG Power, Angau sign deal on supply
Content: PNG Power Limited and the Angau General Hospital have signed a memorandum of agreement to ensure an uninterrupted and reliable supply of electricity to the hospital. It follows a parliamentary committee special inquiry in Lae on the deaths of five patients during a power outage. PNG Power chief executive officer Paul Bayly said that while power outages in Lae had inconvenienced many, they did not cause the deaths at Angau. “The line at Angau on the said date was not out. It was switched to an independent power supplier at Munum through the Milford feeder,” he said. He said the outage on the day had been planned and consumers forewarned a day prior. “Moving forward, PNG Power is looking to working with the hospital to assist in safeguarding their facilities and also invite Angau’s maintenance team to attend our trainings to up-skill,” he said. “We are ready and willing to help by taking Angau off the direct feed from Milford Feeder, and connecting them to an independent power supplier to have uninterrupted power supply.” He added that since Lae received power from only one transmission line from Yonki, the PNG Power team was working to include the additional transmission lines by the end of this year. Dr Kipas Binga, the Morobe Provincial Health Authority chief executive officer, said that the power supply to Angau from the Milford direct line affected their equipment. “Despite getting PNG Power, we still have fluctuations that affect our machines. Therefore, the way forward for PNG Power to assist Angau is welcomed.” He also looks forward to sending the hospital maintenance team to PNG Power for training.

Title: A friend and benefactor of Papua New Guinea
Content: WE atThe Nationalare saddened by the loss of our founder, Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King. A dedicated friend of Papua New Guinea over a long time, Tan Sri Sir Tiong passed away at 11 am on Tuesday at his home in Sibu, Malaysia. Although in his later life, Forbes would quote him as one of the richest persons in Asia with businesses in China, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, Russia, South America and parts of Africa, Tan Sri Sir Tiong was born in a far humbler setting in Fujian province, China on March 18, 1934, the eldest of nine siblings. He left school at the tender age of 13 to work and support his family. He later completed his secondary school and his university education via correspondence studies. This humble beginning and close relationship to his family was to determine all his dealings in his adult years and his philanthropic interests. He was physically imposing but humble and soft spoken. The story of Rimbunan Hijau (RH) started in Sibu in 1975, the year of PNG’s independence, when he and his brothers co-founded the company. The company gradually expanded from hardware and construction materials into timber, oil palm plantations, hotels, retail, information technology and finance. In PNG, Rimbunan Hijau has interests in oil palm, tree plantations, timber, aviation, the Vision City mega mall, the RH Hypermart and other RH retail chains, and the Pacific Star which publishesThe National. The Rimbunan Hijau Group and Papua New Guinea this year celebrated their 50-year anniversary. The founding ofThe Nationalbegan in the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur, around June 1993. On a State visit to Malaysia, then Prime Minister Paias Wingti requested the company of Datuk (as he was then) Tiong at the PNG High Commission and asked him to consider starting a television company for Papua New Guinea. To this request, Tan Sri Sir Tiong respectfully declined, but offered instead an alternative which was the possibility of starting a newspaper. He said he had expertise in newspapers and was already publishing Sin Chew Jit Poh and a number of other titles in Malaysia. Wingti agreed to this suggestion, and they shook hands on it. True to his word, eight weeks later, Tan Sri Sir Tiong sent an envoy to Port Moresby with instructions to start a newspaper. A few months later, on Nov 11, 1993, in the company of Prime Minister Wingti and Tan Sri Tiong, the late Communication Minister Martin Thompson pressed the button to start the press for the first issue ofThe National. The Nationaljust turned 32 on Tuesday this week, November 11, the day the man responsible for its existence, passed on. Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King had made a tremendous and positive impact in PNG. Total investment in PNG is worth at least K1.8 billion, and the RH Group of companies employ more than 9,500 Papua New Guineans. Many Papua New Guinean families have benefited directly or indirectly from the company. That is substantial and is a legacy for Tan Sri Sir Tiong. In June 2009, Queen Elizabeth conferred on him the Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire (KBE) in recognition of his contributions to Papua New Guinea. He was the founding president of the World Fuzhou Association and the World Zhang Clan Association. He will be missed, but long shall we cherish the contributions made by Tan Sri Sir Tiong Hiew King both individually and corporately to the employees and staff ofThe National, the RH Group in PNG, and to the wider community.

Title: PNG, Australia officials commemorate Armistice Day
Content: AN Armistice Day commemoration ceremony was held at the Bomana War Cemetery in Port Moresby on Tuesday. Armistice Day, also known as Remembrance Day, commemorates the end of the Great War (World War I), the signing of the Armistice. The ceremony included a minute’s silence at 11am, marking the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month of 1918, the moment when guns fell silent across the Western Front and the war ended. Armistice Day pays respect to those who lost their lives in all wars and conflicts. In his Armistice address, Australian High Commissioner to Papua New Guinea and Special Envoy to the Pacific Ewen McDonald spoke of the significance of Papua New Guinea in WWI to Australian soldiers. He said “perhaps the most familiar names linking war and Papua New Guinea to Australians are the Kokoda Trail and the Coral Sea from the Second World War. However, New Guinea was the site of the first Australian battles and deaths in the Great War.” Papua New Guinea was the site of Australia’s first successful combat action in WWI, resulting in the taking of an enemy occupied radio station in Rabaul, East New Britain. Visiting Australian Defence Force chaplain Lt-Col Michael Folland recited ‘In Flanders fields’, a poem which speaks of the red poppies, the first plants that sprouted from the devastation of the battlefields of northern France and Belgium. The Flanders poppy has become the flower of remembrance worn on Armistice Day. The commemoration ceremony was attended by PNGDF chief Rear Admiral Philip Polewara, visiting Commander of the 1st (Australian) Division, Major General Ashley Collingburn, Australian Defence Adviser Colonel Nicholas Trotter and several diplomatic and Defence representatives from both countries.

Title: Yama’s election petition against Kumara set for hearing next year
Content: A COURT will proceed to hear an election petition by businessman and former Madang governor Peter Yama (pictured) against Usino Bundi MP Vincent Kumara and the electoral commission (EC). National Court Judge Joseph Yagi, who presided over the matter on Tuesday in Waigani, issued directions that the matter would progress. Judge Yagi fixed Feb 4, 2026, for pre-trial conference, and ordered EC to file affidavits before the matter returned because they were not present in court. Yama filed the election petition on the grounds that there were errors and omissions and illegal practice against EC leading to mass voting which affected the result of the election. Yama argued that EC and its officers had failed in their statutory duty to provide election materials, resulting in the denial of voting rights for 1,700 voters, far exceeding the margin of victory. He alleged another ground – that there were illegal practices conducted by Kumara and his supporters in hijacking one ballot box and stuffing it away which had affected the result of the election. Yama alleged that the scrutiny process failed to meet the statutory requirements for openness and transparency, and unlawfully obstructed the oversight duties of scrutineers, comprising the reliability of the court. He is seeking relief to have the petition upheld by the court pursuant to section 212(1) (i) of the Organic Law, and an order for the Usino Bundi Gama open electorate in this year’s by-election be declared void. He is asking the court to order a by-election for the electorate and for the refund of K5,000 which was paid into the National Court Registry’s Trust Account as security deposit. The court will hear the substantive arguments from all parties when the matter returns after the pre-trial conference.

Title: Governor Rapa supports call for nationwide liquor ban
Content: WESTERN Highlands Governor Wai Rapa has strongly supported earlier calls by many leaders for a total liquor ban in the country. Wai Rapa made the call in light of the recent fight between students of the University of Goroka (UOG) and locals from Ato community in Goroka last Sunday. The fight led to the insecurity of students that forced the university council to suspend the remainder of the 2025 academic year for continuing students while the final year students would remain on campus to complete the year. Rapa said the fight was started by drunk locals from Ato market, a community adjacent to the university, who confronted and assaulted a student from Western Highlands on Saturday night. He said the number one public enemy in the country was alcohol. He said this when addressing almost 1000 students who were evacuated to Mt Hagen from Goroka on Tuesday evening. He said this would not have happened if the locals were not drunk. He said alcohol was the main cause of the fight that started on Saturday night. “Liquor is destroying this country. It would be good if the Government could consider regulating or completely banning liquor. Start with the Highlands region,” he said. Rapa said he had already raised the issue in Parliament. “Papua New Guineans are not fit to drink beer,” said. The same call was made by Minister for Higher Education, Research and Science and Technology, Kinoka Feo on Monday. Feo said alcohol was identified as the chief cause of the fight and called on Eastern Highlands Governor, Simon Sia, to look into the issue. He said Eastern Highlands’ economy can survive without beer. Vice Chancellor Dr Tiang Waninga said every fortnight, when the Ato community received their accommodation rentals from the university, they spent the money on beer. “Alcohol overshadowed the security and progress of people and communities,” Dr Waninga said. Meanwhile, close to 1,000 Western Highlands students studying at UOG arrived in Mt Hagen at six pm on Tuesday to an emotional reception. A few of the students were from Jiwaka, Hela, Enga, Southern Highlands, with a number of them from the coastal regions who live in Mt Hagen. In a convoy of 40 vehicles including buses, led by the police commander, Chief Supt John Sagom, and tertiary students’ tuition subsidy coordinator, Elton Kewa, the convoy ended up at the Queens Park, to be greeted by Governor Rapa, provincial leaders, parents and the communities from the four districts. Students wept openly when they reached Jiwaka and Western Highlands border at Tuman, about three kilometers away from Mt Hagen. People braved the evening showers and chill to stand at the roadside to cheer them on while mothers beat their chest and cried. Wai Rapa greeted the students and embraced their leaders, and welcomed their safe return. Student leader, Jason Goimba, said they were all emotional.

Title: Marape: Respect education and tertiary institutions
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has appealed for discipline, responsibility, and respect for education in the nation’s tertiary institutions, following recent incidents of student unrest and alcohol-related disturbances at several campuses. Speaking at Jackson International Airport upon his return from Brazil on Tuesday, the Prime Minister expressed regret over disruptions at the University of Goroka and Sonoma Adventist College, saying the behaviour of a few should not compromise the future of many. “I apologise to the innocent students, parents, and sponsors affected by these incidents,” Marape said. “Our Universities are places for learning and leadership — not disorder.” He confirmed that the Government is investing more than K100 million in infrastructure at the University of Goroka, with plans to fence and secure the campus in next year’s budget to enhance safety and discipline. Marape also directed Higher Education Minister Kinoka Feo to explore a “no alcohol policy” for students in all tertiary institutions across the country. “Students must focus on their studies. There is time for social life after graduation,” he said. “We want our universities to produce disciplined, ethical graduates who can lead our nation.” Marape appealed to local communities surrounding universities to cooperate with authorities in maintaining peace and security. “The University of Goroka has been a pillar of education for over 50 years,” he said. “I call on local tribes and residents to continue supporting the institution and its students. The local community around the university was very hospitable in the past for so long. Lately it is being noted that there are settlements growing around the north Goroka area. I call on those who have settled into Goroka to live like the way Eastern Highlanders or Goroka people do.” He said that the government would work with the university council to strengthen student welfare, safety, and discipline, including online learning alternatives where necessary to ensure continuity of study. “We are proud of our education system and will protect it,” Marape said. “Education is the key to nation- building, and our youth must take this privilege seriously. “Papua New Guinea’s future depends on the character of its young people.”

Title: Motu-Koita holds first phase of talks
Content: THE Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs has completed the first phase of consultations with the Motu-Koita people in preparation for the creation of their new electorate by 2027. Secretary Philip Leo said the weeklong consultation ended last Tuesday after the views of the people were gathered as they prepare for representation in Parliament after the 2027 General Election. He said there had not been any consultations conducted before the announcement of the new electorate to be created which resulted in confusion among the people. “The consultation has made it evident that we need to seek guidance on boundary demarcation from the Electoral Boundaries Commission (EBC),” he said. “Even the existing report lacks clarity.” The EBC’s 2021 report recommended that Parliament approve the creation of 13 new open electorates in the country. In 2022, only seven (Delta Fly, Hiri-Koiari, Margarima, Nakanai, Popondetta, Porgera-Paiela and Wau-Waria) could participate in the elections that year. The remaining six including Motu-Koita in the National Capital District, Baniara in Milne Bay, Baining in East New Britain, Middle Sepik in East Sepik, Mendi Central in Southern Highlands and Anglimp in Jiwaka, are being prepared for the 2027 elections.
