Leo thanked the Motu-Koita people for their participation during the consultations as it would help in their efforts to address administrative challenges. “The feedback collected will be compiled into a report for the minister to be presented to the NEC,” he said. “The report will also outline administrative challenges and propose strategies on how the Motu-Koita Assembly can collaborate with the NCD Commission to establish the electorate.” Motu-Koita’s 14 wards: Korobosea, Mahuru, Kirakira, Vabukori, Pari Taota, Pari Taurama, Baruni, Tatana, Araira, Elevala Mirigini, Elevala Lahara, Elevala Laurabada, Poreporena Lahara, Poreporena Laurabada.

Title: Government looking at extending prisons
Content: POLICE Commissioner David Manning said they are working closely with Correctional Services to identify land near Bomana to extend the prison with additional accommodation. He said that should cater for about 1,000 prisoners. Manning said they are considering similar additions to like Kokopo, Lae and Mt Hagen. “When we were cracking down on some of the offences, we would need larger capacity jails to keep those alleged offenders in the cell,” he said. “And then we will roll that out in the next couple of years. The second project is having a national referral Family Sexual Violence Unit (FVSU) station to take care of victims.” Manning said they are looking at one of the locations in the city to build that station under the Special Policing Assistance Programme (SPAP) that would house FSVU victims. Manning said that they would be working with their partners to provide rehabilitation services, whether it’s psychological or physical support, and medical services. He said the two projects were expected to be completed by the end of next year, building a conducive environment for women and young girls. “In the next parliament sitting, the Police Minister will be informing parliament as to what we’ve done since the SPAP started and we’ve done some great work in the country,”he said. Manning said the majority of these projects would be delivered by tax payers’ money – that’s including all the renovation of police infrastructures that were built pre-independence that were demolished and reconstructed. “This is to ensure public money is spent correctly and where it matters the most,”he said.

Title: 29 arrested over Erima fight
Content: TWENTY-nine men allegedly involved in a fight at Erima yesterday morning have been locked up at the 6-Mile Police Station, according to police. Police said the fight was among men from Tari, Hela under the Flyover Bridge. National Capital District Metropolitan Supt Warrick Simatab said police acted quickly to stop the armed men who were destroying the market under the bridge. “According to information provided to police, it was a retaliatory fight among Tari men who fought among themselves on Tuesday at 9-Mile,” he said. “The group from 9-Mile retaliated because one of their members was injured.” Simatab said when they reached Erima, they started destroying markets. “Police responded and arrested about 31 individuals, including two community leaders, who were released to identify those who are still on the run,” he said. “The suspects will be profiled, interrogated, and charged accordingly.” Simatab said police would address such issues to ensure order in the city. He said retaliatory fights should not occur because there were avenues to resolve conflicts. “Police stations, village courts, community leaders and parents are available to help solve issues,” he said. He urged the public not to take the law into their own hands and instil fear in communities they live in.

Title: Failure to address law, order cause of Goroka fight: O’Neill
Content: THE failure of law enforcement to control the situation in Goroka on Sunday is linked to the general state of decline in law and order over the past six years, says former prime minister Peter O’Neill. “The decay of law and order came to a devastating pinpoint this week in Goroka when citizens wrongly acted with violence to settle differences,” he said in a statement. The Ialibu-Pangia MP said that the Government led by Prime Minister James Marape had failed the 6,000 University of Goroka students, their families and the people of Goroka. “We all remember how Marape reacted in July 2019, (when) 16 women and children, were hacked and shot to death in his own district. “At the time, Marape made a vow to track down the perpetrators who he called ‘gun-toting criminals and warlords’. “Six years later, no one has been brought to justice. “Prime Minister Marape did not track down their killers and instead presided over a government that has seen violence rip our country apart. “Fast forward to 2025 – and the senate of the University of Goroka have taken the extraordinary step to restore safety by suspending class and curtailing the academic year impacting around 6,000 students. “I do not blame the senate for the decision, but I do blame Marape, his Cabinet and security forces for not providing the support to prevent the incident occurring, and to give the comfort the senate needed so that normalcy could be returned to the university, its students and teachers. “Rather than shut down UOG, teachers and students should be provided with appropriate security to ensure safety while investigations and mediations go on and allow the academic year to be completed. “Perhaps the right move is to stop spending millions of our people’s money globetrotting and instead stay home and lead from the front and fix the mess you have created. “The whole country is begging the prime minister to stop talking and travelling and start working and delivering.”

Title: Thousands leave UOG campus
Content: NEARLY 7,000 University of Goroka (UOG) students started leaving the campus in buses on Monday night after the approval of the academic senate. Vice-Chancellor Dr Teng Waninga announced the senate decision to the students at 7pm on Monday. Waninga said given the assault, invasion of campus, damaging of properties, and use of weapons against the students by locals, the environment was no longer conducive for students to continue to the end of the year. Chimbu students left on Monday night and yesterday, more than 40 vehicles transported students from Western Highlands, Jiwaka, Enga, Hela and Southern Highlands. For the 300-plus Madang students, the provincial government’s repatriation support team arrived on Monday. UOG Madang student’s president Philip Sondo said it was “heartbreaking” but a relief to see buses from Madang and police officers arriving with the Madang flag”. “It’s like seeing our parents come to secure us,” he said. The repatriation support was ordered by Governor Ramsey Pariwa. For East New Britain students, Governor Michael Marum said his government would immediately repatriate all ENB students. Morobe students were also repatriated yesterday. Lae MP John Rosso said the Morobe government sent 20 buses with police to Goroka to get the students. Twenty-nine Manus students left campus yesterday on three buses. They are expected to arrive in Madang and take the Laban Oule to Manus. For Western students, Governor Taboi Yoto said they would be evacuated this weekend. Nearly 2,000 students from Southern Highlands left yesterday with Jiwaka students. Western Highlands Governor Wai Rapa organised 35 buses to transport Western Highlands students back to the province.
People: John Rosso, Ramsey Pariwa, Wai Rapa

Title: Rubiang takes over EHP police to oversee uni fight probe
Content: SUPERINTENDENT Mazuc Rubiang will be acting provincial police commander (PPC) for Eastern Highlands following the sidelining of Chief Insp John Kale. Deputy police commissioner regional operations Samson Kua said that Rubiang would continue as PPC Chimbu pending investigations into the clash between students of the University of Goroka and nearby villagers. “He will be acting while investigations are going on. We have the rural commander for Eastern Highlands to take over as Goroka police station commander until we finalise the investigations,” Kua said. Police Commissioner David Manning said that police work was never easy and the constabulary continued to hold themselves accountable for their actions or inactions. “We need to look within the constabulary to see the causes or reasons for not getting it right,” he said. “I find it downright disrespectful to be questioned why we had to stand people down. Concerns raised were within the organisation.” He said that one party in Goroka was under the influence, and a student became a victim. “What happened was an escalation of the incident on Saturday. Two wrongs don’t make a right and we were caught unaware of the situation,” Manning added. “We are also helping the provincial governments move their students out and enter with conversations with the University to see how we can quickly bring things back to normal. “The university is surrounded by villages there are so many dynamics that we need to be mindful of.”

Title: Lae schools to accomodate university students
Content: THE Bugandi and Lae secondary schools in Morobe will accommodate 700 to 800 University of Goroka students forced to leave campus following a fight last weekend. The principals of both schools confirmed that they were told by Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso to provide the space and have advised their support staff and students. Bugandi Secondary School principal Dennis Miall said that the school could accommodate 300 to 400 students because the Grade 10 classrooms were available. “Our girl’s dormitory can shelter about 50 female’s downstairs if we move the Grade Nine and Grade 11 female students upstairs,” Miall said. “There are 100 spaces in the men’s dormitories available after grades 10 and 12 students left for the holiday. “The mess facilities are available but the authorities will have to provide food to support our students.” Lae Secondary School principal Christopher Raymond said the grades 12 and 10 blocks were available as the students had gone home after the national examinations. “I can accommodate 200 to 500 students here,” Raymond said. “There are spaces at the grade 12 block, but if they are full, then they can be accommodated at the grade 10 block.” The university students need to stay at the schools until they are ready to leave for their provinces.

Title: Yaom Sani – the little girl freed from her ‘heavy burden’
Content: TWO years ago, the story of little Yaom Sani from Hotte village in the Salamaua, Morobe touched hearts across Papua New Guinea. Then, just five years old, Yaom carried what doctors described as a “heavy burden”. She had large swellings in her neck and shoulder area that limited her movement and kept her from playing like other children. Today, aged seven, Yaom has fully recovered and eager to return to school next year. Her father Sani Matayam said the transformation in his daughter has brought hope and joy not only to their family but to the entire community. “She can now run around and play with the other children,” he said. “For a long time, we were worried about her health, but now she is strong and wants to go to school.” The turning point came when Yaom was flown out of her village and underwent a demanding operation at Mt Hagen General Hospital under a specialist team led by Chief Surgeon Dr Benjamin Yapo. Dr Yapo reported that Yaom was diagnosed with a condition known as cystic hygroma, which is part of a group of vascular anomalies located deep in her neck and armpit. Because the growth spanned from her right neck across to her chest wall, the eight-hour surgery was described as extremely difficult. According to reports by this paper on November 22nd, 2023, Dr Yapo said: “Surgery went so well that I surprised myself that I was able to dissect far enough on both ends to remove the complete mass without leaving any part behind.” Yaom and her family have extended heartfelt thanks to everyone who helped: Dr Yapo and the surgical team, the late Luther Wenge (former Governor of Morobe), John Rosso (Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP), the Manalos medivac team and generous individuals who rallied behind her. The support covered the complex operation and travelling logistics. With her physical health restored, Yaom’s dreams are now set on her future. Speaking to this paper, she said she wants to become a doctor when she grows up. “I want to help sick people,” she said. “I want to be able to help other children like me in the future.” For the Sani family, Yaom’s new dream is based on experience that they went through and will be one of the stories that is emotionally tied to one of the good deeds of the late Wenge.

Title: MP warns against using flammable materials in buildings
Content: THE use of combustible materials in buildings should be stopped, especially when the Papua New Guinea Fire and Rescue Service has proven to be ineffective, Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa claimed yesterday. “As far as I know, it is a requirement that all buildings have fire alarms and smoke detectors installed,” he said. He said regular building inspections by the city council inspectors, especially involving multiple rental dwellings, can help to prevent calamities like fires. “It’s with great sadness following the house fire that burnt down the neighbour’s house last week causing the death of three adults and three children,” he said. “It was a tragedy that should not have happened.” Tomuriesa wants the government to ensure that relevant authorities conduct a thorough investigation into the cause of the fire and to hold accountable anybody who may have in one way or another contributed to the tragedy. He also called on the fire service to lift its operational effectiveness and for the building board and the city council to enforce the building code standards for buildings “The historical failure of the government to properly fund the Fire and Rescue Service in all centres of the country is evident in the limitations facing the fire service.”

Title: Igitoi concedes census did not cover entire country
Content: ACTING National Statistician John Igitoi admits that the population headcount during last year’s census did not cover the entire country due to funding and logistic challenges. “All censuses face challenges such as undercounts, over-counts, and missing data,” he said. “Globally, the United Nations (UN) estimates that about six per cent of the world’s population is not enumerated, even in the most technologically advanced countries. “Like many statistical offices worldwide, the National Statistical Office (NSO) faced logistical and fiscal constraints during the implementation of the 2024 national population census. “These challenges are not unique to Papua New Guinea and are recognised by the UN as common in developing contexts. “The 2024 census prioritised the collection of core demographic variables essential for deriving key indicators such as population size and structure, dependency ratios, household composition and population by citizenship. “Detailed information on education, employment and other socio-economic characteristics will be fully collected in the next population and housing census, planned for 2030.” This was his response to Institute of National Affairs executive director Paul Barker who questioned the credibility of last year’s census results. Barker called for an extensive review of the recently released population data which puts the total number of people in the country at 10,185,363. “The administration of the 2024 census seemed somewhat shambolic from the start, with real governance concerns raised as well,” he said. “From various min-sample surveys around the country and ad hoc feedback online, it appears that a substantial portion of the population was never censured, even in the National Capital District where the population was relatively accessible. But Igitoi said: “It is important to clarify that no census in the world achieves 100 per cent coverage.”

Title: ABG partner’s with NSO
Content: THE Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG), in partnership with the National Statistical Office (NSO) and the United Nations Population Fund, successfully completed a four-day training programme on data literacy last month. The trainer of trainers programme represents a strategic investment in human capital and institutional capacity-building with participation from ABG departments, civil society organisations, community leadership, youth groups and educational institutions. The participants underwent training in data collection, analysis, interpretation, and visualisation, as well as in-depth instruction on adult education and training methodologies. Bougainville’s Education Department secretary Dorothy Kenneth commended the achievements of newly certified trainers   would build staff capacity.

Title: Bougainville must exercise power: Masatt
Content: BOUGAINVILLE’s political freedom must take precedence over economic readiness in its pursuit for independence, Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) Attorney-General Ezikiel Masatt says. At the Bougainville House of Representatives sitting last month, Masatt said that international law did not require economic strength as a condition for sovereignty but rather recognised independence based on population size, defined borders, and a law-making authority. “Political power must come first if we are to make strategic economic decisions,” he said. “Take for example, the fishing sector; 30 per cent of the annual one billion Kina industry’s catches occur in Bougainville waters, yet the region receives only K5 million annually from the National Fisheries Authority.” He stressed that Bougainville must exercise its own sovereign powers to redirect economic benefits toward its people and build long-term self-reliance. “We must exercise symbolic sovereign powers in order to make many of these economic strategic decisions,” he said. Masatt also rejected the argument that the presence of weapons remained an obstacle to independence, noting that the Bougainville Peace Agreement’s constitutional provisions under Part 14 were achieved following a verified and phased weapons disposal programme. He added that since the restoration and establishment of the Autonomous Bougainville Government in 2005, Bougainville elections had been conducted peacefully and without gun-related disruptions, unlike incidents often observed during election periods in other parts of PNG. Masatt confirmed that President Ishmael Toroama had already discussed the scheduling of the next joint supervisory body meeting with Prime Minister James Marape which was expected to take place this month. He called on all members of the Bougainville House of Representatives to remain engaged in the process, stressing the importance of accurate information-sharing with their constituencies.

Title: Police stop fight in Abau
Content: A QUICK response by Central police contained a fight at Kupiano station in Abau district yesterday. Police reported that an old man was seriously injured and they were investigating how the fight started. Central police commander Chief Insp Joseph Salle said police officers moved in quickly and advised people who were about to cause more problems to stop fighting or they would be arrested for disobeying police orders. “Despite their limited manpower, they managed to contain the situation,” he said. “Two police units from Central police headquarters and a unit from Kwikila had been dispatched to help the Kupiano officers.” He said counting for the local level government (LLG) presidential seats was supposed to start yesterday but was put on hold to await the arrival of police officers from Port Moresby. “We had received information about armed men traveling from Port Moresby to Kupiano station in support of the fight, and we are looking into that,” Salle said. “Police are communicating with the community to ensure that those who want to take the law into their own hands will be arrested and charged.” Salle said that the counting for the LLG presidential seats was to start today, as per information provided by election officials. He called on the people of Wanigela, who were involved in the fighting, to stop and observe the election peacefully. “Voting had been completed and they are now into counting and declaration of leaders,” Salle said. He thanked the Central police rural commander and his team for their quick response.

Title: Government must do more to address GBV
Content: GOVERNMENT is to be blamed for not doing enough when it comes to addressing gender-based violence as statistics show one out of 10 girls face violence every 10 seconds in PNG, says National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop. Parkop said that besides providing funding support, the government has not “really stepped up” to implement strategies to put an end to GBV, including all other forms of violence in the country. He said this yesterday during an inter-governmental agencies meeting on celebrating the December World Human Rights month. All government agencies, departments, including State enterprises (100 staff each) would march along the Port Moresby’s Hohola freeway during the start of a 20-day campaign against GBV and end it with a pledge where all agencies will sign. “Government will take a hard stand against all forms of violence in the country starting with gender-based violence in workplaces,” Parkop said. “We need to implement the strategies we have. I am sure the development partners like UNDP, UN Women, the European Union, Australia High Commission and the US Embassy have played important role in those areas and as a government it is time we take the lead in implementing it, starting within our own homes, offices and departments.” Parkop however admitted that the Vagrancy Bill was one way to curb violence in the city. He was waiting for the next parliament sitting to announce the bill. “That (Vagrancy Act) including our continuous support to the Police Mobile Squad, City Watch on which we had spent K16 million and the CCTV projects are part of our long term plans,” he said. Parkop said that by implementing a strategy to make awareness on GBVs at workplace, starting with government departments and agencies, was a “strong way” to send out the message that government was taking the issue seriously. The campaign march would stop the city, and even the country, as it would be the intention to capture the country’s attention.

Title: Manning: Avoid driving recklessly
Content: POLICE Commissioner David Manning has warned motorists of the road safety rules following a tragic accident at Konedobu on Monday. Manning said the accident that claimed three lives, leaving one in critical condition, happened because of reckless driving. “We reviewed the footage of the accident, it was just reckless, high speed driving and there was nothing that could’ve avoided that,” he said. “My assessment of that was because I reviewed the footage that was reckless driving and be mindful that there are other people on the road.” He said the more reckless motorists were on the road, the greater danger they posed to themselves and to innocent road users and pedestrians. Manning also said with the festive season coming up and while it was a time to be joyful and celebrate the birth of our Lord and saviour, there’s a lot of things that happen during that time. “The police force throughout the country will be sent out starting on the second week of December to ensure the whole country celebrates in peace,” he said. “We will also be ramping up our traffic enforcement, working closely with the Road Traffic Authority.” He added that everyone needs to take time and pause and reassess what the year has been since the country turned 50 in September. “We’ve had a very busy year so let’s celebrate in true spirit.”

Title: Woman’s body discovered at Roburogo
Content: POLICE in the National Capital District and Central are investigating the death of an unidentified woman whose body was found at Ruburogo along Hiritano Highway in Central’s Hiri-Koiari. Central police commander Chief Inspector Joseph Salle confirmed a man stumbled on the body while heading to his garden. Salle said officers from forensic, Central Criminal Investigation and Laloki police went to the scene yesterday, retrieved the body and brought it to the Port Moresby General Hospital morgue. He said the woman had a tattoo on her right abdomen in yellow, red and black. She was described to have short hair and about 140cm tall. “Police, community leaders and village representatives from the Ruburogo area raised awareness in the surrounding villages and confirmed that all females are present,” he said “We are now extending our call to the general public to check each house, and if any female members that fit the described person are missing. “They can call Central police headquarters and police officers will assist.”

Title: ENB first to complete LLG elections
Content: EAST New Britain (ENB) is the first to complete both the presidential and ward council declarations in the 2025 local level government (LLG) and ward elections. ENB administrator and the chairman of the provincial election advisory committee Levi Mano said that this achievement reflected outstanding teamwork. “I acknowledge all returning officers, police, the provincial administration, and the people of ENB for their support and dedication,” Mano said. ENB completed all counting and declarations on Friday. Mano gave a rundown of the declarations and winning presidents of each LLG in the province. There are eight LLGs in Gazelle district and all have new presidents. They are: Rabaul district welcomed two new presidents for Watom and Rabaul Urban LLGs while two incumbent presidents retained their positions in Kabiu and Balanataman LLGs;   The new presidents for the four LLGs in Rabaul districts are: The newly elected presidents for the seven LLGs in Pomio district are: Kokopo has become the first district in ENB to complete its LLG election results as of Nov 5. The only incumbent to retain his seat was the Raluana LLG president, Tiolam Wawaga, while Duke of York Islands and Bitapaka LLGs welcomed new leadership in Robin Mital and Jack Kongkong.

Title: Toma elects president
Content: THE people of Toma local level government (LLG) in East New Britain (ENB) have finally witnessed the election of their own president after years of being merged with Gazelle’s Vunadidir LLG since the early 2000. In the second exclusion of counting, candidate Elisah Wesley secured 2,179 votes, surpassing the absolute majority of 2,078 voters required – 50 per cent of formal votes plus one. His lead earned him an unofficial declaration as the winner by Toma LLG assistant returning officer Irenius Tiula at midday on last Thursday. During this decisive round, other two candidates remained in the race, including the former president of the once amalgamated Toma-Vunadidir LLG. “Counting for the LLG president seat began on last Monday and last Thursday, we elected a new president. The candidate that led after the completion of primary counting yesterday, maintained his dominance to win,” Tiula said. Wesley emerged victorious from a field of five candidates who initially contested the presidency. Sadly, one candidate passed away just a week before polling started. After updating the results board with the final figures, Tiula stated that the results would be announced onNational Broadcasting Corporation(NBC) ENB, by the provincial returning officer from Electoral Commission in Kokopo, along with declarations for other LLG presidents in ENB. Tiula further explained that following the administrative separation of Tomas and Vunadidir LLGs last year, the Toma LLG structure had been re-established in preparation for this year’s elections to select a political head. “The new president was voted by the majority of the people of Toma and so I believed there will be good things coming and also collaboration between the political head and the LLG administration,” he said. With an elected president now in office, Tiula expressed optimism that the people across Toma LLG’s 18 wards would soon begin to see improved services and development. Meanwhile, the neighbouring Vunadidir LLG had also completed its counting.

Title: WNB district begins campaign
Content: POLIO vaccination for children under 10 is progressing in West New Britain’s Kandrian-Gloucester as the provincial health authority works to improve coverage to 80 per cent, an official says. Cosmas Borewa, a supervisor from the Pha overseeing the vaccination programme in the district, said there had been a positive response from families in the local communities. Borewa said the only issue with the roll out of the programme was the lack of network connectivity due to the remoteness of the location. “We have received positive response from the local communities,” he said. “The health workers in the district are helping to roll out the supplementary immunisation activities which have improved the coverage in most of the areas near the health facilities. “Our biggest challenge is the network coverage which we need to send data collected from the programme. “Despite this issue, we are focused on completing all our activities by this week.” Borewa thanked the Australian Doctors International (ADI) which provided much of the logistical support for their work in the district. “We are glad to have ADI working with us on the ground,” he said. “We planned to complete this vaccination programme in two weeks and their support has been very helpful to us.” ADI coordinator Joyce Seneba said the logistical support was necessary given the remoteness of the people living in Kandrian-Gloucester. “Some of the teams had to travel by boats we had to hire,” she said. “We also had to pay allowances for workers who are working here.” Turuk Catholic health centre officer Steven Kadiko thanked the Pha and Adi for their support to provide such an important service. “We have been facing many problems with vaccinating children below the age of 10 but with this support we have now, we are confident of reaching out target,” he said. “There are more than 1,000 children here that need to be vaccinated so we plan to complete the exercise by this week. “We encourage more parents to bring their children to be vaccinated.”

Title: Classroom project completed
Content: THE board and staff of Billiau Primary School in Madang’s Raicoast have received praise for completing a double classroom project on time and within budget. Governor Ramsey Pariwa visited the school last Friday to witness the opening of the building funded with provincial services improvement programme funds. “Billiau is the third school to have successfully completed its classroom project upon receiving funding and I want to thank the head teacher, the school board and the contractor for working together in collaboration,” he said. “That’s the way it should be. We should put our differences aside and work hand-in-hand to see productive results not only in education but also in other sectors.” Provincial education director Alphonse Igag told the gathering: “At the education division and the administration are happy that he (Pariwa) is pushing for us to come up with proper systems and ways which the government and the administration are supposed to run in Madang.” Head teacher Siloi Dimas, when presenting a brief report of the project completion, said the school looked forward to working alongside the provincial administration to deliver more projects.

Title: All 20 Turkish troops killed in Georgia plane crash
Content: Ankara: Turkey’s defence ministry says 20 soldiers were killed in the crash of its military aircraft in Georgia a day earlier, as inspectors continued to seek clues what caused the Nato member’s cargo plane to go down. The C-130 plane took off from Azerbaijan for Turkey and crashed in Georgia on Tuesday. Ankara has not yet provided a reason for its deadliest military incident since 2020. It said Turkish and Georgian authorities began inspections at the site, in the Sighnaghu municipality of Georgia’s Kakheti district, on Wednesday morning. Initial footage from the scene showed chunks of twisted metal strewn across a grassy knoll, while unverified footage on social media showed the plane breaking apart in mid-air and then corckscrewing towards the earth in a blaze. On Wednesday, the Turkish Defence Ministry released a list of the 20 soldiers killed in the crash. The leaders of Azerbaijan and Georgia, as well as the Nato secretary general Mark Rutte, have all conveyed condolences. Tom Barrack, the US Ambassador to Turkey, has also expressed his country’s solidarity with Turkey after the crash. Turkish Defence Minister Yasar Guler on Tuesday spoke to his Georgian and Azerbaijani counterparts, as well as Azerbaijan’s chief of staff, to discuss search and rescue operations. US firm Lockheed Martin, which makes the C-130 Hercules that is widely used by air forces around the world, expressed its condolences and said it was committed to helping Turkey in any way during the investigation. The C-130 Hercules is a cargo, troop and equipment carrier aircraft. It is described as a four-engine, turboprop military transport aircraft that can make use of unprepared runways for takeoffs and landings. Its versatile airframe has enabled it to be used for other purposes as well, including as a gunship and for airborne assault and reconnaissance operations. It is now viewed as one of the main tactical airlifters for many militaries. Source: Reuters

Title: Forests, finance, fossils: Climate talks hit full steam
Content: Canberra: Tens of thousands of delegates have descended on a small town in Brazil for annual climate change talks, where adaptation, forests, finance and fossil fuels are set to dominate. Formal negotiations will kick off on Monday following a meeting of heads of state last week in Belem, the gateway to the Amazon rainforest. Australian Climate and Energy Minister Chris Bowen is due to attend the two-week Conference of the Parties summit, where last-minute lobbying for the rights to host the next round of United Nations climate talks will be a priority. The Australia-Pacific co-bid has stalled as a competing bid from Turkey remains in play, with no location set and just 12 months to prepare. Australia has been gunning to host the 2026 conference to attract international investment in clean industries and strengthen its relationship with strategically important Pacific neighbours. The annual talks take place at a strained time for global co-operation on responding to the challenges of temperature rise. The US government has been actively pulling back and so far, Europe has not stepped in to fill the void as assertively as it has during other periods of faltering climate ambition. And while pollution-slashing promises have the world tracking towards less warming than the troubling trajectory that first spurred Paris into existence a decade ago, the pact’s stated goals of keeping temperature rise below 2C, ideally 1.5C, are still off track. The gap between emission reduction commitments and temperature limits is expected to dominate the event, as well as discussions on adaptation, climate finance and phasing down fossil fuels. Carbon-absorbing forests will also be given prominence thanks to the symbolic location in the Amazon rainforests, known as the “lungs of the world”. Source: AAP

Title: No rules, no use: Aussie firms may miss AI opportunity
Content: Brisbane: A lack of rules governing artificial intelligence technology is holding Australian businesses back, a report has found, and could result in them squandering a AU$142 billion (about K397b) opportunity. Networking firm Cisco and the Governance Institute of Australia issued the warning on Tuesday after conducting research across multiple firms, including banks, charities, education and retail groups. More Australian organisations were adopting the technology in 2025, the study found, although the nation still lagged behind others in the Asia Pacific region. The findings come after the federal government pledged to release a national AI plan before the end of the year, and following an update to Australia’s Voluntary AI Safety Standard. The report, called Turning Hesitation Into Action, analysed Cisco’s AI Readiness Index and the institute’s AI Deployment and Governance Survey, in addition to holding discussions with representatives from the finance, education, non-profit and retail sectors. It found Australian organisations were slow to adopt AI tools, with just 22 per cent expressing full confidence in the technology, up from four per cent in 2024. Almost two in three organisations did not offer AI training to staff (64 per cent) and most could not effectively measure the return on their AI investments (93 per cent). Many Australian businesses lacked the necessary expertise or guidelines to invest in AI innovation with confidence, Cisco Australia and New Zealand chief technology officer Carl Solder said, despite OpenAI’s estimate it could deliver a $142 billion dividend by 2030. Source: AAP

Title: Protesters storm COP30, Newsom slams Trump’s absence
Content: Belem: Dozens of Indigenous protesters have forced their way into the COP30 climate summit venue and clashed with security guards at the entrance. Shouting angrily, the protesters demanded access to the UN compound where thousands of delegates from countries around the world are attending this year’s UN climate summit in Belem, Brazil. Some waved flags with slogans calling for land rights or carried signs saying “our land is not for sale.” An Indigenous leader from the Tupinamba community near the lower reaches of the Tapajos River in Brazil told Reuters that they were upset about ongoing development in the forest. “We can’t eat money,” said Gilmar, who uses only one name. “We want our lands free from agribusiness, oil exploration, illegal miners and illegal loggers.” Security guards pushed the protesters back and used tables to barricade the entrance. A Reuters witness saw one security guard being rushed away in a wheelchair while clutching his stomach. Another guard with a fresh cut above his eye told Reuters he had been hit in the head by a heavy drumstick thrown from the crowd. Security confiscated several batons. Source: Reuters

Title: No nation can remain alone: Japan’s bid for closer ties
Content: Canberra: Australia and Japan must bolster co-operation between their defence industries, Japan’s ambassador to Australia says, as Tokyo seeks to deepen security ties between the two nations to counter rising tension in the Indo-Pacific. In an address to the National Press Club in Canberra on Wednesday, Suzuki Kazuhiro will call for the partnership between Tokyo, Washington, and Canberra to be stepped up. He will also advocate for the Quad, a four-nation diplomatic framework which includes India to be strengthened. “A stronger Japanese presence in Australia not only enhances Australia’s deterrence, but also reinforces Japan’s strategic resilience, thereby strengthening our joint deterrence,” he will say. “Japan and Australia standardise their equipment and develop systems for mutual logistical support, we will greatly enhance our collective resilience.” Relations between Washington and New Delhi hit a low point after the Trump administration imposed punitive tariffs of 50 per cent on Indian goods, including a 25 per cent penalty for its refusal to stop buying Russian oil as the war in Ukraine draws out. Suzuki said both nations must “advance defence industrial co-operation”. “When all is said and done, our relationship has endured because — just as ‘no man is an island’ — no nation can remain alone and adrift on the tides of change,” he will say. “In today’s more serious and complex environment, our cooperation will become even more indispensable to maintaining the peace and prosperity of the region and realising a free and open Indo-Pacific. “Bound by trust, we must continue to steer together.” Source: AAP

Title: ‘You are free to go home’: UOG’s academic senate approves two-week break before final exams
Content: THE University of Goroka’s academic senate has approved a two-week break for students before sitting their final semester exams online and in-person, vice chancellor Dr Teng Waninga says. “You are free to go home as of tonight,” he told a student meeting on Monday night after a lengthy senate meeting. He said all continuing students would return home while their remaining examinations would be conducted online via Google Classrooms between Nov 24-29. Final year students, content upgrade and second year in-service students will return to campus after the two weeks break to complete their studies. Waninga said the fight erupted after a student was harassed by drunkards from Ato Market. “As of 24th– 29th exams will open through Google Classrooms and you do your exams,” Waninga said. “75 per cent of the assessments have been completed, the remaining 25 per cent for continuing students will be done online or thorough Google Classrooms at home from Nov 24-29,” he said. “Your task is for you to keep in touch with your lecturers to submit your tasks and get ready for your graduation in January 2026,” he said. He said students who could not go home for the two weeks’ break could remain on campus.

Title: Morobe providing refuge for disrupted UOG students transiting to their provinces
Content: Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso has confirmed that The University of Goroka students transiting through Lae to their respective provinces will be accommodated in Lae while waiting for their flights. The Lae City Authority and the Morobe Provincial Government dispatched 20 buses with police escort to Goroka on Tuesday to move these students to Lae. Students have been repatriated back to their home provinces since Monday night following a decision by the university’s academic senate to give them a two-week break. They would sit for their exams online at the end of this month. Provincial governments have started repatriation exercise, sending buses and security escort to Goroka to move students back to their homes. Rosso said students transiting to the New Guinea Islands, Momase and Southern regions would be accommodated at secondary schools in Lae. Bugandi Secondary School principal Dennis Miall told The National that dormitories were being cleaned out in preparation for the students. He said the school was in close communication with the Lae City Authority, Rosso and the Morobe administration. Other Morobe MPs also supported students from their districts; Finschhafen MP Reinbo Paita with eight buses, Markham MP Koni Iguan with four buses and Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jnr. Iguan said there was no place for violent behaviour in our society, emphasising that education was paramount and should always be protected and valued as the foundation for our future. He called on police to investigate thoroughly and ensure that justice took its course. Morobe administrator Max Bruten said the provincial government is coordinating the exercise. “We prioritise student safety and we also prioritise their education, hence we did not make any move to transfer students until we got confirmation from the university of class termination,” Bruten said. “Buses are already on ground and will be bringing the students back under police escort.”
People: John Rosso, Koni Iguan, Sam Basil

Title: Government to consider all options before deciding on students
Content: THE Government is considering whether to send University of Goroka students home then conduct exams for them early next year, or provide them accommodation nearby and continue the academic year. Higher Education, Research and Science Minister Kinoka Feo said: “We can either send students home and get continuing students to come back early 2026 to do exams, given the trauma experienced, or get police on site in the university, relocate students to guests houses and other colleges and where there is accommodation over two to three days to conduct examinations before they can go back home.” He said that the National Executive Council would release K10 million to build dormitories to accommodate students in 2026, and for fencing. The Works and Highways Department has been tasked to build the dormitories given the urgency of the situation. Nearly half of the students residing off campus rent nearby rooms and homes and travel daily to classes. “We are progressing on it so students don’t have to live within the town and communities,” he said. Feo reassured parents and MPs that everything was under control given the police reinforcement from Mt Hagen and Chimbu. A fight started between Asaroyuifa settlers and students on Saturday after a student was nearly robbed at the market. “Given the trauma experienced by the students, they may have to be relocated to other schools in Eastern Highlands for temporary refuge – that is if we decide to continue the academic year,” he said. “If we close now, the challenge is how to cater for new intakes in 2026. “We will address all options. Based on advice from the university, I will make a decision. “Locals must understand that the school is in our province and we must protect it. We are good people and it’s a minority who is tarnishing our good name.”

Title: WHP officials in Goroka to evacuate students
Content: WESTERN Highlands Governor Wai Rapa has sent officials to the University of Goroka to evacuate students from the province studying there. As the university senate met to discuss the future of students for this year, nearly 1,000 Western Highlands students were evacuated. The team was led by Chief Superintendent John Sagom, provincial administration officials and the drivers of at least 20 buses to bring the students home. Western Highlands police sent a Mobile Squad to the university on Sunday. Sagom briefed the bus drivers on the convoy protocols and traffic laws before departing Mt Hagen at around noon. Jacob Nikints, representing the parents, thanked Rapa for stepping in immediately for the safety of the students. It was reported that the fight started when a student from Western Highlands and some drunk locals at the area where the student was living had a row. Reports also reaching the province indicated that locals entered the Goroka General Hospital searching for injured students seeking treatment.

Title: Maru wants proof Sepik River will be protected
Content: YANGORU-Saussia MP Richard Maru wants more time and evidence before he is convinced that the Frieda River mine will not pose a risk to the lives of the Sepik River people. “Any projects that mean all the fish will die and hurt the people, I cannot support,” he said. “But I do know in this day and age there is technology for tailings like the proposed Frieda gold/copper project to be put into a hydro and it can be done safely. “I am aware of one or two mines in the world where such as technology is used. So before I make up my mind on this, I want to travel to these countries and see how their tailings system works. “If I am convinced that lives and fish along the river will not be affected, then I will have no issues but support the project.” Maru said the lives of 300,000 people along the river were at stake. The project is in Telefomin, West Sepik, and partially along the East Sepik border at Ambunti Drekikier. It will pass along Pagwi to Vanimo as the main port for exports. Last week, seven leaders from the Sepik region indicated their support for the Frieda project to proceed given that tangible benefits must reach the people. A signed paper was presented to Prime Minister James Marape highlighting that the Frieda project must be developed with appropriate technology and with sound environment protection consideration and social responsibility. The leaders were West Sepik Governor Tony Wouwou, Nuku MP Joseph Sungi, Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim, Aitape Lumi MP Anderson Mise, Wewak MP Stanley Muts, Angoram MP Salio Waipo and Ambunti Drekikier MP Johnson Wapunai.
People: Anderson Mise, James Marape, Johnson Wapunai, Richard Maru, Salio Waipo, Solan Mirisim, Tony Wouwou

Title: No change in budget deficit forecast: Treasurer
Content: TREASURER Ian Ling-Stuckey says the 2025 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO) indicates no change in the 2025 Budget Deficit of K2,949 million. He said this yesterday while brushing aside a recent statement by former prime minister Peter O’Neill accusing the Government of raiding public companies for nearly K2 billion to resupply its depleted accounts. O’Neill had said: “Revenue is down K1.6 billion and spending is up K500 million resulting in a nearly K2 billion budget hole after the first half of this year.” Ling- Stuckey said: “The 2025 MYEFO does not require an increase in public debt, as it keeps within the original budget deficit. “The 2025 MYEFO shows revenues down by K1,183 million, or 4.7 per cent.  The challenges this presents were highlighted in the MYEFO. Policy adjustments are required, just as they were in 2015. “The 2025 MYEFO shows budget implementation of 42 per cent. Expenditure by the end of June was K11,900 million.  Budget expenditure was 121 per cent higher than in 2015. PSIP at 60 per cent. DSIP at 60 per cent. “The 2025 MYEFO also uses better estimating methodologies for changed expenditures. Specifically, it estimated that 2025 expenditures would be K494 million higher than budgeted. “This extra K494 million is attacked as irresponsible by O’Neill – claims of just “Resupply the Waigani Slush Fund”.  But what is he hiding? “Why doesn’t he mention that K220 million of the expected expenditure increase is due to more salary payments required for our teachers?  Does he want to sack teachers at our children’s schools?  Isn’t it better to make provision for the extra teachers, to ensure that they can continue to be paid on time?  Making provision for this extra cost is good budget management. “The second part of the increased expenditure is an increase in donor grant funding support of K274 million. Why does he oppose our international friends providing grant support for our development? “This extra donor support counts as both extra revenue and expenditure, so it has no impact on the deficit. “The attack on this increased allowance for expenditure is clearly sensationalist and irresponsible. We want to pay our teachers, and we kindly accept over half of this expenditure increase, which is 100 per cent grant support from our international friends. He chased away all of our international friends.”

Title: Police inability to tackle crime forcing people to fend for themselves: Ipatas
Content: THE inability of police to address lawlessness in the country has forced the people to take matters into their hands, says Enga Governor Sir Peter Ipatas. He said that the recent unrest at the University of Goroka was an example of the breakdown of law and order, leaving people to fend for themselves in times of trouble. “Police are meant to be the enforcers of law and order but right now there is not much they can do,” he said. “The Constitution gives the police force the powers to conduct investigations, make arrests and prosecute, but there is a serious lack of capacity in all these areas. “The Government must immediately step up its efforts to fix the police force before things get worse.” He added that the upkeep and functions of the police force was the responsibility of the Government which should fund it and provide adequate resources for officers. “We see policemen walking around without any bulletproof vests. Some criminals carry more high-powered weapons than the police which makes their job even more dangerous. “The Government has a responsibly to protect and support our police force because they are the ones who should maintain law and order. “You can talk about improving the economy or making social changes, but if there is not law and order in place, then nothing will be achieved.” Meanwhile, Sir Peter advised Engan students at the university to remain calm and wait for the provincial government to repatriate them upon the advice of the university’s academic senate. “Leaders must not evacuate students without authorisation from the university. This can cause problems for the administration and the students in the future. “The issue has escalated beyond control, and any attempts to evacuate students could affect their education in the future.”

Title: Hahembe wins Miss East Sepik
Content: MISS Wosera-Gawi, Vilousa Hahembe, was crowned Miss Bird of Paradise -East Sepik on Saturday night in Wewak, East Sepik. “I will wear this crown with grace and humility, upholding the values, traditions and strength of our Sepik way of life,” Hahembe said. Hahembe was among five other contestants who entered the pageant to represent each of the district in East Sepik. She graduated from the University of Papua New Guinea with Bachelor in Economics from the School of Business and Public Policy and currently has a role as the country representative of PNG to the Commonwealth Students’ Association. “I strongly advocate and work in youth spaces focusing on education and youth empowerment,” she said. “As part of my journey, I am committed to creating education accessible to children and youths. “I believe education is the key to finding one’s purpose. “Education not only in the sense of going to school but also cultivating one’s talents to empower them to discover their purpose,” she Hahembe said. “I wish to extend my sincere gratitude to Miss Manui, East Sepik pageant committee for their dedication, vision and tireless commitment to empowering young women leaders of East Sepik. “Your work is not only transforming lives but also shaping the future of our province and our nation. She thanked her family from Wosera-Gawi and Yangoru-Saussia for their support, belief in her and their love. She now moves on to prepare to represent East Sepik at the Miss PNG National Pageant.

Title: Hau’ofa is PNG’s first UN ambassador
Content: AMBASSADOR Michelle Hau’ofa says Papua New Guinea remains committed to the principles and purposes of the United Nations to multilateral cooperation, peace and security. She said this while presenting her letter of credentials recently to Tatiana Valovaya, Director-General of the United Nations (UN) in Geneva at the United Nations Office. According to Foreign Affairs Department secretary Elias Wohengu, the ceremony signifies the appointment and recognition of Papua New Guinea’s first ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, following the establishment of its first permanent mission in Geneva in April. Wohengu said Hau’ofa was appointed by the National Executive Council to head the country’s mission in Geneva. During the event, Hau’ofa said: “I represent my country with a deep sense of responsibility in this distinguished multilateral environment, and sincerely appreciate the global work of the UN, especially in PNG in areas including health, education, environment and climate action, human rights, trade, investment and sustainable development.” She further said the Government fully recognised the importance of opening a mission and having a diplomatic presence in this strategic location. Hau’ofa is supported by John Emilio, deputy permanent representative and Issac Givolo, first secretary to PNG’s permanent mission in Geneva.

Title: Sir Peter points out change in attitude
Content: LOCAL level government (LLG) leaders should be servants of the people they represent and not do the job only for the money, Enga Governor Sir Peter Ipatas says. Sir Peter, who made his way up the ranks from a council president after 18 years, said it was a worrying to see the trend of candidates contesting the LLG elections because of money. “In our time, we served the people as volunteers who were paid small allowances,” he said. “We mainly took the job as a form of service to our community. “Most of us were paid only K6 per quarter. But now we can see that everyone wants to become a councillor because they will be on payroll after they are elected. “This is not the right thing to be doing, especially for leaders at the sub-national level who are meant to live with the people and solve issues on the ground.” Sir Peter said this year’s LLG elections were a cause for concern, especially seeing the behaviour of candidates having changed compared with how things were in the past. “There is no point in holding big campaign rallies when the people who you are trying to serve live with you,” he said. “This shows that the systems meant to govern are failing us.” Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe had announced earlier this year that elected leaders would be paid fortnightly. He said this was part of the government’s efforts to improve the country’s third tier of government by empowering LLG leaders. “The government has made some significant and important improvements in the LLGs since 1995 such as putting ward councillors and (LLG) presidents in the governments’ payroll system to receive fortnight salaries of K300. Writs are expected to be returned next Friday (Nov 21).
People: Peter Ipatas, Sir Peter Ipatas, Soroi Eoe

Title: Marape: Our forest is our contribution to humanity
Content: PAPUA New Guinea offers 35 million hectares of rainforest as its contribution to fighting climate change as Prime Minister James Marape call on world leaders to honour their commitments. “Act now and act responsibly to save the planet,” Marape told a COP30 World Leaders Climate Summit in Belem, Brazil yesterday. Marape urged nations to honour their commitments under the Paris Agreement and embrace nature-based solutions as the foundation for global climate action. He said for PNG climate adaptation and mitigation was not a choice but a matter of survival. “Forests and oceans offer nature-based solutions and technologies to replenish Mother Earth,” he said. “PNG safeguards 35 million hectares of pristine rainforest – the lungs of the earth – and we offer this as our contribution and legacy to humanity. “This shows that even a small forest nation like PNG can drive global impact. “Our intention is to ratify the protection of 30 per cent of our ocean area from illegal and commercial exploitation. “With seven per cent of the world’s biodiversity in our land and waters, the sustainable use of our oceans and forests is vital to saving this planet.” Marape acknowledged global partners including the United Nations, the Green Climate Fund, France, Australia, the Coalition for Rainforest Nations and the World Agroforestry Centre (ICRAF) for supporting PNG’s conservation efforts. “Without saving our forests, trees and oceans, the climate change conversation is redundant,” Marape said. “Technology is important, but without nature-based solutions, it cannot succeed. “You can look at 46 billion light years into the universe, and you will not find another planet like ours. “This planet is worth fighting for. Let us pass on a liveable earth to our children as our ancestors did for us,” he said. Marape pledged PNG’s support for Australia’s bid to co-host COP31, which he said, would “bridge the conversation between forestry and ocean nations, uniting both fronts to keep our earth in balance.”

Title: Funding support needed for forest nations, PM says
Content: A STRONGER global financing mechanism should be in place to support forest and ocean nations, Prime Minister James Marape said during the COP30 Climate Summit in Belem, Brazil. He stressed that tropical countries like PNG, Brazil and Congo were “carrying the weight of the planet’s survival” in their fight to preserve the world’s last great carbon sinks. “Forests and ocean nations are carrying the burden of the entire planet’s atmospheric balance,” he said. “The Amazon Basin, the Congo Basin, and the tropical forests of PNG and Southeast Asia together form the lungs of the earth. “Conserving them is the greatest mitigation effort we can make to save humanity itself. “When I first began this journey, I thought I was fighting to save our forests. “Now I realise I am fighting to save humanity. “Our forests, oceans and biodiversity sustain all life on earth – and without them, we have no future.” Marape told the participants at a thematic session yesterday that there was no substitute for the earth’s natural systems, urging them not to look to other planets for survival but to preserve the one they already inhabit. “There is no planet like earth,” he said. “Mars and Mercury are unliveable. Here, rivers, trees, mountains and oceans sustain life. “That is worth fighting for. “Our forests deserve proper conservation financing. “Nature-based technologies must begin by valuing standing forests – not just harvested timber. “One hectare of conserved forest can save the world far more than any industrial offset.” He urged the international community to deliver a new era of equitable climate finance. Meanwhile, Marape said PNG committed to halting large-scale deforestation, restoring degraded land and supporting sustainable development for local communities. He also highlighted PNG’s readiness to work with global partners to advance forest-nation diplomacy and operationalise long-term climate financing solutions. “For six years as prime minister, I have been saying: stop deforestation,” he said. “If this generation of leaders fail to find real financing solutions for forest nations, history will judge us harshly.”

Title: Hope at last for displaced islanders
Content: HUNDREDS of Kadovar islanders living at a care center in East Sepik since 2018 will soon been permanently resettled at Kaup. This is according to the Department of Provincial and Local-level Government Affairs (DPLGA) staff who are in the province with a team from the Department of Lands and Physical Planning, the provincial and Wewak administration. It is understood that the government delegation was identifying and negotiating with the proposed Kaup landowners to acquire 97.6 hectares of land for permanent resettlement. The volcano on Kadovar, which is part of the Schouten Islands Group, erupted on Jan 5, 2018, which forced the islanders to the Wewak mainland. The displaced population was relocated to the Dandan Care Centre, which occupies a 3.5-hectare low-lying coastal area bordered by steep hills on one side and the sea on the other. According to the DPLGA, the acquisition of the land at Kaup would provide a long-term and secure settlement site for the islanders. The department in a statement said: “Consultations and land acquisition processes are currently progressing, with permanent relocation expected by mid-next year. “Since the displacement, the Internally Displaced Persons at Dandan Care Centre have relied heavily on food assistance. “The DPLGA has been providing food rations since 2019, while also leading efforts toward a sustainable and permanent resettlement programme. “The centre remains highly prone to flooding, especially during heavy rain. “Limited land space and unresolved ownership issues have restricted agricultural activities, preventing self-reliant food production and worsening nutrition and living conditions. “The proposed Kaup resettlement site offers safer and more sustainable living conditions. “Negotiations with Kaup landowners are ongoing to finalise the land acquisition process.”

Title: Hydro project to hopefully ease ESP district’s power woes
Content: YANGORU-Saussia’s long-standing power problems might be nearing an end with the start of a pre-feasibility study into the proposed Sikau Hydro Project. Local member and Minister for International Trade and Investment Richard Maru presented a cheque of over K300,000 from the District Development Authority last Friday to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Construction (Smec) to start the study in December. The study is expected to take four months to complete. “The district has been plagued by power problems due to continuous power blackout in the Wewak grid and falling power poles which have not been attended to by PNG Power Ltd (PPL). “The longest (period of blackout) is at four months now which has affected the schools, hospitals, businesses and the villages,” he said. He said the proposed Sikau Hydro will be an independent mini grid and there are plans to sell the power as an independent power producer. The DDA plans to invite PNG Power to be one of the first foundation shareholders in this project along with the Yangoru-Saussia DDA and the landowners. This is part of the DDA’s commitment to this project by funding the pre-feasibility study before seeking assistance from other stakeholders on the cost of full feasibility study and the construction which would be over K50 million. Meanwhile work has started on a new standby power station at Haripmo in the Sepik Plains. The Yangoru-Saussia DDA bought two generators for the purpose. SMEC senior hydropower engineer Sujan Ghimire said the project is a small hydro capable of delivering between two to five megawatts. “Once viable, then the next stage is tendering and construction and based on experience should take up to two years to complete,” he said. PNG Power chief technical officer Tony Koiri said PPL stands ready to assist any district and province in their efforts to participate in the energy sector within the country.

Title: ENB’s Pomio ends LLG elections
Content: THE local level government (LLG) elections in East New Britain’s Pomio concluded on Thursday, with the declaration of all seven LLG presidents. The final declarations were made for Sinivit and East Pomio LLGs where Boniface Gerep retained his seat as Sinivit LLG president while newcomer Rodney Simai unseated Steven Sinkie to become the new East Pomio LLG president. The declarations took place at Warangoi and Milim, respectively. The first LLG in the district to declare its result was West Pomio LLG, which saw Paul Pavol regaining his seat last Tuesday. This was followed by Central Pomio LLG where John Raloga also retained his position as president after being declared on Wednesday, Nov 5. On the same day, three more LLGs announced their results, including Inland Pomio LLG, which elected Philip Tova as its first president, and Mamusi Yana LLG, which saw Sylvester Konte becoming the inaugural president. These two new LLGs were created following the administrative split of the former Central Inland Pomio and West Pomio Mamusi LLGs. The final declaration came from Melkoi LLG where incumbent president Thomas Osa was unseated by newcomer Francis Aluka.

Title: Madang musician ‘Shydeez’ takes part in town clean-a-thon
Content: THE Madang public and business houses gathered again on Saturday, Nov 8 to continue with the clean-a-thon programme, an annual initiative led by the Madang police prosecution section. Among those who joined was Madang’s music legend Vok Kiatig, popularly known asShydeez, along with his family. The group took part in the cleaning the town area from the 17A bus stop to Bates Oval. Kiatig appealed to the public, especially those living and working in Madang to take initiative and be more responsible for their rubbish by disposing them in the right places. He also thanked Eugene Wanai from the Madang police prosecution section for taking the lead in the clean-a-thon. He also encouraged more business houses and individuals to join in the effort. Senior Constable and acting OIC police prosecution, Eugene Wanai announced that the next clean-a-thon is set for Dec 20, 2025, in preparation for the Christmas Eve period. This period is expected to see an increase in many visitors to Madang. “Keeping the town clean will reflect positively on what visitors hear and see about Madang through mainstream media and social media platforms,” Wanai said. The clean-a-thon has become a monthly programme aimed at maintaining the township.

Title: Government using revenue to pay last year’s cheques, says O’Neill
Content: FINANCE and Treasury officials have warned of a serious budget blowout next year if the practice of using current year revenues to pay previous year’s bills is continued. Former Prime Minister Peter O’Neill echoed the public servants’ warning contained in the mid-year economic and fiscal outcome in a statement on Thursday. Said O’Neill: “According to a Finance Department written brief of Nov 3 (Monday last week), more than K1,209,000,000 of last year’s Finance Department cheques had been paid out of this year’s budget with over K160 million from last year still to be cashed by Finance. “Furthermore, the Finance brief points out that if all cheques were presented and paid, the Waigani Public Account would be overdrawn by K1.6 billion. “Marape is robbing this year’s budget to pay last year’s bills. “He is expecting public servants to undertake terrible administrative irregularities just so that he can continue to be cashed up to stay in power. “The brave public servants in Treasury have made it clear there is rampant manipulation going on with their red flag warning on page 52 of the outcome report: “Using this year’s revenue and financing (loans) to fund last year’s cheques could affect this year’s budget execution. “This vicious cycle could continue if large cheque floats are allowed into the next fiscal year. “The Marape government is writing out cheques without having the money to honour them and using the next year’s budget to pay last year’s bills. “We can assume their political masters will expect Treasury and Finance staff to cop the blame when things do not go to plan.” O’Neill further said democracy was decaying as fast as quality of life was slipping under Marape “Daily living costs have spiralled; wages have been stuck, and violent crime has increased considerably,” he said. “Power supply is going from bad to worse; our Kina is losing its value and medicines are simply not supplied. “GDP (gross domestic product) is growing due to the price of gold and commodities rising globally but investment in our country is shrinking due to a lack of confidence in the Marape government. “This is greatly impacting jobs growth.”

Title: Bodies of landslide victims taken home for burial
Content: RELATIVES of the 21 persons killed in a freak landslide in Kukas, Minamb Valley, Wapanemanda, Enga, recently have taken the bodies of their loves one’s home for burial. An outpouring of emotion flowed as relatives wept when the coffins were taken out of the mortuary on Friday in Mt Hagen. Family members in Mt Hagen contributed cash to those who came from Enga. Two children, three women, including one who was pregnant, and 16 men were understood to be sleeping in two homes when the landslide struck around 2am on Friday, Oct 31. The 21 coffins were loaded into three trucks and departed. Enga’s deputy administrator Henry Kapao supervised the repatriation of the 21. Kapao thanked the Mt Hagen community for the support and sharing of grief. He said that the Enga provincial administration was taking care of the costs of putting the bodies in the funeral home and the repatriation. Disaster response agencies and the International Migration Office are responsible for relief assistance. Australian officials stated after the incident that they would help when and where required.

Title: Sir Puka explains reasons behind Opposition’s motion of no confidence
Content: Abau MP Sir Puka Temu highlighted the deteriorating law and order situation in the country as one of the reasons behind the Opposition’s recent motion of no confidence. The motion filed on Oct 29 had named Ialibu-Pangia MP Peter O’Neill as the alternative prime minister. The motion was to be moved by Sir Puka and seconded by Chuave MP James Nomane. However, On Oct 30, the Private Business Committee rejected the motion because of Constitutional Amendment No 48 to Section 145 of the Constitution pertaining to motions of no confidence. Sir Puka said law and order collapsed under the leadership of Prime Minister James Marape. “Violent crime, tribal fighting, and armed robberies have become normal headlines. “Police are under-resourced and demoralised. Communities live in fear, and the government has lost control of maintaining basic safety for its citizens. “This is not leadership — it is neglect,” Sir Puka said. Sir Puka said the people wanted leadership that delivers results and ‘not endless talk.’ Sir Puka added; “Some question the timing of this motion, saying the elections are near. “But that is not a reason to sit idle while the country suffers. A lot of damage can still be done between now and 2027, and as we have seen in the last six years, it only gets worse. This motion had to be moved. Leadership means acting when it matters, not when it is convenient. “I understand that O’Neill is not without criticism, but I have personally witnessed a genuine change in his leadership since stepping down in 2019. He has reflected deeply on his past mistakes and shown a willingness to correct them. “That level of self-awareness is rare in politics and deserves recognition,” he said.
People: James Marape, James Nomane, Puka Temu

Title: Food festival supports children’s ward at PMGH
Content: A TWO-DAY food festival in Port Moresby recently will see a portion of the proceedings donated to the children’s paediatric and cancer ward at the Port Moresby General Hospital. Since its establishment in 2019, the Hamamas Food Festival 2025, an event aimed at giving back to the local community resumed on Saturday following the Coronavirus setback. The festival was held at the Dynasty Restaurant at Vision City Mega Mall and brought together 13 known restaurants in Port Moresby, showing support and celebration of flavour, culture, and community. Dynasty Seafood Restaurant manager Nelma Cruz said they decided to resume the event after receiving requests from people willing to support it. Cruz said 10 per cent from the sales will be given to the hospital’s children’s ward 1E. “We have a committee that chooses a non-organisation to donate the proceedings to, but due to the demand in health, we have decided to put forward the donations to a government sector.” She said the director of the restaurants Ricky Yu initially came up with the idea of giving back to the community by inviting Port Moresby restaurants where a portion of the sales would go as a donation. “The festival is not just about great food, it is basically about giving to those who need assistance, and that is the least we could do,” she said Cruz thanked sponsors South Pacific Brewery, RH Hypermarket, RMC Maintenance and Colour Boys, and said that a cheque will be presented to the ward after reconciliation is done. She said they would donate to a different organisation next year and hope to make this an annual event. The festival ended yesterday.

Title: Lae’s power woes due to supply and old grid
Content: LAE MP John Rosso says constant power outages in the city are due to power supply and an old grid. Rosso said that they are collaborating with State Enterprises (SOE) Ministry and the PNG Power Ltd (PPL) to fix the issue. “I also live in Lae and I am aware of the constant blackouts, but it is not an easy fix,” he said. “It is a mixture of power supply and an old grid in the city. “Therefore, we have transformers being blown up and lines collapsed. “But I can assure the people that after speaking with the PPL and the SOE Ministry, we will make sure to rectify the problem in the long run.” An old grid refers to the aging and unreliable electricity infrastructure managed by PPL. Rosso said that it would take a longer period to fix the power issue. “But I can assure everyone that we are working on it,” he said. “PPL has brought in 10 major gen-sets and are currently in the process of fitting them in at the Taraka substation. “They already got a 132kv transmission line that connect from Yonki all the way down to assist with the power problem in Lae.” The line is connected from Singsing to Lae through Erap and Taraka substations, constructing new towers and rehabilitating substations. It is believed to be a rehabilitation programme aimed to enhance reliability and improve the quality and stability and reduce power outages in Lae. Rosso assured people that the power issue would be fixed, but it would take a longer period to ensure the problem is fixed properly. Meanwhile,The Nationalhas observed that areas and settlements in Lae experience constant blackouts, where it affects daily operations. Many households go without power for three to four days or a week because a line has collapsed or transformers have blown.

Title: More time needed to fix power and water, says Duma
Content: GIVE government a “little more time” to turn the current situation around with PNG Power Ltd and Water PNG Ltd, says State-owned Enterprises Minister William Duma. Asked to provide an update on the issues and challenges within some of the SOEs (state-owned enterprises), Duma said these were legacy issues surrounding the country’s utility company, and that ongoing work, including a possible public privatisation arrangement of PPL is being done to address them. He explained that there were ongoing challenges in modernising the aging (more than 50 years old) infrastructures across the country. “We still have ongoing challenges in terms of changing the attitudes of our workforce. We’ve been able to recruit a gentleman from New Zealand to be our CEO (for PNG Power),” Duma said. “There is a turnaround plan that has been endorsed by cabinet. And while, we are also working on the arrangement to partially privatise PNG Power, we are not waiting for the progression projects to be completed as early yet. “In the meantime, there’s ongoing work across the country to upgrade all our infrastructures. “We’ve had some challenges with the substation such as the continued work at Konedobu substation (Port Moresby). There’s some technical issues, and ongoing restoration work in Lae, which is a very important industrial city. “There’s ongoing work in Lae to ramp up the provision of power. There’s remedial work being done from Singsing Creek all the way down to Lae. “The ternary lines are being replaced slowly, and we’ve also ordered new generators to be able to provide good assistance for Lae at this time. So a lot of money has been invested.” He added that for Lae, there were also plans to put up a solar plane delay so that when one system is down, solar could then provide immediate, temporary relief. “So all of those are ongoing,” he said. “We’ve spent a lot of money and hopefully by the end of or middle of next year, you’ll see results for Lae. “There will be a complete turnaround. We are carrying out rehabilitation work for our Ramu generation facilities out there. “We have logistics challenges in continuing to provide reliable diesel for our power savings as we work.” Furthermore, regarding the ongoing bulk water supply issue in the urban areas in the country, Duma said it was again aging facilities and population increase challenges that they need to deal with. He said in Port Moresby, the Mt Eriama water treatment facility was designed for population of less than a million, about 500,000. However, currently, due to population increase, Water PNG had to increase and improve the capacity in order to release water to a population of a million.

Title: PPL boss in Lae to understand challenges
Content: PNG Power Limited (PPL) chief executive officer Paul Bayly is in Lae to understand the challenges facing the company’s critical regional operations, especially the Ramu Power Grid.
