Bayly’s visit is also expected to include a meeting with staff and tour Lae substations. Bayly stressed that people are his first priority in turning the company around. He is also expected to meet with commercial and industrial stakeholders in Lae to discuss their power supply concerns, future expansion needs, and how PPL can better support the city’s economic growth. He said Lae industries are highly reliant on a stable power supply from the Ramu system. He said visits to regional centres like Lae are seen as a critical component of his strategy to stabilise and modernise PPL, moving away from a Port Moresby-centric management style and ensuring that resources and attention are directed to where the power is generated and distributed.

Title: Police chief visits city wardens on training
Content: NATIONAL Capital District (NCD) and Central Acting Assistant Commissioner of Police Benjamin Turi, has commended City Wardens for helping police to crack down on petty crime in the city. The City Wardens programme, which started last year, is an initiative of the National Capital District Commission, due to the rising safety concerns in the city. Turi met with the wardens who were undergoing a weeklong training at Kuriva, in Central on Friday. “You all need motivation,” Turi told the wardens. “Since your deployment last year, you all have been working hard to make Boroko clean. Gordons has reported fewer bag-snatching cases, and other centres where your presence is seen have also experienced changes. “We do have weaknesses, and most of our weaknesses have been aired out by the public on social media, which we have all noted. Your week-long training will help shape you into good officers when you return to your respective areas of operation, the commander told the wardens,” Turi said. Central police commander Chief Insp Joseph Salle, and reservist coordinator Chief Insp Ruben Guisu accompanied Turi.

Title: Top cop hails Chimbu for peaceful LLG polling
Content: THE local level government (LLG) elections in Chimbu were carried out peacefully despite minor issues encountered at some polling booths, according to police. Chimbu police commander Supt Mazuc Rubiang thanked the people of Chimbu, including candidates and their supporters, for ensuring a peaceful and orderly conduct of the election throughout the province. “Despite minor hiccups, the overall polling process was conducted smoothly and successfully in all the districts except for Karamui, where polling is still underway,” he said. Rubiang said police had faced logistical and funding challenges during the operation. But he assured the public that such difficulties did not deter their commitment to maintaining law and order. “As I reminded my officers during a recent briefing, funding constraints will not stop us from carrying out our duties, we remain committed to ensuring that our people exercise their democratic rights fairly and equally,” Rubiang said. He said the dedication of his officers showed that they serve not only as law enforcers but also as members of the same communities they protect. “We have taken an oath to serve our people and will continue to maintain our operations throughout the counting period and declaration of the LLG presidents,” Rubiang said. “I appeal to all the candidates and supporters to continue to maintain peace and patience as counting continues to ensure Chimbu remains the model for peaceful LLG elections in the country.”

Title: Two killed while in police custody
Content: TWO men killed at Kinim Station, Karkar Island in Madang, on Friday were under police custody, Madang police say. Their commander Acting Superintendent Robert Baim said: “These killings were brutal, barbaric and inhumane and the incident is a serious breach of law and order.” He confirmed that the two deceased were from Gial village and the suspects were alleged to be from Urugen village. The killings were believed to be a retaliation. Of the two killed, one was beheaded after he was taken into police custody at Kinum Station early the day. “From the initial report, the deceased persons were already under police custody when the attack occurred and this in itself is a serious breach of law and order so we will ensure those responsible are brought to face justice,” Baim said. It was also understood that a police task force unit was sent to stabilise the situation from escalating further between Gial and Urugen villagers. “I am calling on community leaders from both sides to stay calm, cooperate with police as the case is now a police matter so let police deal with it,” Baim said. “Those with information should come forward and assist police to ensure investigations are fast-tracked to get the suspects under arrest and charges are laid.” Baim urged the suspects to surrender to police to make situation easier for them. “Do not let police come after you as the situation may not be good for you and your families.” Baim said the incident happened after youths consumed illicit substances such as marijuana and homebrew (steam). The incident happened in the morning and Madang Governor Ramsey Pariwa said that such an act is painting a bad image of the beautiful Karkar Island and the province. Pariwa said the deceased were in the lawful precinct and custody of police. “We must respect the law and the lawful processes in place and abide by it and not to take the law into our own hands,” he said “The ultimate act of beheading a deceased person as if he were an animal is so cruel in nature and I totally condemn it. I also call on the villages of both Gial and Urugen to observe peace and allow the law to take its course with the help of our police. “I appeal to my communities on the island to assist police to do their work in enforcing the law and maintaining peace and order.”

Title: Australia GG new patron for Kokoda Track Foundation
Content: Australian Governor-General Sam Mostyn is the new patron of the Kokoda Track Foundation (KTF). “I’m delighted to become patron of the Kokoda Track Foundation,” she said. “The friendship between Australia and PNG is one of deep history and shared purpose. “I look forward to sharing KTF’s stories about how they have been working hand in hand with communities across PNG to strengthen education, health, equality and leadership.” KTF chair Ian Kemish said: “KTF’s approach reflects perfectly the wonderful spirit of partnership between Australia and Papua New Guinea, because partnership is at the core of everything we do – with the people, communities and government of Papua New Guinea. “In welcoming the Governor-General as our patron, and with her deep commitment to supporting Australians and our neighbours alike, we look forward to expanding our impact, working alongside the people of PNG to drive meaningful change.” KTF chief executive officer Dr Genevieve Nelson welcomed the appointment. “We are delighted and incredibly grateful that Governor-General Mostyn is continuing her longstanding engagement with Papua New Guinea through this role,” she said. “Since her inspirational address at KTF’s Lt Col Ralph Honner Leadership Oration in 2016, Her Excellency has been a steadfast friend to both PNG and KTF.”

Title: Basil Jnr concerned over adjournment of Tutumang
Content: BULOLO MP Sam Basil Junior has underline concerns raised by the public on the one-week adjournment of Morobe Tutumang’s special sitting to elect a new governor. He released a statement calling on the Assembly Clerk to seek proper advice from the Secretary for Provincial Affairs on such matters. “The delay will create more instability and portrays bad governance and set bad precedents especially when we are in LLG elections,” he said. Basil, leader of the United Labor Party is an intending nominee for the vacant governor position. Noting also the interest of Dr Kobby Bomareo and Rainbo Paita, both Ministers, Basil said it was healthy for ministers to take interest in the development aspirations at the provincial level and to contribute to the national agenda. He then pointed out that written instructions were given in early October by provincial administrator, the Clerk of the Morobe Tutumang and the deputy Governor. “We are very well aware of the requirements that a person holding a ministry or constitutional office must resign to be nominated as a candidate,” he said. “Considering that from the ten members of parliament, we have five MPs holding important constitutional responsibilities such as Deputy Prime Minister, Ministers, chairman of Citizenship Advisory Committee and Deputy Speaker positions, I indicated my intention. “I also made a public announcement and communicated my intentions to the Prime Minister in relation to my position as Vice Minister for Mining and Sports. “The Clerk and the provincial administration must be conscious of the advice provided that elections must be conducted well before Nov 21, 2025.”
People: Kobby Bomareo, Rainbo Paita, Sam Basil

Title: Police houses commissioned
Content: TEN new police house and a renovated police station in Bereina, Kairuku, Central, were commissioned by Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr on Friday. The houses cost K3.9million and was funded by the Government through the Special Police Assistance Programme (SPAP). Tsiamalili, while acknowledging the assistance given by the government, said Kairuku might be only an hour away from Port Moresby but still lacked government services. This was a reality faced right around the country, he said. Tsiamalili said through the SPAP, the government, across the country, is making a difference with regards to policing infrastructure, particularly in rural areas. He told police officers and the people gathered for the occasion: “I want to appreciate my police officers. “Continue to serve your country; this is your country. “This is a job that you made a decision to join the police force and you believe in the uniform. “We can have many people criticising us, but no one fits into our shoes. “They can continue to criticise us, but you have a minister who has the greatest trust in all of you. “Despite the challenges of many governments in the past, no other government is investing more in police than this government.” Tsiamalili added that, he was trying his best to make sure police infrastructure is looked into, police cars are given to increase police presence, and police officers are trained to increase police manpower throughout the country. Tsiamalili said that getting the simple things right, like repatriating the retired officers back home and getting the uniforms for the police officers, are some of the things that are being looked into. He also challenged the serving police officers to look after the new officers who will graduate and join them in the future. He urged them to teach new cadets the good habits of discipline that they were taught at Bomana Police College. Tsiamalili thanked the landowners of Bereina who provided land to build the police houses. He also thanked Kairuku MP and Energy Minister Peter Isoaimo, who donated two open-back Toyotaland cruisers vehicles to Bereina police. The commissioning of the 10 houses were witnessed by senior police officers from police headquarters and the NCD/Central command, along with the police officers of Central and Kairuku MP, as well as the people of Mekeo and Bereina.

Title: 130 Grade 12 students graduate from Ogelbeng
Content: WESTERN Highlands’ grades eight and 10 students will continue on to their next grades next year without going through the selection process, says an official. Education executive officer, Tony Buldung made this known to parents and students at the first Grade 12 graduation of Ogelbeng Lutheran Secondary School on Thursday. Buldung said the Education Department allowed Western Highlands among six other provinces to implement the policy “no examination for grades eight and 10” due to the high retention of enrolment in the province. Buldung, while congratulating the 130 Grade 12 students who graduated together with the 450 Grade 10, said the policy challenged students to work smart to get a placing in higher learning institutions after completing Grade 12. Also, the provincial government, through Governor Wai Rapa, is positioning itself to embrace the high number of Grade 12 student turnover by building technical and vocational education training (Tvet) institutions in the province, he added. Buldung said four new Tvet schools would be built in the four districts, bringing the number to seven. He said as part of a motivational programme, the provincial government also had an annual budget of K2,000 for each student who secured enrolment in higher learning institutions. The graduation was attended by officials from the province and the Education Department, with guest speaker James Anis Wapyer, a senior lecturer from the University of Papua New Guinea.

Title: Two dead, one million evacuated as Typhoon Fung-wong slams into the Philippines
Content: ISABELA, Philippines: Typhoon Fung-wong ravaged the northern Philippines overnight, killing at least two people and cutting off some towns as residents emerged on Monday morning after a sleepless night to start assessing the damage. More than one million people were evacuated before Fung-wong made landfall as a super typhoon in the eastern town of Dinalungan in Aurora province on Sunday night. It pounded parts of the country’s main island of Luzon with fierce winds, heavy rain and storm swells through the night. The typhoon, locally named “Uwan”, damaged houses in the northern city of Santiago in Isabela province. Tree branches and electric posts were also felled by the typhoon. “We could not sleep last night because of the winds hitting our metal sheets and the tree branches falling,” said Romeo Mariano, who was sheltering with his grandmother in their home. “Almost all of the tree branches nearby fell, and when we got out to check our home, we saw the damage,” he added. At least two people were killed by the typhoon, according to an early report from the Civil Defence office, with two others injured. Aurora vice-governor Patrick Alexis Angara said at least three towns were inaccessible due to landslides and broken roads. The state weather agency said the typhoon was now moving over the South China Sea, and is forecast to shift northeast towards Taiwan. It warned that a large portion of the country still faced heavy rains and severe winds, along with storm swells in coastal areas. Over 400 flights have been cancelled since Sunday, the civil aviation regulator said. Fung-wong was the 21st storm to hit the Philippines this year and came immediately after Typhoon Kalmaegi, which last week killed 224 in the country and another five in Vietnam. Source: Reuters

Title: Eleven found dead in Thai-Malaysia search after Rohingya migrant boat sinks
Content: LANGKAWI, Malaysia: The number of people confirmed dead after a boat carrying members of Myanmar’s persecuted Rohingya community sank near the Thailand-Malaysia border rose to 11 on Monday, authorities said, with about 70 people believed to have been on board the capsized vessel. The status of another boat carrying 230 passengers remained unclear, Malaysian authorities said, adding that 13 survivors had been found so far, mostly Rohingya. Thai authorities said they had recovered four bodies, including two children, adding to the seven found by Malaysia’s maritime agency. Facing violence at home in Myanmar and increasingly difficult living conditions in sprawling refugee camps in Bangladesh, Rohingya from both countries regularly attempt perilous journeys by sea, including to Malaysia and Indonesia. Myanmar’s impoverished Rakhine state has suffered years of conflict, hunger and ethnic violence mostly targeting the Rohingya Muslim minority community. Driven from Rakhine following a brutal 2017 military crackdown, about 1.3 million Rohingya live as refugees in Bangladesh. At a press conference on the island of Langkawi, close to the search area, Malaysia’s maritime agency said air assets were being deployed by both Thailand and Malaysia to search for survivors. “We have got very good … relations with the Thai agency so we have got good communication and exchanges of information,” said Romli Mustafa, director of the maritime agency in Malaysia’s Kedah and Perlis. “It will be easier for us and our sea assets,” he said of the use of air assets to support the search by boats, adding that the search operation could last seven days. Romli said information received by the agency indicated a boat had departed Myanmar, near the border with Bangladesh, about two weeks ago, but some passengers had moved onto another vessel on Thursday. Of the 13 survivors, 11 were Rohingya and two from Bangladesh, he added. Source: Reuters

Title: South Korea special prosecutor indicts ex-President Yoon on more charges
Content: SEOUL: South Korea’s special prosecutor on Monday indicted former President Yoon Suk Yeol on additional charges of abusing power and aiding an enemy state related to his short-lived imposition of martial law last year. Yoon attempted to provoke military conflict between South and North Korea in order to declare martial law, a prosecutor’s spokesperson told a briefing, citing evidence found on a military official’s mobile phone that included some words suggesting potential provocations against North Korea, such as “drones” and “surgical strike”. Yoon was removed from office by the Constitutional Court in April and is on trial for insurrection stemming from his failed martial law declaration. If found guilty, he could be sentenced to death. Yoon has said consistently he never intended to impose military rule but declared martial law to sound the alarm on wrongdoings by opposition parties and to protect democracy from “anti-state” elements. According to the memo, Yoon, former defence minister Kim Yong-hyun and former military intelligence chief Yeo In-hyung planned to induce a North Korean attack against the South, the spokesperson, Park Ji-young, said. The trio conspired to create tensions in the country as a justification for Yoon to declare martial law, she said. Kim and Yeo were also indicted on the same additional charges, the prosecutor said. The special prosecutor’s team has accused Yoon and his military commanders of ordering a covert drone operation into the North to inflame tensions between the neighbours and justify his martial law decree. In October last year, North Korea said the South had sent drones to scatter anti-North Korean leaflets over Pyongyang, and published photos of the remains of a crashed South Korean military drone. Despite intense scrutiny and political pressure, South Korea’s military declined at the time to comment on the suspicion of conducting a drone operation. A defence ministry official on Monday said it had no comment on the matter. Former defence minister Kim is also on trial on charges related to the martial law declaration. Yeo has said he deeply regretted not challenging the order from Yoon, according to media reports. The prosecutor’s spokesperson said Yeo was making excuses that did not make sense about the notes discovered on his mobile phone. Source: Reuters

Title: Trump to meet Sharaa at White House, capping major turnaround for Syria
Content: WASHINGTON/RIYADH: Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s White House meeting with US President Donald Trump on Monday caps a stunning year for the rebel-turned-ruler who toppled a longtime autocratic leader and has since toured the world as he seeks to end Syria’s international isolation. Trump is set to welcome Sharaa in the first-ever visit by a Syrian president to the White House, six months after the pair first met in Saudi Arabia and just days after Washington said the former al Qaeda member was no longer a “Specially Designated Global Terrorist.” Sharaa, 42, took power last year after his Islamist fighters launched a lightning offensive from their enclave in Syria’s northwest and overthrew longtime Syrian President Bashar al-Assad just days later on Dec 8. Syria’s regional realignment has since moved at a dizzying pace, away from Assad’s key allies Iran and Russia and toward Turkey, the Gulf – and Washington. Security is likely to be a top focus of the meeting on Monday. The US is brokering talks between Syria and Israel on a possible security pact, and Reuters reported that the US is planning to establish a military presence at a Damascus airbase. Syria is also set to join a US-led coalition to fight Islamic State, which could be formally announced at Monday’s White House meeting. Days before the meeting, Trump told reporters at the White House that “a lot of progress has been made” on Syria. “I think he’s (Sharaa’s) doing a very good job. It’s a tough neighborhood, and he’s a tough guy, but I got along with him very well,” Trump said. After Sharaa and Trump met in Riyadh in May, Trump announced he would lift all sanctions on Syria. But the toughest measures, known as the Caesar Sanctions Act, require a repeal from Congress. The White House and State Department have publicly backed lifting them before 2025 ends, but experts say the government shutdown may affect that time frame. Source: Reuters

Title: Two Government ministers resign from portfolios to contest vacant Morobe governor’s seat
Content: A SPECIAL Tutumang sitting scheduled for Friday has been deferred for a week after two Government ministers vying for the vacant Morobe governor’s seat were late to provide copies of their resignation notices to the provincial assembly. Acting Prime Minister John Rosso confirmed that two Morobe MPs – Tewae-Siassi MP Dr Kobby Bomareo (Housing Minister) and Finschhafen MP Rainbo Paita (Mining Minister) – have resigned from their ministerial portfolios. The third candidate is Bulolo MP and Vice Mining Minister Sam Basil Jr. The special sitting will appoint an acting governor after the passing of Songang Luther Wenge. It has been adjourned to next week Thursday. “I received one of the resignations yesterday and the other this morning,” Rosso said. “Therefore, the Tutumang Special Sitting has been adjourned to next week Thursday to give enough time to process the resignation documents.” Tutumang’s deputy chairman Willie Simbisi said despite a full house at 10am on Friday, the assembly had to be adjourned because he did not receive any notice of resignation from Paita and Bomareo. “They have to submit their resignation to the National Executive Council who will then approve and decommission them and send a copy of their resignation to me as confirmation for them to be eligible to contest,” Simbisi said. “For now, I have not received any so they are disqualified; this extra week should give ample time for due process to take place until we convene next week Thursday.”
People: John Rosso, Kobby Bomareo, Luther Wenge, Rainbo Paita, Sam Basil, Sam Basil Jr.

Title: Fire service calls for exits, extinguishers in every home
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Fire Service has warned that it is a priority to have fire extinguishers and escape doors in every home in case of a fire and occupants need to get out. Gerehu fire station acting superintendent Johnson Charles was commenting on the early morning fire on Wednesday in Gordon, Port Moresby in which a family of six perished. “For that case at Gordon, there were people who wanted to help the occupants because they were crying for help and were struggling to escape,” he said. “But there was no fire exit, and the windows were grilled. “So they were trapped inside and couldn’t escape because the fire was blocking the entrance.” Charles urged home owners to seek advice from the four fire stations in Port Moresby about installing fire detectors. The fire service normally advises builders and home owners to install smoke detectors, fire extinguishers and to have an escape door. He also said that it would help the work of firefighters if bystanders do not interfere with their work. “Let us assess and do our jobs. That’s where the police help to control the crowd so that we can do our job. Another risk of being close is the water pressure from the hose-pipe which can be dangerous,” Charles said. “When there is a fire, the first thing you do is call the toll free number 1100. A vehicle will be sent. Don’t wait till too late. “It’s not only the job of the occupants to call. Everyone living in the area when noticing a fire must call.” Charles also explained that apart from the water in their trucks, they depended on the hydrants. “Sometimes we have water rationing in the city and there is not much pressure or the hydrants are removed due to construction. So we have to source water from the next hydrant,” he said. He added that hydrants must be installed every 100 metres by Water PNG. The inspections are carried out by the fire stations. “Water PNG erects the hydrants but we do the cleaning and painting so that they stand out. We check if they are working. If not working, we report to Water PNG and notify people living nearby to look after them,” he said.

Title: Lae Secondary students return from robotic competition in Panama City
Content: MOROBE’s Lae Secondary School has again participated in the Global Youth Challenge Robotic Competition in Panama City representing Papua New Guinea. The school board and administration supported four of their students under the science stream and they came in 90th place out of the 181 countries that participated. Two teachers, Martha Aaron and Trevor Elia, had accompanied the students. Aaron said countries formed an alliance to challenge each other, so in order for them to win, it depended on how they worked together. “They had met challenges, but gave their best in the competition,” she said. There were three days of competition, therefore, the competing countries had 12 games each. Aaron stressed that the robotics team could do better if there was a national competition introduced to allow schools to participate and be more flexible when attending the global competition. “However, the schools will have to purchase their own kits, which is quite expensive,” she said. “It is a worldwide competition which helps students with problem-solving skills. This competition has helped some of our students who are currently at university taking engineering courses.” The school usually sends a team every year to compete in an educational programme which focuses on giving Papua New Guinean students an opportunity on the world stage. Aaron acknowledged the First Global, school board, Lae MP John Rosso, Wantok Auto Parts and BluePac Trading for their support for the team to take part. She said this competition will boost their confidence, knowledge and a experience to share with peers. The students are: Jastina Grochau (18), Delewai Pakop (17), Bonaventure Boaging (16) and Carol Bopi (17). The school has taken part in previous competitions in 2018 (Mexico), 2019 (Dubai), 2022 (Geneva), 2023 (Singapore), 2024 (Athens, Greece) and 2025 (Panama City). This also gave students exposure to what other countries were doing in this field, and also to prepare students to meet the expectations of the stem (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) education. Meanwhile, the participating students acknowledged the competition and urged the establishment of a national robotic competition.

Title: Capacity building is key for national aspiration, says Powi
Content: IMPROVING the capacity of government services and functions in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville is crucial in its pursuit of independence, Southern Highlands Governor William Powi says. Powi, a member of the Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville Matters, said capacity building was an issue that needed to be addressed during this transition period for Bougainville. He said many provinces also struggle with capacity building even after 50 years of PNG’s independence.  “Capacity building is a long-term effort. “This must be addressed before the ratification of the referendum results by Parliament,” he said. “We must ensure that there is a proper transfer of powers to Bougainville for them to manage their affairs. “This transfer of powers is one of the key pillars of the Bougainville Peace Agreement that has yet to be fully implemented. “This is a serious issue for both governments to consider. “The transfer of powers and functions should be in the region by now in preparation for this transition to take place and for them to build their capacity.” Powi, also the former chairman of the Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on the Bougainville Peace Agreement, said their visit to the region in 2019 revealed a lack of capacity of the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG). “During our tour of Bougainville in 2019, we realised that there was a lack of capacity in a lot of the levels of government,” he said. “It was evident in the different aspects of the government such as human resource, procurement, revenue-generation and project implementation. “Once the capacity of the government is improved, there will be better services and functions provided for the people of Bougainville.” Former education secretary of Bougainville Joel Nava shared a similar view, as many key functions outlined in Part 14 of the Constitution were not granted to the ABG to administer.

Title: MPs urged to understand Bougainville before deciding
Content: MEMBERS of Parliament (MP) have been urged to understand the history of Bougainville before making a decision during ratification of the 2019 referendum results. Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville Matters chairman and Rabaul MP Dr Allan Marat said the onus was on all MPs as the final decision-making authority on the referendum results. He urged MPs to also understand the provisions and details of the Melanesian Agreement and others that had led to the current stage of Bougainville’s path toward independence. He said these were some of the provisions that were important in the agreement between the Government and the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG): Marat said that Part 14 of the Constitution was also important to note as it provided the foundation for Bougainville Peace Agreement and other subsequent agreements which provide a clear pathway forward. “Some of us know the affairs of Bougainville all too well, but some do not,” he said. “All MPs have a responsibility to understand the importance of the decision they will soon make. “We, the committee, will present to Parliament our report of these regional consultations to help us vote on the referendum results.” He said the referendum results would be brought to Parliament by way of a sessional order to be recommended by the Speakers of Parliament and the Bougainville House of Representatives.

Title: Peace central to referendum result, Government decision: Temu
Content: ABAU MP Sir Puka Temu says peace must always be maintained with the people of Bougainville, regardless of the outcome of Parliament’s decision on the 2019 referendum results. Sir Puka, a member of the Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville Matters, said the decision of the 11th Parliament would not end PNG-Bougainville relations. He said if Parliament agreed on the referendum results, then there would be a process to follow, if it did not, then a peaceful consensus had to be reached on what to do next. “If Parliament decides to ratify the referendum result in favour of independence, we must be able to manage this process over an agreed period of time,” he said. “We must be able to identify issues and determine strategies within the timeframe that can be delivered. “We much also consider the need for a new agreement towards full political and economic independence. “On the other hand, if Parliament does not ratify the referendum result in favour of independence, how can both sides manage this through peaceful means? “What are the options? “Parliament must clearly articulate the reasons for not ratifying the referendum result and articulate the way forward to avoid further conflict between Bougainvilleans and the Government. “We must be aware of the preventative measures that should be considered before Parliament is asked to make the final decision.” Sir Puka said continued dialogue between the Government and the Autonomous Bougainville Government was important in preparation for the outcome of Parliament’s decision on the referendum results. “This is a national conversation that must be held. “There must be a way to continue dialogue while maintaining peace going forward,” he said. Joseph Mona, former Lule member in the fourth Bougainville House of Representatives, agreed that peace had to be maintained given the violent history on Bougainville. “We have come a long way in our journey to independence and advocate for peace at all times,” he said.

Title: Candidates question credibility of LLG counting process
Content: CANDIDATES contesting the Madang town mayor’s seat have expressed concerns over the credibility of the counting process. This came after local police arrested a presiding officer this week while in possession of unused ballot papers in the counting venue at Tusbab Provincial Secondary School. Police confirmed the arrest and identified him as a 38-year-old teacher from Enga. A candidate, Bonny Solomon, said the candidates don’t have any differences among themselves, but are concerned about the process and the way the election officials are carrying out the counting which started on Saturday. “We have seen many discrepancies and irregularities since counting commenced Saturday at ward one,” he said. “How did the unused ballot papers make their way into the counting venue and in the possession of a presiding officer?” He said the law states that after polling, all unused ballot papers will be returned along with the ballot boxes and locked up for counting. The candidates who are contesting under the Madang Urban Local Level Government (MULLG) Elections have now asked election officials to suspend counting, they claimed this was unlawfully conducted by an Electoral Commission worker. The candidates are seeking legal advice from lawyers to address the matter and whether to have it declared as a failed election. Meanwhile, Madang police commander Supt Robert Baim said despite lack of resources, they have ensured a peaceful election with several LLGs making declarations.

Title: 14 councillors declared unopposed in Imbonggu
Content: FOURTEEN councillors have been declared unopposed for Southern Highlands’ Imbonggu local level government (LLG). The declarations were made for the 14 who contested the 14 new wards. Imbonggu assistant returning officer (ARO) Bruce Kamuge said the declarations were made at Walume on Tuesday after polling ended last week. Kamuge said he was happy for the rare outcome adding that such a number were never allowed unchallenged in the past. “However, the councillors declared unopposed denoted a new beginning for Imbonggu,” he said. He said the government had created 541 new council wards in the country, Imbonggu received 15. “Out of 15 wards, one was issued to Sumia 4 in Lower Mendi LLG, and 14 were given to Imbonggu, adding the tally to 33 wards,” he said. “Since the wards were newly-introduced, people did not want to contest against the councillors representing these new wards but come next election they will vie for it. “We never witnessed such a big number of councillors going unopposed and what had transpired for this election is history in the making.” In addition to that, the Imbonggu district works project officer, Nick Paka, assisting the ARO, said that election process was delayed due to minor disruptions but eventually they resolved it using amicable solutions.

Title: PM: PNG, Brazil carry burden of climate crisis
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has told Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva that forest and ocean nations like Papua New Guinea and Brazil “carry the burden of the world’s climate crisis”,” even though their carbon footprints are minimal. Speaking during a historic bilateral meeting on the margins of COP30 in Belém, Marape said Papua New Guinea’s presence at the summit was to reinforce solidarity with Brazil and other developing countries demanding fairness and justice in global climate action. “Excellency, I want to thank you sincerely for your warm welcome and hospitality since I arrived in your country,” Marape said. “Papua New Guinea has just celebrated 50 years of democracy since our independence from Australia in 1975. “Although we are on opposite sides of the world — you in South America and us in the Pacific — we have many things in common.” He said both countries were natural allies because of their vast forests, rich biodiversity, and shared experiences as developing democracies advocating for climate justice. “As a forest nation and an ocean nation, our carbon footprint is minimal, yet we are the victims of climate change,” he said. “Our forests and oceans carry the weight of the world’s excess carbon, but the benefits have not flowed equitably to our people.” Marape praised President Lula’s leadership on the global stage and his advocacy for climate justice and reform of the global financial system, which he said continues to favour industrialised nations in the north. “Mr President, I have followed you closely since your election and I commend your strong voice on issues that affect the Global South — on climate change, on global inequality, and on financial systems that benefit the rich and disadvantage developing countries,” he said. He said Brazil’s decision to host COP30 in the Amazon was “deeply spiritual and meaningful,” calling for discussions to focus not only on emissions but also on protecting the lungs and lifeblood of the planet — forests and oceans. “The conversation on climate change is wasted if we don’t talk about saving forests, saving oceans, and preserving biodiversity,” Marape said. “Forest nations are keeping the planet alive. We must be recognised and fairly compensated for that.” Marape said both Papua New Guinea and Brazil must continue pushing for justice and equity in global climate and trade negotiations, including greater recognition for the environmental services provided by forest nations. “The big carbon-emitting nations have not transitioned away from fossil fuels. Coal is still being used heavily in major economies,” he said. “Forest nations are doing their part, but the rewards and recognition have not come.” He reaffirmed PNG’s support for implementing Article 5.2 and Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement, ensuring that carbon markets are transparent and that forest and ocean nations receive their fair share of climate finance. “Papua New Guinea stands with Brazil and the forest economies of the world to ensure that climate justice becomes real,” Marape said. “It must not just be a slogan — it must be lived reality for our people.” Marape recalled that as a student in 1992, he followed Brazil’s hosting of the first Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, saying it was meaningful to now return as Prime Minister to continue the work that began then. “It is deeply meaningful to be here where it all began, continuing the same message: let us save our forests, protect our oceans, and pass on a healthier world to our children,” he said.

Title: Morobe PHA extends polio campaign
Content: ROUND two of the polio campaign period has been extended until next Friday due to delays to the start this month, says public health director in Lae. Kelly Mesere, Morobe PHA public health director, said that it is a no-cost extension. “With the non-cost extension of two weeks it means that we will not be using funding from our donor partners, instead it is strictly from our national government,” he said yesterday. “With Lae district, we have already reached over 100 per cent of our immunisation coverage and this week we have started the mop-up exercise. “Almost 50 per cent of children aged 10 years and below are vaccinated by the fractional dose of Inactivated polio vaccine or fIPV and 53 per cent received novel oral polio vaccines or nOPV in the province. “The provincial coverage for Morobe round two polio campaign stands at 53 per cent, with Lae district leading with 76 per cent coverage.” Mesere said only four health facilities in Lae are continuing polio campaigns while the rest are carrying out mop-up activities. He said the mop-up exercise is used where teams were sent into communities such as schools to provide vaccination for those children from 10 years and below who had missed the campaign. “The initial 15 days set for round-two campaign, which is 13 days for implementation and two days for mop-up activities in the country. “For Lae district, we have gone past the 15 days and are into our mop-up activities but with the non-cost extension now in place. “We are using this period to do more mop-up activities.” He said other districts apart from Lae are continuing on with the round-two polio vaccination campaigns. Children aged 10 years and below who have missed the campaign are advised to visit a nearest public health facility and get vaccinated during the extension period until Nov 14.

Title: Sir Bob completes visit to Tonga
Content: GOVERNOR-GENERAL Sir Bob Dadae has ended his visit to Tonga, attending celebrations marking the country’s sesquicentennial (150th year) celebrations of the Act of the Constitution of Tonga. Sir Bob and his wife Lady Emeline had an audience with King Tupou VI (sixth) and Queen Nanasipau’u during which Sir Bob acknowledged the close historical ties between Papua New Guinea and Tonga established when the early Tongan missionaries brought Christianity to PNG more than a century ago. “In celebrating Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary this year, as a nation we acknowledge and are indeed grateful to the immense contributions of the early Tongan missionaries who contributed to our development in training teachers, nurses, missionaries, built schools and taught our people to be industrious,” Sir Bob said. “They made huge sacrifices, many died due to tropical diseases such as malaria. “Many Tongan residents in PNG are descendants of the early missionaries, fostering the people-to-people relations between our countries.” He conveyed to the King, PNG’s appreciation to Crown Prince Tupouto’a Ulukalala for attending the recent 50th Independence anniversary on Sept 16 in Port Moresby. Sir Bob also acknowledged and expressed his appreciation for “the important roles and contributions His Majesty’s Armed Forces played in the peaceful resolution of the Bougainville Crisis”. He pledged Papua New Guinea’s commitment for closer collaboration on issues of mutual interests such as climate change, sustainable development, management of the Pacific Ocean and its resources and combating illegal fishing. Earlier this week, Sir Bob and Lady Emeline attended a ground-breaking ceremony for the construction of a new Legislative Assembly building at ‘Talangaholo’, Royal Estate, Tufumahina. Sir Bob and Governor General of New Zealand, Dame Cindy Kiro participated in the ground-breaking ceremony with King Tupou VI. The former Parliament Chamber used for the Legislative Assembly for 126 years, was destroyed by tropical Cyclone Gita in 2018. Speaking at the ground-breaking ceremony, King Tupou VI said the site of the new Parliament building held historical significance in the reunification of Tonga and the “laws promulgated in the Va’vau Code (by King Tupou 1) to apply nationally” and set the stage for the 1875 Constitution of Tonga. “It was from (a) trip to Sydney in 1863 that (King) Tupou 1 saw landless indigenous people that influenced him to seek protection from this ever happening to Tongans in their own country,” he said. “He sought protection for Tongans being landless in their own land. “That protection, he believed, came partly from the Constitution and laws passed for the smooth running of a responsible parliament that is responsive to the needs of the Tongan people.” Sir Bob and Lady Emeline also attended a Remembrance Service programme during which Sir Bob took part in a wreath-laying ceremony alongside King Tupou VI in honour of former Sovereigns of Tonga, including King Tupou 1. Sir Bob was invited by the government of the Kingdom of Tonga to attend a week-long event of activities marking 150 years of the enactment of Tonga’s Constitution on Nov 4, 1875, which established Tonga as a constitutional monarchy. The governor-general returns next week.

Title: Minister looking to establish new body for health workers
Content: A HEALTH Service Commission will be created to register all health works in the country, if minister responsible, Elias Kapavore has his way. Kapavore told a workshop in Port Moresby yesterday: “My aim now is to establish a Health Service Commission – like the Teaching Service Commission, where all health workers, upon graduation, are directly deployed to all Provincial Health Authorities in the country rather than having to wait for DPM (Department of Personnel Management) to give approvals. “The Government is committed to supporting Health. It’s now up to us to create the agenda and come up with the priorities with specifications and seek support. “Everyone coming out of the institutions must be posted to a position that is waiting for them. No more advertisement, no more going to DPM.” At the same time Kapavore directed his department to move to digital registration of health workers in the country by next June. The minister told a workshop that digital registration of all cadres of health workers is long overdue and a matter of critical concern. “We can’t continue the manual registration of health workers,” he said. Kapavore was speaking at a Port Moresby workshop, titled “Strengthening Health Workforce Program: Nursing Regulation and Accreditation.” He urged the medical and nursing registration divisions within Health Department to reorganize their offices and give prominence to digital registration. “Manual registration of health workers must cease immediately and establish efficient HR (human resource) data that must reflect the changing digital age,” Kapavore said. Kapavore reiterated that the PNG University of Medicine and Health Sciences Bill recently passed in Parliament is aimed at increasing enrolment to meet the health workforce gap. “This arrangement will complement the recently approved Health Services Commission arrangement,” he stated. “These are key revolutionary and milestone strategies that must now pave the way and set the scene for a modernised health sector workforce in PNG for the next fifty years. Kapavore acknowledged development partners including the Australian Government, World Health Organisation and others that continue to provide capacity building support for the country’s health workforce.

Title: Digitally restored 1982’s Tukana premiers at Paradise, Arc cinemas
Content: THE digitally restoredTukana–Husat I Asua(1982) premiered at the Paradise Cinemas at the Vision City Mega mall in Port Moresby on Tuesday. The film, which was supported by the Australian High Commission premiered simultaneously with its screening at the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia (NFSA)’s Arc Cinema in Canberra. According to the Australian High Commission,Tukanawas digitally restored by the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia in partnership with Spectrum Films and gifted to Papua New Guinea’s National Film Institute to commemorate 50 years of Papua New Guinea’s Independence. The restoration builds on a four-year co-design project with the Institute, assisting them to better preserve and access their films, with funding from the Australian Government’s International Cultural Diplomacy and Arts Fund. This initiative is a demonstration of Papua New Guinean and Australian cultural sector collaboration. The screening event was supported through the Australian High Commission’s Yumi Stap Wantaim campaign that celebrates 50 years of Papua New Guinea’s independence and the deep and enduring ties between our two countries. Police Minister and acting Minister for Information and Communication Technology Minister Peter Tsiamalili Junior said: “It doesn’t matter how old you get, this movie [Tukana] pulls family together and still, the anchor of the story still resonates today. “I’m proud that I’m able to come here and see what’s been done with the collaboration between Australia and PNG, particularly in the film industry, and this will continue to inspire the new industry in our country, and 50 years is a time for us to really elevate and excel in this industry.” NFI’s Film Archivist Zoe Baru said: “The collaboration with the NFSA provided the practical support to enable the NFI to preserve and digitise our films, the collection is now accessible to us and we look forward to sharing with the PNG public for generations to come.” Deputy chief executive officer of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia, Jacqui Uhlmann said: “As we did the work, we started to understand just how important the film was and with the 50th anniversary of independence coming up we thought there is no better birthday present than a properly restored version of that film. “We did it through our NFSA Restores programme. That’s where we do quite extensive technical restoration of a film which includes a digital clean-up, a rework of the audio and work on the colour.”

Title: Publish 2025 spending reports: MP
Content: CHUAVE MP James Nomane is calling on the government to stop using the allocation service improvement funds to deflect how the government budget is being spent. Nomane said the people of PNG demand total accountability for the K28,357 billion 2025 budget. “No more deflection using district (DSIP) and provincial service improvement programme (PSIP),” he said. “No more excuses and just publish the expenditure reports.” Nomane said the reports should show how all the money allocated under various heads was spent, who or what agency got what and how much. “According to a chart on the government budget, PSIP and DSIP portions of the budget constitute only 5.2 per cent, which is equivalent to K1.5 billion and this is almost a small fraction of the total Government budget. “The graph shows, the government has a bloated recurrent budget of K22 billion that includes DSIP and PSIP at K1.5 billion, education at K4.4 billion, health at K2.0 billion, law and justice at K2.3billion, utilities at K1.4 billion, administration at K5.6 billion, debt servicing at K3.5 billion and others at K0.7 billion. “Under the capital investment budget; transport has K2.0 billion and provinces have K4.4 billion which are meant to fund roads, bridges, wharves, and airports and capital grants to sub-national programmes. “The Implementation and Rural Development (Dird) is mandated to oversee the function of transparency and checks on site projects in all provinces.” “However, over the years since 2018, lack of resources especially funding has hindered progress causing a backlog of reports to the Dird. “Reports show 59 districts and provinces have not acquitted with most of the reason being lack of funding, logistics, newly formed districts and other administration issues. “This figure is most likely to be carried over to 2026, adding to a backlog of acquittals from 2018 yet to reach Dird. “Prime Minister James Marape admitted that K56.0 billion in six years produced “no results.” “The national debt level stands at K65 billion.”

Title: PNGDF takes part in ‘Exercise Paradise 2025’
Content: Patrol boats from the Papua New Guinea Defence Force and Australian Defence Force have completed joint navy surveillance and constabulary operations as part of Exercise Paradise 2025. Held between Oct 21-24 in PNG, the exercise involved PNGDF’s guardian-class patrol boatHMPNGS Ted Diroand ADF’sHMAS Albany. During the exercise, the boats conducted a range of evolutions including coordinated patrols and combined maritime surveillance operations, safety of life at sea, search and rescue exercises, and seamanship and mariner skills training. Australia’s Chief of Navy Vice Admiral Mark Hammond, said Exercise Paradise was part of a wide partnership with Papua New Guinea, Australia’s largest defence cooperation program. “Bilateral defence training like exercise paradise strengthens our strategic partnership with Papua New Guinea and enhances our shared maritime security,” Hammond said. “It builds interoperability and enhances our shared response to maritime challenges in the region, including illegal fishing and transnational crime. “We are pleased to join our closest neighbour for this important regular training opportunity and thankHMPNGS Ted Dirofor the opportunity to work together.” Commanding OfficerHMAS AlbanyLieutenant Commander Phil Wager said the exercise participants responded to realistic scenarios. “We always enjoy training alongside our PNG friends in critical areas such as border security, fisheries protection, illegal drug interdiction and search and rescue,” he said. “Exercise paradise is a regular navy-to-navy exercise we have with PNG and is a great opportunity to build interoperability and enhance our shared vision of a free and open Pacific.” HMPNGS Ted Dirowas handed over to the PNGDF in 2021 and is one of four guardian-class patrol boats delivered to PNG under Australia’s pacific maritime security programme. Future joint exercises, like Exercise Paradise 2026, are an opportunity to strengthen and expand defence cooperation.

Title: Busu Secondary open new gym
Content: MOROBE’s Busu Secondary School opened a K61,000 fully-equipped gym yesterday, which will be used for academic and personal purposes. Principal George Noble highlighted that the building would be used by students, staff, board members, support staff and the community. “The revenue generated from this building will be used for another Student Representative Council (SRC) project next year,” Noble said. He added that the building was an old girls’ ablution block, which had not been used for some years, and the SRC had turned that old building into a gymnasium. “This is a major SRC project, after the construction of the school market,” Noble said. “The next SRC project we are looking at is the 3D cinema for the students, which is expected to be constructed next year.” The K61,000 funding was used to complete the building and buy gym equipment. Noble thanked former board chairman Peter Kesu for being a visionary, and leading the school to achieve some of its goals, including the building of the gym. He elaborated that the building will be used by grade nine students during the Personal Development class under the topic “health and fitness”. He said the Grade Nine students would bring their practical lessons into the gymnasium. “Also, teachers usually work under pressure every day, which also affects their blood pressure level, can also use the gym to keep fit and healthy,” he said. The gym space can hold a maximum of 15 persons at any one time. The school will be working in collaboration with the Sports Foundation, where three of their teachers would go for training so they could look after the facility. Noble acknowledged the Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP, John Rosso, as well as the parents, students and others for their contributions towards building the gym. Provincial education adviser Keith Tangui said the innovation was a way forward for all schools to excel in education and life.

Title: Fire claims 6 family members
Content: A FAMILY of six perished when their home went up in flames around 2am yesterday at Kingfisher Street, Gordon in the National Capital District. No comments could be obtained from the Port Moresby metropolitan police. But Gerehu fire station acting superintendent Johnson Charles said the three adults and three children were from Southern Highlands. “Firefighters were on the ground to assess the situation and help to stop it. “The six are the father, his mother in law, sister in law and three children under age six,” he said. “We received multiple calls around 2am yesterday on our toll free number. The first one was at 2.47am. Our team at Waigani was sent to the fire scene.” Charles said when they arrived, the fire had engulfed the whole rental property. He said: “The property had a structure with a trade store underneath one of the buildings in front. It also had rooms on top. The second structure was converted to rental rooms within the area.” He said the family lived on the ground floor of the second building behind the store. Charles added that investigation was underway to establish the cause of the fire. Meanwhile, residents in the city are urge to report any fires quickly to the fire stations.

Title: Pirates rob passengers, sink  boat off Busu River delta
Content: A PRIME suspect to a sea piracy incident at the Busu River delta on Tuesday was shot and hospitalised while seven others are still on the run, says Morobe police commander Chief Superintendent Samson Siguyaru. Siguyaru said that during the attack between 8am and 8.30am, the eight suspects held up a passenger boat that was travelling from Lae to Siassi and took K20,000 meant for business transactions on SIassi Island. “The boat which  was carrying a woman, her baby and seven other passengers was held up by the pirates (who were) armed with four home-made guns and four bush knives. The suspects fired shots at the boat injuring the skipper, before attacking the passengers,” Chief Supt Siguyaru said. He said when the suspects boarded the boat, they assaulted three other men (passengers) and robbed them. “After the robbery, the sea pirates rammed the boat which caused it to sink off the Busu River delta. The suspects fled the scene while the boat and the passengers were left floating in open sea.” The incident was reported by by-standers which alerted the Lae Water police personnel who rescued the eight passengers. Morobe Water police then mounted activities at Voco Point from 7pm to 10pm on Tuesday night. “At around 10.20pm, the prime suspect was spotted by member of the Morobe Water police trying to return the stolen boat. He was approached by police personnel. He tried to avoid arrest but was shot on his right leg and was admitted at the Angau hospital” Siguyaru said police recovered a waist bag that was thrown into the sea at Voco Point allegedly by the suspect that contained K700 which police believe was part of the K20,000 that was stolen. Investigation are continuing while police are advising all boat operators, travelers and coastal communities to take precautions while travelling especially between Lae, Finschhafen, Wasu and Siassi Islands. The are advising the public to avoid carrying large sums of money or valuable items without proper security assessments, and to travel in groups and inform local police prior to departure. They should report immediately any suspicious boats drifting on the way.

Title: Partnership boosts healthcare in SHP
Content: IN the rugged mountain ranges of Kagua-Erave district in Southern Highlands, the sound of helicopter blades brings hope, relief and lifesaving care. Children in Tiri village shout “chopa kam, chopa kam”  as they race barefoot to the grassy clearing that serves as a landing pad. For locals such as Selina Temo, the helicopter’s arrival is a symbol of connection. “The chopper coming means someone cares enough to reach us.” This quarterly medical patrol to hard-to-reach areas is made possible through a partnership between the Santos Foundation and the Southern Highlands Provincial Health Authority. SHPHA’s expanded programme on immunisation manager Alphonse Sambai said: “Reaching these remote communities is a powerful reminder of the barriers many still face. “The first airlift into areas unaware that support is coming is deeply moving and symbolic of the transformative impact and consistency of this partnership.” Jodie Hatherly, chief executive officer of the Santos Foundation said: “We are dedicated to creating opportunities and empowering communities where Santos operates. “Supporting health patrols in remote areas is one way we ensure our partnerships deliver real impact where it’s needed most.” It delivers healthcare to communities such as Tiri, Waposale, Mt Tawa, and Sopose, where the nearest health centre can be a week’s walk away. Health workers Timon Arufi, Sister Lilian Yamo, and Jethro Janget are flown in to provide care. From treating malaria and tuberculosis to administering vaccinations, antenatal care, and family planning, these patrols offer more than medicine, they bring dignity and connection. Janget, who became a health worker in 2019 after losing his mother, says: “Through these patrols, I help deliver essential care to remote communities, ensuring people receive treatment no matter where they live.” He recalls villagers walking five to six hours to reach patrol sites, mothers carrying babies through mountains, rivers, and swamps. While Jethro is dropped off at Tiri, the helicopter returns to Santos Moro Camp, where a dedicated Santos team ensures the safe transport of another dozen health workers and medical supplies to Mt Tawa and Sopose. Hundreds of people will be served during this patrol cycle. Sister Lilian Yamo, TB Coordinator at Ialibu District Hospital, recalls a defining moment in Waposale. “In 2024, we discovered TB in the village,” Yamo said. “Locals had many myths to explain the symptoms, but with Santos’ support, we confirmed a TB outbreak, treated over 300 patients, and raised awareness. “Today, it’s contained,” she said. Tiri ward councilor Jim Aiyepe said: “To access proper healthcare, we must walk a full day. There are threats – snakes, wild animals, bad weather. “We’ve lost family members along the way.” The patrols enable 1,087 children under five to receive vaccinations. The Santos Foundation supports the SHPHA to deliver 5,018 outreach clinics and reached 69 health facilities in Southern Highlands, Gulf, and Hela where Santos operates.

Title: Increased demand, theft, leaks reasons for water woes
Content: GROWING population, water theft, leaks and bursts, deteriorating infrastructure, and outstanding debts of government agencies are the main causes of bulk water supply shortages in the country, says Water PNG chief executive officer James Young yesterday. Young highlighted that much of the outstanding bills held in Finance Department needed to be released to fix and maintain issues with water supply. The top 10 of these departments and agencies are Police, Defence, Correctional Services, hospitals, University of Papua New Guinea, Sports Commission, Works, Education, Agriculture and Livestock, and University of Natural Resources and Environment. “The current outstanding debt by government agencies, to be paid by the Department of Finance, is problematic as these funds should be immediately re-invested in infrastructure,” Young said. “Water PNG will continue to engage with the Department of Finance to recover these substantial outstanding debts, as well as those from large private sector debtors. “As it currently stands, there a very serious risk of imminent water network shutdown if contractors, staff and suppliers cannot be paid,” he said. He said that water interruptions were due to basic supply and demand, as well as many of the systems had been built in the 1960s and 1970s. This was made worse by substantial water theft through illegal connections to businesses and homes. According to reports in 2022, Water PNG losses in revenue for Water theft alone is around K50 million. “Preventative maintenance has been stepped up to try and stay ahead of busts and leaks, and we have rapid response teams that move quickly to rectify faults when they occur,” Young said. “At the same time we use any investment we are able to obtain to upgrade water networks. “In dealing with water theft, our investigators are detecting illegal connections in Port Moresby, Mt Hagen and other areas. “When these are found, the connection is cut off, bills with penalties are issued that have to be paid before reconnection, and we refer serious offenders to police for criminal prosecution.” Young said that reforms were underway to make it fairer and easier for customers to pay for their water including the introduction of smart meters. “Customers in homes and businesses can also help by being water-wise, and mindful of water wastage. “Every litre saved stays in the network and can be used by others, it also saves on customer water bills,” he said.

Title: Polling underway in WNB
Content: POLLING for the 2025 local level government (LLG) elections in West New Britain has progressed through most wards and LLGs as voters continue to cast their ballots this week. Polling ends on Saturday and the counting of votes is expected to start soon after. Talasea LLG assistant returning officer Fred Waluka said a  mop-up exercise would be conducted for those who were notable to vote during the one-day polling period in certain areas last week. “In wards five, six, seven and eight of the LLG, we have successfully completed the 16 polling venues,” he said. “However, we need to go back again to do a mop-up exercises as some places were short of ballot papers so polling was suspended. “We have rescheduled for this so we will go back to finish the polling before the week ends. “Overall, our polling teams in the Talasea LLG have reported that people turned up in numbers to cast their ballots and there was not much trouble. “Our polling teams were able to help many of the voters cast their ballots last week when polling started.” In Kandrian-Gloucester, Kaliai-Kove assistant returning officer Bernard Penga said polling had progressed peacefully. “Despite no police presence for the elections here, security was not an issue as the five polling teams are still conducting polling according to their respective schedules,” he said. “Polling for Kaliai-Kove is progressing well and is expected to be completed soon.”

Title: Chimbu delivers peaceful LLG polling, says official
Content: CHIMBU’s 20 local level governments (LLGs) with 317 wards in the six districts have finished polling and counting commenced yesterday at the designated centres, the election boss said. Election manager, Tom Sine, said the last of the ballot boxes from Karamui LLG were brought in on Tuesday after polling was concluded last weekend. Sine said four wards in the province have only one candidate each, and those candidates were announced as elected councillors by the assistant returning officers (AROs). With the boxes kept at the Kundiawa police station, Sine urged all stakeholders to enforce security of the counting process till Nov 11 when counting is expected to end. Election manager said the province concluded the polling peacefully and the same is expected of during the count. Provincial police commander, Superintendent Mazuc Rubian, could not be reached for comment on security measures. He said funding was a major obstacle faced but with support from the provincial government which gave K200,000 and the district development authorities of Gumine with K100,000, Chuave and Sinasina-Yongomugl with K50,000 each, the election was delivered without too much hassle. He said the air-linked Karamui LLG, contributed to the extended timeline as it required careful coordination of the movement and return of the ballot papers. Sine said all the districts finished their polling by observing and upholding the election integrity. He then thanked the efforts of the AROs with their teams, security personnel, and community leaders for taking ownership of the election despite the challenges. “Despite a few challenges, electoral teams took control and ensured polling was completed with minimal inconvenience to the voters,” he said.

Title: Villagers receive food supplies
Content: THREE villages affected by recent floods in Kandep, Enga, have received food supplies from Caritas PNG. Caritas Enga coordinator Jonathan Sope Anro said the affected people were living in difficult conditions and needed urgent help. “Families lost their properties and crops and many people are now homeless and struggling to find food,” he said. He said the disaster had caused great suffering in the affected communities. Mid last month, heavy rainfall in the region caused severe flooding that affected several villages in Kandep, destroyed homes, food gardens and damaged road links and other infrastructure. Caritas PNG received support its PNG national office in Port Moresby, and Caritas Enga facilitated food supplies to the flood victims, and had brought in clothes, cartons of food, tinned fish and other essential items. Community leader William Toke expressed deep gratitude to the team on behalf of the victims. “The flood victims are still mourning their losses with all their homes, belongings and gardens destroyed. “They are asking the Government and other bodies to provide more help and support during this time of distress,” he said. He said the communities needed more help at this time to maintain them and rebuild after the floods.

Title: Cop30 participation shows PNG’s role to address climate change
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s participation at the 30th Conference of the Parties (Cop) in Brazil next week highlights the country’s role in the global movement to address climate change, says Prime Minister James Marape. Before leaving for Cop30 on Tuesday, Marape said: “PNG is also uniquely qualified to advocate on the impact of climate change. “Our Mortlock and Carteret islanders were the first in our country to relocate due to sea level rise, soil salination and water contamination.” Marape said that PNG’s presence at Cop30, which is the main global forum under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change where world leaders negotiate and implement international climate agreements, was important as a forest nation. “This is an extraordinary Cop for Papua New Guinea and Brazil,” he said. “Brazil, the biggest forest nation, is hosting it. So, a large forest nation is hosting the conference for the first time. “This aligns with Article 5 and Article 6 of the Paris Agreement, which focuses on forests and forest resource management. We will have PNG’s say at Cop30. “We are saving our forests, which are among the world’s major carbon sinks, so industrialised countries with large carbon footprints must compensate us accordingly.” Marape said that PNG qualified for both mitigation and adaptation discussions under global climate frameworks and would continue to advocate for maintaining life on islands wherever possible. He also emphasised that climate change discussions were incomplete without acknowledging forest resource management and sustainable ocean governance. “We are renowned for our biodiversity while our oceans and forests hold tremendous ecological value. “The world has invited us into high-level global discussions on this matter. Fossil fuel use has not been seriously addressed, and despite all the talk, the world still depends heavily on fossil fuels. “Transition energy options have not been fully used,” Marape said.

Title: One step closer to hosting Apec ’33
Content: Prime Minister James Marape has announced this week that Papua New Guinea’s ‘bid’ to host the Asia-Pacific Economic (Apec) Leaders’ Summit again has been accepted by the Apec membership for the year 2033. Marape made the revelation as he commended his envoy to the 2025 Apec, Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso, for leading the PNG delegation and for expressing PNG’s interest to host the summit. “It was a good meeting for us. Our presence was evident. I want to announce to our country that the Apec secretariat has accepted our bid to host Apec 2033,” he said. Marape made the announcement at his departure press conference early this morning to Sydney enroute to Brazil for the United Nations climate summit, COP30. Apec meetings are hosted by a different member economy each year on a voluntary, rotational basis, with the selection process largely based on consensus among all 21 member economies. However, the selection for host is not a competitive public ‘bidding’ system in the traditional sense, but an internal co- ordination and agreement process involving voluntary offers, consensus decision and advance planning. The consensus for PNG as host in 2033 will make it the second time PNG will host the Apec Leaders’ Summit after 2018. Marape also revealed that PNG is posed to host the United Nations Oceans Conference – widely known as the “global oceans conference”– in 2030, as the country prepares to deposit its ratification at the UN next year to reserve up to 30 percent of its ocean spaces for conservation. “We are hosting an oceans economic ministers’ forum next year,” he said. “This is a precursor to 2030, where there is a high possibility that PNG will host the global oceans conference, similar to the one we attended in Nice, France last year. “We have put our hands up for it and France and many of our partner nations have offered us support.” “Hosting the global oceans conference is confirmation by the global community of PNG’s role.”

Title: Ex-servicemen call on government to pay outstanding entitlements
Content: A GROUP of former soldiers are appealing to the Government to honour its commitment and pay them what they say are unpaid entitlements in the form of the State component of 60 per cent and others in the form of pension under the Defence Force Retirement Benefits Fund managed by the Comrade Trustees Services Ltd (CTSL). They said the delays had caused a lot of misery and inconvenience for their families and some of them have waited since 2002. Apart from the entitlements, they are also appealing to the government to fix what they call are systemic failures within the Papua New Guinea Defence Force, the Comrade Trustees Services Limited and the Bank of Papua New Guinea that had denied a lot of members to miss out on benefits they are entitled to. Spokesperson of the group who call themselves Reorg Rehab, retired Corporal Rex Wararu, explained that in 2015, through a submission made by CTSL, the National Executive Council made a decision to make changes to the DFRBF from a defined benefit scheme to a dual system of accumulation and defined for those who were recruited before 2015. Under the defined benefits scheme, the government does not pay its component until a soldier is retrenched where they get a 60 per cent guaranteed pay out. Under the accumulation scheme, the employer (Government) portion was paid every fortnight. Wararu, who was retrenched in 2000 after 29 years in the force during the government’s downsising exercise, said he had been fighting for the State component of his entitlements since leaving the force. Another member ex-private Danny Sakail said he wanted the government to look into what he called systemic failures within the retirement fund: “We are not merely demanding our State share, we are demanding full restitution of credit-rated payments and interest unlawfully denied to us under this fund architecture in the last half a century.” CTSL management when contacted about the issue have denied that the fund owes the soldiers any entitlements and have called for the ex-servicemen to meet them if they have any queries. The Nationalunderstands that State owes millions of Kina in unfunded liabilities to the Defence Force Retirement Benefit Fund, managed by CTSL. The liability stems from the government’s obligation to pay the employer’s portion of contributions and accumulated interest for members. The delay in payment may have prevented some personnel who have reached retirement age.

Title: Paita wants Finschhafen split into two sub-districts
Content: FINSCHHAFEN MP and Mining Minister Renbo Paita announced last month that the district will be split into two sub-districts following the local level government elections. Paita told the people of Burum-Kuat LLG during the opening of major projects in health, education and bridge infrastructures at Ogeranang Station that since the district is huge and rugged, it will be appropriate to have two separate sub-districts. Paita said there be two separate chief executive officers at the district level – one for Yabem-Mape, Kote and Gagidu Urban LLGs, and another for Burum, Kuat and Hube LLGs. “It will be easier in terms of service deliveries and other aspects of developments in the district,” he said. While announcing this, Paita said the district development authority has also allocated K500,000 for designing other projects, including a technical school to provide trade skills for students. Paita, while thanking public servants in remote areas of the district, acknowledged the efforts of teachers and health workers in ensuring that people in these locations receive essential services. Meanwhile, Paita also officiated at the opening of Mandang Memorial High School at Ogeranang Station. He announced the DDA will give K1 million to the high school by next year to assist the it in its areas of need.

Title: PM dares Opposition to block 2026 budget
Content: Prime Minister James Marape has dared the Opposition to block the budget in two weeks, if it has the numbers. Before leaving for Cop30 in Brazil, Marape said the “real test is in two weeks’ time whether the Opposition can block the Budget”. He said: “If they can’t, then they should eat humble pie, respect the people’s mandate and prepare for 2027.” He urged Papua New Guineans to remain calm and allow Parliament to function normally. Marape’s statement comes amid heightened political chatter over a possible vote of no-confidence, following failed attempts by the Opposition to demonstrate unity or numerical strength. He reaffirmed that the Government’s majority remains intact, noting that the: “Papua New Guinea’s democracy remains stable,” Marape said. “Our government is focused on governing — not politicking.” He then issued a strong challenge to the Opposition, led by Ialibu-Pangia MP Peter O’Neill, to demonstrate their numbers on the floor of Parliament rather than creating public confusion through social media and the press. “Many people don’t realise that every meeting of Parliament gives the Opposition an opportunity to prove they have the numbers,” Marape said. “If they truly had the numbers, they could have blocked government business last week — including when Parliament was adjourned, when bills were passed, or when key reports were tabled. But they did not.” Marape pointed to the passage of several major bills, including the Coffee Act and the Higher Education Act, as clear evidence that the government maintains a firm majority of over 96 MPs.

Title: Jail conditions queried by Wabag resident Judge Ellis
Content: RESIDENT judge of Wabag Graham Ellis has written to the Correctional Services (CS) Minister Joe Kuli, over the condition of Baisu Jail, the largest facility in the highlands region. The minister has been asked to provide answers for why urgent maintenance have not been done at the Baisu Correctional Facility in Western Highlands. It is understood Judge Ellis used his own initiative to take this course of action after finding out that the condition of the facility risks a mass breakout and further that the entire facility might be forced to close. Baisu houses prisoners from Eastern Highlands, Enga, Jiwaka, Hela, Southern Highlands and Western Highlands. An officer from Minister Kuli yesterday confirmed receipt of the correspondence from the judge. Minister Kuli has been given to 4pm Friday, Nov 14, to provide an adequate answer as to why budgeted repairs have not been made and when such work might commence.
