Acting Correctional Services (CS) commissioner Bernard Nepo explained at a media conference that the office did not receive an amount of K49 million for the upgrading of Baisu prison as was reported on social media. In 2023, some of its buildings including the security cell blocks, and the building where the prisoners’ rations are stored, have been condemned by the provincial health authority, as they deemed unfit for human habitation. Judge Ellis after concluding a trial in Baisu discovered these issues for himself, leading him to take the action he did. He is writing to Kuli so that the court may determine whether it was necessary to make further orders or declarations for the purposes of enforcement of Basic Rights under Section 57(3) of the Constitution. That particular provision and Sect 57(1) outlines the power the court exercises on its own merit to enforce the rights and freedoms of accused persons and person who have been sentenced to serve their time at the Baisu facility. In a letter published byThe Nationaldated Feb 28, 2024, a citizen raised his concerns for Baisu prison’s urgent renovation. The article stated that the facility (correctional institution), being the largest and oldest ever established in the Highlands region, caters for more than 1,000 convicts and prisoners at any one time and has not been maintained for more than a decade.

Title: Moresby police recover nine stolen outboard motors
Content: POLICE have arrested an employee of a major automotive company and recovered nine outboard engines from an island believed to have been stolen. Metropolitan Supt Warrick Simatab confirmed that police investigators recovered the nine outboard engines on Fishermen Island yesterday. Police believe that the offence was committed between October 2024 and August 2025 by the employee who allegedly sold the engines to the islanders. Simatab said that after the arrest of the suspect in September, police officers worked hard to locate the stolen items which included 40-horsepower and 15-horsepower engines. “I want to thank the police officers from Hohola and the Water Police unit who worked together to recover the outboard motors,” Simitab said. He thanked the community leaders who provided information on the whereabouts of the stolen items. Simitab said policing the community was a community effort.

Title: Congenital abnormalities make referral of twins difficult
Content: CONGENITAL abnormalities of the three-week-old conjoined twins make it impossible to make a referral, says Port Moresby General Hospital chief executive officer Dr. Paki Molumi. “We had to make all parties and the parents understand the complexity of the twin’s condition because they are sharing one kidney, a liver, have small lungs, one bladder, sharing intestines, a rectum, spinal issues being fused and one twin has a heart defect,” he said. “The hospital is giving them every care possible in the special care units but given the current situation, the chance of survival is slim.” The twins were received by the neonatal team following their medical evacuation from the Angau Memorial Hospital in Lae on Oct 15. They have been under the supervision of the neonatal and specialist teams. After extensive consultations, examinations and assessments by a multi-disciplinary clinical team, both infants were found to have complex congenital anomalies. Director Medical Services Dr. Kone Sobi said the team had conducted multiple medical consultations, including with pediatric surgeons and counterparts in Australia. “The underlying thing is that both twins have significant congenital anomalies and we feel that even with care and treatment in the highly specialized units, the chances of survival are low,” he said. “And based on that we feel that both twins will remain with us and we will continue to provide care as long as possible. That is basically our stand.” He said that they had discussed the situation with the family members and “it’s very difficult if you put yourself in those circumstances for family to come to grip with this scenario”. “There have been concerns of getting them to Australia, from a medical point of view, based on the conditions of the babies, it is not possible. “Where they go from here it’s anyone’s guess. But as long as we provide support to them in terms of feeding them, (it’s) one of the priorities guarding against infection.”

Title: Parents urged to monitor movements of children
Content: PARENTS and guardians should constantly monitor the movements and activities of their children, says Child and Family Services director Jerry Wap. “It is the role and responsibility of parents to ensure children under their care are well protected and kept safe at all times,” he said. It follows the discovery of the bodies of three children under the age of five in an abandoned vehicle at a 9-Mile settlement on Oct 26. The children aged two, three and four went missing on Oct 24. Their bodies were found two days later. Wap called on parents, guardians and care-givers to ensure children under their care are protected. “You must be extra cautious about the activities and movements of your children to prevent bad things from happening to them,” he said. “This is the third incident in the last two years where children died in a brutal manner and their corpses dumped like animals.” He said that on March 2, two cousins from Enga aged two and five went missing in Gereka. Their bodies were found in an abandoned vehicle on May 2. “A similar incident on Dec 15 last year saw a five-year-old boy from Nipa in Southern Highlands went missing. His body was found in a drain at Vadavada after three days. “These homicide cases involving children display a distinct pattern, and it could be perpetrated by an individual or group of people targeting neglected and vulnerable children,” he said.

Title: Nature Park opens new orchid garden to showcase PNG’s unique flora
Content: THE Port Moresby Nature Park has a new orchid garden, showcasing some of Papua New Guinea’s unique species of flora and rich biodiversity. Conservation manager Francis Gundu provided an hour-long tour for park members and their children through the newly-constructed green space during the opening on Saturday. They were privileged to receive first-hand information about the history associated with the orchid plants and cultural artefacts on display. The design of the garden reflects a celebration of PNG’s geography, divided into regional sections, each featuring unique displays. The Momase section shows orchid varieties unique to the area, complemented by carved totem poles that represent the artistic traditions of the Sepiks. Southern features regional orchids and cultural artefacts, including the famouslagatoi,Kevau Bada, fromRea Rea village. The Highlands section displays unique high-altitude orchids and associated cultural items. The New Guinea Islands presents its distinct collection of orchid plants and artefacts. Port Moresby Nature Park communications officer Franolyn Yuarufo said: “It is an exciting experience for them to learn first-hand information about the unique orchids from different parts of the country.” Santos is the major sponsor of the construction with support from Total Energies, Rotary International, Paga Hill Estate, Royal Papua Yacht Club, OM Holdings Ltd and the Government of Ireland International Development Programme.

Title: Country’s population growth rate ‘one of Pacific’s highest’
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s annual population growth rate of 2.6 per cent is one of the highest in the Pacific, according to acting National Statistician John Igitoi. “Papua New Guinea’s population growth is one of the fastest and highest growing in the Pacific region, determined mainly by births and deaths,” he said. “On average, each reproductive mother, from 17 to 49 years of age, bears one child after every three years. “Since the last official population count of 7.2 million in 2011, it is practically and statistically not possible in PNG to have a population of over 12 million people. “However, the final population count for 2024 is still very high and is capable of causing a lot of strain on government infrastructure and facilities, and has the potential to drain its resources if unchecked and uncontrolled. “The current population number still places us at the lower middle end of per capita income among the global economies.” Last year’s population census report by the National Statistical Office shows 10,185,363 people – 5,336,546 men and 4,848,817 women. Of that, 5,827,441 persons are over the age of 18. The report states that Southern (3.6 per cent) had the highest regional annual growth rate, followed by Momase (3 per cent), New Guinea Islands (2.3 per cent) and Highlands (1.9 per cent). The fastest growing provinces were the National Capital District, Western, Milne Bay, and Madang, each recording more than 3 per cent average annual growth rate since 2011. Meanwhile, Prime Minister James Marape said PNG’s demographic and economic history had shown that the country’s population has tripled since 1975, while economic growth has been stagnant. “The population has grown by 2.6 per cent annually, increasing by approximately 2.9 million persons in the past 13 years, underscoring the urgency of managing population growth in line with the nation’s economic strength.”

Title: Data could be used for political gain: Economist
Content: AN economist has warned that the national population data collected from last year’s census should be used only for planning, and not for any political purpose. Institute of National Affairs executive director Paul Barker said: “Politicians need to utilise the outcome of the census data, including for national and local planning and monitoring purposes, but should not be engaged or interfering in the process itself, as clearly the statistics must be immune from perceived manipulation or slant. “Politicians need to approve budget allocations for the conducting statistical collection and analysis, but, as with electoral processes, should be well removed from the operations and presentation of the outcomes. “Political input doesn’t lend the process credibility as they are seen to have a politically vested interest in the outcome. “Of course, there are some political advantages of having a lower population, in term of economic performance, per capita income and trends. “There can also be pressures to inflate the figure, as per constituencies and for allocations.” Barker argued that any population data collected from a census is crucial for development planning and should not be used as political tools to exploit the people. He added that the recently released population data needed to be reviewed as it could be manipulated during the 2027 General Election. “A census is very much a technical and statistical exercise that needs credibility. It was a worry when the Government launched the 2024 census as it entailed so much political fanfare. “The administration of the census seemed somewhat shambolic from the start, with real governance concerns raised as well, as with the tablets purchased not seemingly through a conventional tender process entailing information technology firm, but awarded to a timber-associated business run, reportedly, by persons associated with politically exposed persons. “This did not provide a good look. “This is why in many countries, the statistical office is protected by laws of independence and standards, and often reports directly to the legislature, rather than specifically to a minister of the executive government.”

Title: Nomane calls allocation argument a ‘deflection’
Content: CHUAVE MP James Nomane has urged the Government to stop using the allocation of service improvement funds to deflect how the government budget has been spent. “No more deflection using district (DSIP) and provincial service improvement programme (PSIP), no more excuses and just publish the expenditure reports,” he said. He said the people demanded to know how this year’s budget was spent and who got what and how much. A chart on the government budget shows the provincial service improvement programme (PSIP) and district service improvement programme (DSIP) allocation at 5.2 per cent, which is equivalent to K1.5 billion. The graph shows that the government has a bloated recurrent budget of K22 billion that includes DSIP and PSIP at K1.5 billion, education at K4.4 billion, health at K2 billion, law and justice at K2.3 billion, utilities at K1.4 billion, administration at K5.6 billion, debt servicing at K3.5 billion and others at K0.7 billion. The capital investment budget includes Transport at K2 billion and Provinces at K4.4 billion — to fund roads, bridges, wharves, and airports, plus capital grants to sub-national programmes. However, since 2018, lack of resources especially funding had hindered its progress causing a backlog of reports to the DIRD. Reports show only 59 districts and provinces have not acquitted with the main reason being lack of funding, logistics, newly formed districts and other administration issues. This figure is most likely to be carried over to next year adding to a backlog of acquittals from 2018 is yet to reach DIRD. “The Prime Minister admitted that K56 billion in six years produced no results. This is incompetence at its best,” Nomane said. “Spending money with no audits, no accountability and without results. This demonstrates poor budget management and has constricted the implementation schedule of districts and provinces.”

Title: Peaceful polling in Morobe
Content: LOCAL Level Government elections in Morobe are into the counting and declaration phase now after observing a quiet polling period in the province. From reportsThe Nationalgathered, polling in some parts of Morobe ended last Friday with counting and the declarations progressing starting on Monday. Assistant returning officer in Kapao, Menyamya, Nande Awape, said the polling has ended and the counting is underway. Kapao has 15 wards, of which five ward councillors have been declared, while others are yet to be declared. Counting for the Watut LLG in Bulolo, started on Monday and is progressing well, according to a report. Watut has about 12 wards. Of these three wards have been completed, while counting continues in the other 10 wards. In the 20 wards of Buang, polling and counting ended last week, with declaration of the ward councillors expected to happen this week. Assistant returning officer, Tuwut Kole, said once the counting is complete, all the presiding officers will meet with him at the LLG station to verify the journals to make sure the records are correct, so they can declare the ward councillors. After verifying the data, all declared councillors will be sworn-in and the polling for the LLG president is likely to happen this week. In Bulolo-Urban, according to reports, the counting is underway, and the declarations of ward councillors are also in progress. Meanwhile, Tewae-Siassi’s three local level governments (Wasu, Sialum and Siassi) moved their election materials late from Lae to their respective LLGs due to funding constraints. District administrator Sam Engam toldThe Nationalthat the district development authority (DDA) under the chairmanship of the local MP, Dr Kobby Bomareo, has assisted Sialum, Wasu and Siasii LLGs with funding to move the materials to their respective locations. Wasu ARO, Gyria Gyria, said the polling in the 18 wards of the LLG will most likely end today.

Title: Jiwaka PPC says counting will begin despite disruptions
Content: DESPITE disruptions with the 2025 local level government (LLG) elections in Jiwaka, polling has ended with all ballot boxes brought to Minj for counting this week, according to police. Provincial police commander acting Supt Laimo Aisi said polling was completed in all districts, except for the LLGs of Anglimp and Kuna-Komun which have been suspended over reports of them being illegally created. “We are now complete, and ready for counting, except Anglimp and Kuna-Komun as these are two new LLGs within Anglimp-South Waghi that are still under dispute. “Those two LLGs are yet to start polling. “The dispute is over the creation of new wards and two LLGs, including wards that were created recently. “All on dispute, and we had a meeting yesterday (Monday) with the relevant authorities, but still awaiting feedback from the Electoral Commission on issues raised by those respective councillors and members of the community,” Asi said. He said this was an issue that needed to be addressed as soon as possible. He added that police had not received any reports of deaths or serious incidents in the province, only that a few ballot boxes were damaged. Even though one ballot box was hijacked, he said it was brought back and people continued with polling. Aisi commended the work of his officers during the LLG elections. He said they were able to successfully manage the polling period while not receiving much support from the provincial administration and the Electoral Commission.

Title: Tuman leaders call on commissioner to lift suspension
Content: LEADERS in Tuman, one of the four zones of Jiwaka’s Anglimp local level government (LLG), have called on the election manager, Rossie Paundihau to relay to the Electoral Commissioner to lift the suspension imposed on the 14 new wards and allow polling to proceed in all of the 51 wards. In a gathering at Tuman in Kindeng last Friday, seven councillors said the protest staged by the people and leaders of Anglimp – Kuli last week that led to the blocking of the Highlands Highway was uncalled for. Councillor Simon Komp of Kindeng block said the Tuman zone had 25,000 populations in the 2022 electoral roll for the eight existing wards of which the big voting population warranted new wards. Komp said there was nothing sinister about creating the new wards, and the wards were created in the Anglimp LLG chamber, where president Nicholas Kurua was the chief signature to the endorsement of the motion to create the wards. However, Nicholas Kurua took the matter to the National Court for reasons only known to him, where the court dismissed the application while another attempt made by North-Waghi MP Benjamin on the same case was also dismissed. He said the Tuman people did not take part in the protest and the blocking of the Highlands Highway because Anglimp South-Waghi MP and Correctional Services Minister, Joe Kuli, is from Tuman and they have respect for that. However, Komp was concerned that the rest of Jiwaka including the new Kambia LLG had gone to the polls, and it was unfair for Anglimp LLG not to start at all. The same sentiments were expressed by councillor Peter Seina of Epine Mombegl, Joe Win of Andekilaka, John Koim and Anis Palme representing Roag Three and Four, Frank Kalenda for Enga, and youth leader Joe Dosie. These leaders requested the Electoral Commissioner to uplift the suspension and allow polling to start before the counting schedule on Nov 9. Attempts to get comments from election manager, Rossie Paundihau, were unsuccessful

Title: Deaths reported at Angau will be investigated: Kapavore
Content: HEALTH Minister Elias Kapavore says that facts surrounding several recent deaths at Angau Memorial Hospital in Morobe, will be established following an investigation. Kapavore made this statement yesterday following questions from Kabwum MP Patrick Basa in Parliament last week. The minister said there was an investigation to establish whether those deaths happened because of a prolonged blackout. “Facts surrounding the deaths are part of an investigation,” Kapavore clarified. “Causes of the deaths will be established once the investigation is complete. “We need to know how or why the patients lost their lives.”

Title: Agency partnership with AFP vital: Manning
Content: POLICE Commissioner David Manning says it was important to sign the Joint Agency Agreement (JAA) with the Australian Federal Police to disrupt international criminal activities before they infiltrate our countries. Manning said the agreement, signed on Nov 2, is focused entirely on the sharp-end of policing deploying critical resources to identify and break apart criminal gangs before they can set up in PNG. “The JAA is not about training, it is about aligning our policing operations to ensure we break apart these transnational criminal organisations, and arrest criminals and local facilitators who support them in both countries. “This agreement gives us better access to intelligence products from our regional partners because these criminal groups do not respect borders. “International criminal networks are attempting to use Papua New Guinea as a stepping stone for extending their illicit activities into Australia, but our police forces are working together to shut them down before they become active. “We are stopping these gangs before they can try to transship drugs, money and precious metals such as gold, as well as stopping the human trafficking of vulnerable people.” Manning said the JAA is managed by a steering committee. This committee is made up of specialised police leadership from PNG and Australia. “The Joint Steering Committee facilitates the sharing of intelligence leading to the active detection of illegal movements and the interception and apprehension of criminals,” he said.

Title: Renovated barracks set for police recruits
Content: THE 14 renovated recruit barracks at the National Centre of Excellence, opened over the weekend, are expected to accommodate more than 300 recruits starting next year. The college is also expected to undergo a two-year construction phase to upgrade training facilities at a cost of K10 mil funded by the Australian Government. Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr stated that the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC), in line with the PNG and Australian government’s plan, aims to modernise to tackle modern criminal threats, including drug trafficking and money laundering. “These are new threats and we must work together we must share intelligence shut them down and bring them to justice,” he said this during a ground breaking ceremony over the weekend. “The Pukpuk treaty is a great example of us working together with Australia.” Tsiamalili noted that for regional cooperation, they are collaborating with Australia, Fiji, and other regional partners through Interpol and the Pacific Policing Initiative to strengthen these efforts. The phase three projects will include a new classroom, multipurpose centre, and male and female cadet barracks. “With these new barracks we will be able to train an additional 700 police each year increasing the numbers to 1,400 per year,” the minister said. “Our population is around 10.2 million, so we need to ensure our police force is appropriately staffed. “The probation period for recruits is now five years.” Police Commissioner David Manning urged police officers and recruits to never forget why they joined the force. He said the refurbished facilities provides an additional 408 beds for recruits. “The facility will support our other pacific family and we will continue to ensure that police family around the region benefits from this training infrastructure by offering positions on our recruitment.” New Australian Federal Police (AFP) Krissy Barrett added that they have 50 AFP members in Papua New Guinea are working together with the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary counterparts to uplift operations, training and capabilities and delivery infrastructure.

Title: Official: Accurate reporting helps development
Content: REPORTING accurately contributes to national development, the media and public servants were told last Friday. Department of Personnel Management deputy secretary (policy) Elison Kalimet told a one-day workshop: “The media plays a pivotal role in any democracy; you are the watchdogs who hold institutions to account. “You are the storytellers who inform and educate our citizens and the bridge that connects government actions with public understandings. “Without your engagements, public trust in our institutions would erode and misinformation would quickly fill the void.” The workshop was focused on public sector reforms and management and involved representatives from the media in Port Moresby. Speaking on behalf of secretary Taies Sansan, Kalimet said the workshop was designed to foster mutual understanding between the department and the media, allowing for discussions to clarify misconceptions about the public service and its systems. He said that misinformation, particularly that reported of the public service, has led to much criticism from the people. The media also had a responsibility to ensure that news was correctly reported, Kalimet said. “Our goal is simple yet essential; to help the media understand how we operate so that your reporting is accurate, factual and balanced,” Kalimet said. “When information is reported correctly, it builds public confidence, strengthen governance and reduces the space for corruption and confusion. “The Department of Personnel Management remains committed to ensuring fair and transparent recruitment and the media plays a crucial oversight role on this. “Together, our collaboration strengthens accountability and public trust in Papua New Guinea’s public service.”

Title: Doctor urges increased awareness on risks of breast cancer
Content: A HEALTH specialist has highlighted the urgent need for increased awareness about breast cancer risks in the country. Paradise Private Hospital obstetrics and gynaecology specialist Dr Grace Raire stressed the importance of empowering women with knowledge on breast cancer risks, early detection, treatment options, and self-examination techniques. This was part of a education session with Papua New Guinea Chamber of Resources and Energy on Monday under its Safety Talk of the Month initiative. Their presentations covered topics on self-breast examinations, clinical screenings, and the crucial role of mammograms in early detection. The women in attendance were encouraged to prioritise health screenings and to educate their families and other women in their communities about the importance of early detection. “The urgency of addressing breast cancer must be noted, given that breast cancer remains a critical health challenge, being the leading cause of cancer-related deaths among women in Papua New Guinea and globally,” Raire said. “In 2023 alone, there were about 2.3 million new diagnoses worldwide, resulting in over 670,000 fatalities and PNG makes up part of the statistics. “There is concerning statistics in PNG, where breast cancer accounts for an estimated 4,000 new cases and over 1,600 deaths annually,” Raire added. She said awareness sessions like these aim to highlight concerning statistics and stress the importance of early detection and timely interventions in combating breast cancer.

Title: Sepik leaders back Frieda project
Content: LEADERS from East and West Sepik have united in their commitment to advancing the Frieda River copper-gold project. Wewak MP Stanley Muts Samban, Aitape Lumi MP Anderson Mise, Angoram MP Salio Waipo, Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim, Nuku MP Joe Sungi and West Sepik Governor Tony Wouwou met with Prime Minister James Marape in Parliament last week. Marape praised their unity and maturity, emphasising responsible, transparent resource development that balances economic growth with environmental protection, reaffirming the government’s commitment to both. “Frieda River must be developed to the highest environmental management standards,” he said. “We will not allow any mining activity to harm the Sepik River – the lifeline of the region. “This commitment is also personal to me, as my wife’s family comes from the Sepik River and Chambri Lakes area. “We will protect the river while ensuring responsible economic development.” Marape called the Frieda River Project a key driver in PNG’s northern resource corridor — alongside Porgera and Ok Tedi — directing the Department of Mining to address legal issues and remove non-genuine investors. “We want credible investors who are ready to responsibly develop our resources,” he said. “Now that the Sepik leaders are united on the Frieda project, the Government will ensure the project is advanced properly and in full compliance with national standards,” he said. Marape acknowledged other leaders from the region including Vanimo-Green River MP Belden Namah for their maturity, leadership, and cooperation in progressing the project.
People: Anderson Mise, Belden Namah, James Marape, Joe Sungi, Salio Waipo, Solan Mirisim, Tony Wouwou

Title: Marape: O’Neill’s call to retire after 2027 a ‘gimmick’
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says the promise by Ialibu-Pangia MP Peter O’Neill to retire from politics in 2027 is just a gimmick. O’Neill said this week that he would retire from politics in 2027 if the Opposition formed the government from the motion of no confidence it had filed. O’Neill is named the alternative prime minister in the motion. But the motion was rejected by Parliament’s private business committee on Thursday, forcing the Opposition to seek legal action. Marape described O’Neill’s “retirement promise” as a tactical narrative designed to lure members of parliament and the public into forgetting his record of abuse and corruption. “We remember the very man who now speaks of renewal was the architect of the greatest erosion of integrity and accountability in our democracy,” he said. “He presided over unauthorised loans, deepened national debt, compromised our institutions, and left our people poorer. “Now, when the same man says he will retire if he regains power, we ask: how can we trust someone who never kept his word when he was in power for eight long years?” Marape said O’Neill’s attempt to paint himself as a reformer was an insult to the intelligence of Papua New Guineans. “He said similar things before 2011, before 2017, and again before 2019. “Yet he never walked away when the people wanted accountability. PNG knows this pattern too well.” Marape added that a motion of no confidence should be about the nation’s future and not a vehicle for one man’s redemption story. “The people of Papua New Guinea deserve leadership that builds, not leadership that manipulates and divides,” Marape said.

Title: Bird: K104million allocated funds yet to be received
Content: EAST Sepik Governor Allan Bird told Parliament that K104 million in allocated funds for last year and this year, including function and infrastructure grants for the province, are yet to be received. He explained that East Sepik was supposed to receive K57 million for function grants and K10 million for infrastructure grants from last year’s budget. However, the province only received K23 million of the K67 million that was allocated. He questioned Finance Minister Thomas Opa about the possibility of receiving the outstanding funds this month to address pressing issues such as teacher leave fares and medicine shortage. Bird said: “A lot of time, the government announce large sum of money for provincial governments but we do not actually see the cash at our end.” Opa acknowledged the delay, particularly funds for provincial health authorities and that the department is working with agencies to release 60-70 per cent of the outstanding funds. Prime Minister James Marape had previously committed to releasing the funds. Bird urged Opa to prioritise ensuring the people of East Sepik receive funds owed.
People: Allan Bird, James Marape, Thomas Opa

Title: Leaders of fighting tribes put under house arrest
Content: THE leaders of two warring tribes in Wapenamanda, Enga have been placed under house arrest with strict conditions after they were questioned by police for breaching a National Court order to stop fighting. Judge Graham Elis last month ordered MP Miki Kaeok and businessman Danny Katie as the leaders to implement the ceasefire within seven days regarding the fight between the Yakuman and Yangakun tribes. They were questioned at the Boroko police station in Port Moresby, according to Assistant Police Commissioner Highlands Western End Joseph Tondop, in relation to a fresh tribal fighting in Mambisanda in which two men died and others were injured. “The conflict in the Wapenamanda district of Enga between the two tribes has escalated again,” he said. Tondop said a member of the Yakuman tribe fired shots at villagers at a polling station who were casting their votes for the Local Level Government election on Thursday at Takaipus village. “Motive of the attack is unknown at this stage but it is believed this incident is related to the current tribal conflict between the Yakuman and Yangakun tribes. “A retaliatory fight happened and three staff houses at Mambisanda Lutheran Hospital were burnt down. Police and soldiers are camping at the area to provide security,” he toldThe National. Tondop said the attack by both partiers was a clear breach of the court’s ceasefire orders. “I have taken steps to stop this conflict from escalating further. Part of the steps include, writing to Commander Wagambie to invoke certain provisions of the Counter Terrorism Act so we can detain ring leaders and have them processed in accordance with the laws of the land.” Tondop added that he would be writing to the National Court in Wabag of the actions taken to enforce the court orders. “The house arrest action will be reviewed on Wednesday in preparations for the second round of peace talks to be held in Port Moresby on Thursday.”

Title: NSO faced significant challenges which delayed census, says Igitoi
Content: ACTING National Statistician John Igitoi said the National Statistical Office (NSO) faced significant logistical challenges during last year’s census, which delayed the release of final population figures. He said NSO deployed over 35,000 field officers and data collectors across 398 local level governments (LLGs), 6,908 wards, and 30,501 villages. “NSO deployed them to those households to count our people, to ensure they were recorded on the government’s official database. “Added to these challenges were the critics of the Government and the NSO questioning our ability to deliver the census,” he said. Igitoi said despite the population headcount being a resource-intensive exercise, NSO was able to complete it in less than two years after one year three months of data collection, data verification and data processing. The 2024 NSO population census report shows a total of 10,185,363 people in the country, with 5,336,546 men and 4,848,817 women. Of the total, 5,827,441 persons were over the age of 18. The report says: “This represents an increase of 40 per cent (2,910,039 people) in PNG’s population count since 2011 (7,275,324). “The average annual growth rate over the past 13 years, since the 2011 census, was 2.6 per cent. “Annual growth rate since the 2011 census is higher (3.1 per cent) but is likely to be artificially inflated because of non-demographic factors such as higher undercounting in 2000 and improvements to the 2011 and 2024 census coverage methods. “More males than females were counted in PNG on census night (52.4 per cent and 47.6 per cent of the total population, respectively). “This represents approximately 110 males to every 100 females. “The average number of people per household was five for PNG. “Since the first census in 1980, five years after independence, there have been an additional 7.2 million people added from 3.0 million in the last 44 years.” Of the 22 provinces, Morobe had the highest population with 997,545, and Manus the lowest with 69, 560.

Title: Disaster happened in area prone to landslips: Officials
Content: THE tragic killing of 21 people at Kukas village in the Minamb Valley of Enga occurred at a communal house built in an area susceptible to landslips. The joint disaster assessment team deployed to Kukas village in Enga’s Wapanemanda on Friday found that the area was susceptible to landslips and that homes were not built in the area for that reason. The communal building was used to accommodate visitors from the Yambalikin tribe of Lower Lai many kilometers distant who had come to attend a funeral at Kukas. Tragically, the people were unable to return home on Thursday due to renewed tribal fighting in Wapenamanda between the Yangakun and Yakuman tribes which prevented any access. The team comprising officers from the Enga disaster center, Wapanemanda district administration, National Disaster Center (NCD) and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), visited the site that was covered in a landslide in the early hours of Friday. The report said the landslide in Kukas, Minamb Valley, killed 21 people hospitalised five, and traumatised 45 others. Of the 21 deaths, 17 were males, and four females including two children and a pregnant woman. Two food gardens were destroyed including the communal house where the people from Lower Lai were accommodated on Thursday night. Most of the deaths were from the Yambalikin tribe of Lower Lai, except one from Yarapaki tribe. They came for a funeral service at Kukas. In the joint operation, the IOM activated its Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) Emergency Event Tracking (EET) tool to assess the situation. The report noted that loosened soil, unstable slopes, and ongoing water seeping across the Minamb Valley, created conditions that pose a continued risk of secondary landslides. The affected site is situated less than five meters from the Minamb River, where sustained heavy rainfall likely exacerbated the instability of the already saturated ground. The report said the disaster response team provided the required support which included retrieving the bodies, medical evacuation to the survivors and providing relief assistance to affected families. The report said due to ongoing tribal fighting in Wapenamanda, the provincial administration sought consent from families of the deceased to transport the bodies to Paradise Funeral Home in Mt Hagen on Friday evening. The deceased remain under the care of the Enga government, and the joint assessment team recommended that communities residing along the affected slope consider relocating to safer areas, given the continuous rainfall and unstable conditions. The team also recommended maintaining regular security patrols to help ensure safety in the area due to the tribal conflict in Wapenamanda. As a result, travel from Wabag to the affected area is considered unsafe without a security escort. Access from Mt Hagen remains open and is currently being used as the preferred route for response and assessment teams. As part of its programming, IOM has strengthened the capacity of local authorities in Enga in mental health and psychosocial support services (MHPSS). To ensure an effective coordinated response to the landslide in Kukas village, the following actions were recommended:

Title: Central polling meets very few hassles
Content: POLLING for the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections in Central has progressed without much trouble, except for reports of limited ballot papers at certain venues, according to police. Provincial police commander Supt Joseph Salle said: “I am happy with how the people of Central are behaving during the election, even though eligible voters have raised issues regarding their names not being on the common roll and the shortage of ballot papers. “However, they have come to an understanding and proceeded with the voting, which is nearing completion. “Most of the ward councillors have been declared, while the other wards are still voting. “After all ward councillors are declared, the election officials will continue to count the LLG president votes.” Salle said three persons have been arrested and are detained at 15-Mile police station for hijacking ballot papers during polling last week, adding that police officers would only assist when the need arises at the polling venues. He said that the issue leading to the hijacking of the ballot papers was due to the limited number of ballot papers compared to the eligible voters there, urging the Electoral Commission to address this issue immediately to prevent such incidences from happening again. Salle confirmed that there were no major incidents reported, except for only one at a ward in the Hiri -Koiari LLG. Polling ends on Saturday (Nov 8).

Title: Breakadown in law and order concerns Powi
Content: SOUTHERN Highlands Governor William Powi is concerned about the recent breakdown of law and order in the Nipa Basin local level government (LLG) of Nipa-Kutubu during this year’s LLG elections. Powi said the recent unrest was linked to the many discrepancies found in the 2025 voter enrolment figures across wards which needed to be verified to prevent further problems. “These discrepancies should be verified and cross-checked against the 2022 figures and properly assessed,” he said. “However, polling has already started, and we cannot change the rules or the roll mid-process. “Our duty now is to protect life, uphold order, and record every anomaly for the proper authorities to address.” Powi said he had reported the matter to the Electoral Commission and the Department of Provincial and Local-Level Government Affairs, through the provincial election steering committee. “We have institutions of government for a reason,” he said. “Respect for the rule of law and following the proper process leads to good governance and respect for leadership. “We are not playing cards or gambling with people’s lives – leadership is a serious business. “We must live up to it with simplicity, humility, and the values of respect and humanity – not the arrogance of someone in a hurry.” Powi called for the immediate implementation of the following: “Our people have not had sufficient time to verify and confirm the new voter rolls,” Powi said. “That is why Basin communities are raising serious concerns. “People will not participate in LLG and district democracy if that democracy is compromised.” But now that elections are in progress, we must proceed within the law, keep the peace, and channel disputes into the proper forums.” He urged the local people to stop the violence and allow the police and courts to function, while authorities document issues and prepare for a thorough review.

Title: Governor announces hydro project on hold
Content: A PROPOSED hydro-power project in the Saidor local level government of Rai Coast, Madang, requires the approval of landowners in Yaganon, says Governor Ramsey Pariwa. He told locals at the Dein Primary School last week that he had been approached by groups of people since 2022 claiming to own the land where the Yaganon hydro-power project would be located. “I don’t want to create divisions among you,” he said. “I am confused as to whom to assist.  One group shouldn’t force me to accept its position and overlook the others. That is not right. “I am for you all. I want you to regroup and agree to work together for a better way forward.” Pariwa told the people that while talk on a new project was exciting, the actual magnitude of the hydro power project would require much work. He said that the provincial government was ready to support the project and has already earmarked K5 million for the feasibility study. He called on all parties involved in the project to come to an agreement before any development could take place. Yaganon Landowners Association chairman Wilas Weta said had been to Port Moresby to seek assistance for the project but he was advised to go back home and organise the people to come to an agreement before the project could start.

Title: Grade 4 student, 14, found dead at Koki Fish Market
Content: A 14-year-old grade 4 student from Goilala, Central, was found dead at Port Moresby’s Koki Fish Market yesterday. According to the mother, she discouraged her son, Stanley James, from going swimming at the beach at Koki on Sunday but he escaped and went, and never returned home that afternoon. The mother said that they searched everywhere they thought he would be at but never found him. It wasn’t until they drove back to Two-Mile when they heard the news that a body of a young boy was found at the Fish Market. She said they went there and confirmed that it was her son. “We now leave it to the police to investigate and find out how he died,” she said. “The police and doctors will tell us how he died, so we will wait for the results.” The National Capital District Criminal Investigating Division police officers were understood to be investigating the incident. NCD Met Supt Warrick Simatab said police units were collecting evidence from possible eyewitnesses to establish the cause of death. Simatab said that the number of deaths in the city was increasing. He said people were dying in different ways. Some were murdered, others from accidents and others died from illnesses. “I am calling on the city residents to be cautious when moving around,” Simatab said. “With the increasing death toll, some people do not have respect for others. “Small things can lead to people losing their lives, like not monitoring each family members on how they move around and where they go. “Checking on your family members daily shows that you care for them.”

Title: Toroama outlines vision for Arob
Content: BOUGAINVILLE President Ishmael Toroama presented a bold vision for the region’s future, focusing on political independence, economic self-sufficiency, and good governance during his inaugural address last week. Toroama emphasised Bougainville’s clear path to political independence, citing the overwhelming vote for independence as outlined in the PNG Constitution. He stressed the need for the PNG Parliament to honour the people’s choice through the Melanesian Agreement and Sessional Order. On governance, Toroama advocated for Bougainville to become a true republic with a directly elected president, free from the constraints of the current hybrid system. He also called for institutional reforms to ensure governance aligns with the new republican system. Toroama stressed that economic independence must start at the family and community levels, ultimately contributing to Bougainville’s long-term prosperity. “At the government level, my government will first of all ensure that Panguna quickly progresses to the next stage of development,” he said. Regarding economic development, Toroama highlighted several key projects: Toroama challenged the leaders to take the lead in practicing good governance and called on citizens to follow the rules and laws of the land. He reiterated that the transformation he was advocating for under the three agendas mentioned is not difficult to achieve with co-operation at all levels and roles that leaders and citizens played in Bougainville society. Toroama reaffirmed his commitment to a 100-day action plan, urging leaders and public servants to align with his priorities to ensure Bougainville’s sovereignty was realised.

Title: Economist questions 2024 census results
Content: AN economist has questioned the credibility of the result of last year’s national census, and called for a more extensive review and verification of the recently released population data. Institute of National Affairs executive director Paul Barker said: “The administration of the 2024 census seemed somewhat shambolic from the start, with real governance concerns raised as well. From various mini-sample surveys around the country, and ad hoc feedback online, it appears that a substantial portion of the population was never censured, even in the National Capital District where the population was relatively accessible. “From many small samples around the country, people said their households were never visited, or if they were, either the forms were not received or the filled forms never collected. “Maybe, following extensive credible and independent verification, the latest census figures, nationally and sub-nationally, will prove correct. But at this stage, there remains a disappointing and expensive lack of desirable certainty.” Comparing census events from previous years, he noted that a lower budget was allocated for the 2024 census, and that crucial questions to understand the country’s demography were left out. He added that population data was crucial for all development plans for the country, including the common roll update. “For the 2024 census, there was a significantly lower budget allocated, in relation to prior exercises, which meant that it was going to need to be conducted on a relative shoestring, requiring mechanisms to apply efficiencies. “As a result, the National Statistical Office (NSO) slashed the questions, leaving little more than a head count, and omitting valuable questions like the level of education of respondents, and whether or how they were employed – which were included in prior censuses. “It is unfortunate that, especially in the lead-up to the preparation of the electoral roll for the 2027 election, a census outcome has not been reached, which provides wholesale reassurance, let alone beyond a mere head count.” Barker recommends that the data released by the NSO be properly verified for more accuracy about the country’s population. “The test of accuracy will depend on closer examination of provincial and local data, using trends, cross-checking reliable local data from the past and present, including from other reliable sources, and records from village recorders and specific local surveys,” he said.

Title: Citizens urged to consider responsible family planning
Content: PAPUA New Guineans have been urged to seriously consider responsible family planning given the current socio-economic state of the country. Prime Minister James Marape warned that the rapid population growth could outpace the nation’s economic capacity if not properly managed. “From conception to adulthood, it can cost up to K5 million to give a child a decent, modern upbringing,” he said. “Parents must think carefully. It is not about how many children you have, but about the quality of life you can provide for them.” Marape urged young couples to consider limiting their families to two or three children, warning that the cost of raising a child to adulthood in the current state of the county was an expensive exercise. He said that a Government proposal would have the first two or three children in a family receiving full education support, while additional children would be the responsibility of parents. “This is a conversation we must have maturely in churches, communities, and families. A sustainable country must have its economy growing faster than its population.” He also announced plans to make population monitoring a continuous process, urging all provincial administrations to work with health facilities to ensure that every birth and death is recorded. This, he said, would enable accurate and efficient census exercises conducted in the future. Meanwhile, Marape said PNG’s demographic and economic history showed that the population had tripled since 1975, while economic growth has been stagnant. “For the first 27 years, our economy grew at less than 0.3 per cent while our population rose at around 3 per cent,” he said.

Title: 10million is the figure to plan for: Statistician
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s official population of 10,185,363 is the figure to be used for all development planning, says acting National Statistician John Igitoi. “These population numbers should guide us to reset our development agendas and strategise and refocus on what areas we need to address to have maximum impact on the lives of our population,” he said. “It will become the common denominator for any development planning, strategies, decision-making and resource allocation. “We can now properly manage the affairs of the population. “That is, we can procure and distribute the correct amount of medical drugs proportionate to the population who needs them in those various locations. “We now can know what number of people we are connecting to with infrastructure developments. “We can now build classrooms and train teachers proportionate to school-aged children in those various communities, and so on.” Igitoi said that a lack of population data for the past 13 years had left many using only estimates in development plans. He said that this round of census by the National Statistical Office would ensure that estimates would no longer be used. “Since the 2011 national population census, our understanding of the people of this country are based on outdated information and estimates using both conventional and unconventional statistical method. “This census was a very resource intensive exercise, and for the first time, we used technology for data collection in this round of census, on a very large scale, which has assisted us to reduce time lag by more than one year compared to the previous censuses. “The final population figures in the previous four other censuses were often announced after more than two years. “For this round of census, we are announcing it after one year three months of data collection, data verification and data processing.”

Title: Rural Enga hospital burnt down. Bishop Urame condemns act
Content: THE Luthern Church’s Mambisanda rural hospital in Enga was burnt to the ground last Thursday evening. Information received from the Evangelical Luther Church which ran the hospital reveals that thugs attacked the hospital and burnt down staff houses as well. Head Bishop of the Evangelical Lutheran Church Dr Jack Urame has called for the immediate arrest of those responsible of burning the hospital. “I condemn the act and urge the police to arrest those responsible and they must face the full force of the law,” he said. Urame confirmed that the facility belonged to the Good News Lutheran Church, under the Lutheran Health Services. “It was built by volunteers from the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod between 1955 and 1957; dedicated on 22nd June 1957.” “I talked with the Bishop of the Good News Lutheran Church in Enga and received confirmation of the destruction of the Mambisanda rural hospital (on Thursday night).” “Warlords attacked the hospital and burnt down staff houses.” Urame said no lives were lost. “The police and soldiers moved in and guarded the hospital and protected the hospital community,” he said. “Staff houses were burnt down while parts of the hospital were saved.” Urame said tribal fighters were a threat to people, to peace and harmony in the community and called on the government to come down hard on these men who causing destruction in the province. He said such negative behavior was not a sign of freedom and prosperity when the nation just celebrated its 50 years of political freedom. He said public utilities and institutions served the whole community and attacks like this were totally unacceptable. “Buildings are not enemies, they don’t react and cannot fight back,” he said. “Public utilities and institutions like hospitals, schools, church buildings, bridges and other infrastructures are not private but for the community for the benefit of everyone.” “The hospital was there to save lives; it’s theirs and they benefited from it. People must respect public utilities and institutions.” He appealed to the people to behave like rational and civilized human beings and stop the culture of tribal war, vandalism, arson and violence. “Tribal war and violence are not a sign of freedom and progress but of enslavement and societal regression.”

Title: Kramer raises query about funds used for LLG elections
Content: MADANG MP Bryan Kramer asked the Government in Parliament on Friday if district funds used to run the local level government elections are going to be reimbursed. In his grievance debate Kramer said there were so many commitments made that funding would be released but according to information from his district, electoral officers were seeking help to pay counting and polling officials. “K10, 000 was given when the writs were issued to conduct the training and recruitment of counting and polling officials and that K10,000 was used and the provincial government gave another K19,000,” Kramer said. “So they had K29,000 to run the entire elections and now they are looking for money for hire vehicles. “Why are we paying national election rates where there is high risk for LLG elections? “Some even asked for advanced payment before deployment.” Kramer said Administrative Services Minister Richard Masere said funds were paid but put on hold and were to be released today (Friday) when polling starts (but that) was a complete misinformation. “So who’s funding the LLG national function? “Are we getting our money back now that we’re helping to fund the election when the Government releases the money? “Hospitals are asking for money for fuel drums. “Police are saying they are not briefed about the polling schedules and they don’t know if they will be given allowances for the operation,” he said. Kramer said that during the three-day biometric workshop on polling and voting, a United States company was one of the main presenters and their cofounders were indicted for bribery in the Philippines which should raise serious concerns.

Title: O’Neill promises to resign from politics if Opposition forms government
Content: FORMER Prime Minister Peter O’Neill says if the Opposition forms government during a Vote of No Confidence, he will resign from politics permanently in 2027 and will not lead People’s National Congress Party to the next election. O’Neill made this known in a statement yesterday after he accepted to be the Opposition’s nominee as the alternative prime minister in their recent motion of no confidence against Prime Minister James Marape. However, the motion was rejected by Parliament’s private business committee on Thursday. O’Neill, who is the Ialibu-Pangia MP, said: “Leadership is not about power or privilege, but about service and responsibility. “It is from this conviction, and after much reflection, that I have decided to accept nomination to serve as Prime Minister of our beloved country once again,” O’Neill said. O’Neill said if given the opportunity to become prime minister again, he would focus on areas such as; rebuilding economic confidence; investing in education and healthcare; clamping down hard on violence and illegal activities; and restoring trust in democratic leadership through accountability and transparency and delivering a free and fair General Election (GE) in 2027. “I know there are Members of Parliament who may not agree with my decision to stand.  To you, I say this: I respect your right to hold your views. Our democracy is stronger because we can debate ideas openly. Our democracy has been weakened by division of late. It is not the way of democracy nor is it the way of Melanesian leadership,” O’Neill said. “To every Member of Parliament, I extend my hand in friendship and cooperation. Let us put the interests of our people before ourselves and over the next 18 months, until the GE in mid-2027 and work together to restore confidence, stability, and hope in our democracy. “I will ensure that the 2027 elections be conducted free and fair so our people can elect properly mandated leaders and do away with the rigging that was common in 2022. “Let me make this clear commitment: I will serve faithfully as a Member of Parliament and as your Prime Minister, should I be elected, until the next GE in 2027 and then retire permanently from politics.”

Title: Enduring hardships for no gain
Content: TWO men from the Kapao local level government area of Menyamya in Morobe, carried a ballot box tied on a tree branch and crossed a river to the polling station. This has happened at every election since Independence. People struggle to pick their leaders at every election but after each election the leaders forget the people, a concerned local Lincoln Peter toldThe National. Peter said this has been practiced for years, where people have been carrying ballot boxes and crossing rivers and mountains to ensure they elect a representative. Peter said the people played their part in electing a leader but they never receive development. “These people are neglected, but not forgotten,” he stated. “The two men were crossing the Kariba River with the ballot box to ensure they take part in the election.” Peter said despite the people being part of a democratic process at every election, they have been neglected by the people they appoint into power. “The two men are from ward 15 of the LLG, who waded through the fast-flowing Kariba River, carrying a ballot box bound for ward 14 during preparations for the 2025 council election,” he said. “The wards (11, 12, 13, 14, and 15) lie at the far end of Kapao LLG, an area that has remained largely isolated and underserved.”

Title: Lae clinic runs out of meds, closes
Content: A CLINIC in Lae has been closed for a week due to a shortage of medical supplies, with all emergency cases referred to the Angau General Hospital. PNG Family Health Association regional coordinator Mavia Mumuan, who manages the Sir Bob Sinclair Clinic in Ward Two, said they were providing only family planning and maternal and child health services. “We exhausted all our supplies last week so unfortunately, we had to close our outpatient this week,” she said. “We placed our order for restock about two weeks ago. “We are not sure when these supplies will come in so we can reopen. “I feel sorry for our people but we cannot do much.” She said that a woman trying to seek help from the clinic almost died. “Yesterday, we almost lost a mother. “She crawled from the gate and we had to rush her to Angau,” she said. Mumuan said the association facility had been operating in partnership with the government through the Morobe Health Authority for the past 10 years. But they receive little assistance from the government to maintain operations. Morobe PHA chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga said drug shortage was a nationwide issue and not isolated to Morobe Binga said the K2 million given by Morobe government last March to address the drug shortage then was used in small amounts to support emergency drugs for rural facilities over time until they exhausted in first quarter of this year. He said Angau drugstore will be opened in November “Our challenge now is to have a central drug facility for the province where we park all supplies and have visibility of its use. “Unfortunately we have not been able to do so,” he said.

Title: Basil Jr set to contest regional seat
Content: BULOLO MP Sam Basil Jr has announced he will contest the Morobe regional seat following the death of former Governor Luther Wenge. Basil, in a statement, said it was important to announce his intention so the people of Bulolo and Morobe are informed, while emphasising his continued responsibility to his constituents. The clerks of Morobe Tutumang issued a notice on Oct 29 for a meeting to vote on a new governor on Nov 7, following advice from the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs and the Organic Law. “It may be a short period, however, it is important for Morobe, I have consulted with colleague Members of Parliament, members of Tutumang and my constituents to contest for the position of Governor when Tutumang meets,” he stated. Basil said that there were many reasons for him to raise his hands, and some were: “This will only consolidate the aspirations of the Morobe people where we want the best for our society and economy,” Basil said. “My intention is to work with all our National Members, nominated Members of the Tutumang and the elected presidents of all LLG in the province and provide stability and direction until the people of Morobe elect our new governor.”

Title: Tutumang meeting on Friday to vote for new governor: Bruten
Content: MOROBE administrator Max Bruten says the Tutumang (Morobe) assembly will meet on Friday, Nov 7, to vote for a new governor. Bruten said the Tutumang clerk issued a letter to all assembly members last Wednesday. He said this followed the advice of the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs (DLPLLG) and was guided by the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Government (OLPLLG) 1995, after Governor Luther Wenge’s death last month. Bruten said a respectable time was given to mourn while preparations were made on ground to hold the special Tutumang, also considering the national parliament session. He said the process to elect the province’s new governor will be guided by OLPLLG and closely observed by the DPLLG and the parliament as well. He asked for the understanding and cooperation of the Morobe people. DPLLG secretary Philip Leo confirmed that the OLPLLG governs the process of electing a new provincial governor in various circumstances, such as the untimely passing of Morobe’s late Governor Wenge. He said the OLPGLLG does not make provision for an “Acting Provincial Governor” nor a “caretaker Provincial Governor”, in the event of a vacancy. Section 21 of the OLPGLLG states that: “If the provincial governor vacates his office in accordance with Section 19(1)”, as in this case, the provincial assembly shall, from amongst the members of the assembly including members of the parliament, elect the provincial governor, under the chairmanship of the deputy governor, he said. “It is important to note that Tutumang has the authority to conduct this election process under its own Standing Orders, as provided for in Section 7 of the Provincial Government Administration Act 1997.” There has been calls by the people – some calling for a by-election to maintain transparency and democracy, a leader elected by the people. Leo, however, said per OLPGLLG, there is no process of a by-election. “Deputy governor will assume Chairmanship of the Tutumang under Section 14 specifically for this purpose. “All LLG heads including Open MPs as Members of Tutumang will convene to elect a new provincial governor. “The LLG heads are leaders and are qualified to participate in the Tutumang Assembly until the writs are returned in the coming LLG Election.” Bruten said LLG presidents would be called to participate in voting only. “Elected members of the 10 electorates are eligible to be nominated for the governor seat; but he must resign from holding any ministerial portfolio, even as vice or shadow minister, member or chairman of the public accounts committee to contest.”

Title: Minister explains Angau power issue
Content: STATE Enterprises Minister William Duma raised concerns about misinformation spread on social media about the power supply to Angau Hospital. He said that the outage on Oct 18 and 19 was the result of a faulty equipment at the hospital. “The Angau Hospital is an essential public service and a priority for electricity distribution in Lae,” he said. “There was no disruption to the PNG Power feed. “On Oct 18, there was an internal malfunction within the Angau Hospital’s own 415-volt switchboard which is maintained by a private contractor to the hospital. “PNG Power offered assistance to Angau, but were advised by hospital administration that a private contractor were dealing with the issue. “Under the direction of the PNG Power chief technical officer, workers remained on standby if required to assist. “The switchboard malfunction meant that the hospital could not receive electricity either from PNG Power or from the hospital’s generator. “PNG Power would have preferred that the hospital had asked PPL engineers to fix their internal switchboard problems instead of engaging private contractors.” Duma said the question in Parliament raised by MP Patrick Basa to Health Minister Elias Kapavore was genuine. “This was a decision made by the hospital, but there are misleading claims by faceless keyboard warriors trying to manipulate the public and they should be ashamed of themselves,” he said. “Public healthcare is a priority for all members of the Parliament and debate is important, it is disappointing that people with an agenda seek to mislead the people.” Angau is a major hospital and second largest referral hospital in the country providing much needed public healthcare services.
People: Elias Kapavore, Patrick Basa, William Duma

Title: Police shoot and kill two in highway looting incident
Content: POLICE in Madang have shot dead two armed men after a confrontation between the locals and the police at Naru section of the Ramu-Madang Highway last Thursday, says Madang police commander acting Superintendent Robert Baim. The incident happened after a confrontation between locals and police personnel that were sent from Madang to stop locals from looting a truck. The truck was loaded with cartons of tinned fish from Lae heading to Madang and had a mechanical fault which forced it off the road. “The people then chased off the driver of the truck and his crew and started looting the 20-foot container truck,” Baim said. “The first police unit that was sent there was outnumbered by criminals and members of the community.” It was also reported that while the women and children took away the looted items from the truck, some youths started taking off valuable parts of the truck like car stereo, battery, tyres and other parts of the vehicle. Baim also said that commuters along that part of the highway at that time were also harassed by criminals and members of the community there as well. “An additional police task force unit was sent there late on Thursday and the situation was contained, but some minutes later, the villagers retaliated and attacked the police with offensive weapons.” He said the confrontation between the police and the locals went on for an hour and the police personnel were attacked from all directions and were outnumbered at that time. Baim said the two men that were shot dead during the confrontation were armed and were among the members of the community and were trying to fight back at the police when they were shot during the shoot-out. He further warned anyone or opportunists trying to interfere with the travelling public along that section of the highway will face police.

Title: RPNGC recruit intake to increase
Content: POLICE recruitment will increase from 300 to 700 per intake, according to Police Commissioner David Manning. He made this known during the groundbreaking ceremony to upgrade training facilities at the Bomana Regional Center of Excellence. The event coincided with the welcoming of new Australian Federal Police (AFP) Commissioner Krissy Barrett. Manning said the refurbishment of the police barracks would enable the increase in the number of recruits to 700 per intake. Manning thanked the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea for supporting the police department. Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili said that the recently signed security agreement allowed the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary be able to work with their counterparts to fight crime in the region. Australian High Commissioner to PNG Ewen McDonald, thanked Tsiamilili and Manning, stating that what they had discussed regarding police manpower was now coming to fruition. AFP Commissioner Barrett pledged her support to work with Police Commissioner David Manning and Fiji Police Force Commissioner Rusiate Tudravu to help the policing service in Papua New Guinea, Fiji and the Pacific.

Title: Sir Bob attends Tonga’s National Day celebrations
Content: GOVERNOR-General Sir Bob Dadae is in Tonga for its sesquicentennial celebrations of the Act of the Constitution of Tonga. Sir Bob arrived last Wednesday and was met by Papua New Guinea’s High Commissioner to New Zealand Sakias Tameo and Tongan government officials. On Friday, he attended a breakfast hosted by King George Tupou VI and witnessed the commissioning of the Queen Salote International Wharf in the capital, Nuku’alofa. Sir Bob then paid a courtesy call on Tonga Prime Minister Dr Aisake Valu Eke and attended a reception hosted by Crown Prince Tupouto’a Ulukalala. Dr Eke thanked the PNG Government for supporting Tongan students attending education institutions in PNG. Yesterday, Sir Bob and Lady Emeline Dadae attended a thanksgiving service with King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipau’u. Sir Bob was invited by the Tongan government to attend week-long activities marking 150 years of the enactment of Tonga’s constitution on Nov 4, 1875. Tonga’s constitution established the country’s independence preventing it from being colonised by European powers and protects land ownership and sale of land to foreigners. Papua New Guinea and the Kingdom of Tonga established diplomatic relations in 1980.

Title: Yangoru-Saussia polling into second week
Content: POLLING in the Yangoru-Saussia, East Sepik, entered its second week today as the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections continue. District administrator Jeffrey Leni said polling had been progressing steadily since it began last week. “Polling teams have been moving across the wards according to the schedule, with support from police and election officials,” Leni said. “Despite some logistical challenges in remote areas, polling has been generally peaceful and well-organised.” Leni said East Sepik was among the provinces using the limited preferential voting (LPV) system to elect their LLG presidents. He said the LPV system allowed voters to rank three preferred candidates for first, second and third. “In the previous LLG election, ward members elected the LLG presidents,” Leni said. “This sometimes led to disagreements and questions about fairness. With the LPV, every eligible voter now has the right to choose their LLG president making it more democratic and transparent. “The system gives people confidence that their votes truly count.” According to from Electoral Commission, the use of LPV in selected provinces is to strengthen democracy and improve voter participation at the community level.

Title: Mekeo polling off to good start, says official
Content: THE first day of polling in the Mekeo Local Level Government (LLG) in Central on Monday was peaceful and well-coordinated, says assistant returning officer Richard Naime. Naime also confirmed that Charlie Inee Opu was declared the winner for Ward Three (Oriropetana). He is the first councilor to be declared in Kairuku. Naime said nine polling teams were operating in Mekeo. “Polling for East and West Mekeo constituencies is expected to be completed by Friday this week, except for North Mekeo which may take a bit longer,” he said. “We appreciate the efforts of the police and thank the communities for keeping the process peaceful. “This shows real leadership and cooperation at the village level.”

Title: Officers help with security at Central Gazelle polling sites
Content: Police were sent to all polling locations in Central Gazelle Local Level Government (LLG) in East New Britain after the first day of voting, following reports of sites operating without security. Central Gazelle LLG manager and acting returning officer (ARO)Gerard Melodi said polling began last Monday, along with the rest of East New Britain province. He said the first day saw no police officers at polling sites, but security was put in place from day two to support election officers and voters. Melodi said eight polling teams were assigned across 29 venues including Karavia 1, Talakua, Karavia 2, Malmaluan, Tavuiliu, Latlat, Rakunai 1 and 2, Kabakada, Navunaram, Vunagogo, Takekel, Tinganagalip, Napapar 1,2,3 and 4, Kerevat township and Tavilo. He said polling generally started slowly each day but ran smoothly overall. However, many voters were turned away at different locations because their names were not on the Common Roll. Melodi added that large and scattered wards such as Takekel, Vunagogo and Tinganagalip made access difficult for residents, and suggested two days of polling should be allocated for such areas. He said all teams are expected to finish today, except the Team who are doing counting at Tavuiliu as they will complete polling on Friday. Counting for the president’s seat will start next Monday. Meanwhile, the LLG is into its third day of counting votes for ward member seats. Melodies said counting began on Tuesday, starting with wards that completed polling the previous day. Only two ballot boxed were counted on the first day, from Karavi 1 and Latlat, due to a slow start. He also noted that the slow start on Tuesday was caused by the late arrival of the scrutineers. However, four ballot boxes were completed from Vunagogo, Takekel and Napapar 1 and 2. Counting continued on Thursday for wards that finished polling on Wednesday.

Title: Bishop Urame calls for urgent arrest of ‘warlords’ who burnt down hospital
Content: Head Bishop of the Evangelical Lutheran Church Dr Jack Urame has called on the immediate arrest of those responsible for burning the Mambisanda Hospital in Enga. He confirmed the facility belonged to the Good News Lutheran Church, under the Lutheran Health Services. “I talked with the Bishop of the Good News Lutheran Church in Enga and received confirmation of the destruction of the Mambisanda rural hospital,” Urame said. “Warlords attacked the hospital and burnt down staff houses. “No life was lost; the police and PNG Defence Foce moved in and guarded the hospital and protected the hospital community. “The attack on public utilities and institutions like this is totally unacceptable; I appeal to the people to behave like rational and civilised human beings and stop the culture of tribal war, vandalism, arson and violence. “Tribal war and violence is not a sign of freedom and progress but of enslavement and societal regression.”

Title: Rescue efforts continue as 21 bodies recovered in Wapenamanda landslide
Content: ABOUT 21 bodies were retrieved from a landslide that occurred in the early hours of Friday morning at Kukas village in the Minamb valley, outside Wapenamanda station, Wabag. Acting provincial police commander Chief Insp Kelly Sombe said locals reported that all the victims were from the Yabalekin tribe of Lower Lai in Wapenamanda. A huge landslip at 2am on Friday morning covered three houses, killing more than 21 people who were still sleeping. Sombe said villagers recovered 21 dead bodies – two children, three women and 16 men. He said three people sustained serious injuries and were admitted at Wabag hospital. “Other four villagers have sustained minor injuries. Police and Enga Disaster teams were at the scene early in the morning,” Sombe said. “So far, 21 bodies have been recovered.” Heavy rains overnight triggered the landslide. The community are still searching for those still missing, believed to be buried under the mud. Attempts to get comments from the district administrator and disaster coordinator were unsuccessful.

Title: NSO: PNG’s population now stands at 10 million
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s current population officially stands at 10,185,363, following the census conducted by the National Statistical Office (NSO) last year. Prime Minister James Marape announced the figure in Port Moresby last night – 13 years after the nationwide headcount conducted in 2011. The 2024 population census report by the NSO indicated that of the 10,185,363 persons in the country, 5,336,546 are men and 4,848,817 are women. Of the total, 5,827,441 persons are over the age of 18.
