Marape said this would be the numbers used by the Government and agencies in development planning for the future. “The economic growth of our country has not been equal to the population growth,” he said. “With the population figure now announced, it will be the basis upon which the Government and all agencies must work with. “It will also allow us to properly allocate funding and resource equally to all provinces and districts. “Going forward, we must ensure that our development plans align with our growing population.” Marape said that with PNG still a developing country, having a high population could put a strain on the economy. He said that the Government would consider implementing family planning policies to manage the growing population. Under the Ministry of Administrative Services, the NSO was tasked to conduct the K200 million exercise initially set from June 16 to 30 last year. June 16 was the reference night – the point in time reorded when and where a person spent the night before counting began on June 17. Authorised by the Statistical Services Act, the NSO is required to conduct a census every 10 years, ensuring that every citizen and foreigner in the country is recorded. PNG has only had five census after the first one in 1980 recorded a population of 3.1 million. In 1990 and 2000, a population of 3.8 million and 5.5 million were recorded respectively. The fourth census in 2011 saw 7.8 million persons counted. The fifth, planned for 2021, was deferred to last year. Acting National Statistician John Igitoi said despite the challenges during the census exercise, the NSO was able to produce the population figures with the support of its stakeholders and development partners. “This investment in the census will help with the Government’s development agendas through more population-focused programmes,” he said.

Title: Opposition to seek court order to recall Parliament
Content: THE Opposition will seek a court order to recall Parliament to accept a motion of no confidence rejected by its Private Business Committee yesterday, according to Ialibu-Pangia MP Peter O’Neill. “We will ask the court to intervene,” he said. “We are (seeking) to recall Parliament to entertain the motion. “Second, we are seeking that there will be punitive charges against the Speaker, the Clerk and members of the Private Business Committee.” O’Neill was named the alternative Prime Minister in a motion by the Opposition filed on Wednesday. “I’m not taking up this challenge because I’m desperate of becoming Prime Minister again,” the Ialibu-Pangia MP said. “I’m quite happy to retire tomorrow if the country was running well. “I have agreed to put in this motion on (the condition) that if we form the Government, I will only serve this term and retire at the end of the term. “I will not contest the open seat in my own (Ialibu-Pangia) electorate if we succeed to replace (Prime Minister James) Marape. “I have had the privilege of running this country for eight years and I am at the end of my career to which I would like to retire and move on. “But I am remaining in politics because I see that the way our country is being managed, everything is being politicised. “Everything is being compromised from politics to public service to every institution of Government.” Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa said they were going to court as “we want to see change happen in the country”. “The motion was signed by 22 MPs (including 17 Opposition MPs) that shows confidence in the Opposition. “If Government cannot entertain this, what are they afraid of? They have the numbers, test your numbers.” Abau MP Sir Puka Temu said that Speaker Job Pomat had defied the decision of the committee which sat on Wednesday by calling another meeting yesterday. “Our opinion is that there can be one more motion before the amended Section 145 comes into effect. “We complied with everything. That motion should have been put on the notice paper today (Thursday). We should have risen for seven days and come back.  We are very disappointed.”
People: Douglas Tomuriesa, Job Pomat, Puka Temu

Title: Integration of data from state agencies crucial: Marape
Content: PRIME Marape James Marape says that the integration of population data from all agencies is crucial in updating a common roll that is credible for use in the 2027 General Election (GE27). Marape said the Government would implement reforms in the next 18 months including the introduction of the biometric and identification-based voting, appointing a new electoral commissioner, and cleaning up the common roll. “In 2026, we will use the national census data to clean up the common roll to ensure every eligible citizen is properly registered,” he said. “Our goal is to have a reliable biometric or ID-based voting system in place by 2027. “Our people deserve to exercise their constitutional right to vote freely, without undue influence.” He was responding to Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa’s query about the Government’s plan to improve the electoral system, particularly through an updated common roll. Tomuriesa said this was necessary given the current push for electronic and biometric voting in GE27. “We have about 18 months to go before the next election and I have not seen one update of the common roll,” he said. “We have seen a lot of failed elections because of this, so we cannot leave the update of the common roll until the last minute. “What guarantee can you provide to voters and citizens of a fair and free election through an updated common roll?” Marape said the Electoral Commission would be allocated substantial funding in the 2026 National Budget to cater for early election preparations. He said that 2026 would be focusing on integrating data between the National Statistical Office and the Electoral Commission, improving logistic and fixing election integrity measures. “Every citizen has a responsibility to make sure they are enrolled to vote. When the Common Roll update begins, make sure your name is on it. This is your democratic right,” Marape said.

Title: Government looking to address country’s poor health outcomes
Content: A UNIVERSITY of Medicine and Health Sciences has been set up following Parliament’s passing by an absolute majority of a Bill yesterday. Prime Minister James Marape, in welcoming the initiative, said: “There is no greater investment than investing in doctors, laboratory technicians, and the health infrastructure of our nation. “PNG faces many challenges in the health sector. At one point during the Covid-19 pandemic, our country of almost 10 million people had only 44 oxygen-ventilated beds and a doctor-to-patient ratio of roughly one to 20,000. This new institution is a structural readjustment that will help bridge that gap.” The new university, expected to be operational by 2030, will take over the functions managed under the University of PNG School of Medicine and Health Sciences. Higher Education, Research, Science, Technology and Sports Minister Kinoka Feo said PNG had 0.58 per cent health workers per 1,000 population, when compared with Fiji’s 2.23 per cent and Samoa’s 2.74 per cent. “We have 16 community health worker training schools, 15 nursing colleges and only two universities delivering medical officer training programmes,” Feo said. He said 30 per cent of skilled health workers occupied administrative roles rather than direct patient care. “Our capacity to train health staff has declined significantly over the last 24 years with newly qualified staff production well below workforce attrition rates,” he said. “Our maternal mortality ratio remains high at 171 per 100,000 lives births, which is among the highest in the Western Pacific region.” Meanwhile the infant mortality is 33 deaths per 1,000 live births and 40 per cent are approaching retirement age. Feo said the university would establish a research center of excellence to set up research standards for PNG-relevant clinical research, focus on diseases and health challenges, generate evidence-based solutions to improve peoples’ health outcomes.

Title: Bus and taxi fares up by 60 and 40 per cent respectively from Jan 1
Content: BUS and taxi fares will go up by 60 per cent and 40 per cent respectively from Jan 1. This will increase the city route fares of PMVs from K1 and K2 to K1.60 and K2.60 respectively. The Independent Consumer and Competition Commission (ICCC) said the main cause for the hike is the increase in fuel costs. It said bus fares will be implemented in phases, 20 per cent annually for the first three years of the five-year regulatory period. Likewise, increase in taxi fares will also be implemented in phases by 16 per cent, 14 per cent and 10 per cent for the first three years of the five-year regulatory period. In addition, to this upfront increase, fares will be subject to annual adjustments linked to changes in fuel prices and the Underlying Consumer Price Index (CPI). The ICCC has proposed that a 60 per cent weighting in the adjustment formula will be allocated to fuel reflecting its dominant share in operator costs, particularly PMVs, while the CPI component will represent 40 per cent of the adjusted fares, capturing broader cost drivers. Acting ICCC chief executive Officer Jack Timi said that PMVs and taxis were a vital component of PNG’s transportation system, particularly for people who do not own private cars. They fill a critical gap by providing accessible transport in urban and non-urban areas, connecting people to services and economic opportunities. “Most importantly, the draft report contains the proposed PMV and taxi fares that will be applied starting Jan 1,” he said. “Given its importance, the ICCC commenced a pricing review into the PMV and taxi industry earlier this year, calling for submissions from all stakeholders as part of the consultation process,” Timi said. He said the draft report contains ICCC’s preliminary findings and draft determinations for setting the PMV and taxi fares for the next regulatory period (2026-2030). Other key findings from the review are: Timi has urged all PMV and taxi owners, operators, PMV associations, commuters, Government agencies and the general public to provide their written comments and submissions on ICCC’s draft determinations. All the comments and submissions provided will help ICCC to complete the review process and release a final report before the end of this year, containing the final determinations.

Title: Department probes law firm
Content: JUSTICE Minister and Attorney-General Pila Niningi has tasked his department to investigate a law firm in Madang over allegations of it claiming funds from a district development authority (DDA) in the province. Niningi said this in response to Bogia MP Robert Naguri in Parliament yesterday asking for clarification on the practice by the law firm which claimed funds from the Bogia DDA through a garnishee order – a method of enforcing a court judgment allowing the recovery of money from the judgment debtor. Naguri called for an investigation into the law firm in question, asking if such a practice was legal or illegal. “There is a law firm in Madang that has taken my district to court over some false claims,” he said. “The National Court in Madang has awarded the law firm a garnishee order and it has walked to the bank and got those monies. “This particular lawyer has found an easy way to make quick money so I would like you to ask the people of Bogia and the rest of the MPs if this is legal. “If it is illegal, what will the PNG Law Society do to this particular law firm in Madang?” In response, Niningi said this was a serious concern raised and his department would investigate the law firm. He added that some lawyers had gone into such practice to solicit money without the knowledge of the people they are meant to help. “This has happened in other districts as well so I will ask the department to investigate the matter,” he said. “I will come back to you on how we can straighten this issue once the investigation is complete.” Madang MP Bryan Kramer then asked a supplementary question, urging Niningi to also consider making amendments to the DDA Act to prevent such practices from happening again. “The only appropriate action that you can take is that you amend the DDA Act that says that lawyers cannot garnish DDA accounts, just like they cannot garnish the State. “Instead of the long process to investigate, you just make the amendments to address this issue,” Kramer said. Niningi said all possible options had to be considered before finding the best approach to take.
People: Bryan Kramer, Pila Niningi, Robert Naguri

Title: Minister tells districts, provinces to work with DIRD
Content: FINANCE Minister Thomas Opa is encouraging districts and provinces to work with the Implementation and Rural Development Department to start using the Bilum project. “It’s a good initiative, and it takes into consideration the transparency and accountability of public funds,” he said. This, he said, in response to Wabag MP Dr Lino Tom questioning what the government was doing in terms of accountability on allocated funds, given that there have been issues of ghost projects for which funding was sought. He (Tom) questioned Opa if he was aware of a former system that over 15 years no district had implemented and if there was an efficient system in place to track projects around the country. “Under Finance, there is an agency responsible for the appropriation of the national budget, and we take things seriously on the disbursement of public funds,” Opa said. “Now, in terms of the Bilum project, all provinces, district and others must sign up and start using this platform. “This takes into consideration the transparency and accountability of government-allocated funding. “We have stopped all claims to Finance, and we don’t deal with that culture anymore. “All claims must now be diverted to the provincial government, agencies, departments making reference to “you go there”. “Over the last six months, we have been appropriating money to provincial health authorities, education sector, districts and provinces among others, as PM has alluded to. “In terms of district services improvement programme funds and provincial services improvement programmes, we have 95 per cent completed and our strategy is that all Opposition and government MPs will have all their funds retired in full by end of November. “There are a lot of reforms taking place, and we are looking at the e-government, so we can monitor the appropriation of our government.” Opa said MPs should work together to ensure the reforms are fully implemented.

Title: More foreigners arrested for alluvial mining in Morobe
Content: ANOTHER 44 Chinese nationals have been arrested at different locations outside Lae following an operation by PNG Immigration and Citizenship Services Authority and police, says Lae metropolitan commander Chief Supt Chris Kunyanban. Kunyanban said some of those who were arrested allegedly came on visas to do certain work but breached their visas by engaging in alluvial mining activities. All those who were arrested were alleged to have breached several provisions under the Migration Act and the Employment of Non-Citizens Act. On Tuesday, 105 Chinese nationals were arrested, locked up at Lae Central police station cell and were later sent to Port Moresby and are now at the Bomana detention centre. As of yesterday, the 44 who were arrested were still held at Lae Central police station and will be sent to Port Moresby in due time, according to Supt Kunyanban. “After the arrests of the first 105, some of those expatriates went into hiding. Police made a follow up raid on Wednesday and arrested the 44 expatriates. We believe more are still there and more arrests are expected in coming days and weeks,” Kunyanban said. At this stage, police are only detaining the expatriates. Kunyanban said police had no powers to intervene. He said the operation in this issue will still continue following complaints from the people over the years about localised jobs and businesses being taken over by expatriates. Kunyanban thanked Deputy Prime Minister and Immigration Minister John Rosso for taking a bold stance on the issue, resulting in the arrests of the expatriates. He explained to landowners who might have been affected due to this exercise that the government was only following the laws. He said that if foreigners wanted to come into the country for work or any other businesses, they have to abide by the laws of the country.

Title: 3 arrested in Central
Content: CENTRAL police yesterday arrested two men including a ward councilor for damaging a ballot box at Beroro polling booth at the Vanapa Brown area along the Hiritano Highway. They are detained at 15 Mile police station. Assistant police commissioner National Capital District and Central Benjamin Turi said the three will be charged under the Election Offences Act. He said the Electoral Commissioner would decide later whether the election will be held in the area. He said except this incident, the election in Central had been trouble-free. “We received positive results from all the districts in the province, with more than five ward councilors declared,” he said. Turi said police officers had been carrying out normal duties, monitoring polling booths in the province. “I want to thank the people of Central for the past three days of peaceful polling,” Turi said. While acknowledging the good work of both the police and the public, he also called on those who are traveling to witness the polling and counting not to disturb the peaceful election process that is currently ongoing. “Let the people elect their leaders independently. Police will not hesitate to arrest those who disturb the LLG election. “The three individuals who were arrested and detained will appear in court when their court files are ready,” he said.

Title: Counting starts in Central Pomio LLG
Content: COUNTING has been underway in several wards across East New Britain’s Pomio District following the commencement of polling on Monday. The polling exercise began simultaneously in all seven local level governments (LLGs) within the district, with some polling teams in West Pomio and Central Pomio LLGs moving swiftly into counting and even making unofficial declarations for a number of ward seats on the same day. Pomio district has a total of 119 ward seats and seven LLG seats being contested in this year’s elections. However, two ward seats- Lau and Puapal, both in West Pomio LLG, were declared failed after their nominated candidate passed away following the nomination period. Additionally, the district recorded 26 unopposed ward member seats, inclusive of the two failed wards. Pomio election coordinator Joshua Jeremiah, confirmed that counting had started in several wards on the first day and described the start of the polling as smooth and largely free of disruptions. He noted that polling teams were able to carry out their duties efficiently, with communities cooperating well throughout the process. Polling and counting activities continued into the second day on Tuesday, with election officials working to ensure transparency and timely completion of the process across all remaining wards in the district.

Title: 2022 roll used in polling
Content: POLLING for the 22 local level governments (LLGs) in Southern Highlands are using the 2022 voters’ common roll instead of the 2025 updated rolls, says election manager Grace Wong. Wong said this earlier this week before distributing the polling materials to the LLGs. Wong said the decision was reached by the provincial advisory committee after assessing complaints raised by the LLGs with their wards regarding allegations of inflated figures on the updated rolls, both for existing and new wards, particularly for Nipa-Kutubu electorate. Wong said she agreed with the decision reached through consensus and added that for the new wards that had figures reaching more than 1,000, the number of ballot papers were reduced to half. She said everyone agreed to the decision reached and polling was in progress in all the LLGs. Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai had directed the election manager to reach a decision that would not affect the integrity of the election in a letter dated Oct 29. Meanwhile, the unopposed candidate, Peter Alega, of ward two in the Kagua LLG had signed all the first preference votes for himself on Wednesday. Alega, after signing all the ballot papers to himself, thanked the people of Rogoma and the potential candidates for putting their trust in him to be the ward member without a race. In a small gathering in the presence of the election and security officials, Alega said being declared unopposed among the rest of the 30 wards, was history for him, ward two and Kagua LLG. He said he was looking forward to working with the people at the community government in addressing their development needs. Owen Rombala, an elite of Rogoma, congratulated Alega as being the unopposed ward two member. Rombala said Alega will formally be declared at Kagua station later when all counting for Kagua LLG are completed. The one-person polling started at 8am and concluded at 9am. Meanwhile, the neighboring Erave LLG with its 28 wards was the second last LLG in Southern Highlands to get their polling materials from Mendi police station on Wednesday. It was hoped that Erave would start its polling today.

Title: Department urged to revoke 14 new wards
Content: LEADERS behind the staging of protests against the local level government (LLG) polling in Jiwaka’s Anglimp South-Waghi have called on the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs to revoke the 14 new wards. John Kumb, who is the chairman of the protesting committee, in a gathering of leaders at Anglimp on Wednesday, said the Tuesday’s event involving communities from Kudzip to Komun would not have happened if authorities would seriously look into the matter. Kumb said community leaders with their people in Anglimp LLG saw and felt that current leaders created the wards by hijacking processes. He said nine of the 14 wards are in Wara Tuman zone where local MP and Minister for Correctional Services Joe Kuli comes from while five are in Peng zone. “The population in Tuman zone is not bigger than Peng zone,” he said. The seven leaders from both Anglimp and Kuna Komun raised the same concern that for polling to proceed, the 14 new wards should be excluded and the 2022 electoral roll be used. That was the announcement made by Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai on Tuesday after going through the petition, allowing polling to proceed in other areas.

Title: Five held over illegal roadblocks
Content: POLICE arrested five persons from Jiwaka’s Anglimp-South Waghi for allegedly setting up multiple of illegal roadblocks along the Highlands Highway on Tuesday. Provincial police commander Chief Insp Laimo Asi, who with six of his officers were attacked by a mob in Kuli, confirmed that the five were arrested and were in police custody. Asi said those arrested would be charged under the Anti-Terrorism Act. He also called on Anglimp local level government president Nicholas Kurua to identify those suspects involved in attacking the police. Asi explained that the roadblocks set up by the people of Anglimp and Komun were illegal because no prior police clearance was sought. Also illegal was the protest in Banz on Monday, he said. Asi added that police were keeping a close watch on Anglimp-South Waghi, and police and other security reinforcements from within the Highlands would be called in to deal with any similar incidences. Meanwhile, local leaders from Anglimp and Komun, in a gathering on Wednesday, apologised to Asi and his officers. Senior councillor Elvis Lo said the community would formally apologise to Asi and his men for the injuries they sustained when attacked by youths at Kuli. Elvis Lo said there was a long-standing dispute between the police and the community since 2022, where police allegedly shot and killed four youths, and injured 28 others in an election-related issue. He said the matter, though being pursued by the police hierarchy, did not come out with any results. The youths were understood to be upset over this and that resulted in them attacking the police.

Title: Relatives want answers from police after man found dead
Content: RELATIVES of a man from Jiwaka who was found dead on Oct 14 at Brown River handed a petition yesterday to police demanding answers within five days The man was identified by police as Aiwa Ape, a 62-year-old from North Waghi, Bokapai village who was reported missing earlier this month. Ape’s first-born son Hilary Aiwa said their father, who was working for the National Narcotics Bureau, was on his way to work when the incident happened. “We thank the PPC and his police officers for bringing in the suspects,” Hilary said. “They chained him and cut off his legs and threw him into a bag and hung it on a tree, something not worth describing.” “That act didn’t settle well with us but we want the law to take its cause. “We only want peace.” According to police, five suspects were arrested after they were notified through social media. Hilary said they had not received any support from Central leaders since the incident. “This shows how disrespectful these people are, and the family demands a good explanation from the community leaders, including the national leaders,” he said. “The vehicle had been in the village for days, and no one bothered to report it to the police until the police, after seeing aFacebookpost, went and recovered the vehicle.” The family in their petition are demanding Governor Rufina Peter and Hiri-Koiari MP Keith Iduhu to come forward and address the issue and the family on how they can repatriate Ape’s body to Jiwaka. They also demanded the vehicle be fixed and returned and K1 million from the suspects for the killing. Central police commander Supt Joseph Salle said the criminal investigation division team was on the case. “Our approach is we believe the leaders will respond. “We appeal for peace among everyone and we want everyone to work with us,” Salle said. “Police investigation is in progress. Police are doing their best to ensure justice is served.” He said the family should work closely with police and should not disturb the witnesses who would assist the police.

Title: Authorities in ENB close four Asian shops
Content: FOUR shops operated by Asian business owners in East New Britain’s Kokopo have been ordered to close after inspections   revealed serious health and building hazards regarded a threat to customers and employees. The Kokopo-Vunamami urban local level government (KVULLG) condemned the premises after findings confirmed major building and health safety violations. The affected shops include NBI Supermarket, Talina Trading, Islands Supermarket and JJ Mart, all located along the Kokopo beachfront. According to Kokopo City manager Alkan Mararang, the decision was made after comprehensive environmental health inspections carried out by KVULLG environmental health officers. Inspections were conducted on March 11 for NBI Supermarket, Talina Trading, and Islands Supermarkets, and on Jan 9, for JJ Mart. “These defects pose serious risks to the public, occupants and workers,” Mararang said. “The environment was not conducive for occupation.” He said the action was taken in response to formal complaints from the East New Britain physical planning board, the building board, and the KVULLG Business Licensing Committee, which raised concerns about the deteriorating state of the buildings. The poor condition of the buildings created potential dangers such as fire, electrocution, structural collapse and the spread of infectious diseases. Mararang said notices were issued prior to the closure, but the tenants failed to take any action to improve the conditions. “They were given a grace period of three months to vacate, but they did not comply, so in June the buildings were closed permanently,” he said. However, Mararang confirmed that JJ Mart has since complied with KVULLG’s directives and is carrying out demolition and reconstruction to meet building safety and health standards. He added that as the responsible authority, KVULLG will uphold the decision to close the facilities. “We will work with the landlord to ensure the buildings are removed and proper facilities are constructed in accordance with the building board guidelines,” Mararang said. “We need to address this and get it sorted out.”

Title: MP urges Kapavore to conduct inquiry into Angau affairs
Content: WAU-Waria MP Marsh Narewec wants Health Minister Elias Kapavore to instruct the Health Matters Committee to conduct an inquiry into the affairs of Angau Memorial Provincial Hospital in Lae. “Angau hospital serves eight provinces and it is a transit point for all Highlands and Madang,” Narewec said. “So it is an important hospital in the country. “You cannot solve all the problems on your own. “Therefore, you need the help of parliamentarians in this area.” Narewec, in support of the questions raised in Parliament by other MPs on the state of affairs of Angau, said given the ongoing blackouts and a lack of medical facilities and medicines to the hospital, this was now an urgent matter. “I’d like Kapavore to advise the chairman to conduct an inquiry into the hospital as this is clearly not only a power issue,” Narewec said. “It seems we have management issues, logistics problems, a lack of medical supplies, and other issues. “As minister concerned, you have the directive to advise the chairman in Parliament to conduct the enquiry. “We can bring the chief executive officer of PNG Power Ltd to the inquiry, all other concerned stakeholders, the public health authorities and question them to see where the problems lie,” Narewec explained. “We need support to get the chairman of health matters to treat Angau as a special case. “There are many people who would want to come and be a part of this enquiry.” He said this could be open to the public of Morobe and so they could listen to what was actually happening to the hospital.

Title: Police prioritise manpower increase
Content: POLICE Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr says increasing the manpower of the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary is a priority before General Election 2027. He said plans were in place to beef up the number of policemen in the country to 10,000 officers in the next two years. Tsiamalili said this in response to Moresby North-East MP John Kaupa in Parliament on Wednesday, who had asked if there were any plans to address the country’s ongoing law and order issues before the next general election. “Our country’s law and order situation has gone worse,” Kaupa said. “And now we have less than a year before the next general election in 2027. “Are we prepared for that in terms of security? “What is the preparation like for our security in the provinces, districts and the capital city? “How are we going to do that? “If you have a plan, you have to tell us.” In response, Tsiamalili said the Government had invested significantly to improve the constabulary’s capacity in the last six years, particularly in infrastructure development for the police force. “The Government has made it clear to increase the numbers of our police force,” he said. “We have also invested significantly in the infrastructure for the police right across the country. “Yes, 2027 is just before us, so we will continue to make significant investments in our police force. “We are on target to increasing our numbers to around 10,000 regular policemen. “We are equipped to be ready by 2027 and beyond that.” Tsiamalili said a collaborative effort between the provinces and districts was needed to boost police numbers and address law and order issues in the country. “We will continue to try and address the most of the challenges to do with law and order in the country,” he said. “We lack strong middle management policing for operations in our districts and provinces. “This requires partnership and working collaboratively to address our law and order issues.”

Title: Rosso attends annual Apec meet in Seoul
Content: DEPUTY Prime Minister John Rosso is currently attending this week’s annual Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) Leaders’ Meeting in Seoul, South Korea on behalf of Prime Minister James Marape. Rosso said Papua New Guinea’s attendance at Apec remained crucial as it provided an important platform for the country to engage with regional partners, advance national interests, and attract investment opportunities. “Apec is an important forum for Papua New Guinea to engage directly with some of the world’s largest economies on matters that impact our region and our people,” Rosso said. “Our active participation ensures PNG continues to be part of discussions on inclusive growth, trade facilitation, and sustainable development,” he said. The Apec Economic Leaders’ Meeting brings together headsof government and senior leaders from the 21 member economies to discuss key global and regional economic issues, strengthen trade and investment ties and promote sustainable growth across the Asia-Pacific region.

Title: ENB’s Yalam road work nearing completion
Content: WORK on the first five kilometres of Raunsepna Transit to Yalam village road in Gazelle’s rural Lassul-Baining local level government area of East New Britain is nearing completion. Civil Works supervisor with the East New Britain Division of Infrastructure and Transport, Benson Tamgoi said the cost of the project was K1, 498 million and was funded by the ENB government through its Provincial Services Improvement Programme (PSIP) funds. The project was awarded to local civil contractor, Atlumas Civil and Construction Limited. Tamgoi said the project was progressing well, and plans were in place to begin the next phase, which would cover the remaining nine kilometres to Yalam. Tamgoi said that work on the road was about 60 per cent complete which included clearingand grubbing of the first five kilometres were almost done and road gravelling had so far covered 800 metres. They expected to complete the remaining 4.2km soon for road gravelling. He said once the road reached Yalam, the next goal would be to connect Yalam to Komgi village, however, the main challenges were the weather and difficult terrain, which caused delays as the contractor could not work during heavy rains. He said that ongoing work had already brought relief to locals from Yalam and Raunsepna areas, who had begun accessing the cleared sections of the road. ENB Governor Michael Marum assured all Baining communities within Lassul-Baining LLG would benefit from this road service.

Title: Marape reaffirms Pukpuk Treaty
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has reaffirmed that the recently- signed Papua New Guinea-Australia Mutual Defence Treaty, known as the Pukpuk Treaty, is a forward-looking sovereign decision by PNG to strengthen its national defence capacity and regional security posture while deepening the country’s historic relationship with Australia. Marape said this when responding to questions raised by Hiri-Koiari MP Keith Iduhu in Parliament yesterday. Iduhu questioned why the treaty was not tabled and debated in Parliament before it was signed and why there were no consultations. “Why the rush. Were there extreme circumstances where the people should be aware of?” he asked. “Is PNG under threat and are we going to war? Does it align more with Australian issues than PNG’s?” He also said how the treaty stabilised threats from within, given the ongoing tribal fights and other problems arising from the Connect PNG Programme. “There are also discussions about recruitment for permanent residents in Australia, it’s not for all Papua New Guineans. “Does that include the general upkeep of Goldie Barracks staff and trainees?” he asked. Iduhu said it seemed like the treaty changed PNG’s non-aligned foreign policy by legally obligating it to defend Australia as if they needed our help. Marape clarified that the treaty was initiated at PNG’s request, constructed within the bounds of the Constitution, and did not compromise Papua New Guinea’s sovereignty in any way. “As prime minister, I am the No.1 security officer of this country,” he said. “My foremost duty is to protect our people from external and internal threats. “This treaty was not imposed on us – we asked for it because it elevates the capacity of our Defence Force to stand alongside one of the region’s most capable and trusted defence partners.” Marape assured the House that the treaty fully complies with Section 206 of the PNG Constitution and the Visiting Forces Act of 1975, which provides the legal basis for Defence Cooperation with foreign forces. “Our founding fathers created those provisions knowing that as a young nation we would need to cooperate with trusted partners,” Marape explained. “This treaty sits firmly within that Constitutional framework. Once all checks by the state solicitor and relevant agencies are completed, it will come before Parliament for debate and ratification under Section 117 – as required by law.” Marape said the treaty represents the culmination of nearly five decades of Defence Cooperation between the two nations, beginning with the Status of Forces Agreement (1977) and later the Defence Cooperation Agreement (2013). The Pukpuk Treaty now lifts that relationship to the highest level – a mutual defence treaty that ensures shared responsibility for Regional Peace and Security. He emphasised that PNG must build a modern, well-resourced Defence Force capable of safeguarding its 10 million-plus persons, 462,840 square kilometres of land, and more than three million square kilometres of maritime and airspace. “Our nation is not small,” Marape said. “We have a vast ocean, a long border, and a growing population. “Over the next 10 years, we will systematically grow our PNG Defence Force to 7,000 men and women in uniform and 3,000 reservists. “With the treaty, we also create pathways for up to 10,000 Papua New Guineans to train and serve within the Australian Defence Force, building skills that will return home to strengthen our own capacity.” The treaty will enhance PNG’s Defence capability across land, air, and sea domains, including maritime surveillance, air mobility, technology transfer, and joint training. “This partnership does not erode our sovereignty – it strengthens it,” Marape said. “Our Defence Force will always report to the commander of the PNG Defence Force. “Australians and Papua New Guineans serving under the Australian Defence Force, will report to their own commander. “We train and operate side-by-side, but sovereignty is never compromised.” Marape said the treaty acknowledges PNG’s right to maintain defence relationships with other nations and is guided by the principles of non-alignment, transparency, and accountability. “No bilateral partner has raised any objection,” Marape noted. “Every mature nation recognises the sovereign right of independent states to choose partners they trust. “Geography and history bind us to Australia – we share a neighbourhood and a destiny.” Marape described the treaty as a strategic investment in national security for future generations, enabling PNG to respond effectively to modern challenges including border incursions, transnational crime, illegal fishing, terrorism, and natural disasters. “The Pukpuk Treaty is not about geopolitics – it’s about securing our home,” Marape said. “Just as Israel’s long-term alliance with the United States has ensured its survival and strength, Papua New Guinea’s partnership with Australia will anchor our stability and growth for decades to come.” He also confirmed that the Government’s broader security agenda will include rebuilding the Police Force, Correctional Services, and national law and justice institutions, so that “our entire security sector rises together”. Marape paid tribute to Australia as PNG’s “foundational partner,” noting that the relationship is rooted in shared values of democracy, faith, and mutual respect. “From the womb of Australia, we were birthed into our sovereign nationhood in 1975,” Marape reflected. “Fifty years on, Australia has never abandoned us. “This treaty reaffirms that enduring bond – not as subservient partners, but as equals standing side-by-side, protecting our common home.” Marape concluded by reaffirming his commitment to national unity, constitutional process, and the vision of a self-reliant PNG. “The Pukpuk Treaty is a tree we plant today whose shade future generations will enjoy,” Marape said. “It ensures that our children and their children will inherit a safer, stronger, and more secure PNG – confident in its sovereignty and proud of its partnerships.”

Title: Marape explains his absence from Apec meeting in South Korea
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has commended Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso for representing him at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) Leaders’ Summit in South Korea this month. He also congratulated and thanked the South Korean government for successfully hosting the summit, while highlighting the country’s development success as a model for many developing countries to use. Marape was not able to attend the summit because of parliamentary commitments, and his earlier commitment to the United Nations summit on Climate Change, the Conference of Parties, which he will be attending in Brazil on Monday (Nov 10-21). “I commend the deputy prime minister for representing our country as my envoy to the Apec meeting,” he said. “He did a wonderful job presenting for our country, and I commend his leadership both at the Apec summit and other international forums that he has represented us. “He always rises to the occasion. “I always say the strength of a nation’s economy drives government performances, and our conversation is that all barriers of trade must be taken down and all economies given every opportunity to grow to its full potential to be able to take care of its citizens. “For Papua New Guinea, I continue to strongly advocate for free trade within Apec and outside of it to assist us transition from our over-reliance on aid and grants to exporting our raw – and later – finished products. “We want to become self-sustaining, empowered, full contributing, dignified citizens of the world. “South Korea is the precise venue for hosting an Apec meeting, because of the many lessons it continues to provide on the strength and growth of its economy. “The country was birthed in 1953 out of the remains of war and destitution, but has risen from poverty to a powerhouse Group of 20-member economy that has made its mark in manufacturing, technology and information and communications technology.”

Title: Law panel proposes changes to government system
Content: THE Constitutional and Law Reform Commission (CLRC) has recommended seven changes to the country’s system of government following a two-year consultative process around the country. Prime Minister James Marape, when tabling the CRLRC’s two-volume report in Parliament yesterday, said that the seven recommendations were now up for debate to allow for changes to legislations, including the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Governments and the Constitution. The recommendations in the report titled:“Review of the Form and System of Government”are: The CLRC’s terms of reference which guided the review were summarised as: Of the seven recommendations, the second was made by the CLRC as it found that people did not fully understand the powers and functions of the King as the Head of State. “The commission recommends that the Kind of England be removed as the Head of State and replaced with a Papua New Guinean,” the report stated. “From the consultations, it is clear that most people have not fully understood the powers and functions of the King as the Head of State. “They did not understand that the King as the Head of State is merely a rubberstamp and has no real power. “Further, they did not understand that removing the King as the Head of State will affect PNG’s membership with the commonwealth of nations.” Marape commended the CLRC’s report, saying that it was part of the work of the Government to review the system as part of the 50-year reforms to strengthen the parliamentary, public service and government processes and mechanisms of the country. “This is a well-researched report that demonstrates the extent CLRC has gone to ensure that every opportunity was given for all to participate and contribute their views in the review,” he said. “As a Government, we must not be scared of change, however daunting it may be, especially changes that are necessary for our progress and our future prosperity. “Given the country’s experience in the 2011 political impasse and the corrupt practices of the leaders and bureaucrats, the Head of State needs to be empowered to intervene and that is only possible if the King of England is remove and replaced with a Papua New Guinean. “By removing the Kind as the Head of State and replacing him with someone who will exercise real powers, the country will be satisfied that it is maintaining an office that is established for the good governance of this country. “Symbolically, it will affirm PNG as a truly independent sovereign State resolving any ongoing claims of neo-colonialism being exercised in PNG “Real powers will be vested in the Head of State who would play a figurehead role over the State in terms of governance.”

Title: No bulk fee payment, says UPNG’s Finlay
Content: THE University of Papua New Guinea is willing to return K343,500 to the Eastern Highlands provincial government so it can distribute to students who will now pay individually. Vice-Chancellor Prof Ian Findlay said that the bulk payment by the provincial government had resulted in mishap involving students from the Eastern Highland as reported in the media recently. Findlay said in a statement that UPNG had changed its policy relating to bulk payments and had reverted to students settling their tuition fees individually. Findlay said the policy was necessary because UPNG had more than 7,000 students registered annually in its five schools, as well as a growing number of Open Learning Colleges. Said Findlay: “It is extremely difficult and time consuming to reconcile student accounts with the many types of sponsorship payments, especially when sponsors make bulk payments which don’t identify which students are being sponsored. “This causes substantial delay and disappointment for students.” In January 2023, UPNG published a circular in newspapers informing every one of the new policy. Instead of bulk sponsorship payments that don’t identify students, the public and sponsors were directed that: Findlay said: “The vast majority of sponsors complied. Last year, West New Britain Governor Sasindran Muthuvel and Gulf Governor, Sir Christopher Haiveta asked for clarification which was supplied by then acting vice-chancellor Prof Cecilia Nembou. “However, it now appears that despite the 2023 circular, the East Highlands provincial government has continued to make a bulk payment. “This has caused the confusion. “UPNG confirms that it received K343,500 from the Easter Highlands provincial government on Oct 9. He said UPNG is happy to return these monies to the provincial government so it can distribute to students directly as per the published circular,” he said. “UPNG will also send further reminders to sponsors explaining the new policy.”

Title: Seven policemen assaulted at Jiwaka road block
Content: SEVEN policemen are nursing injuries, and four police vehicles were damaged during a protest by locals along the Highlands Highway in Jiwaka on Tuesday. Jiwaka police commander, Chief Inspector Laimo Asi, said he managed to flee from an attacker armed with an axe. But six of his officers received cuts. Asi said that locals set up roadblocks at Kuli to protest the creation of 14 new wards in the Anglimp and Kuna Komun local level governments. The Kumul 23 Task Force under the command of Anthony Wagambie Jr, Western Highlands command Chief Superintendent John Sagom, and assistant commissioner of police eastern-end Clement Dalla assisted his officers to remove the road block at Kuli and others from Kudzip to Komun. “I am warning people making the false accusations, setting up of road blocks and attacking police personnel that you will be investigated,” he said. He said that they would be charged under the Terrorism Act. He also urged Anglimp LLG president, Nicholas Kurua, to identify the suspects involved in attacking the police.

Title: Juffa urges Kapavore to check companies involved in medical supply
Content: NORTHERN Governor Gary Juffa is urging Health Minister Elias Kapavore to look into the status of medical distribution companies tied to its Northern health authorities. He said it was recommended by a public accounts health inquiry in 2019 that certain companies be removed as there were reports of widespread corruption in the distribution process. “I raise this question because it’s come to my attention that some companies are still operating and still very much involved with the Health Department,” Juffa said. “This particular company is involved in the distribution of drugs and logistics companies. “Now this particular company operating in Popondetta does not have a warehouse, and it gets these from the area store and keeps the stock under the house. “This is making it difficult for the PHA, they are compelled to pay again to get the drugs distributed when these companies are already paid to do so. “The company was highlighted in the inquiry as being one of the bad actors and its contracts should have been terminated at that point, yet it is still engaged and operating,” the Oro governor said. Juffa asked Minister Kapavore, who is also Pomio MP, to look into this and act on the recommendations set by the inquiry. Kapavore said he was fully aware of the 15 recommendations and has established a taskforce to look into this. He said he will be paying a visit to the province next week to check on the progress of the Northern PHA and to confirm its medical supplies.

Title: State aiming to have 100 homes built by year’s end
Content: THE National Housing Corporation (NHC) aims to build 100 houses at the Duran Farm housing project in Port Moresby by the end of the year, Housing Minister Dr Kobby Bomareo says. When presenting the NHC 2024 annual report to Parliament yesterday, Bomareo said the project remained a state priority as it would provide affordable housing for public servants. “Twenty houses are currently being constructed at the Duran Farm project site,” he said. “Ten are being built by the NHC’s newly-established construction and maintenance unit. “The other four houses are being built by Rhodes PNG. “Six more will be constructed before the end of December. “A further 40 houses are slated for construction, reaching 60-plus before the end of 2025.” Outlining the current progress of the project, Bomareo said: “The Duran housing project remains the Government’s flagship initiative aimed at developing a housing estate for public servants,” Bomareo said.

Title: Hospital needs constant power supply, says Health Minister
Content: HEALTH Minister Elias Kapavore wants the Lae business community to step in and help Angau General Hospital ensure power supply is maintained. “We have an ongoing power problem which the hospital cannot financially sustain given the use of almost 5,000 litres of fuel which is required for emergency equipment and general upkeep of the hospital,” he said. He said the current generator is faulty and the hospital has placed an order for a part which will arrive from abroad in three weeks. This was in response to a concern raised by Kabwum MP Patrick Basa on a 20-hour blackout on Oct 18 -19 that cost the lives of seven patients. Basa asked for clarity if this was a PHA problem and if funds were being dispersed then why wasn’t the generator working that day. Kapavore said: “The Government has done its part by providing the funding to the provincial health authorities, but this is a serious issue and we need the help of the business community while we wait on the parts to arrive. “Angau is under Morobe, looking after over one million people over 10 districts and many of the deliveries are coming to Angau like NCD. “Angau is stressed with cancer patients with over 800 people going through. We are forced to take care another 200,000 patients in a year going by the count in 2024. “The Morobe PHA needs to organise their system and sort out primary health care in Lae city. “For the record, to date K347 million, about 68 per cent of funding, has been given to Morobe. “Medical supplies, last two weeks ago, were supplied to Angau and it is now up to those who are accessing it to put in their orders to the transit stores to get their supplies.

Title: HIV infection rate high in women: UNAIDS official
Content: OUT of the estimated 120,000 reported cases of people living with HIV/AIDS in the country, the majority (60 per cent) are women, says UNAIDS country office adviser, Mosende Zimmbodilion. Speaking at the PNG Christian Leaders Media conference in Port Moresby yesterday, Zimmbodilion said nearly half of these women and girls were exchanging sex for money, transport, goods or just to be able to continue their studies. “From our studies some are selling their bodies to male clients to be able to put food on the table for their children and support their families,” Zimmbodilion said. He highlighted that the other half of these women were not sex workers and many of them had no idea how they got infected. “We have no idea why women who were not sex workers were infected. We are guessing that those women and girls’ husbands are clients of female sex workers or their husbands who have sex with other men who also have wives,” he said. Zimmbodilion said from their surveillance, they had determined that three out of 10 or one out of three of married men were also having sex with other men. “But we have no idea what’s the magnitude and that’s why hopefully we can have more surveillance done and identify the root causes why our adult females are getting infected,” he said. Meanwhile, he highlighted that the majority of transmissions of HIV/AIDS virus were sexually transmitted either by male to female, female to male and even male to male. “There is also a significant proportion of transmission from pregnant mothers to their children who are not on treatment,” he said. Meanwhile, he raised concerns that 20 per cent of people living with HIV/AIDS were aware of their status but were not going to the hospital for further test and treatment. “We need to ask, why 20 per cent of infected people even though they know their HIV status and also the availability of Antiretroviral Therapy (ART) drug in nearly 200 clinics in the country, and in almost all districts of the country. “Why are they not taking ART? It’s free, and funded by the government,” he said. He urged everyone to go for HIV/AIDS testing and if they are positive, they would be put on treatment which is free and this can stop the virus from transmitting to their partners. “We have proof that once you are on ART treatment, your viral load can no longer transmit the virus to your partner or baby.”

Title: Morobe roads damaged by alluvial mining activities
Content: WORKS and Highways Minister, Solan Mirisim, is appealing for responsible alluvial mining practices in Wau-Waria and Bulolo areas to avoid sections of the roads being washed out. Mirisim made the appeal, clarifying that the alluvial mining activities along the Bulolo and Watut Rivers, had contributed to siltation, river diversions, and road and bridge embankment erosion that severely undermined the highway, bridge, and drainage crossings. He stated that the department was doing several minor emergency works worth K5 million to repair washed-out sections caused by severe alluvial mining activities. “While the department continues to maintain and upgrade the highway, I appeal to the Bulolo and Wau-Waria MPs, including the Morobe administration, district development authorities, Mineral Resource Authority (MRA) and Kumul Mineral Holdings Ltd to manage and control alluvial mining activities,” Mirisim said. “Control these activities undertaken by the locals and contractors, especially in areas such as Sambio and Pine Tops, where heavy dredging operations are directly damaging the national road infrastructure. “These recurrent road failures are largely man-made disasters, and district level management and enforcement of environment and mining regulations are critical to protecting public infrastructure investments worth millions of Kina,” Mirisim said. He further said that the Government remained fully committed to upgrading and maintaining all strategic national highways, including the Trans-National Highway corridor, as part of the Connect PNG Programme to ensure safe, reliable, and climate-resilient connectivity across the country. He said the department had secured a loan from the Asian Development Bank and the design work between Nentino to Bulolo was in its final stages. He said the Bulolo to Lae was designed under the Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific programme, and design works for Kumalu crossing were fully funded. Funding has been sought from development partners to construct a permanent crossing option. “We are committed to fully rebuilding this important national highway to a class one road.’’

Title: Biometric system to be implemented carefully: Sinai
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai says a biometric system of voting must be implemented through a cautious and phased approach by 2027. “We are committed to innovation and have already piloted technology-based voter registration methods such as photo-roll registration in several locations,” he said. “However, the time and resources available are not adequate to implement full biometric registration, voting and counting by 2027. “Rushing this process carries significant risk and could divert critical funding and attention away from other essential preparations needed for a credible and orderly election.” Sinai said the commission’s photo-roll project had been successfully implemented in New Ireland, East Sepik and Central in previous years, and more recently, the Motu-Koita Assembly elections held in the National Capital District. He said such technology, including that of a biometric system, must not compromise the integrity of the electoral process, calling on all voters and stakeholders to work together to improving election outcomes in the country. “In line with the global trends and regional developments, the Electoral Commission acknowledges the potential of technology to strengthen electoral integrity. “Change is imminent and the Electoral Commission is prepared to to accept and adopt to new innovations and technology by embarking on a system voter identification and enrolment,” Sinai said. “While challenges remain in improving elections and addressing voter concerns, the Electoral Commission is committed to ensuring the successful outcome.”

Title: Long-time residents turned away at polling
Content: ELIGIBLE voters are being sent away because their names are not on the electoral common roll to cast their votes in the 2025 local level government elections. The Nationalhas reached out to a few concerned citizens regarding the issue of people being rejected from the polling booth due to their names not being on the roll. Lae Urban’s ward two presiding officer, Timothy Holingu, said that it was heartbreaking to see people who had grown up together in the same street were sent away. “These people have lived in the area for more than 15 to 20 years,” Holingu said. “They were told ‘no names, no vote’. “I managed to explain properly to them that the error was not conducted by the polling officials, and they are not to be blamed.” He said about 20 voters were sent away. “This error was not supposed to happen because these people have the right to vote,” Holingu said. “We don’t know if the error happened because the common roll was updated or not, but these people were eligible to cast a vote in the 2022 National General Election, but for the LLG elections, their names are not on the list.” The same sentiment was shared by the presiding officer of Bulolo-Urban’s ward three, Kallang Muting. He said polling had been conducted well but the roll update was causing hindrance to the flow of polling as people had been resident for more than 15 years. “But their names are not on the common roll,” he said. “Prior awareness needs to be done before polling starts to ensure everyone is informed of the polling dates and schedule.” The Nationalwas also advised that the same issue happened in Finschhafen and Markham, where a handful of voters were turned away.

Title: K165 million for works on Bulolo Highway
Content: WORKS and Highways Minister Solan Mirisim says the Government has committed about K165 million for the Wau-Bulolo Highway maintenance. Mirisim said 57km of the road is in good condition, and 59km is in “fair to poor condition”. He said the road was being progressively upgraded under the Connect PNG programme and Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific (AIFFP). The department has reduced the scope of work, the 45km section from Lae to Timini Bridge is funded under the AIFFP for K66 million. Miirism said 27km has been sealed to a high standard, and 18km remained to be completed once loan variations are approved by AIFFP. “The project is progressing well under the supervision of the Works and Highways Department and the contractor remains mobilised,” he said. From Timini Bridge to Bangulum Bridge is 33km, which is funded under the Connect programme worth K38 million. Sealing work has started at Timini village and the contractor is working on the site, making steady progress towards Bangulum. From Bangulum Bridge to Pine Top Bridge is another 33km, and the procurement has been completed, and work is starting under Connect PNG phase one budget of K55 million. “Several minor emergency jobs worth K5 million are being undertaken to repair washed out sections caused by severe alluvial mining activities along the Bulolo and Watut Rivers,” Mirisim said. “This government is addressing legacy issues and the Wau-Bulolo Highway is one of those legacy issues that has been neglected by successive governments. We are addressing it at the moment.” Mirisim responded to a petition by Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jr, who raised concern regarding the state of the highway, stating that it has disintegrated into a bush track and is much worse than when funding was provided. Basil was disappointed with the Transport sector support programme and the Works and Highways Department regarding the continuous deterioration of the Wau-Bulolo Highway.

Title: Permanent bridge at last for Burum
Content: A PERMANENT steel bridge was opened last Saturday over the Burum River in Burum-Kuat local level government in Finschhafen, Morobe after four footbridges were washed away over the last 50 years. According to the contractor, the steel bridge has a life-span of 50 years and will serve the more than 30, 000 people of Burum-Kuat, Mongi, neighbouring Pindiu and other areas in the district. Mining Minister and Finschhafen MP Renbo Paita when officially opening the bridge said it was a shared effort from the people themselves, the district development authority and the contractor which saw the bridge constructed. “Without your contributions in one way another, this bridge would never have taken its shape as we witness today,” Paita told the people. He said the next focus will be on developing a hydro project. “This is the sign that we are now ready to push for road constructions and also the hydro projects involving Burum Two, Burum Three and Burum Four hydro projects” Paita appealed at the same time to landowners to prepare for the projects so they can gain maximum benefit.

Title: Governor Pariwa: Pursue Fode studies
Content: Madang Governor Ramsey Pariwa is urging students who completed their national examinations to consider upgrading their marks through Flexible Open Distance Education (Fode) if they do not make it into the formal system. Addressing grade 8 students from the Naru Adventist Primary School in Usino Bundi recently, he said: “This year we sent 20 Fode students to India. “The Fode office in Port Moresby assessed their marks and we paid for their school fees and sent them and we will look at increasing the number up to 40. “Those of you who have dropped out of the formal system last year and are in the village doing nothing, I encourage you to go and upgrade your marks through Fode.” Pariwa also presented a cheque of K40,000 to support the school to build a four-in-one double classroom. Pariwa told the students, teachers and school board who gathered last Friday that his government prioritised education in the province and has created opportunity to support initiatives such as the Sir Peter Barter Scholarship to subsidise school fees for students going to tertiary institutions. The Naru Adventist Primary is a new school established in 2011 with a total of 199 students currently enrolled from elementary prep to grade 8.

Title: NCD health authority, City Pharmacy team up
Content: CITY Pharmacy Limited (CPL) partners with National Capital District health authority (NCDPHA) to provide better accessible healthcare products to the public. The partnership agreement will see the construction of new City Pharmacy and Bon Café outlets built on hospital premises under the Build Operate Transfer (BOT) model. NCDPHA chief executive officer, Dr Robin Oge said that this partnership with CPL marked a significant step forward in their mission to strengthen healthcare delivery in Port Moresby. Dr Oge said by leveraging the BOT model, they are not only expanding access to essential pharmaceutical services through outlets like City Pharmacy at Gerehu General Hospital but also ensuring that these facilities ultimately serve the public. “It’s a sustainable model that eases pressure on our hospitals and brings vital services closer to the communities that need them most,” he said. CPL head of pharmacy Pradeep Panda said this partnership with NCDPHA reflected their shared commitment to improving healthcare access and infrastructure for communities across Papua New Guinea. “The Gerehu General Hospital project is a testament to what public-private collaboration can achieve, and we are proud to be part of a solution that benefits both the Gerehu community and the wider Port Moresby population because a key feature is that ultimately, the infrastructure becomes public property,” he said. The private public partnership between provincial health authorities and CPL has enabled the development of already one City Pharmacy store under the BOT model in Kundiawa, Chimbu. Currently, one additional outlet is under construction at Metoreia Hospital, and plans are underway for several more BOT model pharmacies to be established across the country in the coming months, with Gerehu General Hospital now a new addition.

Title: Over 100 expatriate miners arrested in Morobe
Content: A TOTAL of 105 expatriates, of Chinese origin, alleged to have been unlawfully engaged in alluvial mining activities in Morobe were arrested during a joint operation by immigration officials and police on Tuesday. Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Immigration, John Rosso, yesterday said that the 105 expatriates are mainly of Chinese origin. Majority of those that were arrested have been processed and placed in police custody at the Lae Central police station before being transported to Nadzab’s Tomodachi International Airport and put on a flight yesterday morning to Port Moresby. “Many of them were found to have breached their visa conditions under the PNG Migration Act and were allegedly working in the alluvial mining sector,” said Rosso. He also said that these 105 expatriates will be processed and assessed carefully and if other PNG laws are seen to have been breached, then they will be charged and fined by the courts depending on which laws they breached. “I am continuing to take a hardline stance on such and foreign nationals in the country should by all means abide by the laws of this country at all costs,” Rosso said. “And if they are found to have breached any law(s) of this country through the courts, they will be fined and deported forthwith.” Rosso further urged all foreigners who are doing business or are on tourist visas in the country to respect the laws governing this country and must abide by these laws at all times to avoid inconveniences during their stay in the country. Chief Migration Officer Wellington Navasivu said the individuals arrived in Port Moresby at mid-day yesterday and will be held in immigration detention awaiting administrative removal from the country. He also said the 105 were apprehended at five illegal mining sites along the Sambio River, Wau Waria. The suspects were found to be in breach of several provisions under the Migration Act and the Employment of Non-Citizens Act. The breach includes working at unauthorised locations, absence of valid work permit documentation, engagement in employment inconsistent with visa conditions and providing false information to immigration officers. Navasivu said the suspects were flown to Port Moresby today and will be held in detention until all administrative processes are completed and they will be removed from the country. “We will ensure the individuals are placed on alert and will not return,” Navasivu gave his assurance. “The company and their sponsors who brought them into the country will be held responsible and necessary administrative and compliance charges will apply”. Alluvial mining is a business activity reserved solely for Papua New Guinea citizens. The Mining Act 1992 requires alluvial mining activities to be licensed and the Mineral Resources Authority has a policy to reserve alluvial mining for citizens.

Title: Patients given Panadol, told to go home
Content: NINE women waiting for surgery at the Angau Memorial General Hospital’s gynaecology and obstetrics ward were given Panadol and told to go home to await their review dates next month. The patients were discharged on Friday because Angau’s sterilisation unit was down, affecting surgeries at the theatre. They were told that there were no drugs and consumables, or basic linens to perform surgery. One of the patients admitted with ovarian cyst toldThe Nationalthat she was taken off solid food in preparation for her operation and her families were called in to donate blood. “I went in to Angau with very high hopes but my hopes crashed when we were discharged without a positive response,” she said. The 60-year-old single mother said she started feeling ill in September. She tried a private hospital first but the total costs was K800 and increasing to more than K1,000. She went to Angau where she was admitted at a general ward and then transferred to the gynaecology and obstetrics ward this month to await surgery to remove the cyst. “I was taken off solids and put on Panadol and drip only in preparation for surgery,” she said. “I had five family members come in to donate blood. “I was happy and mentally prepared to get this over with. “Unfortunately, my happiness was not long-lived. “We were told that the machines are spoilt, lights are off, no oxygen, no tubes, no linens, no threads and needles. “When we asked for a referral so we could check other hospitals, they said no and they did not give any reasons why. “When I enquired about the blood donations under my name, they said blood could only stay fresh for up to a week so they could not do much. “You go home and come back on your review date next month and we’ll figure something out. “I was then given Panadol and discharged, now I’m awaiting my review. “This is not the service average Papua New Guineans should receive anywhere in the country – from the way the doctors speak to the patients to the availability of resources – people’s health is a sensitive and stressful issue that must tread with care.” Morobe health authority chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga said funding was the main bottleneck among reasons for issues at the hospital, including the restoration of sterilisation services. Binga said Angau has a sophisticated sterilisation unit which could only be maintained by technical expertise from Australia. He said this was the second time the unit had gone down, unfortunately, the help cannot be accessed immediately as there was no money. “We’ve communicated with people in Australia and they gave us the cost, but we could not pay because the money for operational   funding is not coming in,” he said, “We are back by three or four months to get our CFCs – we got 50 per cent of our appropriation for this year. “We just received last month’s CFC and we are very grateful; we hope to get one for this month and next month so we can to carry out operations. “That’s a reason why we cannot pay directly for some of the costs to bring service in.” Binga said after redevelopment, Angau was given a budget of K8 million for normal maintenance of the new facility. “This was factored into our recurrent budgets over the years but the reality is that budget appropriation is one thing while getting the actual funds depends,” he said. Binga said Angau has been sending equipment to Goroka General Hospital for sterilisation. He said in the meantime, a technical team from Port Moresby was brought in to set up sterilisation units at Tent City and West Taraka clinics, as well as Bulolo and Mutzing District Hospital. “Management is now seriously looking at purchasing or procuring one sterilisation unit that is user-friendly,” he said.

Title: China ready to implement reasonable governance system, foreign minister Wang says
Content: CHINA is ready to join hands with the international community to fully implement the Global Governance Initiative (GGI), Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi says. He said the initiative built reasonable global governance system and would create a brighter future for humanity. Wang made the remarks while addressing the Lating Forum on improving global governance to build a community with a shared future for humanity, which was held at the Foreign Affairs ministry in Beijing on Monday. He said the GGI builds on the principals of the United Nations (UN) Charter, reflecting the Chinese diplomacy tradition and upholds the vision of a shared future and voice for developing countries. “It also responds to the world’s needs and people’s wishes, a new major global public good contributed by China,” Wang said. He said President Xi Jinping last month put forth the GGI that advocated five concepts: Wang, who is also a member of the Political Bureau of the China Central Communist Party central committee, said this promised much needed stability and received support from over 140 countries and international organisations. “The international community believes that the initiative is a timely call for solidarity in a world threatened by fragmentation,” he said. “The world currently witnesses more than 50 ongoing conflicts, with over 10 million people displaced. Such a world, marked by turbulence, is in greater need of global governance than ever before. “China is ready to work with all parties to put the GGI into action through equal consultation and maximum consensus. “It also calls on all countries to engage with the UN on the cooperation agendas across poverty reduction, infrastructure, education and health.”

Title: Drug shortage forces clinic to scale down operations
Content: A CLINIC in Lae has been closed for a week due to shortage of medical supplies, with all emergency cases referred to Angau General Hospital. The Sir Bob Sinclair clinic in Lae’s ward two has been closed for a week now due to medical drug shortage. PNG Family Health Association regional coordinator Mavia Mumuan, who manages the clinic, said they were only providing family planning and maternal and child health services. Morobe Health Authority chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga said they were assessing the situation and have consulted the board to either scale down or close services. Morobe Administrator Max Bruten told The National that the provincial government would meet the remaining operational grants to the Morobe Health Authority. “I will not state the exact amount but I can confirm that we will give funding to assist with the drug shortage and pay fuel for generator at Angau Memorial General Hospital,” Bruten said.

Title: Villagers in Aitape-Lumi call on government to fix road
Content: Eritei villagers in Aitape-Lumi’s West Wape LLG are calling on the government to help them rebuild their roads under the Connect PNG programme in order to access basic services. Demas Metine said the Aitape-Lumi development authority has turned a blind eye on the struggle faced by the community. “They (villagers) are struggling every day for basic services and also needs and wants,” he said. “Since Aitape-Lumi MP (Anderson Mise) took office after the by-election, he never went back to visit the district.” Metine said the community was suffering silently because the only road linking their village in West Wape LLG’s ward 15 and Vanimo has deteriorated and was inaccessible. Men from the village recently carried two solar dryers for vanilla and walked for two days from Karate village to reach Eritei. The solar dryers were funded by European Union Support to Rural Entrepreneurship, Investment and Trade in Papua New Guinea (EU-Streit PNG) for vanilla farmers in Eritei villagers. “We are suffering because of no proper roads. When will the government help us?” he said. “Aitape-Lumi lacks infrastructure development – poor roads and bridges. We’re tired.” He said 50 years on after the country’s independence, life was still a struggle for them.

Title: Marape slams O’Neill: He is misguided
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has hit back at his predecessor Peter O’Neill, describing the latter’s attacks on his government as “misguided and selective”. He said that O’Neill’s criticism of his government’s performance was akin to the “pot calling the kettle black” – someone criticising another for a fault they share. Said Marape: “We picked up the country he destroyed, and now we are putting it back on a path of growth. It was a K79 billion economy when we took office in 2019. Despite global crisis and giving so much tax relief to businesses and workers, our economy has grown to over K130 billion – adding more than K50 billion in such tough times.” He said that the Government’s prudent management and policy interventions had restored investor confidence, unlocked stalled projects, and positioned PNG as a stronger, more resilient economy. “Ask ADB, IMF, World Bank, Westpac, ANZ, BSP, the Central Bank or even our own superfunds like Nasfund and Nambawan Super. “They will all confirm that our economy today is far improved compared to the declining days from 2014 to 2018 when our economy was in recession,” Marape said.
