Marape pointed out that under his leadership, resource projects such as Porgera, Papua LNG, P’nyang, Pasca A and Wafi-Golpu had been renegotiated to secure a fairer share of benefits for the State and landowners. “Unlike in the past, where major resource projects were signed with minimal returns to our people, this Government has made it mandatory that Papua New Guinea gets better equity, better local content, and better long-term value,” he said. He said that the projects, valued at more than K300 billion in total investment, would create jobs, boost exports, and strengthen foreign reserves. The Government has also delivered key reforms and infrastructure investments that benefit the people, including tuition-free education fully restored, with budget allocations for secondary and tertiary education. In health, Marape said that new district hospitals and community health posts had been built or upgraded in more than 50 districts, including the East Sepik Provincial Hospital, Enga Provincial Hospital, Boram Hospital, Mendi Provincial Hospital, and major upgrades at the Port Moresby General Hospital. On law and order, Marape said that there was increased funding for the police, judiciary and Correctional Services, plus new police housing programme and the strengthening of the Independent Commission Against Corruption and judiciary infrastructure. He also pointed out that more than 6,000 kilometres of roads were rehabilitated or constructed since 2019. There is also continued investment in Connect PNG and national energy grid projects, plus port upgrades in Lae, Port Moresby and other regional centres. Responding to O’Neill’s comments on debt and foreign assistance, Marape clarified that all borrowing under his Government has been transparent, concessional, and directed toward nation-building, unlike previous commercial loans that lacked accountability. He said that the International Monetary Fund (IMF), World Bank, Asian Development Bank (ADB), and the Australian Government had partnered with PNG under strict conditions of transparency and fiscal discipline – a sign of restored international confidence in PNG’s governance.

Title: PM tells Nomane to show receipts
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has asked Chuave MP James Nomane to produce records of payments by the Government to the district. Marape said that in the past three years, Chuave received more than K40 million. And last year and this year, it was paid the Service Improvement Programme (SIP) funding of K10 million annually. “It’s been six years in a row (that) we have been fair to all districts. “And MPs in the Opposition know that they have received their payments on the District Service improvement programmes (DSIP),” he said. Marape was responding to Nomane’s question in Parliament on why his district was being ignored in the budget and if it was intentional. Nomane said it was unacceptable that Chuave received only K8.8 million in functional grants over nine months, which was only 25 per cent of what it was due. Marape had said last week that in the past six years, K56 billions of public funds had been spent with no results. Nomane questioned Marape on when Chuave was going to receive its K10 million funding. Marape said: “The K56 million I made reference to does not include recurrent component. It talks about the quantum transferred of money to the district, provinces and sector department and statutory bodies since 2019. “We have been transparent, telling the country how much we have transferred. “We have the Final Budget Outcome from 2018 to 2024 that predicts all administrations are there for public scrutiny, affirms to the people’s house and how the government has delivered on the commitment as far as budget views are concerned.”

Title: 2026 budget will continue government focus: PM
Content: Prime Ministers James Marape says that the 2026 National Budget due this sitting will continue to focus on consolidating growth, reducing debt, and improving service delivery. “The 2026 Budget will show a clear path to fiscal balance, more investment in rural districts, and continued focus on law and order, health, education, and infrastructure,” he said. “We are not here to rewrite history or point fingers. We are here to rebuild our country. I respect all leaders, including O’Neill, but I will let our record and our people’s verdict in 2027 speak for themselves.” Marape reiterated his call for unity and constructive leadership. “Papua New Guinea is not served by negativity. Our people want solutions, not blame. My Government will remain focused on doing what is right — growing the economy, creating jobs, protecting sovereignty, and ensuring no one is left behind.”

Title: Sri Lankan judge to serve three years
Content: A JUDGE of the National and the Supreme courts was sworn in before Acting Governor-General Sir Gibbs Salika at Government House yesterday. Judge Rangajeeva Wimalasena, from Sri Lanka, was appointed to serve three years. He was among three expatriate judges whose appointments were announced by Minister for Justice and Attorney-General Pila Niningi on May 27. Judge Wimalasena recited the oath of declaration of office, loyalty and judicial before Sir Gibbs in the presence of judge Joseph Yagi, and a few members of the National Judicial staff. He was appointed to the Court of Appeal in Nauru, and has worked to strengthen judicial institutions in other countries, including Papua New Guinea. He worked more than 25 years in the legal field, practising as a prosecutor since 1999 in the attorney-general’s department of Sri Lanka. He was then appointed to the bench in Sri Lanka in 2002 and later served in Fiji’s judiciary. Then in 2022 he became a Justice of Appeal in the Nauru Court of Appeal, serving as the president. Following his recital of the oaths, Judge Yagi was sworn in as nominee to the Chief Justice of the Salaries Remuneration Commission (SRC). The role of this nominee is to represent the chief justice (CJ) and to bring in all issues especially on remuneration and speak on behalf of the CJ. Secretary to the SRC Emma Faiteli told The National that the nominees of the SRC is quite powerful as it is made up of leaders of the three arms of government. “The nominees normally step in for the commissioners in their absence.” she said

Title: Health budget intact, says Kapavore
Content: HEALTH Minister Elias Kapavore says funding is not an issue in the critical shortage of medical drugs in hospitals around the country. Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa’s asked Kapavore in parliament yesterday to clarify the concern in hospitals, clinics and aid posts. He also asked if this was due to shortage of funds, management issues or if funds in the budget for health had been diverted to other sectors. Tomuriesa said his queries were based on letters from four provincial health administrators and a recent visit to Alotau General Hospital and statistics on the alarming number of people dying from curable diseases. Kapavore said he was fully aware of what was going on, contradicting the lack of urgency to hospital managements putting up notices to scale down operations, decrease the number of patients and distribution of medicines. He said he was in constant communication with medical supply managers and chief executive officers and getting updated information on what was happening. His report said Government had allocated K295million for medical supplies to go around the country. To date, only K150 million was released – about 60 per cent on medical drugs and 40 per cent yet to procure, according to him. This would indicate an outstanding K145 million which is crucial to ensure all medial stores around the country are fully stocked. “We are trying our best to see that medical supplies procurement goes to medical provincial stores and to the respective primary health care facilities. “We have also identified issues of logistics, there are a lot of illegal taps going on with the medical supplies system. “When medicines leave the department health facilities, along the way there are some medicines that get stolen and end up on street markets. “So public is urged that if you see people selling these, let the authorities know so we can send in the fraud squad to make arrests. “We are trying out best under many challenges and as we speak there are some to deliver, delayed along the Highlands Highways due to roadblocks and other issues,” he said.

Title: Alotau MP Morris queries log export levies worth K30 million
Content: ALOTAU MP Ricky Morris has asked Prime Minister James Marape for a review into the Non-Tax Revenue Act given unequal distribution of shares of log export development levies which is held in trust by the State. He made specific reference to the levies in trust for the past six years amounting to K30 million. “Can the people of Milne Bay and Northern (Oro) province be informed on the oil palm that was paid for in cash by the New Britain Palm Oil Limited (NBPOL) in 2010?” Morris asked. “We want a report on this because the shares earned have been in trust by the State in the last 15 years. “We acknowledge the Government has released K10 million on each of those dividend shares, but respectively these funds have been held by the State for the last 15 years,” he said. The Non-Tax Revenue Administration (NTRA) Act 2022 instructs that all non-tax revenue collected by government statutory bodies and authorities must be remitted to the Consolidated Revenue Fund (CRF). This Act replaced the Public Money Management Regularisation (PMMR) Act and aims to improve the management of these funds to support the national budget. Prime Minister James Marape said “the review is not out of reach and “we can make amends to see the mechanics of the NTRA that it must work well without killing the goose that lays the egg”. “Statutory bodies must submit their budget proposals for the following year, and the funds are then allocated back to them for reasonable operating requirements, according to the NTRA Act,” Marape said. “The ration of NTRA was such that many of the boards for statutory bodies to its sectors, were not open for public scrutiny except through Cabinet, so the work plan comes from Cabinet and upon minister’s submission of annual reports to parliament. “But we have observed over time that this backdates into possibly two governments up till the Pangu administration and will require a review. “There is a teething issue and the administration of NTRA might not be fully intended for what it stands for but I want to give assurance and we will certainly look into this,” he said.

Title: Mum, baby safe and sound thanks to Manolos
Content: A MOTHER and her baby from Anagi in Gulf were returned safely to the village after they received treatment at Angau hospital on Monday. The 39-year-old mother was medevaced by Manolos Aviation Limited into Lae on Oct 20 for emergency medical care after being in labour for three days. Captain Jurgen Ruh, Manolos Aviation chief executive officer, said that this was a successful completion of a life-saving mission that began with teamwork and compassion. “It’s always rewarding to see a case like this come full circle,” Ruh said. “Our team was there when the mother needed urgent help and now we’re able to return her and baby safely home with the community’s support behind them.” The mother gave birth minutes before Manolos helicopter arrived on Oct 20. Individuals in Lae donated clothing and baby essentials to the mother and child. Anagi is located at the border of Gulf’s Kerema district and Menyamya in Morobe. Meanwhile, according to its website whilst commencing as a commercial venture in 2008, Manolos Aviation has re-evaluated its strategy and adapted a direction focused on humanitarian needs. The Helicopter Emergency Medical Service pilots, nurses and operations team are on standby 24/7 and are able to deploy within 20 mins from an emergency call-out.

Title: LLG elections in Jiwaka hit a snag
Content: POLLING for Jiwaka’s local level government (LLG) election hit a snag after people in Anglimp-South Waghi protested against polling in two new LLGs created for the district. Groups took to Highlands Highway yesterday morning to air their grievances and harrassed the commuting public travelling the higway. Electoral Commissioner (EC) Simon Sinai later announced the suspension of polling for the two LLGs). He said he made the decision based on security and integrity of the polling officials and electoral processes, while calling on the Provincial and Level Government Department to investigate the creation of the two LLGs. EC’s decision was compliant to the people’s demand petitioned to Sinai last week, wanting the 14 new wards in Anglimp Rural and Kuna Komun not to go into the polls this week. Locals alleged that the creation of the new wards was illegal and did not comply with the due processes, Sinai said. “Security is entirely lacking and the situation is escalating out of control.” A letter to the Minister was copied to the chief secretary, Provincial and Local Level Department secretary, provincial administrator Rick Kogen, police commander Chief Inspector Laimo Asi, and Anglimp LLG president Nickolas Kurua. All vehicles from Upper Highlands and Chimbu were turned back from roadblocks staged from Kudjip, Kindeng and Komun sections of the highway. It started on Monday with a peaceful protest in Banz which was addressed by the election manager Rossie Pundihau but in yesterday’s roadblocks, demands were made of Sinai to respond to a petition within 24 hours. Pundihau said she will withhold the election until Sinai responded to the petition. She said polling in Minj, Jimi, and North Waghi which are on schedule for this week are affected by the protests in Kudjip and Anglimp LLGs. Yesterday morning thepeople blocked sections of highway with logs and heavy materials, cutting off transportation access. Provincial police commander Chief Inspector Laimo Asi and Pundihau have yet to respond toThe National’s queries on the recent situation, but the travelling public wants the road blockages to be cleared immediately. Chimbu’s grade 12 students who were to sit for their entry tests for the Pacific Adventist University (PAU), University of Goroka (UoG) and the University of Technology (Unitech) through the STAP-P (Skills for Tertiary Admissions Test) programme in Mt Hagen yesterday were turned back. Among travellers turned back to Mt Hagen was school teacher Kiagi Maima, who was returning to her school in Chimbu. Spokesperson from Kudzip LLG Angra Asip Gola said the protest on Monday was to show frustrations over the manner the two new LLGs of Kuna Komun and Kambia were created where they claimed common rolls were inflated with ghost names. Similar complaints were echoed by John Kumb from Anglimp LLG who said no proper census was done to update the common roll to create new LLs and wards. He said the PLLGA failed to conduct a stakeholders’ referendum to get collective views of the people.

Title: Polling in most parts of the Highlands region continues
Content: THE Highlands region has gone into the local level government (LLG) polling while Jiwaka’s Anglimp-South Waghi’s LLGs of Kudjip and Anglimp protested, affecting polling in the province since Monday. The issue was on the creation of two new LLGs, Kuna-Komun and Kambia that were alleged not to have followed proper procedures, and inflation of voters’ common rolls in the new wards. Earlier, similar concerns were raised by 32 councillors in three LLGs in Nipa, Southern Highlands, of added names in 11 new wards that were created, but Nipa-Kutubu MP Dr Joseph Billy addressed the concerns by saying that since the polling has commenced, he would take it up with the Electoral Commission to look into it. Jiwaka’s Anglimp and Kudjip LLGs protested against polling since Monday. The people took to the Highlands Highway yesterday, blocking off parts of the highway with logs, trees and heavy objects. Western Highlands’ Baiyer and Lumusa’ councillors also petitioned the EC on the appointment of assistant returning officer Tony Kolo, to Baiyer LLG where there were allegations of Kolo misconducting the 2022 National General Elections for the district which is before the Supreme Court. Western Highlands’ election manager Phillip Telape has yet to ascertain whether polling for Baiyer and Lumusa LLGs will proceed as scheduled yesterday. Telape said Dei’s polling, which was conducted on Monday, went well, with Tambul-Nebilyer today and ending with Mt Hagen Central tomorrow. Election managers for Chimbu, Jiwaka, and Southern Highlands said polling for their provinces started yesterday, while Western Highlands polling started on Monday. Chimbu’s Tom Sine said polling was on schedule and started in all six districts while Jiwaka’s Rossie Paundihau said polling had started there except for Anglimp-South Waghi district which was put on hold over a petition. Southern Highlands and Enga’s polling also started yesterday with ballot papers being distributed on Monday in Mendi and Wabag. Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai said polling is expected to end on November 8 with counting to proceed and writs returned on November 21. Sinai said the seven Highlands provinces with Morobe will have their elected ward councillors hold a separate election to vote in their respective LLG presidents. Election updates from Eastern Highlands and Hela were not obtained but it is believed polling is on schedule for this week.

Title: Names not on roll: Candidate
Content: AN intending candidate for the Pomio’s West Pomio local level government (LLG) president seat in East New Britain has raised concerns over the failure of the Electoral Office to register eligible voters on the common roll. John Leo, a candidate for the West-Pomio LLG president seat, raised this concern yesterday (Tuesday) in Pomio. According to Leo, many voters in West Pomio LLG were denied the right to vote on the first day of polling after being told their names were not on the roll. Similar issues occurred during the 2022 general election, causing frustration among residents. “The law has deprived voters of their right to vote again, including myself,” he said. Despite efforts by residents to register their names at the ward and LLG levels, the common roll had not been updated, hindering the voting process. Other parts of the province have also reported missing names on the roll on the first day of polling. Leo emphasised that voters had done their part, but the Electoral Office had failed to update the common roll. “We have done our part, this is not our fault,” he said. The issue raises doubt with the country’s readiness to have elections and legitimacy of outcome. “People are not voting because their names are not on the common roll. Who is failing the voters? People sitting in that office should be committed to addressing election issues,” he said. Leo highlighted a previous recommendation that a supplementary roll be used in situations like this. The supplementary roll allows those whose names are missing from the common roll to vote. “The supplementary roll is more accurate because people are recorded by where they reside. This makes it easier and convenient for voters who would otherwise miss out,” he said.

Title: Polling starts in ENB without a hitch, 137 polling teams engaged
Content: POLLING started on Monday in East New Britain on a high note without any trouble. The only issue was to do with voters not having their names on the ward roll. ENB election manager Joap Voivoi said those without names on the ward electoral roll will not be allowed to vote. Voivoi explained that as per schedule, ENB started polling on Monday and should conclude by Friday. There are total of 137 polling teams in the province. Voivoi also urged ward recorders to be present when polling is being conducted in their wards. “The ward recorders must be there when polling is done, so that they can identify the people (voters) who say their names are not on the ward roll,” he said. “This is because we have had instances where people come in from other places claiming to be from that ward.” Voivoi confirmed that the last ward roll update in the province was done in 2024 but so far, on the first day of the polling around the province, a number of people had been turned away due to them having no names on the ward roll. Voivoi further advised that counting for the ward member seats, have begun in some wards after the close of polling with names of winning candidates announced at the ward. “However, those winning candidates can only be declared by the ENB Provincial Returning Officer (PRO) Theresa Sam. This will be done after all the polling and counting are completed, including that of the local level government (LLG) president seats in all the 23 LLGs,” Voivoi said. He said that on the first day, polling started at 8am and concluded at 6pm and this would continue every day until the end of polling.

Title: Yafai set to appeal 22-yr sentence
Content: CONVICTED former deputy Finance secretary Jacob Yafai is expected to appear in court next month to appeal his conviction and 22-year prison sentence. Yafai, through his lawyer Edward Sasingian, filed the Supreme Court application without leave, to review the decision of Sir Gibbs Salika made on Aug 19, which convicted him on four counts of misappropriation and one count of abuse of office. Yafai was convicted and sentenced for misappropriating K41.8 million of public funds. He argued among other grounds that Sir Gibbs had erred in law and fact when he had him convicted and has sought orders to uphold the appeal, and have the whole of the judgment of Aug 19 quashed. He is arguing that Sir Gibbs had made an error of convicting him on the finding that he was directed by the secretary for Finance Steven Gibson (late) to verify the claim by Paul Paraka and that when he failed to do so, he was acting dishonestly, when the evidence before the court said otherwise. On another ground of appeal, Yafai argued that Sir Gibbs erred in mixed fact and law, when he accepted the evidence of the former Minister for Finance James Marape that was given against him in court, when it was unreliable and contradicted State exhibit, indicating bias. He further claims that the trial judge erred in law and fact in convicting him on abuse of office, for directing the payment of K41.8 million to Paraka Lawyers when the evidence before the court did not support the element. These and other grounds of appeal will be submitted before the higher court when the matter is listed for directions and allocation of hearing date. Yafai has also sought an order to alternatively have the matter remitted to the National Court for a retrial before another judge.

Title: Committee in Kokopo for Bougainville consultation
Content: CHAIRMAN of the Parliamentary Bi-Partisan Committee on Bougainville Affairs and Rabaul MP Dr Allan Marat has told people in East New Britain that the decision of the Parliament on Bougainville’s independence will based on the referendum results. He said this when speaking during the committee’s consultation on Bougainville independence referendum results in Kokopo, attended mainly by representatives of the Mataugan Association and others. Marat was responding to questions on what would happen if Parliament decided not to rectify the referendum results in favour of Bougainville independence, among others. Marat explained that the Government and Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) had committed themselves to further consultations, so even if parliament said no, both parties would conduct consultations. “If the parliament votes against Bougainville independence, that is not the end of the matter, because the two parties had committed themselves to further consultation according to an agreed timeline,” he said. “The purpose of this consultation is to get your views on why the Government must give independence to Bougainville and why it must not give them independence. “This committee will interview you to get your views, therefore, we want honest answers and opinions.” Deputy chairman of the committee and West New Britain Governor Sasindran Muthuvel said that they represented the Government and they were in Kokopo to conduct consultation to get responses from people regarding the Bougainville independence issue. Muthuvel said the issue was a very important matter for the parliament and therefore, feedbacks from the people would help leaders to make the right decisions.

Title: Dedication turns dream into reality
Content: AT just 23-year-old, Emmanuel Tausem from Ku Mordern village in Chimbu has already proven that discipline and dedication can turn dreams into reality. Tausem, was part of 255 students who graduated on Friday with diploma and certificates from International Training Institute (ITI) from different business courses. He was proudly recognised as a top student among his course mates undertaking the Diploma in Business Management. Tausem was awarded the chairman’s award, an achievement which he dedicated to his family and faith. “I’ve always been passionate about leadership, organisation and how businesses operate to create value. while I was growing up. “I became facinated and admired how business-minded people were able to manage their time and resources effectively. This curiosity and facination inspired Tausem to take up studies in business management at ITI. He said that by taking up these courses, he would be better able to gain the right knowledge and skills to become a successful leader in the field of business,” he said. He used the occasssion to share the many difficulites and challenges, he had encountered as a student, especially managing and prioritising time between studies, sports and personal responsibilities. “At times as well, financial difficulties and limited resources were also tough on me, but I continued to stayed focused, disciplined and prayed regularly. “I always try to remind myself that challenges are part of the journey to success and with faith, consistency and hard work, I pushed through them. Through those difficult moments, he found that discipline also played an important part in his school life and thus, dedicated his time towards his studies which paid off for him. “I developed strong study habits, consistent reading time, setting clear goals and stayed organised. “I also made sure to balance academics with rest and prayer,” he said. He acknowledged and thanked his family for their support, guidance and encouragement that kept him grounded and able to complete his studies to bag that award. “My future plan is to further my studies and gain more experience in the business management field and contribute what I’ve learnt to organisational growth and eventually take on leadership roles or running my own business,” he said. His advice to those still in school is to stay focused, humble and never lose or give up. “Also manage your time wisely, respect your lecturers, schoolmates. “And most importantly, keep God in the centre of everything.”

Title: Sapulai to clock in 29 years with MRDC
Content: KILANGIT Sapulai is close to reaching his 29 years of service with the Mineral Resources Development Company (MRDC). Hailing from Central and Manus, he is one of two employees who have worked for so long with the company, having joined in 1996 as an administration officer. Like many in the company, Sapulai has transitioned roles over the years to his position as senior treasury officer. He has seen it all, the changes from where the company was to where it is now, a partner in nation building. Coming up, is his 29th year with the MRDC in December, Sapulai says he has managed to stay this long was because of the progressive career pathway offered to him. His journey began when he joining the company straight after completing his grade 12 to having been sent overseas for studies and coming back to assuming his role as a treasury officer. “I am looking after the MRDC Group’s treasury and all the funds and where they sit in different accounts and funding for various projects and plans we have every year,” Sapulai said. “When I was first employed in 1996, I was an administration officer, and after six years, I was sent to study abroad. And upon my return, I got a promotion to became a treasury officer in 2006. “I have also gone into other roles including commodity administrator and so forth. Sapulai said some of his proudest moments and contributions highlighting his achievements over the years was being involved in the distribution process of project beneficiary benefits and seeing the smiles on people’s faces when they receive their benefits. Contrasting between the early years and today, Sapulai said MRDC has grown exponentially in staff numbers, the number of subsidiaries it manages, the technology that is being used and management changes to now an organisation positioned for growth. Being part of a company looking after beneficiary interests, he has seen firsthand some of the major projects and investments the company has done for its project beneficiaries. “Those are some of the major projects I’ve seen, personally, that have happened. “I’m reaching my 29 years in December, and I look at the future and I see the restructuring and the plans that the organisation has. “Technology advancement is improving, and there are better ways of managing businesses and serving our local beneficiaries now. “One of the other things I like is MRDC’s mandate, we are managed by the Oil and Gas Act, we manage two requirements, future generation trusts, and community infrastructure trust funds. “These are for the beneficiary of all the projects, from gold to the oil to gas because they all come under the Oil and Gas Act”.

Title: Efforts to stamp out violence ‘failing’
Content: NATIONAL Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop, who is also chairman of the Permanent Parliamentary Committee on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment, says the fight against Gender-based Violence is failing because government agencies have not taken ownership of the response strategy. Parkop made this known during a senior government officials meeting in Port Moresby yesterday to mobilise action against GBV. He noted the persistent high prevalence of violence was a major impediment to achieving national progress. Parkop pinpointed the solution, a mandated policy enforcement across all State entities. “The government itself is not taking ownership and responsibility for the response strategy to GBV and that is why it is failing,” he said. “We are not showing leadership. We are not taking ownership. We are not walking the talk.” Parkop issued a stern challenge to all State institutions to implement immediate action. “I want to see in the city all the government departments, State agencies and State-owned enterprises taking ownership of the strategy, and implementing it at workplaces, in homes and in communities,” he said. “Make it the terms and condition of employment of all the State employees.” Parkop said NCD Commission was already implementing zero tolerance as a term and condition of employment, and this mandate must be extended nationwide. The meeting, which was hosted by Personnel Management Department secretary Taies Sansan, serves as a preparation platform for the upcoming 20 Days of Activism against GBV and the NCD “Redvember” campaign. The nation’s alarming GBV statistics, which continue to rise despite decades of activism, were front and centre in the discussions. Sansan stressed that combating violence was not merely a women’s issue but a shared human responsibility. She focused her call to action directly on the nation’s bureaucracy, urging public servants to lead the change. “Ending violence is everyone’s responsibility,” Sansan said. “It is not just a women’s issue. “It is a human being issue both male and female.”

Title: Governor Rapa to discuss safety along Highlands Highway in Parliament
Content: WESTERN Highlands Governor Wai Rapa has reiterated that he will raise law and order issues along the Highlands Highway in this week’s Parliament sitting with the Police Minister. Wai Rapa said he will ask Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr what strategies the Government has in place to deter or address criminal activities along the highway that links the seven Highlands provinces to Lae in Morobe, Madang, and Gulf. Rapa said the recent killing of Mt Hagen bus driver Tony Pes by criminals from the Tiungka community outside of Eastern Highlands’ Kainantu along the Barola to Kompri section of the Highlands Highway has brought the safety of people and goods along the highway into sharp focus. He said the Highlands Highway is a national asset, allowing goods and services needed by the people to be made accessible including the carriage of production materials for gold, oil and gas in Hela, Southern Highlands and Enga. The Highlands Highway allows for the Government to collect huge revenue for the development of the nation, and that calls for regular police presence on the road to provide the required security, Rapa said. He added that the Police Department must have in place strategies to address law and order issues spilling onto the road in hotspots to protect lives of people using the road and of resources being transported.

Title: New Caledonia’s President Ponga in PNG for bilateral talks
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape yesterday met with Alcide Ponga, the President of the Government of New Caledonia, for bilateral talks in Port Moresby. It reaffirms the bilateral cooperation between Papua New Guinea, the French territory and France. Marape highlighted on the expanding relationship with France through President Emmanuel Macron over the last six years. He plans to open a PNG diplomatic mission in Paris next year. He acknowledged the relations Papua New Guinea has with New Caledonians as Melanesians, and highlighted on New Caledonia’s higher standard of living as a territory of France. Marape used the opportunity to seek the territory’s assistance in areas it is strong in such as solar energy development and further training opportunities for PNG athletes. President Ponga offered New Caledonia’s support, saying that his government wanted to target specific areas of development. He and his team are in the country as part of the development support efforts between the two governments. It is his first visit to PNG. A joint cooperation plan between PNG and New Caledonia will be signed before President Ponga leaves PNG later this week.

Title: Nestle PNG’s workshop receives accreditation
Content: THE Nestlé PNG mechanical workshop has been accredited as a Trades Testing Centre last week Thursday. The accreditation means that the workshop is recognised by the government as a training and testing centre where people can take examinations and achieve certificates for levels one and two trades in maintenance fitting and machining, says Moses Joseph, the head of human resources and corporate affairs. It was granted by the Papua New Guinea National Apprenticeship and Trades Testing Board (NATTB). This ensures Nestlé’s continued commitment to building a skilled workforce and supporting technical education in the country. The process began in 2024, the assistant director of Quality Assurance and Accreditation at NATTB, Arthur Geno, conducted a comprehensive assessment of the workshop. Following his review, Nestlé initiated trial trades testing and assessor training to meet national standards. In March, with support from Giwi Yaeng, an experienced trainer and assessor, the workshop conducted trial testing for selected fitters Michael Philip, Elias Kopman and Jonathan Tobata and assessor training for David Kewand and Matare Waga. Joseph said the final assessments were completed in August, leading to the accreditation. During the ceremony, level one Trade Certificates were awarded to the fitters, while Trainer/Assessor Certificates were presented to David Kewand and Matare Waga.

Title: US claims ceasefire holding as Israel strikes Gaza
Content: Jerusalem/Cairo: Israeli planes have launched deadly strikes in Gaza after Israel accused the militant group Hamas of violating a ceasefire in the Palestinian territory, the latest test of a fragile deal brokered earlier this month by US President Donald Trump. Local health authorities said the strikes killed at least 26 people, including five in a house hit in the Bureij refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip, four in a building in Gaza City’s Sabra neighbourhood, and five in a car in Khan Younis. The attacks by Israeli planes continued into early Wednesday across the Gaza Strip, according to witnesses. The latest violence in the three-week-old ceasefire followed a statement by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office saying he had ordered immediate “powerful attacks.” The statement did not give a specific reason for the attacks but an Israeli military official said Hamas had violated the ceasefire by carrying out an attack against Israeli forces in an area of the enclave that is under Israeli control. The US-backed ceasefire agreement went into effect on Oct 10, halting two years of war triggered by deadly Hamas-led attacks on Israel on Oct 7, 2023. US Vice President JD Vance said that despite the latest flare-up, “the ceasefire is holding.” “That doesn’t mean that there aren’t going to be little skirmishes here and there,” he told reporters on Capitol Hill. “We know that Hamas or somebody else within Gaza attacked an (Israeli) soldier. We expect the Israelis are going to respond, but I think the president’s peace is going to hold despite that.” Hamas denied responsibility for an attack on Israeli forces in Rafah. The group also said in a statement that it remained committed to the ceasefire deal in Gaza. Tuesday’s strikes on Gaza City followed what Israel called a “targeted strike” on Saturday on a person in central Gaza who it said was planning to attack Israeli troops. Netanyahu said earlier on Tuesday that Hamas had violated the ceasefire by turning over some wrong remains in a process of returning the bodies of hostages to Israel. Netanyahu said the remains handed over on Monday belonged to Ofir Tzarfati, an Israeli killed during Hamas’ October 7, 2023, attack. Tzarfati’s remains had already been partially retrieved by Israeli troops during the war. In response, Hamas initially said it would hand over to Israel the body of a missing hostage found in a tunnel in Gaza. However, Hamas’ armed wing, Al-Qassam Brigades, said later it would postpone the handover, citing what it said were Israel’s violations of the ceasefire. Late on Tuesday, Al-Qassam issued a statement saying it had recovered the bodies of two Israeli hostages, Amiram Cooper and Sahar Baruch, during search operations in Gaza.. Hamas has said it will take time to locate and retrieve all the hostage remains amid Gaza’s ruins. The issue has become one of the main sticking points in the ceasefire, which Trump says he is watching closely. He has touted the truce and hostage-prisoner exchange deal as one of the top foreign policy achievements of his second term, and he and his top aides have sought to keep the ceasefire intact. Source: Reuters

Title: Huge raid on Rio gang leaves at least 60 people dead
Content: Rio De Janeiro: About 2,500 Brazilian police and soldiers have been involved in a massive raid on a drug-trafficking gang in Rio de Janeiro, arresting 81 suspects and sparking shootouts that left at least 60 suspects dead, officials said. The operation included officers in helicopters and armoured vehicles and targeted the notorious Red Command in the sprawling low-income favelas of Complexo de Alemao and Penha, police said. The police operation was one of the most violent in Brazil’s recent history, with at least one human rights organisation calling for an investigation into each death. Rio’s state Governor Claudio Castro said in a video posted on social platform X that 60 criminal suspects were “neutralised,” 81 arrested and 75 rifles seized during the one-day raid that he called the biggest such operation in the city’s history. An Associated Press journalist saw the bodies of at least two police officers among 10 bodies brought to the Getulio Vargas hospital in Penha. Police did not immediately confirm the deaths of officers. César Muñoz, director of Human Rights Watch in Brazil, called Tuesday’s events “a huge tragedy” and a “disaster.” “The public prosecutor’s office must open its own investigations and clarify the circumstances of each death,” Muñoz said in a statement. Footage on social media showed fire and smoke rising from the two favelas as gunfire rang out. The city’s Education Department said 46 schools across the two neighbourhoods were closed, and the nearby Federal University of Rio de Janeiro cancelled night classes and told people on campus to seek shelter. Suspected gang members blocked roads in northern and southeastern Rio in response to the raid, local media reported. At least 70 buses were commandeered to be used in the blockades, causing “significant damage,” the city’s bus organisation Rio Onibus said. Governor Castro, from the conservative opposition Liberal Party, said the federal government should be providing more support to combat crime — a swipe at the administration of leftist President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Gleisi Hoffmann, the Lula administration’s liaison with the parliament, agreed that coordinated action was needed but pointed to a recent crackdown on money laundering as an example of the federal government’s action on organised crime. Rio has been the scene of lethal police raids for decades. In March 2005, some 29 people were killed in Rio’s Baixada Fluminense region, while in May 2021, 28 were killed in the Jacarezinho favela. Sociologist and public safety expert Luis Flavio Sapori argues these kinds of operations are inefficient because they don’t tend to catch the masterminds, but rather target underlings who can later be replaced. “It’s not enough to go in, exchange gunfire, and leave. There’s a lack of strategy in Rio de Janeiro’s public security policy,” Sapori said. “Some lower-ranking members of these factions are killed, but those individuals are quickly replaced by others.” The Marielle Franco Institute, a nonprofit founded by the slain councilwoman ‘s family to continue her legacy of fighting for the rights of people living in favelas, also criticised the operation. “This is not a public safety policy. It’s a policy of extermination, that makes the everyday life of Black and poor people a Russian roulette,” it said in a statement. Source: AP

Title: Twisted games: young girls targeted by online gangs
Content: Canberra: Young girls are being hunted by young men online who are coercing their vulnerable victims into carrying out “twisted” acts of violence, the new head of the federal police warns. In an address to the National Press Club in Canberra on Wednesday, Krissy Barrett will announce three domestic arrests and 59 alleged offenders identified as members of decentralised online crime networks. “In this new, twisted type of gamification, perpetrators reach a new status or new level in their group when they provide more content showing more extreme acts of depravity and sadism,” she will say. “These crimes are now spilling into the real world and have real-world consequences.” The creation of a new taskforce will crack down on these networks and “crime-influencer” perpetrators. Young people have been reached on platforms including Roblox and messaging apps such as Telegram. The girls tended to have low-self esteem, mental health issues and a history of self-harm, Barrett will say. Previously serving as the agency’s deputy commissioner with oversight of national security, Barrett will point to growing strategic competition being exploited by state and non-state actors. Standing alongside Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the media conference announcing her promotion, the chief said a focus of her tenure would be ensuring the federal police had a healthy workforce. Source: AAP

Title: Melissa hits Jamaica with full force, on path to Cuba
Content: Kingston: Heavy floodwaters swept across southwestern Jamaica, winds tore roofs off buildings and boulders tumbled onto roads as Hurricane Melissa came ashore as a catastrophic category five storm, one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes on record. Landslides, fallen trees and numerous power outages were reported as Melissa hit with 295 km/h winds near New Hope, with officials cautioning that the cleanup and damage assessment could be slow. “There is no infrastructure in the region that can withstand a Category 5,” Prime Minister Andrew Holness said. “The question now is the speed of recovery. That’s the challenge.” Floodwaters trapped at least three families in their homes in the community of Black River in western Jamaica, and crews were unable to help them because of dangerous conditions, said Desmond McKenzie, deputy chairman of Jamaica’s Disaster Risk Management Council. He noted that extensive damage was reported in the southwestern parish of St. Elizabeth, which he said “is underwater.” McKenzie said it was too early to talk about the extent of the damage because the hurricane — the strongest to hit the island since recordkeeping began 174 years ago — was still pummelling the country. It has since weakened slightly, to a still destructive category four system. The country’s Meteorological Service, warned that as Melissa moves off the coast its counterclockwise rotation will bring a heavy storm surge to northern Jamaica through the night. The storm is headed toward Cuba, where it’s expected to make landfall as a major hurricane early on Wednesday. Source: AP

Title: Democracy dips as Australia slips in global law ranking
Content: Canberra: Australia has slipped in a global rule of law ranking due to a decline in checks and balances, judicial limits on government power and justice being free from improper interference. It ranked 11th out of 143 nations, decreasing two ranks on the World Justice Project’s 2025 rule of law index, which was released on Tuesday. Australia’s score has slowly decreased since 2015, before bouncing back slightly in 2023. The project rates nations against benchmarks including constraints on government power, corruption, fundamental rights, order and security, civil and criminal justice and the enforcement of regulation. Freedom of assembly, freedom of opinion and expression and civic participation remained strong in Australia. New Zealand topped the East Asia and Pacific regional rankings – followed by Australia and Japan – and notched 5th overall. Although Pacific island nations aren’t included in this grouping. Eight out of 15 countries in the region went backwards in the last year, half of which also slipped the previous year. Denmark topped the list, followed by Norway, Finland and Sweden. Venezuela ranked the lowest, with Afghanistan and Cambodia rounding out the bottom three. There has been a global decline of the rule of law, with more than two-thirds of countries dropping down the rankings, compared to 57 per cent the previous year. Risks to democracy were spurred by an expansion of authoritarian trends, including the judiciary losing ground to executive overreach and rising political interference. The index is based on 215,000 household surveys and 4,100 surveys of legal practitioners and experts. Source: AAP

Title: From chaos to code: why AI is boosting developer ranks
Content: Brisbane: Artificial intelligence technology is not just helping to create more software but to create more software developers after a leading platform added a record 36 million users in one year. The coding tools could address some of Australia’s skills shortages, experts said, even though additional training would be required. GitHub reported the results at its annual developers event on Wednesday, also revealing that eight in 10 new users deployed AI in their first week on the platform. The announcement comes after the Tech Council of Australia predicted AI could help to create 200,000 jobs in the country by 2030 and as the federal government considers what regulations will be required to govern its safe use. GitHub, the world’s largest software development platform, introduced AI tools in 2021 but the company said the technology had delivered its largest growth to date in 2025. More than 36 million new users joined the platform in the year to August, bringing its user base to more than 180 million, according to its Octoverse report, and representing growth of 23 per cent. Most new users adopted its AI software within their first week and GitHub Asia Pacific vice-president Sharryn Napier said the trend proved software developers did not view AI as an enemy. “The story of 2025 isn’t AI versus developers – it’s about AI transforming how developers work,” she said. “More developers moving faster is good news for Australia as we continue to tackle our tech skills shortage and productivity challenges.” The company’s newest users included first-time developers, students and people trying to solve tech problems who did not see themselves as software creators, GitHub chief operating officer Kyle Daigle said. But veteran developers and open-source contributors were also using AI agents more often, he said, and in more places. “Sometimes we can get caught up in the Silicon Valley nature or the North American nature of it but where we’re seeing the growth accelerating so aggressively is outside of this single microcosm,” he told AAP. “This is the biggest year of growth that GitHub has ever experienced and it is incredibly global.” The company also revealed plans to expand its AI features, adding support for agents from companies including OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, Cognition and xAI. The wider support would help software developers to choose the best tools for their tasks, Mr Daigle said, and could help to bring more clarity to what had become “innovative chaos” since the launch of generative AI tools. AI had the potential to accelerate productivity over the next five years, he said, both in training more developers and helping others solve problems faster. “I want to be able to do things that are not economically viable today or weren’t years ago because the tools are there,” he said. “We’re seeing more open-source projects created on GitHub than ever before. Source: AAP

Title: AUKUS subs deal won’t be expanded to include Japan: PM
Content: Canberra: Anthony Albanese has shut down suggestions of Japan being a fourth player in the Aukus alliance, despite the ally helping to produce frigates for Australia’s defence forces. The prime minister held talks with his newly elected Japanese counterpart Sanae Takaichi, the first woman to hold the role, on the sidelines of the Asean summit in Malaysia. “The meeting I had … was very positive and constructive. She has invited me to come to Japan,” Albanese told reporters in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday. Takaichi told Albanese she wanted to “promote strategic co-operation with Australia” and improve the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue (Quad) co-operation. The Quad, which includes the United States, Australia, Japan and India, was set up to counter China militarily and diplomatically in the Indo-Pacific region. While Albanese said Australia was purchasing Japanese-made Mogami frigates, Japan would not play a part of the Aukus pact alongside the US and UK “Aukus is an arrangement between Australia, the United Kingdom and the United States and we’re very much focused on delivering that,” Albanese said. “Of course, the Mogami frigates that we are purchasing from Japan are going to be very important.” He said the frigates will also be produced in Western Australia with the support of Japan. Albanese spruiked the critical minerals deal inked with the US last week after being asked whether China would question the agreement. The agreement aims to challenge China’s global market dominance of critical minerals and rare earth elements. “Just as Australia has benefited from resources in the last century, such as iron ore, that will continue,” Albanese said. Source: AAP

Title: North Korea shows its firepower as Trump visits South
Content: Seoul: North Korea has trumpeted the success of its recent test-firings of sea-to-surface cruise missiles, in another display of its growing military capabilities as US President Donald Trump visits South Korea. North Korea’s official Korean Central News Agency said the missiles fired on Tuesday flew for more than two hours before accurately striking targets in its western waters. It said the weapons would contribute to expanding the operational sphere of the country’s nuclear-armed military. South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff said the military had detected the North Korean launch preparations and that the cruise missiles were fired in the North’s northwestern waters at around 3 pm Tuesday. The joint chiefs said South Korea and the United States were analysing the weapons and maintaining a combined defence readiness capable of a “dominant response” against any North Korean provocation. The North Korean report came hours before an expected summit between Trump and South Korean President Lee Jae Myung in the city of Gyeongju, where South Korea is hosting this year’s Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meetings. Speaking with reporters aboard Air Force One en route from Japan to South Korea, Trump downplayed the North Korean launches. “He’s been launching missiles for decades, right?” he said, referring to Kim Jong Un. Trump reiterated he still wants to meet with Kim, whom he met three times in 2018 and 2019 before their diplomacy derailed over disagreements on US-led sanctions against the North. “We had a really good understanding of each other,” Trump said. KCNA said the tests were attended by senior military official Pak Jong Chon, who also inspected training for sailors aboard North Korea’s newly developed destroyers Choe Hyon and Kang Kon, which leader Kim Jong Un has described as key assets in his efforts to strengthen the navy. North Korea’s latest launches followed short-range ballistic missile tests last week that it said involved a new hypersonic system designed to strengthen its nuclear war deterrent. During his South Korean visit, Trump is scheduled to meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping. However, South Korean officials have said a Trump–Kim meeting is unlikely. North Korea has shunned any form of talks with Washington and Seoul since Kim’s high-stakes nuclear diplomacy with Trump fell apart in 2019 during the American president’s first term. Kim’s top foreign policy priority is now Russia. In recent months, he has sent thousands of troops and large quantities of military equipment to help fuel President Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine, while embracing the idea of a “new Cold War” and positions his country as part of a united front against the US-led West. Last month, Kim reiterated he wouldn’t return to talks with the United States unless Washington drops its demand for North Korea’s denuclearisation, after Trump repeatedly expressed his hopes for new diplomacy. Source: AP

Title: Anzacs’ messages in a bottle found on Australian beach
Content: Melbourne: Messages in a bottle written by two soldiers on their voyage to the battlefields of France during World War I have been found more than a century later on Australia’s coast. The Brown family found the Schweppes-brand bottle just above the waterline at Wharton Beach near Esperance in WA earlier this month. Deb Brown, her husband Peter and daughter Felicity made the find during one of the family’s regular quad bike expeditions to clear the beach of trash. “We do a lot of cleaning up on our beaches and so would never go past a piece of rubbish. So this little bottle was lying there waiting to be picked up,” she said. Inside were cheerful letters written in pencil by Privates Malcolm Neville, 27, and William Harley, 37, dated Aug 15, 1916. Their troop ship HMAT A70 Ballarat had left Adelaide on August that year on the long journey to the other side of the world where its soldiers would reinforce the 48th Australian Infantry Battalion on Europe’s Western Front. Neville was killed in action a year later. Harley was wounded twice but survived the war, dying in Adelaide in 1934 of a cancer his family say was caused by him being gassed by the Germans in the trenches. Neville requested the bottle’s finder deliver his letter to his mother at Wilkawatt, now a virtual ghost town in South Australia. Harley wrote “may the finder be as well as we are at present.” Neville wrote to his mother he was “having a real good time, food is real good so far, with the exception of one meal which we buried at sea.” The ship was “heaving and rolling, but we are as happy as Larry,” he wrote. Deb Brown suspects the bottle didn’t travel far. It likely spent more than a century ashore buried in the sand dunes. Extensive erosion of the dunes caused by huge swells along Wharton Beach in recent months probably dislodged it. The paper was wet, but the writing remained legible. Because of that, Deb Brown was able to notify both soldiers’ relatives of the find. Harley’s granddaughter Ann Turner said her family was “absolutely stunned” by the find. “We just can’t believe it. It really does feel like a miracle and we do very much feel like our grandfather has reached out for us from the grave,” Turner told the ABC. Neville’s great nephew Herbie Neville said his family had been brought together by the “unbelievable” discovery. “It sounds as though he was pretty happy to go to the war. It’s just so sad what happened. It’s so sad that he lost his life,” Herbie Neville said. “What a man he was,” the great nephew added with pride. Source: AP

Title: Marape appeals for calm, peace to ensure safe polling
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has appealed to all candidates and voters to uphold peace, discipline, and respect during the Local Level Government (LLG) elections. In a statement, he said: “The Electoral Commission, with the support of local-level administrators is doing its absolute best to ensure a free, fair and safe elections. “I urge all candidates and voters not to cause stress or disruption to their communities. “Elections are serious national exercises, and they must be conducted with dignity, peace and respect.” Marape explained that through legislative amendments, the Government has now legitimised and properly aligned the timing of LLG elections so that they are held midterm between national elections. This reform, he said, provides greater consistency in governance and allows for a timely refresh of local leadership across the country. “Since the deferral of the 2017 LLG elections, we have worked to bring the system into proper alignment,” he said. “The amendments we made now give certainty. National elections are held every five years, and LLG elections at midterm. “This ensures that democratic renewal continues smoothly at all levels.” He said that LLG presidents had an important role in the country’s governance framework as members of District Development Authorities (DDAs) and Provincial Assemblies, ensuring that local voices contributed meaningfully to district and provincial planning. “Do not vote for wantoks or sell your vote for a meal,” he said. “Vote for someone who is a true leader, a person respected in your community, who lives a disciplined life, takes care of their family, does not drink excessively or gamble away family resources, and who helps mediate disputes and promotes peace. “I encourage all Papua New Guineans to cast their votes correctly and peacefully, choosing leaders who will unite, serve, and strengthen our communities.”

Title: First day of elections in Morobe without hiccup
Content: POLICE in Morobe cannot provide security to areas in the province that do not have roads as there were no funds available to do so, says provincial police commander Chief Superintendent Samson Siguyaru. He said that districts accessible by road, police personnel were sent to assist. He urged people to take responsibilities to provide security themselves. “This also applies to those areas only accessible by sea transport. “We cannot send police personnel there as we have no funds to hire boats for that purpose,” Chief Supt Siguyaru said. He said the police boats that the province had were out of service and could not assist when police needed transport. “I have instead, send some police personnel to the Lae Urban local level government to assist personnel at Lae metropolitan in the LLG election” Siguyaru said for districts that had roads, police personnel from the Morobe police command were now providing security. He stated that as of yesterday afternoon, police election operations went well with no reports of any election-related violence. He urged the people to uphold the law and ensure citizens are given their democratic rights to choose the person they want to represent them.

Title: Electoral Commissioner calls for review of LLG processes
Content: ELECTORAL Commissioner Simon Sinai has called for a review of the local level government (LLG) processes, particularly the creation of new wards and LLGs. He said that the issue needed to be addressed by the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs to prevent further deferrals of future LLG elections. “These legal issues need to be handled with care, such as identifying a voter for a new ward and creating a new roll,” he said. “Once you have separated the voters according to the new wards from the existing rolls, you then take into account new voters who are not on the roll but turned 18 and are eligible to vote. “The 2022 electoral roll can be used as the base to update the roll. “But if any person who is not happy must object to the enrolment which is provided for under Section 48 of the Organic Law on National and Local Level Government Elections.” Sinai added that the issues which arose from the creation of new wards and LLGs strained the resources of the commission. “Provincial electoral staff were placed under pressure to identify and create new rolls before polling could start. “To avoid a repeat of such situations in future, the LLG processes need reviewing so that the legal requirements for creating news wards and LLGs are strictly managed and guided and implemented within a fixed timeline,” he said. “The Electoral Commission is required to prepare the electoral rolls six months before the anniversary of the next election, be it the general election or the local level government elections. “Due to staff shortage, the commission gets support from LLG public servants and provincial administrations to assist with the roll updates in provinces.” He recommended that a holistic approach be taken to review the LLG system of the country to avoid such issues in the future. “We are asking the Government, provincial administrations, LLGs, wards and citizens to help identify voters for the good of the elections.”

Title: West New Britons cast ballots in LLG election
Content: POLLING for the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections is afoot in West New Britain as voters cast their ballots for the future leaders of the 12 LLGs and 119 wards. Provincial election advisory committee chairman John Sitapai said all polling teams had been deployed to assist during the polling period which started yesterday. A one-day polling period was held for the four LLGs of Kimbe Urban, Talasea, Mosa and Hoskins. All other LLGs in the country will go to the polls as per their respective schedules before polling ends on Nov 8. “We have beefed up the number of our polling teams so that they are able to help the people cast their votes and ensure that the elections are done well,” Sitapai said. “People are expected to vote for good leaders in a very important tier of government. “It is up to our people to choose the right leaders who will lead them in the future.” He urged government agencies and businesses operating in the province to allow time for workers to exercise their constitutional right to vote during the election period. Talasea MP Freddie Kumai, who cast his vote yesterday at the Kimbe Urban LLG polling site, said that the elections had been a long time coming for the people of West New Britain. “Despite the many deferrals, I am sure that the people are happy that the LLG elections has started,” he said. “LLGs are a very important tier of the government and we, as national leaders, must also support. “It is an important tier of government that is closest to the people so we must do our part to assist them, especially by ensuring that this year’s LLG elections is conducted successfully.”

Title: Training combined to develop combat skills
Content: EVERY year, soldiers from the Australian and Papua New Guinea Defence Forces unite in a show of military cooperation on Exercise Wantok Warrior, a series of training activities focused on developing infantry skills at the Combat Team level. This year around 300 soldiers and officers from the PNGDF and ADF, including frontline troops and support staff, have been carrying out daily drills and war games. Liaison officer Major Derek Levi, who was an instructor at the School of Military Engineering at Holsworthy Barracks in Sydney, said it was important to train the tactics and capabilities that would be required in conflicts. “It’s good to train on them and know how to use them, so that if a fight comes we’ll be ready,” Levi said. Since its first iteration in 2005, the exercise has cemented itself as one of the most noteworthy bilateral training activities undertaken annually between the two countries. Over the 20 years since its inception, the exercise has developed in complexity by incorporating multiple platforms to increase interoperability and shared understanding. This provided participating members from both countries with exciting opportunities to share skills, resulting in enhanced leadership and military capability for both countries. For many, this exercise is one of the highlights of the year, affording soldiers from both countries the opportunity to work closely with their counterparts and friends from across the Torres Strait. Daily combat scenarios included small boat insertions to attack fictitious enemy air defences, long jungle patrols, casualty treatment and aero-medical evacuation as well as the defence of critical infrastructure. Airlifted into Lae on CH-47F Chinook helicopters, the integrated force from First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment, PNGDF Engineering Battalion and First Battalion, The Royal Australian Regiment, used Igam Barracks as a base for operations. A key objective for this year’s exercise was to practise capturing and securing critical infrastructure, which included urban clearance drills. For 28-year-old Private Mikessy Anthony, from Poloko Village in the Southern Highlands, ocean-going small boat drills were far and away the most daunting. “We went in the boats yesterday and I was a bit scared, it was my first time in a boat,” Anthony said. “The exercise isn’t just about training and capability, it’s also an opportunity for our troops to build on the friendships and camaraderie that our defence partnership is founded on.” Anthony said working with the ADF was rewarding experience for the different skills and techniques they were able to pass on. “Working together with the ADF I’ve learnt a lot, we’ve been able to bring different ideas and have this shared experience.”

Title: Children killed elsewhere and placed in car, police say
Content: POLICE are treating the deaths of three children found in an abandoned vehicle on Sunday at the 9-Mile Hagen Kona settlement as suspicious, The Nationalwas on site yesterday with police and confirmed their naked bodies were found about four meters away from the settlement’s water source. Assistant Police Commissioner National Capital District and Central Benjamin Turi urged residents to provide information to police for arrests to be made. “Seeing the crime scene myself, it doesn’t make sense. It’s not that far from where people collect water,” he said. “Our homicide will have to dig deeper and check the parents, the aunty and the person who sleeps inside the vehicle and the community.” The three are cousins – a girl and her two cousin brothers – who had followed an aunt of theirs for a wash and wait for her to fetch water. Turi said it didn’t make sense because the area is surrounded by houses and the water area is always packed with people. He urged parents to always keep an eye out for their children there are cases of minors being abused or murdered. This is the second time in the same year for police to deal with such suspicious cases involving children under 10 years. “This is similar to the Gereka case a few months back where the decomposed bodies of two cousins were found after three months but this case is a day and a half,” he said. “The aunty who had brought them down to the water area will also be taken in for questioning, as well as the parents.” According to police reports, the girl had bruises on her waists and a post-mortem will be done soon and investigation is ongoing. Turi said the three went missing on Friday between 3pm and 5pm and a complaint was laid. The person of interest who usually sleeps in the vehicle open the door on Sunday at around 3am and discovered the bodies. “That person of interest is locked up at the Boroko Police Station. Forensic attended to the crime scene and took pictures,” he said. “Particulars from witnesses were taken. The bodies were transported to the hospital and person of interest taken into custody.” Police also said when they checked the scene, the children were naked. Their clothes were placed next to them. All possibilities of suffocation have been ruled out as police alleged that they were murdered somewhere and placed in the vehicle.

Title: High court reserves Paraka decision
Content: THE Supreme Court has reserved its ruling on an application by convicted lawyer Paul Paraka to set aside the decision which dismissed his appeal on conviction to a later date. A three-man bench comprising justices David Cannings, George Manuhu and Joseph Yagi yesterday presided over Paraka’s appeal. Paraka, who is representing himself, filed the application and has sought orders to set aside the decision which dismissed his appeal on conviction, arguing that there was some judicial bias. He said there was no evidence that proved the allegations against him at that time was true and argued that his conviction made by the primary judge was based on lies. Paraka was found guilty of five counts of misappropriating K162 million of State money and was jailed 20 years. He said there were transactions made at that time, but none of them were deposited into the Paraka Lawyers bank account. He asked the court to assess what is before them, the affidavits and said they would realise that there was no evidence of deposit records. Paraka also informed the court that the decision on his bail application sought on serious medical grounds for medical treatment overseas heard last month before the National Court, is yet to be made. He asked the bench to grant him a bail of K5,000, pending his appeal on sentence. State prosecutor Helen Roalakona objected and argued that the application is well out of time which is 21 days. The State argued that there were no exceptional circumstances or a reasonable explanation to the appeal, as the application is not compliant before the Supreme Court Rules. The State submitted that the jurisdiction has not been invoked, with respect to the slip rule application. On the ground of appeal in terms of perception bias, the State submitted that it has been misleading in what is being sought and is an abuse of the court’s process. The State argued that Paraka had filed similar applications and similar grounds had been raised.

Title: Government urged to urgently fix Bulolo road
Content: FARMERS and Settlers Association president, Wilson Thompson, wants the Government to address the continuous deterioration of the Bulolo Highway to enable smooth flow of business. Thompson said the Bulolo Highway is the transnational highway connecting New Guinea to Papua, therefore, the Government should ensure it is an established Highway at all times. The Bulolo Highway is a short route that carries heavy traffic and loads for the Hidden Valley Mine and many small and alluvial miners, forestry plantations, timber products, farm input, poultry products and the coffee industry. The highway also connects Wau-Waria and Menyamya, providing accessibility to local farmers, entrepreneurs and business houses. “Bulolo Wau Menyamya Highway is still in a mess and affecting the country,” he said. “PNG is facing shortages of chicken and poultry products, not because of production and availability, but because the major supplier is affected by the road.” Thompson said while new funding was allocated under the Transnational Highway, the state of the Bulolo Highway is a burden on the people and businesses in Bulolo, Wau Waria and Menyamya and other users from Gulf.

Title: Nomane granted application
Content: THE Supreme Court yesterday granted Chuave MP James Nomane’s application to challenge the position of Opposition leader held by Douglas Tomuriesa. A five-man bench comprising Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika and justices Kingsley Allan David, David Cannings, George Manuhu and Derek Hartshorn ruled that Nomane had raised significant constitutional issues which were justifiable. Nomane had filed the application through his lawyer Paul Mawa, seeking declaration pursuant to Section 64(2) of the Organic Law on Integrity of Political Parties and Candidates (OLIPPAC) for purposes of electing the Opposition leader in a democratic manner. Nomane is asking the court to declare that support for him as the Opposition leader by 10 out of the 18 Opposition MPs satisfied the requirements of Section 64(2) of the OLIPPAC. Nomane’s lawyer argued that section 64 may not be directly a provision, but is a Constitutional right. He said that Nomane is only asking the court to declare that he has standing to challenge Tomuriesa’s position, which according to OLIPPAC referred to the majority rules. Tomuriesa’s lawyer argued that Nomane had no standing, and that the application did not raise a serious constitutional issue. He submitted that the application should be dismissed. Second intervener Attorney-General Pila Niningi made no objections and supported Nomane’s application. The bench declared that Nomane has standing to bring this matter to this court. “We are satisfied that he has sufficient interest as a member of the Opposition. The interpretation and application of section 64 of the OLIPPAC is a serious issue. “We agree that Nomane has standing and the application is granted,” the bench said. In June, 10 out of the 18 MPs in the Opposition caucus endorsed Nomane’s nomination as the Opposition leader after Tomuriesa became the leader of the People’s Progress Party and reduced himself to a one-man party. On July 29, Parliament Speaker Job Pomat announced that he would recognise Tomuriesa as the Opposition leader and James Donald as the deputy opposition leader. Pomat told Opposition MPs to resolve the matter. They wrote letters individually to Pomat to recognise Nomane as the new Opposition leader.  The matter will go back to the listings court for parties to meet and discuss on how the matter would be dealt.
People: Douglas Tomuriesa, James Donald, James Nomane, Job Pomat, Pila Niningi

Title: Mapex graduates 59
Content: Kevin Rupa stood tall and proud after receiving his certificate as a dump truck operator at the 21st graduation of Mapex Training Institute in Port Moresby recently. Rupa said it was tough but he had to push through to add value to his life and also create change not only for himself but his family as well. Rupa, 26, from Hula in Central, was among 59 students who graduated with certificates as motor vehicle and plant operators. He said: “Over the past four months, we learnt both theory and practical lessons. I have learnt so much and am grateful because apart from receiving certificates, we have been given licenses to operate as plant operators. “I came from a tough background and for me, this means that I am able to secure employment and there are many opportunities out there in the technical field,” he said. He said he was grateful for the guidance from the school and assistance from family and friends. MTI principal Vipin Vincent said over the training period of 16 weeks from July to October, what the students had learnt had been transformed into real work readiness and despite challenges in terms of funding and transportation, they had shown resilience and willingness to learn. He said Mapex had up-skilled the nation for the past 20 years, with more than 10,000 graduates now employed in different sectors in the country. MTI Board chairman and UPNG academic Dr. Solomon Awili said the Government must prioritise Tvet not only for lifelong skills for the country but to export them to neighbouring countries like Australia and others. He said MTI started as a private trainer provider and was recognised by the Higher Education and Research Science Technology (Dherst) in 2022. “It is a registered private higher education institution, taking in technical and vocational and formal courses for both school and non-school leavers,” he said.

Title: Michael Mapai speaks for Cheshire
Content: THE Cheshire Disability Service(CDS) hosted its annual red feather fundraiser in Port Moresby last Thursday. The event was attended by Governor General Sir Bob Dadae who is the CDS patron and sponsors from both the public and private sectors. Michael Mapai, 32, a resident at CDS thanked Sir Bob Dadae and everyone who attended the fundraiser. “Your presence, your support means so much to us at CDS. We believe in creating a community where every person with or without a disability has the opportunity to live, learn, and dream without limits,” he said. “I would like to say that CDS is truly a champion in what it’s doing for lives in Papua New Guinea,” Mapai added. He shared his experiences after joining CDS three years ago and so far it has encouraged him to do many things, especially building his confidence in public speaking. “I always dreamed of coming out and speaking here in public places and trying to break the barriers for myself,” he said. He also acknowledged CDS young voice youth programme that helped him and others. “As persons with disability, usually we are really isolated from each other, but CDS and the programme, has brought us together,” he said “Events like this reminds us that inclusion is just not a word, but an action. It’s in how we open doors, extend hands, and stand together and to all the business houses and sponsors, I just want to say a big thank you.” He said every donation, every word of encouragement given helps programmes CDS runs.

Title: Ministers discuss security issues
Content: TRANSNATIONAL crime and the impact of climate change were the highlights of discussions at the 10th Defence Ministers’ Dialogue in Chile last week. Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph was accompanied by Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) chief Rear Admiral Philip Polewara and Defence Department acting first assistant secretary policy Elijah Satubun at the meeting. The annual South Pacific Defence Ministers’ meeting (SPDMM) held from Oct 22 to 24 was to discuss regional security issues in the Pacific.
