Dr Joseph confirmed PNG’s commitment to regional forums such as SPDMM to promote stability and address shared security concerns in Indo-Pacific. Members discussed new trends in security challenges facing the region and reaffirmed the importance of operational collaboration.

Title: Help for mother in labour in remote Gulf village
Content: A 39-year-old mother from Anagi in Gulf was airlifted into Lae on Monday after going into labour for three days. Manolos Aviation responded to the distress call by a Seventh Day Adventist Missionary based at Anagi following authorisation from Gulf Governor Chris Haiveta. Sailas Seapso, the husband, said to walk to Kerema would take them three days and then to another two days to Menyamaya. “Seeing the helicopter coming to take my wife and child, I cannot explain my gratitude,” Seapso said. Seapso’s wife gave birth to their baby few minutes before the Helicopter landed, allowing the Manolos team to stabilise the mother and child before taking them to Angau General Hospital in Lae. Captain Jurgen Ruh, Manolos Aviation chief executive officer, commended the work of his crew for their professionalism and dedication despite the pressure. “Flying into places like Anagi is never easy, the terrain, the weather and everything works against you. “Seeing a mother give birth just before we arrived and lifting her and her baby wrapped in that traditional bark blanket – that’s the moment you remember why we fly as an aeromedical team.” The mother and the child are at Angau hospital.

Title: New WW2 fiction book
Content: A NEW fiction book capturing a forgotten history that rests on events that took place during the Japanese invasion of Rabaul in 1942. Lae-based author Marisa Jones released her latest book on Saturday in Port Moresby,A Forgotten Land, is a harrowing story of a family’s will to survive in WW2 New Guinea. “When I started researching, I was amazed by the depth of history in Rabaul, it was a place that had seen more devastation than anywhere else in PNG,” she said. “Eighteen hundred Australians were left behind when the Japanese invaded Rabaul in 1942, including 18 Australian nurses who were taken as prisoners of war at Vunapope Catholic Mission. “Australia knew the Japanese were coming, and yet they did nothing to save their people, or to protect the local; Tolai people. “There were also 800 Chinese that were interned at Ratongor Catholic Mission and they were treated terribly by the Japanese. “Other than Berlin, Rabaul was bombed more than any other place in WW2. “More Australians died in Rabaul than in Kokoda and yet it’s not honoured the same way and therefore, this is important history and it should be remembered.” Jones held a book signing day on Saturday and each book priced at K70.

Title: Ineligible candidates should not be entertained in LLG elections: Department
Content: ELECTION officials assisting ineligible candidates in the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections will face disciplinary action, an official says. Provincial and LLG Affairs Department Secretary Philip Leo also warned provincial and district administrators not to assist ineligible candidates, such as public servants who had not resigned from their positions as required by law. They would be in breach of the Organic Law on National and Local Level Government Elections provisions and the Public Services (Management) Act,” he said. “Electoral officials must verify the employment status of all candidates prior to polling,” he said. “Provincial and district administrators must enforce disqualification provisions and report any breaches to the Electoral Commission and the Department of Personnel Management. “Public awareness campaigns should be conducted to educate communities about lawful candidacy requirements. “Electoral officials who knowingly facilitate ineligible candidates may face disciplinary action. “Allowing unqualified individuals to contest undermines the integrity of the electoral process and could lead to legal challenges, nullification of election results and loss of public trust.” Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai warned that penalties for disrupting elections were severe, including a life ban on contesting elections. “The minister responsible can use his powers to suspend elections in any affected LLG and ward where fights and disruptions occur,” he said. “I am again appealing to all candidates and supporters to observe and respect the laws, respect one another and ensuring a peaceful election.” Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe warned that the LLG elections would be declared failed in areas where the election processes were disrupted.

Title: Possible loss of life due to blackouts: Doctor
Content: THE frequent power outages in Lae has caused the Angau Memorial General Hospital a lot of damage and possibly the loss of lives. Hospital chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga said the most recent power outage was last weekend when it was off for more 20 hours, during which about five deaths were reported. “We (however) cannot say that all were directly due to the power situation,” he said. “Three of those (deaths) were expected. “It just so (that they) happened (when) the power was out. “The other two (persons) were quite sick and machine-dependent.” Binga said that on Saturday, Oct 18 at around 9pm, the blackouts caused a fire in the PNG Power circuit breaker connecting to the hospital. It reportedly caused a technical fault, leaving the system unable to read accurately, and switching between two alternating power sources – the PNG Power main grid and Angau’s Central Energy Unit. “The lever was locked in so even when the PNG Power supply went off, our system was reading that there was power from the main grid,” Binga said. He said the hospital had been relying on a power generator for over a week. “The hospital consumes about 5000ltrs of fuel over a 24-hour period,” he said. “This is a big concern for us, especially when 20ltrs cost about K78,000. “We are struggling to find money to find fuel to sustain us. “According to our technical team, the breaker parts need to be procured from Australia. It needs to be assembled and sent over. “This will take up four weeks after payments are made. “Quotations were finalised from supplier on Friday evening. “Will make payment, hopefully Monday or Tuesday. “The Australian department of foreign affairs and trade is willing to assist us doing this.” Binga also revealed plans to install solar panels. “Hopefully we are supported through our submission for 2026 for solar power which would really help us cost wise,” he said.

Title: Marape’s performance will be judged, says O’Neill
Content: IALIBU Pangia MP Peter O’Neill says Prime Minister James Marape will be judged on his performances, not promises, come the 2027 General Election. “Every decision, including what the budget is spent on and how effectively the budget is delivered, is the responsibility of the head of Government,” he said. O’Neill was responding to a statement by Marape blaming the lack of impact during the past six years as PM, claiming that he didn’t know why K56 billion had been wasted. “The wasted K56 billion under the watch of Marape, and yet he wants to try to rewrite history by blaming the governors, provincial health authorities, and tertiary institutions?” he said. “It is gut-wrenching to watch this level of arrogance and lack of care for our people. “Just ask any Papua New Guinean and they will tell Marape to stop talking and start doing. Stop the cover-ups and get to work for the people. “At a time when gold and other commodity prices have been at record sustained highs, we are going backwards, not forward. “Celebrating record Gross Domestic Products (GDP) has not put food on the table, not improved law and order, not created jobs, not put medicine into hospitals or made schools more modern and progressive.” O’Neill said “big GDPs have resulted in massive public debt with our only lenders now the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Australian Development Bank (ADB), World Bank and the Australian Government”. “Marape has not only misspent and wasted the borrowed billions, but has also comprehensively shackled our country to foreign interests that care little for Papua New Guinea’s sovereignty or the progress of our people,” O’Neill said.

Title: People in Rabaul district see changes
Content: PEOPLE in the Rabaul district of East New Britain are beginning to experience safer and more reliable infrastructure following the completion of major projects, an official says. District administrator Freddy Lemeki said that the projects were funded by the District Services Improvement Programme (DSIP) and Provincial Services Improvement Programme (PSIP) funds. They include the upgrading and extension of the Watom seawall, rehabilitation work on Blanche Street, repairs on Second 22nd Street and Tunnel Hill Road and the completion of the Toleap reinforced cncrete box culvert. Lemeki said the 80-metre sea wall built in front of the Vunakabai government station at Watom was a priority, as the area had been badly affected by rising sea levels and coastal erosion. The project, constructed by Senuak Contractors under DSIP funding, took four months to complete. It now provides much-needed protection for coastal communities and public facilities that were once at risk of being washed away. He said that the road works and rehabilitation projects were expected to significantly improve the transportation network within Rabaul town and surrounding areas. The Blanche Street rehabilitation, Second 22nd Street and Tunnel Hill Road projects undertaken by Nivani Limited, have a combined value of more than K8 million. The upgrades are expected to reduce travel times, improve road safety, and support local economy. The Toleap culvert, completed by Senuak Contractors for K373,862.50, ensures that the road remains accessible even during heavy rains, addressing long-standing issues of flooding and erosion that once made the area impassable. Lemeki said the completion of these projects was a major step forward for the district. He added that Rabaul will continue to prioritise infrastructure development across both the civil and building sectors to ensure communities benefit from safer, stronger and more resilient public infrastructure.

Title: Suspects held over killing
Content: POLICE in Kainantu, Eastern Highlands, are processing six suspects alleged to have shot dead a Highlands Highway PMV bus driver Tony Pes last week, police say. Goroka police station commander Chief Insp Timothy Pomoso (pictured) confirmed on behalf of provincial police commander Chief Supt John Kale that six suspects were identified among 20 men that police rounded up in a raid last week were being interrogated. He said police raided Tiunka community near Kainantu town after villagers failed to cooperate with police to surrender suspects. Pomoso said police brief from Kainantu police stated the suspects were being processed and locked up in the police cell. He told family-relatives of late bus driver Tony Pes, Western Highlands police commander Supt John Sagom, Assistant Commissioner Police Eastern Command Clement Dalla, Eastern Highlands Governor Simon Sia, Henganofi MP Robert Atiyafa, Eastern Highlands administrator Allan Los and public servants on police progress since the killing on Oct 17 at 3pm in Barola. Pomoso said it would be hard to establish a police post along the Eastern Highlands section of the highway, with land being a complicated issue. He also said there were 350 police officers trying to police more than 700, 000 people in eight districts, police need more manpower. Meanwhile, Governor Simon Sia committed to build police posts at Kassam Pass, Barola and Daulo Pass before the end of next year. He said police would receive 12 new vehicles this year to enhance their work. An angry Robert Atiyafa said police should quickly hunt down the suspects and bring them out ‘dead or alive’. He said criminal elements who chose to take innocent lives did not deserve to stay alive. He paid tribute and apologised to relatives of late Tony Pes from Togoba area in Western Highlands who was shot at Barola last week. “This was an unusual happening for human beings with pigs and dogs’ mentality to cause the death of an innocent young man, these people do not deserve to live, they must die or face full force of the law,” Atiyafa said. “Police must work hard to get them, leave no stone unturned, get the suspects arrested and the angry relatives will feel relieved of getting justice.”

Title: PNG among 65 nations signing cymbercrime treaty
Content: PAPUA New Guinea is among 65 states that have signed the United Nations Convention Against Cybercrime in a global commitment to strengthen cooperation and combat the rising threat of cybercrime, a cabinet minister says. Acting Minister for Information and Communications Technology, Peter Tsiamalili Jr said: “Cybercrime is one of the fastest-growing global challenges, with losses exceeding US$9.5 trillion (about K39.9 trillion) in 2024 and projected to surpass US$10.5 trillion (about K44.1 trillion) in 2025.” The signing took place on Oct 25 at the National Convention Centre in Hanoi, Vietnam, where Steven Matainaho, Secretary for the Department of Information and Communications Technology, signed on behalf of Papua New Guinea. He was accompanied by chief legal officer of Nicta Oala Moi. Tsiamalili said this followed two recent Cabinet decisions to ratify international conventions on cybercrime, making PNG one of the few Pacific countries now to start the ratification journey for international frameworks on cybercrime. Next month, PNG is expected to deposit an accession instrument for the pioneering cybercrime international convention, the Budapest Convention on Cybercrime. Acceding to both the Hanoi Convention and the Budapest Convention would provide a foundation for PNG for stronger cooperation, harmonised laws, and coordinated responses to digital threats. Tsiamalili said cybercrime affected citizens, economies and governments, demanding collaboration to protect digital trust and security. “The department will now work with the United Nations and the Council of Europe to review and modernise our national laws and institutions,” he said. “This includes updating the Cybercrime Code Act, Electronic Transactions Act, introducing Digital ID, Cybersecurity, Data Protection legislation and strengthening coordination between the department, Nicta, the police Cybercrime Unit and other agencies.”

Title: MP frustrated with transport programme over bad roads
Content: BULOLO MP, Sam Basil Jr, is disappointed with the Transport Sector Support Programme (TSSP) and the Works and Highways Department regarding the continuous deterioration of the Wau-Bulolo Highway. Basil said that despite the interventions by the Australian-funded TSSP and funding from the Australia and PNG Governments totaling more than K150 million, the road had deteriorated. He said the district development authority (DDA) had even gone to the extent of funding maintenance work due to flooding and other deterioration. “Since my election, concerns about the state of the Bulolo Wau Menyamya Highway have always been my priority,” Basil said. “I have raised this in Parliament to the Minister for Works and Prime Minister and have written numerous letters and raised it in the media. “I am disappointed to say that both TSSP and Works Department have failed.” He said that the Highway had disintegrated into a bush track and was much worse than when the funding was provided. Basil said that the Prime Minister, James Marape, launched the maintenance twice and also traveled to Wau and Bulolo in 2023 to launch the two district plans. “It would have been better for the Government to distribute the K150 million to the development authorities of Huon Gulf, Bulolo and Wau-Waria, so that we could have bought graders, trucks and patched the holes and cleaned the drains,” he said. “I wish to assure the people of Bulolo and Morobe that I waited for the Works and Highways Department. It appears that there is no solution at present.” Basil will present a petition to Parliament. “The business community and road users have presented a petition dated Sept 23, 2025, to the Prime Minister,” he said.

Title: IOM conducts workshop on mental health, GBV referrals
Content: THE International Organization for Migration (IOM) conducted a workshop on mental health, psychological pathways, and Gender-Based Violence (GBV) referral pathways in Lae, Morobe. This three-day workshop was held with the support of the US government to ensure the IOM educates and informs front-liners on emergency response and relief. IOM national protection officer, Natalie Kuri, highlighted that the IOM has been partnering with the Directorate For Social Change and Mental Health Services to deliver the workshop that brought together participants who are working in the space of GBV referral pathways. Kuri clarified that IOM worked with communities that were affected by manmade or natural disasters, and their mandate was to work with people in the area of safe migration and to support government to build back safer and sustainable communities. “Through such a workshop, we’ve been trying to emphasise how GBV has been a very big component in times of disaster,” she said. “GBV happens when there is a disaster, and how can we support our partners on the ground to identify if there is a GBV case during disaster. “And also, the psychological first aid is something that they can do to support any survivors of GBV. “The workshop is on that, and it’s almost like a refresher for them because they have been working in the space for a longtime.” Kuri said the IOM also conducted a workshop to learn and to find out how the emergency front-liners deal with emergency cases. In that way, they can support them.

Title: Catholic church holds thanksgiving mass in honour of St Peter ToRot
Content: SAINT Peter ToRot has been described as the light that rises from the Pacific, giving an opportunity for renewed appreciation for the laity in the Catholic Church. Archbishop of Port Moresby Sir John Cardinal Ribat said many lay Catholic men and women, especially those who gave their time and life to the Church in the ministry of catechists in PNG and the Solomon Islands, continued to actively serve in the ministry, many 50 years and beyond. “The church depends on you. You keep the church alive, in the parishes, schools, hospitals, rural missions and remote communities where no one would dare to go,” he said. Cardinal Ribat, as the main celebrant in the thanksgiving mass for Saint Peter ToRot, held yesterday in Port Moresby, reflected on the life of the Catholic Church and its contribution to the country’s development, and why it was important for others to understand and accept Martyr Peter ToRot as the country’s first Saint. All 20 parishes in the city gathered in union to honour the life of the saint. The parishes joined in choir and prayer and sharing in the eucharist. Bishops from PNG and the Solomon Islands, missionaries, layman and parishioners were present to take part in celebrating the thanksgiving. Catholic Bishops Conference of PNG and Solomon Islands social communications deputy Bishop and Wewak Bishop Jozef Roszynski, in his homily, reflected on Saint Peter ToRot’s faith, courage, and example of service to God and community. “In this jubilee year 2025, we thank God for our young country celebrating 50 years of Independence and its spiritual journey,” Roszynski said. “Despite having over 800 languages and tribes, we somehow are united as one nation and churches have played a critical role in setting the foundation for building this nation. “The Catholic Church has contributed not only to preaching the gospel but at the same time, the services of education and health that have been and still are evident in the most remote places around the country. “That has been evident even before independence in 1975, and now 30 years later since late Pope John Paul II declared the Martyr Peter ToRot as Blessed in 1995, we have a saint,” he said.

Title: Academic programme offers second chance
Content: THE rollout of Academic Renewal Programme (ARP) in East New Britain’s Gazelle District has helped almost 100 unselected Grade 12 students to get into tertiary institutions in the country. ARP founder and managing director Samuel Vaulai also acting executive manager for Planning and Partnership with the Department of Higher Education Research Science and Technology explained that the programme started in 2023 and was piloted in the three wards of Vunagogom Takekel and Tinganagalip in Central-Gazelle . Through the pilot programme, 62 unselected Grade 12 students had been assisted to upgrade their academic marks at registered Flexible Open Distant Education (Fode) centres in the province. Vaulai confirmed that most of these students were now studying in various tertiary institutions in the country and of the 62, one woman had been awarded scholarship to take up studies in Indonesia. ARP is a programme that that is focused on giving a second chance opportunity to unselected Grade 12 students through an education pathway where they upgrade their marks to be accepted into tertiary institutions. Lorraine Pidik said she was not accepted to any tertiary institution after completing Grade 12 in 2023 but through the ARP, she was able to upgrade her marks and was awarded an overseas scholarship this year (2025) to study in Indonesia. Pidik, 20, is from a mixed parentage of Madang and ENB. She said that because of the programme, she would be studying in Indonesia. Pidik said that in 2024, she upgraded her marks for biology and chemistry at PNG University of Natural Resources and Environment (PNGUNRE) FODE centre. “I was fortunate to be selected to study in Indonesia and I believe I am the first student coming out from this ARP and therefore I am so grateful for this opportunity”.

Title: Marape assures Auditor-General of full funding & support in 2026
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape on Friday met with Auditor-General Gordon Kega and his senior management to seek ways to strengthen the capacities and effectiveness of the Office of the Auditor-General. The meeting comes a day after Marape launched the Reset PNG@50 roadmap, Papua New Guinea’s development blueprint for the next 20 years. Marape revealed at that time that more than K56 billion has been to provincial governments, government agencies, districts, and public institutions in the last six years for development purposes. With the leap in the PNG population to 10.1 million, Marape also warned of the urgency in matching this expanded growth with service delivery to the people. Marape was informed by the Auditor-General that there was very little response from across the government sector in government agencies submitting their financial reports. As is the requirement under law, all public agencies must submit their financial reports by 31 March every year. The office is an independent constitutional office of government established under Section 213 of the Constitution to audit public accounts and oversee financial transactions to make sure public funds are used efficiently and with accountability. The office does this by conducting financial audits, performance evaluations, and investigations across national, provincial, and statutory bodies, and reports the findings to Parliament for review by the Public Accounts Committee. Marape directed that the Auditor-General’s Office (AGO) furnish to him with a full brief on the audits of all government institutions to date. He also gave his full assurance that the AGO would be fully resourced from next year, 2026, onwards in terms of budgetary support so the office is best placed to carry out its duties. “For too long, we have not given fair consideration to the AGO but this will change. I now give my full support to the office”. Marape reassured the AGO of its constitutional mandate, adding that any other government mechanism set up in this area, such as the newly-established National Monitoring Coordinating Authority (NMCA), will only work to support the AGO in carrying out its responsibilities. “The NMCA will do the physical checks. You will come at the back to do the actual audit to make sure that the funds have been put to good use,” he said. Marape said he would make an announcement at the next Parliament sitting of the names of all non-complying public institutions who fail to meet this mandatory requirement to furnish annual financial reports.

Title: Top cop: Laws on sorcery-related killings a worry
Content: ASSISTANT police commissioner (Northern) Peter Guinness says the laws addressing sorcery-related killings have had little impact, as such offences continue to occur despite existing legal provisions. Guinness noted that most victims of sorcery-related killings are vulnerable individuals in the communities. He also suggested that the government consider separating sorcery-related offences from the PNG Criminal Code Act to address the issue more effectively. “This means that sorcery should have an Act of its own. Those commuting crimes in relation to it, the person alleged to have committed the crime, (and) the burden of prove can be shifted to that person,” Guinness said. He said when an accused person appears in court, they should be able to present evidence proving that the victim was indeed a sorcerer, allowing the court to assess the validity of the claim. For other cases, the burden of proof is always with the State to prove beyond reasonable doubt, but for sorcery-related cases, it has to be reversed so that the burden of proof has to be with the accused. Guinness gave an example that when the accused go to court, they can then prove to the court by way of evidence to tell the court that the person is really a sorcerer. “This means that the accused person(s) must produce to the court that the deceased or those injured were involved in sorcery act and let the court decide,” he said. He made these comments after noting that lately in Lae, sorcery-related killing and injuring of innocent people has gone out of hand. That is not only in Morobe but throughout the country. “When this Act comes into play, it will assist to minimize the number of sorcery related killings and torturing” He said any offences in relation to sorcery have to be dealt with separately from the Criminal Code Act. Guinness said that, while the Westminster system of government may not support such changes, sometimes laws need to accommodate local customs and practices in order to be more effective.

Title: Minister Eoe reaffirms UN commitment
Content: PROVINCIAL and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe has reaffirmed Papua New Guinea’s commitment to the principles and values of the United Nations (UN). Eoe, speaking on behalf of Prime Minister James Marape, addressed the national commemoration of United Nations Day in Port Moresby on Friday. He highlighted that PNG’s modern nationhood is closely tied to the United Nations, from its early years under the UN Trusteeship system to its admission as the UN’s 143rd member on Sept 16, 1975. Eoe also noted that PNG’s cultural and linguistic diversity reflects the UN’s global mission of unity through diversity. “Like the United Nations, we are a nation of hundreds of languages and cultures, yet united under one flag,” he said. Eoe outlined how, over the past five decades, PNG had exercised principled leadership at the UN, especially on issues that directly affect its people. “We speak for communities on the frontline of climate change,” he said. “We advocate for sustainable oceans, forest stewardship, and financing models that reward countries protecting the lungs and blue carbon sinks of the planet.” Eoe said these positions were rooted in the daily realities of Papua New Guineans — from the Highlands to the Sepik, and from the Bismarck to the Coral Sea. Eoe highlighted the strength of the partnership between PNG and the UN across key areas such as climate-resilient infrastructure, clean energy, and job-creating agriculture. “When droughts, landslides, and health emergencies struck, the UN stood with us – from vaccination campaigns to emergency relief and reconstruction. This is multilateralism in action: a hand extended when it matters most,” he said. Eoe also paid tribute to the UN’s role in peace-building efforts in Bougainville, acknowledging its contribution from ceasefire monitoring to post-referendum dialogue.

Title: Public solicitor highlights key achievements
Content: PUBLIC solicitor Leslie Mamu highlighted key achievements in the 2024 annual report, including the opening of a Jiwaka office, improved staff housing, and advancements in legal aid and ICT connectivity. Mamu highlighted the office’s ongoing efforts to improve institutional conditions and expand its reach. The report also noted improvements to housing for senior staff in Alotau, Vanimo, Kimbe, Lorengau, and Mt Hagen, alongside new partnerships with provincial governments to support operations in regional branches. Mamu further discussed the office’s role in the provincial connectivity information and communications technology programme, which is progressing with three out of 19 provinces already connected. In legal aid services, particularly in the crimes division, the Indictment Section closed 292 cases in 2023, a significant increase from 166 cases the previous year, indicating enhanced productivity in legal services. The report, presented to Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae last week, also included several recommendations for parliament, such as increasing the budget for the Grade 14 salary structure, budget for replacement of ageing vehicle fleet, allocating funds for institutional housing, and supporting the construction of a permanent office headquarters in Port Moresby. Mamu stressed that these improvements are crucial for maintaining the office’s efficiency, and ensuring that legal aid services continue to reach those in need.

Title: Communities to access clean, reliable electricity through project
Content: REMOTE communities in Northern and Central will soon have access to clean, reliable electricity for healthcare and education, through a new solar mini-grid project. The project is led by the Kokoda Track Foundation (KTF) in partnership with the Australian Government called REnew Pacific. REnew Pacific’s first PNG project will install solar mini-grids at the Sanananda Aid Post, which supports 7,000 patients a year across Northern, and at the Mt Koiari Flexible Open and Distance Education (FODE) Centre along the Kokoda Track in Central. FODE is the first secondary school in the region with around 50 students enrolled. These systems will power medical equipment, vaccine storage, classrooms, digital learning technologies and satellite internet, improving essential services in some of the country’s most remote off-grid areas. According to the Australian High Commission, REnew Pacific is investing K205 million (A$75 million) in off-grid renewable energy for remote communities across the Pacific and Timor-Leste. The programme complements Australia’s broader package of off-grid investments being undertaken in partnership with the PNG Government and rural and remote communities across PNG. The projects at Sanananda Aid Post and Mt Koiari FODE Centre build on KTF’s successful pilot mini-grid at Kokoda College launched early this year, which improved outcomes for more than 200 students. REnew Pacific responds directly to the Pacific’s call for urgent climate action, showcasing Australia’s climate leadership and partnership in tackling the region’s greatest shared challenge. It sits within the Pacific Climate Infrastructure Financing Partnership, a A$350 million (about K959 million) initiative delivered through the Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific. This announcement brings the Australian Government’s investment in off-grid renewable energy in Papua New Guinea to more than K80 million (A$33 million).

Title: US Navy helicopter, jet crash into South China Sea
Content: WASHINGTON: A fighter jet and a helicopter based off the aircraft carrier USS Nimitz both crashed into the South China Sea within 30 minutes of each other on Sunday afternoon, the Navy’s Pacific Fleet said. The three crew members of the MH-60R Sea Hawk helicopter were rescued, and the two aviators in the F/A-18F Super Hornet fighter jet ejected and were recovered safely, and all five “are safe and in stable condition”, the fleet said in a statement. The causes of the two crashes were under investigation, the statement said. The USS Nimitz is returning to its home port in Naval Base Kitsap in Washington state after having been deployed to the Middle East for most of the summer as part of the US response to attacks by Yemen’s Houthi rebels on commercial shipping. The carrier is on its final deployment before decommissioning. Another aircraft carrier, the USS Harry S Truman, suffered a series of mishaps in recent months while deployed to the Middle East. In December, the guided-missile cruiser USS Gettysburg mistakenly shot down an F/A-18 jet from the Truman. Then, in April, another F/A-18 fighter jet slipped off the Truman’s hangar deck and fell into the Red Sea. And in May, an F/A fighter jet landing on the carrier in the Red Sea went overboard after apparently failing to catch the steel cables used to stop landing planes and forcing its two pilots to eject. No sailors were killed in any of those mishaps. The results of investigations into those incidents have yet to be released. Source: AP

Title: Asean risks losing credibility if it fails to stay united, warns PM Wong
Content: KUALA LUMPUR: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) must “stand together as one” in an increasingly uncertain world or risk losing its credibility and relevance on the global stage, said Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong on Sunday. Speaking at a closed-door retreat session held at the end of the first day of the 47th Asean Summit in Kuala Lumpur, he said Asean must safeguard its centrality and demonstrate its ability to resolve differences and maintain peace among itself. Wong expressed hope for swift resolutions to both the recent border tensions between Cambodia and Thailand, as well as Myanmar’s ongoing political crisis. Thailand and Cambodia had been locked in a border dispute, with tensions escalating in July into their deadliest military clashes in decades, killing more than 40 people and forcing around 300,000 to flee their homes. Both sides agreed to a ceasefire on Jul 28 after talks in Kuala Lumpur mediated by Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, the bloc’s rotating chair. On the sidelines of the Asean summit on Sunday, an agreement to cease all hostilities at the disputed border area and release captured soldiers was signed by both countries. Wong commended Malaysia’s efforts in finding a diplomatic solution and welcomed the signing of the agreement. However, this is “only the beginning”, he said. “There is still a long road ahead, and Singapore encourages both sides to exercise restraint to avoid any further escalation, and to resolve differences through peaceful engagement and dialogue, and established mechanisms.” On Myanmar, which has been in turmoil since a 2021 military coup ousted the elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi and triggered an armed rebellion, Wong said the immediate priorities are to de-escalate violence, facilitate humanitarian access and create conditions conducive for dialogue. “A sustainable solution and lasting peace is only achievable through constructive dialogue and engagement amongst all key stakeholders, and we have all said this before, that any solution must be Myanmar-owned and Myanmar-led,” he said. He noted that the efforts of the special envoy and the Asean Coordinating Centre for Humanitarian Assistance are important, and called for the appointment of a special envoy with a multi-year term “to provide continuity” after Malaysia. Source: CNA

Title: Israel to decide which foreign troops secure truce: PM
Content: Jerusalem: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel will determine which foreign forces it will allow as part of a planned international force in the Gaza Strip to help secure a fragile ceasefire under US President Donald Trump’s plan. It remains unclear whether Arab and other states will be ready to commit troops, in part given the refusal of Palestinian Hamas militants to disarm as called for by the plan while Israel has voiced concerns about the make-up of the force. While Trump’s administration has ruled out sending US soldiers into the Gaza Strip, it has been speaking to Indonesia, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Qatar, Turkey and Azerbaijan to contribute to the international force. “We are in control of our security, and we have also made it clear regarding international forces that Israel will determine which forces are unacceptable to us and this is how we operate and will continue to operate,” Netanyahu said. “This is, of course, acceptable to the United States as well, as its most senior representatives have expressed in recent days,” he told a session of his cabinet. Israel, which besieged the Gaza Strip for two years to back up its air and ground war in the enclave against Hamas after the Palestinian militant group’s cross-border attack on Oct 7, 2023, continues to control all access to the territory. Last week Netanyahu hinted that he would be opposed to any role for Turkish security forces in the enclave. Once-warm Turkish-Israeli relations soured drastically during the Gaza Strip war, with Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan criticising Israel’s devastating air and ground campaign in the small Palestinian enclave. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio, on a visit to Israel aimed at shoring up the truce, said on Friday the international force would have to be made up of “countries that Israel’s comfortable with”. He made no comment on Turkish involvement. Rubio added that the Gaza Strip’s future governance still needed to be worked out among Israel and partner countries but could not include Hamas. Source: Reuters

Title: Venezuela slams CIA, Trinidad and Tobago ‘provocation’
Content: Caracas: Venezuela’s government has condemned what it says is a military provocation by neighbouring Trinidad and Tobago in co-ordination with the US Central Intelligence Agency, aimed at spurring a full military confrontation with the Latin American nation. Joint military exercises between the US and Trinidad and Tobago are currently under way in the Caribbean and Venezuela said it had captured a group of mercenaries “with direct information of the American intelligence agency” and whose goal it was to carry out a false-flag attack in the region. A false flag attack is an operation when an act is carried out in such a way that a different party appears responsible. “A false flag attack is underway in waters bordering Trinidad and Tobago or from Trinidadian or Venezuelan territory to generate a full military confrontation with our country,” Venezuela’s government said in the statement. The statement, issued by Vice President Delcy Rodriguez, did not offer further details or evidence of the false flag attack accusations. Earlier in October, US President Donald Trump confirmed reports he authorised the CIA to carry out covert operations in Venezuela. Venezuela’s President Nicolas Maduro has levied accusations of false flag attacks before, including a plan to plant explosives in the US embassy in Caracas in early October. The US State Department was not immediately available for comment. Trump has carried out a number of strikes on boats in the Caribbean and Pacific that the administration claims are trafficking drugs. The Pentagon escalated its military build-up in the Caribbean on Friday by deploying the Gerald Ford aircraft carrier group. Source: Reuters

Title: Australia holds firm as foreign aid cuts hit Pacific
Content: Canberra: Australia remains the largest foreign aid donor in the Pacific as other Western partners including the US, the UK and New Zealand cut funding. The forecast of aid plateaus through to 2028 with Australia’s increasing infrastructure lending largely offsetting cuts by other donors, the Lowy Institute’s Pacific aid map reveals. “Australia’s steady aid spending and rapid expansion in infrastructure lending looks set to cushion the Pacific from the impact of major donor cuts,” lead author Riley Duke said. “Australia’s dominant role in Pacific development is expanding. “By 2028, it will likely deliver more than double the combined support of Japan, New Zealand, the United States, France, Germany, and the United Kingdom.” The map tracked official development finance between 2008 and 2023, which revealed a 16 per cent dip of total funds to about A$5.5 billion (about K15b) in 2023 compared to the previous year. Preliminary data and forecasts have been used for 2024 through to 2028, following the Trump administration cutting foreign aid and Australia stepping up to plug the gaps in the Pacific. Australia makes up 43 per cent of official development finance in the region, four times more than New Zealand in second. China has moved away from loan-financed infrastructure projects to grants and smaller community initiatives. This has allowed Beijing to strengthen political and grassroots ties while spending remains flat. “China now spends less than it did a decade ago, but its aid reaches far deeper into Pacific communities. Projects are smaller but more frequent and locally targeted,” Duke said. While the impact of USAID cuts in the region had been overstated, which played into China’s narrative of US unreliability, it had hurt Washington’s standing in the region, the aid map’s project lead Alexandre Dayant said. “While Washington steps back, Beijing is winning something far more strategic: narrative dominance,” he said. “For Australia, America’s withdrawal is more than inconvenient, it leaves Canberra increasingly alone in countering Chinese influence.” Source: AAP

Title: Baby choking case: Man accused of hanging boy in cupboard switches lawyers
Content: SINGAPORE: A man who is facing multiple charges of child abuse for repeatedly choking a baby and placing him on a hanger in a cupboard has switched lawyers. The 32-year-old Singaporean man cannot be named due to a gag order on his and the victim’s identities. Their relationship was not specified, but the case is classified as one of domestic violence. The accused was previously represented by Gino Hardial Singh, but he was discharged as counsel at a further mention on Oct 15. In a pre-trial conference on Monday, the man was newly represented by veteran lawyer Amarick Singh Gill and S Ramanujen. The judge adjourned the case for the defence counsel to take instructions from the accused and send representations before the next pre-trial conference. The man was charged in September mostly for abusing a baby he was caring for at a flat in July and August last year, when the boy was between nine and 11 months old. The more than 30 charges he was handed detailed acts like stepping on the baby’s face, pushing the boy’s head into a pail of water, choking the boy repeatedly, suffocating him with a pillow, hanging the baby in a cupboard by the back of his singlet with the door closed and punching his face. The most recent offence is said to have occurred on Sep 16, 2024, at a void deck instead of the usual location, with the accused allegedly twisting the boy’s arms, punching his face, shaking his head forcefully and dragging him along a table by his neck. The next pre-trial conference is set for Nov 24. For each charge of ill-treating a child under the Children and Young Persons Act, the man could be jailed for up to eight years, fined up to US$6,170 (about K26,307), or both. Source: CNA

Title: Put interest of people before yours, leaders told
Content: THE country’s leaders must not forsake the interest of the people for their own interest, says Dr John Momis. Momis, a founding father of the nation, urged today’s leaders, especially politicians, to empower the people by ensuring that they all have equal opportunities to improve their lives. “Leaders have a responsibility to the people as it is the people who put them in power,” he said. “When we have good leaders, we can develop good systems, structures and policies for our people.” He said some leaders had forgotten the people and had become more concerned about making money and holding on to power. “Leaders in politics must do the right thing because it is through politics that one can do the most good, and it is through the abuse of politics that one can do the most evil,” he said. “We are now at the mercy of a highly centralised and bureaucratised Government.” He made the remarks during the launching of the Reset@50 document at the University of PNG in Port Moresby yesterday. Momis, who was the deputy chairman of the constitution planning committee, mentioned the five national goals and directive principles in the Constitution as the key pillars of development. They are: “We have strayed over time from important principles in the Constitution like the sharing of power,” Momis said. “The Bougainville situation is an example of this. “Our Constitution already recognizes that we are a Christian nation, as well as acknowledging our PNG ways. “We don’t need to change the Constitution again for this. “We need the moral conviction to do what is right for our people.”

Title: Citizens must help themselves too: Prime Minister
Content: THE Government can only do so much to provide for the people, so every citizen must play their parts to contribute to national development, says Prime Minister James Marape. Marape said that as part of the Reset PNG@50 agenda, every person – from department heads to the ordinary citizen – had a responsibility to contribute to the greater good of the country. The Reset@50 document launched at the University of PNG in Port Moresby yesterday outlines a roadmap for policy, planning and implementation over the next 20 years. “We must reset our hearts before we can reset our systems,” Marape said. “Our positions are a gift from our people. We must serve with integrity.” Marape said that the Reset PNG@50 was not just a document but a national mirror and roadmap. “It is also not the Ten Commandments and can be improved,” he said. Marape called on all public servants to review their performances and do better by following the document which contains recommendations on improving the state of the country. “In 20 years, most of my generation will be gone. What will we leave behind?” he said. “You don’t need to be Prime Minister to contribute. Wherever you are, whether in your job or in your home, do your part.” Marape urged young people to get involved in the reform agenda and contribute to the development of the country as well. Former deputy prime minister and Alotau MP Charles Abel, who chairs the Reset@50 steering committee, said the document was a blueprint for the next 20 years for all to follow.

Title: PNG’s population at 10.1 million
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape, more than a year after the national census was conducted, reveals that the country’s population is 10.1 million. “This is far from the three million in 1975,” he said. “Our population grew faster than our economy – over three per cent annual population growth, while our economy grew at less than three per cent. “That is not sustainable.” The census, conducted by the National Statistical Office on June 16, 2024, was held at the cost of about K200 million. The previous one was held in 2011. Marape said according to the census results from the data collected, there were 10,185,363 persons in the country as of June 16 this year. He said that the census figures indicated that 5,827,441 persons were above the age of 18, while 4,357,922 were below that age. He added that financial accountability was directly linked to the census figures, which revealed that PNG’s population now stood at 10.18 million “With over 10 million citizens to serve, every Kina matters,” he said. “The K56 billion we’ve spent must translate into better services – not lost in bureaucracy, corruption, or inefficiency. “Our number one focus must be economic growth, to generate the revenue needed for services like education, health, and infrastructure.” Meanwhile, National Research Institute Director Dr Osborne Sanida described PNG’s high population growth rate as unsustainable, and worsening the youth bulge and unemployment issues. Sanida said a lack of updated population data used in government policies and plans had led to many pitfalls in national development. “PNG’s population growth of around 3 per cent is higher than its real economic growth, which is unsustainable,” he said. “The unreliability of population data has adversely affected development planning.” For example, he said that the 2011 national census was deemed unreliable. “Instead of a 10-year interval, the 2024 census was 13 years after the previous 2011 census,” he said. “The unsatisfactory conduct of population census has created uncertainty regarding the accurate figures of the population. “Without proper and timely conduct of population census, PNG has been using estimates, which vary from source to source.”

Title: IRC commissioner Koim joins the Icac fray
Content: INTERNAL Revenue Commissioner Sam Koim has inserted himself into the current controversy surrounding the Independent Commission Against Corruption (Icac). Koim, who previously chaired the successful Taskforce Sweep (TFS), yesterday posted a commentary on Facebook, seeking, as he said, to “separate the facts from the myths”. Koim was referring to recent public exchanges between Prime Minister James Marape and the two suspended deputy commissioners of Icac, Graham Gill and Daniel Baulch. He wrote: “As someone who has championed the fight against corruption for many years, and laid much of the foundation upon which this institution was built, I feel compelled to offer a neutral, factual and historically grounded observation.” He said that Icac had political backing, had constitutional protection and institutional independence but that two years on, Icac’s leadership and delivery were in question. He wrote: “Two years after their appointment, the public expectation was that Icac would already be demonstrating tangible operational results. “This expectation is not unrealistic. “When TFS was given its mandate, operations commenced almost immediately. Icac was launched with far greater legal power, financial backing and international expertise. “The commissioners were expected to leverage this head start, not to embark on long periods of global familiarisation tours or awareness exercises. Their role was to act – to identify, investigate, and prosecute major corruption cases. “Because corruption is a big development challenge and these experts were procured and resourced to address it head on from the get-go.” Koim said the recent public exchange of allegations between the commissioner and the two deputy commissioners revealed a “serious leadership crisis within the Icac that probably explains why there were no results for the last two years”. Koim also asked that in the name of natural justice, a tribunal be convened speedily to ensure the suspended commissioners were heard and justice is served. In a response to Koim on the same forum, Gill said that the IRC commissioner raised some valid points. “For the avoidance of doubt, no-one is blaming the Prime Minister or other politician for the supposed ‘lack of progress’ by the Icac,” Gill said. “What clearly sits with the prime minister as chair of the Appointments Committee is a failure to act when a report of corrupt conduct was personally presented to him, and the suspension of the Deputy Commissioners in the circumstance set out in my earlier statement – which I stand by. “I agree with Koim that there should be an appropriate tribunal, however it would be very nice to be provided with the reasons for our suspension and the opportunity to respond. That is where due process starts.”

Title: Marape questions use of K56 billion distributed to government agencies
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has directed government agencies, provincial administrations, districts and public institutions to be accountable for the K56 billions of public funds spent over the past six years. “In the past six years under my watch, we released K56 billion to provinces, districts, departments, provincial health authorities, and tertiary institutions,” he said. “Every leader, administrator, and public servant must ask: what have we done with it? That is not a small sum. “But I ask again: what has been achieved? Where are the results? Are we seeing improvement in schools, hospitals, and roads?” Marape said that recent administrative reviews had uncovered serious gaps in financial reporting and compliance, including agencies and authorities failing to submit expenditure reports for several years. He said the Government would no longer tolerate poor financial management. Every public officer entrusted with funds must report transparently. The establishment of the National Monitoring and Coordination Authority would oversee every project implementation and expenditure. “This new authority will check where the money goes, what it delivers, and whether it benefits the people,” he said. Marape reminded leaders and officials that their positions were a privilege and responsibility, not an entitlement. “If a minister or superior asks you to do something against the law, stand for what is right,” he said. “The laws come first, not politics, not personalities.” He warned that any official found mismanaging or misusing public funds would be held accountable under the Government’s anti-corruption framework. “Our people have waited too long for change. Let’s not waste this opportunity. We owe it to them to deliver results,” he said.

Title: Sinai: All provinces set for LLG election
Content: ALL provinces have received their materials for the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections as polling is set to start on Monday, according to Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai. Sinai said voters in all provinces, except the National Capital District and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, are expected to elect their leaders for the 375 LLGs and 6,916 wards in the country. He said all election materials have been sent to the provinces and election managers have distributed them according to the number of polling teams on the ground. “Voting for the long-awaited elections is set to commence this Saturday, however, the weekend is considered time for resting and polling stations will officially open on Monday for polling to commence,” he said. “All provinces have conducted second and third tier training for polling and counting officials are ready to conduct polling from Monday onwards.” Sinai said eight provinces would see the election of presidents done by ward councillors in their provincial assemblies through a single ballot paper. The eight provinces are Hela, Southern Highlands, Enga, West¬ern Highlands, Jiwaka, Chimbu, Eastern Highlands and Morobe. For the other 12 provinces, he said the people would elect presidents through the limited preferential voting system by which they will be issued two ballot papers for the ward and president candidates. The 12 provinces are Madang, East Sepik, West Sepik, Northern, Milne Bay, Central, Gulf, Western, Manus, New Ireland, West New Britain and East New Britain. Sinai said provinces can decide on when to start polling but it must be done within the specified polling dates which is between Oct 25 and Nov 10. Southern Highlands electoral process trainer Saletial Ank said officials in most of the districts of the province were trained and ready to conduct the LLG elections come Monday. Yangoru-Saussia in East Sepik has indicated it is ready for polling to start as district administrator Jeffrey Leni informed this paper that election materials have already arrived in Wewak. Meanwhile, Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs secretary Philip Leo urged all public servants to resign from their salaried positions before contesting the elections. “Electoral officials who knowingly facilitate ineligible candidates may face disciplinary action. “Allowing unqualified individuals to contest undermines the integrity of the electoral process and could lead to legal challenges, nullification of election results and loss of public trust,” he said.

Title: Mother calls for justice over son’s death
Content: A MOTHER is crying for justice for her 20-year-old son whose body was found in a dormitory at the Papua New Guinea University of Technology Bulolo Forestry College on September 18. Victoria Kalupio, mother of the deceased, Malachi Jude Kalupio (pictured), wants justice for the death of the first year student studying Bachelor of Forest Resource Management. The mother said the police investigation into the death of her son is taking time, and the college administration has not been communicating and responding to any of the relatives’ queries regarding the death of their son. “Malachi is a well-mannered young man, hardworking, and a social butterfly who mingled with everyone,” she said. “According to reports, Malachi was found dead in his room on that day, and the people who were in-charge of the investigation, said that it was a ‘suicide.’ “But, I was not satisfied with the report and conducted a postmortem, and from that report, we found out that it was a homicide. “Still to this date, we have not received a report from the college administration on how they are going with the investigation, and it is frustrating.” She expressed frustration, stating that the college administration has to respond to the family with valid reports because their reports stated that he committed suicide, but the post-mortem stated homicide. “According to reports presented, he hung himself with a rice cooker cord in his room,” Victoria stated. “I am still dissatisfied with the reports, therefore, I am calling for a proper investigation into the death of my son.” Malachi is of mixed parentage of East and West Sepik as well as West New Britain, and is survived by his mother and his two little siblings. The Morobe police commander, Chief Supt Samson Siguyaru, had directed the rural commander, Yonga Yawongan, to bring the case officer with the file for him to go through the case again. Siguyaru recently replaced former PPC, Jacob Singura and might take time to review the case before taking the next course of action. Meanwhile, the family has written to the institution requesting answers and accountability regarding their son’s death. Due to the seriousness of the matter, the university management will respond after communicating with the college.

Title: Committee wants peace and normalcy along national highway
Content: THE Kainantu peace working committee wants peace and normalcy along the Kainantu section of the Highlands Highway. Eastern Highlands’ Kainantu moved swiftly on Monday to set up the committee following the death of a bus driver from Western Highlands lást week. Driver, Tony Pes, from Mt Hagen, was shot and killed in Kompri while he was transporting passengers from Lae, Morobe. The death was widely condemned. Kainantu MP William Hagahuno, described it as “barbaric and tragic”. Hagahuno directed his district administration to work with all concerned stakeholders to finding a peaceful conclusion to this issue. Kainantu administrator Dickson Penai, who is a member of the peace committee, relayed the MP’s concerns and directives. The committee thanked Hagahuno for his swift action and he pledged to work with all stakeholders, including the Eastern Highlands government. In a big public gathering at Kainantu’s peace park on Monday, the committee was set up comprising churches, local level governments, women, youths, business houses, bus owners and district administration representatives. The two main issues brought up were: the immediate surrender or capture of the alleged killer of the bus driver and fundraising as“sore moni”for the relatives of the deceased. The committee resolved to pursue the“sore moni” issue only after the capture/surrender of the alleged killer. The peace working committee has resolved on the amounts of money to be contributed by various groups as follows:

Title: Lutheran health services to open new office
Content: LUTHERAN Health Services national administration will open a new office building with the swearing-in of new board members at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of PNG headquarters in Lae yesterday. Rev Jack Urame, ELCPNG Head Bishop, said that having all church services based at a central location promoted togetherness. “Relocating our national Lutheran Health Services Office to Ampo is one of our church’s vision.” He said having church services office located in different parts of the city affected their communication and efforts to work together for the greater good of all. “Our vision was to bring all church service arms together in one location, making it easy to manage, communicate and strengthen the work of the church through its services.” The Lutheran Health Services national administration office has moved to Ampo while the Lutheran Health Service Morobe Provincial office is still located at Top Town in Lae.

Title: ‘No one will escape’: Minister Tsiamalili says police will trace stolen K41.8 million
Content: POLICE will begin a broader money-trail investigation into the misappropriation of K41.8 million of public funds after former Deputy Finance Secretary Jacob Yafai was sentenced to 22 years in prison on Thursday. Yafai, from Karapia village in Yangoru-Saussia, East Sepik, was found guilty on four counts of misappropriation, and one count of abuse of office. Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jnr said the court’s conviction has now provided the legal foundation and momentum for police to begin tracing the stolen K41.8m. Tsiamalili commended the National Court, the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC), and the Office of the Public Prosecutor for their steadfast work leading to Yafai’s conviction, describing the decision as a landmark moment for justice and accountability in Papua New Guinea. “The conviction of Yafai is not just the end of one case — it is the beginning of a full-scale financial recovery operation,” Tsiamalili said. “Now that the courts have established guilt, the RPNGC has a clear legal mandate to follow the money trail — wherever it leads and however far back it goes. No one who participated in these crimes will escape accountability.” He confirmed that Police Commissioner David Manning has directed the Asset Restraint and Recovery Working (Arrow) Group to immediately pursue all assets linked to the stolen funds, including those transferred, hidden, or laundered through associates. The Arrow Group includes financial and legal experts from the Bank of Papua New Guinea’s Financial Analysis and Supervision Unit (Fasu), the RPNGC National Fraud and Anti-Corruption Directorate, and the Office of the Public Prosecutor. “The conviction gives us the authority to act decisively. Arrow is now tracing all transactions, properties, and offshore holdings connected to these funds,” Tsiamalili said. “There is no way K41.8 million of public money will simply disappear. The law allows us to seize every asset gained through these crimes and return it to the State.” He warned that white-collar crime was not victimless, stressing that every kina stolen from government accounts deprives Papua New Guineans of essential services and life-saving programmes. “When criminals steal from the State, they steal from the sick in our hospitals, from the children in our schools, and from our police who serve the people,” he said. “The conviction of Yafai gives confidence that the system works — and it empowers us to recover what was stolen, not just from this case but from years of unchecked corruption.”

Title: Kapavore says reform of procurement process affecting medical supplies
Content: HEALTH minister Elias Kapavore says shortages of medical supplies at public health facilities in the country are not a situation of non-availability of government funding. He said they however occurred as the Department of Health tried to reform its procurement processes by going out on public tenders to restore transparency and integrity into the procurement process so medicines were procured and made available by complying to proper procurement processes outlined in the Public Finance Management Act 1995 and the National Procurement Act 2018. Kapavore made these comments in response to recent concerns that certain public health facilities in the country were experiencing shortages of medical supplies. “Government procurement processes are time bound and so they may affect timely award of contracts and thereby impact timely delivery of medicines,” he said. “This process shall be refined and improved in subsequent procurements in 2026 to address turnaround times between calling a tender and making an award.” Kapavore said the Health Department had recognised this as a matter of priority and was working with its partners to have it resolved. “The Health Department is working with the World Bank, World Health Organisation and UNICEF to develop a supply chain strategic plan, among other activities such as health facility distribution mapping to address the government recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee,” he said. “It is hoped that this plan will set the foundation for further improvements to the whole supply of medicines in PNG by exploring better strategic interventions that may also include devolving some supply chain functions top Provinces.” Meanwhile, about five public hospitals in East Sepik, Hela, Chimbu, Milne Bay and Lutheran Health Services had been reported to scale down their services and were attending only to emergency cases due to lack of medicine supplies.

Title: Industrial centre gets K1.5 million boost
Content: OPERATIONS of Malahang Industrial Centre in Lae have been enhanced following a recent K1.5 million infrastructure boost. Centre manager Catherine Wari said their administration building underwent a complete renovation, 160kv generator set had been installed and four vehicles were acquired to help with staff transportation, security operations and admin purposes. Wari, who has been with the centre for almost 12 years and recently promoted to a managerial role, said this was a first direct financial intervention to MIC from the Department of Commerce and Industry. Under the then Industrial Centre Development Corporation Act 1990, Malahang Industrial Centre was the first establishment of its kind in 1999. Wari said MIC sat on 27 hactares of land, operated by 62 staff, including security personnel taking care of more than 50 plus building tenants (those leasing properties) and more than 30 individual titles (outright purchased vacant allotments). MIC acting managing director Osborne Kiluwa said the most basic step forward had already impacted performance of the centre. He expects the centre to raise more revenue over the coming years. Kiluwa said industrial centres had been the missing link, overlooked for many years. He acknowledged the foresight of the current Minister for Commerce and Industry Win Daki for the allocation of K2 million to MIC which allowed for this improvements to take place. “Industrial centres concepts were initiated to stimulate the economy, especially for small businesses,” he said. “MIC was established with K20m and has grown asset value to more than K100 million; we have contributed a lot to the country’s economy.”

Title: NAC to offer airport shuttle and taxi service
Content: A SHUTTLE bus and taxi service at the Jackson International Airport is to be managed by the National Airport Corporation (NAC), says Civil Aviation Minister Wake Goi. Goi said that it would improve services for passengers arriving or leaving the airport. “The increase in Air Niugini and PNG Air fleet will mean that the available resources, including parking bays at Jackson International Airport, must be effectively managed by NAC, to enable timely movement and processing of passengers from the terminal to the aircraft and vice versa,” he said. “The shuttle service is now operational, following successful trials by the NAC last weekend.” The services are for the domestic, international, and Apec terminals. It is part of a NAC plan to streamline inter-terminal movement, reduce transfer times, and ensure more efficient use of airport resources. It reflects the NAC’s commitment to improve services for travellers. There are also two electric carts (buggies) available to assist passengers with mobility needs. The environmentally-friendly buggies offer a safe and accessible option for navigating terminal areas for passengers with reduced mobility. A regulated taxi service will be introduced under a partnership with a private operator. The service will operate from designated pick-up zones at the domestic and international terminals, providing arriving passengers with a reliable and secure transport option directly from the terminal frontage. Goi said that these improvements were part of a plan to build a more integrated and passenger-focused airport environment at the international airport.

Title: Government questioned over jobs
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa has questioned the Government over its commitment to provide one million jobs for Papua New Guineans by 2027. Tomuriesa said it was an unrealistic goal as there has been little to no growth in job opportunities over the past five years, especially for youths. He said a lack of jobs has led to the high unemployment rate which has fuelled many of the law and order issues in the country. Last year, Labour and Employment Minister Kessy Sawang announced that the Government had set a goal of creating one million jobs for Papua New Guineans by 2027. She said this was captured in the medium-term development plan four (MTDP 4) as part of the Government’s overall strategy to drive the country’s economic growth and gross domestic product. In February, Prime Minster James Marape commended the National Superannuation Fund (Nasfund) for recording 34,450 new members in 2023, stating that this was a direct reflection of job creation and economic growth in the country’s private sector. He attributed this milestone to the Government’s efforts in fostering economic expansion and creating jobs across various industries. However, Tomuriesa said the reality on the ground was different. Tomuriesa  highlighted the recent dilemma that saw more than 200 Telikom workers retired from their jobs. “It is quite concerning to learn that such a large number of workers were laid off from work,” he said. “If the goal of the Government is to create more jobs, why would it allow for such a retirement exercise to be carried out? “This will only add to the high unemployment rate in the country.” Tomuriesa added that unemployment, especially among the increasing youth population, was a major factor that contributed to lawlessness in communities. “Unemployment is one of the biggest factors contributing to lawlessness,” he said. “It is because of this that service delivery is affected in many parts of the country.”
People: Douglas Tomuriesa, James Marape, Kessy Sawang

Title: Marape to attend climate change meet in Brazil
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape held a briefing with key government agencies in preparation for Papua New Guinea’s participation in the upcoming COP30 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Brazil next month. Marape is set to speak at the Leaders’ Session on Nov 6, focusing on rainforest protection, biodiversity, carbon trading, and equitable access to climate finance for developing nations. He emphasised PNG’s role as one of the last large rainforest nations, whose forests absorb carbon for the global good, yet receive minimal recognition or compensation. He reiterated that developed nations, responsible for most global emissions, must honour their climate finance commitments. Marape notably skipped COP29 in 2024 due to dissatisfaction with the lack of action on climate promises. However, he expressed optimism that the collective voices of Pacific and rainforest nations are being heard. He stressed that COP30 will be a pivotal moment to turn promises into tangible outcomes. Papua New Guinea’s growing leadership in climate discussions was highlighted, with a focus on balancing conservation with sustainable development, empowering local communities, and strengthening climate resilience. Marape concluded that PNG’s efforts extend beyond COP30, with plans for post-conference implementation to attract green investments and align policies for future climate action.

Title: Morobe school gets tanks and desks
Content: MUNUM Elementary School in Huon Gulf, Morobe, received four 9,000-litre water tanks and 30 new desks to support the school. The school was established in 1998, serving Wara Kalap and Munum areas. Like other schools in rural and settlement areas operating without clean water, the 1000-plus students, including Munum Primary School pupils, have been using a 9,000-litre tank donated by the Rotary Club. Thanks to the Australian government in partnership with the Morobe administration through its social sector, they are delivering water tanks and new desks to 31 schools in the districts. Morobe deputy administrator (social services) Robin Bazinuz acknowledged the Australian government and taxpayers, through Australian consulate-general Brenton Kanowski, for working in partnership to deliver the water project to identified schools in the province. “This project is all about supporting and improving the conditions and the learning environment for the students to continue teaching and learning,” he explained. The Australian government, in partnership with the Morobe administration, is delivering 930 new desks and 90 rainwater tanks to 31 elementary schools in the province. This is part of the Morobe Water Security Project, supporting selected early childhood centres in Lae, Huon Gulf, Markham, Nawaeb, Bulolo, Wau-Waria and Menyamya. The initiative was supported with a K6 million investment from the Australian government and a K500,000 contribution from the Morobe administration to help education and water security for more than 8,000 students.

Title: 71 soldiers begin corporal course
Content: SEVENTY-ONE Papua New Guinea Defence Force personnel will be able to lead effectively as section commanders after two months of doing a corporal qualifying course, a commanding officer says. The course held at the Second Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (2RPIR) command at Moem Barracks, Wewak, started on Tuesday, with the aim to empower corporals to lead with knowledge and skills and to qualify their ranks. Regiment commanding officer Lt Col Francis Vitata said the corporal rank is more than just another stripe on the sleeve. “It represents trust that is built to lead, mentor and to make decisions when it counts. “From this point onward, you’re not only responsible for yourself, but for those you lead,” he said. Of the 71 soldiers, 41 are from Moem and the rest are from the Lombrum Naval base in Manus. The course is expected to finish by Dec 12. “You’re not here by chance, you’re here because someone recognised your leadership potential. “Now it’s time for you to rise to that challenge.” Vitata said over the coming weeks, they will be tested physically, mentally and morally. “You’ll be given the tools to lead effectively, communicate clearly and enforce standards with integrity,” he said. “Leadership at this level is not about barking commands: It’s about setting the example being the first to step up and the last to step down.” Vitata urged them to be serious, ask questions, challenge themselves, and learn as much as they can from instructors and peers. “Step forward with confidence, humility and determination. “The journey to becoming a corporal starts now,” he said. He thanked the Australian Defence Force for their continued partnership and support towards the renovation of the training cell facilities that are used for the course.

Title: Governor committed to autonomy agenda
Content: NEW Ireland Governor Walter Schnaubelt has reaffirmed his government’s commitment to advancing the long-standing autonomy agenda for the province as the people are determined to move forward in unity. “Autonomy is not about separation; it is about empowerment,” he said. “It gives us the ability to manage our own affairs, make decisions closer to the people, and ensure that development truly benefits our communities.” Schnaubelt, also the Namatanai MP, made these remarks when opening the inaugural meeting of the newly-appointed New Ireland autonomy committee in Kavieng recently. The committee, endorsed by the provincial executive council, comprises Pedi Anis (chairman), Stephen Pokawin (deputy chairman), Ngen lsana, Veronica Jigede, Vinnie lkau, Genly Malawae Kalu Yomilewau (legal counsel) and Ricky Fugonto (director for autonomy, district and LLG affairs). The committee had resolved to request the National Task Force on the New Decentralised Government System to meet jointly with the New Ireland and East New Britain autonomy committees to share documents and agree on a model to be presented to the national government for approval, hence continue drawing down powers and functions under the current Organic Law, while awaiting the granting of full autonomy. Schnaubelt commended the committee for its commitment and professionalism, noting that the meeting marked an important step toward realising New Ireland’s vision for responsible and people-focused autonomy. “The new committee brings together some of our most experienced minds and patriotic citizens who will help refine our autonomy roadmap and work collaboratively with the national government and other provinces,” he said.

Title: New Ireland communities to benefit from solar project
Content: ACCESS to clean affordable energy is expected to raise living standards and empower local communities in New Ireland following the completion of the “Pawa Bilong Niu Ailan” project. The project, implemented by Australia and the United Kingdom, with support from local authorities, installed solar power systems in 74 of the district’s most remote villages. The new solar systems are supplying clean, reliable energy to more than 9,000 households, 76 community facilities and 151 streetlights, lighting up homes, streets and public spaces for more than 35,000 persons. New Ireland Governor Walter Schnaubelt recently joined representatives from Australia and the United Kingdom to congratulate Namatanai authorities on the successful completion of the project. “These solar lights will provide a safe learning environment for our students, and communities’ livelihoods will improve,” he said. Local communities have also played a key role in the project’s long-term success. Through the initiative, a total of 592 local solar champions (296 women and 296 men) have been trained to provide ongoing maintenance for the new solar systems. Backed by a dedicated Solar Hub in Silom village, set up to provide technical guidance and spare parts, the champions are ensuring their communities have access to clean and reliable energy in years ahead.
