Australian High Commission minister counsellor Dr Cate Rogers commended the commitment and hard work of project partners. “The project owes its success to the communities themselves – their support and participation were vital,” she said. “Australia remains committed to working alongside Papua New Guinea to achieve its ambitious electrification targets – to connect 70 per cent of the population by 2030 and 100 per cent by 2040.”

Title: Governor urges government and department to increase grants
Content: MADANG Governor Ramsey Pariwa has urged the Government and the Department of Implementation and Rural Development (DIRD) to increase constitutional grants. He said this during the presentation of the Madang government’s provincial support grants (PSG) acquittal reports to DIRD on Tuesday. Pariwa said constitutional grants such as the PSG and District Support Grants (DSG), including provincial services improvement programme (PSIP) funds and district services improvement programme (DSIP) funds, which when properly allocated, have ensured effective service delivery touching lives of ordinary people in rural areas “Therefore, I would encourage us to increase it for now as it is outdated compared with the population increase. I don’t know the population from the recent census but the population is increasing every year so if we could increase those PSGs and PSIPs for the provinces up a bit so that we can continue to touch and impact the`small people’ in the villages,” he said. “Maybe increase it to K500,000 for discretionary and K500,000 for non-discretionary components of the PSG, and then we can do much better as we are already doing great. “But we can do better than that if by next year and onwards we increase the ceiling.” Pariwa told DIRD deputy secretary (programme implementation wing) Gordon Wafimbi and his team, who received the acquittals, that it is mandatory that constitutional grants for provinces and districts be released on time and there should be fairness in its allocation to provinces and districts. “But one thing I want to point out here is that these are constitutional grants, and it is important that these funds are released on time and equally to all provinces and districts,” Pariwa said. “All these other big funding such as PIP and others are not constitutional grants, yet they are released while the constitutional grants are delayed and left out. “Constitutional grants must be released according to law. The highest law – the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Governments – warrants for this funding to be released other than all this other funding is not warranted by law, yet they are released.” The acquittals presented on Tuesday captured last year’s K250,000 discretionary component of the PSG, and a total of K1.4 million rollover of the PSG funds from 2022 to last year, which have been expended to fund prioritised development projects in Madang that were selected based on their potential to deliver tangible benefits to communities. Wafimbi assured Pariwa that his points raised were valid and the DIRD will take it into consideration and relay them through the appropriate channels.

Title: Chief secretary extends gratitude to Fiji PM
Content: CHIEF secretary to Government, Ivan Pomaleu, has thanked Fiji Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka, for hosting the Papua New Guinea delegates to Suva who were attending the Pacific Heads of Prime Minister’s Departments meeting in Fiji. Pomaleu was speaking during a welcome dinner event on Wednesday in Suva. He acknowledged Rabuka, and his Fijian counterpart, Dr Lesi Korovavala, for hosting the event. “On behalf of all the delegates representing the Pacific governments, I extend our sincere gratitude to you, your government, and the people of Fiji for your hospitality and for your continued leadership in our region,” he said. “We thank you for your inspiring words this evening, and for reminding us that public service is ultimately about service to our people with humility, integrity, and purpose,” Pomaleu added. While emphasising on the theme of the meeting, “coordinating policy and delivery across government”, Pomaleu explained: “It speaks directly to the core task that binds us all as public service leaders which we share a common mission: to translate political vision into tangible results for our people. “The exchanges we will have tomorrow on tracking policy progress, strengthening public service leadership, and upholding our values in a political environment will help each of us to do that better in our respective countries, which in turn strengthens us collectively.” In addition, Pomaleu said for PNG, “our partnership with Fiji has a deep friendship and shared history which has been forged for a very long time”. “We have long admired Fiji’s leadership in regional affairs, and we continue to value the close cooperation between our governments and our public services through trade, education, peacekeeping, and people-to-people connections,” Pomaleu said. “Your voice has been prominent in sustainable development and climate change. “I was privileged to be in the room sir, as you and Prime Minister Marape, conducted your conversations in Port Moresby.” Pomaleu reaffirmed that PNG will continue to advocate for a stronger and resilient Pacific.

Title: PNG’s ‘youth-heavy’ population is 10.1 million, with 4 million under age of 18
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s current population is 10.1 million as per the national census conducted last year, Prime Minister James Marape revealed. He said the National Statistical Office reported that there was 10,185,363 persons in the country as of June 16 this year. “This is far from the three million (persons) in 1975,” he said. Marape said about 4.3 million of this population was under the age of 18, highlighting the youth-heavy nature of PNG’s demographic structure. “This tells us something very important — the majority of our people are young. That’s a lot of mouths to feed, schools to build, teachers to train, and jobs to create,” he said. “In 1975, we were a nation of about 3 million people. “Fifty years later, we are more than 10.1 million strong — that is a massive increase, and it must change how we plan, budget, and deliver. Marape warned that while the population has grown by over 3 per cent annually, economic growth has lagged behind, averaging below 3 per cent. “That is not sustainable. If our population is growing faster than our economy, then we are stretching limited resources thinner and thinner. This is why growing the economic basket is not optional — it is critical.” He stressed that government service delivery should now be planned around real-time, evidence-based data, using accurate population numbers to determine where funding, infrastructure, and staff should go.

Title: Baruni rape, murder suspects served files
Content: THREE men allegedly involved in the rape and murder of a woman at the Watermark Estate in Baruni, Port Moresby on Feb 14, were served their police files. The defendants Kamilo Peter, Joemaiya Nelson and Jerry Pyasor, appeared before Committal Court Magistrate Paul Puri Nii, yesterday for mention. Prosecutor Sgt Sandra Holland informed the court that the police files were tendered to the three on Oct 8. The trio told the court that they were preparing their submissions and had asked the court to give them a month’s adjournment. Prosecution did not object. The court fixed Nov 19 for mention. Magistrate Nii has also extended the warrant of arrest for Aputi Tuman, John Akinai, and Awui Paul. These three are allegedly the co-accused who are still at large. Following the incident involving the victim Margaret Gabriel, police took some time to identify the suspects. According to police, six men were allegedly involved in the rape and murder of Gabriel. Peter, Nelson, and Pyasor were arrested on Feb 18 after being identified by their fingerprints at the scene. They first appeared in court on March 31 and have been in custody for seven months, awaiting police files. When the matter returns next month, the defendants will make their submissions on sufficiency of evidence and the prosecution would respond. It is alleged that on the night of Feb 14, the six suspects were seen at the Watermark Estate at the apartment belonging to Gabriel and her boyfriend. They allegedly broke in between 1am and 2am, robbed Gabriel’s boyfriend of his money and a few properties, and dragged her out of the house. Police alleged that she was gang-raped, murdered and left in the nearby bushes. The three are remanded at the Bomana prison.

Title: 14 girls create history for school
Content: FOURTEEN Grade Eight girls at Mary Immaculate Girls Technical Secondary School in Chimbu have made history as the first to sit for their national examinations. The school, located in the remote Gumine, is the only girls’ school in the area. School deputy principal, academic, Kiagi Maima, shared that of the 26 students enrolled last year under the 166 structure, only 14 reached grade eight this year. “They (students) are the first and pioneer grade eight students for the school,” she said. The school is a Catholic agency school committed to providing educational opportunities for girls in the region.

Title: Pariwa goes rural bearing gifts
Content: A JUNIOR Primary School in Madang’s Rai Coast will have a new classroom, thanks to the provincial government. Governor Ramsey Pariwa visited the newly established St Peter’s Gumbi Junior Primary School in the remote Saidor local government area bearing K20,000 for the building and polo shirts for the teaching staff. A Gumbi spokesman, Sharklee Bingai thanked Pariwa for honouring the commitment he made last year to return to the school situated in a very isolated place to deliver some assistance.

Title: EC ‘should’ cop the blame for further delays
Content: THE Electoral Commission should be held accountable if there is another deferral to the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections, Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa says. “Our people have already grown tired of the constant deferrals to the LLG elections,” he said. “The candidates themselves who are contesting in the LLG elections have already come to a point where they have exhausted most of their resources. “We cannot continue to have any more deferrals with the LLG elections as the people have been denied their rights for too long.” Tomuriesa argued that the main cause of the delays was a lack of funding to conduct the LLG elections, adding that the Electoral Commission and other authorities should be properly supported before polling starts. “We all know that the elections were delayed because of a lack of funding and had nothing to do with exam dates or other events,” he said. “Whatever the issue may have been, we hope there is sufficient funding made available for the LLG elections to be conducted without any further delays.” Meanwhile, Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe confirmed last month that the LLG elections would proceed with the new schedule announced by the Electoral Commission. Eoe said all matters concerning sub-national governments, particularly LLGs, in the country were under his jurisdiction, however, other government departments should work in collaboration to deliver the elections. “LLGs are an important tier of government in the country and there must be no more deferrals to the elections,” he said. “We will be working with all our stakeholders to ensure that polling is not delayed again.” Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai said polling is scheduled to start on Monday and end on Nov 8. Writs are expected to be returned on Nov 21.

Title: Eight, including two infants, dead
Content: TWO infants and six adults were killed in a road accident at Korofeigu section of the Highlands Highway in Unggai Bena district in Eastern Highlands on Tuesday. The infants were believed to be travelling with their parents from Lae, Morobe, to Mt Hagen, Western Highlands. Eight others are admitted at the Goroka Provincial Hospital’s intensive care unit with serious injuries. Hospital staff who did not want to be identified said three were undergoing surgery. Eight others were treated and released. The deceased are at the hospital morgue, family and relatives are yet to identify them. Eastern Highlands police commander Chief Supt John Kale, when confirming the accident yesterday, warned drivers of PMV buses and trucks to drive with care and attention. He said police and the emergency response team which included police, fire officers and ambulance and hospital staff were at the scene and helped retrieve bodies. They also helped to transport injured to the hospital. Kale said the Highlands Highway after going through major rehabilitation was in good shape. He said good road did not mean drivers could speed to get to their destinations quickly. He described the accident as very unfortunate, Police and a homicide squad are investigating to establish the cause of the accident and compile reports on those who died.

Title: PNG needs policies to aid gender inclusion
Content: PNG needs to target policies to promote women’s inclusion in the workforce, an academic says. Professor Martin Davies, a visiting lecturer at the University of PNG School of Business and Public Policy, said promoting women’s inclusion in the workforce ensures a fair distribution of economic benefits. “Policies promoting women’s inclusion in the formal labour market, combined with investments in education and training programmes for women, could help close the gender participation gap and ensure that economic gains are evenly distributed across the sexes,” he said. Additionally, gender disparities in labour market participation underscore the need for targeted policies to promote female inclusion in the workforce. “Interestingly, women in the non-mining workforce experienced higher real wage growth than men,” he said. “This is likely to be a reflection of the higher entry barriers women face, and the higher qualifications they require, to secure formal employment.” Davies said according to a new study, which used a dataset from Nasfund superannuation covering all formal private sector workers from 1999 to 2018, there existed gender disparities in real wage trends. He said the findings highlighted structural inequalities in PNG’s labour market, where access to formal sector employment remains limited for women. “During periods of economic expansion, men experienced higher wage growth than women.  However, men also bore wage declines during economic downturns.”

Title: Bus driver’s relatives ask for peace, justice
Content: RELATIVES of Tony Pes, the bus driver form Western Highlands’ Mt Hagen who was shot dead last Thursday in Eastern Highlands’ notorious Kombri section of the Highlands Highway, presented their petition to Eastern Highlands authorities yesterday. Western Highlands Governor Wai Rapa and police commander Chief Supt John Sagom, received the petition on behalf of Eastern Highlands authorities and will today convey it to Goroka. The proceeding was put on mobile conference call so Eastern Highlands Governor Simon Sia and his law and good order chairman Robert Atiyafa, could listen in. The relatives and their leaders presented the petition that carry four main points: bringing the suspect (s) to the law, compensation for the family of late Pes, compensation for the communities and making the Kompri and Barola area in Kinantu safe for road users by beefing up police presence. Mt Hagen Urban local level government president Paul Tonimb, who represented the relatives, outlined to Sia and Atiyafa the demands. He said the demands were for the upkeep of the family of late Pes and the safety for road users in future. Tonimb said the Kompri to Barola section of the highway had been a notorious part of the highway from the 1980s and many people were killed and injured at the hands of a few people there. Tonimb said police presence must be felt from Barola to Kompri Valley, adding that Eastern Highlands police based in Yonki to Wata Bung should perform their duties diligently. Tonimb said no monetary claims were put in the compensation demands. Sia and Atiyafa thanked Rapa for accepting the petition on behalf of Eastern Highlands. Sia said Eastern and Western Highlanders had no enemity, accept for one trigger-pulling happy person who caused a lot of disturbances. He said he took note of the four points that were highlighted in the petition, and admitted that they were true, saying police efficiency and code of conduct along the Highlands Highway had dropped. The presence of police in hotspot areas from Barola to Kompri have been discussed and the provincial government will pursue to ensure police patrols are maintained through putting up a boom-gate and a police post, he said. Sia said he will do what was required of him before leaving for the parliament session. Atiyafa said the fatal incident did not happen through roadblocks but one person just opened fire and shot the bus driver, which was inhuman. He said on Tuesday, he received information of the prime suspect being arrested by police, and a briefing was to be presented yesterday afternoon by the provincial police commander Chief Supt John Kale. Representing the Wanenga clan, Togoba of Mt Hagen, Patrick Namba, Jacob Teremo, and Beldes Joel thanked Rapa, Sia and the police in both provinces for their timely response to the death of Pes. Namba said the two provincial governments had maintained contacts on the situation while police were collaborating well in containing spill-over effects, particularly in Mt Hagen.

Title: NIO launches five-year corporate plan
Content: THE National Intelligence Organisation (NIO) corporate plan 2025-2030 that was launched yesterday will be the first for the organisation to be implemented, says acting director-general Lt Col Joshua Dorpar. He said there was a draft document that was formulated in 2015 but didn’t go through verification and approval and thanked former director-general Gary Baki for taking that initiative that year. “In past years the core functions of the NIO were executed without a strategic pathway to guide and provide the leverage for the organisation to achieve its goals and objectives,” he said. “Working in isolation and on adhoc basis, drastically defies the progress in terms of its functionality, operational effectiveness and capability and infrastructure development aspirations.” Dorpar said the formulation of the plan will align PNGNIO’s corporate objective and its strategic intent to be achieved within the five-year term. The eight objectives identified to strengthen national intelligence capabilities, safeguard PNG’s sovereignty and national interests, provide strategic forecasts and assessments to government, enhance intelligence oversight and governance, promote security and good order, build strategic partnerships and intelligence collaboration, advance organisational reform and capability development and ensure accountability and reporting. He said in accordance with the objectives, the four major intents are infrastructure development, organisational restructure, review of the PNGNIO Act and human resource development and training. “The NIO Act 1984 is nearing 80 per cent of the review process and will be tabled in parliament for ratification in the first quarter of 2026,” Dorpar added. “PNGNIO in its current form is the weakest link in the chain of defences to safeguard the country’s national security and sovereignty.” Dorpar also said the plan was the first of many steps needed to transform the organisation so it became an institution effective and efficient in responding to our growing security challenges. “PNG can no longer ignore the ever-changing national security threat environment and we are committed to ensuring that the objectives of the blue print are pursued,” he said. Dorpar added that it encompasses the principles of the broader government policies like Vision 2050, the Medium Term Development Plan 4 and the proposed National Security Policy 2024-2029 to foster a vibrant and robust policy document that will effectively underpin the current and future intentions of the NIO. “With numerous consultative workshops held with stakeholders and internally, the document denotes a vigorous policy document entailed by collective professional inputs from individuals and participants,” he said.

Title: Kapavore appointed vice president of World Health Assembly
Content: HEALTH Minister Elias Kapavore has been appointed Vice President of the World Health Assembly (WHA), representing the Western Pacific Region (WPR). The announcement was made during the 76th Session of World Health Organization (WHO) Western Pacific Regional Meeting currently underway in Nadi, Fiji. The WHA is led by one president, and six vice presidents, each representing the African Region, Region of the Americas, South-East Asian Region, European Region, Eastern Mediterranean Region and Western Pacific Region respectively. WPR comprises 38 countries and areas representing 2.2 billion population making up one third of the world’s population. The WHA is the highest decision-making body of the WHO, where health ministers from 194 member states gather annually to set global health policies and priorities. The WHA plays a vital role in shaping the direction of WHO and addressing pressing health challenges worldwide. In his comments on this significant appointment, Kapavore expressed humility, saying he is honored to have the opportunity to represent the region. “I thank the WHO Western Pacific Regional Director, Dr Sai Ma-u Piukala, for his strong leadership. “The WHO Western Pacific Region’s vision of ‘Weaving Health for Families, Communities and Societies”, underpins our united effort in advancing quality health for all. “I thank the WHO Western Pacific Regional countries and areas, for their endorsement on my appointment, and I pledge commitment to not only serving our Region but the UN global one health agenda,” he said.

Title: China supports PNG’s fight against malaria
Content: CHINA has reaffirmed its commitment to supporting Papua New Guinea in the fight against malaria, acknowledging the disease as a significant public health concern in the country. This commitment was confirmed during a bilateral meeting between Health Minister Elias Kapavore and China’s acting director general for international cooperation Feng Yong. The meeting on Tuesday was held on the margins of the 76th Session of the World Health Organization regional committee for the Western Pacific in Nadi, Fiji. Kapavore highlighted that PNG sees nearly one million malaria cases annually, with around 200 deaths. He emphasised the need for research collaboration between PNG’s Institute of Medical Research and Chinese scientists, citing the growing resistance of mosquitoes to traditional treated nets. “It is important to have strategies that are successful in China to be implemented in PNG,” he added. Feng Yong, shared that China has successfully eliminated malaria nationwide and stressed the importance of evidence-based prevention strategies. “We need scientists to support us to do some research,” he said. “I will consult with the expats.” The discussion also expanded to cancer capacity building in PNG, with Kapavore advocating for more skills transfer, particularly in urology, oncology, and kidney transplants, through existing partnerships with Chinese institutions, including the Chongqing University Cancer Hospital. Additionally, there are ongoing efforts to integrate traditional medicine research, with a focus on 20 types of herbal medicine in collaboration with the School of Medicine and Health Sciences. “Current partnership with China is very strong,” Kapavore said.

Title: Pacific urged to modernise passport system, adopt biometric technology
Content: THE Papua New Guinea  Immigration and Citizenship Service Authority (PNG ICSA) hosted a  regional workshop in Port Moresby, focused on biometrics and passports in the Pacific. The event was held in partnership with the Pacific Immigration Development Community (PIDC), the Australian department of home affairs, the Australian Passport Office, the New Zealand department of interior affairs, the Biometrics Institute, the US department of state and the International Civil Aviation Organization (Icao) International Capacity Building Working Group (ICBWG). The three-day workshop, from Aug 19-21, had in attendance immigration officials and technical experts from across the Pacific region with representatives from PNG, the Solomon Islands, Fiji, Tuvalu, Vanuatu, the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), Tonga, Nauru and other PIDC Member States. The workshop was designed to address the growing need for Pacific nations to modernise their passport systems and adopt biometric technologies that meet international standards. Chief Migration Officer Wellington Navasivu said the event emphasised PNG’s leadership role in the region. “The workshop not only strengthened technical knowledge but also fostered enduring partnerships that will support the region’s technological modernisation,” he said. The workshop provided tailored sessions contextualised for Pacific nations, including presentations on ICAO guidelines, biometric fundamentals, and hands-on support from global experts. The programme was led by New Zealand department of interior affairs director of international and product strategy – regulatory and identity services, Dion Chamberlain, chair of ICAO’s ICBWG, who underscored the importance of regional collaboration. Head of secretariat for PIDC, Akuila Ratu, highlighted the strategic importance of the event for regional development. Specialist presenters included representatives from ICAO, the Biometrics Institute and passport offices from New Zealand, Australia and the United States.

Title: Nomane says unfair distribution of budget ‘depriving’ Chuave people
Content: CHUAVE MP James Nomane is seeking a Supreme Court reference to enforce the appropriations Act alleging inequity in budget distribution. Nomane said selective warranting had “deprived the people in Chuave of their rightful budget appropriation.” Nomane said Prime Minister James Marape bragged about a historic K28.357 billion national budget that would be a “game changer” for the country but that budget has not translated into service delivery in some districts and parts of the country. “At the end of 2025, we are looking hard to see how this budget had translated into service delivery and tangible development for our people,” he said. “Chuave has not received its budget appropriation. Where is the minimum K20 million under DSIP, DIP and Kina-for-Kina?  Where is the PIP for our roads, power, and our limestone project?  Why are we expected to be beggars in Waigani like the money belongs to the Prime Minister? “Why hasn’t Simbu Provincial Government received its K34 million functional grants? “The time has come to put a stop to this inequity and petty politics based on political cronyism and favouritism. “We must measure leadership by results,” Nomane said. He blamed the government for mismanaging the 2025 budget, calling it “failed because of the Marape government’s unsustainable spending, excessive borrowing, and an unrealistic revenue projection, worsened by weak fiscal management, poor implementation of government policy, and political interference.” Reality is replaced by vanity, pride, and ego with a debt at K65 billion, he said. “When inconsistency, unfairness, and oversight in budget implementation occurs through selective warranting leading to sectors, provinces, and districts missing out on funds, then we must question how on earth the Prime Minister is running the country,” he said. “The country is just too big to be subject to such nefarious tactics and weak leadership.” He said the country has had enough after six years of “this pathetic PANGU-led government, and continued budget failure because of incompetence and the need to serve selfish interests” above the needs of the nation” . “What is happening to Chuave and Simbu are not isolated – it’s happening to other districts, provinces, and sectors. “Members of Parliament must stop pretending,” Nomane said.

Title: ABG signs MoU to support young offenders
Content: THE Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) plans to give young offenders in the Mabiri Juvenile Rehabilitation Centre a chance to reform, rebuild, and reintegrate into productive citizens. This follows the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between the Department of Justice and Attorney General (DJAG), the Autonomous Bougainville Government, and the Catholic Diocese of Bougainville. Secretary of DJAG Dr Eric Kwa said this MoU marked a continuous partnership and mutual commitment to the effective operation and management of the Mabiri Juvenile Centre. “This arrangement is in line with the Juvenile Rehabilitation and Reintegration Policy framework that enables us to strengthen our partnership to deliver justice services in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville,” he said. Dr Kwa said that the MoU drews its strength from the guiding principles of our Constitution, the Juvenile Act 2014, the Juvenile Rehabilitation and Reintegration Policy 2021-2031, and the Bougainville Peace Agreement 2001. He said it also acknowledged the valued support of the Australia-PNG Law and Justice Partnership, particularly through the Shaping Bougainville Justice Programme. Secretary for Department of Justice and Legal Services Leontine Ivano said this MoU was a testament to their shared commitment to improving the lives of the children and community. “The Mabiri Rehabilitation Centre plays a crucial role in providing a safe and supportive environment for young people who come into conflict with the law. “This MoU will ensure that our young people receive the care, guidance, and support they need to reform and reintegrate into society,” she said Dr Kwa thanked the Catholic Church, the Government and those that continued to support the Juvenile Rehabilitation Centres in other parts of the country. The effective operation and management of the Mabiri Rehabilitation Centre caters not only the juveniles in AROB but the whole of New Guinea Islands region.

Title: Two juveniles sit Grade 8 exams
Content: TWO juveniles from Erap Boys Town Primary School are sitting their national examinations alongside 174 Grade Eight students from Erap Primary School in Morobe. The collaboration between the two schools is part of a juvenile justice rehabilitation initiative, providing individuals a second chance at education. Head teacher Herman Agregum explained that the partnership helps integrate the juveniles into a larger school community. “The Erap Boys Town Primary School has been sending students to sit their national examinations at Erap Primary School. “This is because a lone student cannot sit alone in a big room to do his examination because he will feel lonely. “And it will psychologically affect him,” Agregum explained. The programme is supported by the Department of Justice and Attorney-General and is designed to assist the rehabilitation of juveniles. Agregum further noted that the students from Erap Boys Town are also involved in various school activities, particularly sports, to foster a sense of belonging within the community. The juveniles, escorted by juvenile officers, travel about four kilometres from the Boys Town to the primary school for their exams and return to their centre afterward. Agregum emphasised the importance of offering these students a second chance, stating, “The Erap Primary School will continue to support the rehabilitation programme, because these students deserve a second chance in life.”

Title: Head teacher confident about students’ success
Content: OMILI Primary School head teacher Yelo Amu remains confident that his students will succeed and progress to Grade Nine despite facing significant challenges. Omili Primary School, one of the largest schools in Morobe and serves about 5,000 students, is battling funding constraints, overcrowding, and a lack of educational materials. Amu emphasised the resilience of the teachers and students, stating that the school has managed to overcome these obstacles and is ready to send as many students as possible to continue their education next year. Currently, 485 Grade Eight students are sitting their national exams, joining their peers nationwide. “We had a total of 535 students during enrolment, unfortunately, some withdrew from school due to school fee issue and other personal reasons,” Amu said. The exams began on Monday with English, followed by mathematics and combined subjects. Despite the challenges, Amu expressed gratitude and optimism, saying, Omili is progressing well in terms of academic performance. “I am confident that this lot will make it through to Grade Nine next year, because there is no room for negativity,” Amu said. The school follows the government’s policy of “leaving no child behind”, with a student-teacher ratio of 1:70, higher than the recommended 1:45 for effective teaching. Omili has a strong track record, sending a good number of students on to Lae Secondary School for further education.

Title: Police probing military personnel’s involvement in Chimbu tribal fight
Content: CHIMBU police are investigating a fight between the Era tribe and the Kalubiagao tribe in Digine which involved a soldier. Provincial police commander Supt Mazuc Rubiang said the fight started on Monday when the soldier who was on leave was attacked by youths from the Era tribe during a fight. “Guns were used in the fight, which resulted in shots being fired and several people injured. “Five houses were burnt. Police are now investigating the matter,” Rubiang said. “Those involved will be identified and dealt with accordingly because some innocent people had been injured and lost their property. “I have been raising awareness about how alcohol (had affected) lives and property.” He said yesterday that at 4am, he was with officers making sure that the situation was under control. Rubiang said they spoke to both sides and advised them to assist police in identifying suspects. Police will patrol the area.

Title: Marape reaffirms commitment to Icac’s independence
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has reaffirmed his commitment to the independence of the Independent Commission Against Corruption (Icac), following comments by two suspended deputy commissioners in the media. Suspended deputy commissioners Graham Gill and Daniel Baulch had accused Marape of interfering in the operations of the anti-corruption body. Gill posted on his Linked-In page that he and Baulch were informed by email four months ago by Marape, the chairman of the appointments committee, that they were suspended. But no reason was given for it. However, Marape in a statement yesterday said while every citizen, including senior officers of the law, had the right to express opinions, public forums and media statements were not appropriate avenues for discussing ongoing legal and administrative matters. “As a senior officer of the law, the suspended Deputy Commissioner Daniel Baulch should know that due process must be allowed to take its full course,” he said. “He remains innocent until proven otherwise by the Judicial Tribunal to be established by the Chief Justice.” Marape clarified that the suspension and related proceedings involving the Icac Commissioner and two Deputy Commissioners were conducted strictly under the Organic Law on Icac, the Constitution, and the Organic Law on the Duties and Responsibilities of Leadership. “This is not a political issue or a government decision – it is a matter arising from allegations and counter-allegations among the three senior officers themselves,” he said. An inquiry was conducted by a panel led by the Secretary for the National Judicial Staff Services, with the State Solicitor and the Secretary to the National Executive Council as members. Marape said it was disappointing that the three senior officers of Icac, who were appointed to lead the fight against corruption, were instead engaged in fighting each other. “Two or three years on, instead of fighting corruption, these gentlemen have been fighting among themselves despite the major budgetary support my government has given to Icac,” he said. “So, what do you expect me to do? We have to refer the matter to due process to determine the facts and separate hearsay from truth.”

Title: Bougainville Government swears in cabinet
Content: A 14-MEMBER Bougainville Executive Council was sworn in yesterday as the next phase in the leadership and governance of the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, says President Ishmael Toroama. Toroama, after the 14 were sworn-in by Magistrate Bruce Tasikul, reminded them that their roles were not just to govern, but also to lead with integrity and discipline. Toroama is the Minister for Intergovernmental Affairs, Mining, Communications and State-Owned Enterprises. Others are: “The people of Bougainville have entrusted you with a sacred duty,” Toroama said. He emphasised that the BEC must demonstrate loyalty to the Bougainville constitution and the people. “Loyalty must mean fidelity to the constitution of Bougainville, to the guiding principles of good governance, and to the dreams of every Bougainvillean in every corner of our land,” he added.

Title: Labour productivity key for long term wage growth, official says
Content: LABOUR productivity, the amount of output a worker produces, is an important driver of long term wage growth and improvements in living standards in Papua New Guinea, an academic says. Professor Martin Davies, a visiting lecturer at the University of PNG School of Business and Public Policy, said an increase in labour productivity could lead to businesses being more efficient and paying workers higher wages. “Workers may become more productive through better tools, improved skills or more efficient organisation, better infrastructure and institutions,” he said. “When this happens, businesses can afford to pay higher wages without losing competitiveness. “If wages rise faster than productivity, firms may cut jobs or pass on costs through higher prices. “If productivity rises but wages do not, workers are left behind. “Linking wages to productivity provides a sustainable path to rising incomes and competitiveness.” Davies said based on the “Productivity Study of the Non-Resource Sector in Papua New Guinea, 2001-2024”, which provides an analysis of productivity growth in the formal services, industry and agricultural sectors, policymakers could link wage policy and economic reform to the measure of productivity in the country. He said that the findings from this study also helped to inform the Minimum Wages Board to approve the increase of the country’s minimum wage rate to K5 an hour by Jan 1 next year. He added that the study provided an evidence-based benchmark for policies in minimum wage setting, agricultural reform and improving the current business environment. “With productivity growth averaging 1.5 per cent per year, minimum wages adjusted for inflation can rise in line with this benchmark without undermining competitiveness. “Secondly, stagnant productivity in agriculture reflects structural problems: weak infrastructure, poor market access, low technology adoption and limited investment. “Without reforms, agricultural incomes will continue to lag those in other sectors. “Finally, productivity gains in all sectors are being held back by deteriorating conditions. “Fixing foreign exchange access, utilities, regulation and security issues are critical. “Without these reforms, PNG risks eroding the productivity growth its more dynamic sectors have managed to achieve.”

Title: Jailed 20 years for murder
Content: A 36-year-old woman was jailed 20 years for the death of her husband after stabbing him in the neck with a kitchen knife in Port Moresby. Janet Mara, of Enga’s Imam Village in Kompiam Ambum was found guilty before National Court Judge Nicholas Miviri on Oct 6. The court noted that Mara worked as a cleaner while her late husband, James Paulus, worked as a driver of the National Judicial Staff Service (NJSS).  Judge Miviri when handing down his decision on sentence, said that this was a very serious case of murder committed as depicted by the evidence. “No one should be denied the right to life under section 35 without sanction of the law. Because we only live once.” he said. “Mara’s antecedent report states that she was the cleaner of the Chief Justice chamber for nine years. “She was literally at the doorsteps in the hall of Justice law and order. Both had their livelihood and sustaining in life demarcated by this foundation.” Judge Miviri urged every staff and employee of law enforcement agencies of Government to show light to the world instead of committing such offences. The court heard that on July 5, 2024, Mara and her husband, who were living together at the time, had been drinking with two others outside a trade store near their home. An argument broke out between the couple between 1am and 2am. Mara left briefly and returned shortly after. She then approached her husband and stabbed him on the left side of the neck with a small knife. After pulling out the weapon, she attempted to flee but was apprehended by bystanders. Judge Justice Miviri also recommended that Mara be transferred to Baisu jail in Mt Hagen, so she can serve her sentence closer to her family.

Title: Fode grade 10s in Southern Highlands sit exams
Content: FLEXIBLE and Open Distance Education (Fode) grade 10 students in Southern Highlands’ Imbonggu and Pangia sat their national examinations on Monday. Fode assistant coordinator for Imbonggu, Justin Kera said that 207 grade 10 students from Ialibu Pangia and Imbonggu started their exams at the Ialibu Secondary School and will continue next week. Kera said Ialibu Pangia and Imbonggu were beneficiaries of the Education Department’s pilot project that established Fode at district level in 2023. “Otherwise, Fode centres would only be operated in the main centres of the country,” Kera said Through the Fode centre in Imbonggu, many students were sent to the University of Goroka, Port Moresby Technical College and teachers’ colleges.’’ He said Fode was designed for students who could be enrolled in the mainstream education system due to various reasons. He encouraged young people to upgrade their academic marks at the Fode centre to enable them to continue on with their education.

Title: ENB locals urged to take up rice farming
Content: RICE farmer and Volavolo-Rasimen ward councillor John Potol is urging people in East New Britain to take up rice farming. His journey began through a Local Level Government (LLG) programme that distributed rice seeds to ward councillors in Gazelle’s Reimber-Livuan area. His dedication earned him a spot in a Trukai Industries training in Port Moresby last year, which aimed to certify farmers to establish model rice farms. Following the training, Potol’s farm was selected as a model rice farm for East New Britain. He now promotes two main Trukai rice varieties grown in Papua New Guinea (PNG): White Finch (Jasmine), which takes seven months to mature, and Trukai-12, which requires good irrigation and matures in three months. A third variety, Trukai-26, is under trial in Australia. At the Gazelle Agriculture Show, Potol demonstrated rice milling techniques and offered local rice for tasting. He emphasised the benefits of growing Trukai-12 in well-irrigated areas and encouraged other farmers, including cocoa and balsa growers, to make smart agricultural choices. “We want more farmers to grow rice, and hopefully, in time, we can cultivate the Trukai- 26 variety here in PNG,” Potol said. He sells his Trukai-12 rice for K5 and White Finch for K7 per 600 grams. Potol’s two-hectare farm supports Trukai’s push to expand local rice farming, using retained seeds for replanting. He also grows vegetables, watermelons, and raises livestock. Two Gazelle farmers have joined him in Trukai’s training programme to support local production.

Title: Union critical of overcrowding in jails
Content: THE Correctional Service Employees Association (CSEA) is calling on the Government to treat overcrowding of all its prison facilities as a matter of national security. CSEA president Daniel Mollen said: “Decades of neglect of the CS is no longer a legacy issue of administrative failure, but a serious security and safety risk that directly endanger the lives of correctional officers and the public.” He made reference to a report on page one ofThe Nationalon Oct 8 relating to overcrowding and jail capacities taken from a human rights report. The report as published, indicates that jails are overpopulated, giving rise to concerns on human rights, health, sanitation and under feeding which lead to frequent jail breaks. The report states that the holding capacity of the 21 prisons across the country is 5,000 prisoners which cannot cater for the current intake of more than 7,000. From this, the current ratio is one correctional warder to 20 prisoners and less for less populated prisons, further posing risks with ailing infrastructure, less CS personnel and other issues. Mollen said: “The report confirms what our officers live through every single day and our jails are at a breaking point. “For too long, the government has turned a blind eye to the correctional system”. The association also highlighted some key areas that needed urgent attention which included having a permanent commissioner, supplementary budget, court hearings, staff welfare and allocation of emergency capital funding for urgent infrastructure expansion.

Title: Marape wants to be known for quality education
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says the greatest legacy he wishes to leave behind for the next generation – especially the children of his Tari-Pori district and the wider Hela – is quality education. Speaking on Sunday at the opening and handover of three new staff houses – each vauled at K700,000 – at the Hope Institute in Tari, he said material possessions such as money and wealth come and go. Marape said education remained the key to a better future and should always be every parent’s top priority. “Our plan and aim are to give hope to the children,” he said. “They must feel that they are valued and that they can continue to learn and improve their lives through the formal education system.” Marape thanked Hela Governor Philip Undialu and the Hela government for supporting the Hope Institute, describing it as a “second-chance school” for students who had completed grades eight, 10 and 12 but were unable to progress to secondary or tertiary institutions. He said the school was once located on swampy land, but it had been drained and rehabilitated for new infrastructure. “The decision by Governor Undialu and his education division is highly valued and appreciated,” Marape said. “Thank you for giving us the three staff houses to accommodate our hardworking teachers who are shaping the next generation of good citizens.” Marape noted that the original school buildings were damaged by a major earthquake, and development had been delayed by landownership issues. This has now been resolved, with the land placed under State ownership and managed by the district and institute. Upgrading facilities and buildings for the future with these challenges resolved, construction will now proceed on new classrooms and staff housing, including a four-in-one double classroom funded by the Hela government. Because the site sits on reclaimed swamp, all future classrooms will feature reinforced concrete foundations to withstand seismic activity. Marape also announced plans to elevate Pai Hope Institute to university status through the establishment of Hope Polytechnic College, catering for grades 10 and 12 graduates. “Dreams start small, and already there is a big ray of hope at Hope Institute,” Marape said. “That is my dream for Tari-Pori and Hela – to give hope to our children.” Marape said the Hope Institute and Hope Polytechnic should uphold discipline and moral values. “We want our schools to be betel nut and smoke-free,” he said. “Teachers and staff must be role models.”

Title: PNG Law Society joins international legal body
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Law Society (PNGLS) is now a full member of the Law Association for Asia and the Pacific (Lawasia). This follows a successful address delivered by president Hubert Namani at the Lawasia Council Meeting held in Hanoi, Vietnam, recently. Namani said this marks Papua New Guinea’s a return to the regional legal stage and reaffirms PNGLS’ commitment to the promotion of justice, the strengthening of the rule of law, and meaningful collaboration with legal communities across the Asia-Pacific. “Our readmission to Lawasia opens new pathways for PNG lawyers to engage in the international legal dialogue, access high-level professional development, and contribute to critical regional discussions affecting the rule of law and fundamental rights,” he said. In a development of great national significance, Lawasia has also confirmed Papua New Guinea to host the Lawasia Environmental Law Conference in Port Moresby, next year. The conference will provide a platform for PNG to: Through the reinstated membership, Papua New Guinea Law Society members will gain access to Lawasia conferences, forums, and workshops across the region and platforms on legal and rule of law issues and others.

Title: Some grade 8 students starting their exams today
Content: ABOUT 130,000 grade eight students from 3,400 primary schools in the country were scheduled to sit their English Paper One on Monday, followed by mathematics yesterday. They will sit English Paper Two today and conclude with combined subject’s tomorrow. However, more than 200 students from five schools on remote Rossel Island in Milne Bay were not able to sit their exams on Monday and yesterday because the papers did not reach the island. St Mary’s Primary School teacher Nathan Iwaidina said they had been waiting since the weekend for the papers. “Teachers, students and invigilators were on the ground but the exam papers did not arrive till Tuesday afternoon,” he said. Iwaidina said the 49 grade eight students from his school and other four schools would sit their firsts exam today and finish it on Saturday. “My appeal to the authorities to make this a first and the last incident because this is the future of our children we are dealing with,” he appealed. Meanwhile, Ted Diro Primary School saw its 353 students sitting the exams since Monday. Ted Diro head teacher Cecillia Kelgai said she has confidence in her students because teachers had done many remedial classes and conducted mock exams and they were well prepared. “Our school has been in the top 10 places in the past few years and we know this lot of students would also do well,” she said. Kelgai said the school needed new and additional infrastructures to cater for the increasing numbers. “Currently, we have many students and there are about 50 to 60 students in one class with one teacher and this is not acceptable, but teachers are doing their best,” she said.

Title: ‘Black flight’ smugglers jailed over AU$17m drug plot
Content: Brisbane: Two members of a “black flight” drug syndicate that smuggled AU$17 million (about K47m) worth of methamphetamine into Australia from Papua New Guinea have been jailed. The smugglers masterminded a scheme to fly a twin-engine Beechcraft aircraft to the historic gold mining town of Bulolo in the mountain ranges of Papua New Guinea’s Morobe. Two men piloted the unauthorised flight from regional town of Monto, northwest of Brisbane, to Bulolo. After landing safely at the PNG airstrip, they loaded five duffel bags packed with methamphetamine. Inside were 87 plastic bags containing a white crystalline substance weighing 71.5kg. Testing later revealed the pure weight of the drugs was 56.98kg. The men are alleged to have collected the meth and concealed it in the plane’s nose cone before embarking on a “black flight” return to Australia – flying at low altitude with the transponder off in a bid not to be detected. The cargo was bound for NSW, but when the return leg of the flight touched down in Monto on March 21, 2023 to refuel, the authorities were waiting. Two of the five smugglers – co-pilot John Otto Horvath, 55, and 57-year-old Peter David Payne who provided ground support – pleaded guilty to a single charge of importing a commercial quantity of drugs in the Brisbane Supreme Court on Tuesday. Two other syndicate members have previously been sentenced for their part in the elaborate scheme. Justice Rebecca Treston said Horvath and Payne were far from the top of the syndicate hierarchy and had no idea of the quantity of the drugs the smugglers were bringing into Australia. “I accept you did not finance any aspect of the importation nor were you particularly instrumental in the organisation of it.” Horvath was recruited for his piloting skills and stood to gain a slice of the profits. “You had a significant role in the actual movement of the importation of the drugs,” Justice Treston said. “I accept you did not recruit anyone to the venture, and were in fact recruited yourself. “But you helped fly the plane both to Papua New Guinea, allowed the collection of the drugs onto the plane, and then flew the plane back to Monto.” Payne lives next door to another of the smugglers and failed to grasp the extent of the importation plot. “However, your conduct was more than objectively reckless, especially when you became aware of the true nature of the importation,” Justice Treston said. Payne did not hide his movements, used his own car to transport the fuel and even booked accommodation in his own name. “It’s probably best described as logistical support … both of you were to receive a financial reward from your involvement in the drugs being imported into this country,” Justice Treston said. Horvath was sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment, with a non-parole period of 10 years. Payne was handed a lesser sentence of eight years and will be eligible for release after five years. Source: AAP

Title: Suspended Icac deputy commissioners take aim at PM
Content: TWO suspended deputy commissioners of the Independent Commission Against Corruption (Icac) have taken direct aim at Prime Minister James Marape and accused him of interfering in the operations of the anti-corruption body. Graham Gill posted on his Linked-In page that both he and Daniel Baulch had been informed by email four months ago by Marape, the chairman of the appointments committee, that they were suspended. But no reason was given for it. Gill said: “In 2023 I took up the role of deputy commissioner with the Icac in PNG with the best intentions of making a difference, helping the people of PNG to fight the scourge of corruption and having taken the assurances from (Marape) at face value. “While I knew the work would be difficult, I never expected things to blow up in my face, quite as they did! “There have been many lessons about personal integrity – importantly how you have to set and live by your own standards and, sadly, how others don’t. “It is now four months since my fellow deputy commissioner Daniel Baulch and I were suspended by the appointments committee led by the Prime Minister (for those of you outside PNG, the Appointments Committee is the administrative body that appoints the Icac commissioners). “Neither deputy commissioner have at any time been provided with the reasons for the suspension – we just received a suspension notice by email (yes true!). I am as much in the dark now as I was four months ago. “This is an ‘unusual’ position to be in personally but as a PNG Constitution Office Holder it is quite outrageous and unlawful. “As time goes on, it is very clear that this is just action with a smokescreen of credibility to sideline the deputy commissioners at a point when we were starting to ask serious questions about corruption by politicians. Information from confidential sources supports this.” They said they were whistle blowers to alleged corruption within the office of Icac but the appointments committee failed to act properly. They and certain officers were “subjected to a vendetta of retaliatory actions – including fabricated complaints that provided the substance for our suspension”. “This whole affair sends a very poor message to potential whistleblowers in PNG. Do so at your own peril,” Gill said. “If the head of the Government can sideline the leaders of the supposed cornerstone in the fight against corruption in PNG, what does it say about the political will to change? “Serious questions need to be asked and answered. The people of PNG should not put up with the usual placatory, evasive statements from those in power. “Transparency and accountability are the foundations of integrity. PNG deserves better.”

Title: Multi-million Kina boost for defence
Content: THE Australian government has approved a A$7.7 million (about K19.7 million) investment for a 200-bed facility at the Goldie River Training Depot to train 200 recruits annually. Australian acting prime minister and defence minister Richard Marles said a taskforce would be established to facilitate the recruitment of PNG citizens directly into the Australian Defence Force (ADF), with PNG permanent residents able to join by January 2026. Additionally, Australia will invest AU$2.2 million (about K5.63 million) to design a barracks in Hela for the third brigade of the PNG Defence Force, and will train six PNG pilots annually to strengthen the country’s air capacity. He added that they would be providing more than 3,000 rifles over the next four years to build up the armory which would be around a AU$356mil (about K910.56 million) commitment. “All of these are important steps forward in terms of operationalising the alliance that we have built on the deeply integrated defence relationship.” Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph said he was happy to see what would benefit PNG from the treaty and happy to work alongside the Australian government. The Ministerial Forum provides an opportunity for ministers in key policy areas to advance shared goals across comprehensive strategic and economic partnership. Australia’s Foreign Minister Penny Wong called the developments a historic moment between the two nations. “Australia and Papua New Guinea have never been closer, evidenced through the number of ministers we will have around the table today.”

Title: Aust-PNG Ministerial Forum stresses defence recruitment
Content: THE Albanese government yesterday welcomed ministers from Papua New Guinea to Canberra for the 31st Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum. The forum co-hosted, by Australian minister for foreign affairs, Senator Penny Wong and Papua New Guinea Minister for Foreign Affairs Justin Tkatchenko, follows the recent signing of the PNG-Australia Mutual Defence Treaty – the Pukpuk Treaty – by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Prime Minister James Marape. The treaty elevates the relationship to an alliance and reflects both countries’ commitment to each other and to a region that is peaceful, stable and prosperous. Australian acting prime minister and defence minister Richard Marles said building on decades of close collaboration, the forum would build on the decades of cooperation and elevate the two neighbours engagement on shared priorities, including: The delegation will also engage with Australian and Papua New Guinean private sector representatives through the annual Australia-PNG Business Dialogue, co-hosted by Australian Minister for Trade and Tourism Senator Don Farrell, and PNG Minister for International Trade and Investment Richard Maru. Wong added: “This is a historic moment in the story of our two nations, Australia and Papua New Guinea; we are the oldest of friends, closest of neighbours, and soon-to-be, newest of allies. “Today, we take our first steps on the stewardship of our alliance and nurture our full breadth of interests to shape a peaceful, stable and prosperous Blue Pacific.”
People: James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko, Richard Maru

Title: PNGDF personnel complete training
Content: SIX Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) personnel from the Air Transport Wing last week completed a two-week course on engine services. Mike Mitchell, a PT6A engine trainer from New Zealand, said the course was limited to basic servicing requirements for aircraft engines and centred deeper into engine construction. “The course is also into the operational aspects of the engine which at this point they haven’t been involved in so the engine running and operational checks are being taught,” he said. “They get a lot of structural knowledge and we also ventured into the operational side the actual operation of the engine and understanding how it works.” Mitchell said that they discussed a lot about engine fitting using the PAC750. “What they are looking at, what they are seeing, what the engine is like and trying to represent that to them in the classroom which is quite a difficult concept to comprehend if you’re more comprehensively minded,” he added. He also said general maintenance is quite a different thing to operational requirements and hopefully the six have that broad range of information that they can use to work to advance and improve their knowledge. “I gave a list of systems that they need to remember and understand different parts of the engine that they can work and further they knowledge.”

Title: School instils God comes first before every exam
Content: MORE than 170 grade eight students from Gama Lutheran Primary School put God first while doing their national examinations this week. School head teacher Jpsy Bino said as a church agency school, they dedicated all the 177 grade eight students to God through a church devotion and prayers before the examinations began. He said the school was instrumental in staging church devotion and engaged students in prayers because they needed divine intervention during the exams. “Apart from the church pastors praying for them, teachers and elders gave advice and counselling to the students last week. “We are confident after preparing the students to sit for the examinations, and hope they will do well,” Bino said. He said Gama Lutheran Primary School had four classes of grade eights doing their exams this week. Bino thanked external invigilators from nearby West Goroka Primary School who came to the school to administer the examinations. The Education Department has confirmed 130,000 grade eight students began their examinations yesterday with English paper one. The examinations continue with other subjects today, they will end on Thursday. Eastern Highlands education adviser Albert Wesley could not be reached for comments yesterday.

Title: Governor wants villagers to surrender suspects
Content: EASTERN Highlands Governor Simon Sia is urging police to do a thorough investigation and arrest suspects in the shooting of a bus driver by alleged gang members over the weekend. Sia said the incident that occurred at Tiunka village has affected people who use the Okuk Highway. “Eastern Highlands has no problem with people from the upper Highlands, and taking an innocent life at such a young age when his wife, children and tribe didn’t expect such a tragic death is deeply painful,” he said. “I extend my sincere condolences to the immediate family members of the deceased.” Sia also urged community leaders of the surrounding villages to cooperate with police and promptly surrender those involved in the killing. “The Highlands Highway is a vital national road connecting seven Highlands provinces and key national projects that support the economy,” he added. “From the entry and exit points within the Eastern Highlands boundary, people must not interrupt normal traffic. “People living along the highway from Kasam to Daulo Pass should not disturb traffic or engage in illegal activities to disrupt the road. “You cannot hide in your caves; the law will catch up with you.” Sia assured the immediate family of the deceased that the provincial government will work closely with police investigation team to ensure the culprit s are brought to justice. He urged the family members of the deceased not to take the law into their own hands but to allow justice to prevail. Meanwhile, Western Highlands Governor Wai Rapa urged security forces in the area to step up and get the suspects behind bar. Rapa said Western Highlanders contribute to providing services like transport and small and medium enterprises. “Taking away the life of an innocent driver is unacceptable. I support the public transport in my province. “We pay their registration fees, we do not want to see such.”

Title: Communication devices for villages along Frieda Project zone
Content: SEVEN villages in the Frieda Copper Gold Project zone have been equipped with communication devices for emergency and development purposes, says a project worker. Frieda River Limited (FRL) community affairs supervisor John Ramit said seven radios had been installed in the communities against weekly schedules set for Monday, Wednesday and Fridays where regular checks are made on the villages. “This is to update the communities on the project and mostly for any medivacs. They communicate to base and upon their information sent through, we send it to the medical team to assess before we dispatch a helicopter to assist them,” he said. He said the village areas do not have mobile network and rely heavily on the radio transmitter for communication. The Frieda project lies on the political boundaries of East and West Sepik, with Paupe the only village in Ambunti Dreikikier and Wabia, Ok Isai, Wameimin One and Two, Sokamin and Amaromin in Telefomin, West Sepik. In the past, villagers have had to track for days for emergency or to relay messages. All the villages in Telefomin are scattered and takes hours or up to a day to reach the next village. The only village that is close to the Frieda River airstrip camp is Paupe in East Sepik. FRL country manager Dr Joel Hamago said FRL covered the full cost on maintenance and licensing fees. “We cover the costs because it’s the lifeline of the communities, they don’t have mobile phones so if they don’t talk to us and if something happens, they have to walk for days to get to Telefomin or the nearest village for help,” he said. “They can also communicate among themselves too, and not necessarily for the project but for their own well-being as well.” Hamago said costs have increased over the years, along with the added cost of doing business and development insurmountable and therefore encouraged the villagers to take care of the radio transmitters.

Title: Minimum wage increase targets low income earners, says chair
Content: THE minimum wage rate increase from K3.50 to K5 an hour aims to help minimum wage earners keep up with the rising cost of living in the country, an official says. Minimum Wages Board chairman Beverly Doiwa said the new minimum wage rate would address issues faced by low-income earners and persons unemployed, urging that it would act as threshold that wages should not drop below. The board’s determination, as gazetted on Sept 8, sets the national minimum wage rate at K5 an hour from Jan 1 next year, followed by a staggered increase to K5.25 in January 2027, and then to K5.50 in January 2028. Doiwa said that the determination would apply to all employers and employees in compliance with the Employment Act, adding that a minimum wage earner was defined as an unskilled worker aged 16 and over in formal employment in any industry or sector located in either an urban or rural setting. “The new rate is aimed at addressing the rising cost of living in the country, especially for low-income earners,” she said. “The new rate has been considered against many economic indicators of the country. “During our consultations throughout last year and this year, we heard of different rates but could only settle on one that would be manageable by most employers. “The new rate is to act as safeguard for all minimum wage earners, especially those that are unskilled and joining the workforce for the first time.” She urged all employers to implement the new minimum wage rate as outlined by the board’s determination for the next three years. “The determination has been in operation since the date of publication in the National Gazette and employers can start paying their workers on the new rate,” she said. “By the Jan 1, 2026, the national minimum wage rate shall be K5 an hour. “Twelve months from the date of publication in the National Gazette, the national minimum wage shall increase to K5.25 an hour. “Twenty-four months from the date of publication in the National Gazette, the national minimum wage shall increase to K5.50 an hour. “We need to work together to ensure that the minimum wage rate is enforced, especially when the new rate comes into effect for all by next year.”

Title: Take Bougainville independence seriously: Sir Puka
Content: SIR Puka Temu has asked every Papua New Guinean to take the Bougainville independence issue seriously. Temu is part of the Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville Matters currently running regional consultations to gauge views. He said the Melanesian Agreement signed on June 12, 2025, recommended that a report of the Bipartisan Committee must go to Parliament with other reports. He said for those who cannot attend consultation meetings must submit their views in writing. “As far as we and the Parliament is concerned, the Bougainville issue is one of the major issues that this country has ever dealt with,” he said. “It is a serious issue and, therefore, we want you to be knowledgeable, well-informed and then advise the committee.” He said result of the Bougainville Referendum was – 97.7 per cent in favour of independence while 2.3 voted for greater autonomy. “This is an overwhelming majority – this vote for independence and the referendum was authorised by our constitution, so it met the legal requirements,” he said. “The time has come for Parliament to make their decision and we are now following the law to consult people with the referendum results.” He said it was agreed that a decision had to be made during the 11th parliament, under the Marape-Rosso government.

Title: WHO recognises PNG’s efforts
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s efforts in producing positive health outcomes have been recognised at a regional health conference for World Health Organisation (WHO). WHO Western Pacific Director Dr Saia Ma’u Piukala, in his address at the opening of the 76th session of the regional committee of the Western Pacific yesterday in Nadi, Fiji, acknowledged PNG’s efforts. “Fiji and PNG have eliminated trachoma as a public health problem. These victories remind us that diseases of poverty and vulnerability can be defeated when evidence, commitment and community converge,” Piukala told the 38 member states. “But achieving UHC (universal health coverage), means tackling the deeper drivers of health system effectiveness — such as antimicrobial resistance or AMR. “This year, we saw strong momentum: Papua New Guinea and the Philippines strengthened their national AMR guidelines and plans. “Despite global funding challenges, our region is pushing forward on the unfinished agenda of communicable diseases: Papua New Guinea, screened 79 per cent of its target population, for neglected tropical diseases. “While physician and nurse numbers have improved, pharmacist density, remains low. Cambodia, Fiji, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, developed long-term workforce strategies. “Laboratory capacity is the cornerstone of effective outbreak response. “Today, only 15 countries in our region have in-country sequencing capabilities. “Laboratories in Papua New Guinea, and seven other countries, are being trained in sequencing, by Australia’s Centre for Pathogen Genomics, to establish and strengthen, end-to-end genomic surveillance capacities. “PNG (has also), developed its National Digital Health Strategy (2025–2030), aligning with global frameworks, and incorporating inputs, from national and local stakeholders. In response, Health Minister Elias Kapavore extended appreciation to WHO for support in addressing several positive health outcomes. “Papua New Guinea particularly values WHO’s technical and operational support in our efforts to eliminate trachoma, a preventable cause of blindness, and in building national laboratory capacity, including the training of PNG laboratory teams to enhance diagnostics, surveillance, and preparedness for emerging health threats,” Kapavore said. Kapavore told the meeting that as part of the country’s continued commitment to public health, in May this year, the Government took decisive action to ban the sale of e-cigarettes, marking an important milestone in tobacco control and a strong step to prevent new forms of addiction among the young people. “PNG remains committed to the regional priorities highlighted in the report strengthening One Health collaboration, building climate-resilient health systems, and promoting equity in health service delivery across all provinces,” Kapavore said. “As we look ahead, we reaffirm our commitment to working closely with WHO and member states to advance Universal Health Coverage, health security, and resilient health systems, ensuring that no one in our region is left behind,” Kapavore added.

Title: Lapses in health supply management worry Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has expressed concern about lapses in provincial health supply management, warning that negligence leading to expired medical stock and disruptions in health service delivery will not be tolerated. Marape made the remarks following reports from the Health Department showing significant drug wastage at the Milne Bay Provincial Transit Store, where more than K236,000 worth – or 63 per cent – of medical supplies had expired due to a lack of oversight and stock control. The issue was identified through the MSupply electronic monitoring system, which tracks pharmaceutical stock movements nationwide. Data revealed that the Milne Bay Transit Store had recorded no stock audits or orders for over a month, resulting in critical inefficiencies and wastage. “The data clearly shows a lack of responsibility and accountability by the store management,” Marape said. “When public officers fail to perform their duties diligently, they are directly compromising the health and lives of our people. This is unacceptable.” Marape reaffirmed his government’s commitment to improving transparency, performance, and accountability in the delivery of essential health services, especially under the provincial health authority (PHA) system. “I commend the health minister and the department for closely monitoring the system in real time,” Marape said. “This digital oversight allows us to act swiftly. Warning letters and disciplinary measures, including termination of underperforming officers, will be enforced where negligence is proven.” He urged all PHA chief executive officers and provincial store managers to ensure strict compliance with reporting protocols, stock audits and timely ordering through the MSupply system. “Our government continues to invest heavily in the health sector. We expect those entrusted with managing these critical resources to do so with honesty, diligence, and accountability to the people of Papua New Guinea,” Marape said.

Title: Bougainville ‘has more powers’ than other provinces, says Sir Peter
Content: THE Bougainville government has more powers than the other provinces in the country, says Enga Governor Sir Peter Ipatas. He said unlike the other provinces that operated under the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Government, Bougainville operated under its own powers. Sir Peter said these at the highlands regional forum on Bougainville matters held in Goroka, Eastern Highlands last Friday. “Bougainville does its own budget and approves its own budget, while we, the other provinces, get our budgets approved by Waigani,” he said. Abau MP and member of the Bipartisan Committee on Bougainville Matters, Sir Puka Temu, said Bougainville received more money than rest of the provinces. He said the National Government allocated more than K400 million every year to Bougainville. Sir Puka said the increased allocations catered for more developments of basic services such as education, health, agriculture, fisheries and many more. The two veteran politicians said these in response queries by participants at the forum who requested for more financial resources to be given to Bougainville to prepare for independence. Committee chairman Dr Allan Marat and his members were questioned continuously on what should happen if Parliament refused the Bougainville referendum. Dr Marat said there had to be a national conversation to ensure respect for each other. Many who attended the one-day regional forum urged Parliament to accept the result of the referendum and provide the resources for Bougainville to prepare for independence. Members of the bipartisan committee at the forum were William Powi (Southern Highlands Governor), Sir Peter (Enga Governor), Sasindra Muthuvel (West New Britain Governor), Dr Marat (Rabaul MP) and Abau MP Sir Puka.
People: Allan Marat, Peter Ipatas, Puka Temu, Sir Peter Ipatas, William Powi

Title: Department celebrates World Food Day
Content: DEPARTMENT of Agriculture and Livestock (DAL) became part of more than 150 countries that celebrated World Food Day 2025 on Thursday. A collective action to ensure food security and sustainability was highlighted during the local celebrations at Kerevat in East New Britain. Acting director for DAL in the New Guinea Islands (NGI) region Misbil Garalom said Papua New Guinea’s participation reflected its commitment as a partner country of the Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO). “Food security is not only about having enough food,” she said. “It’s about nutrition, access to land and water for food production and making smart decisions to sustain these resources for the future.” Garalom said challenges such as climate change continued to disrupt food systems by altering crop calendars, reducing yields and increasing greenhouse gas emissions from land clearance for livestock.

Title: Josephstaal to get school
Content: STUDENTS from the remote Josephstaal Rural Local Level Government area, Middle Ramu, Madang, will soon have their own secondary school, thanks to the Madang government. Governor Ramsey Pariwa, during a recent trip to the district, recently committed K650,000 for a new four-in-one double classroom. He explained the commitment would see the Josephstaal Rural LLG area have its own secondary school so students from there would not risk their lives travelling far to Malala Secondary, Aiome, or Tusbab Secondary, to attend school. Pariwa also took time to explain to the remote people that he envisioned to establish secondary schools in all 21 LLGs in the province. He noted how most of the government infrastructure collapsed due to negligence by successive governments over the years after the closure of Josephstaal airstrip and the lack of maintenance to the Tanggu-Josephstaal Road. Pariwa announced that a funding of K4 million had been set aside for the road connectivity along the Sogeram-Josepstaal road.
