Local spokesperson Philip Yatukru acknowledged the visit by Pariwa and his team to the remote part of the province, saying they have been deprived of vital government services for years.

Title: MRDC signs four Hela projects
Content: MINERAL Resources Development Company (MRDC) signed four agreements aimed at transforming lives of landowners and people of Hela last week. Prime Minister James Marape, who is a trustee or shareholder in MRDC also officiated at the ground-breaking ceremony for the Hela Heritage Hotel within the township. The agreements were: 5MW power supply from Hides into Tari, shareholder’s agreements and ground-breaking ceremony for the Hela Heritage Hotel, opening of a MRDC office in Tari, and annual K1 million support from Petroleum Resources Kutubu (PRK) to Hela Provincial Health Authority. MRDC’s managing director Augustine Mano said with ExxonMobil agreeing to provide gas for up to 5MW of power, landowners from the licence area in Hides, Tari town, its surrounds and other districts of Hela will benefit from the cheapest power in PNG. “This has been the dream of our leaders like late Anderson Agiru, and Prime Minister James Marape (then Finance minister) when they signed the PNG LNG Gas Agreement in 2009,” he said. “It has taken a while to deliver because we had to negotiate. But it is finally a reality and I want to thank the leaders involved, and the landowners and Hela people for being patient. “Through power, places change, development happens through investments. Hela will get the cheapest power in all of PNG and it’s reliable. There will be no blackouts,” Mano said. He said that the hotel, to be completed by early 2027, will be more of a cultural hub where visitors and guests could learn and appreciate the traditions and culture of Hela. Mano also said that Heritage hotel would complement existing lodges and guest’s houses operated by local businesses in the area. The expectation is to see increase tourism and business in the province starting next year. The hotel will create employment and support service business opportunities for locals during construction, and when operational. Furthermore, on the agreement signed with the Hela Provincial Health Authority, MRDC’s subsidiary the Petroleum Resources Kutubu (PRK) has agreed to provide K1 million annually as incentive for health professionals who serve in the Hela region. Mano said: “We have many good doctors but they don’t come to the provinces to work because of many challenges so they must have incentives. So this K1 million is their incentive. We have also done the same for Southern Highlands and Gulf provinces.” MRDC also opened its office in Tari at the Hela 2 building complex. This office will specifically deal with landowner issues.

Title: Marape commends K92 mine for setting benchmark in PNG
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has praised K92 Mining Limited as a “model of good corporate citizenship and efficiency”, highlighting the company’s strong operational record, transparency, and partnership with the people and Government of Papua New Guinea. During his visit to Kainantu to witness the pouring of gold at K92 Mine – a major milestone following an investment of more than K1.3 billion (US$350 million) — Marape thanked chairlady Anne Giardini, chief executive officer John Lewins, the board, management, and staff for their dedication. “In my six years as Prime Minister, I have witnessed only two gold pour milestones — one at the New Porgera Mine and the other here at Kainantu,” he said. “This demonstrates the determination and efficiency of your team. You are a shining example of how mining in PNG can be done responsibly and profitably.” Marape noted that K92 Mining had paid more than K500 million in taxes in 2024 and 2025 alone, contributing significantly to the national treasury through both corporate and personal income taxes. He commended the company’s transparency through the Mineral Resources Authority’s new digital monitoring system, which tracks production and revenue in real time — a first in PNG’s history. “K92 Mine is a benchmark for how mining companies should operate — transparent, efficient, and respectful of landowners and the State,” Marape said. “You are not just mining gold; you are building trust.” Marape also encouraged greater local participation in spin-off businesses, employment, and procurement. Marape expressed confidence in the future of the gold industry, predicting continued strong demand and high prices. “I said three years ago that gold would hit US$5,000 per ounce, and I stand by that prediction. “Gold remains the safest store of value, and PNG will continue to benefit as long as we maintain good governance and investor confidence,” he said. He also called on the company to invest further in education and community development. Marape said he was confident that K92 Mine would soon achieve Tier-One status, producing more than 400,000 ounces of gold annually, while continuing to demonstrate the highest standards. Marape also wants PNG to be the most attractive destination for mining investment in the Pacific.

Title: Australian defence deal to train PNG troops a ‘win-win’
Content: Canberra: Thousands of Papua New Guineans will be eligible to join the Australian Defence Force within months. A specialist taskforce to recruit PNG citizens will be set up, with as many as 10,000 Papua New Guineans tipped to join the Australian Defence Force, including infantrymen and medics. PNG permanent residents in Australia will be eligible to join the defence force from January. The taskforce was set up as part of the landmark Pukpuk treaty signed by the neighbouring nations two weeks ago, with Australia making multi-million dollar pledges to strengthen Papua New Guinea’s defence capabilities. Acting Prime Minister Richard Marles, Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Pacific Affairs Minister Pat Conroy announced funding for facilities, training and weapons alongside a delegation of PNG ministers in Canberra during the first ministerial forum between the two countries since the treaty was signed. “Today’s ministerial forum is very much around operationalising the alliance which we have just formed,” Marles said. The recruitment taskforce is set to have its first meeting this year. “They will be members of the ADF, so there will be no coaching going on from Papua New Guinea Defence Force,” PNG Defence Minister Billy Joseph told reporters. Deputy PNG Prime Minister John Russo called it a “win-win on both sides” as it enhances Australia’s defence capabilities while providing jobs to young Papua New Guineans. Australia will also provide AU$7.7 million (about K21m) to fund the construction of a 200-bed facility at the Goldie River Barracks in PNG and AU$2.2m (about K6.1mi) to design barracks in Hela. “This will enable an additional 200 soldiers to be trained each and every year into the PNG,” Marles said. “We’re also announcing that beginning next year, we will be training six PNG pilots each year to build (air crew) capacity.” Marles said 3,500 rifles will be provided to the PNG defence force over the next four years. An education and skills package worth over AU$150m (about K4.6m) will be delivered to support PNG’s “productivity, economic growth and human development” as well as a AU$25m (about K69m) humanitarian aid disaster package. Among the defence initiatives, Conroy added that Australia was the largest trade and investment partner for the PNG, labelling new NRL team the PNG Chiefs as a key economic partnership. “I can’t wait to see them getting on the field in 2028 and they’ll soon dominate the competition,” Conroy said. The pact means PNG joins the United States and New Zealand as the third defence ally of Australia, and the newest in 70 years. The signing of the Pukpuk treaty, named after the PNG word for crocodile, followed a botched attempt in Port Moresby in September, dashing hopes the trans-Torres treaty would be confirmed alongside PNG celebrating its 50th anniversary of independence. Source: AAP

Title: Fiji police recover body of former PNG Pepes coach
Content: SUVA: Fiji police have confirmed recovering the body of former Papua New Guinea Pepes coach Unaisi Rokoura, who was reported missing on Saturday (local time) after a suspected drowning incident while gathering freshwater mussels. Rokoura, 47, represented the Fiji Pearls at two Commonwealth Games and two Netball World Cups as a player. She had two stints as the Pearls’ head coach and also coached the Pepes from 2015 to 2017. Rokoura was with three other women collecting mussels near Navuso Agriculture School in Naitasiri province, in Fiji’s Central Division, according to local media reports. One woman ­– a 34-year-old – was trying to hold on to Rokoura, but both subsequently disappeared. Police had earlier confirmed recovering the body of the 34-year-old, and said a post-mortem examination would be conducted on Monday. On Monday morning, police said the search for Rokoura was ongoing, with divers from the Mobile Force and the Fiji Navy deployed to the area. “The joint search team consisting of officers from the Fiji Police Force and Republic Of Fiji Navy, have recovered the body of the former national netball coach, from the Rewa River,” police said in a statement issued at about 1.30pm (11.30am PNG time). “The victim’s body was recovered near the Waila dredging plant.” – RNZ

Title: Judge orders warring tribes in Enga to stop fighting
Content: THE National Court in Wabag has ordered members of two tribes in Wapenamanda, Enga, to stop fighting immediately. Resident Judge Graham Ellis issued the order after noting that the leader of the Yakuman tribe Danny Katie, and the leader of the Yangukun tribe MP Miki Kaeok, had agreed to an unconditional ceasefire. The order requires all members of both tribes to: Judge Ellis warned that any person who breached the order would be charged for contempt in the National Court. The orders were issued in the enforcement of basic rights in regards to tribal fighting in Wapenamanda and its impact on the work of the National Court and the education of children. Katie and Kaeok were ordered to obey all reasonable directives from the acting provincial police commander, the provincial administrator, or their nominees. The two tribes are given until Oct 24 or a later date the court may order, to finalise a peace agreement between them. The leaders were directed to negotiate in good faith as part of the peace process, and the mediators may advise the court in writing. Failing to do so may be considered contempt of court.

Title: Rosso warns settlers to respect eviction notice
Content: LAE MP John Rosso has warned settlers of Three-Mile in Lae who were served eviction notices recently to abide by the law. Rosso addressed people in Ward Four of Three-Mile on Saturday, exercising his powers as the Lands Minister to acquire portions of land there to allow people to remain. “This action has been taken in the interest of the wider public and to safeguard stability within our community,” he added. He said the eviction that was supposed to occur was instigated by the Fresh Produce Development Agency (FPDA) who own the land. “They are entitled to pursue their rights through the courts, and I respect that legal process,” Rosso said. He told the people that the land was compulsory acquired using the power he has as the Lands Minister, but the matter will be fought out in court. Rosso said that the Lands Department would negotiate with the FPDA to find a solution which respected its legal interests while addressing the humanitarian concerns of the people. “This eviction will stop, but the matter is taken to court now, which will be battled (between) the Lands Department and the FPDA,” he stated. Rosso warned settlers not to start ethnic clashes, sorcery-related killings, drunk and disorder behaviour, and petty crimes to disturb the peace. “I don’t like petty crimes to be practised here and along the highway,” he added. “If any misbehaviour happens, then I will evict you because we have all left our villages looking for better opportunities and lifestyle in town areas. “People who move to Lae must abide by our city’s laws and regulations, respect their fellow citizens, and live peacefully.”

Title: Marape upbeat about Hela gas-fired power project
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has commended PNG Power Limited, ExxonMobil PNG and the Hela government for a gas-fired power project that will provide electricity to Hela and parts of Southern Highlands. The new facility at Hides will supply five megawatts of power, with infrastructure work – including generation and transmission – now nearing completion. It will light up Komo, Koroba, Kopiago, Pori, Tari, Magarima, Nipa, Mendi, and Kandep. “This project is deeply personal to me,” Marape said. “I have lived and worked in this electorate since 1994, and I have seen the power lines pass over our heads to supply Porgera, while Tari and the Hela Basin remained in darkness.” “To see power finally coming to our people fulfills one of the reasons that drove me to politics in 2002.” Marape described the achievement as “prophetic,” noting that it aligns with the traditional Hela prophecy that “the gas from Hides would one day light up the world”. He praised ExxonMobil for being a responsible and committed corporate partner in the development of Hela and Southern Highlands, and PNG Power for ensuring that the energy generated is affordable and accessible. “This is not just about lighting homes – it’s about lighting opportunities,” Marape said. “With power now coming into Hela, our people can venture into agriculture, small-medium enterprises, and tourism. “This electricity project will be an incubator for local growth and development.” The Hela gas-fired power project complements the 132-kilovolt transmission line being developed to connect Hides to Yonki and onward to Lae. It will form part of PNG’s national grid transformation programme. Marape revealed that the project had generated more than K32 billion in revenue to date, K15 billion collected by the Government in taxes, K11 billion in dividend earnings through the Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited and K3 billion to K4 billion for landowners, pending the resolution of legal processes. “PNG LNG has been a cornerstone of our national revenue base over the past decade, and now it is fitting that it is giving back directly to the province where it all began – by providing power from Hides to light up Hela,” Marape said.

Title: ToRot’s family proud of historic moment
Content: A RELATIVE of Peter ToRot has described him as a man of faith who believed in the Holy Sacraments and died because of his faith. John Keleto is ToRot’s grandson. His father is the son of ToRot’s sister ‘IaVarpilak. On Friday,The Nationalvisited some of the sites at Rakunai in East New Britain where ToRot gave sacraments to people and conducted church services during the World War II. Keleto said that ToRot was 33 when he was killed by the Japanese soldiers because he refused to listen to them and continued to spread the word of God. “I am blessed that I am his (grandson). I am blessed my grandfather will become the first Catholic Saint for Papua New Guinea, East New Britain, especially from Rakunai,” Keleto said. “While some of our family members are now travelling to Rome, we are here preparing several sites where my grandfather used to conduct church services and prayer gatherings during the war.” The four sites at Rakunai include:

Title: Special masses to celebrate PNG’s first saint
Content: CATHOLICS around the country held special masses to honour Blessed Peter ToRot’s historic canonisation as Papua New Guinea’s first saint. The Mary Queen of the Pacific (MQP) parish in Waigani, Port Moresby, held a mass to commemorate his life, martyrdom and canonisation yesterday. The mass was led by main celebrant Fr Francis Tilo, MSC, and Fr Joseph Amith. During his homily, Fr Francis emphasised the importance of prayer. “The readings of today has reminded us to grow our faith in God,” he said. “The Gospel of Luke talks about the parable of the persistent widow and the unjust judge, emphasizing the importance of perseverance in prayer.” Fr Francis said that prayer was also Torot’s tool which helped maintain his faith. “Let us offer this mass in honour of him, and to pray together that we will maintain the habit of praying daily.” ToRot was canonised by Pope Leo XIV yesterday with six others – Ignatius Maloyan from Armenia, Carmen Martinez from Venezuela, Maria Troncatti from Italy, Vincenza Poloni from Italy, Jose Hernandez from Venezuela and Bartolo Longo of Italy. In East New Britain, parishioners gathered for a three-day prayer pilgrimage to Rakunai, ToRot’s place of birth and where his burial site is. Parish members from Pomio, Kokopo and Rabaul met in Kokopo for a thanksgiving mass before making the journey. The pilgrimage started yesterday and will continue tomorrow. Rabaul Archdiocese Archbishop Rochus Tatamai, before leaving for Rome, said the combined programme was to celebrate the country’s first saint. “In celebrating the work and life of the catechist, though long gone but for us the programme facilitates in the jubilee year, that we are called to journey together in hope,” he said. A vigil on Saturday was followed by a combined mass on Sunday in Kokopo and the pilgrimage to Rakunai. Today, a Eucharistic celebration starts at 9am. The Rakunai community programme takes over tomorrow.

Title: Canonisation seen as a symbol of hope, resilience
Content: THE canonisation of Peter ToRot is a symbol of hope and resilience for Papua New Guinea, says Archbishop Rochus Tatamai. “Peter ToRot’s story is not just my family’s story, it belongs to the whole of Papua New Guinea,” Archbishop Rochus told theVatican News. A Canonisation process by which the Catholic Church declares a deceased person a saint, making them worthy of public veneration and adding their name to the church’s official list of saints. “He stood firm in faith at a time when our people were under immense pressure. His witness, simple but profound, he refused to abandon God, his family, or his community and continues to inspire us,” Bishop Rochus said. In a separate interview with Vatican News, Fr Tomas Ravaioli, vice-postulator of the Cause of Canonisation, attested that “people are excited with the canonisation of Peter ToRot not only an exterior preparation, but an interior one. “Everybody is praying through his intercession, and at the end of the Mass, many people come for confession. His canonisation has brought renewal in the Church of Papua New Guinea,” Fr Thomas said. “Our Melanesian brother showed that holiness is possible in ordinary family life. He lived the Gospel as a lay person, and that makes his example accessible to the majority of our people,” Fr Thomas said. Sr Daisy Lisania, the secretary of the Social Communications Commission the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of PNG and the Solomon Islands said: “Rakunai (in East New Britain) is where he grew up and was formed, a place forms you to be who you are because of the context of the surroundings and the faith formation.” Sr Daisy had visited Rakunai village, where Peter ToRot was born. She added: “In the Shrine of Blessed Peter ToRot lies his remains, well kept in a wooden box. The atmosphere is quiet and peaceful, and there are children who visit the sacred place from the nearby school during their break to pray always.” Peter ToRot’s father was the head of the community, one of the first to be baptised in his village, and he donated the land for the construction of the church, the school and the mission house. His generosity and witness of faith had an impact on his people, leading to a radical transformation, replacing constant fighting, and witchcraft with a more cohesive, peaceful society whose life began to revolve around the school, the medical clinic and the Church. What is still called “the mission” today. Archbishop Rochus echoed these sentiments. “ToRot’s legacy is visible in the life of the Church in Rakunai and across the nation. Pilgrims visit his grave, families gather for prayer inspired by his witness, and catechists see in him the model of their vocation.” He quietly but courageously continued to teach catechism, organise prayer and defend the dignity of marriage, which led to his martyrdom through execution by Japanese soldiers in 1945 during World War II. “He was not a priest, or a bishop,” Archbishop Rochus said. “He was a layman, a father, a husband. That is why his life resonates so deeply. “People see in him the possibility of holiness in everyday life.” Fr Thomas reiterates Pope Francis’ words: “This is the saint the Church needs in these times.” Peter ToRot’s life bridges local culture and universal faith as a catechist. Peter ToRot’s faith was closely linked to his sincere friendship with the missionaries of the Sacred Heart. This relationship was based on missionary work that today is described as a “shared mission.” It was a collaborative effort between religious men and women and the laity of Christian communities. “The event of canonisation will be far more than a Church celebration,” Archbishop Rochus said. “It will be a blessing for the whole country, reminding us that society itself depends on the strength of families, it’s a gift to our country as a national revolutionary that calls us to holiness that begins in the family and extends to the whole society. “He was known for humility, service to the poor, devotion to prayer and respect for elders. “He challenges every one of us to live lives of service and generosity, ToRot’s story offers practical guidance.”

Title: Parliament should accept Bougainville referendum result in ‘original form’
Content: THE Bougainville Referendum must be accepted in its original form by parliament, former Internal Security Minister Bire Kimisopa says. He cautioned that if Parliament denies the referendum, every MP should go to Bougainville and apologise to every Bougainvillian from the youngest to the oldest. ‘’It’s nearly 40 years gone after the crisis, children born during the crisis have not gone to school, we offered no help in humanitarian needs nor did the Government ran to its rescue,” he said. Kimisopa told members of the Parliamentary Bipartisan Committee on Bougainville Matters during its Highlands regional consultative forum in Goroka on Friday that what he raised was his personal thoughts. He said Bougainvillians will not suddenly deviate from PNG, it will remain as it follows the processes to become a fully-fledged independent country. He said Parliament should not procrastinate, it should accept the result of the Bougainville referendum in its original form. Kimisopa said the referendum result of 97.7 per cent of Bougainvilleans wanting independence and 2.3 per cent preferring   greater autonomy showed their position. He said PNG today has many unresolved issues “because of our insensitivity to manage such issues”. “Today, PNG is different, so fractured because it has too many provinces to run, some provinces get a lot of money, while some of us get peanuts. “It goes for Bougainville as well when your attitude is like this, how do you expect them to cooperate?” He said the buck stopped with Parliament, if Bougainville must behave there should be equity in everything. “Bougainville is an integral part of PNG, deserving love and respect. With only one copper mine in Bougainville, it served PNG well. “Forty per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) comes from Bougainville, 40 toea in every K1 comes from Bougainville copper, it makes sure health and education services are operational, we get a lot services from the mine,” Kimisopa said. He said Bougainville also played its part to help PNG gain independence 50 years ago, the result of the referendum be accepted. The former Goroka MP urged committee chairman Dr Allan Marat to table the referendum in its original form and let Parliament accept it.

Title: Committee seeks public’s view on Bougainville referendum results
Content: THE Bipartisan Parliamentary Committee on Bougainville matters has started its regional consultations to gather views of the people on the 2019 Bougainville Referendum results and post-referendum developments. Committee chairman and Rabaul MP Dr Allan Marat said the consultations were an important part of the Melanesian Agreement which was signed by Prime Minister James Marape and Bougainville President Ishmael Toroama on June 26, stating that Bougainville Referendum and the Joint Consultation Report be presented to the 11th Parliament. Dr Marat said the committee began its consultations in Goroka on Friday and will be in Lae today, and then move to Kokopo on Thursday. He added that the committee would also hold a consultation in Southern, followed by the final meeting in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville at a later date. “These consultative forums are of importance for dialogue, consensus-building and democratic participation on Bougainville’s Referendum,” he said. “From these consultations, the committee will report to Parliament its findings and recommendations, as Parliament has the final decision-making authority on the referendum results. “Interested groups and individuals, and the public at large, are invited to attend these forums and participate in this parliamentary process.” Marat said the consultations were a matter of national importance, adding that the committee would also accept written submissions from those who cannot attend in person. He said the future of Bougainville could depend on the outcome of the committee’s nationwide consultations, hence, all persons interested to contribute were welcome to do so. “It is important that everyone, especially Bougainvilleans, come attend these consultations. “We are here to talk and discuss about the matter of Bougainville and its future, so we encourage people to come and speak their minds as your contributions will help in our report that is to be presented in Parliament.” Meanwhile, Dr Marat said PNG and Bougainville should be prepared for the decision that would be made by Parliament once the result of the Bougainville Referendum is tabled. “Bougainvilleans have already spoken through the referendum with the 97.7 per cent vote for independence, while the rest voted for greater autonomy. “Now, we must all think of what will happen if Parliament agrees or does not agree to Bougainville’s independence. “This is why we are holding these consultations so that the people will understand what could happen or they can give their view on what they would like to see done. “It may not be easy but we are here to listen to the people,” he said.

Title: Marape directs department to lead consultation with landowners
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has directed the Department of Mining to return to Kainantu and lead consultations with landowners, the Eastern Highlands government, and district leaders to strengthen the structure of landowner and provincial government benefits in the mining sector. “The Government will take a submission to cabinet to review and strengthen how landowner and provincial government benefits are structured under our mining framework,” he said. “As a Pangu-led Government, we remain firmly pro-landowner and pro-provincial government. “Those who host mining projects must share equitably in the wealth generated from their land.” Marape said that under Pangu’s policy, 40 per cent of any equity gained by the national government in a project is passed back to provincial governments and landowners of the mining areas. “In this context, the current memorandum of agreement (MoA) for the K92 Mine will be revisited to ensure fair and transparent benefit-sharing,” he said. He announced that a high-level interagency team led by the Department of Mining will be assembled to address outstanding land disputes and legacy issues, and to facilitate open dialogue with all stakeholders. “We must sit down together – landowners, provincial government, district, company, and national government – to find a meeting point where no one is offended,” he said. “As a country that operates under the rule of law, we must never take our disputes to the streets or the bush. The law protects us all.” Marape drew comparisons with the PNG LNG Project, where billions of kina remain tied up in court disputes, and urged local leaders to prioritise mediation and collaboration. “We have learned from the LNG experience that court battles only delay benefits,” he said. “Dialogue and consensus will ensure that the people receive what is rightfully theirs.” Marape also said Cabinet will soon consider a submission to provide special recognition and benefits to Eastern Highlands, which he said deserved acknowledgment for hosting one of the country’s most efficient and transparent mining operations. “Eastern Highlands is paying huge tax revenues through this mine and deserves due respect from the national government,” he said. “This will be reflected in future cabinet decisions on mining and petroleum benefit distribution.” Marape commended governor Simon Sia, Kainantu MP William Hagahuno, and Henganofi MP Robert Atiyafa for their leadership and constructive engagement, and thanked Australian High Commissioner Ewen McDonald for his continued support to PNG’s mining and governance sector.
People: James Marape, Robert Atiyafa, William Hagahuno

Title: Medical supplies for Milne Bay arrives by road
Content: MEDICAL supplies for the Milne Bay health authority (MBPHA) were delivered by road in Alotau from Port Moresby for the first time on Saturday. Health Minister Elias Kapavore said this is history brought about by the Government’s flagship Connect PNG programme which linked Alotau and Port Moresby by road. “Express Custom Logistic (ECL), our Southern Logistics Distribution contractor, is engaged by the Health Department to deliver these supplies,” he said in a statement. “Two Isuzu dyna, and two open-back land cruisers trucks loaded with 620 cartons earmarked for Milne Bay health authority.” Kapavore said after 17 hours of navigating the long stretch of road between Port Moresby and Alotau, the delivery team that brought medical supplies, arrived safely at 6.30pm in Alotau. MBPHA chief executive officer Dr Perista Mamadi confirmed that the delivery team had to cross three big rivers on the Milne Bay side to get to the province. “I was worried for the Abau side because of the mud but it was dry,” Mamadi said. “On Milne Bay side, the team had to cross three rivers. One of the rivers was high so they had to put off the engines and pull the vehicles across the river. “They did well and arrived at 6:30pm, Saturday, at ECL warehouse.” ECL delivered the medical supplies at Milne Bay PHA Medical Store yesterday. “They are now at Alotau Provincial Hospital to load the empty oxygen cylinders,” Mamadi added.

Title: Department gives K500,000 for PNG-Indonesia border post maintenance
Content: THE Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs (DPLLGA) has supported the Department of Works and Highways (DoWH) with K500,000 to maintain the PNG-Indonesia border post at Wutung, West Sepik. DPLLGA secretary Philip Leo presented the cheque to DoWH rural infrastructure programme division first assistant secretary Alois Atbo in Port Moresby on Thursday, following the fourth Inter-Agency Border Development Coordination committee meeting. The committee was recently established to coordinate and deliver critical infrastructure development at the Wutung border post. Leo said the funding support was aimed at improving maintenance work on the administration buildings located at the border post which houses key government agencies like the DPLLGA, PNG Customs Service, Immigration and Citizenship Service Authority, National Agriculture Quarantine and Inspection Authority and the Royal PNG Constabulary. “In addition to the building maintenance, key utility upgrades at the border facilities have been completed,” he said. “The long-awaited water project has finally been connected to surrounding communities after decades of delay. “Two spare generators have also been repaired and are now providing reliable electricity supply to the border facilities. “Discussions are also advancing on the proposed off-grid power supply from PLN Indonesia to provide a sustainable energy source for Wutung villages and border facilities.” He added that the Inter-Agency Border Development Coordination Committee played an important role in coordinating preparations for the Wutung border post to be fully operational by next year.

Title: PNG, Australia working on ADF recruitment pathway, says minister
Content: PAPUA New Guinea and Australia are working on a recruitment pathway to enable PNG citizens to join the Australian Defence Force (ADF), says Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph. He made this known following the recent signing of the Pukpuk Treaty between PNG and Australia. “As an essential part of this (treaty), both countries will establish a bilateral PNG-Australia recruitment taskforce to oversee the development of that pathway,” Joseph said in a recent statement. Joseph said the recruitment taskforce will be led by himself and Australian Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles, and will comprise officials from PNG and Australia. He said the first meeting was expected to be held before the end of the year. “Among its key focus points, the taskforce will establish a methodical and considered process to identify eligible PNG citizens to join the ADF,” Joseph said. “The taskforce will also focus on providing opportunities for PNG youth, while maintaining the integrity of ADF recruitment standards and continuing to help support growth of the PNGDF as an independent sovereign state.” Joseph added that PNG and Australia will work in partnership to develop a sustainable pathway for PNG citizens to enlist in the ADF. “This initiative will take time to develop and refine,” Joseph added. “However, both PNG and Australia are committed to its success,” Joseph said. “This builds on the momentum on the announcement that eligible permanent residents living in Australia who are also Papua New Guinean citizens can apply to join the ADF from Jan 1 next year.” Joseph said developing a recruitment pathway from PNG into the ADF was a historic step, reflecting the shared history and commitment to enhance integration between both countries. “Since beginning this process in January, we have now seen a transformation in our defence relationship through the signing of the Pukpuk Treaty, which is reflected in what we are doing in terms of recruitment, our joint exercises and our operations,” Joseph said. “I am looking forward to working with my good friend and counterpart Minister Marles to develop a taskforce that will see this recruitment and integration come to fruition.”

Title: Tarutia ready to take on challenges in army role
Content: INCOMING Force Sergeant Major (FSM) chief warrant officer James Tarutia is ready to take on challenges of his new role after a handover on Friday at Murray Barracks in Port Moresby. Tarutia, the 11th FSM of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force, took over from chief warrant officer Donald Yalom. FSMs take care of the military’s culture. “I am aware of the challenges ahead, and I accept this appointment as I prepare to meet them along the journey,” Tarutia said. He thanked Yalom for his leadership in the last five past five years, and acknowledged bilateral partners like Australia for their support and guidance. “I also note the unwavering support and guidance as well from our families that brought us this far,” Tarutia said. “I trust to get all responsibilities and duties correct and in order as I take on this role.” Tarutia joined the army in July 4, 1984, and was posted to the Alpha Company, Second Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (2RPIR) in Wewak as a rifleman. He was transferred after two years to the mortar platoon, a support company of 2RPIR. Yalom, who joined on Jan 27, 1980, said it was not easy to put into words the emotions of pride and gratitude. “I am so happy to work alongside dedicated men and women in the force,” he said. “My journey began on Jan 27, 1980, as a young soldier full of dreams for the 2RPIR.” Yalom said working in the force had come with good opportunities and experiences that he would depart with. He was posted to 2RPIR and served as a private and a warrant officer from 1980 to 1999. In 2000, he was posted to the Joint Academy in Lae as an instructor.

Title: PNG Power conducting upgrades along Ramu Grid
Content: PNG Power Limited is currently constructing a second transmission line and conducting upgrades of substations along the Ramu Grid in Morobe. PPL, in a statement, said this was expected to significantly improve the reliability of the power supply through to Lae. “Funded by Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and the PNG Government, the project involves installing a new 132 kV transmission line from Singsing to Lae through Erap and Taraka substations, constructing a new Singsing substation, constructing new towers, and rehabilitating substations like Taraka and Erap,” PPL said. “Recent activities include the energisation of a new 132 kV bay at Erap substation, replacement of a faulty circuit breaker at Taraka and ongoing work on capacitor banks at Milford Haven. PPL said the rehabilitation programme aimed to enhance reliability that was to improve the quality and stability and reduce power outages in Lae and surrounding areas. “Adding a second transmission line from Singsing Creek to Lae would increase the redundancy by allowing one line to be used in the event that the first one fails,” PPL said.

Title: Kipo-Saraga road to cost K9.2 million, says city manager
Content: THE 1.2km Kipo-Saraga Road that will run from 6-Mile is estimated to cost around K9.2mil, city manager Ravu Frank said. Frank said it was part of their project in transforming settlements into suburbs during ground-breaking ceremony for the road on Thursday. “We rolled out the settlement to suburb project in Nine-Mile and rolling it out to other parts of the city,” he said. “This will continue into the next 10 years. “It’s not an easy task but through leadership we are still delivering the programme.” He said they were also aiming to have schools and businesses operate in the area after completion of the project. Moresby South MP Justin Tkatchenko said roadworks would not only start at Kipo but also on the other side at Six-Mile Ragamuga coming through to Saraga. He said there should be peace between Chimbu and EasternHighlands and they should appreciate the work their leaders were trying to do. “We’ve had numerous conversations about where the road is going, how people will be given humanitarian assistance when they pull down their own homes for the roads and services to go through,” he said. Tkatchenko thanked the Lands Department and said they had acquired 17 hectares of land on the mountain side towards Saraga to be subdivided into 300 allotments “Those affected will be taken care of and will have another block available for future issues that might come up between Ragamuga and Kipo,” Tkatchenko said. He thanked the National Capital District Commission (NCDC) for sponsoring 16 classrooms at the Saraga elementary and primary schools. He said they wanted to employ youths for road construction. “Don’t fight back development, this is a positive development that will allow people to grow and will be permanently here,” he said. “Some of us live on customary land, we will work with the landowners with NCDC to ensure that we can acquire that for long-term development,” he said.

Title: Gazelle will host agro show to mark World Food Day
Content: GAZELLE is hosting its first agriculture show to coincide with the World Food Day and the International Rural Women’s Day. The three-day event will be held at the Kerevat Sports Field from Oct 16-18 under the theme: “Farming forward: Innovation for a resilient tomorrow”. The show aims to showcase the agriculture developments, livestock projects, fisheries farming or aquaculture and agriculture business projects that are being developed in the LLGs and wards. The event is an initiative of Gazelle MP and Minister for Fisheries and Marine Resources Jelta Wong to support the district’s economic sector. District agriculture and livestock officer Henry Kahoraso, said the district’s economy was driven by agriculture, livestock, fisheries, forestry, and small and medium enterprises (SMEs), which generated income for the people. He said the show will focus on promoting these key areas. Kahoraso said the event would feature displays of locally made products from small processing activities such as cocoa butter and powder, chocolate, virgin coconut oil, soap, biscuits, and other products. Agriculture groups, stakeholders in institutions involved in agriculture trainings, livestock and economic programmes will also participate to showcase their work. Gazelle district has a vast land area and a large population that contributes to the production of cash crops, food crops, livestock, forestry, and fisheries products.

Title: Parkop sees preventive healthcare as a priority
Content: NATIONAL Capital District Governor Powes Parkop has urged Papua New Guineans to prioritise preventive healthcare over curative treatment, particularly in relation to cancer. Speaking during the Pinktober Walk for Xancer in Port Moresby yesterday, he said there is no guaranteed cure for the disease, hence prevention is paramount. Parkop emphasised the importance of practising health lifestyle choices, early screening and regular checks and public awareness to reduce cancer cases and save lives. “In country now, there is an increase in not only breast cancer, but cervical cancer, oral cancer, lung cancer prostate cancer and many others as according to doctors,” he said. Parkop said this is something everyone shouldn’t take lightly and find ways to help those who have been affected by the cancer to recover. He added that everyone should take heed of the statistics and promote preventive measures because there is no exact cure for cancer has been found as yet and so prevention is better than cure and it an individual’s responsibility. “Everyone must go for regular checkup at least once in six months, this would help everyone to know if they have any sick in their body or not and seek treatment early if they are sick.” He also urged everyone to limit the amount of betel nut, alcohol, smoking, unhealthy diet and mostly importantly to have regularly exercises. Parkop thanked everyone who were part of the walk, noting that this would spread the more awareness in combating cancer and helping those battling the disease right now.  Meanwhile, he urged all the parents and guardians to ensure their children up to age 10 to go get polio vaccines.

Title: K250,000 aid post opens in Markham’s Wantoat
Content: A NEW K250,000 aid post was opened in Bumbum, Wantoat, Markham, after three years of construction, providing much-needed healthcare access to the remote community. The project, located in the Leron-Wantoat Local Level Government (LLG) area, was counter-funded by local family support and the Brian Bell Foundation. Of the total cost, K241,000 was contributed by Neritha Gengewe Ganzik and her family, while the Brian Bell Foundation supported the project with K9,000. Ganzik, who is also the president of the Leron-Wantoat Women’s Association, said the deteriorating Leron-Wantoat road, left in poor condition for the past eight years, has made it difficult for essential services to reach the area. “But luckily we were able to deliver all the materials with only 25 runs which is a big sacrifice by my family to give back to our community.” She said the counter-fund from Brian Bell Foundation was taken from an earmarked K29,000 for the construction of the Women’s Resource centre. She said the rest of the money (K20,000) is kept to build the resource center. Morobe Provincial Health Authority (PHA) chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga opened the new Bumbum Aid-post in Wantoat Station, 66 kilometers from the Okuk Highway, marking a major upgrade for local healthcare services. The old aid-post, built in the 1980s on short stilts with concrete floors, was demolished due to disrepair. In 2012, the community constructed a new aid-post, but roof damage from a fallen tree forced them to rely on a temporary clinic until now. Binga noted that an additional health worker was added to Wantoat Aid-post as part of Morobe PHA’s restructuring. The aid-post is expected to greatly improve healthcare access for Wantoat and surrounding communities.

Title: 19 attend week-long nurses course at Port Moresby General Hospital
Content: A WEEK-LONG Basic Assessment and Support in Intensive Care (BASIC) for Nurses course was held at Port Moresby General Hospital recently, drawing 19 participants from across the country. The training was conducted by the Regional Emergency and Critical Care Systems Strengthening Initiative (RECSI) who facilitated workshops, lectures, and practical sessions for the nurses. There were four facilitators from overseas and two from PNG with three newly trained. According to Melissa Njoku, RECSI critical care nursing adviser for PNG and Timor-Leste, and Interim Clinical co-lead for RECSI critical care (PNG), the training was designed to strengthen and empower nurses in their professional practice. The programme started with a one-day instructors’ course, followed by a two-day providers’ course, covering essential topics such as respiratory and cardiovascular physiology, airway management, mechanical ventilation, neurological assessment, and cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). Participants also engaged in skill stations focusing on real-world intensive care scenarios, including mechanical ventilation troubleshooting, intubation care, and communication during emergencies. Following the training, participants were awarded Certificates of Attendance in recognition of their participation. This initiative was made possible through the support of the Society of Anaesthetists of Papua New Guinea, the Australian and New Zealand Intensive Care Society (ANZICS), the Global Intensive Care Initiative, and in collaboration with the National Department of Health, Port Moresby General Hospital, and the PNG-Aus Partnership.

Title: Soldier killed in tragic boat accident while on border operations in Western
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Defence Force have confirmed the passing of a soldier who died in a tragic boat accident along the country’s border with Indonesia. Chief of Defence Force Rear Admiral Philip Polewara said private Ian Bailey was attached with the First Royal Pacific Island Regiment deployed to the southern land border in Western. He died on Saturday, Oct 11, in a tragic boat accident which also left another soldier seriously injured. “Members of the First Battalion, Royal Pacific Island Regiment, deployed in operations on the southern land border suffered a tragic boat accident on Saturday, Oct 11 in Kiunga, Western,” Polewara said. “The accident claimed the life of a member and left another seriously injured. The injured soldier is receiving treatment and is stable. “However, PNGDF lost 814776 private Ian Bailey in the accident.” Polewara said Bailey’s death was the second casualty suffered this year in an area of operations that was dangerous, isolated and remote which the service men and women operate in. “As much as it is a loss for the force, which will be immediately felt at the unit level, the passing of private Bailey on Saturday is an even bigger loss to his family and clansmen,” Polewara said. “I can only imagine the pain and grief to have lost a father, son and brother at 30 – the prime of his life. “On behalf of the PNGDF, I send condolences to his wife and children, his extended family and his kinsmen.”

Title: Kombra says schools may slightly adjust dates for Grade 8 exam
Content: EDUCATION Secretary Dr Uke Kombra has advised provincial education authorities and schools to be prepared to adjust examination dates for Grade 8, depending on when they receive the exam papers. Kombra said exam papers arrived at the Measurement Services Division a few days later than usual, and while all materials have been dispatched through Air Niugini Cargo to the provinces, some deliveries may experience delays due to flight disruptions and rescheduling. He said Grade 8 examinations were originally scheduled to start on Monday to Thursday (Oct 20-23). “However, the Department has advised provincial education authorities and schools to be prepared for slight adjustments where necessary,” Kombra said. “In case some schools do not receive their examination papers on time, provincial education authorities may reschedule the exams to be completed by Friday, Oct 24. “Any further changes beyond this date must be approved by my office.” Kombra reminded all school administrations to take full responsibility for the safe storage, security, and fair administration of all examination materials in their care. “Provincial education advisers, examination supervisors, and primary (school) inspectors have been instructed to communicate this notice to all schools in their respective provinces,” he said.

Title: Avira charged with official corruption
Content: ROAD Traffic Authority (RTA) acting chief executive officer John Daveona Avira appeared in court yesterday charged with official corruption, misappropriation, and abuse of office over the use of more than K200,000 in public funds. Committal Court Magistrate Paul Puri Nii in Waigani read the charges to the 59-year-old from Kieta, Central, in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville. He appeared from bail. Before the court fixed a date for Avira’s mention, he made an oral application that the complainant (named) had withdrawn the matter a month prior through an affidavit. Magistrate Nii said that whatever the complainant wished to do should come from the prosecution. “Until and unless such applications are made, the matter shall proceed as committal,” he said. The matter was adjourned to Nov 18 for mention. Police alleged that Avira was appointed acting RTA CEO in November last year, as per the National Gazette. He acted in the position for three months, until his term expired. Police allege that Avira, without a proper employment contract, continued to occupy the office, and used his powers to conduct administrations and operations of the RTA, including the dissemination of funds. On July, 17, he allegedly instructed the RTA finance department to pay K150,000 and K122, 815.83, into PNG Motors’ bank account. It is alleged that K272,815.63, belonging to the RTA was procured to purchase a new vehicle for his use without the approval of the board. Avira allegedly instructed the sales officer of the motor vehicle company to register the vehicle under his name. Police alleged that he did this to misuse the funds belonging to the office and the State.

Title: PNG Power substation under repair
Content: THE Konedobu substation in Port Moresby has undergone repairs to resolve power issues following a fire last month which affected its operations, says PNG Power Ltd chief executive officer Paul Bayly. “This is a high priority for us as we are putting all our effort into restoring power to the people and businesses in the central business district area, and the Kone feeder eight corridor,” Bayly said. It covers customers in Downtown, Hohola, Waigani and other surrounding areas. “In response to prolonged supply disruptions impacting our customers, PNG Power mobilised its substations, transmission, distribution, and contractor teams to deliver a fast-tracked infrastructure solution,” Bayly said. “The centrepiece of this effort is a newly installed containerised switchboard and capacitor bank at the Kone substation, designed to restore power to the affected zones.” He thanked affected customers for their patience, cooperation, and continued support during the restoration process. Two contractors were engaged to carry out preventive maintenance on Kone feeders four and seven, after both experienced repeated failures. “Final high-voltage cable connections to Kone feeder poles and underground links to the substation’s control room are being completed as these connections are essential for operational readiness,” Bayly said. “Following successful technical testing, PNG Power is initiating a trial energisation of the substation. “This will pave the way for the restoration of Kone feeders four, five, seven and eight to bring back power to key parts of the city over the next few days.” PPL chief technical officer Tony Koiri said the fire on Sept 19 damaged much of the substation’s infrastructure.

Title: Police arrest 18 grade 10 students over disorderly behaviour
Content: EIGHTEEN grade 10 male students arrested for alleged disorderly behaviour in public after their final exams last week appeared before the Kundiawa District Court on Wednesday for mention. Chimbu police commander Supt Mazuc Rubiang said that of the 18, five pleaded guilty to liquor-related offences and were sentenced to six months in prison. But the sentences were suspended on the condition that the five be on good behaviour for one year. Supt Rubiang said the other 13 students who pleaded not guilty would return to court on Nov 15. They are remanded at the Kundiawa Police Station. The students are waiting for their remand warrants before they can be transported to the Barawagi Correctional Services Institute as their parents could not pay the K1,000 police bail. Rubiang urged grades 12 and eight students not to misbehave after their national exams. He urged parents and community leaders to take responsibility by discouraging disorderly celebrations. He also reminded students that their exams marked an important stage in their education journey.

Title: Troops arrive in Lae as Exercise Wantok Warrior kicks off
Content: EXERCISE Wantok Warrior 2025 (WW25), a combined military training activity that brings together Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) and Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel, has begun in Morobe. Troops from both forces arrived on Wednesday by CH-47F Chinook helicopters at Igam Barracks, Lae with about 300 personnel conducting fighter training from Oct 13-Oct 29. A joint-force of 150 soldiers will conduct activities through a vacant university in Lae. On the weekend the troops will conduct a search operation at a primary school using three Australian CH-47F Chinook helicopters. The exercise partners the First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (1RPIR) Alpha Company and the Engineering Battalion (Bravo Company) with the First Royal Australian Regiment (1RAR) as well as several other ADF units including aviation, medical and engineers. Acting officer commanding 1RPIR Captain Jonathan Kerenge said that WW25 sets the conditions for that engagement and interoperability as well as person to person integration. “When you fight, you do not fight as a country, you’ve got your partners and to know them, understand their culture, that’s an important dynamic, it goes beyond boundaries,” he said. WW25 has been conducted annually since 2009, with the aim of building interoperability between two forces to enhance defence capability in the region. Australian counterpart, Officer Commanding Bravo Company 1RAR, Major Patrick Hoare said it’s an opportunity to work primarily with our PNGDF partners, and they are fortunate we have a strong relationship with 1RPIR. “We’ve got quite a junior team here and having the access to the different platforms and obviously the knowledge that the PNGDF bring at an individual and small teams level is invaluable to us.” Training serials for WW25 will take place across the province. At Salamaua units will conduct a small boat insertion to destroy fictitious enemy air defenses and at Wau, a platoon-level assault will be carried out supported by the helicopters No live ammunition is being used during the exercise and all activities are being conducted with strict safety and operational guidelines. Noise management and the environment were key considerations during the planning of WW25.

Title: New leaders will take part in two programmes, official says
Content: EAST New Britain has two programmes to be carried out after this year’s Local Level Government (LLG) Elections. ENB election coordinator Rose August said the first programme is to induct the newly-elected leaders at the wards and this will be followed by appointment of ward recorders in all 382 wards. August said the induction of ward member elect is a programme that is normally conducted after every LLG elections, aimed at educating them on their roles and responsibilities. The next programme, relating to ward recorders’ recruitment, is only just being introduced this year. August said that ward recorders in ENB currently receive monthly allowances from the ENB government through the divisions of finance and revenue and LLG and ward affairs. August who is also adviser for ENB division for the human resource management under the provincial administration said the ward recorder appointment is important, because the officer is responsible for the administrative functions of the ward. This is to complement the election of the ward members. “Unlike past practices where the ward member appoints a ward recorder, we see that it is better that the people themselves appoint the ward recorder through a fair process,” August said. She said the appointment process will see elected ward members conduct a ward government meeting to call for nominations from the people. There can be up to five nominees per ward and once the nominations are done, all names are submitted to their respective LLG administrations for screening by a selection committee. This programme is aimed at strengthening the administrative operations of the ward governance under the provincial government’s ward focus policy. The ward recorder appointment was a transparent process, August said.

Title: Parkop wants stronger leadership to protect children and youth
Content: PARLIAMENTARY Committee on Children and Youth chairman Powes Parkop wants stronger government leadership to protect children and youth. The demand follows a series of concerns raised during a two-day inquiry. Parkop emphasised that while non-government organisations (NGOs) like ChildFund PNG were providing critical services, the primary responsibility for safeguarding children rested with the Government. “The Government must be at the frontline providing the basic services for our children and public at large,” he said. “NGOs are there to complement, not replace, the role of the State.” ChildFund PNG highlighted the service gap, noting its 1-Tok Kaunselim Helpim Lain (7150 8000), the country’s only 24-hour, toll-free national service for survivors of gender-based violence and child abuse, had received more than 87,000 calls since 2015. However, this essential service operates primarily through donor support, mainly from the New Zealand government. The committee would finalise its recommendations for Parliament to ensure child welfare remains a top national priority. He warned that if these provincial governments and other State agencies did not voluntarily appear before the committee in future, the committee would issue summons to them to appear. At the hearing, only Chimbu was present. Western Highlands, Hela, Enga and Madang did not turn up. The committee will ensure all children are given better foundation in the future.

Title: Awareness focuses on healthy diets and lifestyle diseases
Content: THE Nationalnewspaper’s staff were reminded yesterday of everyday lifestyle diseases and the importance of having a healthy diet. A health advocate with Resource for Life operating under Home Health Education Services Media Sherol Banda said there was nothing more important than living a happy and healthy lifestyle. “Lifestyle diseases is one of the biggest problems affecting the lives of our citizens,” she said. “Cancer is one of them and it’s very sad to say the highest rates we hear every year are from our country.” Banda said the type of food we eat would determine if we live longer. “Always be mindful of what you are putting into your mouth, exercises that you do and water that you drink,” she said. Banda also said water is important and it helps to clean out the kidneys, not frizzy drinks. Prevention is better than cure, she added. “Improving our lifestyles is based on knowledge,” Banda said. “We are reintroducing this holistic living by going back to the basics, where we come from and how we were brought up.” Banda while sharing her experiences with people who are suffering from lifestyle diseases said they try their best to do door to door awareness targeting families. She advocated on the eating a lot of organic produce, fruits and having a disciplined mindset that will help not only to protect an individual but a family. “We are also selling books on healthy diet, what sort of medicinal plants to take for certain diseases and sickness. “Basically, all these plants surround us but we are ignorant.”

Title: Marie Stopes launches new initiative, expands vasectomy services
Content: A FIVE-year initiative to expand access to vasectomy services across the country was launched yesterday in Port Moresby. Marie Stopes Papua New Guinea, as a part of the global MSI Reproductive Choices partnership, launched the five-year initiative non-scalpel vasectomy (NSV) project with five provincial health authorities, namely Morobe, Central, National Capital District, Western Highlands and Eastern Highlands. The project aims to expand access to vasectomy services across the country, backed by an A$1 million (about K2.73 million) philanthropic commitment from long-time MSI supporter Graham Smith. Marie Stopes country director Angelyn Famudi said the “Increased Access to and Uptake of Vasectomy in PNG” project, which started in July and would run until June 2030, aimed to make vasectomy a safe, accessible, and widely accepted family planning choice for men throughout the country. “This investment of A$200,000 (about K546,600) per year over five years, will strengthen service delivery across the National Capital District, Central, Eastern Highlands, Western Highlands, and Morobe through static clinics and dedicated outreach teams,” Famudi said. She said the vasectomy project would raise awareness of non-scalpel vasectomy as a safe, effective, and permanent family planning method for men and increase demand for NSV services at the community level through advocacy and communication. “The project will strengthen partnerships with provincial health authorities to integrate NSV into routine reproductive healthcare and build local clinical capacity through training and mentorship to ensure sustainable quality services. “It will deliver high-quality NSV services across selected provinces, expanding access in both urban and remote areas,” Famudi said. Famudi said with the new funding, Marie Stopes will scale its male engagement and outreach initiatives, including community dialogues, storytelling campaigns, and male champion networks, to make vasectomy a visible and accessible option across PNG. Meanwhile, Morobe Health Authority chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga said family planning was the way forward. He said with the rising cost of living, family planning was vital to help parents to fully provide for their children.

Title: Rosso backs ‘One China’ policy, expand cooperation in various fields
Content: DEPUTY Prime Minister John Rosso says that Papua New Guinea will abide by the “One China” policy and expand cooperation with it across various fields to achieve greater development in bilateral relations. Rosso made this known on Monday when he met with Chinese vice-president Han Zheng in Beijing on Monday. Rosso, attending the Global Leaders’ Meeting on Women in Beijing, commended China on being the host and its leading role in responding to global challenges. Han said next year will mark 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between China and PNG. Han told Rosso that China was willing to work with PNG to deliver on important common understanding between the two countries’ leaders and advance the partnership. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping said women played an important role in creating, promoting and carrying forward human civilisation, and the international community had a responsibility to empower women. “Equality between men and women is now a universal consensus of the international community, with prominent progress achieved in women’s empowerment,” Xi said. “Their educational attainment has been steadily improving, women are playing an even more important role in economic, political, cultural and social affairs. “Many outstanding women have stepped up to take international stage, living their life to the full, and making contributions with their wisdom and strength. “Today, Chinese women ‘hold up half the sky’ in economic and social development. “China, through its development, provides supports for global women’s cause and promotes international exchange and cooperation on women. “In the next five years, they will donate another US$10 million (about K41 million) to UN Women and earmark a quota of US$100 million (about K419 million) in China’s Global Development and South-South Cooperation Fund to implement projects for women and girls in collaboration with international organisations. “It will also launch 100 small livelihood programmes with Chinese assistance, invite 50,000 women to China for exchange and training programmes, and establish a global training centre for women’s capacity building.”

Title: European Union to invest in projects supporting climate resilience
Content: THE European Union (EU) aims to invest in critical infrastructure projects that support climate resilience in Papua New Guinea via its Global Gateway programme. New EU ambassador Erika Hasznos said this when she presented her credentials to Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae at Government House in Port Moresby yesterday. She said: “I have been entrusted with the mission to foster a stronger partnership with Papua New Guinea. Our partnership is built on the solid foundation of our long years of close cooperation. “I have had the privilege of arriving in time to witness the country’s 50th independence anniversary. During my mission, I look forward to jointly celebrating our bilateral 50th anniversary. The European Union and Papua New Guinea have many things in common despite the geographical distance.” She referred to shared fundamental foreign policy principles such as peaceful co-existence and upholding the international law, to the commitment to focus on common long-term challenges, “in particular climate change and on-going cooperation on good governance, human rights, youth empowerment, gender equality and elimination of gender-based violence”. Sir Bob said climate change is at the centre of everyday discussions given the impact it has in PNG. “With the change in weather patterns, rising sea level and natural disasters taking place in the country and within the Pacific region, PNG is thankful to the European Union and other like-minded partners who have rendered support as the country embarks on climate change mitigation and forest biodiversity conservation initiatives. “These programmes are aimed at protecting the environment while contributing to the reduction of climate change induced destructions,” Sir Bob said. “In this regard, PNG would like to also thank the European Union for its assistance under the multi-annual indicative programme introduced in 2021, and runs through to 2027.” He said under the framework, PNG was receiving assistance in projects under forest and climate change, water, sanitation and hygiene and transparent and accountable governance. Hasznos is the 15th EU ambassador to be accredited to PNG since the establishment of diplomatic relations in 1977. Before joining PNG as ambassador, Hasznos was head of sector “Europe” at the European External Action Service in Brussels, working with the EU’s common security and defence policy operations and missions in Ukraine, Moldova, Kosovo, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Georgia and Armenia. Beforehand, she had served as deputy head of delegation in the EU delegation to Moldova. She was posted to the EU delegation to Bangladesh. Before her career in the European external action service, she had worked 10 years in multilateral climate change diplomacy. She had served as EU negotiator at the UN climate change conferences, working with carbon market mechanisms. Earlier, she was deputy head of the Hungarian climate presidency team.

Title: NCD aims to achieve 95 per cent of polio vaccination by end of October
Content: THE National Capital District Health Authority is continuing its polio vaccination campaign in NCD and Motu-Koita communities, aiming to achieve a 95 per cent vaccination rate by Oct 31. Authority chief executive officer Dr Robbin Oge,said the second round of the nationwide campaign is focused on protecting children uo to age10 from the polio virus. During the first round, the authority achieved a remarkable 97.8 per cent vaccination rate, vaccinating 133,000 children in NCD. Oge expressed gratitude to volunteers, staff, parents, community leaders, and partners for their significant contributions to this achievement. NCD Governor Powes Parkop praised the success of the first round and appealed to the residents of NCD and Motu-Koita villages to participate in the second round to ensure every child is vaccinated and protected. Oge said the presence of the poliovirus in PNG makes it crucial for all children under 10 to receive the vaccine. He reassured the public that the polio vaccine is safe, effective, and free, underscoring the responsibility to protect children’s health for a brighter future. Oge also acknowledged the ongoing support of Health Minister Elias Kapavore and Acting Health Department Secretary Dr Ken Wai.

Title: Hundreds attend Pinktober event
Content: A Pinktober Breast Cancer Awareness Community Programme was held at the Sir Hubert Murray Stadium in Port Moresby on Wednesday. “Seeing over a hundred women come together shows the need for accessible health information and screening in our city,” National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop said in a statement. Parkop said women’s presence is a testament to the message that “early detection stops cancer.” The awareness was oranised by the National Capital District Commission through the Active City Development Programme. The awareness included free health screening, immunisation and discussions from the experts’ base with the NCD Public Health Authority and the Sir Brian Bell Centre of Transfusion.

Title: We need to work together: Marum
Content: EAST New Britain Governor Michael Marum has called on provincial leaders, public servants, and business partners to collaborate in creating a long-term vision for sustainable infrastructure development in the province. Speaking at the opening of the Infrastructure Development Forum, Governor Marum said the event marked a crucial step in shaping a roadmap for East New Britain’s future, under the theme ‘Building a Resilient and Prosperous Future: Towards a Long-Term Strategic Roadman for Infrastructure Development’. Marum acknowledged the contributions of past provincial leaders, administrators, churches, and business partners who had helped build the foundations of East New Britain over the years. “We stand on their shoulders, and we honor their service. But today, our task is to look forward, not just to the next five years, but to the next 20 years,” he said. He said the infrastructure development must focus on long-term impact rather than short-term fixes. “Infrastructure is not about short-term projects or quick fixes. It is about laying down foundations that will last for generations. “The road we build today must still serve communities tomorrow,” he said. Marum urged contractors, the business community, and public servants to engage constructively and think beyond immediate challenges. He further highlighted the importance of collaboration with national agencies and development partners to align priorities for the province’s benefit. Marum also addressed the ongoing national discussion on autonomy, urging leaders to prepare for responsible governance should greater powers be granted to the province. “This forum must also help us think about governance, capacity, and accountability, so that autonomy, if achieved, becomes a tool for growth and not a burden,” he said.

Title: Miss Pacific Islands contest in February
Content: THE 37th Miss Pacific Islands Pageant — celebrating culture, beauty, and empowerment across the Pacific — will be held from Feb 13-20 at King Charles Park in Nadi, Fiji. Fijian minister for local government Maciu Nalumisa also confirmed that the Miss Fiji Pageant will be held from Dec 10 to 13 in Suva, with the venue yet to be confirmed. Nalumisa said that for the first time the Fijian diaspora in Australia, New Zealand and the United States will participate in the Miss Fiji Pageant. Long-reigning Miss Fiji 2019, Jessica Fong, has reminded contestants to come prepared to enjoy the event. The Miss Pacific Islands Pageant will include contestants from Fiji, Tonga, Samoa, American Samoa, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, Nauru, Palau, Tuvalu, Kiribati and Hawaii.

Title: Kokopo group hosts food festival
Content: A LOCAL group in the Mope zone of Kokopo’s Bitapaka local level government (LLG) area in East New Britain hosted a cultural food festival to showcase traditional food and dishes to commemorate World Food Day. Moreover, the event was held to raise awareness about increasing cases of dietary-related diseases and the loss of knowledge about traditional food. It aimed to showcase traditional food, dishes, and cooking methods under the theme, “Self-determination development and sustaining our future together now for the next 50 years”. The two-day programme included the launching of the Mope Zone Strategic Plan 2025- 2029, spearheaded by the Mope Development Corporation (MDC). MDC is a multi-stakeholder community-based organisation working in collaboration with wards in the zone: Ganai, Watwat, Vunabaur and Marmar (Mope Lelege). The strategic plan is guided by the vision of improving lives, creating opportunities, and increasing people’s standard of living. The event was held in partnership with the International Fund for Agriculture Development, a donor partner supporting MDC with the Mope zone strategic plan. The Cultural Food Festival heavily involved students and mothers, who participated in fun educational activities and a food display contest. Speaking at the programme, provincial food crops coordinator Shilla Sato said there had been an increase in dietary-related cases reported at local hospitals. She warned people about the effects of eating processed food. “Diseases like diabetes are affecting people in the villages too. You leave your villages to go to town just to buy tinned food, and you turn to soft drinks instead of water. Let’s go back to eating garden food,” she said. Chief executive officer (CEO) for the ENB Market Authority, Peter Lapim, acknowledged the women of Ganai and Mope wards for continuing to supply the main market with garden produce. “The market is yours, I am only managing it. That place is for you to go and sell your food,” Lapim said. The interactive sessions were insightful, and reminded participants of the importance of eating healthy, conserving traditional cooking methods, and preserving traditional food.

Title: Man held on suspicion of killing wife in Alotau
Content: A SUSPECT in Wagawaga village, Alotau, was arrested over the weekend for allegedly killing his wife of seven years. According to police reports, the deceased was physically abused throughout the marriage. Milne Bay police commander Chief Insp Benjamin Kua said several reports were laid at the Ulabo police post, but were withdrawn by the suspect’s wife. “Last Thursday, at about 8pm, the suspect started abusing the deceased, beating her and stripped her naked,” he said. “It continued throughout the night and towards daybreak. “At about 6am on Friday, the deceased escaped naked to a neighbouring house to seek assistance.” Kua said she was helped to Daio village where she was put on a dinghy and transported to Alotau, and admitted after at the Alotau General Hospital. Police confirmed that she passed away at about 8pm. “Police had the suspect arrested and he will be charged soon. Their child is with the suspect’s relatives at Wagawaga,” Kua said. He urged husbands to take care of their wives and not beat them up every day. “We are taking this case very seriously,” Kua said. “This should be a message to all men who hide and do such things to their wives.”

Title: Sir Bob’s Tongan wife now a PNG citizen
Content: Lady Emeline Tufi Dadae, wife of Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae, is now a Papua New Guinea citizen. “Today is very emotional for me,” Lady Emeline said on Tuesday after she obtained her naturalisation citizenship certificate from the PNG Immigration and Citizenship Authority. “My marriage is now complete.” Lady Emeline, in the presence of officials from PNG Immigration and Citizenship Authority, formally renounced her country of birth, Tonga, in favour of PNG. Lady Emeline said since she married Sir Bob in 2020, she had immediately applied for citizenship and her efforts finally paid off five years later. “I have finalised my marriage by becoming a citizen of my husband’s country. “I have been doing everything I can to apply for citizenship and today, I am happy that I finally receive this citizenship certificate,” Lady Emeline said. Sir Bob, who was present at the occasion, said he was pleased with his wife’s decision to become a PNG citizen.

Title: Road to help families, farmers
Content: THE construction of the Lowai-Finongang road in Upper Erap, Morobe, was recently launched to reconnect isolated communities with government services. Led by Nawaeb Development Authority (DDA) chairman and local MP Theo Pelgen, this long-awaited project aims to provide access to vital infrastructure for the people of Lowai and Finongang, who had been cut off for over 10 years. The road, which had been neglected for nearly 49 years, limited families and farmers’ access to basic services and markets. Pelgen expressed his commitment to improving infrastructure across Nawaeb. “For too long, our people in Lowai and Finongang have been left behind,” he said. The road is not just a physical connection but a symbol of restored hope and opportunity, Pelgen said. As construction began, many residents, especially mothers, expressed joy, knowing they could now access services easily. The new road is expected to provide critical access for coffee farmers, fresh produce traders, schoolchildren, health workers, and local traders. It connects wards three and four of the Wain-Erap local level government area to the Erap-Lae route, enhancing economic opportunities and improving quality of life for the community.

Title: Bible-based organisation visits country
