Content: ISRAEL United in Christ (IUIC) founder Bishop Nathanyel Israel is in the country with a delegation to enhance understanding about history, heritage, empowerment of people towards self-reliance, order, and socio-economic development from a biblical perspective. “United States-based IUIC is a bible-based international charity organisation teaching the history and heritage of Black and Hispanic people,” Israel said. “The visit to Papua New Guinea underscores our shared responsibility to ensure that the historical insights that connect our people to their rich heritage are made accessible so they can contribute positively to their community.” The IUIC team will hold a session at the PNG Bible Translation Association in North Waigani tomorrow to respond to questions regarding the delegation’s engagements with the public sector, local partners and communities during the visit. “The discussion will focus on the projected outcomes of education and support programmes in PNG schools, and public awareness campaigns which aim to enhance understanding about history, heritage, and empowerment,” Israel said.

Title: Chimbu sets up data division for women and children
Content: THE Chimbu government, under its restructure, has a division responsible to collect data on issues relating to children and women. Administrator John Punde told the Parliamentary Committee on Children and Youth that they had not held any consultations with the National Office for Child and Family Services. Punde was responding to committee chairman Powes Parkop on whether they had consultations with the National Office for Child and Family Services to establish a council in the province. “We’ve not had consultations with the director and the team but have a division with officers who will go out to generate data on certain issues in the communities,” he said. “The data will then be sent to another division to develop or redevelop programmes to suit the needs of a particular area.” The provincial government was the only one that turned up for the inquiry. Western Highlands, Hela, Enga and Madang did not turn up to provide information on issues affecting youth and children. “We may have an elementary school that does not have water supply,” Punde said. “Who provides these information? That’s where our division comes in. “We have done a lot of good work and policy but the problem is implementation.” Punde said that one of the areas they were looking into was community development and how to best tackle issues concerning their youths, children and women. He added that they had a lot of discussions driven by partners and not necessarily by the Department of Community Development, Youth and Religion. “The other development partners come and discuss with us their requirements for all these topics before projects or programmes are carried out.”

Title: Grant inconsistency ‘affecting’ services
Content: INCONSISTENCY in providing function grants is affecting service delivery in Chimbu, says Governor Noah Kool. “Last year we received only K14 million from the Government. We have K19 million still outstanding. And this year, we received only K8.8 million last month,” he said Kool said that the provincial government usually received K34 million function grants yearly. And the inconsistent government funding is hindering the delivery of services. Kool told the Special Parliamentary Committee on Children and Youth inquiry into social services for children in youth in Port Moresby yesterday that most services and development in the province were made possible through national agencies in partnership with donors. “We appreciate what the donors have been doing because we cannot do anything ourselves in the province,” he said. Kool said that despite the funding issues, the provincial government was doing its best for youths and school-aged children in terms of health, education and other services. “In vaccination coverage, just like last year, Chimbu covered 83 per cent in round one of polio vaccine rollout this year,” he added. “Round two will commence this month and we are expected to cover all areas.” Kool said the Chimbu health authority also carried out other health outreach and programmes for children and mothers. On education, Kool said Chimbu had started the implementation of education policies to achieve the desired retention outcomes of the Basic Universal Education.

Title: Court wants answers for delay in station rape case
Content: A COMMITTAL Court has ordered the police officer investigating an alleged rape case involving three policemen in a Port Moresby police station to explain the delay in the investigation. Waigani Committal Court Magistrate Albert Daniels yesterday ordered the officer to file an affidavit before Dec 11 – the last mention date. Failing this, the court will strike out the case. The officers being investigated are Sergeant Carl Yori, 53, of Gogo village, Constable Jerry Aura, 34, of Ghun village both of Chimbu, and Danny Karayo, 45, of Raku village in Kagua, Southern Highlands. They have been charged with deprivation of liberty and the rape of a 22-year-old woman on June 3. Magistrate Daniels made this order after prosecution informed the court that the police files were yet to be served on the three officers. During their court appearance in August, the prosecution told the court that police were still working on the case. The court granted a two-month adjournment then. Yesterday was the third time they had appeared in court. The court fixed Dec 11 as the final mention date. It was alleged that on June 3, Yori, Aura and Karayo in police uniform were in a police vehicle which Yori was driving. Auxiliary officer Soweto Maima, who is still on the run, was with them. They allegedly picked up the woman at the Manu Autoport and took her to the Saraga Police Station, telling her that she was having an affair with a married man, and that a complainant was waiting for her at the station. They allegedly took her phone, asked her for money and told her that if she did not give it, she would be arrested. They told her that her bail would be K5,000. Aura then allegedly told her that if she had sex with him, he would let her go. She was then allegedly raped in turn by Aura, Maima and Karayo. Aura and Karayo are being remanded. Yori’s bail has been extended.

Title: Registrar explains why parties are facing deregistration
Content: THREE of the 32 political parties facing deregistration for not complying with provisions of the Organic Law on the Integrity of Political Parties and Candidates has explained why, an official says. Political Parties Registrar Emmanuel Pok said the Integrity of Political Parties and Candidates Commission had put 32 political parties on notice as they could be in breach of the Olippac, and potentially be deregistered for five years after 2027. He said only the Liberal Party, People’s Reform Party and PNG Country Party had responded to the commission’s notice of intention to cancel registration as of yesterday. He urged the other 29 to show cause. Pok said that these parties had breached either sections 24, 25, 28 and 88 of the Olippac. “Section 24 requires that every registered political party have membership representation in all four regions of Papua New Guinea, but many parties on notice have failed to meet this minimum requirement” he said. “Section 25 mandates that all parties must have a functioning executive structure and some parties listed currently have no appointed executive officers, which is grounds for deregistration. “According to Section 28, many parties have not updated their financial membership lists, revised their constitutions, or maintained updated party policies. “The majority of these parties have failed to submit their annual financial returns, as required by Section 88, for two consecutive years (2023 and 2024), which is another key ground for deregistration under the law.” Pok gave the parties until Oct 28 to respond.

Title: District reopens historical WW2 Kapa Kapa Trail in Central
Content: GABAGABA village in Central, known for its historical significance during World War II, has reopened the Kapa Kapa Trail, now named the Ghost Mountain Expedition. This trail, which was used by American soldiers in 1942, is the second-largest tourism trekking route in the region, following the famous Kokoda Track. The reopening aims to attract both international and local trekkers, boosting the province’s economy. Rigo MP Sir Ano Pala highlighted the village’s key role in WWII, where it assisted American soldiers on the frontlines. Now, Gabagaba will once again take the frontline, but this time for peace, leading visitors along the 48km trail southeast to the Kokoda Track. This initiative not only honors the historical significance of the site but also promotes tourism and economic growth in the region. “As we launched the Ghost Mountain Legacy Track, the revisit of the Kapa Kapa Trail, let us be reminded of our needs and our leaders must stand together to bring all our needs as basic services,” Sir Ano said. The Ghost Mountain Expedition name was initiated by the PNG Tribal Foundation, with support from Central Governor Rufina Peter and Sir Ano. This initiative is set to boost tourism and improve basic services, including schools, aid posts, and electricity, in remote villages along the WWII trail. These villages, starting from Dorobisoro and its neighboring areas, were vital during the war when locals assisted soldiers in battle. Foundation President Gary Bustin announced that 10 trekkers from Colorado, USA, and Australia begun the eight-day trek on Monday, starting from Dorobisoro. “We will be visiting the villages as we walk through the track and help with basic medical supplies, also we will be talking to the villages and see the needs especially schools, aid posts and others that we can build for the villages. “It is not just the trekking but brining basic services to the villages that we were once helped the American soldiers during the WWII and how we can give back to the communities,” Bustin said. Provincial government economy and tourism chairman Desmond Baira on behalf of Peter and Sir Ano committed K200,000 each to the village for its basic services. Prime Minister James Marape has welcomed the reopening of the Kapa Kapa Trail describing it as a major step towards promoting wartime heritage tourism, rural development, and international friendship between Papua New Guinea, Australia, and the United States.
People: Ano Pala, James Marape, Rufina Peter

Title: Army chief grateful for partners’ support during PNGDF Week
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) chief Rear Admiral Philip Polewara thanked friends and partners for their support through the PNGDF week and independence anniversary last month. He said the force has done so well by providing security and also participating in some events. “As the dust settles from our arenas and we return to business as usual, I reflect on the participation of the PNGDF in the country’s Golden Jubilee celebrations.” “The PNGDF’s celebration of the 50th anniversary began much earlier than the rest of the country, in July, when we launched the Exercise Antap Long Ol that culminated in the military week from Sept 1-6,” he said. The First Pacific Islands Regiment was presented its new King’s Colours by Prince Edward, Duke of Edinburgh. Polewara said the PNGDF participated in providing guards of honour to visiting heads of state, took part in various military drills and assisted police to provide security. “Our performance in the events would not have been captivating, grandiose and an outright success without the support and help we have received for the cause. “I thank the support of forces like Australia Defence, New Zealand Defence, Japan, United Kingdom, United States and France. “Our military celebrations had a particular Pacific flavour because we not only had support from major partners in the region but were also joined by Vanuatu, Fiji, and Tonga,” he said. On Sept 16 Polewara was joined by Fiji’s Chief of Defence Major-General Ro Jone Logavatu Kalouniwai, ADFs Chief of Defence Admiral David Johnstone and other military partner heads.

Title: 230,000 reached in round one of polio vaccination campaign
Content: THE round one of the polio vaccination in Morobe topped 230,000, an official says. The target was set at 290,000 children below 10 years old in Morobe. Dr Kelly Mesere, director of Public Health under the Morobe health authority, said the first round nearly reached its target. “We now have only 60,000 more children to be vaccinated under the age of 10 in the province and that is a good coverage for us,” he said. He said the province has reached 80 per cent of all children under 10 and looked forward to carrying out the campaign in schools, as 50 per cent of children under 10 are in school. “In the province, Menyamya district has recorded the highest number of children vaccinated whie Nawaeb and Markham districts recorded the lowest.” He said the vaccination coverage in this two districts were low due to denominator issues and mobile population. “Also mountainous districts such as Kabwum in Morobe were not reached during the first round due to logistical and funding issues.” He said the two-week given was also not enough to cover a big province such as Morobe with 10 districts. “Despite all these challenges, we were able to reach 80 per cent coverage of both polio vaccination and routine immunisation in the province.” The round two campaign in Morobe has   and will end on Oct 31.

Title: Madang police ban end-of-year school picnics
Content: POLICE in Madang are banning all end-of-year school picnics and social gatherings after some students were stranded on Pik Island outside Madang last weekend. Madang police commander Acting Superintendent Robert Baim, when issuing the order on Tuesday, said no more picnics or gatherings outside classrooms or school boundaries will be entertained in the province. The incident on Pik Island saw more than 20 students from Kusbau Primary School unable to make it back to Madang after a picnic because the boat had failed to return to pick them up. It was also alleged that students, many of them minors, drank homebrew (steam) on the island. “For the safety of the children, it is better to have all such gatherings within the school premises rather than taking it out and risking the lives of the children,” Baim said. He said when having such gatherings in the school grounds can be supervised well by both the parents and teachers. “From now on, students must return directly home after all official school programmes and not engage in any other unofficial school programmes like end of year parties.” As the year’s end approaches, many students who finish their exams will try to make their class party to say goodbye to their friends. But for this year in Madang, police will not tolerate that anymore, Baim said. He said all students should enjoy their holidays in a peaceful manner and not get into trouble like the Pik Island incident. Baim urged parents, teachers and citizens in Madang to work in partnership towards ensuring their students’ approaches towards life is given priority and stop engaging in illegal activities that will place their lives and education in danger.

Title: Bulolo locals urged to start growing trees
Content: LOCALS in Bulolo district of Morobe are being encouraged to take the lead in growing trees as part of a new plan to create jobs, protect the environment, and support local communities. At the recent launch of the Bulolo-Wau Plantation Extension Project, Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jr called on government agencies to help his district start small-scale tree planting, especially through community nurseries. He said Bulolo already had successful small farmers growing cocoa and coffee, and now it was time to add trees to that list. “This is about giving our people the tools to help themselves,” Basil said. “With the help of the National Forest Authority and PNG Diwai Holdings, we can provide tree seedlings and support so individuals and families can plant trees on their own land.” Basil believes this project will not only help the environment but also create income opportunities for local families. He stressed that long-term investment in tree planting could provide economic benefits just like cash crops. National Forest Services managing director John Mosoro said the idea fitted well with the current extension of the Bulolo-Wau plantation. He said planting materials and land would be made available, but it was important that the district worked with local landowners to ensure land was ready. Mosoro said: “This is not just a government project, it’s a chance for the whole community to be involved in sustainable forestry.” The Bulolo-Wau plantation is one of the oldest and best-managed forest areas in PNG. First established in 1962, it now covers thousands of hectares and is divided into zones to manage planting and harvesting. To support the expansion, two vehicles and staff housing were also launched during the event, which shows that the project has both planning and resources behind it. Basil encouraged all people in Bulolo to support the tree planting initiative, and said that it was a long-term investment in the land, the people, and the future of the district.

Title: Early childhood centre gets tanks and desks
Content: AFTER 21 years of facing water shortages, Esther Early Childhood received two 9,000-litre water tanks and 30 desks from the Australian government and Morobe administration. The school was established in 2005 at Yanga village in the Ahi local level government area of Lae, and has been serving the community for 21 years. The population there is at least 200. Provincial deputy administrator, social services, Robin Bazinuc was overwhelmed, saying that seeing students benefit through such a contribution was a relief. “I thank the Australian government through the Australian consulate general Lae, Brenton Kanowski, for working in collaboration with us to serve future generations,” he said. Kanowski acknowledged the late Morobe governor, Luther Wenge, and his administration for having the vision to partner the Australian government to demonstrate its commitment to the people. “You are the future leaders of the country, therefore, we are here to support and provide a future for you,” he said. The Australian government, in partnership with the Morobe administration, is delivering 930 new desks and 90 tanks to 31 elementary schools in the province. This is part of the Morobe Water Security Project supporting selected early childhood centre in Lae, Huon Gulf, Markham, Nawaeb, Bulolo, Wau Waria and Menyamya. The initiative was supported by a K6 million investment from the Australian government and a K500,000 contribution from the Morobe administration to help improve education and water security for more than 8,000 students.

Title: East Sepik Health Authority prepares to receive direct funding from donors
Content: The East Sepik Provincial Health Authority is gearing up to become a direct recipient of donor funding starting next year. Chief executive officer Matthew Kaluvia expressed optimism about the authority’s ability to handle these funds but noted the importance of improving staff capacity in governance, public financial management, and programme oversight. The authority was rated 76 per cent ready by the Accelerated Immunisation and Health System Strengthening Programme, phase two (AIHSS2), in its transition to receive funds directly from donors such as DFAT, MFAT and Gavi. To be considered ready for transition, the PHA requires a score of 80 per cent. The authority is preparing to join the West Sepik Provincial Health Authority and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville in becoming direct recipients of donor funding in 2026. “We must prepare ourselves to take on the responsibilities of being a direct recipient from donor partners,” Kaluvia said. “We are focused on strengthening our systems to meet the requirements of our funding partners.” Recently, the authority hosted a transition workshop in Wewak aimed at equipping its middle management team with the necessary skills to manage this funding independently. “This is a significant moment for us,” Kaluvia said. “We are excited about the opportunities ahead and view this as a step forward. Our team is dedicated to refining our internal policies to ensure compliance with national and international standards. “It’s about more than just receiving funds; it’s about building a strong and transparent health system for the people of East Sepik.”

Title: Australian Defence Force flight training winding down in PNG
Content: FLIGHT training in the Central Highlands for pilots and aircrew of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) is winding down as the visiting fifth Aviation Regiment turns its attention to supporting the Papua New Guinea Defence Force during Exercise Wantok Warrior. About 100 ADF personnel and four CH-47F Chinook helicopters have conducted daily flights around the Owen Stanley Ranges as part of Exercise Helicon Luk 2025, an annual activity aimed at getting pilots and aircrew qualified to fly at altitude and in mountainous terrain. Captain Lloyd Struber said being qualified to fly at high-density altitude and in mountainous environments was necessary to prepare the unit to operate in all conditions and in all terrain. “The aircraft behaves differently at higher-density altitudes because the air is thinner, you’re using more power but creating less lift, and if we’re to go out the door on humanitarian assistance and disaster relief, or defence aid to the civil community, or combat missions, we have to be able to fly everywhere,” he said. At Townsville in North Queensland, where the fifth Aviation Regiment typically trains, the highest peak is around 1,700 feet or 518 metres. In the Central highlands the pilots fly and practice take-off and landing manoeuvres in altitudes above 9,000 feet (2,743 metres). He said the challenging flying conditions in the Central highlands were nothing new for the Officer Commanding Task Unit Brahman. “Papua New Guinea is a beautiful country that offers access to terrain, and environments that don’t exist within Australia.” “The communities out there are phenomenal, it’s wonderful to see them get out and embrace our presence,” he added. Potter said he looks forward to seeing future iterations of Ex Helicon Luk and other exercises as both countries grow their relationship as alliance partners under the Mutual Defence Treaty.

Title: 32 political parties put on notice
Content: THE Integrity of Political Parties and Candidates Commission has put on notice 32 political parties that they will have their registration cancelled for failing to comply with certain provisions. Political Parties Registrar Emmanuel Pok gave the parties until Tuesday (Oct 21) to respond. They could be in breach of the Organic Law on the Integrity of Political Parties and Candidates, particularly the non-submission of financial returns for 2022, 2023 and 2024 to the registry. He said that some of the political parties did not have any office. The People’s Reform Party (PRP), which currently has members in Parliament, is also listed. The members are East Sepik Governor and party leader Allan Bird, North Fly MP James Donald and Middle Fly MP Maso Hewabi. PRP general-secretary Ismael Tamutai toldThe Nationalthat the party’s management was aware of the notice and was “working on it”. The other parties are the New Generation Party, PNG Destiny Party, People’s United Assembly Party, Grassroots United Front Party, Paradise Kingdom Party, Papua New Guinea First Party, Model Nation Party, Trust PNG Party, PNG Youths Party, Coalition for Reform Party, Allegiance Party, Liberal Party, People’s Transformation Party, PNG Country Party, United Party, People’s Resource Awareness, Levites Party, Transformation PNG Party, PNG One Nation Party, Papua New Guinea liberal Democratic Party, People’s Empowerment Party, Papua New Guinea Youth Empowerment Party, PNG Prosperity Party, Indigenous Liberation Party, Nation Action Party, League for National Advancement PNG Party, Advance PNG Party, Future PNG Party, Great Nation Party, People’s Guided Democracy Party and National Development Party. “These political parties have 21 days as of Sept 30 to respond to the registrar,” Pok said.
People: Allan Bird, James Donald, Maso Hewabi

Title: Wai: Provinces’ lack of outreach affecting immunisation coverage
Content: THE contributing factor to low immunisation coverage in many provinces is that their health facilities do not conduct clinic outreach, says acting Health secretary Ken Wai. He said that the Government and donors were supplying vaccines and equipment to immunise children. Wai was responding to questions during the Special Parliamentary Committee on Children and Youth on the cause of low immunisation coverage in some provinces. The inquiry into social services for children and youths began yesterday in Port Moresby. “The Health Department with partners like Unicef are supplying cold chains (vaccine freezers), vaccines and even transporting the vaccines to provinces to carry out the immunisation,” he said. “But it’s the health facilities and provincial health authorities (PHAs) who do not do clinics.” Wai added that while the department coordinated the overall health system, the PHAs were given powers to execute service delivery including human resources, facilities and funding. Health Department’s population and healthy community acting executive manager Dr Lutty Amos said that they identified during visits the lack of leadership and communication by provincial heads right down to the village level. It was one of the contributing factors to the low immunisation coverage. She added that logistical issues also affected the rollout of vaccines. “For instance, in Mutzing, Morobe, the health facility there has only one vehicle to help with the daily operations,” Dr Amos said. “It cannot go out to help with the immunisation programme.” She said that they were identifying problems and were working with PHAs to address them. They also monitor and follow up on the vaccines rollout programme.

Title: Kombra says education system was fine before reforms
Content: THE education system in the country was working well prior to the 1995 reforms, says Education Secretary Dr Uke Kombra. “We had a system that was working because the education secretary was able to control everyone down the system right to the village level,” he said. Kombra was responding to queries during the Special Parliamentary Committee on Children and Youth formal inquiry into social services for children and youth which started yesterday in Port Moresby. He was asked why not many students made it to secondary school and how early childhood education was being rolled out. He said that they had created policies such as Early Childhood Education (ECE) to combat school dropouts and other issues. The problem is the implementation of the policies. “With the 1995 reforms, the system was abolished,” Kombra said. “Now we have the new system. “Education advisers in the provinces report to the provincial administrator. “They are not accountable to the secretary for education. “That’s one of the impediments we have at the moment, and I don’t know the extent of how we could look into this to make some reforms.” Kombra said some reforms needed to be carried out so that education advisers became accountable to the secretary of education. It will mean that the standards of policies the department wants can be implemented more efficiently and effectively. Meanwhile, Education Minister Lucas Dekena said he wanted to develop children into God-fearing, law-abiding citizens. Dekena and Kombra said the department relied on the Government in terms of funding to roll out these policies.

Title: ToRot portrait to hang among saints
Content: A PORTRAIT of Blessed Peter ToRot will be placed alongside those of other Saints in Rome as part of the canonisation process scheduled for Sunday, says a clergy. Fr Thomas Ravioli, the vice-postulator to the canonisation of blessed Peter ToRot, said those in attendance must look out for the portrait. “The Catholic Church in Papua New Guinea is filled with pride and all should look to him as a model of faith and courage,” he said. “The portrait will hang among other portraits of saints, but it must serve as a visual aid for devotion, reminding people of the saint’s life and inspiring the people to follow his examples.” Ravioli is a missionary from Argentina who had served in PNG for 15 years. He spent the last five years on the canonisation before departing in June for Rome. He joined the work of gathering documentation for ToRot’s canonisation. His work concluded in the submission of the necessary documentations to Rome. “The support of the PNG Bishops has been instrumental throughout this process,” he said. “Archbishop of Rabaul Diocese Rochus Tatamai, who is also the grandson of ToRot, has played a critical role in providing guidance and support throughout the cause.”

Title: Emergency load shedding targeted for peak hours
Content: ELECTRICITY transformers and feeder lines will undergo emergency load shedding during peak hours to avoid overloading substation transformers, says PNG Power Limited (PPL). PPL said certain feeders continue to carry on part loading of the affected Konedobu feeders that were destroyed in a recent fire. That is the Boroko feeder one, three, six, seven and eight, which are serviced by the Boroko Substation transformers one and two. The affected areas include Boroko, Korobosea, Taurama, Hohola, Six-Mile, Gare and Barakau. Meanwhile, PPL said installation and connection work were completed for the temporary Konedobu containerised substation. “(Yesterday) the feeder cables from the containerised control room will be connected to the feeder poles,” PPL said. “Then our technical test team will step in to carry out testing for all the work that was done. “This technical work may take 2-3 days. “We will update on this after the tests are carried out.” The Konedobu substation was destroyed in a fire on Sept 19. It resulted in several feeder lines being put out of service.

Title: WW2 bomb removed at ENB settlement
Content: A World War Two bomb found at East New Britain’s Gelegele settlement has been safely removed and transported to a secured site for disposal. Governor Michael Marum said at about 3pm on Thursday, the United States AN-M66 general –purpose bomb, weighing more than 900kg, was lifted and relocated. Marum said the operation was a joint effort by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) explosive ordnance disposal unit, provincial disaster management division, Kokopo Fire Service, police, Rabaul’s Kombiu local level government officers, local contractor Kokopo Plant Hire and volunteers. Marum said the bomb was accidentally unearthed on Sept 25 by a group of youths digging a pit toilet, sparking fear throughout surrounding villages. It was later confirmed to be a 2,000-pound AN-M66 bomb, a type widely used by Allied Forces during World War Two. Rabaul was one of the Japan’s major military bases during the war. To neutralise it, the US carried out massive bombing campaigns, leaving behind hundreds of unexploded ordnances still being found across the province, Marum said. Retired PNGDF bomb specialist Philip Makoan, now attached to the provincial disaster office, praised the joint effort.

Title: Drunk students will get criminal records: Police
Content: POLICE in Chimbu have warned misbehaving students that those arrested will have police files which will affect their future drastically. Provincial police commander Supt Mazuc Rubiang made clear following the arrest of 18 Grade 10 male students from various high schools and secondary schools following reports of disorderly behaviour after the exams. Rubiang said the students were taken into custody in Kundiawa over the weekend and were now facing charges related to alcohol and public disturbances. “I have directed my officers to go through each and every one of them by fingerprints and photographs and update their criminal records,” he said. He added that students must understand that in any further studies or employment, they will be required to provide police clearance and such records would stop their future opportunities. “The students were arrested following my directives to Grades eight, 10 and 12 students not to misbehave after their final examinations,” he said. Rubiang had warned that students found misbehaving or involved in liquor related offences after the exams would be arrested and charged and police bail will be K1, 000. “My appeal to parents and families that my decision on K1, 000 police bail still stands and I will not change that on any formal request from parents and families,” he said. He also asked parents, leaders and community members to help police by discouraging disorderly celebrations.

Title: Literacy essential for inmate rehabilitation: Commander
Content: BUIMO Correctional Services Commander Michael Wundia has called the reintroduction and funding of literacy programmes in prisons. Wundia highlighted the critical role of literacy in the rehabilitation and reintegration of inmates. He said a lack of basic literacy among inmates was a barrier to successful rehabilitation. “One of the main challenges we face in correctional services is that many inmates do not know how to read and write,” Wundia said. “We need a literacy programme inside the camp so that those who are illiterate can learn before they return to society. There should be life after prison for them.” He acknowledged the role of the Education Department in supporting prison literacy initiatives and thanked the education department for making prisons a partner in driving literacy in the compounds. Wundia noted that a literacy programme once existed within the prison system but ceased operating 10 to 15 years ago. “We had a literacy programme in the past, but it stopped over a decade ago. “Since then, we’ve tried to implement rehabilitation programmes focused on skills and education, but we can only enroll inmates who already know how to read and write. It’s a basic requirement,” he said. He stressed the importance of preparing inmates for life after freedom and reducing reoffending by equipping them with foundational skills. “We want them to change inside before they come out. Literacy helps change mindsets. “If they learn to read and write while serving their time, they are more likely to return to society with a new perspective and avoid going back to the behaviours that brought them in,” he said. Wundia also made a plea for greater financial support from the government and stakeholders. “I’d like to ask that funding be made available to support such programmes, not only in the communities but also within correctional services. “Juveniles especially need access to these programmes so they don’t go back to the same things they came in for,” he said.

Title: ENB launch polio campaign
Content: The East New Britain Health Authority has launched a two-week long poliomyelitis (polio) campaign targeting children aged between three months and 10 years across the province. In response to the national outbreak of polio, the authority developed a provincial outbreak response plan outlining immediate, medium- term, and long- term strategies guided by three objectives: Protect children from poliovirus infection, prevent further spread and stop poliovirus circulation, and strengthen routine immunization programs in the province. The campaign, which will run from Oct 13 to 29, aims to protect children from the potentially crippling disease and strengthen the province’s overall immunization coverage. Speaking at the official launch of the campaign, authority chief executive officer (CEO) Dr Ako Yap said the current coverage has reached only 60-70 per cent of the population and expressed disappointment in these statistics, saying services have reached many rural parts of the province and it should not be an excuse.

Title: Court refuses to grant Nepo’s stay application
Content: THE Supreme Court yesterday refused to grant leave on the stay application by acting Correctional Services (CS) commissioner Bernard Nepo. Justice Derek Hartshorn, who presided as a single-man bench, ruled that Nepo would not face direct prejudice if leave was not granted. Nepo filed the application for an order to stay the proceedings and orders of the National Court made on Aug 1, in the case between David Suagu and Nepo and the State, pursuant to Section 19 of the Supreme Court Act, pending determination of the appeal or until further orders. The respondents in this matter are Suagu and the State. Nepo, through his lawyer, argued that the determination of the decision of Aug 1 appealed against will settle not only the legality of the contract of employment of Suagu but for other senior management members also. He submitted that the National Court erred in both law and fact in holding that he did not have authority to terminate the Suagu, which has the effect of opening floodgates for disgruntled officers to dispute critical decision by him. He argued that this could cause instability in the service, an important government institution, and asked the court to grant leave on the stay application, pending determination of the substantive appeal. Suagu’s lawyer objected and among other grounds, argued that there was evidence that his client was left out of payroll and benefits of his position, and submitted that Suagu would suffer greater prejudice, and hardships more than Nepo, if leave was granted for a stay. Lawyer representing the State objected, and conceded that Nepo was not re-appointed so he did not have the powers to make the decision to terminate Suagu at that material time. After considering the parties’ arguments, Justice Hartshorn ruled that Suagu would suffer great prejudice for being left out of payroll and benefits of his position. “I make an order that the application for a stay filed on Aug 6 is refused,” he said.

Title: Five held over murder of 62-year-old man
Content: FIVE suspects have been arrested for allegedly murdering a 62-year-old man from North Waghi in Jiwaka after he was reported missing earlier this month. Police yesterday found his body at Brown River and identified him as Aiwa Ape. Central police commander Supt Joseph Salle was informed by family members that Ape left home on Oct 3 and had not returned since. “The reason behind his death is now under investigation. My officers were notified through a Facebook post that included a photo of the late Ape standing in front of his vehicle before he went missing,” he said. “The vehicle was recovered in Mekeo, which later led the police to identify the person who drove to Mekeo.” Salle added that the suspect who drove the vehicle to Mekeo was picked up by Bereina police on Monday. He led them to where Ape’s body was found. “We spoke to the family of the deceased, who accompanied us to the location where we retrieved the body and took it to Port Moresby,” Salle said. “We will work closely with the family to ensure that those involved face the full force the law.”

Title: Bougainville members attend induction
Content: THE 45 members of the 5th Bougainville House of Representatives have begun a week-long induction programme in Buka. Speaking at the opening of the programme on Monday, Autonomous Region of Bougainville vice-president Ezekiel Masatt emphasised the importance of the induction in helping members understand the functions of government and how to translate that knowledge into meaningful action. He reiterated that while political independence remains the core agenda, there were equally important issues that must be addressed collaboratively. “It is not just political independence, the economics, the administration, our foreign policies; we must address these issues that support our political independence aspirations,” Masatt said. He reminded the members that Bougainville’s journey to independence will ultimately shape the lives of future generations. “It is us and our children and our children’s children who will live this independence,” he added. He commended the speaker and clerk of Parliament for organising the induction programme, noting its importance, particularly for the new members who make about half of the fifth House of Representatives. “If you want to be an effective leader, you need to know the structure, the process, the mechanisms that are in place,” he said. The week-long programme includes presentations from the Bougainville administration and the Bougainville parliamentary services, focusing on strengthening members’ understanding of their oversight roles, participation in parliamentary debates, constituency duties, and committee responsibilities.

Title: ToRot to become first native saint
Content: AFTER 30 years, Catechist Blessed Peter ToRot has passed the final chapter of the cannonisation process and will be the first native Papua New Guinea Saint. ToRot, originally from Rakunai in East New Britain, will be recognised on Sunday at the St Peters Basilica in the Vatican City by Pope Leo. In attendance will be Archbishop of Port Moresby Sir John Cardinal Ribat, Catholic Bishops Conference General-Secretary Fr Lawrence Arockiaraj Bereina, president of the Catholic Bishops conference PNG and the Solomon Islands, and Bereina diocese Bishop Otto Separy, Catholic officials, more than 80 Catholic faithful and immediate family members. Sir Cardinal Ribat said that ToRot’s courage in defending the sanctity of marriage during the Japanese occupation of PNG, and his ultimate martyrdom by poisoning in 1945, served as a profound inspiration for all Catholics and all people of faith, not just in PNG but across the Pacific. Sir John said that the cannonisation marked a historic spiritual milestone, making him the nation’s first saint and a recognition of PNG’s Christian heritage. “Despite being a layman, he dedicated his life to the church even surrounded by danger and was a devoted husband and father. “This serves as a strong example and encouragement for Catholic families and people of faith worldwide. “This is the time when we are to pray together for this event and to be of service just as what ToRot demonstrated by his faith. “He stood firm on the Christian values of honouring one marriage partner, and that is how all should live during this time.” During the canonisation, the Pope will declare ToRot a saint in a special Mass. The ceremony will include the pope reading a formal proclamation and the relics of the new saint are then presented for adoration by the faithful. Catholic Bishops Conference General Secretary Fr Lawrence Arockiaraj said that bishops and church officials would arrive in Rome on Friday. “On Saturday at 9am, the PNG delegation will visit the tomb of Pope Francis at St Mary Major, followed by a vigil in the evening at the Daughters of our lady of the sacred heart church in Piazza Navona. “The canonisation takes place on Sunday at the St Peters Basilica where ToRot is recognised as the country’s first saint among others from around the world. “On Monday, the delegation including Bishops from the Solomon Islands have an audience with the Holy Father Pope Leo. “A thanksgiving mass follows for by then Saint ToRot, followed by dinner.”

Title: Project enters second phase to empower communities
Content: THE Rural Service Delivery Project (RSDP), implemented by the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs, has entered its second phase to empower communities for the next five years. Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe said the project had been rolled out, with the support of the World Bank, in five provinces since 2017. About K27 million has been used to deliver services to more than 400,000 people in the country. “(The project) was designed to bridge the development gap between urban and rural areas by improving access to infrastructure development to deliver services to the people,” he said. “The first phase was hosted in Central, Western, Chimbu, West Sepik and East New Britain. “The project has funded 60 rain water catchments, 31 gravity-fed and bore wells with solar pump systems, 15 household solar lighting, 51 double classrooms and school libraries, 35 community aid posts, eight staff houses, 30 community and ward halls, 17 women resources centres, two community markets and four livelihood subprojects. “It is targeting the lowest level of government and strengthening bottom-up planning as with the objective of strengthening good governance, empowerment and ownership at LLG level.” Eoe said the second phase would be rolled out in at least 12 provinces with about K15 million allocated to each once fully operational. Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim said his district would provide K200,000 funding towards the completion of projects in the district. “Counterpart funding support from provincial governments, DDAs and other development partners have assisted RSDP and communities in fully completing their sub-projects,” Eoe said. “If that support was not given, many sub-projects would not reach the completion stage.”

Title: HIV clinic reopens after renovation
Content: THE St Theresa’s HIV Clinic in Hohola, Port Moresby, was reopened yesterday after undergoing a refurbishment funded by the Australian government. Attending the event were Australian High Commissioner to PNG Ewen McDonald, Australian Senator Nita Green, Health Department deputy secretary Dr Dora Lenturut-Katal and Catholic Church Health Services staff members. Lenturut-Katal said that partnerships between the Catholic Church Health Services (CCHS) and Australia were critical to HIV services. “In 2024, more than 27,000 HIV tests were conducted and this is in addition to outreach, counselling and treatment of clients,” shesaid. “I expect that this will increase given the extra support received from the Australian government. “We hope it will decrease the number of HIV cases that we have in the country or even try prevent the spread of HIV.” She thanked the Australian government for the additional Australian $1.5 million to CCHS in response to the declaration of a national HIV emergency by the Government in June. Green said Australia’s support for the renovation was a small symbol of a commitment to the PNG health sector and an enduring pillar of the two countries’ development partnership. “Australia shares a desire with the PNG government and the CCHS to drive better outcomes across PNG and together, we stand as partners in responding to the HIV situation in PNG with urgency, compassion and resolve,” she said. “We know that rising rates of HIV in PNG are threatening lives and livelihoods and in support of the PNG’s declaration of a HIV emergency in June, Australia is nearly tripling its investment in HIV services here in PNG in 2025 and 2026,” she said.

Title: Spicy aroma fills mega mall as Malaysians display cuisine
Content: A SPECTACULAR display of Malaysian culture and cuisine caught the attention of many who were at the Vision City Mega Mall in Port Moresby on Saturday. The event showcased the Sabah cultural group and cooking demonstrations of traditional food which were done in commemoration of Malaysia Day and 50 years of PNG-Malaysia bilateral relations. Malayan High Commissioner Hamizan Hashim said the event was held to celebrate the positive and mutual relations both countries have had since July 12, 1975. “This year, PNG celebrates 50 years of independence,” he said. “Similarly, Malaysia also celebrates 50 years of bilateral relations with PNG. “On Sept 16 when PNG celebrated its golden jubilee, Malaysia also celebrated its national day with PNG. “To commemorate this special occasion, we share with you all our cultures and cuisine today. “On behalf of the people and government of Malaysia, I extend our warmest and most heartfelt congratulation for 50 years of PNG being a great friend of Malaysia through our mutual respect, shared goals and people to people connections.” The three-hour long spectacle was filled with music and dance, accompanied by the sweet and spicy aroma of the Malaysian cuisine. The cooking demonstrations featured a few famous Malaysian dishes, which includedroti jalawith chicken curry,kuih pajaram,kerabu betikandambuyatwith fish gravy. A few shoppers and spectators were given a change to indulge in the culinary delights. The event ended with traditional performances.

Title: Bilum show promotes Sepik artistry
Content: THE second Pinktober Sepik Bilum and Basket Show started at the Sir Michael Thomas Somare Stadium in Wewak, East Sepik yesterday. The three-day annual event celebrates the artistry and cultural heritage of the Sepik region through the intricate bilum and basket creations of local female weavers and serve as a platform for cultural preservation, women’s economic empowerment and the promotion of local tourism. Under the empowering theme: ‘I am my cultural identity’, the event is an interesting landmark for Sepik women involved in the art and craft business, particularly mothers dedicated to bilum and basket weaving. Dubbed the second Pinktober, this event also aims to raise awareness about the increasing cases of breast cancer among women in Papua New Guinea and worldwide. Matiba Wek, 31, from the Chambri Women’s Group, said it took them one day to travel down to Wewak to participate in the event to showcase their Chambri baskets and they are happy and proud to have showcased their work. “To weave a basket, if all materials are available, it takes us just one day to complete a basket and each basket has its own purpose and its use. Apart from showcasing our basket, I will also be modelling a basketwear that is woven by one of the mothers in the group,” Matiba said. The Sepik Bilum Basket Show is their second and more than 30 groups, primarily from the Sepik River, Angoram local level government, along with additional groups from the Wosera-Gawi, Maprik and Karawari are taking part. Launched last year, the inaugural show was a resounding success, providing vital exposure and recognition for the creativity of East Sepik women and girls. It showcased unique woven pieces that reflected the rich history and traditions of their respective tribes and villages in East Sepik. Over three days, this show will empower mothers and young girls to present their handiwork to a global audience, enabling them to forge essential business connections while celebrating the unique craftsmanship of Sepik bilums and baskets and skills that have been passed down through generations.

Title: 36,500 Grade 12 students nationwide sit exams
Content: ABOUT 36,500 Grade 12 students from 250 secondary schools, including seven National Schools of Excellence, started sitting their national examinations yesterday, with mathematics and history papers. Today, the students will sit physics, geography and accounting exams. On Wednesday, they will sit biology, business studies and economics. On Thursday, they will sit language, literature, and chemistry, and will conclude with mathematics paper two on Friday. Kopen National School of Excellence has marked a significant milestone, having its pioneer batch of 83 students sit the Grade 12 national examinations starting yesterday. Principal Saju Francis said the group comprised 57 male and 26 female students, cementing the school’s place as the nation’s institution dedicated to science, technology, engineering and mathematics. He said the first intake of Grade 11 students was selected in 2023, and they now completed their Grade 12 academic year, culminating in the national exams. Francis expressed confidence that this historic batch of students would perform well. Meanwhile, an all boys’ school, Dela Salle Secondary School (DSSS)-Bomana, outside Port Moresby had its 213 students sit the exams. Deputy principal Daka Paglau said: “We have 213 boys, comprising of five classes. “We have two science classes, one social science class and two business classes. “We’ve always done well despite being a boys’ school and this year Grade 12 boys have worked very hard and the teachers have also prepared them well and we know they will do better.” Paglau said the school encountered no problem this year and students were well behaved, responsible in their actions and conduct in their studies and towards their teachers. “The school also helps to provide for their breakfast daily including shower blocks for them to have a proper shower and breakfast before everyday classes begin because not many were able to have these necessities,” Paglau said.

Title: 1,600 die of breast cancer at PMGH annually, says CEO
Content: PORT Moresby General Hospital (PMGH) has recorded about 4,000 new cases of breast cancer and at least 1,600 deaths from the disease each year, the chief executive officer says. Dr Paki Molumi revealed this during the welcome reception for the team from Chongqing University Cancer Hospital in China who are attached to the hospital on a voluntary basis. “Alarmingly, 40 per cent of affected women are under the age of 50, and many present advanced stages due to limited awareness and access to detection,” Dr Molumi said. “This visit by the Chongqing University Cancer Hospital is not only timely but is transformative,” he said. He said this visit reflected a critical step towards reducing breast cancer mortality through capacity building, clinical mentorship and infrastructure support Dr Molumi said during a recent visit by the hospital and Health Department staff to Chongqing, they were impressed with the facilities and service provided by the cancer hospital. “During our visit, we had discussions on strengthening partnership to support the Comprehensive Cancer Centre under construction at PMGH. “This centre is expected to be commissioned in the first quarter of 2026, ” Dr Molumi told the visiting team that their visit to PNG was helping the hospital operationalised this facility, which will introduce advanced services. “At PMGH, our vision is to establish a comprehensive cancer centre that integrates diagnosis, treatment and palliative care under one roof and this participation supports our mission to strengthen local activity, expertise and reduce the number of patients who have to travel overseas for life-saving treatment,” Dr Molumi added. Health Minister Elias Kapavore, on behalf of the government, acknowledged the cooperation between the two countries in health. “Over the past years, our cooperation has strengthened our capacity through expertise, training and equipment support,” Kapavore said. “I am proud of the breast cancer training programme, which has empowered many of our local specialists in oncology, pathology and radiology,” he said. Kapavore and Dr Molumi thanked the Chinese medical team for providing health service and support. Chongqing hospital president Prof Wang Ying said their purpose of their visit further deepened the profound friendship and close cooperation that had existed between the two hospitals. “Over the coming week, through a series of activities, including surgical demonstrations, academic exchanges and public health consultations, we hope to share our latest insights and practical experiences in the medical field with our PNG colleagues and to jointly explore clinical challenges and opportunities,” she said.

Title: School celebrates third Grade 10 batch
Content: KAUGERE Junior High School in Port Moresby last week saw its third cohort of Grade 10 students sitting their exams. The school is one of the first schools in National Capital District (NCD) to implement the 1-6-6 education policy. Head teacher Robison Isowalito said this year, there were 489 students who were supposed to sit the exams, but 80 did not turn up. “Our first Grade 10s in 2023 did very well, however, last year they did not perform, but we expect some good results for the third lot,” he said. Isowalito highlighted the school had encountered many challenges when taking on Grade Nine and 10 students since 2023. “Like many other primary schools that converted to junior high schools, the school was meant for primary schools only and the facilities we had were for primary school,” he said. Isowalito said the school had taken on the junior high school status, without any science laboratory, library, administration building, computer building and other important infrastructure. “These are very important buildings that were supposed to be put in place before taking junior high school status,” Isowalito said. He said many of other schools in NCD were not properly planned, and faced the same problem. “We were told to take on grades nine and 10, but the infrastructures are poor. It doesn’t complement the status changes, and we are struggling,” he said. Isowalito said the school also did not have enough curriculum materials for teaching and learning. “We don’t have these important things, but we are seeing an increase in the enrolment since 2023, and it is putting pressure on the teachers and the limited resources we have,” he said. Isowalito said their classroom usually catered for less than 40 students, but now they were more than 60 students in the one classroom. “I don’t know, how long we will continue on like this, unless the relevant authorities come to our aid,” he said.

Title: Lae firm supports primary school
Content: HEAD teacher of Milford Haven Primary School in Lae, Morobe, Samela Pisep says without proper equipment, a teacher cannot fully teach. During a cheque presentation to the school through an Islands Petroleum (IP) charity event, Pisep posed a challenge to the audience through a demonstration. “I have a faucet. I have a magnesium ribbon. I’m ready to teach a chemical reaction. But I don’t have a match. Can anybody in the crowd give me a match?” she asked. Pisep’s words delivered a hard truth, no matter how prepared or passionate a teacher is, without the right tools, learning can’t take place. “I am a teacher and I will be teaching in that classroom. My lesson won’t be interesting until I have that match. “Students learn in the classroom when things are available and when we support them. I cannot teach a very good lesson until I have everything,” she said. Organised by Islands Petroleum, this was the second fundraiser held for the school which raised K81,960, the first took place in 2017. The second one was this year on July 13 that brought together children, families and corporate sponsors, to show support towards a common goal. “Your support is not just helpful, it’s transformational,” Pisep said. “You are not just giving to a school. You’re investing in the future of a community. “Globally, the learning trend has moved on in the sense that both teachers and students need that kind of support you have given us, especially using the colour run fundraiser. “We also are willing to upgrade children in e-library or maybe the IT equipment so that both teachers and students go to internet to access what they’re going to learn in the classroom. “Apart from that, we also have been introduced to 1-6-6 policy from the Education Department, which will have more infrastructure to take care or to cater for the students.”

Title: First 100 days crucial, says Toroama
Content: BOUGAINVILLE President Ishmael Toroama says the next 100 days will be crucial for the future of his people and their journey toward independence. He told the inauguration ceremony of the fifth House of Representatives in Buka on Friday: “Bougainvilleans will disagree on many things, but there is one agenda where Bougainvilleans will always stand as one people – and that is independence. “It is now 36 years since the beginning of the crisis in 1989, 32 years since the beginning of restoration in Buka in 1993, 24 years since the signing of the Bougainville Peace Agreement in 2001 and 20 years since the formation of the Autonomous Bougainville Government in 2005. “After two decades, we are just now beginning to seriously think about development and transformation. At this juncture of our journey, independence, economy and good governance are essential.” He said that of top priority in the next 100 days of his presidency would be to:

Title: Bougainville to become a demilitarised zone: Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says Bougainville will be declared a demilitarised zone as part of the Government’s commitment to ensuring no foreign military presence in the region. He told the inauguration of the fifth Bougainville House of Representatives in Buka on Friday that demilitarisation in Bougainville was an important component of the agreement to maintain peace and stability. “By next year, we will put in into law that no PNG Defence Force soldiers or allies will go into Bougainville,” he said. “We have heard from the people of Bougainville and we will work together as part of our Government’s commitment to peaceful dialogue, economic empowerment, and shared prosperity.” Marape addressed concerns over the recently signed Pukpuk Treaty between Papua New Guinea and Australia. He also congratulated Bougainville President Ishmael Toroama and his people for their strong democratic expression and continued commitment toward peace and progress in the region. “Today is a momentous moment. “The people of Bougainville have re-elected the Toroama government into office as a mark of continuity of the work that was started not just in 2020, but more importantly, the work that began under the 2001 Bougainville Peace Agreement,” Marape said. He called for mutual respect, cooperation, and the need for Bougainville to build a stronger economy as the region progresses toward its long-term aspirations. “We recall the past, but we must construct a future that fully embodies the aspirations of our people. “Bougainville and Papua New Guinea must continue to walk hand in hand, side by side, towards a peaceful and prosperous future.” Toroama said that the current geopolitics at play within the Pacific could bring benefits as well as risks to all within the region, including Bougainville. “The world was already divided into political and economic alliances by the colonial powers,” he said. “Today, these powers are competing for global or regional influence using trade, aid, financing, education, security and telecommunications as the tools of influence. “Geopolitics offers us opportunities as well as risks. “Bougainville will assess for itself, the merits of these arrangements. “The lessons of Panguna are too devastating to continue the status quo.”

Title: 45 members sworn in at inauguration
Content: THE 45 members of the fifth Bougainville House of Representatives were sworn in by Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika at the inauguration ceremony in Buka on Friday. The Bougainville Constitution recognises the House of Representatives as the legislative arm of the government. The 45 seats comprise one for the president, 38 for single-member constituencies, three regional seats for women, and three for ex-combatants. Simon Penatanu was elected unopposed to serve a third term as Speaker of the House of Representatives for the next five years. He thanked the members for their confidence in his leadership, reminding them of their roles and responsibilities to the people, especially in such a critical period of transition for Bougainville. “Bougainville is in the stage of maturing as a vibrant and functioning democracy,” he said. “We must recognise that in this system of governance we have chosen. This parliament is the epitome of our democracy as provided in our constitution.” Bougainville President Ishmael Toroama, into his second term in office, said that his previous term was based on a six-point strategy he had for his people. His plan for the second term will be to focus more on political independence, economic independence and good governance. “Significant progress has been made on the political front with the final hurdle remaining, that of tabling the referendum results on the floor of the PNG Parliament, through the Melanesian Agreement,” he said. “Under this term of government, we will continue to increase our efforts in strengthening relations with our neighbours on social and cultural exchanges and extend the scope of our relationship as Bougainville progresses beyond the Melanesian Agreement and in implementing the Bougainville Peace Agreement.”

Title: Wenge laid to rest in Baindoang
Content: MOROBE Governor Luther Akisawa Wenge, affectionately referred to as the Songáng, was buried at his village in Baindoang, Nawaeb on Friday morning. His tomb stands right in the center of the village next to his grandmother Migere Wenge’s grave. At about 10.30am, his casket was lowered by the bearer party from the Igam Engineering Battalion; the tomb covered with silver white and copper drapes, adorned with laces of national colours. Flowers and wreaths were placed around his casket on the tomb floor, a white veil with a red cross spread over the casket, the universal sign of a believer departing for the Maker. The people of Baindoang cried; the family stood around the tomb – his son Mathew, wearing black and a pig task necklace around his neck, held a PNG flag in his hand. Present to witness the burial was Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP, John Rosso. As mourning songs from Nawaeb were sung, three concrete slabs were pulled over the tomb, closing off the light and any last glimpse of the late leader’s casket. Wenge succumbed to an illness in Port Moresby on Sept 13, 2025. He was flown to Lae on October 3rd, where the national parliament handed his body over to the provincial government and administration. Late Wenge was flown to all districts of Morobe allowing the people to mourn him and pay final respects. Following a public funeral on Wednesday Oct 8, he was flown to Baindoang on Thursday where Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso representing the state handed his body over to his family. Late Wenge’s body overnighted with his people and was finally laid to rest on Friday. So ends the life of a colorful leader of the people.

Title: Finschhafen’s Braun Hospital delivers conjoined twins
Content: A RARE case of conjoined twins was delivered at Braun Hospital in Finschhafen, Morobe, on Friday. Mother Fatima Kevin, from Finschhafen, said doctors had detected two heartbeats during pregnancy, but the conjoined condition was only discovered during delivery. Hospital staff members, despite limited resources, were able to stabilise the newborn boys. A medical officer said the twins are joined at the lower portion of their bodies, share some organs, but have separate limbs and genitals. A medevac team from Manolos Aviation transferred the mother and babies to the Angau Memorial Hospital in Lae for further care. Medical staff members say the twins may be sent overseas for possible separation surgery, depending on further assessment.

Title: No treaty consultation: Scholar
Content: CONSULTATION is one of the biggest things lacking in the Pukpuk Treaty signed by Papua New Guinea and the Australia in Canberra recently, says a PhD candidate from the Australian National University. Michael Kabuni, also a former political science lecturer at the University of PNG, said the Australian parliament had a joint standing committee on treaties. “What they did with this treaty before committing the Australians they held consultations with the public,” he said. “That’s documented and that’s available on the Australian government website. You can read and find out what Australians think of the treaty. You will not find that in PNG or on our websites.” “Where is the consultation?” Kabuni said PNG is more than foreign affairs, and the Office of the Prime Minister with many people outside these offices were never given the opportunity to have their say. “You can go and sign whatever agreement you want with Australia if it benefits you but if you’re committing a nation the nation should have a say,” he added. He also said the counter-argument would be that MPs went through elections and they are the mandated leaders, but during those times, there was no campaign on foreign policy, defence or international obligations. “You never gave the citizens an option to decide you are the right person to be in Parliament to deal with these issues. “You look at the leaders of both countries, one engaged with its population the other one didn’t,” Kabuni said. He added that there are views whether Australian troops on PNG soil would be subject to PNG laws and this is something that we will probably know more as the month progresses and both sides clarify provisions in the treaty. Kabuni said when the Australian government was going for elections last year, they made it clear what their position on foreign affairs was. He said their people knew exactly what they were voting for. “What their foreign affairs would be was made clear to the population. Not the specifics but they gave a general idea of what they were going to do,” he said. During a media briefing on Friday into the recently signed Pukpuk Treaty between Australia and Papua New Guinea, elevating it to an alliance, Kabuni said no PNG political party during the elections said anything about foreign affairs or military. He said Pangu Pati didn’t even have a policy document. Kabuni said when you look, Australia’s defence-related papers of which the most recent is the strategic defence review 2023, China is the reason there are security concerns. “Why would you need 10,000 additional soldiers? It’s been sold to PNG as an employment opportunity. It does not need a treaty to get that amount to serve the Australian Defence Force,” he asked. “That’s not the only way of getting jobs in Australia. “It’s not the strongest argument put forward.”

Title: Fijians donate cash, food to FemiliPNG to mark Fiji Day
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has become “a land of opportunity” for many Fijians who are business owners, aviators and professionals in their own fields, according to Fiji High Commissioner to PNG Jackson Evans. “Today, Papua New Guinea stands as the Pacific’s largest economy and for many, it has become a land of opportunity. Whether in business or community service, it is a privilege to live and work in a country with such potential,” he said. Fijians celebrated their country’s 55th independence anniversary on Friday, Oct 10. This year’s celebrations also marked 50 years of diplomatic relations with PNG and 150 years since the arrival of the first Fijian missionaries. As part of the Fiji Day celebrations, the Fijian community also made a donation to FemiliPNG on Friday. They ended the celebrations with a Fun Day and a dinner on Saturday. Evans paid tribute to the Fijian diaspora community comprising aviators, hoteliers, business owners, faith leaders, professionals, and families for their dedication and service to the people of PNG. “The theme for Fiji’s 55th year of independence is peace, unity and progress for all,” he said. “It is one that is especially meaningful because we also celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations between Fiji and PNG. And just as significantly, we commemorate 150 years since the first Fijian missionaries arrived in PNG, a lasting legacy of courage, compassion, and service. And what they began 150 years ago continues through you today. “Thank you for being proud Fijians. Thank you for keeping the flame of friendship burning strong between Fiji and Papua New Guinea.”

Title: New health board to set 50-year template
Content: THE new National Health Board must write the template for the health system in the next 50 years. This was the commitment and direction from incoming chairman Dr Mathias Sapuri as he was sworn in along with his board on Friday. “You and I may not be here in the next 50 years, but we will write the template for our children and our grandchildren and at the end every citizen in this country must have access to better healthcare,” he said. Sapuri told the board that they should hold the provincial health authorities accountable, look at how to improve human resource in the sector, and put in place a new system to deliver medicine and address the medicine shortage issues. Twenty new board members were sworn in on Friday in Port Moresby to serve for three years. Sapuri, who is Pacific International Hospital chief consulting obstetrician and gynaecologist, was named the chairman. Health Minister Elias Kapavore while acknowledging the outgoing board for their dedication, effort and leadership which saw many important policies were endorsed, said the board stood as the highest administrative, governance and policy oversight body in the health sector. “The board plays a central role in shaping the direction of our health system ensuring that every decision taken at the national level contributes to better health outcomes for our people and their functions and powers are derived from the National Health Administration Act 1997,” Kapavore said. He said the chairman of the board was appointed by the members themselves and was appointed by National Executive Council. Kapavore said apart from two advisers from the Health Department to provide technical and policy advise, there were members of the board from other sectors. “This diverse composition reflects our shared belief that health is everyone’s business and each of you bring valuable experience, collective expertise and influence from their respective sectors, and to strengthen transparency and accountability,” he said.

Title: PNG has much to learn from Malaysia, says minister
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has much to learn from Malaysia’s development over the last 50 years to become one of the leading economies in the world, Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko says. “Malaysia and Papua New Guinea may be two different countries in terms of language and development but we share a similar history,” he said. “In fact, both our countries share the same birthdate. “It is a privilege to congratulate the government and people of Malaysia on a belated Malaysia Day, when a unified Malaysia was born on Sept 16, 1963. “The merging of different cultures, religions, languages and territories under one unified country is a tremendous challenge, yet a significant challenge indeed. “Your transformation since 1963 in economic, technical innovations and sustainable development sectors has demonstrated a unified resilience, persistence purpose and great vigour on both the government and the Malaysian people. “The transformative growth and achievement of unity throughout the years indicates a strong sense of patriotism and resilience of Malaysians.” Tkatchenko made these remarks at a dinner function to commemorate Malaysia Day and the 50th anniversary of Malaysia-PNG bilateral relations held at The Stanley Hotel & Suites in Port Moresby on Friday. He commended Malaysia for its continued support over the years, adding that the country stands as the second largest investor in Papua New Guinea. “Our bilateral relations have been friendly and productive as we continue to strengthen existing areas of partnership,” he said. “Despite the hesitation of others, Malaysian investors continue to invest and thrive in PNG, indicating the ongoing trust in PNG’s economy and our enduring close partnership. “The many Malaysian investments in the country have provided employment and improved the socio-economic welfare of ordinary Papua New Guineans and contributing to the country’s economy. “In that regard, Papua New Guinea values its relationship with Malaysia and will continue to work together in pursuing similar goals of common interests.” Malaysian High Commissioner Hamizan Hashim said his country would continue to support Papua New Guinea into the future, adding that more local businesses needed to look to Malaysia as a viable market. “PNG has an integral part to play in the region and we are committed to working more with PNG as we celebrate our past and look ahead to the next set of challenges in the future,” he said.

Title: Davis to lead police internal affairs
Content: CHIEF Supt Steven Harris from Australia was sworn in over the weekend as executive director of Internal Affairs Directorate (IAD), tasked to investigate and prosecute misconduct within the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary. Police Commissioner David Manning said Harris will have a programme to investigate allegations of corruption and ill-discipline that would include the increase in mandatory alcohol and drug testing. “Chief Supt Harris has more than two decades’ experience in leading positions in policing and public service across Australian jurisdictions, and is now a sworn officer within the ranks of the RPNGC,” he said. “He has led specialist investigations and compliance enforcement in Australia and overseas including the Solomon Islands, as well as a strong background in local policing.” Manning said Harris engaged with international partners to arrange the supply of alcohol and drug testing equipment. “The use of alcohol and drugs is a threat to professional policing, and Harris is tasked with ensuring such unprofessional and dangerous conduct has no place in our Police Force,” he added. “The more police that are detected and dismissed for drugs and alcohol, the greater the public confidence in Police Force.” He said the IAD is hard at work and deploying new means to detect drugs and alcohol and take disciplinary action. Manning said the recruitment of police personnel from overseas jurisdictions has been well received by the police they serve alongside and the broader public. “Our Commonwealth police officers have sworn an oath to protect and serve the people of PNG, they serve under and are accountable to the laws of PNG.” “There is an appreciation within the ranks of hardworking police and in the community that these Commonwealth Police are unbiased professionals,” he said. He said that while almost all of them had served in PNG during their careers, they had no clan or provincial connections that could be seen to compromise their objectivity.

Title: Chimbu attack on worker irks PPL boss
Content: A PNG Power worker fell unconscious after he was stoned in the head by two assailants in Kundiawa, Chimbu, on Thursday night. The man, named by PNG Power chief executive officer Paul Baly as Lenny Igondo, was transferred from the company’s Goroka office to assist with power restoration efforts in Kundiawa when the attack occurred. Baly condemned the attack on Igondo, and urged locals and police to work together to ensure the safety of all personnel involved in power restoration efforts. “The attack occurred around 10pm while Igondo, a Power Station operator from the Goroka centre, was on duty in Kundiawa assisting with power restoration efforts,” Baly said in a statement on Friday. Baly said two suspects hit Igondo on the head with stones, causing him to fall unconscious. The suspects immediately fled the scene, Baly said. “Igondo was in Kundiawa to help generate electricity at the emergency shutdown station,” he said. “His work had been crucial: he assisted in generating temporary power to light up Kundiawa since Thursday. “This temporary measure was put in place while the team waited for the transformer team to install transmission for the burned parts that caused the initial power failure. Baly said the Kundiawa Power Station has been without power since Sept 28, when a fire occurred, destroying vital equipment for generating electricity.

Title: Workshop addresses workers compensation system
