Content: THE Office of Workers’ Compensation (OWC) held a workshop in Port Moresby on Wednesday to raise awareness and inform stakeholders in the workers’ compensation system of their rights and obligations. OWC chief commissioner Martin Pala said the workshop focused on informing all stakeholders as to the roles and functions of his office, a statutory body established under the Workers Compensation Act 1978. He said the OWC’s roles and responsibilities were to: “The workshop is part of OWC’s compliance and enforcement strategy to educate stakeholders and strengthen trust in the system, improve efficiency, and deliver fair compensation,” Pala said. “Workers’ compensation is a form of social protection, and when it works well, it safeguards livelihoods and ensures just outcomes. “When a worker is injured at work, the law requires the employer to compensate the worker. “This programme reminds employers of their legal duty to maintain workers’ compensation insurance with a licensed insurer, ensuring coverage for all employees.”

Title: Gordon Police Barracks receives facelift
Content: ONE of the oldest police barracks in the National Capital District is receiving some much needed attention. Police commissioner David Manning and Australia’s deputy high commissioner Adrian Lochrin last week opened new accommodation at the Gordon Police Barracks that provides modern, professional and secure living space for 48 male and 16 female officers serving the National Capital District (NCD) command. Manning welcomed the delivery of new accommodation for personnel last week. The accommodation, built in partnership with the PNG-Australia Policing Partnership (PNGAPP), adds to an ongoing constabulary’s programme to improve and expand police housing, particularly as the number of police continues to increase. “Our work together, between Papua New Guinea and Australia, is delivering considerable infrastructure investments that are making a real difference across the country. As well as the outstanding new facility at Gordon, we have refurbished police stations and accommodation across the Highlands, New Guinea Islands, and the NCD,” Manning said. He said these critical projects are ensuring that police officers who diligently serve their communities are rewarded with modern and comfortable housing. Manning said professional and diligent members living in police accommodation have the support of the police executive, but residents must also care for and respect their homes. “Show respect and pride in your allocated accommodation, because how you live reflects how you work,” he said. “The Royal PNG Constabulary executive, with the support of Government and partners, are working to ensure that you have better accommodation, modern conditions in which to work and cars and other equipment that is fit for purpose.” He thanked the PNGAPP and the Australian government for the continuing partnership in delivering the newly constructed barracks in Gordon. “I look forward to phase two of the infrastructure programme under our partnership, which will deliver new police housing around the country,” Manning said. “This will further strengthen our frontline presence and support our officers and their families.”

Title: Students warned against misbehaving after completing exams
Content: STUDENTS in Madang have been warned by police not to misbehave after their final national examinations as police will not hesitate to arrest them. Madang police commander Acting Superintendent Robert Baim said all students after their final exams are not to cause any inconvenience as police will be on the lookout. “If police catch any student misbehaving, we will deal with them and they will not be allowed on police bail, but will have to appear in court,” Baim said. He said parents and guardians of students in grades eight, 10 and 12 have to talk to their children and ensure they do not get involved in unlawful acts. In the past, it has been experienced that when students complete their final exams, they go out with their friends and get drunk and do unlawful things. Baim said students after completing their final exams have to act responsibly and celebrate peacefully at their homes while under the watch of their parents and guardians. “This is not the end,” Baim added. “It is just the ending of one chapter of your education and the beginning of another so to get involved in taking alcohol is still not the right thing to do at this stage.” “You are not celebrating a situation where you graduated with a paper that will earn you a job tomorrow, you’ve still got a long way to go.” Baim said the end of exams is the time of planning your next move the coming year and beyond. Do not join groups and start destroying public properties in towns, schools or anywhere else. He urged the public to help police in reporting any incidents of students taking alcohol and destroying properties, and to stop students from doing such as this is not tolerated by police in Madang.

Title: Lae to start work on market
Content: THE construction of the Lae Main Market will start in two weeks, and the public is advised that this will affect bus stops in some locations there, say police. Acting Lae metropolitan commander and operations superintendent Chief Inspector James Luan said public motor vehicle (PMV) drivers and operators and the public are advised to use allocated bus stops either at the temporary market downtown, at Seeto Kui, or at the roundabout near Zenera Supermarket. “PMV drivers and operators, the public is advised that after two weeks from now, the bus stops at the main market area will not be in use anymore,” Luan said. He said all city route PMVs from the Miles area, Kamkumung, West Taraka, Unitech gate, Igam, Bumayong, Back road and Malahang as well as Bumbu Market and China Town will now drop off and pick up passengers at the downtown temporary market. Luan gave this notice two week in advance as awareness to the public as well as PMV drivers and crew. He said PMVs coming in from Markham, Erap, Boana, Nadzab Bulolo and Wau, Mimeng and Markham Bridge, will now pick up and drop off passengers at Kisere Street, Seeto Kui Limited front-side road. “Those PMVs operating on the route from Situm, Wara Market and other areas, they will still use the same place you are using now.” Luan said by this week, police will carry out awareness on this to make sure all are well informed of the changes that have to be implemented. He announced that when the construction begins, the lane of the road to the main market side from Zenera Supermarket roundabout to Bank South Pacific Financial Group Limited market branch will be closed permanently to make way for the construction. “This means that we will have one way in and out, and the companies using this road only will have access to this one-lane road,” Luan said. He estimated that the construction of the main market may take 12 months so it is advisable for people to adhere to this notice and follow it well to avoid inconvenience.

Title: Event raises K163,000 to support health, education
Content: THE return of the Island Petroleum Charity Colour Run to Lae raised K163,000 to support key health and education services in the city. Held under the theme ‘We Are One’, Islands Petroleum general manager Shehab Das said the event brought together more than 2,500 participants and marked Lae’s first involvement in the national initiative after a six-year break. The amount raised in Lae is part of a nationwide total of K503,000, with events also held in Port Moresby and Kokopo. Organisers have confirmed that next year the event will expand to Madang, Kimbe, Kavieng, and Alotau. In Lae, the K163,000 will be split equally between Milford Haven Primary School and Milford Haven Medical Clinic, with each receiving K81,960 to improve facilities and services. At Milford Haven Primary School, the funds will be used to buy classroom furniture, desktop computers, Tuffa water tanks, and sports equipment. The Milford Haven Clinic will benefit from new diagnostic tools, including a haemoglobin analyser, paediatric equipment, medical furniture, and essential medicines. Nationwide, the event raised K503,000, with distributions from Port Moresby (K174,000), Kokopo (K165,000) and Lae (K163, 000). The initiative was made possible through the support of sponsors, including gold sponsor Mobil Oil, which contributed K50,000. Organisers also acknowledged the dedication of teachers and health workers, who continue to serve under challenging conditions. Following this year’s success, the Island Petroleum Charity Colour Run will return next year with expanded coverage, including new locations across the country.

Title: Alliance launches strategy to address climate change
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Environment Alliance (PNGEA) launched a new strategy, Strategy 2025-2027, to address climate change issues through dialogue with NGOs, civil society, and government agencies. The initiative is part of a memorandum of understanding with the European Union’s FCCB-funded programme, implemented by Expertise France. PNGEA coordinator Pamela Avusi said this strategy strengthens PNGEA and civil society organisations as key partners in advancing inclusive climate action, ensuring PNG communities are heard globally, including at Cop30. The EU-FCCB is the largest environmental programme in the Pacific Islands and aims to improve conversations around climate change while developing livelihood options for locals. PNGEA, an umbrella organisation for 12 environmental NGOs and civil society groups, provides a platform for coordinated advocacy to protect PNG’s biodiversity and promote sustainable development. The strategy outlines five strategic goals: The strategy will also address climate finance, traditional and indigenous rights, and local adaptation strategies. Expertise France project manager Alaric Vandenberghe stressed the importance of involving local communities and indigenous peoples in climate conversations.

Title: BSP investing K2.5 million in 50 community projects
Content: BANK South Pacific Financial Group Limited (BSP) is investing K2.5 million in 50 community projects, each worth K50,000, through its ‘50for50-Giving Back Campaign’, says chairman Robert Bradshaw. Bradshaw, speaking at the launch of a BSP-funded water supply project in Nagamizuha, Kama, Goroka, reaffirmed BSP’s commitment to addressing community needs and building a healthier future for PNG. Group chief executive officer (CEO) Mark Robinson said the project would touch every aspect of life in the village. “This water supply will serve families, children, elders, and even livestock, it restores dignity, improves health, and supports daily living in ways that goes beyond words,” Robinson said. “More importantly, it empowers the community to take ownership and sustain this resource for generations to come.” Robinson added that through BSP’s community project initiative, Goroka branch staff members worked closely with Nagamizuha community members to restore this vital service. The water supply has brought much needed relief especially during this time of dry season as a life-changing initiative for the people of Nagamizuha. Nagamizuha is home to about 2,000 residents serving 1,920 family heads who rely on containers, rain water tanks and streams. Nagamizuha leader Hennol Omenefa thanked BSP for providing a water supply, which is one of the greatest needs of the people. He said they need clean water for drinking, cooking, washing and sanitation. Their struggle for water is now solved by BSP.

Title: Wenge laid to rest: ends illustrious career in public service
Content: LATE Morobe Governor Luther Wenge was finally laid to rest on Friday at his Baindoang village in Nabak LLG, Nawaeb, closing the curtains on an illustrious career of serving Papua New Guineans. His tomb stands in the center of the village, next to his grandmother Migere’s grave. At about 10:30am, his casket was lowered by the bearer party from the Igam Engineering Battalion. The tomb was covered with silver white and copper drapes, adorned with laces of the country’s national colours. Flowers and wreaths were placed around his casket in the tomb floor, with a white veil with a red cross spread over the casket. As Baindoang villagers wept openly for their son, who spent his life serving Morobe and Papua New Guinea as a lawyer, judge and politician, his family stood around the tomb wishing their final goodbyes. Son Mathew, wearing black clothing and a pig task necklace around his neck, held up a PNG flag over his father’s casket one last time. Present to witness the burial was deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso. As the villagers sang mourning songs from Nawaeb, three concrete slabs were pulled over the tomb, closing any last glimpse of the late leader’s casket. Wenge died at the Port Moresby General Hospital on Sept 13 after succumbing to an illness. He was flown to Lae on Oct 3, where the National Parliament handed over his body to the provincial government. Wenge’s casket was flown to all districts of Morobe, allowing his people to mourn and pay their final respects. Following a public funeral on Wednesday, he was flown to Baindoang on Thursday and Rosso, representing the state, handed his body over to his family. Wenge’s casket overnighted with his villagers and was finally laid to rest on Friday.

Title: Mainstream media newsrooms are ‘embrasing digital transformation’
Content: MEDIA representatives yesterday told the permanent parliamentary committee on communication inquiry that mainstream media newsrooms were adapting to changes and embracing digital transformation. The National’s Editor-in-Chief Christine Pakakota said that the local media landscape had changed significantly, while embracing the traditional platforms such as newspapers, radio and television, and moving online too. “We started with just the newspaper, then moved to a website, and last year we launched our Facebook page. We’re adapting to change,” she said. But Pakakota noted that the transition had not been easy. She said that the newsroom had to hire not only journalism graduates but also people from other professional backgrounds because there was a need for that. “We recruit people who studied law, for example, because they make good court reporters,” she said. “We just train them to write in simple English for everyone to understand.” Pakakota added that the newsroom operated under the company’s code of conduct and the Media Council’s Code of Ethics, which guided daily operations. Reflecting on her 26 years in the industry, she said that one major issue was the safety of journalists. “Reporters often face threats, dismissals, or lawsuits for their work. Sometimes they are pressured to stop critical reporting,” she said. Pakakota added thatThe Nationaltook such matters seriously. “We report threats to police and relevant authorities. If complaints come from a government department, we deal directly with the head of that department or file a formal report,” she said. Meanwhile, Pakakota welcomed the ongoing collaboration between the parliamentary committee on communications and the Department of Information and Communication Technology (DICT) on the development of the Right to Information policy. “For the 26 years I’ve been in the industry, I’ve seen a lot of challenges and changes that have come about and one of them is the legal and regulatory risk,” she said. “I’m happy to hear that the committee is now working with the DICT and pressing on them the policy of right to information. “That is a policy that will help all media houses put together news for public consumption.”

Title: Council proposes to separate freedom of expression and media freedom
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Media Council has proposed that Freedom of Expression under Section 46 of the Constitution be separated from media freedom so that newsrooms can be independent. Council president Neville Choi said Section 46 which covered freedom of expression was the only place in the Constitution where the media was recognised. “But the freedom of expression doesn’t really protect media freedom. And so what the council is proposing is to (separate) media freedom from freedom of expression (Section 46),” he said. Choi was explaining to permanent parliamentary committee on communication chairman Marsh Narewec how to protect the newsrooms and avoid outside interference and influences. “It is bigger task than within the organisation because if we just focus on the internal mechanisms of every organisation, it still leaves the organisation open to political influences and stress, not the whole organisation but the heads and senior management of the organisation,” he said. “For instance, it can be someone in government not happy with what TV Wan news reports and calling up the heads of TV Wan and threaten them to remove their broadcast licence, if they do not remove the news report or continue reporting the issue.” Choi said that this sort of pressure affected corporate management and newsroom management. “The person who is supposed to be buffering the newsroom and the news team from all these pressure is the editorial news manager,” he said. “If he or she is not on the job or not strong enough, then the editor fails and news report become bias or taken down.” Choi said that media freedom should be protected because it was an essential pillar of democracy.

Title: PNG Power boss lays out 15-year plan to turn electricity supplier around
Content: PNG Power Limited chief executive officer Paul Bayly says that there is a 15-year plan to turn the State-owned electricity supplier around. He told the Petroleum and Energy Conference at The Stanley Hotel & Suites in Port Moresby that they had a lot to do under the plan on networking, revenue enhancement, cost control, managing costs, cash management, people management, improving balance sheet and working with the Independent Power Producers (IPPs). “We are currently working on re-commissioning the Rouna 1 and 2, and we are looking at upgrading our main transmission lines to increase reliability of supply,” he said. “In terms of system reliability, we have to improve revenue that will turn around our plans into profitability and increase cash flow.” He added that PNG Power was slowly improving its reliability performance as it works with IPPs to share the load. Every day, they are switching from their base load to high diesel supply to keep power supply going. State Enterprises Minister William Duma said that the Government had increased funding for PNG Power to maintain and upgrade infrastructure. National Energy Authority managing director Ronald Meketa said that the least expensive power source was solar which cost K3 million per megawatt. For hydro-power, it is between K7 million and K9 million. For geothermal, it is K10 million to K15 million per mw. He added that the IPP was buying at international price, hence the high cost. “It is something the Government should be addressing to improve power supply.”

Title: Prepare to adapt to energy technology, says minister
Content: THE country’s petroleum and energy agencies and stakeholders have been advised to prepare to adapt to the fast-advancing technology in the energy sector, so that it becomes a strong energy hub in the region. Energy Minister Peter Isoaimo issued the advice to stakeholders at the Petroleum and Energy Conference at The Stanley Hotel & Suites in Port Moresby. Isoaimo said the landscape of energy systems would change in 50 years and the world would not look the same. “Africa and the Pacific, including PNG, would rise as energy exporters, not of minerals but of clean power. “So how do we use our wealth beneath our soil to power a cleaner, more secure and more inclusive future above it?” Isoaimo said that the country’s oil and gas revenues should take the nation towards rural electrification, research and development, renewable infrastructure and knowledge creation. “We must also invest in science, in innovation, in Stem (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathemetics) and in our children’s future, not just in projects,” he said. “We must also confront the uncomfortable truths like: will our land still belong to our people in 50 years, will our children inherit opportunity or dependency and will they sell their birthrights out of desperation because we left them unprepared?” Isoaimo said the energy sector must become more diverse, resilient and aligned with global clean energy markets. “Natural gas would remain vital for now to stabilse the economy but the renewables will be our long-term foundation,” he said. He expressed concern that the country may not be ready in time to benefit wisely when energy becomes the new gold in the future. He said he was anxious of foreigners taking control of the country’s energy sector. “Vision of the energy sector for 2075 must be clear that every household must have access to affordable, reliable and sustainable energy, powered by renewable resources of the land and the intellect of PNG,” he said.

Title: Duma blames past governments for ignoring PNG Power
Content: STATE Enterprises Minister William Duma has blamed the failure of many past governments to help PNG Power Limited fund the upgrade of generators and transmission lines for the power supply issues faced today. Duma stated that the Government now had electricity generation as a central policy. It began with increasing funding for PNG Power to maintain and upgrade infrastructure, improving working conditions for staff and improving supply for a growing population. He said that it had not been easy. “The Government has approved a PNG Power stabilisation plan (which) includes measures to enhance revenue and prevent electricity theft, reduce costs as this relates to diesel fuel generators, to (have) better management and restoring and modernising infrastructure,” he said. “We have millions more people using electricity and wanting to be connected. Our Government has set a goal to achieve 70 percent electrification for our people by 2030, with universal access by 2050. “The profit margin for PNG Power before tax has improved and our chief executive officer Paul Bayly has been leading the way to maintain this strength. “But we have to be honest and up-front with our people and businesses who consume power and other stakeholders including potential investors, that we have a lot of work ahead.” He said that the challenge was that every day many parts of the country including Port Moresby faced load-shedding which was not ideal. Duma added that it was the right time to begin the transition of PNG Power Limited from being an SOE to a viable private sector commercial business.

Title: Australian Defence force to start recruiting PNG citizens
Content: Australian and Papua New Guinea soldiers will start working together on a recruitment pathway to enable Papua New Guineans to join the Australian Defence Force (ADF). “Developing a recruitment pathway from Papua New Guinea into the Australian Defence Force is a historic step – reflecting our shared history and commitment to enhance integration between our two countries,” Australia Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles said in a statement yesterday. “I look forward to working with my good friend and counterpart Minister Billy Joseph, to develop a taskforce that will see this come to fruition. “Since the beginning of this process in January, we have now seen a transformation in our defence relationship through the signing of the Pukpuk Treaty, which is reflected in what we are doing in terms of recruitment, our exercises and our operations together,” Marles said. As an essential part of this, both countries will establish a bilateral Australia-PNG recruitment taskforce to oversee the development of that pathway, according to the Australian High Commission. The recruitment taskforce will be led by Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles and Defence Minister Billy Joseph and made up of officials from both countries with the first meeting to take place before the end of this year. Among its key focus points, the taskforce will establish a methodical and considered process to identify eligible Papua New Guinean citizens to join the ADF. The taskforce will also focus on providing opportunities to PNG’s youth, while maintaining the integrity of ADF recruitment standards and continuing to help support growth of the PNGDF as an independent sovereign force. Australia and PNG will work in partnership to develop a sustainable pathway for PNG citizens to enlist in the ADF.  This initiative will take time to develop and refine, however both Australia and PNG are committed to its success. This builds on the announcement that eligible permanent residents living in Australia who are also Papua New Guinea citizens can apply to join the ADF from Jan 1, next year.

Title: Wenge’s body flown to his village
Content: MOROBE Governor Luther Wenge’s body was handed to his family by the State in Baindoang, Ward 4 of the Nabak local level government yesterday afternoon by Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso. At about 10.30am, the helicopter carrier was given a ceremonial wash down at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Outdoor Stadium before it lifted off and people waved and weeped openly. It made two brief stops – at Samanzing and then Kasanombe – before arriving at Baindoang at around 11am at the temporary helipad built by the villagers. Hundreds more people waited there to receive him. They were covered in mud and ash, hands on their head, wailing, some throwing flowers on his casket as it was carried into the main arena set up by pall bearers. The mourning house set up near the tomb was decorated in Morobe provincial colours of yellow, blue and green. Students from Migere Wenge Primary School, which the late governor had founded and named after his mother, led the flag-raising ceremony to open the brief programme. Among those accompanying Rosso to handover the body was Police Minister and Bougainville MP Peter Tsiamalili Jnr, vice-minister planning and Komo-Hulia MP from Hela Daniel Tindipu, Sam Basil Jnr (vice minister mining and Bulolo MP), and Pangu Party executives. Rosso shared condolences of the Governor-General, Prime Minister and the people of PNG and Morobe with the people of Nabak and Baindoang. “It is sad that we meet under such circumstances,” Rosso said as he thanked the family for Wenge’s life. “He committed his life to the country and the people and put you all last; I see how you are and the heart is heavy, I apologise for this. “But maybe, him choosing Baindoang is his final gift to you, his people, so that the government will make a road here.” Rosso assured Baindoang that a road will be budgeted for and constructed to open up access into this remote area. He also committed to assisting Migere Wenge Primary School, while announcing Hela’s K1 million commitment to upgrading Kasanobe Primary School as a “thank you” to the late governor for his input in the formation of Hela as a separate province. “Wenge was born in the village but was educated and became a smart lawyer, smart magistrate, smart judge and a very strong governor, a national leader – he represented you well,” Rosso said. “I encourage you children of Baindoang and Nabak to follow his footsteps.” Rosso thanked his son Matthew Wenge and brother Kennedy Wenge for working with him and the provincialhaus kraicommittee and provincial administration to ensuring a smooth event, funeral and handover of the body. “Only the highest respect was accorded and I thank everyone who made it possible in your own way,” he said. “I now, on behalf of the national and provincial government, the provincial executive council of Tutumang, the provincial administration and the people of Morobe, hand over the body of the late Akisawa Luther Wenge to you. “We have come a long way and this is where it ends; I will come back sometime to visit.” The family in Baindoang receiving body thanked Rosso and the government and rest of Papua New Guinea for all their input in bringing the son of Baindoang back home. Wenge’s body will remain with his family for a few days before he will be buried.
People: Daniel Tindipu, John Rosso, Kennedy Wenge, Luther Wenge, Sam Basil

Title: Respect for governor unite people
Content: THE death of Morobe Governor Luther Wenge united people whether they came from another village, district or province. It was clear, and theThe Nationalobserved this, that people and leaders paying respects and grieving together with the Wenge family remained there for some time. Nobody was in a hurry to leave. Hela, Enga, Eastern Highlands, Jiwaka, Western Highlands, Autonomous Region of Bougainville, Greater Sepik (East and West), Madang, New Ireland and other people as well as the business communities and families, poured into Lae because they all had their own stories to tell regarding their relationship with the late governor. If nothing else, the togetherness, speeches, stories and all else galvanised the man’s popularity. Some of the things he helped fight for were: Due to his vibrant leadership, people followed that voice and footsteps into the heart of Morobe where his casket was laid for final visits and respects. Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso highlighted that Morobe is a central province that connects every province, and the late Wenge always welcomed everyone to Morobe. “The provincialhauskraiunites the country and shows what kind of person he was,” Rosso said. “I now see how the late governor is uniting the country – let us follow his footsteps and legacy, so PNG can be a better place for all.” Many described the late Wenge as “a father figure, a man of friendship, peace, humility and fairness, a voice of justice and heart of compassion”. Prime Minister James Marape said the late Wenge was part of the foundational generation that birthed the country, where that generation was all about what they could do for the country.
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Ex-Telikom staff demand full entitlements be paid
Content: MORE than 200 former staff members of the State-owned Telecommunications company under a retirement exercise yesterday demanded they be paid their full entitlements immediately. In a gathering outside the Telikom Rumana office yesterday, they demanded answers from the management on their retrenchment status and based on what grounds. Former senior finance staff Mary Wak, who worked for 34 years, said it was injustice in the manner they were treated and the retrenchment, according to them, was carried out under the pretext of termination. “Staff were not notified prior to their exit and were only paid their recreational and fellow leave entitlements two days after being served their letters of retirement and retrenchment. This is a call for ex-gratia entitlements against the number of years we were in service,” she said. “There was no human resource consultation and no updates and no discussions on retirement or retrenchment. “During the 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations at Rumana on Sept 12, the chief executive officer publicly declared that funding had been approved to retire for “those above 60 years (old) and those aged 55 who wished to leave” and they would consider the first 100 staff. “Yet, just eight days later, more than 120 employees and including young staff aged 25 to 60 were forcefully terminated nationwide.” Wak said this “was not retirement but a coordinated purge”. In 2019, when bemobile to Telikom PNG merger was announced, the CEO confidently assured staff and the public that no employee would lose their job and that every worker’s position, dignity and entitlement would be protected under the new Telikom Limited. In 2021, the restructure took place and every employee was refitted into new roles. Telikom chief executive officer (CEO) Amos Tepi in a media conference with Kalang FM last week, said he had “done everything possible to accommodate all personnel”. A statement that did not go down well with the staff, now forcefully retrenched and retired. “The CEO’s statements on Kalang and EMTV are a fabrication, meant to sanitise injustice and he has failed in leadership, integrity and moral responsibility,” Wak said. “What should have been a process guided by consultation and compassion was instead executed with secrecy, arrogance and contempt. “The CEO boasted that we have a legal requirement to retire staff at 55, which is fine but where are the full entitlements? “Many long-serving employees with 30, 35 even 40 years of service were handed K50,000, K12,000, K5,000 or even as low as K2,000 and these are amounts that barely cover a few months of living expenses, let alone a lifetime of service. “These token payments represent only furlough and recreation leave, not full retirement benefits. “Therefore, this is not compliance, this is exploitation disguised as policy. “Telikom Limited and the chief executive officer Amos Tepi, general manager corporate services Poyep Kilepak and chief financial officer Esperenza Mendoza must come out and explain the real intent of the exercise and how the calculations were made,” she said. She said failure to address this, the issue will be brought to Labor before considering legal action on the management.

Title: ADF will conduct high altitude flying training in PNG
Content: AUSTRALIAN Defence Force (ADF) helicopters and personnel will be conducting training in and around high land areas of Central over the next few weeks. “The training, which involves four CH-47F Chinook helicopters from the Townsville-based 5th Aviation Regiment, will be conducted in throughout the day within the Owen-Stanley Ranges,” the Australian High Commission said in a statement yesterday. “Areas where the Chinooks will operate include the Waitape, Ononge and Tapini valleys, around Myola Lake, the Kokoda Gap and also in the vicinity of Kosipie Village. “Members of the public in those areas may notice the helicopters landing on high peaks or in open areas around isolated villages.” The high commission said the pilots and crew of these helicopters were training to qualify for high-density altitude flying, skills which would enable them to respond to humanitarian disasters. “The steep peaks and deep valleys of the Owen-Stanley Ranges offer opportunities for the pilots to test their skills at altitude that are not available in North Queensland,” it said. “At the completion of the high-density altitude training, ADF helicopters and personnel will travel north to take part in Exercise Wantok Warrior, an annual joint exercise conducted by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) and the ADF. “During this exercise in Lae, the helicopters will be used to carry PNGDF and ADF infantry soldiers conducting combined air assaults, as well as assist in transporting equipment and troop movements. “There is no live ammunition being used during the exercise and all aircraft activities are being conducted within strict safety and operational guidelines. “The flying activity schedule is subject to change, due to short notice cancellation, including for bad weather and other aviation considerations.” It said safety, noise management and the environment were vital considerations that went into the planning and conduct of the ADF flying activities.

Title: Civil registry says 3.8 million citizens registered so far
Content: ABOUT 3.8 million persons have been registered under the National Identification (NID) project since its inception 10 years ago, according to PNG Civil and Identity Registry. Acting registrar-general Salome Bogosia said the registry has processed about three million records, of which 2.8 million birth certificates and 1.3 million NID cards have been issued. “There have been many issues affecting the project over the years but we are working to resolve them going forward,” she said. “We face rugged terrain, poor Infrastructure, and severe weather delaying outreach and equipment delivery. “Community misinformation and low awareness hinder participation, while staffing shortages exacerbate the strain on peak campaigns. “Offline NID processing continues dally, but backlogs persist. “We are currently pursuing better technology alternatives to address some of the system technical challenges. “We are working through digitisation, automation, and enhanced data security to address some of these issues.” She said the registry plans to recruit more staff next year to help reduce the backlog of registrations that needed to be processed and the issuance of NID cards. “Since 2018, a new human resource strategy focused on recruiting new graduates with a minimum GPA of 2.6 through a resilience volunteer programme. “We are also promoting zero tolerance on a ‘no gift policy’ to manage the perception of bribery and corruption in all client interactions. “We are now currently focused on mobilising manpower to double the workforce from 500 to 1,000 to tackle the call by the Government to register 95 per cent of the country,” she said. Bogosia said the recently enacted Civil Identity Registry Act 2024 provided basis upon which the registry currently operates, adding that it was crucial to the reforms being undertaken to improve its roles and functions. “The Act mandates registration of births, deaths, marriages, adoptions, divorces, and legitimistion, Integrating NID with biometric verification and enabling data sharing. “It also reinforces governance with biometric verification and inter-agency data sharing with the Electoral Commission and National Statistical Office,” she said.

Title: Santos backs NID rollout with registration kits
Content: SANTOS has partnered with the PNG Civil and Identity Registry to provide 120 biometric mobile registration kits for the rollout of the National Identification (NID) programme throughout the country. Santos country chairman Leon Buskens said the kits, worth about K4.7 million, would help in their daily operations, especially to register persons living within certain project resource areas in the country for them to have better access to services. He said the presentation of the kits were based on a partnership agreement between Santos and the registry which started three years ago. “As we all know, there have been many challenges affecting the country for the last 50 years,” he said. “But here at Santos, we want to be part of the solution so we are pleased to be given this opportunity. “These kits will unlock efficiency and allow our people access to opportunities as it will give them true and legal identity. “It will also strengthen our operations so it’s a win-win for us. “PNG has oil, gas, and other resources so it is important that our people in those project areas are identified so they can have access to services.” Administrative Services Minister Richard Masere thanked Santos for its support, adding that the new kits would boost the PNG Civil and Identity Registry’s efforts to increase NID registration in the country. “These kits will allow for people who have long been excluded due to geographic and infrastructure barriers to be registered under the NID project,” he said. “For many of them, especially those in rural and remote regions, access to registration centres has been limited or non-existent. “This donation helps address those gaps and brings services directly to the people.” He said the kits were designed to be used in rural areas where much of the registration still needs to be done.

Title: Registration of all citizens essential, says Masere
Content: ADMINISTRATIVE Services Minister Richard Masere says the registration of all citizens under the National Identification (NID) project is essential for people to access basic services in the country. Masere said despite the negative attention drawn by the NID project over the years, its purpose remained to ensure that all citizens had access to a legal form of identity recognised by the State. He said the NID project, which ran as a standalone Government programme since 2014, was now given to the statutory body, PNG Civil and Identity Registry, to implement. The project, among its other functions, issues a card as the official document issued to Papua New Guinean citizens as proof of identity legislated by the Civil Identity Registry Act 2024. “Since its inception, the NID project was dogged by so much controversy with legacies that continue to overshadow the project, even with the new office of the PNG Civil and Identity Registry,” Masere said. “Despite early controversies with the project, its mission remains vital to providing people access to services like health and education. “The persistent challenges of underfunding, limited staffing and outdated infrastructure, have affected the implementation of the NID project over the years. “Now, the PNG Civil and Identity Registry continues to uphold its mandate: registering births, adoptions, marriages, divorces, and deaths, and issuing NID cards. “These cards, compulsory for all citizens aged 18 and above, are foundational to accessing essential services such as education, healthcare, travel, banking. employment and landowner royalties.” Masere said the NID project was an integral part of the Government’s agenda to provide legal identity for all, including using this data with other agencies to allow ease of services to the people. “In an era shaped by digital economies and data­driven governance, legal identity is more than a personal credential, he said.

Title: 200 PLWDs registered with organisation in Lae
Content: LAE Disability Voice of Hope Charity Incorporated has registered 200 persons living with disabilities (PLWDs) this year for its programmes. It is a community-based non-profit organisation that aims to improve the lives of PLWDs in Lae. Community engagement officer Elsie Ruru said the organisation had more than 10 groups that supported the programmne through providing shelter, essential and opportunities for PLWDs. “There is a total of 17 shelters that we support in Lae, Huon Gulf and Nawaeb,” she said. “The 17 shelters have volunteer caretakers who look after more than 200 PLWDs. Ruru said the organisation not only looked after PLWDs but ensured that caregivers were also well taken care of. “Many a times we focus on the PLWDs and forget about their caregivers who spend most of their time looking after them,” she said. “Our programmes are not only about providing essential items such as food and clothes but we also do house maintenance, medical care help, and social inclusion. “We have projects such as building a kitchen in Bumayong to provide a clean facility for preparing food, a chicken poultry project and sewing project for PLWDs to generate income for themselves.” Ruru said they were working with the Australian Awards to send those who had completed Grade 12 for further studies. “Since we are a non-profit organisation, we do need sponsorship and donations to continue our work, but we are still doing our research and community work in finding and registering PLWDs so that they can have equal access to all services,” she said. Ruru said they had a strong working community, with chairman Bill Hodges ensuring that the organisation – alongside donor partners – helped wherever it could. The organisation was initiated by the Hodges Family and formally established in 2023 as a separate legal entity of Soltra Builders.

Title: Nepo accused of contempt
Content: A CONTEMPT charge has been filed in the National Court against acting Correctional Services (CS) commissioner Bernard Nepo for non-compliance of a court order. David Suagu, deputy commissioner of operations, filed the originating summons 173 against Nepo on Sept 18. Suagu claims that pursuant to Order 14, Rule 42 (1) of the National Court Rules, Nepo be charged with contempt of court over the alleged wilful and unlawful persistent disobedience of the National Court orders of Aug 1. Judge Oagile Dingake made the orders in the proceedings OS JR 40 of 2025 between Suagu and Nepo and the State. A copy of the judgment was delivered to the parties. According to a court document, more than six weeks have passed since the making of the orders and it is alleged that no steps have been taken to comply with order No.6 made by the National Court, in particular to: The matter is pending before the court, and is awaiting a hearing date.

Title: Police say social media created more work for them
Content: USE of social media has created more challenges for police in their work, they say. Deputy Police Commissioner, administration, Dr Philip Mitna, said normally they followed their Occurrence Book (OB) and they knew there was a crime reported and then it was tasked to various investigators to proceed with the case. “With social media, it is quite a challenge, we sometimes have faceless and nameless people putting reports online and expecting us to do our work and that is a challenge of its own,” he said. Dr Mitna said this in response to a series of questions by West New Britain Governor Sasindran Muthuvel, who is member of Parliamentary Committee on Media, during the hearing in Port Moresby on Wednesday. Muthuvel asked: Dr Mitna, in response, said citizen journalism has serious challenges for them. “We’ve attempted and, in some instances, identified the complainants but almost 70 per cent of them do not come forward to give additional information,” he said. Dr Mitna explained that in order for cases to proceed to court they needed additional information and facts even if the police seephotos or clips of the crime committed. Meanwhile, Dr Mitna said the Cybercrime Unit at Seven-Mile in Port Moresby was functional and prosecuting cybercrimes He added that their work with Nicta and Department of Information and Communication Technology (Dict) was work in progress in terms of cyber space.

Title: Tomuriesa questions Pukpuk Defence treaty
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa says the Pukpuk Defence Treaty with Australia has raised questions on Papua New Guinea’s sovereignty, foreign and policy alignment and long-term national interest. He said the first core principles of the treaty undermined PNG’s sovereignty and territorial boundary. “If interpreted, it means if war was not meant for us, will become our wars and Australia’s enemies will become our enemies in the event of any invasion,” Tomuriesa said. “The treaty appears to conflict with PNG’s two long-standing foreign policies of being friends to all and enemy to none and the Look North Policy.” Tomuriesa said this could undermine diplomatic flexibility and reduce opportunities for cooperation with PNG’s key economic partners He said for a developing nation with an open foreign policy, this could jeopardise foreign investments, particularly with China and Japan, which played significant roles in PNG’s economic development. “Restricting military engagements with these nations may send unintended signals and risk destabilising the very investments that sustain our country,” Tomuriesa said. Tomuriesa added that the Government should focus on securing economic treaties and communique rather than securing military treaties. He questioned whether the treaty would benefit the nation or it was just another “boomerang” treaty, which would facilitate only Australia’s security interest. Tomuriesa said one hurdle remained for the treaty and that would involve the Parliament to debate and vote when Parliament resumed on Oct 28. He urged all MPs to critically evaluate and vote for the interest of PNG to safeguard its sovereignty, national interest, and maintaining stronger ties with the country’s bilateral partners.

Title: Tsiamalili defends Pukpuk Treaty
Content: Autonomous Region of Bougainville Regional Member and Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr says the Pukpuk Treaty establishes a comprehensive framework for collaboration across land, sea, air, cyber and space domains anchored on mutual respect for sovereignty, peace and constitutional integrity. “The treaty reaffirms both nations’ commitment to peace, sovereignty and mutual security, and establishes a comprehensive framework for collaboration across all operational domains,” Tsiamalili said. He said the treaty upheld Papua New Guinea’s sovereignty, and ensured that all defence cooperation activities remained subject to PNG’s laws and oversight, strengthening the country’s ability to respond to external threats without compromising internal governance. “This is a partnership of equals. It strengthens PNG’s ability to respond to external threats without compromising our internal governance or political arrangements,” he said. Tsiamalili said while the treaty’s focus was on national defence, it offered indirect but meaningful benefits for Bougainville and its youths. He said the agreement unlocked pathways for Bougainville school-leavers to access professional development, technical training, and employment opportunities. “Like the seasonal worker arrangements, this treaty provides young Papua New Guineans and Bougainvilleans access to critical training that builds capacity, resilience and long-term cooperation.” Tsiamalili added that the treaty respected the Bougainville Peace Agreement and the ongoing post-referendum dialogue, adding that any activities under the treaty within Bougainville would require consultation with the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG). “The treaty respects the Bougainville Peace Agreement and the constitutional framework guiding our peace process,” he said. “Any engagement in Bougainville under the treaty would require full consultation with the ABG, consistent with existing protocols,” he said. Tsiamalili said this was not just an agreement but a platform for trust, development and shared responsibility in a changing region. He said it would build on decades of collaboration, and reflected the enduring friendship between both nations.

Title: New Porgera manager wants Enga government to protect mine’s interest
Content: ENGA needs to protect the New Porgera Limited (NPL) because the provincial government holds 15 per cent equity, says NPL country manager Karo Maha. Maha was speaking on the operations of NPL, in spite of the many challenges it faced, including law and order issues, in a summit in Wabag on Oct 2 aimed at finding a way forward. Maha, in acknowledging the partnership between NPL and the provincial government, said NPL started its operations last year and did not declare any profit, but made a tax contribution of K155 million. This year, from its first half of operations, NPL paid K500 million in taxes, and declared US$230 million (about K959.8 million)  in dividends, she said, adding that five per cent of the amount went to the provincial government. But NPL could be making more money and producing more gold if it had operated from a stable and safe working environment, Maha said. She said NPL continued to face stoppages that resulted in a day’s loss of K300 million in revenue from disturbances caused by illegal miners inside the pit. “We have highlighted to the prime minister, police minister, and mining minister, for the State to intervene. The State is primarily responsible for law and order,” Maha said. “The illegal miners are of threat to our workforce and assets. “Our workers continue to be robbed and harassed inside the open pit. “They are slashed and stoned, equipment burnt when we clear the illegal miners out in the open pit. “All of these add to the mounting expenses of the company, and impact our profit.” Maha said the chief inspector of mines could close down the operations if the issue on illegal mining was not addressed by the State. She said 129,979 trespassers in the open pit had been recorded from January to last month. Maha said employees were being robbed and security personnel shot at by illegal miners. She said Porgera required sufficient security manpower. Maha said through consultations with the Government, NPL had proposed a new tax credit scheme where three to four per cent of accessible tax income be made available to law and order programmes, investing in police and Correctional Services infrastructures. She said NPL, under a temporary arrangement, is taking in a district court magistrate to hear cases. “It is not an easy fix, and it involves a lot of things, but we all need to work together with the landowners to make Porgera safe,” Maha said. “One of the things we have done in our commercial agreement, is to put up US$15 million (about K62.74 million) for Porgera landowners, on the condition that we have a safe and exclusive environment of our tenements. “In other words, no illegal miners, no trespassers.” Maha said the thing that NPL would like to see happening quickly was that through the community development agreement (CDA), to be negotiated, underlined and signed, so benefits could flow to the people on the ground. Prime Minister James Marape said the CDA would be signed off by the end of this month. NPL has approved its national content plan, Maha said. She said the content plan would cover business development and employment. Maha said the plan would be launched before the end of the year. It was made known in the summit that illegal miners were from other districts, and persons with influence sponsored the activity.

Title: Marape describes Japan as a sincere and genuine friend
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has described Japan as a “sincere and genuine” friend for its five decades of continued support to Papua New Guinea. “A friendship built through infrastructure development forged forward from the battles fields of World War Two (WW2) and a gateway into the future,” he said. Japan’s consistent help to the country, under the Official Development Assistance (Oda), exceeds 50 years, with its golden celebrations in October last year. Under the Oda, Japan has contributed immensely to PNG in terms of social, infrastructure, health, education and economic development. It has over the years pumped in more than K6 million to aid development projects under Japan International Corporation Agency (Jica). In October 2023, a new international airport near Lae was opened. It was renamed Nadzab Tomodachi International Airport. The name was proposed by Marape to honour the history between PNG and Japan. This project was part of Jica’s long-term infrastructure support. It was a loan project that supported the construction of a new passenger terminal, upgrade of new runways, construction of taxiways, and renovation of the control and fire towers. At the opening ceremony, Japanese dignitaries, including then foreign affairs minister Horii Iwao, and local leaders attended the opening. PNG shares a historical connection with Japan where in 1943, during WW2, it was the sight for fierce battles where more than 150,000 Japanese imperial Japanese soldiers lost their lives in what was known as the “place of no return” for Japanese troops in New Guinea. Imperial Japan had established bases in places such as Rabaul, Buna and Lae but in 1943, the allied forces launched an airborne operation on Nadzab, quickly capturing the airfield and turning the tide of war. The airfield became a strategic base for allied counter-attacks, known as the “Northern Australian Defence Zone Air Base (Nadzab)”. Once a place of conflict between Japan and allied forces, Nadzab now stands as a symbol of peace and friendship. The airport, named “Tomodachi”, which means “friend” in Japanese, serves as a powerful reminder of hope. Marape said: “Jica has supported airport development throughput PNG, including the Jackson International Airport in Port Moresby and Tokua Airport in East New Britain. “Strengthening airport infrastructure and improving maintenance capacity not only supports economic growth and regional development but enhances to disasters and climate change by servicing as crucial logistics hubs during emergencies. Airport infrastructure plays a strategic role in deepening bilateral trust and partnership, facilitating the entry of Japanese investors and supporting stable energy supplies to Japan. “PNG, rich in natural resources, is a crucial partner for Japan, in terms of economic security. “Imports from PNG account for about 97 per cent of Japan’s total imports from Pacific Island nations. “PNG exports liquefied natural gas, crude oil, copper, nickel, timber, marine products, palm oil and more to Japan.” Marape said PNG was expected to achieve significant growth in the near future. But challenges in economic infrastructure still existed, including airport infrastructure, and continued cooperation was essential for a sustainable development of PNG, he said. The great east Japan earthquake in 2011 was testament to PNG being a true friend, when voluntary fundraising and charity events were held across PNG. A total of K10 million (about ¥320 million), including a government contribution, was donated to Japan. Marape’s words at the beginning reflected the appreciation towards Japan’s long-standing support, even before PNG’s independence in 1975. “In this 80th year since the end of WW2, with the remains of Japanese soldiers still resting in PNG soil, we hope we carry forward what our predecessors have built and continue being a genuine friend,” Marape said.

Title: Safe houses face severe challenges
Content: SAFE houses in Papua New Guinea face severe challenges which include underfunding and acute staff shortages, according to a survey. The safe house 2024 baseline report stated that a major challenge in 51 operating safe houses in 17 provinces was sustainability in terms of funding and management of the safe houses. It said in recent years, cases of gender-based violence (GBV) had increased at an alarming rate, making the cases one of the highest in the world. According to a National Statistics Office (NSO)’s demographic and health survey (2016-2018), 84 per cent of women aged 15 to 49 had experienced some form of physical and sexual violence since the age of 15. A recent family support baseline assessment conducted in nine provinces, including the main centres of Lae (Morobe), Goroka (Eastern Highlands), Mount Hagen (Western Highlands) and National Capital District (NCD), had received more than 177 service users. This had since increased to more than 200, by which a majority of them were adult and child females with a few male service users. The report said as alarming as it seemed, these statistics were but a proportion of the reality and did not encompass the other service providers also supporting GBV and family sexual violence (FSV) survivors. In PNG, the first safe house to be established is Haus Ruth, considered the oldest in the country. It first opened in 2003, and after that many other organisations and groups had opened safe houses to address the rising need in the community. It was noted that most of the safe houses and accommodation were operated and managed by either a faith based organisation (FBO), a church, a non-government organisation or were simply self-funded and self-run. That meant they were individual entities with their own policies, rules, processes, structures and operations independent from the Government and to some degree, different from each other. The report said it was crucial at this time to have government intervention for the long term functionality of safe houses. Youth, Religion and Community Development Minister Jason Peter said the NSO’s demographic and health survey  (2016-2018) wasa critical step forward in addressing the need for safe, secure and accessible shelters for those who were most vulnerable in the communities. Peter said as minister, he would ensure adequate resources were committed to conditions and setting standards for safe houses in Papua New Guinea.

Title: Sinai opposes liability in use of vehicles, properties
Content: Electoral commissioner Simon Sinai says the Electoral Commission (EC) will not be held vicariously liable for any vehicle, property, or asset used in connection with electoral process without the prior written approval from the EC. Sinai, in a statement on Wednesday, said the written approval should come from him or the deputy commissioner and directors. “Any individual or organisation that chooses to deploy vehicles or other services for electoral related purposes without formal authorisation does so at their own risk and expenses,” he said. “The commission will not assume responsibility for any claims, damages, losses or liabilities arising from theunauthorised use of such assets. “This clarification is issued to ensure transparency, accountability, and proper adherence to approved procedures during electoral purposes and other related purposes.” Sinai said this advice was to ultimately avoid unnecessary liabilities against the State.

Title: Rosso: Let Wenge’s story inspire younger generations
Content: LET the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge’s story be an inspiration to the younger generations, says Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso. Rosso made this remark as he told the story of the late governor, who left his remote village of Baindoang, in the hinterlands of Morobe where there is no proper airstrip and road access. “The late governor’s parents were missionaries, and he used to follow his parents around until they resided at Hobu village, also in Nawaeb,” he said. “Despite the remoteness of his village, he searched for education, following his missionary parents to Hobu to pursue education.” Rosso told the public that through his determination, perseverance and dedication, the late Wenge became a lawyer and climbed the leader to being a magistrate and later an acting judge. The late Wenge then joined politics in 1997, where he became the governor of Morobe and represented the province for four terms. “He is a great orator, a great statesmen and a firm defender of the constitution,” Rosso said. He said that the late Wenge’s story, which led him to become a well-known person, portrayed that despite coming from remote areas, one can be successful through dedication and perseverance. “It is a lesson he had shown,” Rosso said. “All it takes is commitment, perseverance and good choice in life.” After leaving his village in search education and pursuing his dreams, the late Wenge had made a final wish on his sick bed to be laid to rest where he first walked. “We were advised by his son, Mathew Wenge, that the late governor wished to be buried at his grandmother’s village (Baindoang),” Rosso said. “That place has no road access, and it was his will for us to complete the road construction he had started to connect his people with government services. “We will make sure some of his visions become reality.”

Title: Chief secretary wants updates from department’s policy officers
Content: CHIEF secretary to Government Ivan Pomaleu has directed policy officers from the Department of Prime Minister and the National Executive Council to provide information on the progress of key sectors under policy wing one and policy wing two of the department. This comes as a result of complacency in work performance and tardy delays in providing feedback, Pomaleu said. He made these remarks during his address to the department’s policy officers in Port Moresby on Sept 29. “Let me first preface my remarks by reflecting on the last four years so that you are aware of the background that I come from,” he said. “So the last four years now, I have been quite observant of the amount of work that we are doing as a department.” Earlier this year, Prime Minister James Marape summoned various agencies, including the department, for their failure to provide timely information and progress updates for each sector. Marape had expressed his dissatisfaction with the level of support the department was delivering to his office, the Government, and its established agenda and priorities for key sectors. Pomaleu said: “It was clear to me that he was dissatisfied with the level of support that the department is providing to his office, to the government, to the agenda that is established by the Government in terms of priorities, the sectors that we should be pushing and engaged in.” Pomaleu said the system of government was such that if you did some reflection, you would find that policies were generally the same. He said the emphasis in terms of priority might differ depending on which government was in office. Pomaleu said these government intentions were significant and primarily conveyed through public announcements by the prime minister or relevant cabinet ministers. “So what we find is that a lot of what the Government intends to do in the time of office is dictated by the different public pronouncements that the prime minister and minister of state do from time to time, the different press and different parliamentary statements that come,” he said. He said Marape was disappointed to note that the department lacked agility in responding to these government expectations and provide feedback on time. Pomaleu said some pronouncements made by Marape in 2019 had yet to be acted upon, thus raising questions about the department’s role as the agency responsible for implementing the prime minister’s intentions.

Title: ABG members to be sworn in today
Content: THE inauguration of the fifth Bougainville House of Representatives is scheduled to be held in Buka today. According to a notice by the Autonomous Bougainville Government, all elected members in the recently-concluded general election will be sworn into office to take the 45 seats for the 38 single-member constituencies, plus three regional seats for women and ex-combatants, and the presidential seat. The Bougainville constitution recognises the House of Representatives (parliament) as the region’s legislative arm of the government which has 45 seats. Previously, there were 40 seats but the Bougainville parliament approved another five last year to accommodate the new single-member constituencies. Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika is expected to preside over the swearing-in ceremony, followed by the election of the new Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Bougainville parliament. Prime Minister James Marape and Bougainville President Ishmael Toroama are scheduled to give their keynote addresses at the event. Meanwhile, Toroama had announced the caretaker Bougainville Executive Council (BEC), following the swearing-in ceremony presided by resident judge Justice Peter Toliken in Buka on Monday. The caretaker BEC comprises Toroama, Tonsu member Ezekiel Masatt as vice president, and Atolls member Amanda Masono. Toroama said the occasion was an important step in Bougainville’s democratic process, signifying a time of transition, continuity and renewed commitment to serving the people. “During this caretaker period, our priority is to safeguard good governance and maintain the trust and confidence of our people,” he said.

Title: 6.6 earthquake causes chaos at Wenge’s funeral
Content: IT was a chaotic scene for some attending thehauskraiof the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge when the 6.6 magnitude earthquake struck near Lae on Tuesday night. The Nationalwas at the Sir Igantius Kilage Indoor Stadium when it hit just past 9pm. The Hela provincial group had concluded their speeches and the late Governor Wenge’s casket was about to be taken back to the funeral home. People were slowly filing out of the stadium when the earthquake struck. It shook everything strong and hard. Ceiling lights swung violently, chairs and decorations were thrown about. A panic-stricken crowd scrambled to safety, pushing through doors and windows to get outside. Thankfully, the threat of a possible tsunami was ruled out by the Department of Mineral Policy and Geohazard Management. Calm and order was restored in coastal communities of Morobe and nearby provinces later. The Nationalreached out for a comment from the Morobe disaster office. It is yet to release the initial report of the earthquakes impact. There was not much damage reported, with only a few traditional huts collapsing, and power outages in certain areas in Lae. PNG DataCo also reported a network outage affecting Momase, Highlands, and New Guinea Islands following the earthquake. A statement said: “Preliminary investigations suggest possible multiple submarine cable breaks. DataCo’s technical teams are currently assessing the extent of the damage and working to restore connectivity. “As a result, internet and data connectivity into these regions may be limited or unavailable today.” The University of Technology’s seismic station at the School of Applied Physics recorded the earthquake at 9.06pm, with a 6.6 magnitude occurring at a depth of 99km near Gabensis and Wampit. Tremors were felt as far as Southern Highlands and the New Guinea Islands.

Title: WNB House rental arrears clears on Thursday: Penias
Content: FINANCE Secretary Samuel Penias says that rental arrears for Government agencies occupying the West New Britain (WNB) House in Port Moresby will be paid today. He toldThe Nationalyesterday that paperwork had been done and sent to the Bank of Papua New Guinea under the Kina Automated Transfer system (KATS) for clearance. It should be cleared today. The media was notified though a notice from the Solicitor-General’s office of an indefinite closure after civil servants were turned away at the gate on Monday. The WNB government in a notice advised that the unpaid rentals amounting to more than K30 million had severely impacted cash flow, making it increasingly difficult to sustain services for the tenants’ benefit. The property continued to incur significant monthly costs to maintain services at WNB Haus, including cleaning, security, generator refuelling and servicing, and lift maintenance. The managing agent, Realtor, was asked to issue a 14-day lockout notice. And unless the arrears are settled by Oct 6, access to WNB Haus will be locked from Oct 7. The premises are still closed. The closure was effected by firstly stopping the refuelling of the generator. The 10-floor building that holds office spaces and amenities is an investment under the WNB government for the people of WNB. The Realtor agency was engaged by the provincial government prior to it being opened. A guarantee letter from the Government, on June 3, undertook to pay K3 million per month towards the settlement of arrears dating back to 2022, including the reimbursement of fuel bought for the generators.

Title: Late Wenge ‘refused’ treatment overseas
Content: THE late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge chose to be treated at the Port Moresby General Hospital instead of in Australia because of his confidence in “our doctors”, Lae MP John Rosso said. “The Prime Minister James Marape, the Morobe administration and Angau Memorial General Hospital chief executive officer Dr Kipas Binga called him to airlift him to seek medical treatment in Australia. But he refused,” he said. “He requested to be treated at the Pom Gen trusting and having faith in our doctors. “Therefore, we respected his decision.” Rosso, also the Deputy Prime Minister, was responding to public query on why Wenge was not assisted to seek medical treatment overseas. “The late Wenge chose to be treated at our (own) hospital and died at our hospital,” he said. Rosso added that the late Wenge had always held Papua New Guinea and Morobe close to his heart, and fought for what he believed was right and according to the constitution. “He was without doubt one of the most legal, intelligent and outspoken leaders our country has known,” he said. “He championed education, infrastructure and empowering people. “He was a fearless governor, who didn’t care about anyone as long as he believed in the rule of law – fairness, equality and justice for every citizen despite their background. “He was a humble, kind and generous person, never forgot his roots in Samanzing, and always gave back to his community. “Wenge lived in the settlement until he died.”
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Rosso reveals Wenge’s projects were commissioned during casket tour
Content: SOME of the projects the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge were to commission were done during his casket’s tour of districts, an official says. Deputy Prime Minister, Lae MP and chief mourner John Rosso said this during his funeral service. “Some of the projects he delivered to the districts were not properly commissioned before he passed away, hence people were waiting for him to personally attend and commission them,” he said. “The late governor had set dates to visit each of the projects in the districts to commission them, but his sudden death has left those projects uncommissioned. “And during these past few days of visits made to the districts, some of the projects were opened, and he even used them where his casket was laid for final respects.” Some of those projects were: “In a way, he was commissioning those projects during his visit in a casket,” Rosso said. “You will not know a person until he/she dies. “In these past four days, I’ve observed the sorrow people showed, and I noticed how people hold Wenge close to their hearts. “When we are alive, we are not aware and recognised of the work we deliver, but when we die, things we do are being told and people are aware. “And that was our late Governor, Luther Wenge, who is popular in the remote places of Morobe.” Rosso further shared that the people of Siassi were waiting for him to attend the upcoming ELCPNG synod in 2026, following the presentation of K2 million he made. “In Markham, he and the Markham MP Koni Iguan had planned to build a stadium, and the people of Markham had agreed to name the field after him to honour his commitment and leadership,” he said.
People: John Rosso, Koni Iguan, Luther Wenge

Title: Chairman Narewec stresses need for partication in ‘last’ inquiry
Content: THE Parliamentary Committee on Communications started its two-day inquiry into the standard and integrity of journalism and the media industry in Port Moresby yesterday. Committee chairman and Wau-Waria MP Marsh Narewec said this would be the final inquiry conducted after it started last year and continued with regional consultations earlier this year. Representatives from the Office of Censorship, Department of Information and Communications Technology, National Information and Communications Technology Authority, National Broadcasting Corporation and the Royal PNG Constabulary were present before the committee during yesterday’s hearing. “The committee is conducting its final inquiry so we have called on relevant authorities today (yesterday) to ask questions that were raised during our regional consultations,” Narewec said. “We will be following up on the questions they raised, including what we asked of you all in our previous inquiry last year to see if any of the recommendations the committee made have been implemented. “This enquiry is important as it will help us to finalise our report to present to Parliament.” Meanwhile, the committee held a workshop on Tuesday with journalists, civil society organisations, government representatives, academics and stakeholders. The committee’s terms of reference are on the: Today’s session will be attended by representatives of the mainstream media, including those from other relevant sectors and social media influencers.

Title: Nicta eyes 5G technology to improve internet
Content: THE National Information and Communications Technology Authority (Nicta) plans to improve network connectivity in the country through the use of 5G technology by next year. Nicta chief executive officer Kila Gulo-Vui said this would enhance internet and mobile services for users, starting in urban areas and then into rural communities. He made these remarks during the Parliamentary Committee on Communications inquiry in Port Moresby yesterday. Committee chairman and Wau-Waria MP Marsh Narewec asked Gulo-Vui whether or not Nicta had plans to roll out 5G technology in the country as internet and communication services continued to be issues. Narewec said every citizen had a right to access information under Section 51 of the Constitution, adding that the 5G technology could help with faster connectivity to access services and information online. “Much of the things we do nowadays relies on the internet and network connections, especially in this time of digital transformation,” he said. “Even the people in the rural areas are using smartphones and we cannot underestimate them. “They are using it for communication and business so they must be able to have access to these services if we provide it for them. “When will Nicta, as the regulator of ICT services, focus on 5G services to help our people? “We need to ensure that this service is provided so our people do not miss out.” In response, Gulo-Vui said: “We have plans for the 5G rollout but currently Nicta is working to plan the radio spectrum, which is basically the airwaves that the signals go through. “This is part of the 5G planning and the spectrum is all set as it was announced by acting ICT Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr.

Title: Act under review, says censor
Content: AN act for classification guidelines for digital contents on social media in Papua New Guinea is under review, says an official. Chief Censor Jim Abani said Censorship Act 1989 was developed when there was no internet and social media platforms and it is 33 years in existence now. “With the advancement of technology, the office identified the issues, and the act is now under final review with the Office of Public Solicitor,” he said. Abani was responding to question raised by Permanent Parliamentary Committee on media chairman Marsh Narewec, about what classification guidelines are for the Office of Censorship updating for digital content for social media content that promotes negativity and harmful contents like videos promoting violence during the committee hearing in Port Moresby yesterday. Abani said they had developed a classification guideline on online content that is something that they had to wait until the act was passed. “But we don’t have to wait for the act to be passed. We are now implementing that in terms of the classification guidelines that have been developed for online content,” he said.

Title: Women researchers to attend training
Content: A CAPACITY building and networking programme for women researchers will be held in Lae in November, supported by the Australian government. It follows on from a successful programme conducted in Port Moresby in June that attracted 41 participants. The Australian Asia Pacific Economy Cooperation (Apec) Study Centre at Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology University, Melbourne, in collaboration with the Papua New Guinea-Australia Partnership, is delivering the three-year capacity building programme to enhance the research skills of women in PNG’s agricultural and economic research sectors. These women researchers completed the initial five-day workshop in Port Moresby. The training covered research methodology, data analysis and management, report writing, leadership, teamwork in research, data-driven decision-making, and policy assessment. Anna Kapil participated in the Port Moresby workshop. Kapil is a lecturer of economics at the School of Business and Public Policy, University of PNG, and recently completed her Master of International and Development Economics at the Australian National University. Reflecting on the workshop, Kapil said: “I think it’s a really good programme focusing on the need for research skills, particularly among early-career researchers.
