The group included researchers from public, private and research institutions and several universities. “This diversity highlights the range of challenges and capacities, so it was good that the workshop started with foundational concepts.”

Title: Ambulance recruits visit fire station, gain experience
Content: THE National Ambulance Education College recruits gained first-hand experience with the Papua New Guinea Fire Service during an educational visit to the Waigani Fire Station in Port Moresby on Monday. In a statement, St John Ambulance national education commander Alexander Dimain said the training programme combined classroom learning with hands-on experience, including managing medical, trauma, and psychological emergencies. “Recruits have parade drills, boot camp-style training, and fitness activities to instil discipline, teamwork, and the endurance required for the challenging role of an ambulance officer,” he said. “Additionally, they will complete an advanced safe driving course for emergency responders to ensure they can respond safely to emergencies under varied and often challenging conditions.” Dimain said the visit played an important role in building inter-agency collaboration. “The ambulance service works closely with the Fire Service during emergencies,” he said. “Through such interactions, recruits gain practical insight into the realities of emergency response, improving collaboration and preparedness in real-world scenarios.” The visit provided the recruits with an understanding of the Fire Service’s daily operations, including station routines, crew readiness, rescue techniques, and incident command procedures. It also highlighted the vital teamwork and coordination required across emergency services to ensure safe and effective responses for communities across PNG. The 24 recruits are in the seventh week of a rigorous 12-week Ambulance Officer Level One Course at the college in Baruni, Port Moresby. Since starting training in August, the group has been immersed in both theoretical and practical learning experiences designed to prepare them for the demanding responsibilities of ambulance work.

Title: Appointment of permanent secretary for health crucial
Content: HEALTH Minister Elias Kapavore says the immediate appointment of a permanent secretary for the department is of critical importance. He said the appointment process that should have taken three months has extended beyond 12 months. Ken Wai took over as acting secretary from secretary Dr Osborne Liko in May. “The public service appointment process needs serious reset to expedite with speed and efficiency,” Kapavore said yesterday. “We have multiple health programmes involving many development partners, and hence, we must reciprocate their commitment with trust by having a permanent health secretary. “The first shortlisted candidates failed endorsement by the National Executive Council (NEC) due to integrity of the selection process from the Personnel Management Department and the Public Services Commission. “Based on this failed process, Vanguard International HR selection process was preferred,” Kapavore added. “I, as the portfolio minister, will insist on an independent and expert assessment on the applicants and present the outcome for NEC’s appointment. “Continuing unnecessary delay on this matter is taking a toll on many health interventional programmes. “I can conclude that my first 12 months in the department could be better as I need a smart, strategic, and conceptual administrator.” Meanwhile, Wai is still acting secretary for the department until a permanent appointment is made.

Title: Madang hospital gets two tanks worth K297,000
Content: PATIENTS seeking treatment at the Madang Provincial Hospital will no longer be turned away due to shortage of water, thanks to the provincial government. According to a statement from Madang Governor Ramsey Pariwa’s office this week, two new Southern Cross tanks were bought with Provincial Services Improvement Programme funding at a cost of K297,200. The 120,000-litre tanks are expected to be installed soon. A spokesperson from the governor’s office and project officer, Stanley Soma, said: “We’ve seen our people being turned away from treatment because of the water shortage issues at Modilon. “Now that the tanks have arrived, we will let the provincial health authority do the installation.”

Title: Marape thanks Morobe for producing leaders with national interest at heart
Content: Prime Minister James Marape has thanked Morobe for producing great leaders such as the late Governor Luther Wenge, who contributed immensely to the development of Papua New Guinea. Marape said Wenge was part of the foundational generation that birthed the country. “The Wenge generation was all about what they can do for the country and not what the country can do for you,” Marape said. “For him, PNG came first, Morobe came second and his family came last.” Marape said the Government would complete the Baindoang road project which Wenge initiated, this time under the Connect PNG, connecting Lae to Finschhafen. “To his family, I leave with you Matthew 5:8 – blessed are the mourners, for they will be comforted; may today be an expression of comfort to you,” he said. Marape said Wenge’s legacy would continue. “The relocation of Tutumang and the Provincial capital to Nadzab, Wafi-Golpu, education scholarship and the assistance to pastors are some of the notable work he started, including other projects in the innermost parts of Morobe,” he said The state funeral was held at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium in Lae. His casket would be taken to his residence at Busu mountain for a few hours and brought to the funeral home. On Thursday, the casket would be airlifted to Baindoang village in Nabak LLG, Nawaeb.

Title: Wenge’s casket to be airlifted to grandmother’s village on Thursday
Content: late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge’s casket will be flown to Baindoang village in Nabak LLG, Nawaeb on Thursday, provincial administrator Max Brutan says. Brutan said Wenge’s tomb was 90 per cent complete. Wenge’s son, Matthew, said it was the governor’s wish to be buried at his grandmother’s village – a place so remote, that it could only be accessed by air. Sources on ground in Baindoang said over 400 people across the Nabak LLG and visitors have already gathered at the village. Extended family members in Lae, along with students from the University of Technology, have trekked to Baindoang and are expected to arrive tonight and tomorrow morning. The state funeral at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium has been delayed for about three hours on Wednesday, awaiting the arrival of the Governor General Sir Bob Dadae from Port Moresby. Late Wenge’s family, members of Parliament and Government ministers waited patiently along with mourners, for the funeral programme which was scheduled to start at 9am. Prime Minister James Marape arrived around 11:40am Hundreds of mourners have braved Morobe’s scorching heat to wait for the state funeral.
People: Bob Dadae, James Marape, Luther Wenge

Title: Bougainville enters next phase
Content: BOUGAINVILLE President Ishmael Toroama has announced a caretaker Bougainville Executive Council (BEC), following the swearing-in ceremony presided over by resident judge Justice Peter Toliken in Buka on Monday. The caretaker BEC comprises Toroama, Tonsu member Ezekiel Masatt as vice-president, and Atolls member Amanda Masono. Toroama said the occasion was an important step in Bougainville’s democratic process, signifying a time of transition, continuity and renewed commitment to serve Bougainville. “During this caretaker period, our priority is to safeguard good governance and maintain the trust and confidence of our people,” he said. He acknowledged that Bougainvilleans have spoken through the ballots in this year’s election, but expressed concern over the conduct of some losing candidates, stating that their actions undermine Bougainville’s democratic values. “It is disappointing that several losing candidates have chosen to express their dissatisfaction in premature and disorderly ways. “Such conduct mocks the democratic values enshrined in the Bougainville Constitution and insults the people of Bougainville, who have spoken with unity and purpose through the ballot box. “The people have made their choice when they elected leaders whom they trust to guide Bougainville through the next phase of our political journey, particularly toward our aspiration for independence. We must honour and uphold that choice with dignity and respect.” He reminded all leaders that leadership is about service and accountability, not personal ambition.

Title: State describes Sonk’s case as ‘abuse of process’
Content: A COURT yesterday was told that the case filed by sidelined Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) director Wapu Sonk was an abuse of process as he had filed similar applications previously. National Court judge Susan Purdon-Sully heard the application filed by Prime Minister James Marape and the State to dismiss the case filed by Sonk challenging his suspension as KPHL director by Marape. The State argued that Sonk had filed five other proceedings prior to the judicial review application before the court, seeking similar relief. It submitted that Sonk, Peterson Pipi, and Dr Bernard Yaru had all filed cases to challenge Marape’s decision. Sonk’s lawyer argued that the proceedings filed were triggered by different circumstances. He said that Yaru’s case never involved Sonk, and they never disposed any cause of action. He submitted that Sonk was named a party in a proceeding by Pipi to challenge Marape’s decision while he was still in office. The court heard that when that matter came before a court for an urgent hearing of the application on Sept 12, the court was granted leave that it be withdrawn as the State was not named as a party. Sonk’s lawyer said that following this proceeding, his client was served the notice of suspension on Sept 19, hence this proceeding. He said Sonk only filed three proceedings. The others claimed by the State did not involve him. The court heard the parties’ submissions and later continued to hear Sonk’s leave application. The matter returns today at 9am.

Title: Return of writs conclude ABG elections
Content: WRITS for the 2025 Autonomous Region of Bougainville general election were returned to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Simon Pentanu, in Buka on Monday. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai returned the 45 writs for the presidency, 38 single-member constituencies and the six reserved regional seats for women and former combatants, in accordance with Section 145 of the Bougainville Elections Act, to mark the end of the election. “With the election now concluded, it is important that all candidates respect the results, uphold democratic principles, and work constructively within Bougainville’s institutions,” he said. “Yes, there were challenges as there were in all large-scale operations. But wherever issues arose, we responded swiftly, within the law, and always in the best interest of the people. “Our systems of verification, oversight, and accountability were tested and they held firm. This election matters not just for today but for our future. “As Bougainville enters the next phase of its political journey, this result affirms the strength of our democratic institutions, and the readiness of our people to lead their own destiny, peacefully and with pride.” Tsianai said the election saw 408 candidates contest the 45 seats, seven of whom were in the race for presidency. “We recorded a total of 408 candidates, including a growing and welcome number of women candidates. 21 women contested constituency seats, up from 14 in 2020. “The final electoral roll included 238,625 registered voters which is the most inclusive and comprehensive roll in our history. “To administer this election, we recruited and trained over 3,000 staff, and deployed across 544 polling teams. “Every ballot was counted, checked, and verified in the presence of scrutineers and observers. “Our counting process was open, transparent, and lawful, ensuring that the final results reflect the will of the people.” Tsianai said post-election reviews would be held to improve certain issues that affected this year’s electoral processes.

Title: Preparing to bid Wenge a final farewell
Content: THE Sir Ignatius Kilage (outdoor) stadium is expected to be filled to capacity today as Members of Parliament and the public pay their last respect to the late Morobe Governor, Luther Wenge. The provincial hauskrai facilitator, Bami Sorekicne, stated that the stadium was prepared yesterday to host the mass funeral service. The late Wenge’s casket arrived in Lae, last Friday, at around 4pm in a long convoy of vehicles into the city. A large crowd who walked in front of the vehicle that carried the casket. It is anticipated that a large crowd will be attending the funeral service to show their respect to one of the province’s more vibrant and vocal leaders. The late governor’s casket made a four-day visit to the nine districts (Menyamya, Bulolo, Huon-Gulf, Tewae-Siassi, Finschhafen, Kabwum, Wau-Waria, Markham and Nawaeb) districts from Saturday to yesterday. Lae, the 10th district, will host the funeral mass which will be attended by the Prime Minister, James Marape, Governor-General Grand Chief Sir Bob Dadae, the 21 governors, and Morobe MPs with their people. Sorekicne added that Marape arrived in Lae yesterday afternoon, and stayed at the provincial hauskrai with the people of Morobe. The late governor’s casket, after visiting Markham and Nawaeb, returned to the indoor stadium to overnight there. Sorekicne said that today, the Defense Force bearer party would carry the casket out of the indoor stadium to the outdoor stadium, for the mass funeral service. “The casket will be brought to where the catafalque is, and they will place it there, and the programme will start,” he stated. Based on the visitations made during these past days, not only will the people of Lae and Morobe pay their last respects but people from all over Papua New Guinea will be attending the mass funeral service.
People: Bob Dadae, James Marape, Luther Wenge

Title: Police report increase in motor accidents despite awareness
Content: AT least five road accidents were reported in the National Capital District over the weekend. Police say awareness raised over causes of accidents seem to have been falling on deaf ears as accidents have increased. National Capital District Metropolitan Supt Warrick Simatab in an interview before the lead-up to independence celebrations last month said the police focus of awareness was on armed hold ups and road accidents. “Drivers have to be reminded that they are not the only ones who use the road. You have other road users, passengers and people who walk along the footpaths,” he said. “Officers were tasked to take care of roundabouts and traffic lights that are closest to their police stations.” According to police reports one of the accidents that happened over the weekend occurred at Bomana before the National Centre of Excellence. The other occurred on Friday around 5am at Wild Life. Both drivers were escorted to the Boroko Traffic office to be questioned. Police have been advocating safe driving during rainy season and officers were sent to certain traffic lights to manage the traffic. In July more than 50 road accidents were reported in the command – all related to speeding. The latest incidents are under investigation.

Title: Council: Two thirds of alluvial gold stolen
Content: A LACK of enforcement to protect Papua New Guinea’s alluvial mining sector has led to an increase in the amount of gold smuggled out of the country, according to the Artisanal Gold Council. So much so that upwards of two thirds of PNG’s alluvial gold is smuggled out with little to no capacity to check it, the council’s founder told the Special Parliamentary Committee on Public Sector Reform. The Artisanal Gold Council is an international organisation founded by Dr Kevin Telmer in 2008 to understand and improve the artisanal and small-scale gold mining sector globally, including Papua New Guinea. Telmer, who presented his findings about the country’s alluvial gold mining sector to the Special Parliamentary Committee on Public Sector Reform in Port Moresby last Monday, said gold smuggling was evident but enforcement to stop it was limited. “PNG’s alluvial gold sector is a perfect engine for upward mobility,” he said. “It is a natural, decentralised system that puts wealth directly into the pockets of your rural people, allowing them to educate their children, build businesses and move toward a better life. “It is a resource that is currently being stolen on a massive, industrial scale, and this theft is destroying the capacity of the sector to empower your citizens. “The data we have compiled leaves no room for doubt:  PNG’s gold sector is facing a crisis driven by sophisticated illegal actors. “Our comparison of PNG’s official exports with international import records shows the stark reality: in both 2021 and 2022, over two-thirds of PNG’s alluvial gold was smuggled out of the country.” Telmer said a lack of enforcement to curb gold smuggling not only affected people’s lives, but also undermines PNG’s standing with international organisations like the Financial Action Task Force. “Most tragically, smuggling is destroying the livelihood of tens of thousands of honest citizens. Legal and illegal gold flows cannot co-exist,” he said. “The illegal actors – who pay no export levy, no corporate tax, no income tax and ignore foreign exchange controls – have drastically lower operating costs. “This commercial advantage forces legal, law-abiding gold buyers out of business, systematically replacing them with an entirely black-market economy. “When the legal market collapses, other aspects of society break down. “The systems and laws to fix this problem are largely in place. “What is required now is political leadership and decisive enforcement.”

Title: Gold worth K1.3 billion drained yearly, says report
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has lost about K1.3 billion worth of gold smuggled out of the country annually, according to the Special Parliamentary Committee on Public Sector Reform. Committee chairman and Northern Governor Gary Juffa said this in a supplementary statement to clarify the estimated financial losses attributed to the illegal export of alluvial gold, as detailed in the committee’s preliminary findings released last Wednesday. “While our preliminary statement estimated the annual loss to be between K300 million and K500 million, new information from experts in the alluvial gold mining business indicates the figure is significantly higher,” he said. “According to these experts, Papua New Guinea is losing approximately K1.3 billion annually due to gold smuggling. “This revised figure is staggering and reinforces the extreme urgency of the situation. “The theft from our nation is far greater than first assessed, making the immediate implementation of our proposed three-phase action plan absolutely critical to stopping this catastrophic economic drain.” Juffa said the committee stands by all other findings and recommendations outlined in its initial statement and reiterates its call for decisive action to reclaim this vital national revenue. He said the committee recommended the immediate adoption of the following:

Title: Papa Max David is Brahman’s living legend
Content: THE Brahman community in Madang recently gathered in a celebration to mark the 93rd birthday of revered lay missionary and educator Sir Max David. The occasion brought together generations of St Michael’s High School alumni, now known as St Michael’s Secondary School, to honour the man whose decades of dedication has shaped lives and communities across PNG. Representing more than 300 former students, Jeffery Vaki, president of the Ex-Brahman Students Association, spoke during the birthday gift presentation to “Papa Max” or “Wawi”, as he is affectionately called by the community, expressing the bond that has kept the alumni connected over the past 35 to 40 years. “For me, it’s been 35 years since I last set foot back in Brahman,” he said. “Yet, here we are, still driven by the values we learnt at this school. “Brahman moulded and shaped us into strong, self-reliant individuals with a robust work ethic, spiritual fortitude, physical strength and mental intelligence.” Vaki credited the pioneering teachers, including Papa Max, John Yama, John Kari and former agriculture teacher and current head teacher John Paul Malangen, for introducing the self-help agriculture concept that instilled resilience, initiative and problem-solving skills among students. The impact of St Michael’s, Vaki noted, extends far beyond Brahman and the bordering rivers of Whege, Imbrum, Tauya and Ramu. Alumni have become leaders’ chief executives, MPs and professionals contributing both nationally and internationally. “These achievements stand as a testament to the strong foundation laid by the school’s values-based education,” Vaki said. He praised Sir Max’s over-70 years of service to Brahman. “Sir Max’s work was never about recognition or personal gain,” he said. “He was driven by compassion, faith and a deep sense of responsibility to serve others. “His legacy is not just in the buildings he constructed or the projects he initiated, but in the countless lives he touched and the community he helped flourish.” To honour this legacy, the alumni presented “Papa Max” with K10,000 towards the continuation of his philanthropic work in education and community service.

Title: Ipatas wants Austalian Federal Police brought to Enga
Content: ENGA Governor Sir Peter Ipatas has raised a lack of police efficiency in enforcing the rule of law in the country, resulting in the breakdown of law and order. The governor was speaking on the topic in the provincial law and order summit held in Wabag last week to find strategies to address tribal fights and lawlessness in the province. Sir Peter said the biggest challenge the country faced was law and order, yet leaders in parliament did not seem serious about addressing it. He said in Enga, there were challenges with tribal fights which cannot be addressed in isolation but at the national level. He asked Prime Minister James Marape, who was in the province on Friday to officiate the Enga Day celebrations, that four Australian Federal Police officers be brought to Enga to boost police capacity. The request was agreed to by Marape in the presence of Police Minister Peter Tsiamalili. While on tribal fights, Sir Peter said guns used in tribal fights and the sponsors were known to communities, but they could not rely on police because they did not have trust and confidence in them. The Government must strengthen its institutions like the police, Correctional Services, PNG Defence Force and the judiciary to stabilise law and order, he said. “We cannot address law and order in a vacuum,” he said. “The courts, police, Correctional Services and other systems of government must function to contain law and order issues.” Sir Peter said he had been vocal on law and order issues in parliament for more than 10 years, but received little attention. “Community leaders and churches can work at their levels, but if the systems of government are not functioning, howfar can you go?” he said. Sir Peter said there was total disrespect by law enforcement agencies, as they were allegedly involved in gun dealings, escorting warlords with guns and cash, and even involving themselves in the illegal gold mining in Porgera. He said at this time, police had not made a single arrest involving people in tribal fights in Kompiam or Wapenamanda, and reports on deaths during tribal fighting had not ceased.
People: James Marape, Peter Ipatas, Sir Peter Ipatas

Title: 200 reservists to boost police in ENB
Content: MORE than 200 trainees who have attended the police reservists training in East New Britain were urged to remain focused and disciplined to complete their training successfully and serve their communities with pride. This call was issued by the ENB Police Commander Chief Insp Felix Nebanat during the launch of the training programme last Friday. Nebanat said that the 200 new reservists will add much needed manpower to support police work throughout ENB. The training programme is currently in its sixth week with several more weeks remaining before the official pass-out ceremony later this month. New Guinea Islands Divisional Command Commander, Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP) Naua Vanuawaru reminded the recruits to uphold discipline, honesty and respect in their duties. “You will pass out as policemen and policewomen. Your role is similar to that of regular officers, so respect the uniform and perform your duties with integrity,” said Vanuawaru. ACP further thanked the ENB Provincial Government and Administration for their continuous support in ensuring the success of the programme. Meanwhile, ENB deputy administrator in charge of the District and Local Level Government (LLG) Services Danley Puapena assured that ENBPG will continue to give support for the initiative. ENB Government is here to assist with infrastructure, allowances, uniforms and other requirements during and after training,” said Puapena. He also noted that ENB currently has about 240 regular police officers serving a population of more than 400,000 people and the inclusion of the reservists will greatly improve community policing and public safety across the province.

Title: Suspended students allowed to sit exams
Content: THE 27 Grade 10 students of Kimbe Grammar Secondary School in West New Britain (WNB) who were denied their examinations on Monday were allowed to return to school yesterday. WNB division of education advisor Vincent Kalatia toldThe Nationalon Monday afternoon that the 27 students were allowed to sit their exams after negotiations between the director of the school and Education secretary Dr Uke Kombra. Kalatia said a letter confirmed that all the suspended students were to sit their exams yesterday. “For the exam papers that the students missed on Monday like Mathematics and Personal Development, teachers will estimate their marks to account for the missed assessments,” Kalatia said. School director Andrew Karl clarified that the 27 students were not allowed to sit their exams on Monday due to non-payment of outstanding school fees. Karl said Kimbe Grammar is a private-run school and has been in operation for 16 years. He said since the school started, most parents had not been paying full fees for their children and the outstanding fees had accumulated to more than K14 million. Karl said the outstanding fees were for students that had already left school. He said as a result of the outstanding fees, most teachers were not being paid their salaries. “It is a private school and we entirely depend on students’ fees to run its operations including the payment of teachers’ salaries. Most parents make promises to pay but they never pay up. “Your child’s education is your responsibility and therefore you must prioritise your child’s fees and other education needs,” Karl said. He said since the students had been allowed to sit their exams, their parents must pay the outstanding fees. The director had warned that a similar action might apply to the 55 Grade 12 students and appealed to parents of these students to pay up their outstanding fees before the exams next week.

Title: Grade 10 students sit exams
Content: THE week-long national examinations for more than 87,500 Grade 10 students across the country commenced on Monday with Mathematics and Personal Development papers. Students continued with Social Science and Arts exams yesterday, while today they will do the science and information and communication technology examination. The exams will continue with business studies and agriculture tomorow and conclude with English on Friday. St Charles Lwanga Secondary School Principal Br Johnson Chacko said from his school the 245 Grade 10 students began the exams with a positive note. The school was ranked third in country in terms of Grade 10 performances last year. Br Chacko toldThe Nationalthat: “The exams went on well as per the feedback from the students with teachers having done very good preparation with the students, doing remedial and extra classes. “Our school has been performing well in the Grade 10 examinations in the last one decade and we believe this year also they would do that and make us and their parents proud,” he said Meanwhile, a newly-established school in rural East Sepik saw its first batch Grade 10 students sit their exams starting on Monday. Karawari Agro Tourism Technical High School head teacher Mark Tapi said initially he selected 54 students to Grade Nine at the new school. “Unfortunately, many left due to lack of resources, infrastructures and teachers’ shortages,” he said. “I am now appealing to Angoram MP Salio Waipo and East Sepik governor Allan Bird to assist the school in terms of resources and infrastructures,” he appealed. Tapi said the school is serving the entire Karawari local level government area and their support is very much needed.

Title: ENB locals farewell senior public servant
Content: East New Britain leaders, families, and communities gathered at Bitamapua United Church in Vunamurmur, Kokopo, on Friday to farewell one of the province’s most respected public servants, the late Ellison Kaivovo. It was an emotional moment, not only for his family and community, but for all who knew him. The packed congregation reflected the deep respect held for Kaivovo, who was remembered for his humility, discipline, and service to the province. Born on Oct 13, 1942, in Vunamurmur village, Raluana, Kokopo, Kaivovo passed away on Sept 29, at the age of 83. His distinguished career saw him serve with the Bank of Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific Commission in New Caledonia, and later became provincial secretary of East New Britain in 1992. He chaired major provincial boards in education, health, and planning, and supported community-based projects, earning him respect. Even after his years of distinguished service at the highest levels of government and international organisations, he chose to live quietly in his village displaying extraordinary simplicity. Kaivovo’s leadership shone during the 1994 twin volcanic eruptions when he was appointed Chief Controller of the State of Emergency Programme, and became a model of resilience for the province. He provided steady, calm, and decisive leadership at a time of disaster. Speaking during Kaivovo’s funeral service, Governor Michael Marum described him as a true son of the province and one of its finest servant leader.

Title: Delegation attends Australia meet on violence
Content: REPRESENTATIVES from Papua New Guinea joined more than 1,000 participants in Sydney for the fifth World Conference of Women’s Shelters –  the world’s largest forum dedicated to ending violence against women and children. The Sept 15–18 event brought together frontline practitioners, policymakers, and advocates to exchange innovations, evidence-based practices, and strategies for managing shelters and safe houses. Among the PNG delegation was Diane Kambanei, director of the National Gender-Based Violence (GBV) Secretariat, accompanied by officials from the Department for Community Development, Religion and Youth. “The conference was an extraordinary opportunity for the National GBV Secretariat and its partners to benchmark PNG’s GBV response against premier global standards,” Kambanei said. The event came at a pivotal time, as the Government, through its Medium-term Development Plan Four and the National Strategy to Prevent and Respond to GBV (2026–2035), aimed to have 80 registered and operational safe houses nationwide by 2027. However, a recent baseline survey led by the secretariat found only 51 safe houses currently operational, highlighting service gaps and resourcing constraints. Kambanei emphasised that improving these systems was “vital to ensure dignity, protection, and equity for GBV survivors”. PNG’s attendance was supported by the PNG Women Lead Programme and the Australia–Papua New Guinea Law and Justice Partnership.

Title: Uniforms for PNGDF
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) under the recently signed Pukpuk Treaty will receive 4,500 new uniforms from the Australian Defence Force (ADF). Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph said the uniforms were manufactured by Australian Defence Apparel, ADF’s supplier. “The uniforms will meet the exact quality and specifications used by Australian Defence personnel, ensuring that PNGDF soldiers are equipped to professional and durable standard,” Joseph said. This initiative marks the beginning of a broader effort to upgrade PNGDF capabilities and align operational standards, logistics and training with those of ADF as part of the growing alliance between the two nations. “As allies, our effort to enhance PNGDF capabilities to the same standards as the ADF has begun,” Joseph said. “This cooperation strengthens the professionalism, morale and operational readiness of our soldiers as we continue building a modern and capable national defence force.” The uniform delivery represents one of the first tangible outcomes of the treaty, signed by Prime Minister James Marape and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on Monday in Canberra, formalising PNG and Australia as mutual defence partners.

Title: Electoral Commission meet to focus on biometric tech
Content: THE Electoral Commission will conduct a three-day workshop next week focused on improving the country’s electoral processes through biometric technology. Electoral commissioner Simon Sinai said the workshop, scheduled for Monday to Wednesday in Port Moresby, would help the commission in its efforts to implement electoral reforms through the use of biometric and digital technologies. Sinai said the workshop would allow national and international experts to discuss innovations in registration, validation, voting, counting, cyber security and data management. He said the workshop would bring together government officials, development partners and international experts to explore fit-for-purpose technologies in: Sinai welcomed all relevant stakeholders to attend and participate in the workshop to improve the country’s electoral processes. Meanwhile, Administrative Services Minister Richard Masere, who oversees the commission, said the workshop was part of the Government’s plan to implement biometric and electronic voting in future elections. “All important government departments and agencies, political parties, provincial administration, bilateral partners and key private sectors partners will be invited to participate in this workshop,” he said. “The companies that have delivered successful elections around the world, including interested PNG businesses, will be invited to showcase and participate at the workshop.” Masere thanked the Special Parliamentary Committee on General Election 2022 for their report and recommendations on improving elections in the country, which was the main reason for conducting the workshop.

Title: Operating room nurses complete training
Content: AN operating room nurse training course in Papua New Guinea was completed at the Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH) recently. The course was led by Xiaoting Zhang (Tina), an operating room nurse of the 14th China Medical Team assigned to PMGH. After eight months of systematic training, more than 50 local nursing staff successfully the studies. PMGH nurse unit manager of the operating theatre Sr Barbra Sobi, at the end of the training, said: “This training has filled the gap in the cultivation of operating room specialty nurses in PNG. “The standardised nursing knowledge and practical skills brought by Tina has significantly improved the theoretical level and operational accuracy of our hospital’s nurses, laying a solid foundation for ensuring surgical safety and enhancing the quality of medical services.”

Title: Breast cancer awareness walk on
Content: A PINKTOBER walk aimed to raise awareness on breast cancer will be held in Port Moresby on Oct 19. PINKtober is an annual international health campaign to raise awareness, educate the public about early detection and prevention, and support those affected by breast cancer. This year’s walk is organised by the National Capital District Commission (NCDC) in partnership with the Active City DevelopmentProgramme and Amazing Port Moresby. Speaking ahead of the event, NCD Governor Powes Parkop said the importance of a united response is needed. “Breast cancer is not just a women’s health issue – it is a societal challenge that touches families, workplaces and our city as a whole,” he said. “The PINKtober Walk is a powerful platform to raise awareness, encourage early detection and support those affected. “I call on every business, organisation, government agency and healthcare institution to mobilise your teams and join us. “Together, we can save lives and show that Port Moresby stands united in hope and action.” The walk will be held on Sunday, Oct 19, from 5am starting at Murray Barracks and ending at Sir Hubert Murray Stadium. This will be followed by a range of activities including; awareness from breast cancer survivors and advocates, exhibitions and educational sessions on cancer prevention and early detection, community and SME stalls promoting health services and local initiatives and live entertainment. The event is free.

Title: 6.6 magnitude quake in Papua New Guinea, no tsunami warning
Content: An earthquake of magnitude 6.6 that struck Morobe on Tuesday night has no potential to trigger a tsunami as it happened about 100 kilometres deep, the Department of Mineral Policy and Geohazards Management says. The US Geological Survey reported the epicentre was about 26 kilometres west-south-west of Lae, and 99.4 kilometres deep. The Department of Mineral Policy and Geohazards Management said the earthquake occurred as a result of the interaction between Solomon Sea Place and Australia Plate. “It is of tectonic origin. It was felt strongly in Lae, and as far as Goroka, Popondetta, Madang, Kimbe, Mt Hagen and Port Moresby,” the department said in a statement. “The earthquake occurred on land, west of Lae, with shaking intensity of around 6. The potential of direct earthquake-triggered tsunami generation is unlikely. “No felt aftershocks have occurred following the main shock. At this stage no reports of damage have been received.” An academic at The University of Technology School of Surveying and Land Studies said the earthquake was not so damaging as it happened about a 100km deep, and the epicentre was around Mt. Shungol, south of the Markham River Bridge. Government official Malum Nalu, toldReutersthe earthquake struck around 9pm local time, when he was in the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium with hundreds of others for a ceremony honouring deceased Morobe governor Luther Wenge. “There was a big rumbling noise like a plane flying overhead, then the building was shaking violently for around three minutes,” Nalu said by phone. “There were hundreds of people inside; it was packed to capacity. People were rushing to get out of the exits and the deputy prime minister was calling for people to keep calm.” A Lae city police official described the earthquake as “very huge”, but both officials said they did not yet have details of any damage. Another witness, who declined to be named, said the earthquake had stirred superstition among locals. No tsunami warning is in place. With Reuters

Title: Grade 10 exams in Morobe to proceed undisturbed
Content: GRADE 10 national examinations in Morobe will not be disrupted by the funeral service programme for the late governor, Luther Wenge, tomorrow, an official says. Provincial education adviser Keith Tangui said the students would continue with their examinations. “We’ve respected our late governor last week when all the schools in the province were closed for two days (Thursday and Friday),” he said. “We are aware that the funeral service will be held on Wednesday. Some of our staff from other grades will be at the funeral service, while others will assist with the examinations.” Tangui said that the Sialum High School in Tewae-Siassi was the only school suspended for the whole year. “Otherwise, congratulations and good luck to those Grade 10 students sitting their exams,” he stated. The students began with the Mathematics paper, followed by the Personal Development examination. “It is a national examination and not provincial, where we can have a say to stop it,” he added. “I appeal to the community to allow and respect our students who have been studying for the last 10 years to sit for this examination.” Meanwhile, Tangui said that the provincial education sector had been facing funding constraints. School heads were advised to shift exam materials to their respective schools. “We (education sector) will reimburse their money as soon as our cash fund certificate comes,” he said. Grade 12 students begin their examinations next week followed by Grade Eight.

Title: Court to sit this month over status of Dr Ambi’s case
Content: A COURT has scheduled a status conference this month on the substantive hearing of the judicial review application by Dr Umadevi Ambihaipahar (Dr Ambi). National Court judge Susan Purdon-Sully in Waigani yesterday fixed Oct 22 for the status conference. A status conference is a meeting in court between the parties involved in a case, to discuss its progress, resolve procedural issues, and set timelines for steps such as the discovery or trial. Ambi had filed a case against Health Minister Elias Kapavore, the State, and Dr Nelson Mek of the Social Change and Mental Health Services (SCMHS) seeking leave to review the decision to revoke her appointment as director of SCMHS. The court heard that she was appointed acting director of SCMHS. On Jan 15, she was served a letter of suspension dated Jan 8 by Kapavore. She filed a judicial review case on Feb 10 seeking leave to review the suspension. On Mar 4, Kapavore served her with a notice of revocation of her appointment and appointed Mek as the director. It was gazetted on Jan 29. Ambi withdrew her case on Apr 3 and filed a fresh proceeding on Apr 28. An order was given to all parties on Aug 27 to comply with, and the matter was fixed for a pre-trial conference on Oct 13, but was rescheduled to yesterday. Ambi’s lawyer Jerry Siki informed the court that they had served the defendants the draft index to review book on Oct 1. The defendants would respond by Wednesday, Oct 8. All parties were ordered to settle the index to review book and have it filed on Friday. The court will consider fixing a date of hearing of the substantive judicial review application.

Title: Pioneer grade 10s in Banz sit exam
Content: FOR the first time, 64 pioneer students of the Kulamp Nazarene Technical High School in Banz, Jiwaka are sitting their Grade 10 national examination this week. School chairman Melex Bosip described it as an historic milestone for the education sector in Jiwaka. “This special group of students will remember this moment for the rest of their lives,” he said. “They should hold their heads high because they will be remembered as the pioneers of this institution which was established in 2024. “The board, teaching staff, and stakeholders concerned are proud of them. “Our headmaster Kole Du welcomed the invigilators to the school to conduct the exams. “The community at Kulamp and the church members were quite emotional when the papers were brought in and the students were lining up. “We congratulate them for this achievement and wish them luck.” Kulamp Nazarene is the first technical high school to be established in the province. “All glory to God above for allowing this to happen in His own timing,” Bosip, a pastor, said. The community and church members were overjoyed to see for the first time girls who could have gone to distant schools sitting the exams at their doorstep.

Title: Treaties must benefit people and nation, says Tomuriesa
Content: PAPUA New Guinea should sign treaties on agreements relating to education, health, unemployment and issues affecting the nation, says Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa. “Treaties are treaties, but if it’s a treaty that is not within the constitution, then we have a problem,” he said.  “In any case, if it does violate our constitution, then the Opposition will challenge the treaty in court. But first we have to look at it.” Tomuriesa was commenting on the recently signed Pukpuk Treaty between PNG and Australia aimed at strengthening defence cooperation between the two nations. “Does the treaty benefit our people? And if so, what benefits are there?  We cannot be signing a treaty. We are sovereign nation. We have to guard our interest first,” Tomuriesa said. He said treaties were good only when they benefit the nation and its people. “I say this because Parliament passed a bill regarding the American army coming into our waters and we haven’t seen much about it yet,” he added. “I don’t see PNG as a threat to any nation in the world. “One time, we signed a treaty to be friends to all and enemies to none. And so does it make us friends to one nation only and enemies to others?” Tomuriesa said Australia needed PNG people to go and work there but the doors were hard to open. Prime Minister James Marape was in Australia yesterday to sign the treaty with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.

Title: Enga signs up for Miss Bird of Paradise
Content: IN a ground-breaking move, Enga has become the first Highlands province to sign up to join the Miss Bird of Paradise family. That marks a significant milestone in the realm of the pageantry, challenging misconceptions that pageants are solely about beauty or appearance. Enga is breaking new grounds by recognising that pageantry encompasses service, leadership, cultural pride and the empowerment of women. Miss Kurie Endopio, 23, and from Enga and Popondetta parentage, was selected as Miss Bird of Paradise Enga, for 2025 and 2026. Eight contestants vied for the Miss Enga pageantry. All were tertiary school students and were sponsored by eight different sponsors within the province. Miss Enga, Kurie Endopio, thanked the judges for choosing her to be “Miss Enga”. “Whatever role we play for the province, we must all work together to promote unity and loyalty, and maintain the good reputation Enga has,” Endopio said after her crowning. Miss Enga will become a cultural ambassador for the province, carrying its dreams, heritage, and aspirations to the national stage at the Miss Bird of Paradise national pageant in December. It is a platform for the young women of Enga to shine and represent their province on a larger scale. Miss Bird of Paradise PNG, May Torowi Hasola, said the pageantry is not just a stage of competition, but it represents voices of women and becomes a strong platform for promoting gender equity and rights. “The event not only promotes the empowerment of young women but also supports local businesses, designers, and creatives within Enga,” Hasola assured. “The province’s courageous embrace of this vision demonstrates exemplary leadership to inspire other regions in Papua New Guinea.” By taking this bold step as the pioneer Highlands province to embrace the vision of the Miss Bird of Paradise pageant, Enga is setting a precedent for other provinces to follow. The province is leading the way and sending a powerful message that pageantry can be a platform for positive change, development, and uniting communities. The maiden event in Enga has captured the essence of the province’s rich culture, stunning landscapes, and hospitality. Enga’s distinctive customs, music, and way of life have showcased the beauty and resilience of the land. The event aims to challenge stereotypes and present Enga as a province filled with beauty, strength, and potential. The pageantry committee extends their acknowledgments to all the participants for their bravery and commitment, the Enga committee for their hard work and dedication, and the Government of Enga, especially Governor Sir Peter Ipatas, for their trust and support.

Title: LLG farewells their ‘friend’ Wenge
Content: THE people of Huon Gulf local level government in Morobe mourned with deep sorrow in their hearts for their late Governor Luther Wenge, as he was friends to most and helped many. On Saturday, his final visit of the day to Huon Gulf in the Morobe LLG Station, where he was solemnly received by the people of Huon Gulf — including Morobe LLG communities, their administration and the wider district population. Among those who formally received his body were former MP of Huon Gulf, Tukape Masani, LLG manager Yaing Agai and LLG president Andrew Tera, together with students and other administration staff. Their presence, alongside the grieving community, reflected the deep love and respect held by the people of Huon Gulf for their late leader. His body was escorted and accompanied by the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Religion and local MP Jason Peter, together with family members, government delegates, and dignitaries. The procession was led by the Deputy Prime Minister, Lae MP and the chief mourner John Rosso, who stood in solidarity with the people. On Sunday, his journey of farewell continued across other districts of Morobe, where more people had the opportunity to pay their respects to his life and legacy. The unity, mourning and respect displayed by the people of Huon Gulf is a testament to the enduring leadership, wisdom, popularity and commitment Wenge had shared throughout his years of service to Morobe and the nation. Peter, on behalf of the people, acknowledged this historic moment of farewell as the province prepared to lay to rest a leader whose contributions will be remembered for a long time.
People: Jason Peter, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Programme set as Lae prepares for late governor’s final goodbye
Content: THE final programme of the funeral service for Morobe Governor Luther Wenge will be held tomorrow at the Sir Ignatius Kilage (outdoor) Stadium in Lae, Morobe. Wenge was taken on a four-day visit to respective districts in the province starting on Saturday and ending today. A chopper took his casket on Saturday to Menyamya, Bulolo and Huon-Gulf, and on Sunday Siwea village in Tewae-Siassi and Finschhafen, on Monday to Kabwum and Tewae-Siassi (again)-Siassi Island and Wasu Station and today to Markham and Nawaeb. Each district was allowed an hour of mourning, pay tribute and show respects to the popular leader. Images and videos circulated on social media showed a large crowd welcoming Wenge. Mourning and chanting in their local vernaculars of their relationship followed and describing what kind of man and leader he was. The casket was flown back to Lae, and overnighted at the provincialhaus kraiat the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium (SIK). Tomorrow (Wednesday), the final funeral service will be held at the stadium, where the programme will start from 9am. The programme is scheduled for about four and a half hours and the casket will depart the stadium by helicopter to Baindoang village in Nabak, Nawaeb at around noon. The casket will be flown to his remote Baindoang village for his burial, as he had wished. The governor’s leadership portrayed the type of man he was, as many shared their tributes describing him as the defender of the Constitution, an advocate for education and the voice of the voiceless. People from across the country had flooded Lae City to show their respects and give contributions through cash and kind.

Title: Policy on use of social media given the greenlight
Content: THE National Executive Council (NEC) has endorsed the National Social Media Policy 2025, a comprehensive framework that ensures the safe and responsible use of social media. Acting Information and Communications Technology (ICT) Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr said the policy would introduce clear rules for user accountability and responsibility, including age restrictions, safeguards for children and vulnerable groups, measures to combat misinformation and disinformation, and requirements for platform accountability. Tsiamalili, also the Police Minister, said: “The policy will require that all citizens aged 14-16 and above use the impending digital indentification infrastructure to access social media, ensuring safe and secure online participation. “This will be complemented by a social media classification framework to guide access and content standards for users of different age groups. “The policy also provides enforcement measures, including penalties for cyber harassment, defamation, and the spread of misinformation. “Social media is a powerful tool for communication, education, and development, but it also presents risks such as online abuse, fake news, and exploitation of vulnerable users. “This policy strikes the right balance by upholding freedom of expression while ensuring safety, decency, and accountability online,” he said. He said that with NEC’s endorsement of the policy, its immediate implementation would focus on the following:

Title: NCD police take control of Sabama incident
Content: ABOUT 17 homes were destroyed and burnt to ashes three weeks ago at Horse Camp in Sabama, Port Moresby after an Engan man was allegedly murdered by another man from Gulf. Assistant commissioner of police (ACP) for National Capital District and Central Benjamin Turi led a police unit to the camp and learned that Gulf people who lived there had left in fear after the incident. Turi confirmed the murder suspect had been arrested and was now in police custody. “The Engans do not have any right to burn the houses and set up a mourning house in a public area that other innocent Gulf people have access to,” he said. He said the funny thing they saw was that the Engans chased the Gulf people out of their houses and connected power from one of the house to their mourning house at Sabama. “This is Port Moresby city, and we do not want to see people bringing their village mentality to the city. “Burning down houses and then trying to claim the land is not right and is unlawful,” he said. “We will investigate the matter and have those who burnt down the houses arrested and charged, just like we did to the person who murdered the Engan man,” he said. He called on the Engans, who supported their tribesmen to set up the mourning house and demanded K200, 000 compensations to stop. “We have names of people who are doing that. “They will be arrested and charged soon,” Turi said. He urged owners of the houses destroyed to provide Badili police with their statements so they could fast-track the case. Turi said that the police will patrol that area to ensure those that left their houses returned and those that were not residents must not create new problems.

Title: Expert enjoys teaching life skills
Content: LOCAL expert Gibing Oboko loves to teach locals the basic life skills in stock feed formulation, cooking oil and soap making, as well as spices using local products. Oboko, from the Gawenglabu village of Finschhafen, Morobe, has more than 30 years’ experience as a life skills trainer. The Market for Village Farmers (MVF) project, co-financed by the Government and the International Fund for Agriculture Development, and implemented by the Fresh Produce Development Agency (FPDA), has been engaging Oboko to impart his extensive knowledge to local fresh produce farmers. Most of the training that Oboko imparted has been well received by farmers in the project-targeted provinces of Chimbu, Eastern Highlands, Western Highlands, Jiwaka and Morobe. The training encompasses food processing techniques by promoting awareness on good hygiene, imparting knowledge on nutrient content, dissemination of food preparation information, and encouraging farmers about downstream processing of local food products for commercial benefits. Oboko is passionate about changing perceptions and making people understand the concept of import replacement. The trainer has been showcasing his products in the public arena drawing crowds as in the recent Morobe Agricultural Show and Goroka Show as well as during training sessions facilitated by the project and FPDA. “I tell the participants in the life skills training to focus and absorb as much as possible because whatever they learn will greatly help them later on,” Oboko said. “The skills we impart are vital as most of the food we have are grown and used locally. “We can stop imports if local trainers are properly supported with the resources required to help local farmers to go into downstream processing. “I thank agriculture agencies like FPDA, through the MVF project, for giving us the opportunity to equip local farmers with vital skills and knowledge so that they can venture into commercial fruits, nuts and vegetable downstream processing,” Oboko added. “This will in turn create employment and promote the growth of local small-to-medium enterprises in the food industry.” Farmers were also in awe of the process involved in which Oboko used waste-likekaukaupeelings and combining them with other ingredients like cassava and coconut scraps to formulate stock feed for chicken, pigs, ducks, fish and eels. “We have everything we need to make our own stock feed or fertilisers and oils which are similar in content to the one we find in the stores,” Oboko added. “What we need are processing facilities and resources and partnership with the right government agencies and private sector to build the local industry.”

Title: Network outages hit health services
Content: ONGOING mobile network outages are affecting health services at Garaina Station in Morobe’s Wau Waria, says a senior community health worker. Garaina Health Centre community health worker Kotoram Autia said the outages were an ongoing problem that had affected some health programmes in Lae. “The outage issue in Garaina has affected our daily reporting, especially for round one of the polio vaccination campaign in the province,” he said. “We need the network to report through WhatsApp as it is fast and reliable.” Autia said they were not sure with what was wrong with the network in Garaina, but there seemed to be outages more often than before. “We also have emergency cases at the health centre that need referrals,” he said. “But due to network outages, we cannot assist them.” Autia said travelling by road to Wau in order to get network, or transport patients, cost them K250. A two-way trip costs K500. “We are yet to get an ambulance as we have a new road connection,” he said. “But for now, we receive assistance from the Wau ambulance for emergency cases and other general health programmes.” Autia said round two of Morobe’s polio vaccination campaign would start soon, so the network issues must be resolved quickly. “We have to report daily back to our colleagues here in Lae about the polio vaccination campaign in Garaina,” he said. “But without network coverage and internet access, we cannot do so. “For the first round of the polio vaccination, we used text messages to report back to Lae and whenever the network picks up our messages get delivered, otherwise they don’t.” Autia is urging network operators and responsbile authorities to resolve the matter t as it was affecting not just health services in the outstation but other basic services too. Round two of the polio campaign is expected to start on Monday (Oct 13) and end on Oct 31 in all 10 districts of the province.

Title: Cocoa growers urged to be steadfast
Content: COMMUNITIES in Bougainville and East New Britain were encouraged to continue investing in cocoa during the 10th Implementation Support Mission (ISM) visit of the Papua New Guinea Agriculture Commercialisation and Diversification (PACD) project last week. Led by senior agriculture specialist Allan Oliver, team leader for PACD, World Bank delegates, PACD project coordination unit in Port Moresby, and representatives from government agencies, the team visited partnerships in Buka and inspected the nearly completed 5.8km Teobhuin- Sipotavai agricultural feeder road. Later the team travelled to ENB to inspect the Vunapalading-Burit road in Gazelle, the Ivon-Kulungere Road in Sinivit and grower partnerships at Kairak. Oliver spoke to growers in each province and reminded them that the project was funded through a World Bank loan and urged communities to sustain their efforts to grow cocoa production. “The funding is a loan from the World Bank and people must continue to grow cocoa and toil the land in return. “It increases the export revenue of the country that it will go back to repay the loan,” he said. He explained that the ISM conducted twice a year, was designed to assess progress and ensure projects were delivering benefits to rural communities. “We are happy that the projects are helping you to increase revenue and income but at the same time all must look after revenue so that you build good houses, savings in the bank and increase asset base in the cocoa industry,” Oliver said. Community leaders and farmers expressed gratitude for the long-awaited infrastructure, noting that road development had not reached their areas for 40 to 50 years, and said the project would transform livelihoods. Acting district coordinator for Tinputz, Joycelyne Karevui, said the investment was a milestone for the district. “This is the first of its kind and we appreciate the Government and the World Bank for funding road infrastructure development,” she said. She added that infrastructure would improve connectivity, facilitate economic growth, enhance social services and boost trade and commerce in the region. Oliver congratulated the cocoa project management unit for its commitment to making sure the funding materialised in a short time.

Title: PNGTPA celebrates with students
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Tourism Promotion Authority (PNGTPA) partnered with the PNG University of Natural Resources and Environment (UNRE) to celebrate World Tourism Day with community-based activities. Students took part in activities reflecting this year’s theme, “Tourism and Sustainable Transformation”. With the support of PNG TPA, UNRE students carried out an awareness programme in schools and a series of clean-a-thons in Rabaul and Kokopo. The outreach included an information session where students highlighted three key areas of tourism: sustainable tourism, youth in tourism, and education in tourism. UNRE acting head of department for tourism and hospitality, Naomi Mwayawa, said World Tourism Day had been part of the school’s curriculum since 2020, celebrated in partnership with PNGTPA. “We have it as an annual event for our university and our students. We commemorate World Tourism Day and celebrate in line with the theme,” she said. She emphasised that the programme reinforced the importance of conserving natural resources and achieving sustainability. “As part of our curriculum, we try to engage our students to work with communities and do cleanups and help them at a community level. When we talk about sustainability, it’s also inclusion and how everybody benefits from developments such as tourism,” Mwayawa explained. PNGTPA executive manager, Kennewton Kennedy, said the sector faced major challenges including land issues and limited financial support. “We need to change the mindset of people and that is the challenge. “We want to go in a big way. We want to drive it to the young people to promote it among their own people and communities,” he said. UNRE International Sustainable Tourism student, Vanessa Mamani, described her involvement as an eye-opener, especially for the students they visited in schools. “They didn’t know that tourism can be integrated into other aspects,” Mamani said.

Title: Marape in Australia to sign defence treaty
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape is in Australia to sign the Papua New Guinea–Australia Security Treaty. Marape said the signing will mark a new chapter in the long-standing partnership between Papua New Guinea and Australia, opening new doors for cooperation across multiple sectors beyond defence. “As I indicated previously in my speech about the security treaty, this agreement opens many doors for us and fine-tunes our relationship with Australia going forward into the next 50 years,” Marape said in a statement yesterday. He emphasised that the treaty will not only strengthen defence and security collaboration but also build opportunities in areas such as clean energy, policing, education and employment for Papua New Guineans. “The treaty reflects the deep friendship and mutual trust that our two nations share,” Marape said. “It is about growing together in peace, prosperity and mutual respect as we chart the next 50 years of partnership.” While in Australia, Marape is also holding key discussions with the National Rugby League (NRL) executives and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese regarding the establishment of Papua New Guinea’s own NRL team. “These talks are focused on finalising the team’s name, structure, membership drives, and sponsorship frameworks that will underpin our country’s entry into the NRL,” Marape said. “Our aim is to ensure that PNG’s NRL team is built on a strong foundation professionally managed, commercially viable and nationally represented.” Marape said updates from these discussions will be presented to the PNG NRL Board later this week in Port Moresby, as preparations continue for the upcoming Prime Minister’s 13 match scheduled for Sunday at the Santos National Football Stadium. Marape is expected to return to Port Moresby this afternoon and will host a press conference upon arrival to brief the nation on the details and significance of both the Security Treaty and the NRL discussions. Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso is acting prime minister.

Title: Wabag court to clear case backlog, predicts disputes
Content: THE National Court in Wabag will clear the backlog of cases this month, as some of them may likely lead to people seeking dispute resolutions through tribal fights, says resident judge Graham Ellis. Judge Ellis said there was a clear desire by the people of Enga to have a National Court judge as quickly as possible. “An indication of that came recently when I sat in Baisu to allocate a hearing date for everyone who is in prison awaiting a trial date in Wabag,” he said. “When the hearing was adjourned (due to the tribal fight in Wapenamanda) the prisoners are affected.” Judge Ellis said that the backlog of criminal cases could be dealt with by the end of October. “We have already put in place a system that anyone who is committed to trial will appear in the National Court on a following Friday, and on that occasion, we will allocate a hearing date,” he said. “The hearing dates for new criminal cases will be in November. “By then, I expect a situation where a time from a person who is committed to stand trial until a time when the trial is finalised will be one month.” Pastors from 17 churches welcomed Judge Ellis. One of them, Josephine Alo of the Four-Square Church, said Enga had many widows and orphans. The Constitution Section 37 SubSection 14 states that an accused person should have their trial started within four months, Judge Ellis said. He added that recently, he found that an accused person had been waiting seven years without a trial. “Had initial trial being committed, had he been found guilty, it is unlikely he would spend further time in prison,” he said. “In this circumstances, common sense prevails. “He was released and I had the police take him home from the court in Wabag, so he hasn’t had to return to Baisu.” Judge Ellis also said that he did not forget the people of Porgera. There are matters in the criminal case list waiting to be heard. He plans to have a Porgera sitting from Nov 10 to 21.

Title: Officers posted to Highlands instructed to restore law and order in hotspots
Content: POLICE Commissioner David Manning has instructed police officers tasked to restore law and order in Highlands hotspots to take up their posts immediately. Manning said senior police officers summoned to meet with him on Friday included Operation Commander Anthony Wagambie Jr, Western Highlands Divisional Commander Chief Supt Joseph Tondop, Southern Highlands Police Commander Supt Epenes Nili, and Hela Police Commander Supt Michael Welly. “I am disappointed that some in senior leadership positions are not on the ground in the Highlands leading the security force personnel,” he said. “These senior personnel will be in place in the Highlands, working with Commander Wagambie who has the responsibility for restoring order in these troubled areas. “There is very little our senior operations personnel can do from a desk in Port Moresby when shots are being fired, people being attacked and homes being burned in the Highlands. “The threats we face from domestic terrorist groups that use violence as part of criminal activities will be overcome. “This is a law enforcement operation being carried out on the ground in affected areas. “The low number of arrest in these commands is unacceptable. “It will not be tolerated. “Arrest will be delivered or those in these commands will be held to account. “Disciplined forces are not normal public sector agencies. “We have chains of command and personnel who fail to follow directions will face the consequences.”

Title: Sir Peter warns Engan leaders to stop arming fighters
Content: ENGA Governor Sir Peter Ipatas has warned Engan leaders to stop keeping guns and getting involved in tribal fights “Tribal fights persist because politicians, businessmen and community leaders are deeply involved in supplying firearms in Enga,” he said. Sir Peter was speaking during the Enga day celebration in Wabag last Wednesday. “These leaders are also influencing village leaders to join tribal conflicts and this has escalated into a far worse scenario for the province,” he said. “All leaders must recognise the need to address these serious issues and to put an end to weapon supplies and the encouragement of tribal warfare, so people can benefit from infrastructure, resources and development the Government is providing.” Sir Peter urged Kompiam Ambum, Kandep, Porgera Paiyala, and Wapenamanda districts to work towards helping to restore peace in Enga. The celebrations focused on the country’s 50th independence anniversary and the work of churches. They also welcomed the resident judge to Enga Graham Ellis, and the start of the law and order summit on Wednesday evening. Prime Minister James Marape reiterated the call for peace and urged the people of Enga to lay down arms, stop tribal conflicts and respect the law. “Tribal conflicts affect families, services and people to lose their lives. “There are many good people in Enga that have contributed to the development of this country in the last 50 years. “There are only a few that cause trouble. “We will work with the Enga provincial government for Kandep, Porgera and Paiela to see a good roads and other projects in progress. “We are now focusing on roads from Wabag to Porgera and Tari, so better services can reach the people,” he said.
People: James Marape, Peter Ipatas, Sir Peter Ipatas

Title: Marape vows to continue late Wenge’s unfinished projects
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape pledged to the people of Morobe to continue the work of their late Governor Luther Wenge. Marape made the commitment on Friday at the provincial assembly in front of the late Wenge’s casket, MPs, provincial government and administration staff, and the people. He highlighted four things: Marape said that the late Wenge was a strong advocator for the Wafi-Golpu mine project. “The 30 per cent of what we collect is to be passed back to the people of Morobe and the landowners,” he said. He said that Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso was in charge of the Nadzab city expansion. “The provincial government headquarters to be moved to Nadzab is a work in progress.” Marape said that country was grieving with the people of Morobe. “Despite the scorching heat and the thirst, you have shown how great a leader Wenge was through your sorrow. “His contribution to Papua New Guinea, whether in the law and justice sector or in political life, stands tall,” he said. Marape will join the provincialhauskraion Wednesday.
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Wenge’s scholarship scheme benefitted many: Bruten
Content: MOROBE’S Gerson Solulu Scholarship was the brainchild of the late Governor Luther Wenge, supporting more than 10,000 Morobe students who now occupy public offices, says provincial administrator Max Bruten. He said that Wenge was a strong supporter and promoter of education. And that can be proved through the establishment of the Gerson Solulu Scholarship Scheme. “Through this scheme, many are now doctors, lawyers, accountant, and other professionals,” Bruten said. “And no one can deny that. “He was not only a provincial leader but also someone who fought for the nation.” The scholarship scheme was implemented in 2004 to support Morobe students in education institutions. Students from institutions gathered on Wednesday and went for a “walk of sorrow” from Eriku Oval to the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium. They were from institutions in the city and province. Those who could not make it to the province showed respect at their respective institutions away from home. Bruten said that the late Wenge would be remembered because of the scheme. He added that the late Wenge also supported law and order, with K3 million allocated to train police reservists, buying police vehicles and other logistics to reduce crime. “His Babafic Trust Fund is also one of the impact projects,” Bruten said. The fund was introduced to support widows, pastors, preachers and persons living with disabilities.

Title: Nari to name information centre after late governor
Content: THE National Agriculture Research Institute (Nari) will be naming its information centre as “Luther Akisawa Wenge Haus”, in honour of their late governor, says an official. Nari director-general Dr Nelson Simbiken announced last week during thehaus kraiat the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium in Lae, Morobe, last week that they will be honouring the governor, through the commitment made. Simbiken shared the moments and contributions that Wenge made with the institution, stating that Nari was a national institution, but Wenge through his wisdom, had supported the institution in many ways. “Wenge was visionary, looking ahead of the role Nari will play in the visibility of the province and the country, and the direct impact his people will have through agricultural research technologies, innovations and employment,” he said. “He embraced the move and stood up for Nari, calling on the Government to fund the institution. “He did not stop there to ensure Nari became what it is today, he continued to provide moral backing and funding support, which saw the establishment of the Alan Quartermain Multi-purpose Hall and the Dr Ghodake National Biotechnology Centre.” The names Alan Quartermain and Dr Ghodake were names Wenge had suggested honouring the contributions of two expatriate scientists, who contributed immensely to agriculture research in Morobe and Papua New Guinea as a whole. “Being a patron of Nari, the late governor, has never missed Nari open days and the Agricultural Innovation Shows even when he wasn’t holding office,” Simbiken shared. “The great Songan has always regarded Nari as a child of Wampar. “He was always there to nurture and guide the organisation.” Simbiken added that the institution would also name the research grant as “Luther Wenge Research Grant”, to honour him. Simbiken clarified that naming the research grant after him was following a commitment of K1 million he made last year (2024) from the provincial government royalties to be deposited at Nari for scientists who are keen to take that route.

Title: Enga assured benefits from new mine agenda
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has confirmed his Government’s commitment to ensuring that the people of Enga directly benefit from the new Porgera Mine, and from the nation’s broader economic growth under a reset agenda. Speaking in Enga on Friday, Marape said the Government’s focus is on growing the national economy so that more resources can flow back to provinces and communities. “In the first six months of this year alone, Porgera contributed over K500 million in corporate tax,” Marape said. “From that, the Enga provincial government has already received K48 million, while K96 million for landowners is being kept in trust until the conclusion of the Community Development Agreement (CDA) this month. These benefits are far better than the old arrangements, and they reflect our government’s way of securing more for landowners, provincial governments, and the nation.” He stressed that the new Porgera arrangements will continue to generate substantial benefits, with another K500 million in corporate taxes expected this year, alongside provincial and landowner dividends. Marape announced that he will return to Porgera later this month to outline the different benefit streams that will be delivered. He also endorsed the Porgera policy requiring all businesses operating at the mine to have addresses in Enga, but cautioned that lasting benefits required peace and order. “How can businesses take residence in Enga when we are still engaged in tribal fights?” he asked. “I appeal to our people to lay down arms, protect land and environment and allow development to take root. The Government is working to strengthen police presence and build more Correctional facilities so law and order can be maintained. We want benefits to flow back to our people, but stability is essential.” Marape commended Governor Sir Peter Ipatas for his leadership, highlighting major provincial achievements including: The Innovative University of Enga, now operational with campuses being developed; Enga Provincial Hospital, fully commissioned and set to be fully staffed next year and K8 million funding for a new large holding facility at Mukurumanda Correctional Service (prison). “Our government has not lost faith in Enga. You are our country’s biggest language group, one province with one language, and we urge you to put politics aside, unite and take ownership of peace and progress. Resources are no longer the problem – Pogera’s new agreement is the best in the country – but our people must settle down to benefit,” Marape said. He reaffirmed that Enga’s resource wealth, combined with national and provincial government commitments, places the province at the centre of Papua New Guinea’s reset agenda to drive inclusive development.
People: James Marape, Peter Ipatas, Sir Peter Ipatas

Title: Sonk’s case adjourned after filing by State lawyer
Content: THE National Court on Friday granted an adjournment of the case of suspended Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) managing director Wapu Sonk, allowing the State to file further submissions. The application was filed on Friday by lawyer representing Prime Minister James Marape, and the State, seeking time to file their submissions. Through an affidavit, the court was told that Marape’s lawyer was busy with the other court proceedings and needed time to file its respective submissions to address before the court.
