Sonk’s lawyer opposed and argued that it was unfair as all parties were given enough time to file their submissions and there was no excuse or reason for an adjournment. He said that this was an important case and since all parties had filed their submissions, it was only a matter for them to speak. He further argued that if the court grants the application for an adjournment then it must not entertain any application, and the matter must return for hearing only. Presiding judge Susan Purdon-Sully said the State lawyer has not had an opportunity to file the respective submissions because he has been in another court throughout the week. “He does not have sufficient time to file his submissions. He had three hours to prepare it today, and it is not sufficient,” Justice Purdon-Sully said. Justice Purdon-Sully said the court was satisfied that the lawyer for Marape and the State would not bring prejudice to the plaintiffs. Sonk has filed a judicial review to challenge the KPHL trustee’s decision in appointing the Aopi board, who have not complied with the appointment process under the Kumul Petroleum Authorisation Act 2015. He is also seeking orders declaring the decision of his suspension being unlawful, invalid and void. The matter returns on Tuesday at 1pm for hearing.

Title: All declarations for Arob polls done
Content: ALL votes for the 45 seats in the 2025 Autonomous Region of Bougainville general election have been counted with all winning candidates declared, according to Bougainville Electoral Commissioner Desmond Tsianai. “This election has been a powerful expression of democratic choice,” he said. “With the declaration of all 45 seats, we bring this electoral process to a close with gratitude, humility and confidence in the will of the people. “I commend the people of Bougainville for turning out in numbers, for respecting the process, and for contributing to the peaceful environment that made this election possible. “Your voice has been heard. “Your vote has shaped the leadership that will carry us forward.” Tsianai acknowledged the peaceful conduct of the elections across Bougainville and those living outside the region. He thanked the voters, candidates, polling officials, security personnel, media and observers for their efforts in ensuring a transparent and credible electoral process. “With the election now concluded, it is important that all parties respect the results, uphold democratic principles, and work constructively within Bougainville’s institutions,” he said. “To the newly elected representatives, the responsibility now rests with you to serve with integrity and commitment to all Bougainvilleans. “If there are any candidates or voters who may wish to dispute the results of the election, please note that you may still submit a petition to the courts within one month of the declaration of the election. “This is your right, and an important part of the electoral process.” Tsianai also expressed appreciation to partners and stakeholders, including the Bougainville police service, civil society, community leaders and technical advisers. “I thank our dedicated electoral officials, the tireless counting teams, and our local and international partners for their professionalism, neutrality and unwavering support,” he said. “The Bougainville Electoral Commission remains committed to supporting transparent and inclusive electoral processes into the future.” Meanwhile, Tsianai said writs were scheduled to be returned today to the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Simon Pentanu. He said post-election reviews would be held after the return of writs to improve the electoral process in the future.

Title: Opposition lays blame on incompetency for delaying election
Content: THE deferral of the local level government (LLG) polling dates has caused confusion among voters and candidates over the past three months, says Opposition Leader Douglas Tomuriesa. “The LLGs and wards play a pivotal role as the first arm of government in the rural areas. By delaying the polling dates, the Government is depriving the constitutional rights of its citizens to elect and represent their constituency,” he said in a statement on Friday. Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso last month said polling for LLG elections was deferred to Oct 25. Polling was initially scheduled to start on Sept 27. Rosso said in the deferral was necessary to allow the national examinations to proceed without interruption. However, Tomuriesa said: “To use the national examination for another deferral is just an excuse and justification that should not be tolerated at such levels. Election is a five-year event and the Government together with the Electoral Commission should have planned this to avoid such schedules in the future.” Tomuriesa said the nation was experiencing a lack of leadership and planning from the ‘incompetent and irresponsible ministers’. He urged Prime Minister James Marape to sack the incompetent ministers. “The Electoral Commissioner (Simon Sinai) should not abuse his constitutional power to defer the polling dates to suit the Government’s fishy tactics and agenda,” Tomuriesa said.
People: Douglas Tomuriesa, James Marape, John Rosso

Title: Judges discuss tackling gender-based violence
Content: SENIOR members of Papua New Guinea’s judiciary convened in the first week of September for a landmark human rights workshop focused on gender-based violence (GBV) as a violation of human rights. Supported by the Australia-PNG Law and Justice Partnership, the event brought together 20 judges from across the country to strengthen approaches for tackling GBV, supporting survivors and shifting societal attitudes. Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika opened the event and underscored the judiciary’s responsibility to uphold dignity and justice for all citizens. “This is not just a legal issue, it is a moral imperative,” he said. “Our courts must be places where survivors find protection, not silence.” Australian High Commission representative, Tessa Plueckhahn commended the judiciary’s leadership and reaffirmed Australia’s support. “Australia is proud to support PNG’s judiciary in its role in upholding the rule of law and ensuring justice is delivered fairly and consistently. “Interpretation and application of the law plays a critical role in how justice is realised for survivors of gender-based violence. “This workshop reflects the strength of our enduring partnership, where legal leadership, institutional integrity, and community needs come together to promote accountability and human rights,” Plueckhahn said. By bringing together members of PNG’s senior judiciary, the workshop laid the groundwork for a more responsive and survivor-centred justice system. The recommendations generated will inform future judicial training and policy dialogue, ensuring that the judiciary continues to play a pivotal role in upholding rule of law, as it relates to the rights of women and girls across PNG.

Title: Medical lab technician association teams up with PEA
Content: THE Medical Laboratory Technician Personnel Association (MLTPA) officially affiliated with Public Employers Association (PEA) as an occupational branch yesterday. PEA general secretary Ugwalubu Moawana described the affiliation a solidarity-enhancing in union movement in the public service and marks PEA’s second occupational branch over the last 12 months. MLTPA president Ernest Velemu said affiliation marks a significant turning point for their profession. “This is more than just a merger, it is a strategic design strategic alliance designed to amplify a voice of medical professional laboratory professionals and ensure we receive the recognition and the support we deserve. “As medical laboratory professionals the critical services we provide are key to accurate diagnosis, effective treatment, disease surveillance, and estimation of disease burdens and ultimately the well-being of the PNG population,” he said. “We perform complex test analyse samples and provide crucial information that doctors and other health professionals rely on to make inform decision about patient care and health responses.” Velemu said yet their conditions are unnoticed and often inappropriately valued. “By joining forces with PEA, we are gaining access to the world of resources and technical expertise in industrial relations, negotiations and advice,” he said. “This partnership will help power us to effectively negotiate with matters that directly impact our members including improve wages and benefits and enhance working conditions, greater public awareness and analysis. “We believe that the partnership with the PEA will ultimately benefit the entire public health system of PNG by attracting and retaining skilled medical laboratory professionals,” Velemu added. Meanwhile, PEA president Isowa More is calling on other unions to come affiliate with PEA for greater support and manpower. ‘This will pave way for negotiations, advocacy and awards among other services that PEA can provide,” More said. Moawana also highlighted through their similar affiliation with Health Extension Officers Association, PEA was able to discuss HEOA’s outstanding agreement and awards with the Health Department. He said they have received a positive response and the agreements on award for HEOs would soon be implemented.

Title: PNG supports Australia bid to host 2026’s Cop31 in Adelaide
Content: PAPUA New Guinea is supporting Australia host the 31st Conference of the Parties (Cop31) to UNFCCC as climate change impacts threatens island nations. Environment, Conservation and Climate Change Minister Simo Kilepa attended the Pacific Climate Change Ministers meeting in Australia last week to show PNG’s backing for Australia to host the Cop31. Kilepa said the Pacific continues to face the “harsh realities of climate change”, rising sea levels, extreme weather events, and the loss of ecosystems and livelihoods. “In response, we are united in calling for urgent and ambitious global action. “We agree to support Australia’s bid to host the Cop31 in partnership with the Pacific. “This bid, currently contested between Australia and Turkey, represents a crucial opportunity for the world to come to the Pacific and witness firsthand the realities of the climate emergency. “Papua New Guinea recalls the strong statement of support delivered by our Prime Minister, James Marape, during the 80th Session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.” Marape underlined PNG’s unwavering backing of Australia’s Cop31 candidacy, recognising it as a Pacific Cop that will elevate the voices and priorities of small island developing states, Kilepa said. Bringing the world to the Pacific during the Cop31 would showcase the urgency of the climate challenge, and to inspire stronger global action for the survival of islands and its future. Meanwhile, the host of Cop31 in November 2026 will be announced at Cop30 in Brazil next month. Australia and the Pacific Islands have put in a joint bid to co-host the event, with Adelaide as the proposed city. Turkey has also submitted a serious bid to host. Australian officials traveled to Ankara in late 2024 to lobby them to withdraw, without success.

Title: Australian government supporting training in climate disaster risk
Content: THE Australian Government has been supporting training for senior Papua New Guinean officials to assess climate disaster risks in major investments before project approval through the annual budget process. Under this initiative, 53 officials from the Department of National Planning and Monitoring (DNPM) and the Department of Treasury – more than a third of them women – undertook training sessions from July to last month. The training emphasised the importance of making public investments both climate-smart and inclusive, taking into account the needs of all people, including those with disabilities. Treasury deputy secretary Napae Hurim and Department of National Planning and Monitoring deputy secretary Roger Kara led their departments’ participation in the tailored training. Hurim said: “Prior to this, no one really had participated in training on how to put on a climate lens and look at the proposals that were in front of us. “We hope that we can take what we have learned from this training forward and make it grow, change it, amend it to suit our local environment here in PNG,” she said. Nathan Gabriel, senior programming and monitoring officer at DNPM, who also attended the training, believes it will help to create a new generation of climate-aware decision-makers. PNG is the first country in the Pacific to secure access to the International Monetary Fund’s (IMF’s) Resilience and Sustainability Facility (RSF).THE Australian Government has been supporting training forsenior Papua New Guinean officials to assess climate disaster risks in majorinvestments before project approval through the annual budget process.Under this initiative, 53 officials from the Department ofNational Planning and Monitoring (DNPM) and the Department of Treasury – morethan a third of them women – undertook training sessions from July to lastmonth. Title: Hundreds welcome Wenge home
Content: Hundreds of people gathered at Lae’s Nadzab Tomodachi International Terminal to welcome late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge on Friday. The chartered Tropic Air flight carrying the body of late Wenge arrived at about 11am after a slight delay. The plane had a proper wash-down as it taxied down the runway with the casket of the late leader one last time. The casket was moved from the plane to the awaiting landcruiser by pallbearers from Igam Engineering Battalion, escorted by sitting members of Morobe. Cries echoed loud over the songs and chants of sorrow by students and people as they formed a body corridor leading out of Nadzab Tomodachi International Airport. He was placed in what was claimed to be his vehicle converted into a hearse and a long queue of vehicles then made the slow journey to the provincial headquarters in Lae. Wenge’s casket entered the provincial assembly chambers one final time at 5.30pm on Friday. Onga Waffa president Willie Simbisi presided over the ceremonial sitting as the acting provincial chairman. Assembly members, including Morobe MPs, and guests stood silently in respect, as the pallbearers laid the governor’s casket in the centre of the chambers. Tributes were shared for the late chairman of the assembly, where once his vibrant voice ruled. He was remembered as a political mentor to many. Watut president Waka Daimon said Wenge’s death was a big loss to Morobe. “He used to say Morobe is sitting on big resource and he fought for Morobe, so I appeal to our Morobe MPs to please carry on the job he left unfinished,” he said. “Fight for Morobe and PNG.” Nawaeb MP Theo Pelgen said Wenge was the guardian of democracy, defender of Morobe and demander of what was right. Provincial members shared condolences with the immediate family, and his political supporters. The provincial assembly chambers (Tutumang) was filled with sorrowful crying as members watched Wenge’s casket carried out by the pallbearers. As the sun set, Wenge’s body left the provincial headquarters for Hobu, the familyhaus krai, on Friday night. District visitation by chopper will begin over the weekend, continuing on to tomorrow. A public funeral mass will be held at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium on Wednesday. His body will be flown to his village in Baindoang, Nawaeb. Provincial administrator Max Bruten said materials for Wenge’s tomb had already been flown to the remote village to prepare his final resting place.

Title: Australia, PNG ink defence treaty after false start
Content: Canberra: Australia and Papua New Guinea have officially inked a mutual defence pact that commits each nation to supporting the other in the event of an armed attack. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and his counterpart James Marape signed the Pukpuk treaty, named after the local word for crocodile, at Parliament House in Canberra on Monday. It followed a false start in Port Moresby in September, when the treaty was slated to be signed at celebrations for PNG’s 50th anniversary of independence, after Marape couldn’t get the green light from his cabinet in time. “History, brother,” Albanese said as he signed the pact alongside Marape before senior ministers from both sides applauded. The treaty also paves the way for Papua New Guineans to serve in the Australian Defence Force, with Marape saying up to 10,000 citizens serve across the Arafura Sea. Australia will also help bolster PNG’s defence force, including through training and new capabilities. The treaty formalises Australia’s first alliance in more than 70 years and only its third overall, after the United States and New Zealand. Source: AAP

Title: Wenge’s casket handed over to Morobe government
Content: THE casket of the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge has been officially handed over to the Morobe government at the Tutumang Haus (provincial assembly) on Friday afternoon. The casket arrived at around 4:30pm at the provincial government. A large crowd of mourners walked in front of the convoy of vehicles from the miles area into Lae Top Town. People showed their last respects to the late governor by walking in front of the vehicle that was carrying his casket. The convoy from the Nadzab airport to Lae took around five hours. At around 5pm, the Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP, John Rosso, formally received the casket of late Wenge from the Deputy Speaker and Markham MP Koni Iguan, in the presence of Prime Minister James Marape, provincial government staff and LLG presidents as well as the people at the Tutumang Haus. The casket has departed to his Hobu in Nawaeb, to overnight with his family. On Saturday, a district visitation will begin, where his casket will be flown to all the districts in Morobe.
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Koni Iguan, Luther Wenge

Title: Public holiday as Morobe remembers Wenge
Content: A PUBLIC holiday has been declared for Morobe today as the province awaits the arrival of the body of their late Governor Luther Wenge from Port Moresby. Wenge passed away on Sept 13 at the Port Moresby General Hospital. The public holiday was declared by Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso as a show of respect as the province prepares to farewell its leader and songang. A funeral mass will be held next Wednesday at the Sir Ignatius Kilage outdoor stadium although it will not be a public holiday as it clashes with the Grade 10 national examinations. “We do not want to disrupt that for our children,” he said. “Governor Wenge as a strong advocate for education. I’m certain that he would not want the children’s exams interrupted.” The Lae Chamber of Commerce and Industry has advised its members to consider closing down today as recommended byMetropolitan Chief Superintendent Chris Kunyanban. Chamber president John Byrne said that a lot of people were expected in Lae today to join the funeral procession around the city. “The majority will be here to mourn, grieve and pay respect to the legacy of the late Governor,” he said. “But a small number will look for trouble and create potential mayhem, in the pretence of grieving, threatening or attacking business for lack of respect. “Manage your staff, production schedules. “Friday 3rd October is a public holiday for Morobe.” Prime Minister James Marape said the funeral party including immediate family members and relatives would depart Port Moresby on a charter flight at 9.45am to Lae today. The provincial government will take over the funeral programme when the body reaches Lae.
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Wenge ‘spent more time with his people than with us his family’, son says
Content: JOSHUA Wenge, the son of the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge, describes his father as a people’s leader. Joshua spoke on behalf of the family at the provincialhauskraiheld at the Sir Ignatius Kilagi Stadium in Lae attended by more than 300 staff members of the provincial government and administration. Joshua told of his late father’s dedication to his role as a leader. “Our father spent more time with his people than with us his family,” he said. He said that his family never experienced what other families enjoyed – spending time together, cracking jokes and laughing with their dads. “We could not go to see him anytime. We had to wait for him to call us if he had something to discuss with us. “That is how busy our father was. “His life was dedicated to his role as the governor. He was always surrounded by people.” Luther Akisawan Wenge, 66, was the Morobe Governor from 1997 to 2012. He was reelected in 2022. He passed away into the third year of his fourth term as governor. Provincial administrator Max Bruten said that Wenge was a national leader who fought for national issues and human rights, and sternly defended the constitution. Bruten said there were challenges but Wenge always ensured to deliver projects that would impact the people. “One thing I will remember him for is that he was a no-nonsense leader who stood firm on his decisions,” he said. “He would make a commitment and then tell me to implement it. At times when I would try to explain that there were processes, he would tell me to get it done. “So I had to deliver. “He held his people close to his heart and would always remind me to put people first no matter what.”

Title: PM calls late governor a ‘constitution defender’
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has described the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge as a “constitution defender”. “If there is one or two words we want to describe Governor Wenge for his work, something I cannot go past is his total commitment to the defence of the country’s constitution. He was truly a constitution defender,” he said. Marape said that the country must appreciate the life and work of a great statesman who in his prime had contributed much to the nation. Marape was joined by Cabinet Ministers, MPs and Government officials at the funeral service yesterday in Port Moresby. He said Wenge was instrumental in his push for provincial autonomy and played a part in getting Hela to break away and form its administration. His recent involvement was in the Governors’ conference bringing to light the decentralisation of provincial powers as a key to provincial autonomy. He was also vocal in driving a positive course for the Autonomous Region of Bougainville. “Lest we forget, for those who are living now as a nation, progressing beyond 50 years of nationhood, we must live in the same manner that the late governor lived. “Many things have been said in the eulogies and tributes that I cannot go past by his children, senior counsels and others who have described this great man. “In Parliament, he holds the record as the most outspoken leader. “We will certainly miss him. “Wenge was the type of man, a senior citizen, someone who attracted a lot of leaders from both the Government and Opposition side. “He has chaired a lot of committees from 1997 until his passing.”

Title: Downsizing Telikom part of privatisation
Content: CHIEF executive officer Amos Tepi says a downsizing exercise underway at Telikom Ltd is part of a privatisation process. He confirmed yesterday that a restructure exercise was ongoing at all departments within the state-owned entity (SOE). Tepi said Telikom had its challenges, especially the legacy issues, adding that the management is working on a “recovery, stabilise and growth” model. “Telikom has obligations to make sure we can effectively service our customers and support economic growth of the Nation. “We are working from the ground up. The restructure programme is ongoing, it is per the Government’s SOE reform agenda. “All of this is preparing for the privatisation which will be done by the shareholders. “Telikom has a bright future. I am confident once we get everything in order, we can turn the SOE around.” Tepi said Telikom is more focused on mobile, fixed line and digital transmissions as its main business. Despite the challenges, he said Telikom had achieved some positive milestones such as going paperless and launching the e-sim. “(Also) Telikom is the only SOE that complies with Internal Revenue Commission (when it comes to tax),” he said. “We want people to appreciate that their company is growing,” Tepi said. “My appeal would be for people to support their own company- Telikom.” The merger of Telikom PNG and bmobile PNG into a single entity, Telikom Limited, was approved by the Government in 2019. The merger was formally concluded in 2021. But the full restructure was not completed at that time due to pending funding availability required to implement the full post-merger restructuring programme.

Title: Treaty to strengthen defence, security deal with Australia
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has announced the approval of the Mutual Defence Treaty with Australia to elevate the two countries’ defence and security partnership. Australia has only one other mutual defence treaty of this type and at their request, Papua New Guinea will sign the treaty reflecting the depth of trust, history and shared future between the two nations, he said. Marape clarified that the treaty will undergo the Constitutional Section 117 process, with the ratification presented to parliament, while Australia will undertake its own ratifications through its parliament in Canberra. The treaty outlines step to modernise and strengthen PNG’s defence capacity across all domains: “Our Constitution is not offended by this agreement. Section 206 of our Constitution allows for our Defence Force to work in synergy with other visiting defence forces, and this treaty is consistent with that provision.” Marape said this treaty elevates relationship to the highest level, where force synergies, and capacity development for interoperability are reached. “We are geographically close and beyond geography, our people have co-existed well before 1975 and after independence. Today, Australia remains our single biggest bilateral partner, and consistent with our past, we are shaping our future.” Marape stressed that the treaty is not about geopolitics but is focused on strengthening their shared region and PNG domestic security. “This treaty allows PNG’s defence capacity to be elevated by leveraging Australian defence capabilities. This partnership strengthens our ability to respond to our country’s key security priorities. “This treaty is not just about maintaining barracks and boats. We are investing in both hardware and software for defence so that we can effectively police our borders and safeguard our nation,” Marape said. He added that both forces would train and operate side by side, but sovereignty won’t be compromised. “We also respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of our neighbours.

Title: Stop supplying guns for tribal fighting, Engan leaders told
Content: ALL leaders in Enga should be held accountable for arming tribal fights, says Attorney-General Pila Niningi. Niningi, who is Southern Highlands’ Imbonggu MP, was frank on Monday, during the opening of the four-days’ celebration of Enga Provincial Day, coinciding with the country’s golden jubilee Independence anniversary at Aipus Oval. He called on leaders in government and businesses not to support tribal fights with guns. “Enga is known for tribal fights. “Why are you doing this? You have the powers to stop that. “Blame must go to the politicians, elites and leaders in government and businesses,” he said. He said if guns are not bought, there will be no fights. “Leaders must live and act like leaders,” he added. On that note, Wabag resident National Court Judge Graham Ellis said gun users, buyers and suppliers are equally guilty of committing murder, if the weapon is used in killing. Judge Ellis said the penalty was equally hard for those in the chain flow of handling guns in tribal fights. Again yesterday, the elites of Enga took the Aipus stage, taking a strong stand on buying and use of guns. National Cultural Commission executive director Steven Kilanda said guns undermined the progress of the province, communities and families. Kilanda said although Enga was 52 years old as a province, its development heightened in the past 25 years with Governor Peter Ipatas at the helm. “I did refuse to buy guns. I’m making an appeal to all elites and leaders to refrain from buying guns in order to build sustainable lives of our people,” he said, urging everyone to support the government on Enga’s development initiatives.

Title: Port Moresby power cuts due to overloaded feeders, says PNG Power Limited
Authority launches arrival card
Content: THE Immigration and Citizenship Services Authority (ICSA) has launched the PNG Digital Arrival Card to register all travellers arriving into the country, as it works to improve border security and modernise services. Effective since Wednesday (Oct 1), the new online system will replace the old paper-based arrival cards needed upon arrival at the Jackson International Airport in Port Moresby. Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso said the initiative was part of the first phase of ICSA’s e-Border Solution Project to integrate the information of all travellers into one system. Rosso, also the Immigration and Border Security Minister, said: “The PNG Digital Arrival Card replaces the old paper arrival card with a secure, online platform. “From now onwards, passengers travelling to PNG can conveniently complete their arrival card 72 hours prior to boarding, making travel easier while also giving our border agencies faster access to accurate passenger information,” he said. He said the new system would also help the new Immigration Operations Command Centre (IOCC), a central hub for real-time intelligence and risk assessments of passenger information, which was also launched yesterday. “For the first time, Immigration, Customs, and the National Agriculture and Quarantine Inspection Authority, are fully integrated into one information system, allowing a whole-of-government approach to secure borders, faster processing, and smarter facilitation of trade and travel. “This is more than just a technological upgrade. “It is a national security priority. “By modernising our border security systems, the Government is protecting our people, strengthening trade and tourism, and ensuring that PNG remains connected to the world in a safe and secure way,” he said. Rosso commended chief migration officer Wellington Navasivu, and his team for their work in delivering this reform, and deputy chief migration officer for visa, passport and work permit, Clarence Parisau, for launching the initiatives. He said the second phase of the project would expand these capabilities even further with full interactive passenger data feeds from all airlines and sea vessels.

Title: Return of writs for Arob on Monday
Content: THE counting of votes for the Autonomous Region of Bougainville general election is wrapping up as writs are scheduled to be returned on Monday, an official says. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai toldThe Nationalyesterday that the counting process would be completed soon as only a few more seats were yet to be declared, adding that the election period was peaceful with no major incidents reported. “Declarations were done progressively across all three regions, with South Bougainville being the first to have successfully declared all its constituency members-elect, followed by Central Bougainville and North Bougainville,” he said. “The last two regional seats for women and former combatant for the North Bougainville is progressing well and will have the members-elect declared shortly. “With the extension of the return of writs to Oct 6, it provided sufficient time for us to successfully complete counting whilst maintaining quality and transparency.” Tsianai said that with counting to end soon, the overall conduct of this year’s general election was peaceful throughout the region. “There were no major incidents reported, which indicated people’s value of the democratic process and more importantly the significance of this election. “All in all, as the electoral commissioner, I am satisfied with the conduct of the general election and would say with confidence that the election was successful,” he said. Meanwhile, Tsianai said that while there were issues raised with the one-day polling conducted last month, his office would work to improve on these areas before the next election in five years. “Polling was generally peaceful and smooth, with voters turning up in numbers at booths. “Likewise, counting proceeded peacefully and smoothly. “The one-day polling model was observed to have promoted transparency and reduced double voting practices. “Despite issues raised by voters around one-day polling not being sufficient and voters not locating their names on the rolls, polling was conducted successfully. “We take these issue seriously and will endeavour to improve on these areas before the next election,” Tsianai said.

Title: Schnaubelt to remain NIP governor
Content: NEW Ireland Governor Walter Schnaubelt says only when the Electoral Commission conducts a by-election for the provincial members’ seat will he step aside from the position. Schnaubelt, who is also the Namatanai MP, was appointed as governor on Feb 28 by the provincial assembly to fill the vacancy of the seat after Sir Julius Chan passed away on Jan 30. “The power is in the hands of the Electoral Commission right now so I only wait to see what decision it will make for a by-election,” he said. “I have no authority to call for a by-election so we must all wait for the Electoral Commission. “If and when a by-election is conducted and a winner is declared, I will step aside as governor. “For now, I only await the decision of the Electoral Commission.” Schnaubelt made this known during a recent visit to the Warangansau Integrated School in the Matalai local level government area in Namatanai, following recent talks about the need for a by-election to be conducted for the governor’s seat. He added that he has no intention to contest in the by-election should it be held in the province. “If the by-election does happen, I will not contest. “I will not because of the simple fact that I am already a member of Parliament. “I am still the Namatanai MP and I have no reason to contest. “For me to contest the governor’s seat, I would have to resign as Namatanai MP, but I will not do that. “If and when a winner is declared, I will step aside as governor because the seat is for the people of New Ireland,” he said. Meanwhile, the Electoral Commission is yet to announce when a by-election will be conducted for New Ireland, including the by-elections for other districts currently without a MP.
People: Julius Chan, Sir Julius Chan, Walter Schnaubelt

Title: One dead, 3 hurt in crash
Content: A HEAD-ON collision last Saturday morning near Boinamo Gravel along the road towards the PNG University of Technology in Lae, known as “speedway”, has claimed one life and injured three others, police say. Lae metropolitan commander Chief Inspector Chris Kunyanban said police suspected alcohol was involved. “A 10-seater Toyota Land Cruiser was involved in a collision with a 26-seat bus,” he said. “The Land Cruiser was badly damaged and was lying on its side.” Kunyanban said the Land Cruiser was heading to Unitech and the bus was heading the opposite direction when they had a head-on crash. He said the driver of the Land Cruiser is believed to have died in hospital. Kunyanban said since June road accidents in Lae were related to alcohol.

Title: UPNG told to ensure proper accreditation for courses
Content: THE University of Papua New Guinea (UPNG) administration has been urged to ensure its academic programmes are accredited to international professional qualifications and standards. Minister for Higher Education, Research, Science, Technology and Sports, Kinoka Feo, made this known when he met with vice-chancellor Professor Ian Findlay and others at the university’s Waigani campus in Port Moresby on Wednesday. The other six objectives that Feo urged the UPNG administration to achieve were to: Feo said he had the support of Prime Minister James Marape and Treasury Minister Ian Ling-Stuckey to secure international development financing to invest in UPNG and other State universities. Feo noted a recent Kramer Ausenco report estimating a total cost of between K1.4 billion and K1.9 billion required to rehabilitate UPNG’s current infrastructure and facilities. Feo also committed to secure immediate funding for UPNG’s information and communication Technology (ICT) infrastructure, systems and training programme in the 2026 Budget. He acknowledged the critical need for staff home ownership and committed to supporting UPNG on this as well. Feo recognised these and other challenges that will be addressed through UPNG’s “Reconstruction and Modernisation Programme” currently being prepared. He also called on UPNG’s leadership and management to take bold and decisive action, particularly on “core business” of increasing access and using assets to resource UPNG.

Title: K615 million parliament budget submission
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape met with Job Pomat this week when the speaker presented Parliament’s 2026 Budget submission of over K615 million. Pomat emphasised that the legislature, as one of the three arms of Government, should receive the same level of diligence and support as the executive and judiciary, further elaborating that parliament by law is a very important symbol of Governance and Law Enactment for the nation and should be given priority in terms of funding support. He underscored that funding Parliament’s operations and infrastructure was essential to strengthening PNG’s democracy. Marape welcomed the submission and commended the speaker’s leadership in ensuring Parliament was adequately resourced to meet present and future needs. “Our Parliament is not just another building. It is the very ‘Seat of Papua New Guinea’s Democracy’. As we celebrate our 50th Independence Anniversary, we must honour and invest in the institution that embodies the voice of our people,” Marape said. He noted that the Government had demonstrated strong commitment to the judiciary through the construction of the new National Court Complex, and pledged that similar support will be extended to the Legislature, in particular the national parliament. Marape added that his Government had invested more than K400 million over the last six years since taking Office towards supporting the judiciary, culminating in the completion of the court complex that housed both the Supreme and National Courts. He stressed that substantial support in similar fashion be mobilised to maintain and expand parliament. The 2026 Budget submission includes provisions for physical renovations to Parliament House, an ICT systems upgrade for a “Paperless Parliament,” and operational support to strengthen the capacity of MPs and parliamentary staff, as well as Parliament library and archives.

Title: Madang taking steps to cut vehicle hire costs
Content: MADANG Governor Ramsey Pariwa says the provincial government is taking steps to cut vehicle hire expenses. Pariwa said this when receiving the keys to four new vehicles bought from Ela Motors this week for office and administrative purposes. “This is part of investing in re-fleeting our aging fleet and to cut down on vehicle hires which has been an unnecessary strain on the provincial administration spending,” he said. The vehicles include a truck for Trans-Gogol Secondary School, a land cruiser for Bogia District Fisheries, a Toyota hilux for the governor’s office administration use and a four-door land cruiser project vehicle. “The past and previous governments have not invested in vehicles for senior officials and provincial public servants to use to serve our people,” Pariwa said. “I do not know but probably former leaders enjoyed the privileges of cuts and funding from hire cars and that is why they have turned a blind eye on getting new vehicles. “These are the first batch of vehicles; the second batch will arrive in due course as back order have been placed.” Prior to this purchase, Madang acting administrator Daniel Aloi, through the administration, bought four new Suzuki’s for its administration. Pariwa applauded Aloi for taking the lead in cutting back costs in regard to vehicle hire and use from private business owners in Madang. “The vehicles are handy for public servants to use in the districts to serve the people in various sectors,” the governor said. He thanked Ela Motors for working in collaboration with MPG in ensuring the vehicles arrived on time.

Title: City authority undertakes clean-up exercise in ENB’s Kokopo
Content: A MAJOR compliance and clean-up exercise following the permanent closure of the unauthorised Kokopo’s Kenabot market was carried out by East New Britain’s Kokopo City Authority (KCA) last Friday. The operation, carried out at Top Brat Trading (TBT) Limited Blanche Bay, opposite the Gunan Na Niuvia training facility in the Takubar area, temporarily halted business activities in order to restore the area to proper standards. The “clean-a-thon” was led by the Kokopo-Vunamami urban local level government (KVULLG) in partnership with Physical Planning, Police, the Internal Revenue Commission (IRC), and the Fire Service. It followed the permanent closure of the unauthorised Kenabot market. At Kenabot, officers and vendors worked together to clean the site, which will remain closed until the new designated market opens. Acting city manager Alkan Mararang said the initiative was part of ongoing compliance checks aimed at improving health and safety in Kokopo. “Today, our team worked alongside market vendors and businesses to clean the front of shops, the market, and the service station at the TBT Blanche Bay,” he said. “We cleared rubbish and betelnut waste, opened drains, and installed extra rubbish bins to keep the area clean.” The team also enforced restrictions on cooked food sales, citing health risks from dust exposure along the four-lane highway. For now, only betel nut and tobacco sales are allowed at the site. Mararang praised KVULLG officers and partner agencies for their cooperation, adding that regular compliance operations will continue to maintain Kokopo’s image as a clean, safe and orderly town. KVULLG environmental health officer Ekonia Walom Jnr said continuous checks would ensure public compliance with city regulations. He added that the team also inspected the Kokopo beachfront boat stop, where plans were underway to enforce rules to maintain order.

Title: Morobe prepares to receive late Governor Wenge’s body
Content: LATE Morobe Governor Luther Wenge’s casket is expected to arrive at the Nadzab Tomodachi International Terminal at around 11am today on a Tropic Air flight. Hundreds of people from across Morobe and neighbouring provinces including the Highlands region have gathered at the airport to welcome him. Wenge will be received by an official party and family and escorted by convoy to Lae. He will be brought to the Morobe Provincial Headquarters, met by the chief mourner – Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso. By midday, Deputy Speaker and Markham MP Koni Iguan representing the Parliament, will handover late Wenge’s body to Rosso, who will then announce the provincial mourning period. A wake will be held at the Lae International Hotel then a ceremonial sitting at Tutumang for the provincial assembly members to pay their last respects to Wenge as the assembly chairman. “It is a formality for respect to the governor,” said Rosso. Late Wenge’s casket will then be driven around the city for the public to pay their final respects. The casket will then depart Lae for Hobu, Nawaeb, to overnight at his family residence for the last time. A four-day district visitation starts on Saturday to Tuesday, where the casket of the late governor will be airlifted to all the districts of Morobe, for the people to pay their respects.Visitations starts with Menyamya, Bulolo and Houn Gulf on Saturday, Tewai-Siassi and Finschaffen on Sunday, and Kabwum, Wasu and Siassi on Monday.The district visitation continues on Tuesday to Markham and Nawaeb before the final funeral service on Wednesday at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium in Lae.After the public funeral mass, his body will be flown to his village in Baindoang, Nawaeb to rest.
People: John Rosso, Koni Iguan, Luther Wenge

Title: Cabinet approves defence treaty, awaits Parliament’s ratification
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape on Thursday confirmed that Cabinet has formally approved the landmark Mutual Defence Treaty between Papua New Guinea and Australia, elevating the two countries’ defence and security partnership to its highest level in history. Marape clarified that the treaty would undergo the constitutional Section 117 process, with the ratification presented to Parliament, while Australia will undertake its own ratification through its Parliament in Canberra. “Our Constitution is not offended by this agreement. Section 206 of our Constitution allows for our Defence Force to work in synergy with other visiting defence forces, and this treaty is consistent with that provision,” Marape said. Marape said for Defence, PNG operated under a Status of Forces Agreement after independence and, in 2013, signed a Defence Cooperation Agreement with Australia. “Now this treaty elevates our relationship to the highest level, where force synergies, and capacity development for interoperability is reached. Australia is our foundational relationship country,” he said. “We are geographically close and beyond geography, our people have coexisted well before 1975 and after independence. “Today, Australia remains our single biggest bilateral partner, and consistent with our past, we are shaping our future.” The treaty outlines steps to modernise and strengthen PNG’s defence capacity across all domains: • NAVY and Maritime Security: Increased capacity to police PNG’s vast maritime borders; • AIR Wing and Air Defence: Enhanced air force capacity through new capabilities and training; • INFANTRY and Land Battalions: Strengthened land forces and the establishment of special forces arrangements; and, • RESERVE and National Guard: Development of 3,000 reservists and national volunteers, with provisions for up to 10,000 Papua New Guineans to serve with the Australian Defence Force under dual arrangements, while PNG builds its own 7,000-strong Defence Force. “This treaty is not just about maintaining barracks and boats. We are investing in both hardware and software for defence so that we can effectively police our borders and safeguard our nation,” Marape said.

Title: Kaeok ‘only appealed’ to the two warring tribes
Content: WAPENAMANDA MP Miki Kaeok yesterday told the National Court in Wabag, Enga, that he had only appealed to the two warring tribes in the district to stop fighting – and nothing more. Appearing before National Court resident judge Graham Ellis, Kaeok said that since the tribal fighting began on Aug 15 after the killing of a man, he had taken minimal initiatives to stop the fight between the Yangakun and Yakuman tribes. Judge Ellis then asked provincial administrator Sandis Tsaka whether a provincial law and order committee existed. He ordered the committee to provide to the court a report on what it is doing to stop the tribal fight. He also ordered Tsaka to submit that report to the court on or before Friday, Oct 10. Judge Ellis wants the report to specify the progress made in restoring peace between the two tribes, and what remains to be done in the peace process. Wapanemanda lawyer Joe Yapao also provided the court details of how the tribal fight started. Yapao requested the court to summon all elected leaders of Enga, including Governor Peter Ipatas, to tell the inquiry of their part in securing peace for Wapanemanda and Enga. He also requested that the Court order a ban on the sale and consumption of alcohol in Enga. Judge Ellis used his powers under the constitution as regards human rights to initiate the Human Rights Own Initiative inquiry. The first hearing was held on Sept 25 where all provincial leaders were summoned to give evidence on the fight and its impact on education and National Court hearings.

Title: Telikom continues restructure
Content: TELIKOM Limited has started the second phase of its restructure programme, which may mean the retrenchment of some workers, following the merger of Telikom PNG and Bmobile, it has been revealed. Chief executive officer Amos Tepi said in a statement: “Change that involves people’s jobs is always complicated, and we have done everything we can to accommodate all of our personnel. “As part of the merger and restructure, there are staff that will no longer stay with the company. Retrenchment and retirement announcements were given to staff during the town hall meetings in 2022, 2023, and last year, and during the recent (one) on Sept 12, that came into effect on Sept 26, through official staff notices.” Tepi said that as a business, “we have a legal requirement to retire staff when they reach the age above 55”. He said that retrenchments were largely due to the change in specialist roles, and the evolving of technology in telecommunications. “I feel for the families of staff (members) that have left the company. “The providers for families have responsibilities to meet, and advance warning and support has been provided to assist in their transition from the company,” Tepi said. However, Tepi said Telikom also had obligations to effectively serve its customers. “This is why we have ensured that all staff retrenched and retired have received the benefits to which they are entitled,” he said. “For those retrenched, Telikom will do all we can to help you find new employment.” The merger of Telikom PNG and Bmobile PNG into a single entity, Telikom Limited, was approved by the Government in 2019. The merger was formally concluded in 2021. Phase One (2022): Aligning Bmobile staff salaries with Telikom’s salary cap for consistency, while maintaining the existing headcount. Phase Two (2025): The retrenchment programme supporting staff transition into retirement, resolving duplicate roles in the merged entity, and addressing performance- related matters. Phase Three: To focus on further optimisation and strengthening of the company’s operational and commercial model.

Title: Inquiry into standard, integrity of journalism set for next week
Content: THE parliamentary committee on communications will conduct a two-day inquiry into the standard and integrity of journalism next week. Committee chairman and Wau-Waria MP Marsh Narewec said the inquiry wanted to promote responsible, ethical, and high-quality journalism. It will also address challenges faced by the media industry. “The (committee) under the authority of Parliament is conducting a final inquiry into the standard and integrity of journalism in Papua New Guinea,” he said. “This is a vital opportunity for all to contribute to strengthening the country’s media environment and restoring public trust. “The committee will explore ways to enhance journalism education, regulation, and professional practice. “Your participation will help shape the future of a professional, responsible, and trusted media sector which is essential for democracy, good governance, transparency, and national unity.” It is scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday at the Parliament House State Function Room in Port Moresby. A workshop will be held at the same venue on Tuesday for media practitioners, civil society organisations, government representatives, academics, and stakeholders. The committee’s terms of reference are on the: Narewec said that records from the two-day inquiry, including written submissions made, would assist the committee’s recommendations to Parliament to strengthen the media industry and protect public interest.

Title: Hiri-Koiari’s Ruth Elijah claims Miss Central title
Content: MISS Bird of Paradise Central Ruth Elijah says there is a lot of work to be done in Central. Elijah, who entered the pageant as Miss Hiri-Koiari, beat four other women to be crowned Queen of Central in Port Moresby on Sunday night. The other contestants were Miss Kairuku Kimjosh Damuri, Miss Rigo Dolores Lamond, Miss Abau Bonita Vaihere and Miss Goilala Sharisse Ila. Elijah, originally from Saroa village in Central’s Rigo district, said she was filled with “joy and excitement.” “It has been a great joy being in this pageant. A journey of learning not just about dresses, shoes or how to walk but learning about how to get the work done back at home,” she said. “There is a need for our people back home that is why it prompts people like us to have the voice to represent them,” Elijah said. She said she carried her title with gratitude for everyone who helped her during the pageant. Miss Bird of Paradise pageant founder Anna Bais said the pageantry was “the beginning of the rise of our daughters from Central, who will use their voices, strength and purpose to uplift our people, our province and our nation.” Bais, who is the former Department for Community Development and Religion secretary, said the pageant was founded on Sept 4, 2023 with the aim to nurture young women leaders. She added that the pageant was also aimed to have women from the 22 provinces. “We did not want Miss PNG to be a Port Moresby-based event. We wanted young women out there (in provinces) to look here (Port Moresby) and see that they can represent our nation as a young woman leader,” Bais said. She added that the national contest will be held in Port Moresby on Dec 3 which is also International Day of Persons with Disabilities. “Miss Bird of Paradise places special attention on educational opportunities for children with disability, aligning leadership with service,” Bais said. “Whoever is crowned Miss Bird of Paradise in December, her province will be the host of the next pageant. This is our contribution to boost local tourism in the country.”

Title: Tomala recalls late Wenge’s ability to correct but keep team united
Content: A FORMER Morobe administrator, Kemas Tomala, says there is a need for leaders who can maintain a workable relation between politics and administration. Tomala said the late Governor Luther Wenge was one of the few politicians who had such a skill. Tomala was appointed provincial administrator in 2010 during Wenge’s earlier term He said Wenge as someone who would correct you on the spot for doing wrong then forgive you immediately after and work with you. “We need more leaders like this – someone who could expose wrong and give you a chance to better yourself,” he said. “Wenge reigned with strong leadership and he helped develop PNG as a whole, not just Morobe.” Tomala implemented the policies and visions of Wenge. He noted the concrete road concept in Lae, the extension of Nadzab Airport by 600m and the Lae Tidal Basin Development. “Many people may not know that these were Wenge’s handiwork. He was a visionary.” Tomala was part of the Huon Gulf group who visited the state haus krai at the Sir Iganatius Kilage Stadium. Huon Gulf MP Jason Peter and district staff were part of the group. Peter said Wenge was a mentor and a strong political figure to him and the new MPs from Morobe. “All MPs from East Morobe were new politicians – myself (Huon Gulf), Menyamya, Bulolo and Wau-Waria,” he said. “Wenge was our voice of strength in parliament. “He was pushing to move the provincial capital from Lae into our district – Nadzab in Wampar. “My people thanked him for all his contributions to our district.” The state haus krai started last week, open to provincial groups, business houses and groups wishing to pay their last respects to the family, sharing food and cash contributions. Yesterday was dedicated to Morobe, where all districts and their MPs visited. Wenge’s body will arrive at Nadzab at 10.45am tomorrow on a Tropic Air flight.

Title: Students pay respect with ‘walk of sorrow’
Content: ABOUT 900 tertiary students studying under the Gerson Solulu Scholarship Scheme did a walk of sorrow to show respect for Governor Luther Wenge. This solidarity walk was led by the Morobe Tertiary Students Union (MTSU) club, with higher institutions like PNG University of Technology and National Polytechnic Institution of PNG. They started the walk at Eriku Oval, went through Lae Top Town and walked down to Sir Ignatius Kilage Stadium where the Haus Krai (wake) is based. Students were joined by staff of respective institutions as well as the alumnae of MTSU, who benefitted from the scholarship, and students from other provinces. They were covered in red soil and wore black to symbolise mourning, respect, and solemnity. Speeches by representatives of each institution described Wenge as a “fatherly figure”, the “voice of the voiceless” and a “nation builder”. Many remembered Wenge as an advocate for education, who supported the state’s policy of leaving no child behind, and implemented it with scholarships. Students were thankful for the scholarship established in 2002, under Wenge and implemented in 2004. They said Wenge was a visionary leader who knew that supporting education would lead to development of Morobe and the country. Tabitha Wosse, a staff member at the PNGUoT, a Morobean and a recipient of the scholarship, on behalf of the former students and parents of Morobe, acknowledged the support Wenge had shown through the scholarship, which had helped many people.

Title: Bird sees eviction as answer to stop fighting
Content: EAST Sepik Governor Allan Bird says they will be looking at a possible eviction for Saksak and Nuigo compounds in Wewak due to continuous fights and killings over many years. Bird confirmed police were on site yesterday attending to another fight between the groups that put innocent lives of students and health workers at risk. “Police are dealing with it now,” he said. “The problem between Saksak and Nuigo compounds has been going on for a number of years and despite many efforts by myself and Wewak MP Stanley Muts Samban and the police to intervene, there has been so many peace gatherings and things like that and it’s not working. “We are going to have to look at evictions next, that’s something that we are exploring at the moment.” Bird said they’ve got to move one or both groups out – that’s the only way locals can have lasting peace in the area and resolve the issues. He added that the issues are long standing and go back many, many years. “There’s been fights between the two groups and people have been killed,” he added. “It doesn’t seem to show any signs of being resolved.” Attempts to get comments from Samban and police commander Chief Insp Christopher Tamari to confirm other details of yesterday’s fight were unsuccessful. According to reports byThe National, the fights go way back to 2014 when both compounds had been attacking each other. Bird said police made sure they were on site yesterday to control the situation before it got out of hand.

Title: Yangoru-Saussia works on solutions to power supply problem, says Maru
Content: YANGORU-SAUSSIA in East Sepik is working on immediate and long-term solutions to permanently improve power supply in the district. “The continuous power blackouts has to be a thing of the past. Our people, businesses, schools, churches, public servants and Government services like health centres and our banks cannot continue to experience power blackouts,” said local MP Richard Maru. In the last three months, the district has experienced total power blackouts because of fallen power poles. Maru met with the PNG Power Ltd chief executive officer (CEO) Paul Bayly to discuss this and he promised to send his chief technical officer, Anthony Koiri, to visit the district next week to see the state of the power lines and poles that had fallen and have the situation fixed so power can be restored as soon as practical. Koiri will be visiting the Haripmo Power Station which Yangoru-Saussia District Development Authority (DDA) is constructing under the supervision of PNG Power Limited. The contractor is Pacific Energy Support Services Limited. “We will have two 600kva generators installed at Haripmo Power Station so we can have standby power supply for the district from Japaraka to Wingei when there is a blackout from the Wewak Grid,” Maru said. He further stated that a memorandum of understanding (MoU) will be signed between the DDA and their long-term partners to build a new hydro at the Pangu village in the Sikau Range to provide a cheaper, clean and reliable long-term power solution for Yangoru-Saussia District. “The MoU for the Sikau Hydro Project will be signed this Friday in Port Moresby between the Yangoru-Saussia DDA and the project partners including PNG Power Limited, Pacific Energy Support Services Limited, and the Sikau Holdings Inc Land Group, representing the landowners,” he said. “I am very happy for the commitment by Bayly for PNG Power Limited to be a signatory to the MoU and to be an equity partner in the proposed hydro project in the Sikau Range in East Yangoru.” Maru said after the signing, the partners will fund the full feasibility studies for the project to be carried out by Snowy Mountains Engineering Company from Australia.

Title: Madang police ‘ready’ to assist LLG elections
Content: MADANG police are ready to help the Electoral Commission carry out the local level government election towards the end of this month, says police commander acting Supt Robert Baim. While making this announcement, Baim also warned that police will not hesitate to arrest anyone trying to disrupt the LLG election. “We have delivered a successful by-election for Usino-Bundi in August with help from our counterparts and we did the same for the 50th independence anniversary,” he said. “So for this LLG election, we will maintain our partnership with EC to deliver it.” Baim urged people in Madang to vote carefully for the leaders that that will represent them at the LLG and ward level and not to cling onto those that will provide them with favors or briberies. “Let us consider the future of our generations to come when making your choice for who you would like to lead you at this level of the government,” he said. Baim said for the better outcome of the LLG election at the provincial level, people had to be abide by laws governing their conducts and work closely with police and other government security forces that were assigned to provide security during the election. “People have the power to decide their own future by choosing vibrant leaders during elections,” he said. “From what we have learnt in the past, let us decide the best we can have and that has to be done in a peaceful, fair and just election.” Baim also warned candidates for president and ward councilor seats to mind their actions and words at this time, as if these were seen to be against the law they can be arrested and charged as well. Meanwhile, Madang electoral commission cannot be reached for the confirmation of how many LLGs and wards in total in the province.

Title: Nine Solomon Island magistrates join regional training
Content: NINE magistrates from the Solomon Islands (SI) yesterday joined magistrates of Papua New Guinea for a three-day regional magistrates’ judicial orientation programme in Port Moresby. The orientation programme aims at helping magistrates to administer law and justice to everyone who comes to their courts. Chief Magistrate of PNG Mark Pupaka, in his opening remarks, said there had been a couple of instances where magistrates from SI had participated in basic mediation skills training, and this was one of them. “To my knowledge, there was one instance where there have been cooperated participation in the orientation programme. “This programme sees how resources can be used to prepare our magistrates to be better on the bench and conduct around ethics of things off-bench,” Pupaka said. The three-day programme is facilitated by PNG Centre for Judicial Excellence under the oversight of the National Judicial Staff Services. Participants are magistrates and judicial officers, who will be taken through sessions under the contexts of the legal system, case types most relevant to magistrates, institutional context, and wellbeing and integrity. Pupaka challenged the magistrates to take the best from the programme. He said magistrates had taken an oath to uphold the law and understand conflicts to resolve them in an impartial way. “The takeaway from this programme is to principally uphold integrity and ethics as a judicial officer. So that is what we will do,” he said. The programme will end tomorrow.

Title: Mt Hagen cops urged to uphold policing values
Content: MT Hagen police on Monday observed Police Remembrance Day with the message of upholding the values of policing. Highlands eastern-end commander Clement Dalla, in his invocation, urged the officers not only to remember their fallen comrades who died while performing their duties, but also to reflect on who they are in the Papua New Guinea Royal Constabulary. Dalla said the remembrance day was a significant tradition for police. “In remembering our fallen comrades who have made the ultimate sacrifice while performing their duties, we also embrace their strength and that of their families and relatives, have gratitude for the work police officers are doing, and create unity among   officers which is a value of good policing,” Dalla said. “They stood there in times of danger and uncertainty. “Behind every death, there is a story of sacrifice. “We wish to acknowledge the families and colleagues of those who died. We stand with you in grief, and in pride of the profession we uphold, that is justice, integrity and duty.” Dalla also acknowledged those who were still serving, and thanked them for wearing the uniform with pride and honour. “Your commitment gives the freedom and security which everyone enjoys, and often people take it for granted,” he said. “We remember the fallen and allow their spirit of service to remain in us as we continue to protect the lives of our people.” Provincial commander Chief Superintendent John Sagom called out a few names of police officers who died last year in the course of their duties. Those whose names that were mentioned on behalf of the many were Senior Constable Jack Kitan (Mt Hagen police), Napoleon Wagambie (Port Moresby), Constable Keith Anthony Smith (Australia), Paul Mailelia (Solomon Islands), and Senior Sergeant Lyn Fleming (New Zealand).

Title: University opens new units to address staff housing woes
Content: PNG University of Natural Resources and Environment (PNGUNRE) has opened its new six–unit flats last Saturday at its East New Britain’s Vudal main campus to help minimise the staff accommodation issue. PNGUNRE vice chancellor Prof Aisak Pue said the new building would mostly accommodate academic staff who were temporarily living at the university’s Kairak Guest House. Department of National Planning and Monitoring funded the project for K2.5 million under its Public Investment Programme (PIP) funds. Prof Pue said many new develpments were taking place at the university with support from the University Council the opening of the new building was one example of these developments. Prof Pue outlined some of the new developments which include:

Title: Marape urges citizens to contribute to PNG’s growth
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says they have two more big international meetings to attend, the COP30 and APEC 2025. He said: “We just celebrated 50 years of nationhood and you don’t have to be a prime minister to contribute to the country’s growth. “Everyone in the public service are asked to contribute and lift their game and all of us in the society too. “One per cent must do the job but the 99 per cent wherever we are, we must work.” Marape said it was painful to see young people engaged in lawlessness by carrying guns brought to them by others who did not live in the village. “Many children are out there in the frontlines of tribal conflicts, persons that buy guns and give them have poisoned them,” he said. “The Government is investing a lot in the court system, police and the Papua New Guinea Defence Force. “We are investing in them not to come and harass and intimidate you rather to protect you.” He urged people to take disputes to nearest villages, district courts and to police stations.

Title: Marape advocates for environment and peace
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape advocated for forest conservation, climate change and peace at the 80th United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) last week in New York, United States. Marape in a press conference on Tuesday said though many might have felt that these conversations were unnecessary to PNG, being on earth exposed the country to anything. “Sitting at the table and discussing issues to find peace can be an alternative instead of using guns as a means to achieve peace. We also support Israel on stopping the conflict in Gaza if the hostages are released,” he said. “Those who hold carbon footprints must offset them by helping us in conservation of our forests and sustainable management of our ocean resources.” Marape said PNG was a unique country that had low lying coastal areas that were exposed to rising sea levels. He said the upcoming UN Climate Change Conference (COP30) in Belem, Brazil on Nov 10-21 would be a platform for assistance in forest conservation. “On Sept 22, I took part in the USA Pacific Business Forum where Pacific Island leaders were brought together. I did indicate to the forum that we are focused on business ourselves,” he said. “We’re not focused on aid and grants anymore, we rather deal with trade than aid and grants. “We did invite US manufacturers in fisheries, forestry and agriculture and even mineral, gas, and oil sectors to look at PNG with possibility of taking up space in our special economic zones,” he said. He said the climate change meetings focusing on forest conservation were held on Sept 23-24. Marape said during the Pacific Islands Forum meeting in Tonga, they established the Pacific Resilient Fund for climate change related activities and in that meeting US$162 milion (about K300 million) was raised with Australia contributing the most.

Title: PNG could be losing K3.8 billion to gold smuggling annually
Content: PAPUA New Guinea could be losing up to US$900 million (about K3.8 billion) worth of gold smuggled out of the country every year, according to East Sepik Governor Allan Bird. He gave his view after the Special Parliamentary Committee on Public Sector Reform and Service Delivery hearing in Port Moresby on Monday which highlighted the challenges affecting the country’s alluvial gold mining industry. Bird, a committee member, said it was a shock to learn that there were many public service institutional gaps that allowed gold smuggling to rise over the years. “Up to 2020, with no mechanised alluvial mining, PNG had an annual export of 120,000 ounces of gold per year,” he said. “In 2023, our alluvial gold exports dropped to 40,000 ounces.” He said evidence from importers overseas suggested that at least 80,000 ounces were being smuggled out of the country. “This represents a loss of US$300 million (about K1.2 billion) in foreign reserves for our country every year,” he said. “My suspicion is that the loss is greater than this. It could be three times higher given the massive investment in mechanised mining in the sector. “If that is indeed the case, then PNG could be losing up to US$900 million (about K3.8 billion) every year.” Bird said that the smuggling contributed to the weakness in the Kina affecting everyone buying imported goods. “ Bank of PNG currently holds US$3.2 billion (about K13 billion) in foreign reserves. “We are losing US$300 million (about K1.2 billion) a year, that’s the equivalent of 10 per cent of our reserves. Bird said the committee would make recommendations to strengthen the country’s public service systems to stop gold smuggling as the hearings continue. “Our State agencies lack the capacity to, inspect, identify or prosecute the offenders. “We suspect that our local landowners could also be treated unfairly by some of these operators due to a lack of policing by our agencies who lack capacity. “Some of these smugglers are known to authorities but they have not been prosecuted and are operating unhindered. Committee chairman and Northern Governor Gary Juffa said it was alarming that more than two tonnes of gold were smuggled out of the country in 2021 and 2022. “Alluvial mining is a vital economic sector and a major economic activity in PNG,” he said. “The widespread presence of alluvial gold indicates the potential for the sector to develop into one of the most successful small-medium scale enterprise ventures. “We have seen that investments are increasing in this sector, yet production has been decreasing over the years. “An intervention is needed to address these serious issues concerning foreign involvement and compliance.

Title: State wants Yafai to serve 42 years for crimes
Content: THE State has submitted to the National Court that the former deputy Finance secretary Jacob Yafai be sentenced to 10 years on each of the four counts of misappropriation, and two years for abuse of office. State prosecutor Linda Maru told Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika who is presiding over the case in the National Court that suspending the sentence was out of the question. “It is submitted that suspension of sentence is not appropriate in this case,” she said. Yafai, from Karapia village in Yangoru-Saussia, East Sepik, was convicted on four counts each of official corruption, abuse of office, conspiracy to defraud and misappropriation of four cheques totalling K41.8 million paid to Paul Paraka Lawyers in 2012-2013. His lawyer Edward Sasingian from Sasingian Lawyers submitted that the sentences for the four counts of misappropriation and one count of abuse of office should be served concurrently. “It is our submission that the head sentence is appropriately 10 years as the starting point for the charge of misappropriation and a head sentence of two years is appropriate for the charge of abuse of office,” he said. Sasingian said the next thing for the court to do was to decide whether the sentence should be cumulative or concurrent because of the multiple convictions. “The reason being that Yafai did not benefit from this offence. He has been convicted which is already a punishment in itself, and the conviction he will carry for his lifetime even though it was never his idea to commit this offence in the very first place,” he said. Sir Gibbs reserved his decision on sentence to a later date. “Bail is extended until the ruling on sentence,” he said.

Title: Vanimo orchestra wins hearts at national event
Content: AN orchestra made up of children from Vanimo in West Sepik are thankful that they were able to take part during the independence golden jubilee celebration in Port Moresby. Catholic priest Fr Miguel de la Calle, the Queen of Paradise Children’s Orchestra programme co-founder and president, said that the organisers greatly appreciated the young members. “It was something incredible for the boys and girls who grew up in villages in Vanimo to represent their province at the national level in an historic event,” he said. “It was certainly the most important stage for our newly- born orchestra. “We were told that we were included in the programme and that we would have the first 30 minutes of the national event at the Sir John Guise Stadium on Sept 16.” Fr Miguel said they had to find a sponsor for the airfares of the 27 members of the orchestra since there was no government assistance. “Finding a sponsor to pay for our plane tickets was the hardest part. But at the last minute, God sent us a sponsor, and we were able to come to Port Moresby,” he said. “We prepared the orchestra in four days of intense rehearsals each lasting three to five hours. “When we left, we had only planned for the stadium concert on Sept 16. But the orchestra ended up playing six concerts in just five days. “We look forward to the future, hoping to soon be able to undertake our first international tour.” Fr Miguel said the people were surprised as was evident in the applause that the children received after each piece. There were invitations to play in other parts of PNG which they are looking forward to. “Our next project is to find donors to transform the string orchestra into a symphonic orchestra, that is, to add a wind section,” Fr Miguel said. “Those instruments are much more expensive and we need help from institutions, businesses, or the PNG government.”

Title: Central church group on two-week tour of ENB’s Kokopo
Content: A GROUP from Port Moresby’s ReaRea United Church travelled to East New Britain’s Kokopo on an educational tour. The ReaRea congregation is within the West Redscar Circuit and is one of the largest congregations in the West Central Papuan region. The group made up mostly of women from the church’s ministry, together with five children and four men, totalling 90, chose East New Britain for their tour. This was the first time they travelled locally. Past tours had been to other countries, especially Australia. The group flew in to Kokopo two weeks ago and spent independence anniversary in the province, residing at the Kenabot United Church. Pastor and congregation Minister Rev. Doura Vai, said many of the women in the ministry had not flown on a plane or seen other places, so they decided to take them to Kokopo. Apart from sight-seeing, the educational tour was aimed at socialising and educating the group about the Methodist background, which contrasts with what they grew up knowing; the London Missionary Society (LMS) teachings. “The Methodist and LMS came together and formed the United Church. That’s the reason we came here, so that we can learn from each other,” he explained. He also noted another reason for coming to ENB was to celebrate the 50 independence anniversary away from home. “We are so glad that the organising committee here inserted us to be part of the celebration which we celebrated at Kokopo’s Malapau Beach Resort and then on Sept 16, we all went down to Kalabond,” Vai said. Some of the activities that were carried out during their stay included, exchanging of baskets or gifts with women from the Kenabot United Church congregation, Bible studies, devotions, learning how to cook local dishes, and sightseeing. Vai expressed great appreciation and joy for the experience of spending two weeks in Kokopo. “We are more than happy because all the ekalesia here at the Kenabot United Church have looked after us well,” he said, noting that the atmosphere and environment in the province made it feel like home.

Title: Parliament outcome on Bougainville not the end, says PM
