Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says whatever the outcome is after parliament’s deliberation on the Bougainville referendum for independence in 2027, it will not be a dead end. “I cannot pre-empt the parliamentary process outcomes but the process is running, we have established undertaking already to the Era Kone Covenant within this term of Parliament,” he said. “The result must be brought into parliament for parliament’s deliberations.” Marape said he had given his assurance to the Bougainville government many times not to fear what parliament will do. “I want to appreciate the Bougainville leadership for the 2001 peace agreement and part of the Constitution is quite explicit, making reference to section 342 sub section 2 of the Constitution that prescribes that parliament will make decision,” he said. “We will not be ignorant to the overwhelming majority to decide for independence. Section 342 sub section one of the Constitution talks about post-referendum consultations.” He said Bougainville will not be a one morning pickup and disappear from the map. “We are here perpetually forever and so it is in our shared interest to firstly maintain peace and secondly to find solutions that are born again from within. “Whatever the outcome of parliament is, it will not be a dead end for Bougainville if parliament says yes to independence then it will be processed and if it says no then again we will process something that is good for Bougainville,” he told The National. “I cannot indicate the mindset of parliament subject to the process, whilst it’s being brought to parliament to handle this one. “But one assurance is that it’s not a dead end. “PNG owes much to Bougainville. We also had soldiers who died and relatives of the soldiers who died. “It’s a delicate situation but credit must go to where it’s due – to the authors of the peace agreement of which President Ishmael Toroama was one.”

Title: Huon Gulf people honour Wenge
Content: HUON Gulf, among the other districts in Morobe, joined the people in paying tribute to their late Governor Luther Wenge at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Indoor Complex Stadium in Lae. The day of mourning began with a walk from the district headquarters to the stadium, where his haus krai is based, symbolising the people’s journey of respect and remembrance for him. In a strong show of unity, headmasters, teachers and students from across the district took part in the tribute, including delegations from Salamaua High School, Zifazing Junior High School and several other schools. Their participation highlighted the late governor’s legacy as a leader who championed education and youth empowerment in Morobe. Also in attendance were people from, Salamaua, Morobe, Wampar Rural and Wampar Urban LLGs, together with their LLG managers, sectorial managers and members of the general public from Huon Gulf. Representatives also came from ungazetted Wampar Urban locations such as Igam Barracks and West Taraka, reflecting the unity of both formal and informal communities honouring Wenge. The district presented food supplies and cash donations as a gesture of respect and solidarity with the Wenge family and the people of Morobe during this time of mourning. The official tribute programme was observed from 11am to noon, marked by speeches. Wenge is remembered for his unwavering leadership, his advocacy for the people of Morobe and his remarkable contributions to development across the province. Speaking on behalf of the district, local MP Jason Peter reaffirmed the district’s deep respect for the governor’s legacy. “Governor Wenge was not only a leader for Morobe but a fatherly figure to all of us,” he said. “His vision and commitment will continue to inspire the district and the province for generations to come.” The district extends its heartfelt condolences to the Wenge family and the people of Morobe as they mourn the passing of a great leader.

Title: ‘Peace must be authentic’: Marape says peace will settle Palestine, Israel issue
Content: PAPUA New Guinea was part of 10 countries that voted against a two-state solution during the 80th United National General Assembly as a means to settle the ongoing dispute between Israel and Palestine. Prime Minister James Marape said the rationale was simple – unless and until you have peace – everything else comes after. “Just like on the Bougainville peace agreement, we didn’t need the United Nations resolution to make sure everything converged on the table for peace,” he said. “Peace must be authentic. “The construct of sovereignty or whatever follows after. “Find peace first then you can talk about other things.” Marape said we cannot force something onto two people to construct something not from within. He said Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is all for the good solution and is willing to talk peace if hostages, including the remains of those who passed away are returned. AnsweringThe National’s question on why PNG voted against the solution, Marape said as part of the small nation they chose to walk the narrow path. “If you want this, give peace a chance instead of fighting at the same time,” Marape said. “We ask them to sit at the table and talk first to find a solution that is better for them. “PNG signed this early without knowing what the Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese gave in a statement reaffirming our view. “Some may not like it but we have to take this stand based on principles.”

Title: Tua trains to become MAF’s first local floatplane pilot
Content: JOSEPH TUA will soon be the first national floatplane pilot for Mission Aviation Fellowship (MAF). MAF, in a press release yesterday, announced this achievement for both Tua and MAF, taking a step forward after winding down at the country’s 50 years’ independence anniversary. MAF said Tua, who is from Southern Highlands’ Pangia, is on track to become MAF’s first national floatplane pilot, bringing vital help, hope and healing to isolated communities across Western. “It’s an honour and privilege to upskill, fly the floatplane, and serve Western’s water communities and PNG broadly…I believe it’s timely. God Himself ordained this. In my human capacity, I couldn’t have planned it,” Tua reflected. His path to this achievement began seven years ago when he joined MAF as a pilot, never imagining he would pioneer this role. Early this year, Tua embarked on an intensive two-and-a-half-week floatplane training course in Western under the guidance of experienced pilot Chad Tilley. Transitioning from mountain landings to navigating the unpredictable waters of Lake Murray, Tua’s training represents a significant step forward for MAF’s mission in PNG. Western’s villages, nestled among Lake Murray’s lagoons and rivers, are among the most isolated in PNG, accessible only by riverboat or floatplane. “A journey that takes one–five days by boat is reduced to just 10-30 minutes by MAF’s floatplane, P2-WET, delivering critical medical supplies, community development resources, and transportation. “These extremely isolated communities rely on the floatplane for community development, medical assistance, and transporting people,” said Tilley, Tua’s trainer.

Title: Public Solicitor’s Office opens in Kimbe
Content: THE people of West New Britain can now have access to important legal services after the opening of the new Public Solicitor’s office in Kimbe on Friday. Public Solicitor Leslie Mamu said the office would provide the local people much-needed legal aid, especially for those who cannot afford to pay for such services. “To put simply, the Public Solicitor is the people’s lawyer,” he said. “When you have court cases or other legal matters that you need help with, you come here for our officers to explain the law, court order, drafting court papers and more. “Most private law firms will cost a lot of money so that is why the Office of the Public Solicitor is here to provide free legal services. “That is a very important office that has a part to play in the national justice administration of the country. “We will now have officers here in Kimbe for you all in the provinces to come and access services.” Mamu said the Public Solicitor’s Office provided services to all citizens, including those who commit crimes and need legal representation in court and setting disputes. He added that the office was empowered by the Constitution, which the country’s founding fathers ensured that all citizens had the right to legal services. “It is important that people understand our roles and functions. “We help resolve conflicts and disputes among families or communities. “We also represent rapists and thieves because the law allows for their protection as well. “Regardless of all the criticism of our office, we are here to help provide justice for all,” he said. He also thanked the provincial government for allocating the office space and a vehicle for the Public Solicitor officers to use. West New Britain Governor Sasindran Muthuvel said the provincial government would continue to support the law and justice services to the local people. “This office symbolises a step in the right direction to ensuring that our people can get services from the Public Solicitor as it has brought access to justice closer to home. “We will continue to support Public Solicitor’s Office and other agencies in the law and justice sector to provide more services to our people,” he said.

Title: Health Department says polio risk still high
Content: HEALTH Department acting secretary Ken Wai says the risk of polio spreading further remains high in the country. He said this was due to the low rate of immunisation being conducted on children between the ages of one to 10 years. “Polio was actually eliminated in the year 2000,” Wai said. “But there was an outbreak in 2018. “That is why the department brought back the immunisation programme. “It is important that we protect everyone by way of vaccination. “We have a target to immunise 95 per cent of all the children. “So far, we have only covered up to 85 per cent, and that is not good.” An outbreak was declared in May after detecting the poliovirus type two, taken from samples in Port Moresby and from two children in Lae. The first case was confirmed in August in a four-year-old child in Lae. It was from this that the department launched a nationwide supplementary immunisation activity in August and is in progress with the second round of vaccination from last month to Oct 17. In a situation report, over 80 per cent of tests were conducted around the country, but the department has yet to confirm if there are more than one positive polio cases. “This immunization will be the second round in October, so that’s going to be open to children aged one to 10 years old,” Wai said. “There have been many cases before where a polio patient suffers from legs becoming weak and hands becoming small and paralysed. “Vaccination has actually eliminated some diseases like measles and whooping cough, so it is important that parents take their children for immunisation as this is the most effective way of preventing childhood diseases. “We have a responsibility to protect both the population, most importantly the children, because they will be adults and the future leaders of Papua New Guinea,” Wai added. He said parents must make it their duty to take their children to local health centres for immunisation.

Title: Interpreters get certification
Content: TWO Papua New Guinean sign language interpreters earned their certification following the World Association of Sign Language Interpreters Oceania Conference held in Fiji last month. With the support of the Australia-PNG Law and Justice Partnership, Anna Thomas and Francisca Sam, from the Community Development and Religion Department, received their certification following the first graduation of regional sign language trainees. The certification marks significant milestone in disability inclusion as it formally recognises the role of sign language, now recognised as PNG’s fourth official language. It also expands access to legal and essential public services for deaf communities across the country, allowing the skilled interpreters who can help deaf individuals access government and justice services. Thomas, a sign language coordinator at the department, emphasised the significance of the certification. “This graduation is about recognition, empowerment and progress,” she said. “We’re building a future where deaf Papua New Guineans can access information, education, and public services in their own language.” The department will now lead efforts to develop a National Sign Language Implementation Plan (2025–2030), establish a registry of certified interpreters, and integrate sign language training into mainstream services, including justice sector institutions. Meanwhile, the conference brought together deaf leaders, interpreters, and disability advocates from across the Pacific, including representatives from PNG, Tonga, Samoa, Australia, New Zealand and the Solomon Islands. The Australia–PNG Law and Justice Partnership recognises that inclusive justice systems require effective communication and the interpreter certification would provide the foundation toward ensuring deaf citizens can engage with legal institutions – from reporting crimes to participating in trials – with dignity, autonomy, and equal protection under the law. The partnership remains committed to advancing rights-based approaches and strengthening inclusive access to justice in PNG by supporting initiatives like interpreter certification and deaf-led advocacy to build an accessible, equitable, and responsive justice system to the needs of all citizens.

Title: Government prioritises persons with disabilities
Content: PERSONS living with a disabilities have the right to be recognised everywhere as a person before the law and to exercise their legal capacity on an equal basis with others, says an official. Community Development and Religion Department deputy secretary Karen Haive said: “As a government, our approach to supporting people with disabilities is guided by key national policy frameworks which is to remove barriers and make rights real. “Papua New Guinea has ratified six of the nine core United Nations human rights treaties with the department, which is responsible for implementing three of them,” she said. This is outlined in the convention of rights of persons living with disabilities that protect the rights of persons with disabilities. Haive was speaking at a consultation on persons living with disabilities and how they were equally included in dignity, liberty, access to healthcare and education, and their participation in other development areas in society. The two-day workshop brought together government officers from the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG), persons living with disabilities, representatives from non-governmental organisations, churches, and key government agencies. The event, which began on Thursday, was the last in a series of consultations held across PNG’s four regions. The consultation involved discussions on how services such as education and healthcare were made conducive for persons living with disabilities. Throughout the consultation, participants engaged in discussions and completed questionnaires focused on how government services, such as education and infrastructure, were supporting the inclusion of persons with disabilities. ABG mandatory and social services manager Donovan Tami said Bougainville’s policy started with raising awareness in the region and removing barriers that hindered progress. “The policy recognises the right of persons living with disabilities to equal opportunities and full participation in social, economic, cultural and political life,” he said.

Title: Canonisation of Blessed Peter ToRot a symbol of strength, faith, says cardinal
Content: THE Catholic Church should continue to see the canonisation of Peter ToRot as a symbol of strength and faith, says Cardinal Sir John Ribat. The Archbishop of Port Moresby said the canonisation next month will mark a historic spiritual milestone, making him the nation’s first saint and a recognition of its Christian heritage. “So after celebrating the country’s 50th anniversary, which the Government has done well, the church also notes that within this time comes the canonisation of blessed Peter ToRot. “He was a devoted catechist for the Missionary of the Sacred Heart who dedicated his life to evangelism even in the face of danger against the Japanese policies imposed in East New Britain during the Second World War. “His life as a devoted husband and father served as a strong example and encouragement for Catholic families worldwide,” he said. ToRot’s canonisation as Papua New Guinea’s first saint will take place on Oct 19, in Rome, Italy. The decree for his canonisation was signed by Pope Francis in March, following a request from the Catholic Bishops of PNG and the Solomon Islands to exempt the process from further miracle proofs due to their recognised sanctity and evidence of grace. ToRot was a Catholic layman, catechist, husband and father who was martyred in 1945 for his defence of Christian marriage against Japanese occupation policies. Ribat said there was no proper schedule out on his canonisation programme but after returning from Rome, a celebration of his sainthood will be held in his home province of East New Britain. “This is the time when we are to pray together for this event and to be of service just as what ToRot demonstrated by his faith. “He stood firm despite many challenges and temptations faced and that is how we should live during these times,” he said.

Title: Governor Pariwa visits remote Teptep in Rai Coast
Content: MADANG Governor Ramsey Pariwa was warmly received at Teptep government station in ward seven of Nayudo local level government (LLG) in Rai Coast district at around midday on Friday, Sept 26, 2025 with a colorful and rousing traditional welcome. Governor Pariwa’s visit to Teptep, situated deep in the highlands of Madang, is his first-ever since he took office. He was offered a kundu drum upon arrival to perform with the traditional dancers who waited eagerly to receive him. Pariwa fitted in nicely with the traditional dancers as they performed and walked in a procession towards Teptep Primary School where the reception was staged. A local elder, Tingneka Tanga, who is also the board chairman of the school, said the Teptep people only knew Ramsey Pariwa through the election posters in both 2017 and 2022 General Elections because he did not set foot in the area. However, his maiden visit on Friday was special as the governor. They were proud to have him mingle with them freely and to spend a night with them at the village. The governor was saddened, and with a shaken voice, he began his address to acknowledge the isolated people of Teptep and Nayudo, and the Yus people of Morobe’s Kabwum who also turned up to dance to acknowledge his presence. He explained his non-appearance in the last two years due to three elections petitions filed against him by losing candidates and two lawsuits filed by the former provincial administrator. These lawsuits had prevented him from performing his duly elected duties accordingly in delivering services. Pariwa’s visit followed constant requests by the board and management of Teptep Primary School for improvement of their facility. He delivered a cheque for K500,000 to the school to improve its facility thus paving way for a junior high school status. Another cheque of K20,000 was presented to Awanas Coffee Farmers’ Cooperative Society also from Nayudo LLG. “Teptep has a special place in my heart. “I am here now and I will still come back,” Pariwa told the people.

Title: All roads in Nuku to be maintained, says Sungi
Content: ALL roads in the remote Nuku district in West Sepik will be maintained to ensure that Government services reach everyone there, Nuku MP Joe Sungi says. During his recent visit to his electorate, Sungi said roads enabled people to benefit from their economic activities. “All the roads will be gravelled before mid-2026,” Sungi said. “All the 82 villages/wards   will be connected. All schools and aid posts should be linked by roads,” he said. “Teachers and nurses must not walk to schools and aid posts. “Vehicles should bring them and their cargo to their destinations. Also, villagers can transport their cocoa and vanilla to sell them at markets.” “Maprik and Wewak to get money. “Store owners can also go to Wewak or Maprik to buy store goods,” he said. Sungi said bridges would be built over fast-flowing rivers. “Four weeks ago I brought two civil engineers and they had a look at the washed bridge at Waramun River. “Now they are building steel decks in China and will ship them to Port Moresby. “By next month, they will ship the materials to the Waramun site, and will begin to punch the piers into the river bed to build the bridge’s foundation. “I thank Nuku district administrator Paul Nengai and district treasurer Steven Auwau who worked with the Treasury Department to secure funds to build those bridges,” he said. Sungi said the washed-out bridge was 49-metres long. “Now the new bridge will be 65 metres long. “It will be high so when the river floods, the bridge won’t be washed away. “But the washed-out bridge will be dismantled and taken to be installed over Yiriwate River. “With the construction of these two bridges, the Central Nuku LLG will be connected to the Sepik Plains. “Another road will also be upgraded to go down from Nuku district to Aitape town. “This new Nuku-Aitape road link will alleviate the risks of travelling to and from Maprik and Wewak towns. “You can conveniently access government services and banking services, and sell your cocoa and vanilla in Aitape,” he said. Meanwhile, a gravel deposit land owner, William Singama, from Nukuaglo Hamlet of Seim village, has offered the gravel from his gravel deposit free of charge for the road construction contractor to extract and maintain the roads in the district. This was witnessed by the Denis Nocombi, a community spokesman and the contractor, and some staff of the district administration.

Title: ‘I have the support of other leaders’: Governor Wouwou backs Frieda project
Content: WEST Sepik Governor Tony Wouwou says future developments on the Frieda project is a Government agenda and will still continue as planned. “I have the support of other leaders and we will still support the Frieda project to continue its operations,” he said. “People are blowing this out of proportion because they do not understand that the process gone through the relevant authorities on checks with waste disposal and other mining, environmental and social issues that may arise.” He said a plan is in place for waste disposal which will not affect the river and the dam is to be used as a power source for the project. Wouwou said that four other leaders were in agreement with him on this which included Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim, who made the proposal to Prime Minister James Marape while launching the road and town plan in Telefomin, Nuku MP Joe Sungi, Aitape Lumi MP Anderson Mise and Ambunti/ Dreikikier MP Johnson Wapunai. All MPs were present in Telefomin on Sept 12 when Mirisim made the proposal for the Government to consider opening the Frieda project. Vanimo Green MP Belden Namah maintained his position by going against the project as this would greatly affect the people along the Sepik River. East Sepik Governor Allan Bird in a recent post in his Facebook page said: “Since when has had the Government honoured its promises on such prospects?” He advised the people to remain calm as from research and findings, the project processes were quite technical and near impossible for the project to take place soon in the region. Attempts to get through to other Sepik leaders were unsuccessful.
People: Allan Bird, Anderson Mise, Belden Namah, James Marape, Joe Sungi, Johnson Wapunai, Solan Mirisim, Tony Wouwou

Title: Over K830 million in Government funds for provinces unaudited, says PM
Content: MORE than K830 million in Government funds allocated to provinces and districts remain unaudited, according to the department of Implementation and Rural Development monthly report. It blames this on the lack of proper oversight and accountability on the Provincial Service Improvement Programme (PSIP) and the District Service Improvement Programme (DSIP) funding. Since 2018, 163 reports are yet to be provided for assessment. They include 74 DSIP and 19 PSIP reports yet to be submitted. They include Government grants for projects, provincial and district MPs’ discretionary funds of K5 million and K10 million under the SIP allocations. Prime Minister James Marape said that as far as the PSIP and DSIP were concerned, the Government had honored its part by allocating funding to the provinces and districts. It is up to the MPs to ensure that the services reach the people. The mandated closing date was March 31. The enforcement of that deadline is for the Ombudsman Commission (OC) to exercise. It should work with the department on compliance. The OC’s concern raised on its website and in public media announcements says that without acquittals, it is difficult to determine the manner in which the projects have been procured and whether they are public in nature with maximum public benefit. However, to date no action or penalties have been imposed on provinces and districts which have not complied with the OC’s demand for timely reports. Deputy Secretary Programme and Implementation Gordon Wafimbi, said the department urged districts and provinces to submit acquittals as and when they could, even if they had missed the deadline. “Some districts whose members have died will have challenges to access funds, administration or high turnover for district administrators so they are not able to coordinate the reporting aspects. There are a host of reasons,” he said.

Title: Enga administrator backs inquiry into rights violations
Content: ENGA administrator Sandis Tsaka has pledged his full support to the National Court inquiry into violations of basic rights caused by tribal fights in the province. The inquiry was conducted by resident judge Graham Ellis last Thursday. Tsaka and Wapenamanda MP Miki Kaeok were summoned by the National Court to give evidence. Tsaka said that he would cooperate with the directives issued by the court to contain law and order in the province. “I’m willing to assist on behalf of the Enga provincial government to provide evidence required by the court, and welcome the inquiry to continue,” he said. Judge Ellis invoked the court’s power to begin proceedings on its own initiative, issuing interim orders to leaders, police, and people to contain tribal conflicts and lawlessness. He was presiding over a Human Rights Own Initiative inquiry aimed at protecting constitutional rights in the face of the fights. Those summoned to the inquiry were Tsaka, Enga acting police commander Inspector Kelly Sombe, PNG Defence detachment commander in Enga, Wapenamanda Member and Yangukin tribal leader Miki Kaeok, and Danny Katie, the leader of the Yakuman tribe. All were in attendance last Thursday except for Kaeok.

Title: NGCB chief executive Agon committed to trial for abuse of office
Content: A COURT has found enough evidence to commit the chief executive officer of the National Gaming Control Board Imelda Agon to trial for attempting to pervert the course of justice and abuse of office. Committal Court Magistrate Paul Puri Nii, in Waigani, committed Agon, 53, of Putsipai village in Kavieng, New Ireland, to stand trial in the National Court. “Evidence is sufficient to commit the defendant for the offence of attempting to pervert the course of justice under section 136, and for the offence of abuse of office under section 92(1) of the Criminal Code Act.” Police alleged that on Feb 12, Agon abused her office by attempting to pervert the course of justice when she had issued instruction on a NGCB letterhead to the No 1 Lotto company to cease operation. At that time, there was a case pending before the committal court concerning an employee of NGCB who was charged with wilfully damaging the company operation. Agon through her lawyer argued that there was insufficient evidence to warrant a trial. Agon said that committal hearing required proper and reasonable assessment of evidence and evidence must meet the elements of the offences. Police claimed that she abused her authority by falsely releasing a public notice which frightened state witnesses from giving evidences in the case. The court found in the police evidence that Agon had abused the authority of her office by releasing the notice which was prejudicial to the rights of police informants where they could not progress the case. “In summary, I rule in favour of the police evidence, hence, the defendant has a case to answer in the National Court.” Magistrate Nii said. Agon will return to court on Oct 13 for a Section 96 (declaration) statement.

Title: Waste of government funds. Public dissatisfied over NID process: Survey
Content: SOME people are dissatisfied with the registration process of the National Identification project, calling it a waste of government funds. This is according to a survey conducted byThe Nationalon the NID card registration in Morobe, Port Moresby and the Highlands region. For Morobe, the NID and Civil Registry office was established in Lae in 2016, to allow for civil registration papers to be processed locally – a fully integrated system to process birth, death, marriage and divorce documents, as well as amendments to civil records and the population information system. Joshua Kepas from Morobe was 20 when he registered. “I am now 28 with two children and still waiting for my NID card,” he said. “Maybe there’s a need for better coordination to improve this service. But in my opinion, this is a failed project – too many processes, even staff asking for extra fees. It is a waste of people’s money.” Misang Iwong said he paid a K40 “urgent fee”. “It’s been over a year since I lodged mine. Why is it called urgent fee yet years of waiting?” Karlym Kerari, who applied in 2017 in Port Moresby, said that without an NID, getting her passport renewed would be a problem. Nurse Ani Kusak-Muriken has been waiting for two years in Lae for her son’s birth certificate. “I lodged the application when he was a week old,” she said. “Right now, I cannot apply for leave. I have to find lawyers or Commissioner for Oaths to sign state declaration form. There’s also delays with passports. “It’s just unreliable.” Former Lae MP Bart Philemon said he was not surprised to read the front page ofThe Nationalon Sept 24 about the Government failing to deliver two promises by Sept 16 – the result of last year’s census and the NID registration. “Statistical facts are vital for the government administration, providing facts needed for informed decision-making, evaluation and fostering transparency and accountability in governance,” he said. “Development plans must be based on current statistical facts.”

Title: Indonesians eligible for visa on arrival
Content: ORDINARY passports holders from Indonesia are eligible for a Visa on Arrival (VOA) arrangement when entering Papua New Guinea, says Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso. “Effective immediately, ordinary passport holders from Indonesia can enter PNG only at the Jackson International Airport in Port Moresby using the visa-on-arrival arrangement,” Rosso said. He said that the bilateral arrangement between the two countries allowed diplomatic, official and service passport holders from both countries to obtain VOA for up to 60 days. “However, because Indonesia is already providing PNG standard passport holders visa on arrival, Papua New Guinea is now reciprocating that for their ordinary passport holders,” Rosso said. Rosso said that the visa-on-arrival would only be available at the Jackson International Airport. He said that Indonesia’s service passport was the equivalent of PNG’s official passport, although the service passport could be referred to as an official passport. Rosso added that the visa on arrival for ordinary passport holders was up to 30 days, while that for diplomats and officials under the current bilateral arrangement was a maximum of 60 days. “That is not applicable to diplomats and officials on long-term engagement, only for short-term visits.”

Title: Hela’s Mt Sisa to get road connectivity
Content: ROAD connectivity into the remote Mt Sisa local level government (LLG) area of Hela’s Komo-Hulia will start next year, says local MP Daniel Tindipu. In his visit to Mt Sisa recently, he told the people that the Hela government had provided K2 million for the road construction, and with district development authority funding, road construction should start before 2027. Tindipu said as Mt Sisa is only accessible by air, the district had allocated funds to the Rural Airstrip Authorities to carry out scoping to maintain the airstrip to accepted standards. He said the district upon requests from Mission Aviation Fellowship (MAF) and Summer Institute of Linguistics (SIL), provided funds for medical evacuation flights out of Mt Sisa. Tindipu said road accessibility into the Mt Sisa LLG area remained a challenge for many years “This narrative for Mt Sisa is about to change,” said Tindipu, who is the National Planning and Monitoring vice-minister. “We have already built new classrooms and delivery wards for mothers at Mt Sisa Government Station.” The visit concluded with the presentation of K60,000 to locals in Dodomona, Huya and Walagu for community livelihood support programmes. Mt Sisa was the epicentre of the 2018 magnitude-7.5 earthquake, which caused widespread damage to Hela, Southern Highlands and Enga.

Title: University of Papua New Guinea students against Frieda project
Content: EAST Sepik students at the University of Papua New Guinea (UPNG) are against the opening of the Frieda project in West Sepik. Vice-president of the East Sepik students Francy Mandau said the reason for their rejection is that the livelihood of 80 per cent of the people depends entirely on the Sepik River and if the Frieda project came into operation, it will have a drastic effect on the people’s source of food and water. “Whether the Frieda project commences operations, the waste from the project will greatly affect the greater Sepik because the majority of the population live along the river. “The people eat, collect food, drink and live along this river,” she said. She said it was important to address this issue now as it will have an adverse effect on the future generations should the government consider taking on this project. A group of students gathered at the Forum Square to explain the effects of the project and to make a call to all Sepiks in the city to prepare for a meeting this weekend. The time and venue will be announced at the end of the week. This students’ call is in regard to a call made by an MP for the Government to consider opening the Frieda Copper and Gold project for exploration and mining prospects along West Sepik. Prime Minister James Marape in his response said the Government would only consider that proposal if all leaders from along the West and East Sepik were in agreement. Vanimo Green MP and Tourism, Arts and Culture Minister Belden Namah pledged his support for the greater Sepik, opposing further operations of the Frieda project. He was speaking at the Crocodile Festival in Ambunti. “I don’t want the copper project to be opened. I want to protect the lives of my people along the Sepik River,” he said. He said he will not allow the Frieda copper gold project to operate as a mine. UPNG academic Dr Andrew Moutu said: “Frieda River project is said to come in as soon and it’s worth an ecological disaster but praised in the name of profit. “Loss is our business because we constantly forge contracts with nonsense and therefore PNG is on its way down the great dissension,” he said. East Sepik Governor Allan Bird said all Sepik’s should remain calm on the Frieda prospect given the response from Marape last week. “The Frieda project is a technically and financially challenging project and of high risk and this is why it has not been developed to date,” he said. He said even if the Government gives the go ahead for the project to proceed to the next stage, it would be difficult to get the project off the ground given the issues of remoteness, potential environment disaster, having low grade deposits and lack of infrastructure.
People: Allan Bird, Belden Namah, James Marape

Title: Government takes measures to regulate indecent online content
Content: THE Government through the office of the Censorship in collaboration with the National Information and Communication Technology Authority (Nicta) is taking measures to regulate online content and ensure a safer digital environment for all citizens. Minister for Community Development, Youth and Religion Jason Peter said as part of their ongoing efforts to protect vulnerable groups and maintain national stability and decency, the Government is working with the three government agencies and internet service providers (ISP) to block access to websites and online content deemed explicit, harmful or inappropriate. The censorship office has submitted more than 5,000 unsuitable sites to Nicta since 2024. “Our collaboration with Nicta, ISPs and other stakeholders will support us in achieving this important goal and ensuring a safer online environment for all citizens,” he said. “The Department of Information Communication Technology was correct in saying that the office of the censorship has been classifying and forwarding the classified listing to Nicta to liaise with the ISPs to block off the unsuitable sites.” He urged public to take an active role in maintaining online safety. “I encourage all citizens to report any online content they believe is explicit, harmful or inappropriate to the relevant authorities that promotes respect, dignity and safety for all,” Peter said. Chief Censor Jim Abani said it was essential that the wellbeing and safety of citizens, particularly children and vulnerable groups was prioritised. “I call on all citizens to join us in promoting a culture of moral decency, respect and responsibility and report any content or behaviour that compromises these values,” Abani said. “The support received by the Government reaffirms its commitment to upholding moral and Christian principles that are fundamental to our nation’s identity and values.”

Title: Mainohana conducts graduation for grades 10 and 12 students
Content: MAINOHANA Catholic Secondary School, the only secondary school in Central’s Kairuku district, conducted a graduation for its grade 10 and 12 students last Thursday. This concluded the school’s internal academic year for 2025 as students prepare for the final examinations in October. School principal Nicholas Maino announced that this was the 71st Grade 10 graduation with 171 graduating and 21st Grade 12 graduation with 82 graduating. He emphasised on the theme of the graduation, ‘lighting the path to the future with faith and love’. He encouraged the students to apply what they had learnt to their future. Maino said the school had made many changes to staff over the years for the school to strive. “There has been a 100 per cent change in the recruitment of teachers and I am proud to say that Mainohana has some of the best teachers from around the country. “Academic results have been improving each year under the care of these teachers,” Maino said. He told the students there were numerous paths to success. “Faith and love will light the path that you take in the future. “If you are unable to reach your path, there are others you can take. “Have faith in yourself that you can achieve what you want,” Maino ecouraged. Guest of honour, Kairuku MP and Minister for Energy Peter Isoaimo, is a former Mainohana student. He encouraged the graduates not to take school for granted. “Life is a long journey and is purpose driven. “You must have a purpose to achieve. “You must not come to school just for the sake of coming to school. “You can achieve your dreams. Nothing is impossible. Sky is the limit. “Education does not end in grade 10 or 12. You learn things your whole life,” he said. Isoaimo also announced that a commitment of K200,00 made earlier in the year was now ready and would be delivered for the school to complete its infrastructure projects.

Title: Department carries out retirement exercise in Lae for teachers
Content: DEPARTMENT of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology carried out a two- day retirement exercise in Lae with the signing of deeds of release for senior teachers. Senior teachers from the National Polytechnic Institute of PNG, Balob Teachers’ College and the Unitech Lae School of Nursing were asked to sign deeds of release on Thursday as part of the department’s retirement strategy plan 2021. Joe Ponau, a senior mechanical engineering lecturer at the National Polytechnic Institute of Papua New Guinea, said some staff members were aged and sick, and could not afford to wait any longer. “Despite not signing a contract with our school since we transitioned in 2021, some of us are past our retirement age as well as having medical issues that does not allow us to stay any longer in the province that we have been serving,” he said. “I have been teaching for over 40 years and right now I have a heart condition that might not allow me to wait any longer for my final entitlements.” He said he is from Manus and needs to move his family and belongings back home with his final entitlements. “I know my other colleagues are pushing to get our contracts signed with the Department of Higher Education, Science and Technology, but some of us cannot wait any longer.” Ponau urged the department as well as the Department of Personnel Management to fast-track their retirement entitlements as some teachers had passed-away before receiving their entitlements. The Department of High Education, Research, Science and Technology are carrying out the retirement exercise in the four regions as this is the final year of the Retirement Strategy Plan 2021.

Title: Bougainville struggling to generate internal revenue: Survey
Content: THE Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) has struggled to generate revenue to achieve fiscal self-reliance, according to a report. The Bougainville Socio-Economic Baseline Survey Report 2021 states that the budget for 2024 was estimated to be K761.2 million, with only K50.7 million (6.6 per cent of the total) expected to be generated as internal revenue, and 93.4 per cent injected by the Government in Port Moresby. It states that to fund its development plan, the Bougainville government introduced the sectoral development budget under the Bougainville integrated strategic development plan. But given the island’s lack of internal revenue, the approach since then has been to make the budget dependent on funding from Waigani and from donor partners. Lowly Institute senior researcher Oliver Nobetau said Bougainville could expand its revenue base by taxing resources such as cocoa, fishing, and tourism. Cocoa and fishing alone are expected to generate K162 million annually. “Due to a global cocoa supply shortfall, receipts of cocoa exports from Bougainville reached more than K310 million (US$73 million) in the first half of 2025. “However, revenue generation for these sectors remain theoretical without a tax administration capable of capturing it,” he said. He said despite reform announcements for the Bougainville Tax Office 2024, it lacked the institutional capacity, enforcement mechanisms and administrative reach to implement and collect taxes effectively. The report states that the ABG believes that the reopening the Panguna mine can have a major impact on the economy and its budget, but is conscious of the sensitivities that must be navigated. However, the Bougainville Copper Limited, has projected that the mine could generate K120 billion over a 20-year period, with K40 billion in direct benefit to Bougainville. “Efforts to reopen the mine have been stalled by a load of issues, including a recent class action suit over environmental damage. The decision to reopen must consider environmental risks, as well as a new regulatory regime that ensures equitable distribution of wealth,” he said.

Title: Japan provides K11.6 million towards PNG’s disaster relief capabilities
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Government and Japan on Sept 16 signed an official security assistance for K11.6 million that will go towards helping PNG’S disaster relief help and infrastructure capabilities. Foreign Affairs minister Justin Tkatchenko in a statement said equipment will be provided to the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) engineering battalion in Lae, Morobe. He said the signing with Japan’s Prime Minister Shiheru Ishiba and Foreign Affairs Minister Takuma Miyaji provided for heavy machinery amounting up to 400 million yen (about K11.6 million). “The help is a historical grant aid signing for both countries in the area of military help,” he said. “The signing on the country’s 50th independence anniversary carried even more significance as the 50th year of Japan-PNG relations. “We must make sure that what we sign and what we agree to is implemented immediately and not put on the shelves where it gathers dust and is forgotten.” Tkatchenko thanked the Japan Government and said they also had to be efficient and prepared to immediately progress negotiations and our processes to ensure that we used this grant and immediately implement. Miyaji said Japan will work with PNG to support the efforts of the PNGDF to demonstrate their capabilities for national and regional security in the Pacific including through the provision of the assistance. “We expect that this will synergise with capacity building assistance conducted by the Japan Ground Self Defence Force as well as with the cooperation activities carried out by Australia at the same location,” he said. He said over the past 50 years since independence, Japan and PNG have enjoyed our relationship as genuine Tomodachi (friends). “To that end, I am committed to working even harder for further development for our bilateral relations,” Miyaji said.

Title: Judge summons Enga leaders to answer for fights
Content: THE National Court has summoned Transport Minister Miki Kaeok among other leaders of Enga’s Wapenamanda district to answer for the continuous tribal fighting in the district. Enga resident Judge Graham Ellis last Thursday summoned Kaeok, provincial administrator Sandis Tasaka, acting provincial police commander, Kelly Sombe, Major Kents, commander of defence force contingent in Enga and a Danny Katie to enforceguaranteed rights and freedoms under Section 57 (1) of the Constitution. Ellis said the court was compelled under Section 57 (1) of the Constitution to act after receiving reports that ongoing ethnic clashes had disrupted schools, delayed court hearings and left detainees stranded in the Baisu Correctional Facility in Western Highlands. Ellis said the affected persons’ rights to freedom (sect 32), to freedom of assembly and association (sect 47) and to freedom of movement (sect 52) were affected by the ongoing violence. Section 57 of the Constitution of Papua New Guinea (PNG) provides for the enforcement of guaranteed rights and freedoms and grants the National Court the power and duty to inquire into, protect, and enforce these rights and freedoms when they are perceived to have been infringed. The matter is the enforcement of basic rights under the constitution (Sect 57) and relates to tribal fighting in Wapenamanda and its impact on the work of the national court and the education of children and the continued detention or remand and imprisonment of detainees, remandees and prisoners from Enga in Baisu prison. Papua New Guinea Law Society President Hubert Namani congratuled Judge Ellis’ initiative to summon the leaders of the province as “the best way to use judicial powers to protect rights and uphold the rule of law”. “The recent decision of the National Court in Wabag, to take the initiative under Section 57(1) of the Constitution and inquire into the impact of tribal fighting in Wapenamanda, is a welcome and timely intervention,” he said. “By stepping in on its own motion, the Court has demonstrated the breadth of its jurisdiction and the depth of its responsibility to protect fundamental rights and freedoms guaranteed under our Constitution.” Namani said this proactive stance was not only commendable but necessary in a time when violence, instability, and impunity continue to undermine the lives of our people. “The issues raised in this case go beyond Enga,” he said. “They reflect broader challenges our nation faces: ongoing human rights abuses, the devastating impact of tribal violence, the denial of education to our children, the obstruction of justice, and the erosion of community safety.”

Title: Wagambie in charge of Highlands operations
Content: POLICE Commissioner David Manning has appointed Assistant Commissioner of Police Anthony Wagambie Jnr as commander of the counter-terrorism operations in the Highlands. The police and members of the Defence Force are involved in the counter-terrorism operations there. He said the joint security operations would be strengthened with the appointment of Wagambie as operation commander. “Protecting innocent men, women and children of the Highlands Region is the priority for the police and soldiers,” he said. “This appointment reflects Wagambie’s extensive policing experience. “Wagambie knows what is expected of him in co-ordinating operations by upholding the rule of law, protecting innocent communities, and bringing to justice those who have sought to hold our nation to ransom. “The Government has declared that there must be zero tolerance in dealing with those who terrorise our communities, and our security forces are meeting this objective.”

Title: Defence treaty does not cede sovereignty: Secretary
Content: MUTUAL Defence does not cede sovereignty but seeks to reinforce and strengthen the very concept of sovereignty, Foreign Affairs Secretary Elias Wohengu has said. Refuting the recent flurry of commentaries opposing the PNG-Australia Mutual Defence Treaty, also known as the Pukpuk Treaty, Wohengu said nothing in the document provides defence personnel integration between the parties but upholds and maintains the authorities of the sovereign command of the Chief of Defence Forces of both countries. In a statement, secretary Wohengu explained: “Operational integration is provided for, so defence personnel of both countries can be trained on similar platforms and assets essential for interoperability.” “Recruitment must not be confused with integration. Recruitment as an employment pathway is pursued in this Treaty and not enlisted uniform personnel integration. “ He said PNG school leavers can now apply to join the Australian Defence Force and vice-versa. Further, both countries coexist bilaterally, regionally and in a multilateral space and the proposed Treaty does not have exclusivity clauses to sovereign and commercial presence according to Wohengu. Wohengu said the ANZUS Treaty, US-Philippines Mutual Defence Treaty and Japan-US Security Treaty are examples of military alliances within our region. PNG has defence cooperation programmes with Australia, France, United States, Indonesia, New Zealand, Japan and also with China. This Treaty is never done to the exclusion of any country or third party commercial presence. He also said Japan and PNG entered into a new programme called the “Official Security Assistance” where minister responsible signed a K11.6mil programme for Japan to fund the PNGDF Engineering Battalion to procure machinery to assist with infrastructure projects. “The Pukpuk Treaty has received legal clearance from the State Solicitor of PNG,” Wohengu said. The Treaty if accepted by parliament, will not require any amendment to any legislation or enactment of new legislation to facilitate its entry into force.

Title: Load-shedding to carry on. Equipment failure causing power outages, says PPL
Content: THE most prominent cause of power outages in Port Moresby is equipment failure, says PNG Power Limited (PPL) chief executive officer Paul Bayly. He said these outages were five times more prevalent than other interruptions. “PNG Power and the Government are progressively replacing old and unreliable equipment and keeping up with the growing population in Port Moresby and around the country,” Bayly said. He added that PPL is yet to determine the total cost of damage at the Konedobu substation following a fire on Sept 19. He said it resulted in several feeder lines being put out of action. “Restoring power following fire damage is a complicated process with the safety of the public and workers of the utmost importance and ongoing testing is underway,” he said. “We are starting to test in each place as we go in the sub-station and we are hoping to have half of the control panels back up in operation probably in the next couple of weeks, so we do not know how badly the damages are until we’ve tested everything as we go, so it is still early to say how much will be the total cost of the damages,” Bayly said. He stated that the Kone sub-station is currently in a horrible condition and they put fans in there to allow the team to work day and night to try to clean it up. “We will have to wait for a while because all the equipment in there needs to be washed with a special solvent due to the fire damage. We’d be in a better position to answer the question on the damage cost in the next two to three weeks. “We are looking across the country to try to find the parts to minimise the money we spend and we have found some, but we will still have to import some parts from overseas and that is where the delay will be to restore the sub-station,” he said. He added that PPL is struggling to ration power to all parts of the city that is affected due to not all Rouna Hydro-power Stations running. He said electricity load shedding in Port Moresby would continue.

Title: Lack of stability in CEO position adding to power woes
Content: REPEATED changing of chief executive officers has contributed to the on-going power woes in the country, CEO Paul Bayly says. Bayly, who is the 14th CEO since 2012, has inherited legacy issues with no proper planning from previous successors in place to use. In a recent dialogue he said regardless of this, he is here to turn the state power provider in the right direction. “I am not worried about the history, I am worried about what we are going to do to change things and we just have to do absolutely what we can,” Bayly stated. Bayly was appointed earlier this year by the National Executive Council (NEC) and his appointment came as a relief to PPL because the power supplier had been without a permanent CEO appointment since 2023. His appointment filled a critical gap in leadership and brought much-needed stability to the SOE which has undergone a lot of turnover in its CEO position. NCD Governor Powes Parkop stated that the change in the CEO since 2012 says a lot and it comes back to Kumul Consolidated Holdings (KCH) and whoever is making the decisions. “We must stop this type of practice. How do we expect planning to take place and strategy planning to be revised and implemented when we keep changing the CEO,” Parkop said.

Title: Power outages taking a toll on residents, says Somare-Brash
Content: PORT Moresby residents have been copping relentless power outages for more than a week. Dulciana Somare-Brash, like many other concerned city residents, said due to constant outages, the central business district and surrounding downtown areas, she spends about K200 per fortnight to refuel two 20-litre containers of diesel for her backup generator. “We saw the PNG Power Limited (PPL) public notice circulating about the Kone sub-station damage. But that doesn’t solve the severe problems we are facing as city residents and businesses. “Costly electrical appliances are constantly being damaged due to constant power surges. Expensive perishable food items are going off/spoiling and we are unsafe at night when our gen sets break down. “Most residence do not have back up power. What about them? Importantly, I am troubled to think of the size of the fuel emissions and discharge emanating from hundreds of industrial-size generators being used 24/7 in the last week,” she said. Somare-Brash, the daughter of the late Grand Chief and the country’s first prime minister Michael Somare, power still goes off now and therefore all other basic utilities like water and sewage are affected too, as people without gen sets will not be able to power their water pumps for showers, personal hygiene, cooking and general cleaning. “Hospitals close when there is no power and disease spreads when people can’t access healthcare. “If we do not know how many people live in this city, how can we know how many kilowatts, megawatt, tera watt hours we need to efficiently support, supply and service commercial and residential needs in our city with exponential population growth and uncontrolled in-migration. “Sadly, the general health of our staff, the natural environment and our families are at risk now with billowing diesel fumes in the air every single day for (more than) one week,” she added.

Title: Eoe confirms deferral of elections
Content: PROVINCIAL and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe says his ministry and department are the only mandated authorities to make any changes to the dates for the LLG elections. Empowered by the relevant provisions in the Constitution, including the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Governments and the LLG Administration Act, Eoe said his department would work closely with the Electoral Commission to ensure that polling for the LLG elections starts on Oct 25. The Electoral Commission confirmed on Friday that: Eoe said that all matters concerning sub-national governments, particularly LLGs, were under his jurisdiction, however, other government departments must work in collaboration to successfully deliver the elections. “There have been many premature announcements about the elections but we will work to ensure that the process is protected,” he said. “LLGs are an important tier of government and there must be no more deferrals. “We will be working with all our stakeholders to ensure that polling is not delayed again.” He explained that it was a Government decision to have the LLG elections deferred so as to allow the grades eight, 10 and 12 national examinations to be completed. Meanwhile, Eoe refuted recent media reports of illegal wards and LLGs being created during the current election period. He called for a stop to this misinformation as it would cause confusion and anxiety. Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs secretary Philip Leo said that if any person sought to pursue the matter of illegal wards and LLGs being created, they could do so in court. Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai said the Commission will be prepared to conduct elections once polling starts on Oct 25. Sinai said despite the deferral of the polling date to allow the grades eight, 10 and 12 national examinations to be completed, the commission was ready as its officers and election materials were already sent to the provinces. Voters in all provinces, except the National Capital District and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, are expected to go to the polls next month to elect their leaders for the 375 LLGs and 6,916 wards in the country. “It is unfortunate that the Electoral Commission, upon the advice of the Government through the Minister for Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister (Soroi Eoe), has made the decision to defer the LLG elections originally scheduled for Saturday, Sept 27,” Sinai said. “This decision was made to ensure a safe and stable environment for students who will be sitting their national examinations.” Sinai added that all other stakeholders, particularly the Finance Department, ensure that timely support was provided to the commission. “Despite the significant operational and financial challenges, the Electoral Commission stands ready to conduct the LLG elections. “Our officers are working around the clock in all provinces to ensure that we are prepared for polling to start on Oct 25,” he said.

Title: Opposition criticises Government for lack of planning
Content: THE deferral of local level government elections has brought an angry retort from the Opposition. Deputy Opposition Leader and North Fly MP James Donald accused government of having no planning and that this was a national concern. Donald said: “Unfortunately, this situation reflects a lack of consistent preparation. “It appears that there has been little to no strategic planning in place. “This government seems to struggle with decisiveness, which is concerning,” Donald said in a statement on Friday. “I question the decision to schedule elections during the national examination period, a major event that is already accounted for in the calendar. “It raises the question of why the elections were planned for a time that conflicts with national exams. “Furthermore, it is both unexpected and regrettable that the Education Minister, who is well aware of the academic calendar, did not advise the cabinet appropriately on these dates. “This situation underscores a need for improved planning and coordination within the government. “The Opposition believes that this oversight has significant implications for our local level governments, and we strongly urge the Government to consider the needs of the citizens who rely on effective representation at the local level.”

Title: Mano calls for calm in ENB
Content: East New Britain provincial administrator Levi Mano has urged local level government (LLG) candidates to remain calm after the Government deferred polling to next month. Mano, who is also the chairman of the Provincial Election Steering Committee, spoke to the candidates and their supporters on Saturday. “I know it’s been a long while before we can see our elected representatives in our provincial government but we must also be mindful of the legislative and the constitutional requirement that we are required to follow,” he said. “I want to encourage all of us to stay calm and ensure that we allow the constitutional process of this activity goes smoothly. “ENB people are known for perseverance and endurance and with this I expect good outcome during the period of this rollout of the LLG elections,” Mano said. He said for East New Britain, polling will be done on Oct 27 and ends on Nov 8, followed by counting. Return of Writs is on Nov 21.

Title: 12,000 diagnosed with cancer yearly, says doctor
Content: MORE than 12,000 women are diagnosed with either cervical, breast, ovarian or endometrial cancer every year in Papua New Guinea, says a doctor. Pacific International Hospital (PIH) chief obstetrician and gynaecologist Dr Mathias Sapuri said these were the four most common types of cancer affecting women in the country, with cervical cancer being the most prevalent. “The number of cancer cases, especially the types that affect our women, are increasing in PNG every year,” he said. “The biggest challenge for women in PNG is that they do not have access or they are reluctant to go and see a health worker or a doctor to regularly do an examination to look for evidence of these cancers. “If women go regularly to see the doctor or health worker to do a clinical examination and look for any evidence of cancer every two years, then it will most likely that you will be aware of this cancer early and treat them early. “With more than 12,000 cases of cancer cases in women in the country, the message of prevention is important.” Sapuri made these remarks after the annual globe-a-thon walk held in Port Moresby yesterday. He said the walk, which was part of the worldwide movement that brings together physicians, patients, caregivers, organisations and people, had been held in the city for more than 10 years to not only raise awareness, but also show support for the increasing number of women affected by cancer in the country. “There is still more work that needs to be done,” Sapuri said. “That responsibility is on all of us to carry the message of prevention and awareness on cancer forward. “It is good to see that many children walked with us today as we need to start educating them as they are the next generation of the country. “Young women and girls must also get tested early to prevent cancer from developing into something worse as they get older. “It is always good to undergo regular checks and examinations at your nearest health facilities to make sure you are well.” Sapuri said PIH offered services to women and girls seeking help or treatment against cancer, particularly the Gardasil vaccine, which prevents cervical cancer.

Title: Marape wants European Union to focus more on trade and investment, not aid
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape wants the European Union to build a stronger trade and investment partnership with Papua New Guinea and the Pacific region, stressing that fair commerce, not aid, is the way to sustainable development. Speaking at the EU–Pacific Islands leaders’ meeting on the sidelines of the 80th United Nations General Assembly last week, Marape confirmed PNG’s solidarity with small island states, highlighting that his country also faced similar challenges through its island provinces and communities. “I want to place my support behind the advocacy of small island states,” Marape said. “While they face unique vulnerabilities, PNG too has small island communities that qualify under this cluster. We share their concerns and challenges.” Marape commended the EU for its longstanding role in the Pacific, describing Europe as an important partner and export market. “Europe has been a constant presence in our region for hundreds of years,” Marape said. “PNG has benefited greatly from European markets, lending and grants. Our emphasis is not on aid but on fair trade,” he said. Marape underscored the Pacific’s vast scale and potential, describing the region as a “big ocean” rather than small islands. “We are big ocean states with big airspace, and in the future, it will be about who dominates these spaces – in technology, commerce and security,” he said. He invited Europe to invest in the Pacific’s resource sectors, including tuna, clean energy, agriculture, and mining, while also encouraging European businesses to relocate and establish operations in the region. “Sixty per cent of the world’s yellow fin tuna comes from the Pacific. We have palm oil, cocoa, coconut oil, coffee, gold, and copper. What we ask for is not aid and grants, but trade. “Trade fairly with us: you sell us what we don’t produce, and we sell you what we do produce. That is how we will sustain ourselves,” Marape told the gathering.

Title: PNG, US renew commitment on sidelines of United Nations assembly in New York
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape met with US Deputy Secretary of State Christopher Landau last week on the sidelines of the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly in New York. Some discussions between the two men centered on: A relationship strengthened by mutual respect, diplomatic engagements at the UNGA and building on shared interests. Marape expressed his appreciation for Landau’s participation in the country’s 50th anniversary celebrations earlier this month, highlighting the importance of diplomatic engagements in fostering cooperation between nations. The 80th session of UNGA provided a platform for world leaders to discuss pressing global issues, and the meeting between Marape and Landau underscored the value of diplomatic interactions in advancing mutual interests and cooperation.

Title: Peace and climate change are priorities, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says as Papua New Guinea celebrates its 50th year of the United Nations membership, peace and climate action are priorities. Marape said this when addressing the 80th United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) in New York on Friday. “Just a few days ago, we celebrated 50 years of our independence and very soon, on the Oct 10, we will mark 50 years since we joined the United Nations,” he said. “Fifty years on, we have been proud participants in the UN family, standing firmly by the principles of the charter.” Speaking before world leaders in New York, Marape said: “I reflect on Papua New Guinea’s unique Constitution, crafted by the nation’s founding fathers and mothers, which has kept the country united across its vast diversity of over 1,000 tribes, 850 languages, and 600 islands,” he said. “Our Constitution safeguards human rights, affirms our Christian heritage, and protects freedom of religion,” he said. “Despite being a Christian country, we protect the freedom of worship of every kind. “Papua New Guinea has one or two lessons to teach the world: living amidst diversity, co-existing and living in unity.” Marape commended the role of churches and faith-based organisations in delivering education, health, and community services, which he said have been fundamental in keeping the nation together. “I want to recount PNG’s own experience with conflict through the 14-year Bougainville crisis which was peacefully resolved through the 2001 Bougainville Peace Agreement under UN oversight,” he said. He said not a bullet had been fired since the agreement was signed. “Bougainville reminds us that peace can be achieved and peace can be found at the table of dialogue,” he said. He urged warring parties across the globe, including in the Middle East, to “give peace a go,” citing recent remarks by Israel’s Prime Minister that hostages must be released to create conditions for peace. “As a friend of Israel, I want to say, come to the peace table where the world can learn from Papua New Guinea that peace, after conflict, is possible.” Marape also warned world leaders about the impacts of climate crisis, stating that the critical role of PNG’s vast forests were oceans as global assets. “Our tropical forests absorb carbon and produce oxygen. “Our reefs and waters shelter seven percent of the world’s biodiversity. “Yet our planet is boiling unless you have a second planet to run off to, we must save this one.” He urged major industrial nations to cut emissions, reform global financial systems and assist forest and ocean nations to preserve biodiversity. “Papua New Guinea produces only 10 million metric tonnes of carbon a year, yet we absorb more than 100 million tonnes,” he said.

Title: Man retrieves papers and gains a ‘son’
Content: A TWIST of fate brought three persons together on Tuesday – a newspaper reseller, a taxi driver and a government officer with the Internal Revenue Commission (IRC). Heming Aru is an evangelist and a reseller ofThe Nationalnewspaper. He started his business in Bulolo, Morobe, in 2015 when he saw the demand for old newspaper. Aru formally registered his business – Waria Victory Trading in 2022, being one of the pioneer businesses under the Small Business Tax Regime. IRC states that the average small business tax rate is K250 per year and is based on cash sales from grassroots and micro businesses operating in the semi-informal sector of the economy. Aru said this newspaper business was part of a bigger plan to tap into the alluvial mining sector, create employment and pay taxes. “I believe we each have a responsibility to help our government and currently mine is to make sure my taxes are paid so government can use to further develop the country,” he said. These plans were threatened on Monday when his carry-bag with all his company documents were stolen in Lae toptown. “I travel to Lae at least three times a week to buy newspaper returns (old) and bring to Bulolo where I resell to women vendors there,” he said. “Monday, while I was in town, I left my bag with the newspaper agent and ran some errands. “I returned to find that my bag had been stolen. For a business owner, these documents are gold. “I don’t trust leaving my documents behind in Bulolo, so I carry them everywhere. So when that happened, I was worried, but I prayed with faith that I will get my documents the next day.” On that day, Kelly Nathan, bored at home, had decided to do a taxi run for his elder brother. “I stopped at toptown and was waiting for customers when a man walked up, opened the cab door, dropped a package on the backseat, and left,” he said. “I thought he would come back with more cargo, but he never returned, so I went about my day. “When I returned home, I opened the bag and saw the documents and instantly had the feeling to return them. I rummaged through the papers, saw a mobile number and established contact.” It was past 10pm on Monday when IRC Lae’s pay officer Ruth James received a message from an unknown number. She said the content — image of a document — was familiar because Aru has been very compliant with paying his tax since registering and was known by the IRC team there. James connected the two men to meet at the IRC office on Tuesday. While exchanging documents, Aru learnt of Nathan’s plight. Nathan, from Wabag’s Ebri village, had migrated to Lae last year after dropping out of Grade 10, he was also fleeing continuous violence in the area, which had drawn in many young man his age. “I have been living with my elder brother and helping him as a handyman while I look for ways to further my education next year,” he said. Aru opened his home to Nathan. “You are now my son – my home in Bulolo is yours. You will work with me and get the education you want,” he said. James said that was the good that came out from the bad situation.

Title: New maternity ward will serve over 4,000 mothers in Nuku
Content: A MATERNITY ward that will cater for about 4,000 persons in Nuku Central LLG, in Nuku, West Sepik, was opened by local MP Joe Sungi last Thursday. Sungi when opening the ward at Wati Sub Health Centre at Wati Catholic Parish, urged the people to look after the health centre and its workers. Meanwhile, acting Nuku health manager Zedrech Tulu said that the maternity ward is a big achievement after 50 years of independence. “I urge people to look after this new maternity ward,” he said. “Many times mothers die and new born babies also die because of delay in getting them to a nearest health facility. “Nuku health centre is also far away.” Tulu said there were three delays that affected pregnant mothers and unborn child. “The first one is in the house when mother and father are not prepared to become parents in terms of finance,” he said. “Second is delay in getting to the maternity ward. “If a pregnant mother is far away from a maternity ward, chances of mother and baby dying are high. “And the other delay is the availability of the maternity ward. “So you must look after this maternity ward. “When you have a dispute in the community, don’t come and destroy the ward or harass health staff. You are only destroying yourself.” Meanwhile, a West Sepik heath authority (WSPHA) board member Tadi Masi was happy for MP Sungi’s support. “In other districts, the health services are rundown because their MPs are not supporting them,” he said. “The PHA is not getting enough funds from the National Government to run health services in the province. “Currently, health indicators in terms of immunisation in Nuku looks good because we have good support from our MP.” Masi also donate K5,000 to the sub health centre committee to go towards the purchase of solar light system for the ward.

Title: Nuku’s yam festival fascinates minister
Content: TOURISM, Arts and Culture Minister Beldan Namah was fascinated by the preparation and celebration of the Wakai Yam Festival in Nuku, West Sepik, recently. Namah was so fascinated that he pledged K300,000 to support the festival and to register it in the National Cultural Commission annual calendar. He also vowed to bring tourists in the next year’s festival. The villages of Wambiyu, Kale, Termes, Ingiap and Imbi-ip hosted this festival as part of the 50th Independence Anniversary celebration in the district. The villages displayed rows of huge yams, built high yam pyramid and put up a drama to tell the story of the introduction of yams in the Central Nuku local level government area. Namah in officiating the ceremony on Sept 19, said that it was a unique festival. “It has its own story. It has its own customs,” he said. “You can’t produce yam for nothing. You must observe customs and traditions. “So, these culture and tradition we must preserve. “To build the pyramid of yams, you must follow cultural protocols. “Women or visitors won’t see it. Man built it at night and in the morning, women and children will be surprised to see it. “So, it is a big custom. “You must keep our customs and village tradition in yam production.” Namah said that this festival symbolised economic independence. “We got political independence on Sept 16, 1975, but not economic independence,” he said. “However, now we are looking at economic independence, and you are already doing that. “You plant yam yourself, store some for-household consumption, share some with neighbours, and sell the rest at the local market. “It is a commodity and it promotes food security.”

Title: West Sepik’s Nuku holds first Sago Festival
Content: THE first ever Saksak (sago) Festival in the country was held at the remote Kafle village in Nuku, West Sepik, on Sept 17. Public Service Minister and Nuku MP Joseph Sungi, who attended the festival, said: “Sago is the staple food of Nuku and that is why the picture of theAmahau(traditional sago pounding stick) is in the Nuku District Development Authority letterhead official’s logo. “Sago will always be with us. As long as you are from Nuku, you will always eat sago. “We have been eating sago for generations.” Sungi also paid tribute to the women and daughters of Kafle and Arkosami villages. “Women and daughters are the backbone in sago making. Almost 50 per cent of sago making is done by women and daughters,” he said. “So, I thank mothers and daughters for making sago to feed their families. “Making sago also has traditional rituals to follow, and daughters know our custom. “For example, if you misbehave and parents are not happy with you, when you set out to produce sago starch, you won’t collect sufficient sago starch. “Sago making is a big job with customs to follow.” Chairlady for Women in Nuku Juscinta Gawi also said that men must not boast about making sago. “But it is the women who work hard to produce sago,” she said. The Kafle Saksak Festival chairman Roxi Endebu said that they started preparing for this festival last October and Kafle and Arksome villages produced a total of 972 bundles of sago and displayed them during the festival.

Title: PNG’s recent past seen in exhibit
Content: WHILE many of the official 50th anniversary of independence celebrations are over, we are very fortunate that some of them remain for people to appreciate. The National Museum and Art Gallery (NMAG) is hostingPiksa Bilong Taim Bipo: PNG’s Recent Past through Photography. This exhibition is co-sponsored by the NMAG and the National Cultural Commission, both under the Ministry for Tourism, Arts, and Culture. It can be found in the NMAG Theatrette.
