The exhibition will be on display until the end of the year. The exhibit contains over 200 historic photographs, from 1875 until the early 1960s, although most predate 1940, after which time photography became much more widespread and available to the public. All of today’s provinces are represented. Most of the images in the exhibition have never been publicly displayed before. They show the ancestors of present-day Papua New Guineans, preparing food, feasting, dancing, fishing, sailing, hunting, fighting, etc. Many images are of activities that are very familiar, while some show things that are less commonplace today. Although many of the people photographed are anonymous, some of them are named. The exhibit asks viewers to consider whether some of them might be your own ancestors. Some photos show regional differences while others reveal great similarities between all parts of PNG – unity in diversity. The photos also show the work of early missionaries and the colonial government at work in different parts of the country. Photography was invented in France in 1826/27. Fifty years later, after numerous technical improvements, the first photos were made in PNG by members of the British Challenger Expedition, when they visited Manus in 1875, as part of an important four-year expedition that established oceanography as a scientific discipline. Norwegian researcher Jan Hasselberg has been investigating early PNG photographs for decades and has organised the NMAG exhibition. He is also the author of the bookBeautiful Tufi: Between the Past and the Future (2013), and is involvedin a photo repatriation project involving different parts of the country. The original photos inPiksa Bilong Taim Bipohave been supplied from 29 archives and libraries in Australia, Austria, France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Papua New Guinea, Switzerland, United Kingdom and the United States of America. These photos serve as an essential part of the cultural heritage of Papua New Guinea and illustrate how important archives are to documenting this heritage. Through the efforts of libraries, archives, and their staff, we can all benefit from these documents more than a century later. This exhibit will stimulate much reflection about our nation’s past, and how these invaluable images resonate with people today.

Title: MP pushes for proper water systems
Content: EAST New Britain’s Pomio MP and Minister for Health Elias Kapavore stressed the importance of having a proper water system for health facilities as the Pomio District Hospital nears completion. “An important part of any healthcare facility is the provision of a consistent and reliable water supply,” Kapavore said, noting that without a proper water system, things were bound to go sideways. The new Pomio District Hospital will have its own water supply system. The district has engaged a local company that has done a feasibility study and was awarded the contract to build the water supply system for both the hospital and staff houses. Kapavore said he wanted to set a standard at the new Pomio District Hospital by ensuring reliable power supply and a consistent water system. He noted that the water system should be completed in two months, coinciding with the hospital’s opening. “I want to make this a model. We will connect the water through a water treatment plant and it will run 24 seven,” he said. He also stressed that the Provincial Health Authority (PHA) heads must be proactive and restructure their systems to create positions in their health facilities, noting concerns raised regarding the lack of manpower and essential services like water and electricity. “We need fully functioning hospitals with water and power supply, and there must be staff on board,” Kapavore said. The district hospital has already recruited more than 70 staff. “As I speak, all the staff are already recruited,” Kapavore said. He further announced that the Government will initiate more similar projects across the country. Kapavore urged the PHAs, as well as Members of Parliament, to work together and ensure that all hospitals in the country have consistent water supply. The water supply system project is valued at more than K2 million under the Water Sanitation Project. It is a collaboration between Pomio District and the Department of National Planning and Monitoring.

Title: LLG polling deferred – again. Priority given to national exams
Content: POLLING for this year’s Local Level Government elections has been deferred again – to allow the grades 10, 12 and eight national examinations to be completed. The new polling date is Oct 25. Acting Prime Minister John Rosso said in a statement yesterday that the deferral was necessary to allow the national examinations to proceed without interruption. “Over the past three days, I have convened a series of meetings involving key electoral stakeholders to consider how best to mitigate and respond to citizen concerns about the impact the Local Level Government elections may have on students sitting the national exams,” he said. Rosso said premised on the need to safeguard both the national examinations and the electoral process, it was agreed that the national exam schedule remain unchanged while the LLG elections be moved to Oct 25. The confirmed dates are: Rosso said the Electoral Commission would announce the revised dates for polling, counting, and return of writs in due course. “This decision was not made lightly,” he said. “However, it reflects on our Government’s commitment to safeguarding the education of our children while also fulfilling the important constitutional requirement of conducting LLG elections. “I acknowledge the operational challenges this presents for the Electoral Commission, given their advanced state of readiness. “The electoral commissioner (Simon Sinai) has considered citizen and government concerns, and has graciously agreed to exercise his constitutional powers to delay the commencement of polling in the interests of our future generations and to prevent disturbance of the national exams. “I commend him for this.” Rosso said the Government acknowledged the legal advice it received from the state solicitor, Department of Justice and Attorney-General. A technical team reporting directly to the chief secretary will work through the issues raised. Writs for the LLG elections were issued in May for polling to begin in July. But they were deferred to this month because of the changes to the number of LLGs. Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe said in Parliament early this month that there would be no more deferrals. “This is the 11th hour, we can’t make any more changes,” he said.

Title: O’Neill slams 3 per cent ‘finders fee’ imposed by NBC to lure in investors
Content: THE Government is meddling with the new National Banking Corporation (NBC), says former Prime Minister Peter O’Neill. O’Neill said that the NBC board purportedly elected to pay certain individuals, including those within the bank’s hierarchy, large sums in “finder’s fees” to bring in clients to its own bank. “Individuals who refer potential investors will be paid a finder’s fee of three per cent plus Goods and Services Tax to be paid to the referrer as either cash or shares,” he said. “There does not appear to be any restriction on who can be a referrer including politicians. So it looks like a chance to earn three per cent of K200 million is open to anyone who knows about these secret deals. “In a statement last week, defending an NEC decision to transfer all government bank accounts to the newly-licensed NBC, the minister responsible stated to all our surprise that the publicly-owned NBC was being privatised with around 50 investors already pumping in K100 million in new equity,” he said. O’Neill added that the people demanded to know “what the heck is going on with the National Development Bank (NDB) and its subsidiary NBC”. “Who are the investors that have signed up? What are the terms of the capital raising? Can those responsible release the terms under which these special investors provided the K100 million – what do they get in return,” he said. “Why are the people of PNG being kept in the dark over this nationally important privatisation of a state asset? “Was there a transparent process followed to appoint the current chairman as the middleman to raise the capital or was this procurement a closed shop arrangement? “This is not how institutions owned by the public are to be governed. We demand better than this especially from people entrusted with the people’s money and assets. “NBC seems to be a new tucker shop for politicians without transparency, scrutiny and the governance needed to ensure credibility and confidence. The FATF grey listing will soon be a blacklisting.” Meanwhile, the State, through the Kumul Consolidated Holdings and NDB, has diluted its shareholding in NBC to 52 per cent, following a private placement phase. NBC chairman Darrell Seeto said that a group of PNG citizens and PNG-owned businesses had taken up a new equity of K100 million. “Phase two of the private placement is underway and by the end of next month, we expect the State’s equity in NBCL will be further diluted to about 35 per cent,” he said. “The interest shown by experienced Papua New Guinean investors in taking up new equity in NBCL has been positive and shows they have faith in the development and expansion plans of the Bank. “It has always been the stated position of the State, that it would dilute its ownership of NBCL at the earliest opportunity.”

Title: Wages ‘should not’ drop below new threshold
Content: THE national minimum wage announced recently is merely a threshold below which wages should not drop and should not be taken as one that people can depend on for long periods, the person in charge of the determination said yesterday. Minimum Wages Board chairperson, Beverley Doiwa said the minimum wage was merely a “protection wage” and should change in keeping with cost of living increases and other factors. Doiwa said she was saddened, during her nationwide tour to make this determination, when she came across instances where people had been on the minimum wage of K3.50 for 10 years ormore. “The minimum wage is really the threshold wage. We should see our people earn more than that,” she said. “We need to tell our people that they should not be on it forever.” A veteran of three similar determinations – 2000, 2014 and 2025 – Doiwa said her board had done its job, and now it was up to government and other stakeholders to do theirs. The first task is to inform the people of what the minimum wage is, she said. Then it must be followed with compliance and enforcement. In this, the compliance and enforcement system is weak and ineffective at the present time, Doiwa said. The applicable laws, the Employment Act and the Labour Act, are outdated and date from 1958 and 1982. Penalties offered under those laws are too weak and need strengthening. Currently if a labour officer finds an instance of underpayment, he would normally advice the company to correct the issue within a set period of time – and that is about all. The workers’ unions have fallen silent and need support to get back to their former vibrancy and effectiveness, Doiwa said. Further, the industrial relations and arbitration division of the Labour and Employment Department needs firing up to operate effectively and efficiently as an implementing arm of the government. Doiwa said there had been a long lull between 2014 and 2025 because there was no political support for the work of her board. She is happy and confident that the political leadership at the present time is right, with Labour and Employment Minister Kessy Sawang who personally ensured that there was K4 million available for the board to do its work and conclude the nationwide consultation. Sawang has also undertaken to review the outdated laws. Doiwa said the board had decided not to consider separate minimum wages for rural and urban areas so that people in rural settings could be attracted by a higher wage to remain there rather than migrate. She called for more regular reviews of the minimum wages in the country to make it commensurate with the consumer price index. She called for the minimum wages setting to be institutionalised in the country rather than its current ad hoc arrangement. Doiwa said a review board or commission ought to be set up to institute minimum wages fixing. The new minimum wage took effect from September 8 when it was gazetted and will be compulsory on all companies from Jan 1, 2026. The public service which operates under its own law is not covered by the minimum wage. Minimum wages were at K3.50 from 2016 to 2025. They rise now to K5 and increase incrementally to K5.25 in 2027, then K5.50 in 2028.

Title: Toroama front-runner in ABG polls
Content: BOUGAINVILLE’s incumbent President Ishmael Toroama looks set to stay after initial results show him way ahead in the polls, according to a report. He was leading the presidential race yesterday with nearly 90,000 votes after a primary count, the office of the electoral commission confirmed toRadio New Zealand(RNZ Pacific). “He is well ahead in terms of the votes he has collected across all three regions on Bougainville,” the electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai toldRNZ Pacific. “Joe Lera, a longtime Papua New Guinea MP in the national parliament, is next, trailing behind with just 17,197 votes at this point,” he said. However, Tsianai said “quality checks” would be conducted on ballot papers from the North, Central and South regions, which could take a further three days. Checks involved combing through the paperwork to identify if there were any discrepancies in the primary count. “After completing those checks, we should be able to calculate the absolute majority and then we will be able to anounce the final results,” Tsianai said. He said that there were 33 single-member constituencies, and another five were approved last year. That makes 38 single-member constituencies, plus three regional seats for women and ex-combatants and the presidential seat – for the 45 seats in the Bougainville parliament.

Title: Work on road retaining wall expected to start next week
Content: ROADWORK to fix the collapsed section of the retaining wall on the Hubert Murray Highway at 2-Mile hill is expected to start on Monday, says National Capital District city manager Ravu Frank. “The construction work is necessary to reinstate the collapsed section of the retaining wall supporting the road,” Frank said in a statement. “The sustained damage was caused by a ruptured derelict Water PNG water main which had scoured the retaining wall foundation; reducing embankment stability and the overall factor of safety.” Frank said reinstatement work is expected to take about four months. “During the construction phase, traffic along Hubert Murray Highway at 2-Mile hill will be reduced to a single lane on the north-bound carriageway (Badili to Boroko). All south-bound traffic – travelling towards Badili – will be redirected onto the north-bound carriageway at the slip lanes adjacent to SVS 2-Mile. “The Purth Street roundabout shall remain accessible, however entry onto the Hubert Murray Highway shall be cordoned off. “The public and motorists are advised to adhere to posted road signage, drive with caution and follow the instructions of designated flagmen,”

Title: Customs says illicit items coming from Asia
Content: PAPUA NEW GUINEA Customs Services (PNGCS) says illicit items are coming into the country “from mostly Asian countries.” PNG Customs Services Commissioner David Towe toldThe Nationalthat Customs had reduced import of illicit tobacco since 2020. In 2018 and 2019, it was about 40 per cent but the figure significantly dropped to six per cent in 2023, he said. “Source (importing illegal items) is mostly Asian countries, Towe said. “Australia is now 30-35 per cent and they are finding it very difficult to bring it down and it is costing the country billions of dollars in lost revenue,” Towe said. “Malaysia has accepted that 40 per cent is illicit. They fight to maintain 60 per cent legal tobacco market. Many other countries are the same. We have been an absolute success by the Grace of God,” Towe said. The PNGCS is amending and reviewing the Customs legislations and will review the penalty provisions to ensure the “highest’’ penalties are applied to any importer who is involved in illicit and illegal trade. In 2018, an independent report by Melbourne-based company FTI Consulting estimated that the presence and prevalence of illicit tobacco in PNG was 36-38 per cent in the market. The report was presented to Prime Minister James Marape by the Manufacturers Council of PNG. Towe said that with combined efforts and collaboration with relevant stakeholders, including Treasury, police and Customs were able to drive down and significantly reduce illicit tobacco to less than six per cent as reported in a follow-up report released in 2023 by the same company FTI Consulting. “This outcome goes to show that with collaboration we can achieve great results. This effort saved the Government more than K200 million in excise taxes,” he added. “While the commendations from the prime minister is highly appreciated by the staff at PNGCS, there are more work to do,” Towe said. He also revealed that investigation into the K3.5 million illicit tobacco found in July was still going on and details of the investigation would be put out once PNGCS and the police concluded their investigation and made arrests. Marape said Papua New Guinea was not a dumping ground for illicit items, illegal trade, and illegal business activities. He said the Government had a ‘zero tolerance policy’ for illegal business activities, and warned that those engaging in illicit trade would face the “strongest possible penalties.” “My Government will ensure that hefty penalty fines are imposed, and we will not hesitate to reconsider and even terminate the business licences of companies or individuals found guilty of such practices,” he said. “Treasury, Customs, and the Investment Promotion Authority (IPA) are being tasked to review our policy, regulations, and laws to strengthen deterrent measures.”

Title: PNG Power still a long way to solving ongoing power crisis: CEO
Content: PNG Power is no closer to solving the ongoing power crisis in the Capital City after frustrating outages for its customers for over a week. Chief executive officer Paul Bayly indicated yesterday they were yet to find the solution so it may take a few more weeks to find and fix the problem. He said they were still working to fix the Kone substation where they believed the faults were located. Bayly said that they did not know the exact cost of the damage because they were still working to get the substation up to solve the issue. “We are currently sourcing the equipment within the country to fix the substation, but there are some other parts that we need to import and if the delivery of these parts are delayed then the issue will still continue,” he said. National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop discussed the constant outages with Bayly yesterday. He said every school, hospital, business house and home in the Capital needed power every day and recent blackouts caused a lot of issues for everyone. He said he was aware that PPL needed about K165 million to fix most of its aging and failing infrastructures and will work with State-Owned Enterprise Minister (SOE) and other stakeholders in the government to push to allocate the amount for PPL in the national budget. “From what I know, the recent power outages is due to the Kone-substation problem but this power issue has been happening before the Kone substation problem. I want PPL to come up with a strategic plan to solve these issues and not only react to work when there is a problem,” Parkop said. Other stakeholders from health, education, aviation, security and business sectors all raised similar concerns of power failure affecting their everyday activities and how costly it is to run on standby generators for more than eight hours.

Title: ‘Sex is not a game’: Wai says number of pregnant mothers with HIV rising
Content: THE Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is spreading unchecked, acting Health secretary Ken Wai says. Wai is sounding the old alarm, saying “sex is not a game”, and that prevention is the only way forward as there is no cure. Alarming too is the fact that there is an increase in the number of pregnant mothers being tested positive for the HIV. Wai said: “It is important for early antenatal checkups for antiretroviral drugs to be administered to stop transmission to the baby.” Health department national statistics show in general an infection rate of 30 cases or persons in a day with seven children being born with the virus. Records show that since the first case found in 1987, the health department have diagnosed up to 100,000 persons. The annual positive rate for new cases rose from 6,500 to 11,000 cases in a year. “The prevalence rate used to be 0.9 per cent but statistics haveseen an increase of up to 1.6 percent and from this observation, much emphasis is now given to mothers when going in for antenatal clinic and this is to make sure the babies are born normal. “The government this year allocated a budget of K2.5million to buy the HIV drugs so anyone that is found to be positive can be put on antiretroviral therapy. “That is not to cure them but to reduce the viral load so that it prevents and protects them from other infections,” he said. Health Department provides services to make sure treatment is administered to prevent the parent to child transmission. Antiretroviral drugs are made available at hospitals, clinics, health centres and aid posts around the country. This follows the declaration of national HIV emergency by the PNG Government in June this year acting on a rising crisis of infection rate. “There are many drivers of the rising HIV rates and some of these are within the health system with inaccessibility to testing, treatment, cultural and social norms that cause stigma and fear. Wai said the strong message is on prevention as the only way to reduce HIV in the country. “For young people, sex is not a game and it’s not a trial and error thing,” he said. “Wait to be married and get tested before marriage and for married people the marital bed is the only bed to have sex and outside of that there is ‘no’ as at this time, it’s risky. “So part of our awareness we advise people to wear a condom for protection or just the best way is to abstain from sex with multiple partners,” he said. Wai said those who have been unfaithful or have multiple partners should go to the nearest health centre to get tested and if found positive to undergo counselling and treatment.

Title: Catholic dioceses receive buses and land cruisers
Content: CATHOLIC dioceses of Port Moresby and Bereina are recipients of a donation of three buses and two land cruisers. When blessing the vehicles, Archbishop of Port Moresby Cardinal Sir John Ribat said these would enhance the health workers’ ability to deliver health care to where it was much needed. “Transport and logistics are two of the biggest setbacks in delivery of health services in the country and the donation of vehicles will make easier for the health workers in the respective dioceses,” he said. Sir John said that with a declared Human Infection Virus (HIV) emergency, these would help with more awareness and outreach in National Capital District (NCD) and Central. The three buses will go to St. Paul Gerehu clinic, St Therese clinic in Hohola and a Catholic agency, Key Population Advocacy Consortium (KPAC) while the land cruisers go to the Bereina archdiocese Veifa run clinic and the Catholic Church health services headquarters in Port Moresby. The fleet of vehicles was procured and handed over by representatives from the Australian High Commission. Australian High Commission Minister Councilor Penny Morton said Australia was committed to ongoing delivery of vital health services to PNG. The Catholic Church health services has 13 facilities that are currently undergoing a sexual reproductive health integration project under a PNG Australia partnership programme. The project over the next 12 months is tied to strengthening engagement with community and key population to gain access to quality HIV and sexual health services. Health Department acting secretary Ken Wai thanked the Australian Government for its continued support to the health system in the country. “Catholic Agencies provide almost three quarters of health and education services to the country and they must be commended for their tremendous effort,” he said. “The country could not take on this provision of services on its own without the services and funding from key partners.”

Title: Proper water system crucial to health facilities, says minister
Content: EAST New Britain’s Pomio MP and Minister for Health Elias Kapavore stressed the importance of having a proper water system for health facilities as the Pomio District Hospital nears completion. “An important part of any healthcare facility is the provision of a consistent and reliable water supply,” Kapavore said, noting that without a proper water system, things were bound to go sideways. The new Pomio District Hospital will have its own water supply system. The district has engaged a local company that has done a feasibility study and was awarded the contract to build the water supply system for both the hospital and staff houses. Kapavore said he wanted to set a standard at the new Pomio District Hospital by ensuring reliable power supply and a consistent water system. He noted that the water system should be completed in two months, coinciding with the hospital’s opening. “I want to make this a model. We will connect the water through a water treatment plant and it will run 24 seven,” he said. Kapavore also stressed that the provincial health authority (PHA) heads must be proactive and restructure their systems to create positions in their health facilities, noting concerns raised regarding the lack of manpower and essential services like water and electricity. “We need fully functioning hospitals with water and power supply, and there must be staff on board,” he said. The district hospital has already recruited more than 70 staff. “As I speak, all the staff are already recruited,” Kapavore said. He further announced that the Government will initiate more similar projects across the country. Kapavore urged the PHAs, as well as Members of Parliament, to work together and ensure that all hospitals in the country have consistent water supply. The water supply system project is valued at more than K2 million under the Water Sanitation Project. It is a collaboration between Pomio and the Department of National Planning and Monitoring.

Title: New York Declaration a positive step, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has welcomed the adoption of the New York Declaration by the United Nations General Assembly, describing it as an important step in the global community’s response to the Israel–Palestine conflict. The declaration, endorsed earlier this month by most member states, explicitly condemned Hamas as a terrorist organisation for the first time, while reaffirming Israel’s right to exist and the Palestinian people’s right to dignity and security. Marape said Papua New Guinea supports the declaration’s message but emphasised that peace must start from within the region itself. A meeting at the “peace table” will set pace for settlement of everything else in the Israeli–Gaza conflict. “If you want peace, both sides must sit at the table together. Dialogue must come first before any solution is decided upon,” Marape said. He urged Hamas to take responsibility as the first step. “Take responsibility, apologise and release the hostages. If you claim to be the voice of the Gaza and Palestinian people, then step up for your people and for peace. The world will protect you when you show responsibility,” he said. The Prime Minister also appealed to Israel to “give peace a chance” by joining calls for a truce and urged the United Nations to lead an immediate effort to facilitate such talks. He reiterated that terrorism cannot and must not be rewarded. “You cannot compel political solutions at the backdrop of terrorism. Hamas must lay down its arms, release hostages unconditionally, and stop holding the citizens of Gaza to ransom. This will enable Israel to come to the table for peace and long-term political solution,” Marape said. While acknowledging international calls for a two-state solution, Prime Minister Marape questioned whether the proposal reflects the genuine will of both parties in conflict. “Real peace between Israel and Palestine must be authentically born from the land and people themselves — not imposed on one or another,” he said. He reaffirmed Papua New Guinea’s firm support for the preservation of the State of Israel, while also recognising the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people. “When Hamas makes that step forward, then Israel must also step forward. That is how real peace will begin — at the table, not at the barrel of a gun,” he said. Marape drew on Papua New Guinea’s own experience of ending conflict through negotiation, highlighting the 2001 Bougainville Peace Agreement. “Papua New Guinea is proof that peace is possible when both sides put down arms and sit at the table. Dialogue, not violence, ended our conflict and it can end others,” he said. He further called on Israel to exercise maximum restraint to ensure innocent civilians are not caught in the crossfire, noting that civilians have too often borne the heaviest burden in conflicts worldwide. Marape said Papua New Guinea will continue to back genuine dialogue, humanitarian protection and locally-driven solutions in line with the principles outlined in the New York Declaration.

Title: ENB officials pay final respects
Content: THE body of Darius Kunai, who served as East New Britain’s Kokopo administrator, was handed over to his family at Kenabot United Church in Kokopo on Tuesday. Kunai passed away three months ago in the Philippines, where he had travelled to seek further medical treatment. His body was repatriated to Papua New Guinea over the weekend before being flown to Kokopo for the handover. The handover was attended by senior government officials including ENB Governor Michael Marum, colleagues, and community leaders who gathered to pay their final respects. Kunai had been a public servant for more than 30 years, and was remembered for his dedication to serving the people of Kokopo district and East New Britain as a whole. The casket was formally received by his family, accompanied by prayers and tributes. Provincial administrator Levi Mano said Kunai’s appointment to the district administrator post, was a testimony in itself. “When changes were occurring, I was looking around for a potential candidate to take the position and one that stood out was this man lying here,” he said. “Our decision to promote him is a testimony of the capability that this man had.” Marum shared similar sentiments. Speaking for ENB’s four MPs and himself, Marum acknowledged Kunai’s service to the province and the people. Other officials who spoke praised Kunai’s service and described him as a hardworking and humble leader.

Title: Governor says Wenge was a ‘national hero’
Content: SOUTHERN Highlands Governor William Powi has described the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge as a “true statesman and a national hero” who has left a ‘huge vacuum’ to fill. “It is not easy to accept that such a man of unmatched integrity and firebrand leadership, has left us,” Powi said in a statement. Powi said Wenge was a man of deep intelligence, wisdom, strength and character, loved by the people of PNG. “He was a leader who appreciated and cherished the significance of our national unity and called for greater political power-sharing with provinces, equitable resource distribution and good governance,” he said. “He tarried until Sept 13, 2025, only to pass away three days before our golden jubilee. “We celebrated our Independence with mixed emotion – sad because he left us early but happy knowing that he served our nation with distinction. “There is no greater honour than to say ‘thank you, Governor Luther Wenge’. I thank the family the people of Morobe for their sacrifices in making a leader and giving PNG a great man. “Morobe sent out missionaries, teachers, nurses and pioneers who impacted our nation, especially the Highlands forever. “Yet, among all your impeccable contributions to nation building, Morobe gave us this great man.” Meanwhile, Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim, in his condolence message said: “Governor Wenge served our nation with distinction as a lawyer, magistrate, politician and leader. “His dedication to the people of Morobe and Papua New Guinea will be long remembered.” A lie-in-State programme for Wenge will be held at the Grand Hall at Parliament House in Port Moresby on Oct 2. This will be followed by the official funeral service on Oct 7, at the Sir Ignatius Kilage Outdoor Stadium. He will be flown to his village in Baindong to be buried.
People: Luther Wenge, Solan Mirisim, William Powi

Title: Concerns over prison’s blocked sewerage strainer
Content: A sewerage strainer located east of the Correctional Service Minimum Security Unit (MSU) at Bomana Prison in Port Moresby is blocked, causing the prison’s toilets to overflow. Low-risk prisoner Allan Aiso, who was assigned to clear out the strainer, said another issue was the smell from the old sewerage ponds at the entrance of MSU and the existing strainer or filter where the waste ran through. “I clear out the rubbish three times a day to avoid the waste building up,” he said. “I use a stick to clear out mostly toilet paper that clogs the pipes here.” Aiso was assigned to the plumbing section under his rehabilitation programme and this was part of his duty while serving his five-year sentence. Apart from the heavy stench, it was also noted that prisoners did not wear any protective gear, masks or gloves. He was not issued any of such equipment but he had to get the job done or it would affect most of the prisoners. The Bomana sewerage covers the CS Barracks, minimum and high risk prison, the Bomana Police Training College, Red Sea Barracks, Kerepia and CS barracks and surrounding areas. The construction of the new sewerage site was underway between the maximum prison wing and MSU and was expected to be completed early next year. Lome Paina Construction Limited managing director Jacob Walo said the existing sewerage was dead, causing the blockages. He said once the new pipes were laid in place and the sewerage chambers were built, the existing pipes would be closed off and waste would flow direct through a new strainer.

Title: Rabaul launches 10 projects
Content: EAST New Britain’s Rabaul administration has launched 10 rural service delivery projects (RSDP) that will benefit communities and complement the provincial administration’s focus on ward governance. The projects launched included four ward halls, a women’s resource centre and five water catchment areas in the Balanataman Local Level Government (LLG). The facilities opened were the Raluan ward two, Malaguna ward two, and Nonga village ward halls, along with the Malaguna ward three Women’s Resource Centre. Water catchments areas were in Raluan ward one, Malaguna ward three, Tavui wards one and two, and Iawakaka ward. Speaking at the closing of the event in Iawakaka, ENB RSDP coordinator Paul Kapa said Balanataman LLG was chosen to pilot the programme. “This RSDP programme is World Bank funded and looks at community driven projects that can benefit communities and complements the administrations’ focus on ward governance,” Kapa said. He announced that Rabaul is the first district to complete all 12 projects under the RSDP programme. Kapa said the launches for Volavolo and Ratavul ward halls would be later due to ongoing law and order issues in the area. He commended the wards for meeting compliance and presented certificates of completion and audit reports. Rabaul administrator Freddy Lemeki praised RSDP and district team for ensuring projects were delivered on time.  He said many wards had long been without proper halls and water catchments, and the new facilities also helped meet the government’s minimum ward standards. Lemeki urged communities to take ownership of the projects by having their operation and maintenance plans in place.

Title: Caritas students on job training with Department of Personnel Management
Content: SIX grade 11 students from Caritas Technical Secondary School in Port Moresby are currently doing on-the-job training with the Department of Personnel Management (DPM). DPM secretary Taies Sansan, in welcoming the students, said the initiative was a key part of DPM’s commitment to supporting education and nurturing future talent in Papua New Guinea. Sansan said the programme bridged the gap between theoretical classroom knowledge and real-world application, equipping students with essential skills and confidence for their careers. She said the students would complete 400 hours of training as part of their academic requirement, gaining valuable exposure to the public service sector.

Title: Police minister welcomes treaty
Content: POLICE Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jr has welcomed the direction taken by Prime Minister James Marape and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on the proposed Papua New Guinea–Australia Defence Treaty, stressing the importance of respect and mutual benefit. Tsiamalili, who is the regional member for Bougainville, said that Papua New Guinea was steadily emerging as a pillar of stability and leadership in the Pacific, and that the country’s security partnerships must reflect its growing role in regional affairs. “We have always insisted that treaties of this nature must be mutually beneficial and respectful. This is about future-proofing our relationships with our traditional partners in the region while safeguarding the sovereignty of our people,” he said in a statement. He highlighted PNG’s growing role in regional policing through the Pacific Police Initiative and the Pacific Police Support Group (PPSG), supported by Australia and other partners, while also acknowledging the need to scale up both the Royal PNG Royal Constabulary and the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF). “The PNGDF must be strengthened to serve not only our communities but also the wider Pacific region. “Whether responding to humanitarian needs or regional security challenges, Papua New Guinea is ready to stand alongside Australia, New Zealand, and our Pacific family,” he said. Tsiamalili confirmed that the proposed treaty will undergo National Executive Council (NEC) deliberation before endorsement by Prime Minister James Marape. “This treaty is not just about defence – it is about building a framework of trust, respect, and responsibility that places PNG at the heart of regional security cooperation,” he said.

Title: New Maramuni hospital to be built
Content: THE Maramuni District Hospital in Wabag, Enga, will be constructed at a cost of K30 million funded by the Asian Development Bank, says Wabag MP Dr Lino Tom. Tom was at the Pasalangus Government Station in the rural Maramuni LLG last weekend when he made the announcement. He said the K30 million level-three district hospital project would take a total of two years to be completed in three stages. He added that the stage one component was awarded to Cost Guide PNG Limited to carry out civil works and construction of an outpatient and accident and emergency block, three staff houses, a genset block, an ablution block and two guard posts. Tom said that the Wabag-Maramuni section of the ongoing Enga Sepik Highway project had been widened and graveled to ensure the construction of this vital health infrastructural project to start as initially planned.

Title: Sonk withdraws cases, will seek judicial review on new board’s appointment
Content: SIDELINED Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) managing director Wapu Sonk has withdrawn the two court cases challenging his suspension, and instead will seek a judicial review of the appointment of new board members. National Court Judge Collin Makail yesterday granted the application to withdraw the two cases. “The two proceedings are now withdrawn and Sonk will pay the cost for both proceedings,” he said. The two cases filed by Sonk were to challenge his suspension as the KPHL managing director, and to challenge the appointment of the new KPHL board. Sonk filed the case against David Kil as the Registrar of Companies, KPHL board chairman Gerea Aopi, and members Jacob Anga, George Gware and Sundaram Srinivasan. KPHL board chairman Gerea Aopi yesterday welcomed the decision by Sonk to withdraw the cases. “The board resolution to suspend Sonk as the KPHL managing director and appoint Luke Liria as acting managing director was not malicious in intent but administrative, to ensure the integrity of process, both for KPHL in ensuring the good governance principle of transparency and accountability, and for Sonk to addresses his personal issues,” he said. He said justice must not only be done but seen to be done. “Whatever perceptions and public opinion may be, only courts of law can ascertain guilt or otherwise. Sonk is therefore innocent as far as the board is concerned.” Court documents show that Sonk is seeking a declaration that Kil has no power under the Companies Act to alter or amend the records of KPHL in the Companies Register with the Investment Promotion Authority (IPA), unless and until it is authorised to do so by the management of the company or its board secretary, and that the decisions and actions of Kil were null and void and of no effect. He requests the court to declare that Aopi, Anga, Gware and Srinivasan are not directors of KPHL and they have no power of management and control over the affairs, employees and assets of KPHL.

Title: Expect more electricity supply interruptions, says PNG Power
Content: PORT Moresby residents can expect more electricity supply interruptions as PNG Power Limited continues to repair the Konedobu substation which was damaged by fire last Friday. “A couple of our feeders from Waigani substation, Boroko substation, Moitaka substation, Kanudi substation and the new Kilakila substation have been offloaded and switched over to assist the Konedobu substation feeders,” PNG Power said in a statement. “All our affected Kone feeder loads are now being taken onboard by various outer substation feeders. “However, we are carrying out load-shedding due to technical limitations.” The fire at the Konedobu substation destroyed the 11 kilovolt insulators for Kone feeders. The damaged equipment requires a replacement which must be brought from overseas. The company said that a new Kilakila feeder under construction since Monday would be undergoing testing. “If successful, this feeder will be energised and can take on more connectivity, relieving the overly stressed feeders within the Port Moresby grid. “We anticipate this to end the load-shedding. Should you experience any unexpected outages, please report to our National Call Center on Toll Free 116 or Email:[email protected]?” Work to put new conductors at the Sabama Junction is almost completed, as well as the upgrade on the similar conductors along Two-Mile. “Once all these work is completed, a technical test will be carried out, before further energisation takes place. This is a critical work that will allow more connectivity and ease loadings from other feeders, assisting the affected Kone Substation Feeders,” PNG Power said.

Title: Counting carries on smoothly
Content: THE counting of votes for the 2025 Autonomous Region of Bougainville general election is progressing without much trouble after polling ended two weeks ago, says Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai. “This has been a transparent and peaceful election process,” Tsianai said. “Together, with the patience and commitment of all involved, we will bring this election to a successful conclusion.” He said that the counting for seats in the region continued with some declarations already been made. They include the 38 single-member constituency seats, three regional women representatives, the three regional ex-combatants’ representatives for North, South and Central Bougainville, and the seat for president. Tsianai said counting started late due to logistical issues with the transportation of ballot boxes after polling ended on Sept 8. “After polling, ballot boxes were securely transported to the four counting centres, with police providing constant security,” he said. “Due to logistical issues, counting began three days later than expected on Sept 12 and continues to progress steadily.” He reaffirmed the commitment by his officers to completing the counting process transparently and as soon possible. The Bougainville Electoral Commissioner had announced that counting was to end on Oct 5, with writs to be returned the day after. Counting was originally scheduled to end on Sunday (Sept 21) and writs returned on Monday. In accordance with sections 146 and 147 of the Bougainville Elections Act, the date for the return of writs was extended to Oct 6, allowing the counting of votes to continue until then.

Title: Ialibu district hospital stages first hysterectomy
Content: A DAY before Ialibu District’s Level Four Hospital commissioned its new operating theatre, doctors successfully performed the facility’s first hysterectomy operation. The operation brought applause from both locals and officials who marveled at what a chance this introduces to the district. One observer wrote to the newspaper with the comments: “Huge congratulations to the entire team at Ialibu Hospital on this incredible achievement! Performing the first hysterectomy operation is a testament to the hard work, dedication, and commitment to delivering quality healthcare services. This milestone is not just a celebration of medical excellence but also a reflection of the positive impact on the community.” Prime Minister James Marape called from New York to praise the Southern Highlands Provincial Health Authority (SHPHA) as a “model of excellence” in delivering facilities such as the Ialibu District Hospital. Marape said in a statement: “For the past three years, SHPHA has delivered vital services and saved lives in some of the most remote parts of our country. This hospital stands as proof that government support, when used well, can make a real difference.” He said that K3.7 million was allocated by the Government to upgrade the facility into a fully-fledged District Hospital. Health Minister Elias Kapavore who officiated at the opening said: “I congratulate the CEO Dr Joseph Birisi, chairman Augustine Mano, and the SHPHA board and management for a job well done. “Our role as government is to make policy, but today, I am proud to see that policy become reality,” Kapavore said. Dr Birisi said that the hospital was now the model district hospital. “We will roll out the same standard to other districts while making Mendi General Hospital the main referral centre for South Highlands,” Birisi said. Special thanks were offered to Ialibu-Pangia MP and fomrer prime minister Peter O’Neill for his leadership and support in advancing healthcare infrastructure in the district and the Highlands region.

Title: We will support Frieda project if all West Sepik leaders are behind it: PM
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says that the Government will support the Frieda copper-gold project if all West Sepik leaders agree to it going ahead. “The project is in your province and if you want it to start quickly, then we stand ready according to your decision,” he said. He said that this was important given the economic impact the project would have in the province and the surrounding provinces supporting West Sepik. The Telefomin district and its surrounding communities are currently supported by the OK Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) tax credit scheme. This has ensured the construction of the Tabubil-Telefomin road plus the provision of health, education and banking services. “We must thank the people of Western for sharing their resources with West Sepik during this time. This district is considered a priority under the OTML tax credit schemes,” he said. “While we are working on the Frieda project, leaders must remain in their districts and work with the resources they have now and not depend entirely on OK Tedi alone.” He said that other resources such as oil palm, forestry, cocoa and marine would generate income for the province too. Marape was responding to a request by Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim last week for the Government to consider opening the Frieda project into a mining exploration given the copper and gold it contains. Mirisim said the project would drive development and progress for his district and would address Telefomin’s isolation.

Title: Marles honours friend, opens PNG Trade Union’s Paska Solidarity Hub
Content: THE renovated building at the Papua New Guinea Trade Union Congress headquarters in Port Moresby has been named the “Paska Solidarity Hub” in tribute to the late John Paska. Australian deputy prime minister Richard Marles, who was a close friend of trade union leader Paska, opened the building last Monday when he was in the country for the 50th independence anniversary celebrations. Marles, also a long-serving trade unionist before entering politics, visited the Korobosea office before attending the programme planned for him. “Paska is my experience and story of PNG,” he said. “It was so sad to hear of John’s passing last year. One of my life-long dreams was to go with John to Kavieng. He promised to take me out shark-calling in New Ireland. “We never got to do that. John was a very different mind and we shared many times and thoughts together. He felt so much for this incredible country. “I just want you to know how much it means to me to pay this tribute to him before the 50th anniversary celebrations and to name this building after him as the Paska Solidarity Hub. It is a fitting tribute to a giant of the PNG Trade Union movement.” Congress general-secretary Clemence Kanau said the building meant a new beginning for the union.

Title: Australian flag lowered on Independence Day returned
Content: The Australian flag lowered on Independence Day in 1975 at Ossima Primary School, West Sepik, has been returned to the Australian government – and is now on display at the National Museum and Arts Gallery (NMAG). Eighty-four-year-old retired teacher Peter Kanawi, who lowered the flag on Sept 16, 1975 has been the guardian of the historic artefact for 50 years. The existence of the flag became apparent after a social media post went viral. His family had put a call out asking for help to give it back to Australia and the Australian High Commission contacted them to retrieve it. As a token of Australia’s deep appreciation for his custodianship of this piece of history, the high commission exchanged the pre-independence Australian flag with a flag of Papua New Guinea for the school to fly in remembrance of Sept 16, 1975, and Australia and Papua New Guinea’s strong partnership. As part of the exchange on Aug 25 at Ossima Primary School, a letter from Australian High Commissioner and Special Envoy for the Pacific and Regional Affairs Ewen MacDonald, was also presented to the Kanawi family. The flag is an important reminder of a pivotal moment in Papua New Guinea’s history. It is currently on display with the Wok bung wantaim exhibition, an exhibition which features archival photographs for the National Archives of Australia’s collection. This exhibition captures the spirit of independence celebrations and the path that led to it. It is a tribute to the architects of independence and the people of Papua New Guinea. Kanawi said: “Australia has been good to us. I kept the flag to honour the relationship and the journey we’ve shared. “I believe God kept me alive to see this day… I am happy and blessed to be here, to return the flag as a sign of respect for my country, for Australia and for leaders like late the Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare who inspired me.”

Title: Ousted MP granted leave to appeal election case
Content: OUSTED Lagaip MP Amos Joseph Akem will go ahead to appeal the decision of the National Court of April 30 that nullified his election victory after the Supreme Court granted leave to his appeal yesterday. Justice Allan Kingsley David, who presided as a single-man Supreme Court bench, ruled in Waigani that the trial judge had erred in fact and law to nullify Akem’s election victory because he was not directly involved in the bribery with Rainbo Paita. “The application for leave is granted to Akem,” he said. Akem’s lawyers Brendan Lai and Randolph Jacob Lains were present in court yesterday when the ruling was made. On April 30, National Court Judge Joseph Yagi ordered a by-election for the Lagaip seat in Enga after finding Akem, who won the 2023 by-election, guilty of committing bribery. Yagi ordered that Akem’s election victory be declared null and void. “A new election or by-election for Lagaip Open electorate in Enga shall be conducted forthwith by the Electoral Commission,” he said. Former Lagaip-Pogera MP Tomait Kapili had filed a petition against Akem, based on bribery allegations. Judge Yagi also ordered that the petition be upheld. He declared that Akem was not duly elected. “Pursuant to Section 216 of the Organic Law, the Registrar of the National Court shall report the finding of the court to the relevant authorities,” he said. Judge Yagi said the Registrar of the National Court shall promptly forward a sealed copy of the order to the Clerk of Parliament.

Title: Inmates from Bulolo want Correctional Service facility in district
Content: BULOLO inmates at Buimo jail in Lae are appealing for a Correctional Service (CS) facility to be established in their district to ease the burden on Buimo. Buimo CS commander Michael Wundia said the facility is holding 1,076 inmates – more than double its intended capacity. This has created serious challenges in accommodation, food supply, hygiene and overall inmate welfare, he said. “The need for accommodation is high, the need for food too is high, but with support from business houses, communities and our Morobe leaders, we are most of the time alright with food rations,” Wundia said. “A rural lockup in Bulolo would be a relief for us here at Buimo.” Wundia highlighted that the late Bulolo MP and deputy prime minister Sam Basil had planned for a rural lock-up in Mumeng during his term. In 2021, the Marape-Basil government reportedly allocated K50 million for a lock-up and rehabilitation centre in Mumeng, with land secured, but construction never proceeded following Basil’s passing in 2022. An inmate from Bulolo, Alfred Lua Manak, who has served seven years at Buimo, spoke on behalf of the 102 inmates from the district. He urged the current Bulolo MP, Sam Basil Jr, to revive his late father’s plan. “I’m sure this plan was already there with your father and now you’re here, I would like to request again for Bulolo to have its own lock-up in the district, a court and our own judge,” Manak said. “That’s our only request.” Wundia also urged the government that in the next 50 years, all districts in Morobe should look at setting up a rural lockup to ease the burden on Buimo.

Title: Work on Bomana sewerage plant nearing completion
Content: CONSTRUCTION work on the Bomana sewerage plant outside the Correctional Service minimum prison wing is nearing completion, says a contractor. Lome Paina Construction managing director Jacob Walo said construction was 50 per cent done with the laying of pipes this week. “Despite having issues with funding, we have now secured the piping before we can start work on building the sewerage,” he said. “There will be three chambers. “The pipes have been strengthened by couplings and tested for leakage. “Once the chambers are built, the tap to the previous manhole will be closed off to let the sewerage flow to the new plant. “We are also looking at installing a pump at the back of the minimum prison but that is not within the project scope. “The pump will accommodate flushing out the waste because the sewerage is in low grounds.” The contractor procured 250 ml diameter pipes which had been laid through to the main hole. The total cost of the septic tank is at K1.6 million and the size will be doubled from the previous of 15 times 20 meters in diameter to 20 by 40 meters. The height of the chambers will be at 3.5 meters and is estimated to last more than 50 years. “A second hole will be constructed at the end of the chambers to act a waste outlet,” Walo said. “An existing main hole which sits next to the current strainer are clogged and will be replaced and pipes removed and diverted once the new septic is built.” CS officials were also on hand to check on the project and to ensure the project was working within its timeframe of 12 months. Over the years the stench had caused health issues to the community and was near a state of being condemned. CS Assistant Commissioner policy planning and evaluation Francesca Marenge said upon two site checks, the contractor was up to date with his work. “In terms of funding, that is slow but the contractor is keeping in pace with whatever resources he has available, and that’s the main point. If funding is delivered than the work can be completed on time,” she said.

Title: Rehabilitation of NCD’s Rainbow road launched
Content: RAINBOW Village in Gerehu will have two entry and exit roads constructed to aid traffic for residents, says National Capital District Commission (NCDC) Governor Powes Parkop. Parkop said this rehabilitation will start along the current entrance into Rainbow, taking the first turn left at the back of the Mobil Service Station and continuing left to the end of the road. “We are rehabilitating that part of the road due to years of neglect by former MPs,” he said. “This project will see some additions to entry and exit points so we control the traffic as right now it is highly congested. “Over the years, some of the poor drainage had contributed to the road eroding and so we will fix it now. “This is a small intervention that we hope can make a bigger contribution to the quality of life and wellbeing here in Rainbow.” Parkop said this road within Rainbow had been here 15 years, and the rehabilitation was long- time coming. Part of the rehabilitation will have an entry and exit point parallel to Port Moresby National High School and one towards the back streets of Rainbow. This will reopen the access parallel to Nautana towards the back of Gerehu. City manager Frank Ravu said this was a very important road to be rehabilitated as the areas housed many public servants and private sector workers and he thanked the NCDC Board and Government for availing funds to this project. Government Chief Secretary Ivan Pomaleu was invited as a resident of the Rainbow. He had submitted part proposal to the NCDC to look into fixing the roads on behalf of the rainbow community. Contractor Reinhold Engineering project manager Fitzgerald Bob said the rehabilitation costing was at K5.6 million and would cater for road works, sealing, drainage and other infrastructure work. The designated road is a collector road that is a feeder to smaller roads within Rainbow. Over the years, the condition of the road has eroded, causing large drenches in the road, affecting flow of traffic and flooding during wet season. He said the current road where the rehabilitation work would start stretched 780 meters in length. This project is an initiative of the NCDC with part funding coming under the provincial infrastructure grant by the national Government.

Title: PNG’s youth unemployment a prevalent challenge, says ILO
Content: THE International Labour Organisation (ILO) has highlighted youth unemployment as a prevalent challenge affecting much of Papua New Guinea’s labour market. In its country report last year, the ILO – a United Nations specialised agency dealing with work and workplace issues, and related rights and standards – stated that youth unemployment in PNG was about three times higher than for the general population. “Youth unemployment is about three times higher than for the general population, largely due to the low absorption of school leavers into the formal employment sector,” the ILO report said. “A growing number of children are engaged in the worst forms of child labour, illicit activities and hazardous work. “Many children below the age of 18 work as domestic servants, on plantations, and in the tourism industry.” It stated that the unemployment rate was 2.7 per cent and rising to 3.8 per cent for the youth in the country, with 27.7 per cent of this demographic in education, employment, or training. Meanwhile, ILO also highlighted that challenges were pervasive in the country’s labour market which has a participation rate of 52 per cent, which includes the informal economy. “A large proportion of the workforce are in informal and subsistence agriculture,” it said. “Over half of the those working in formal wage employment are in the services sector at 53.7 per cent, followed with 38.6 per cent in agriculture and 7.6 per cent in industry. “The private sector accounts for more than 90 per cent of employment, however employment expansion is constrained by infrastructure problems and relatively low labour productivity. “The recent investments in developing infrastructure have supported growth in formal employment, but also created shortages of skilled labour.”

Title: Marape urges world leaders to act on preserving forests
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has urged the international community to act decisively to protect the planet’s forests, oceans and biodiversity, warning that humanity is “borrowing our children’s future” through unsustainable lifestyles. Speaking at a high-level side meeting during the United Nations (UN) General Assembly on unlocking nature finance at Cop30, Marape addressed a gathering of environmental practitioners and partners focused on concrete action. He drew attention to the uniqueness of Earth in the cosmos, stressing that no other planet could sustain human life. “Look 96 billion light years into the observable universe – there is no other planet like ours,” he said. “It does not matter what Elon Musk or others may pursue on Mars, we will never find another Earth. It is better to save this planet than to search for life elsewhere.” The prime minister cautioned that human activity had pushed the Earth close to irreversible damage. “We live at a point in history where human impact on nature is at its maximum tilt,” he said. “If we do not reverse the way we live, our children and grandchildren will not inherit the same comfortable Earth that we enjoy today. We may one day be forced to carry bottled oxygen, just as we now fight over water.” Marape anchored his message in faith, recalling the Book of Genesis and God’s command that humans act as stewards, not destroyers, of creation. “For thousands of years, that balance was maintained. It is only in the last 200 years that mankind’s footprint has caused major damage. We must now take responsibility,” he said. He noted that astronauts who look back at Earth from space often experience what is called the “overview effect” – the sudden realisation of the planet’s fragility. “Neil Armstrong must have felt it in 1969 when he stood on the moon and longed to return to the only blue planet we have,” he said. Marape highlighted Papua New Guinea’s critical role as custodian of one of the world’s last remaining great rainforests and its vast marine biodiversity. “Papua New Guinea is almost 80 per cent forested, and our coral reefs are among the richest on Earth,” he said. “Together with the Amazon, the Congo Basin, and Indonesia, PNG represents one of the final frontiers of tropical rainforest preservation. “These forests are not just a PNG asset – they belong to humanity.” Marape recounted how UN secretary-general António Guterres, during his visit to PNG earlier this month, was “amazed” to witness the scale of the country’s intact forests after flying hours into the interior. “Our forests and oceans are carbon sinks, oxygen producers and biodiversity homes. To lose them is to lose balance on Earth itself.” Marape explained PNG’s efforts to tax loggers, curb unsustainable harvesting and dedicate up to 72 per cent of its landmass to permanent rainforest preservation. But he stressed that without global partnerships, the temptation for landowners to trade forests for quick cash would persist. “Ninety-seven per cent of our land is owned by our people. “They want to protect it, but they are tempted by immediate gains,” he said. “We need investors and sponsors to work with us so that preserving forests becomes more valuable than cutting them down.” Marape said PNG had already increased logging taxes to as high as 72 per cent before settling back to 48 per cent to deter exploitation. “We are serious about protecting our forests, but we need partners who will assist us in conserving this global asset.” Marape gave a stark reminder of the stakes. “This is our one planet. If the balance is broken, we are not just losing trees or oceans – we are losing Earth itself. “Across 96 billion light years of the universe, there is no other home for humanity. It is better to save this one.”

Title: WWII remains of American servicemen repatriated to the US
Content: REMAINS of American World War Two (WW2) service members found during a 76-day investigation were repatriated yesterday. The remains will be taken to the United States Department of Defense Prisoner of War or Missing in Action accounting Agency facilities for possible identification in an ongoing effort to account for US service members who are still missing from the Pacific Theatre during WW2. The agencies Indo Pacific Region deputy director Lt Col Jeremy Smith said following identification, the agency ensures remains are returned to their families to provide answers and closure. “In 2023 we were able to conduct an underwater mission in Morobe where we recovered some of the remains of the B24 bombers that were shot down on March 1944,” he said. “We are currently planning a follow up mission for that effort and we’ve identified four of the 11 crew members from that mission.” He said the investigation team also includes the members of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF), National Museum Art and Gallery officers and the local communities. Smith said the team has two recovery sites and 12 investigations sites in Morobe, East New Britain, Northern and New Ireland. He said at the crash site of the bomber was also where they recovered two remains. With the help of locals, the team was able to pinpoint several sites in Northern that are now going to transition into recovery sites.” “We’re also bringing in remains from a partner mission in New Ireland,” Smith added. Tourism Minister Belden Namah said as a former military officer he understands what it means to never leave a comrade behind. Namah thanked the team for their tireless efforts in investigating and recovering the remains with the support of PNGDF and other agencies. “Their remains will also remind us of the human cost of war and that we must all times pursue the path of peace and harmony,” Namah said. He also thanked locals in the provinces for keeping safe the sites where the remains lay for the last 80 years. US ambassador Ann Marie Yastishock said they do not only honour their service and sacrifice but also the commitment by the US to make every effort to bring them home. “This gives peace and closure to the families of more than 3,000 members who went missing in PNG,” she said. “They may have lost their lives but they are never forgotten. Each recovery is a testament to that unyielding promise that we will never forget.”  Yastishock said this mission was not just about recovery it was about community providing direct economic benefit to the region.

Title: Court grants N’Dranou leave to challenge sacking from force
Content: TERMINATED assistant commissioner of police (ACP) Perou N’Dranou will go ahead to challenge the termination decision of police commissioner David Manning on May 21 after the National Court granted him leave. N’Dranou filed the case against Manning and the State. Judge Susan Purdon-Sully ruled in Waigani on Aug 20 that N’Dranou’s application for leave to apply for judicial review, filed on June 10, be granted. “N’Dranou shall file a notice of motion within 14 days,” she said. “Within 21 days, he shall serve on the defendants a Notice of Motion for substantive judicial review together with its Originating Summons for leave and all supporting documents with this order.” Judge Purdon-Sully said that it was unchallenged that N’Dranou was employed under a three year performance-based contract of employment which expired on Jan 18, 2018. The court heard that on Feb 6, N’Dranou was directed by Manning to continue his employment with the police force as ACP (training) and National Centre of Excellence commandant. N’Dranou’s employment was terminated by a letter from Manning dated May 21, 2025. In making the decision, N’Dranou asserted that Manning acted ultra vires or in error of law, breached the principles of natural justice and that the decision was harsh and oppressive. The relief sought by N’Dranou as pleaded in his Statement in Support filed on June 10, claimed that the decision be quashed, a declaration that his termination was void and of no legal effect, a declaration that Manning had appointed him to continue his employment which for all purposes was an appointment under the Police Act 1998 and an order in the nature of mandamus directing Manning to re-instate him. Judge Purdon-Sully said in opposing the grant of leave, the only issue raised by the State was whether the plaintiff had met the requirement that he had an arguable case. “It was the State’s case inter alia that the plaintiff’s performance-based contract of employment had expired, that it was to the contract of employment that he must look and for this reason judicial review and reinstatement he sought by way of relief were not remedies available to him,” she said.

Title: Motu-Koita election petition filed in district court
Content: AN election petition has been filed in a District Court challenging the election of Kirakira village ward councillor Babani Harry. Petitioner Arutu Bake, a candidate who contested the seat within the Motu-Koita Assembly (MKA) filed the petition through his lawyer Canute Nidue on Sept 1. Bake and Harry were among six candidates who contested the Kirakira village ward Councilor Seat under the MKA elections in the National Capital District. Bake alleges in his petition that there was double voting, under-aged voting, and bribery of supporters by Harry. Bake also claims that the electoral commission’s polling officials failed to prevent double voting. Bake is seeking the court to declare Harry’s election void and for the court to order Bake as Kirakira village ward councilor. The one-day polling was conducted by the electoral commission (EC) at Kirakira village on July 17. Counting started the next day (July 18) at the United Church hall at Kirakira village at 6pm and ended at 9.30pm. Harry won the seat after he polled 457 votes. Bake finished second with 450 votes – a difference of 7 votes. Harry, and the EC have been named as respondents in the court case. The matter is expected to be heard at the District Court in Down Town Port Moresby at 9.30am today (Thursday).

Title: City police recruits start three-month practical
Content: THE latest police recruits started their three-month practical experience on Monday only in police stations in the National Capital District. Assistant police commissioner (training) Silva Sika said the 54 officer cadets would be under the supervision of station commanders. “I strongly warned them yesterday morning (Monday) before deployment to the city attachment to show visibility in their leadership to be focused on the duties as they will be closely monitored and assessed,” Sika said. “To put in a lot of work for professional standards and ethics and in order to support police station commanders they are assigned to.” The cadets were also involved in the independence anniversary operations, providing security during the Akon and Meganesia concerts at the Sir John Guise Stadium. He said the cadets were told to maintain high standards of discipline without inflicting any disciplinary offences. He explained that the three-month practical is for the cadets to get a feel of how to handle everyday claims, public safety, taking statements from complainants and traffic safety. “They will be given a lot of work and we expect nothing but the best. Show us that you are serious in becoming police officers,” he added. Sika said if they did, they would face the consequences that would affect their aspirations of becoming commissioned officers after three years. “They were told to do their best and to do their job diligently to the best of their ability that will have greater impact on the constabulary and more so to the community,” he said.

Title: New Ireland Basin identified as emerging petroleum zone
Content: TWO University of Papua New Guinea researchers have co-authored a paper on the discovery of an active hydrocarbon seep system offshore of Lihir Island, New Ireland. Associate Professor Joseph Espi and Stanis Konabe said the study was published in Nature’s Scientific Reports, one of the most widely read peer-reviewed scientific journals. The international research team, working on the German vessel RV Sonne found that seafloor vents have been releasing methane, ethane, propane, and butane gases – a clear evidence of a working petroleum system in the New Ireland Basin. It confirms that natural gas and condensate liquids are being generated from coal-rich source rocks and are actively seeping to the seafloor. Konabe, who participated as a shipboard scientist and named the newly discovered vent field Karambusel said: “I chose the name Karambusel because of the remarkable mussel beds discovered at the site. “It is the first time these animals have been found living alongside active natural gas seepage in PNG, making it a special discovery for our country.” Espi, the head of UPNG’s Earth Sciences Division, said: “Our involvement in international research ensures PNG has both a stronger understanding of its offshore geology and a direct role in major natural resource discoveries.” PEAK Oil PNG Pty Ltd country manager Michael Nongkas welcomed the findings. “As a New Irelander, this discovery is especially meaningful. It independently confirms the hydrocarbon potential in our province and opens the door to new opportunities in jobs, training, and long-term economic sustainability,” he said. PEAK Oil PNG Pty Ltd holds the petroleum prospecting licences covering the discovery area, positioning the company to further advance exploration in partnership with local stakeholders, government, and the international resource sector. The publication of the find in Scientific Reports is particularly significant because the journal is freely available online and read by millions of scientists, policymakers, and industry leaders worldwide each month. This ensures that the New Ireland Basin discovery will gain global visibility, raising PNG’s profile in both the international scientific and resource development sectors.

Title: Improve conditions first: Economist
Content: IMPROVING the conditions of doing business in the country is needed before the new minimum wage rate comes into effect from next year, an economist says. Institute of National Affairs executive director Paul Barker said good governance and the adherence to the rule of law would benefit employers to implement the new rates recently announced by the Minimum Wages Board. “It should also be recognised that many businesses, be it in the formal sector, some foreign-owned or with foreign beneficial owners in the retail or aspects of the resources sector, are operating in a seemingly unregulated sector,” he said. “They are not applying the minimum wages, let alone paying company or payroll taxes, or superannuation in the process keeping their costs down, but gaining unfair competitive advantage over other local businesses. “While these firms have been bypassing PNG’s rules, the Government itself has recently endorsed such inconsistent preferential arrangements for selected beneficiary firms, even in urban centres. “Under the Special Economic Zone arrangements, selected firms would bypass many standards taxes, including a portion of salary and wages and other taxes and aspects of labour and environmental laws, undermining the principle of a level playing field, and undermining government revenue, even from businesses that could readily pay. “Thus, weak application of governance and the rule of law and a wide application of corrupt practices, at the high level, as well as petty corruption, all undermine business prospects.” Barker said that improved conditions would lower costs and investment in productivity to enhance competitiveness, hence, improving the capacity of businesses to pay competitive wages, incentives, household incomes, welfare and savings. He added that the new minimum wage rate of K5 per hour would not support workers in the country once it comes into effect, especially those in urban areas. “The minimum wage set at K5 per hour (or K400 per fortnight) and rising to K5.50 (in 2027) (K440 per fortnight) is not a decent living wage for an adult in a city, if they also have a family to support.”

Title: Lae business community praises minimum wages board for new rate
Content: THE Lae Chamber of Commerce and Industry has welcomed the increase in the minimum wage rate to be implemented from next year. Chamber president John Byrne congratulated the Minimum Wages Board for a comprehensive and balanced consultation process around the country over several months. He said that the board, made up of industry and government, union representatives were open and unbiased in their conversations, taking on board all opinions with respect and fairness. “The outcome of an increase of the minimum wage threshold to K5 from January 1 2026, and incremental increases in 2027 and 2028, is reasonable and sets a proper platform for our people,” he said. “It is important for our working staff to be made aware that this increase applies only to those on the minimum wage (of K3.50 per hour) currently. “Most of our LCCI employers pay rates (and benefits) are in excess of the minimum wage already.
