These wage and salary structures will remain fixed.” He said the board hearings highlighted a challenge by businesses – the grey-market which did not pay minimum wages, statutory taxes, licences, superannuation and staff benefits. “It is critical for our people and country that we take on the challenge of addressing these operators, and the Lae and PNG Chambers of Commerce are keen to address this major impediment to our people, competition and service improvements,” he said. “It is taxes that funds roads, power and other vital services and these illegal operators must be addressed ensuring our people are paid and rewarded appropriately and proper taxes are also paid.” He said that this provided a platform to protect staff currently on minimum wages, while holding cost pressures on goods and product at the stores, businesses, and services.

Title: Uni student Posa crowned Miss Bird of Paradise Gulf
Content: UNIVERSITY student Annsio Posa was crowned Miss Bird of Paradise Gulf in Kerema last week. Posa, 20, from Uritai village in Gulf, is a second-year Bachelor of Arts student at the Pacific Adventist University. “Thank you so much for all your love and support since day one,” she said during the crowning on Sept 15. “I am honoured and blessed to wear this crown today. “I will be your queen of service. I will create change in our Kerema town. “In the beginning of this pageant I said, I will bring light into Kerema town and showcase us to Papua New Guinea.” Posa became the fourth provincial queen to be crowned. She entered the pageant as Miss Uritai among 12 other contestants. Miss Bird of Paradise Papua New Guinea May Hasola who attended the crowning, said; “We are incredibly proud of you and all that you represent for Gulf and for Papua New Guinea. “This is only the beginning of your journey and we look forward to seeing the impact you will make.” Hasola added: “To all the beautiful contestants representing the length and breadth of the Gulf, thank you for putting your hands up to go on this journey. “You have made history as custodians of your culture during this Inaugural Miss Bird of Paradise Gulf Pageant.” Posa will be among contestant competing for the national title in December.

Title: LLG polling begins Saturday
Content: POLLING for the local level government (LLG) elections is expected on Saturday. It is expected to end on Oct 10, counting to start on Oct 11, and writs to be returned on Oct 17. Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai said materials for the LLG elections had already been sent to most provinces in preparation for polling. “Logistics operations on the movement of election materials throughout the country has started with the shipment of most containers to the provinces,” he said in a statement yesterday. “All election materials, which include ballot boxes, ballot papers, polling kits and voting compartments have been dispatched and most of the provinces have confirmed receiving their containers. “We have a few more to go, but the bulk of the work is done and we are ready and set for polling.” Sinai confirmed that polling for the LLG elections would proceed as per the revised schedule, after it was deferred from the initial date on July 12 due to administrative issues, particularly the alignment of 500-plus newly-created wards and 41 LLGs in 14 provinces. “This was the main cause of the delay,” he said. “Though it is not the responsibility of the Electoral Commission staff, I am happy that most of the realignment work is complete with the rolls being printed and ready for polling.” Meanwhile, Sinai said LLG presidents will be elected in eight provinces by their ward councillors. The eight provinces are Hela, Southern Highlands, Enga, Western Highlands, Jiwaka, Chimbu, Eastern Highlands and Morobe. In 12 provinces, they will be elected by the people. The 12 provinces are Madang, East Sepik, West Sepik, Northern, Milne Bay, Central, Gulf, Western, Manus, New Ireland, West New Britain and East New Britain. Sinai said the limited preferential voting (LPV) system will be used in 12 provinces to elect presidents during the polling period. The National Capital District and the Autonomous Region of Bougainville are not included in the LLG elections.

Title: Juffa opens education conference in Popondetta
Content: EDUCATION in Northern faces many challenges, and it is only appropriate that the 34th senior education officers’ conference is held in the province for the first time. Education Minister Lucas Dekena made this remark during the launching at the Popondetta Independence Oval on Monday. “This is the first time the province has hosted such an important ministry conference, and it also marks the first senior education officers conference to be held after the nation’s 50th Independence anniversary. “By being here in Popondetta, we are also sending a strong message that education is for every province, every district, every ward and every family. “No child should be left behind, no matter where they are,” Dekena said. He reaffirmed the Government’s commitment under the national education plan 2020–2029 to ensuring that every child has access to quality education pathways. “We must ensure that every child has a clear and viable pathway from early childhood to fulfilling a career. “This means strengthening foundational learning, making schools safe and inclusive, empowering teachers and expanding alternate pathways through Fode, Tvet, and higher learning,” Dekena said. Northern Governor Gary Juffa, complementing the Minister’s message, called for a “great reset in education” as the country enters its next 50 years. “The world is changing rapidly with artificial intelligence and new technologies. “Are we preparing our children to be not only citizens of PNG, but global citizens who can contribute meaningfully to the world?” Juffa asked. He further encouraged teachers to speak openly on the issues affecting them and not to hold back. Both leaders stressed that Papua New Guinean children were brilliant and full of potential and realising this required empowered teachers, bold reforms and united action. The conference, with the theme “Accessible education pathways for all”, has brought together more than 100 senior education officers to discuss strategies to improve the education system in the country.

Title: Growing PNG my focus from the beginning, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has reaffirmed that growing Papua New Guinea’s economy has been his central focus since first assuming office on May 30, 2019, and remains the cornerstone of his vision for the country’s long-term prosperity. “From my first speech as prime minister in 2019, I made it clear that the focus of my leadership would be to grow the economy so that we have more resources to sustain our people,” Marape said in a statement. “I spoke about our journey toward becoming the richest black Christian nation, which is in line with the ambitions first laid out by Prime Minister Somare for a happy, wealthy, wise and top 50 nation by 2050. I chose a more aggressive approach to ensure every ministry, department and public servant prioritises economic growth.” Marape said the rationale was simple: a bigger economy provides the resources to fund education, healthcare, infrastructure, welfare and national development. “When I took office, the economy stood at K79 billion. Today, six years on, we are at K130 billion — a growth of over K50 billion. This has happened despite many challenges,” he noted. “Our growth rate is now consistently above four per cent — higher than many other economies. Independent observers such as the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and Asian Development Bank have all forecast PNG’s growth at over four per cent this year.” Marape emphasised that economic growth is the pathway to economic independence — a mission inspired by the late Sir Michael Somare’s words in 2007, when he told a younger Marape and his colleagues that their generation of educated leaders must work towards economic sovereignty, just as his generation delivered political independence in 1975. “Somare’s generation gave us political independence,” Marape said. “It is now our generation’s duty to deliver economic independence.” Marape reaffirmed his ambitious growth targets: “No previous prime minister has spoken about growing the economy to this scale. But it must be done, because a larger economy is the only way to sustain our fast-growing population,” Marape said. He outlined that growth will come from across all sectors — forestry, fisheries, agriculture, mining, petroleum, and, critically, through local content, small-to-medium enterprise and wider participation of Papua New Guineans in business.

Title: Counter terrorism measures employed in response to unrest
Content: TWO hundred security personnel have been deployed to Nipa-Kutubu in the Southern Highlands to quell damage and blockage of the Highlands Highway by tribesmen. This followed reports that locals had dug up the highway and halted traffic flow in protest against the sidelining of Kumul Petroleum Holdings chief executive officer Wapu Sonk by the board of the entity last week. Sonk is a local of the area. Police Commissioner David Manning said: “I have authorised the use of measures available under the Counter-Terrorism Act, and approved counter-terrorism operations to remove this threat to our national security. “Two hundred law enforcement personnel are deployed in Nipa-Kutubu and adjoining areas. “These personnel are afforded the powers and protections of the Counter-Terrorism Act to undertake their duties, and do so with the full support of Government.” Yesterday police claimed calm has been restored and the Highlands Highway reopened in the Nipa-Kutubu district. Manning said: “The destruction of critical infrastructure such as a major roadway to compel government action is an act of terrorism. “The actions of this group are unacceptable and unlawful. Their actions in damaging critical infrastructure risks the lives of our communities who rely upon this roadway for goods and services as well as access to medical care. “The Prime Minister made his expectations clear, to stop lawless behaviour in Nipa-Kutubu, and under my direction the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary and PNG Defence Force have achieved this outcome. “Calm was promptly restored over the weekend and the highway repaired. “Those who sought to hold the nation to ransom are now the subject of ongoing counter-terrorism operations.” Manning said the second phase is to address any remaining threats in this region. He added that surveillance, financial analysis and targeted tactical operations were underway, and would continue throughout the operation in Southern Highlands. “These targeted operations not only address those responsible for these acts of terrorism, but also form part of our operations to provide a secure environment for our communities ahead of the 2027 general elections. “This is part of a long-term commitment by police and PNGDF to remove from our communities those that present a threat to the rule of law. “This operation will continue over the coming months.” The Police Commissioner commended frontline members for the swift response and said now is the time for targeted operations to be implemented against those who sought to terrorise and hold to ransom the nation and those who supported such acts.

Title: Connectivity, access lead to improved outcomes, says Minister
Content: LEADERS must connect to the people and ensure they have access to vital services, an official says. Kikori MP and Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe said: “About 80 per cent of people in the rural areas deserve the same rights as those in urban areas and when leaders are in a positon to help, then do so. “Over the last five years, there have been so many deaths of locals travelling the River Rhine along the West Coast just to get out to access basic services and in search of markets for their produce,” he said. Eoe and his staff and other passengers set sail on MV IBK (Ihu, Baimuru and Kikori) yesterday on her maiden trip to the west Gulf areas. The landing barge is named after the three local level Government areas of West Gulf and is operating under the Kikori District Development Authority (DDA). It was purchased mid-this year to improve sea transport for passengers and cargo, including market produce between Port Moresby and Gulf. The transport system in Kikori, Ihu, Baimuru and other parts of Gulf, is primarily reliant on water due to the district’s riverine and coastal geography. However, recent initiatives are improving road access and sea transport options. “The west coast’s extensive river system necessitates reliance on boats and dinghies for movement in the district and to access other areas. “It is also a coastal area, requiring boats for travel to and from other coastal communities and potentially for accessing markets in Port Moresby,” Eoe said. When commissioning the barge last month, Prime Minster James Marape said this was a start in bringing Kikori and other parts of Gulf up to par in line with other districts around the country. He said western Gulf was an important strategic part of PNG and had been marginalised but despite this called for patience.

Title: Two women claim seats in ABG election, counting continues
Content: TWO women have been declared members-elect for their respective constituency seats as the counting of votes for the 2025 Autonomous Region of Bougainville (Arob) general election continues. Amanda Masono (Atolls) and Carolyn Poli (Mahari) were among 26 others declared out of the 38 constituency seats in the region, after counting was extended to Oct 5. Masono was declared after the seventh exclusion with 897 votes. Poli, who returns for another term, collected 1,427 votes after the seventh exclusion. The other members-elect declared were Robin Wilson (Barawa), Martin Avoata (Rotokas), Albert Punghau (Motuna Huyono Tokunutui), Fabian Epota Saleu (Torokina), Justine Bonai (Bolave), Melvin Wilolopa (Lato), Lawrence Namusi (Baba), Jason Baranangko (Rau), Lucas Bierepi (Kereaka), Ezekiel Masat (Tonsu), Clarence Dency (Eivo Torau), Junior Tumare (Makis), David Vatavi (Taonita Tinputz), Didymus Napto (Nissan), John Bobby (Baubake), Naphtali Veoriva (Taonita Teop), David Miringtoro (Ioro), Philip Singkai (Lule), Henry Potabu (North Nasioi), Luke Karaston (Suir), Justin Borgia (South Nasioi), Paul Cheung (Selau), Willie Masiu (Wisai), Thomas Naisi (Tonolei), Heribeth Benjamin (Konnou), and Earnestly Teduu (Kongara). Meanwhile, Robert Kebau retained his seat as the member for the South Bougainville Ex-combatants’ seat after collecting 22,373 votes. Kebau was declared yesterday as counting for the regional ex-combatants’ representatives for North and Central Bougainville continued. Declarations are yet to be made for the regional women representatives for North, South and Central Bougainville respectively, including the presidential seat. Writs will be returned on Oct 6.

Title: Sewerage issue sees cops put out of housing
Content: NINE policewomen from the Lae metropolitan command in Morobe are displaced from their place of accommodation since Sept 11. Lae metropolitan commander Chief Superintendent Chris Kunyanban said the nine were evicted from their accommodation following an issue with the sewerage system which the landlord is now working on to have it fixed. “This is beyond our control as when the sewerage system is not working properly, it is unhealthy for clients to stay there and add on to the existing problem,” said Chief Supt Kunyanban. He said since the landlord have no other option to accommodate the nine affected policewomen, they are now displaced and are fending for themselves while attending to work. “It is an unfortunate situation at hand now and I have spoken to Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso regarding the issue to see how we can relocate these policewomen.” This is also an issue that the Police Department should also take note of it. The nine policewomen were relocated to a guest house near Igam Barracks after their single quarters at Bumbu police barracks was partly damaged by fire on Feb 5, 2025. Kunyanban said as soon as a new accommodation was located, the policewomen would be accommodated there while waiting for a permanent accommodation to be completed at Bumbu barracks.

Title: Governor General Sir Bob acknowledges late Morobe governor
Content: GOVERNOR-General Sir Bob Dadae has described the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge as a ‘born leader’ who was not afraid to challenge fellow leaders on matters of Constitutional legalities and national sovereignty. “His potential as a leader became obvious at an early age in his education path and later at the workplace before he became a politician. “As a student, he was the school captain of Dregerhaffen High School. Later, as student leader at University of Papua New Guinea, and as President of Law Students Association,” Sir Bob said. “After graduating with a Bachelors’ Degree at UPNG, he worked tirelessly as a Public Solicitor, defending those who found themselves against the laws of the nation. “Later, his legal credentials elevated him to Chief Magistrate before entering politics in 1997. “He was successfully elected as Regional Member for Morobe, now known as Governor. “He served in that capacity as governor for three terms from 1997 to 2012. “He was elected as governor for Morobe in General Election 2022, serving his fourth term, the longest by any Governor of the province,” Sir Bob said. “He is well known and credited for challenging the national government on Constitutional matters that had serious implications for our national sovereignty. “He also spoke his mind on matters of political freedom of indigenous people in Papua New Guinea and the region.” Sir Bob added that as a Christian member of Lutheran Church, Wenge proudly proclaimed his faith in public, saying: “Born Lutheran, baptised a Lutheran and died a Lutheran.”

Title: Six escape from Kerevat jail
Content: SIX male prisoners at East New Britain’s Kerevat jail escaped during heavy rain on Monday afternoon. In confirming the report withThe Nationalyesterday afternoon, Kerevat Correctional Service acting commanding officer Senior Insp Steven Kandu said of the six  escapees, five were convicted and one was a remandee. The five convicted prisoners were categorised as high risk. Kandu said the six climbed the wire fence and escaped. “Warders are on the lookout,” he said. “We have notified ENB police commanders of his four police stations about the incident.” He said the five who were convicted were categorised as high risk prisoners. Kandu said the escapees were a threat to the community and therefore urged the public to report sightings of any suspicious faces. He urged immediate family members to bring them to police if they turned up at their homes.

Title: Connecting PNG
Content: The Tabubil to Telefomin road was carved out of stone, along the Hindenburg wall in West Sepik. One has to travel this road to see the rugged geographic features in a beautiful landscape. The winding steep road with cliffs and rocks acting as barricades only suggests a challenging engineering job to construct one of the country’s “missing links” in its Connect PNG programme. The road links Tabubil to Telefomin in West Sepik, Urapmin and Oksapmin in Western and Lake Kopiago in Hela.

Title: Art exhibition open to public
Content: AN art exhibition, titled “Returning Home”, is open to the public in the National Capital District. The exhibition is organised by Grace Hasu Dlabik, from Austria, Hungary and Papua New Guinea. According to Dlabik, the exhibition centres on “art that reflects our stories, villages, who we are, where we come from and contemporary versions of how we exist in the world”. “It is a testament to the idea that art is a vital platform for preserving and celebrating the nation’s rich heritage, even as Papua New Guineans navigate an increasingly globalised and technologically advanced world,” she said. Dlabik is based in Melbourne, Australia. With her four colleagues, who are Papua New Guineans, their exhibition is a powerful exploration of identity, culture and the enduring connection between tradition and contemporary life. National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop commended the artists, highlighting their role in promoting PNG’s diverse cultures and traditions on a global stage. “Living overseas, they have showcased our cultures and traditions through arts,” he said, emphasising that art would continue to be a source of inspiration for defining the nation’s journey over the next 50 years. Parkop said the exhibition was aligned with the city’s vision to be a hub for arts, culture, and tourism, underscoring a growing recreational and artistic industry.

Title: Wau water supply project to start next year, says MP
Content: WAU-Waria MP Marsh Narewec has announced to the people of his district that work on Wau’s water supply will start after K39 million was secured for the project. However, he told them that they would have to wait until the end of next year for the project to start. “This is because the money to start this project is not from our government but from overseas donors and to get that money, we have to go through some processes,” Narewec said. He said funding was secured under the European Union with support from Water PNG, as well as the Government through the Department of National Planning and Monitoring and Wau-Waria DDA. “This Wau water supply will not start immediately but when we are ready, specialists will be sent here to carry out feasibility studies on this project,” Narewec said. The funding is confirmed so that means Wau’d water supply project is confirmed to begin. Narewec estimated that the water supply may start towards the last quarter of next year, depending on how quick the funding is made available. Over the years, when Wau-Waria was still under Bulolo, this project was given a nod but all attempts to get this project off the ground were unsuccessful, according to Narewec. Currently, citizens in Wau still lack access to clean water supply with many depending on tank water and other systems of providing water for their needs. Meanwhile, Narewec announced that the independence sports tournament was not staged due to the 50th Independence anniversary celebrations this year, but said the tournament should be staged next year. “Soccer will be staged at Garaina Station while rugby will be played in Wau,” Narewec said. He announced that the soccer tournament will kick off by December.

Title: Canada backs tree kangaroo conservation programme
Content: THE Tree Kangaroo Conservation Programme (TKCP) received support from the High Commission of Canada for its One Health Programme in Yus recently. The conservation area in the Yus local level government area is located on the border of Morobe and Madang, making basic services such as health impossible to reach. Modi Pontio, TKCP executive director, said the long-term goal of this project is to help Yus community members and health workers with the tools and knowledge to safeguard human health through the protection of the environment. “Through the help of this contribution, training of village birth attendants, distribution of safe delivery kits and family planning educational talks will commence when our volunteer health professionals travel to Yus in November.” Pontio said that wok is already underway with the Morobe Provincial Health Authority to establish a memorandum of understanding that will allow them to better understand the needs of the Yus people. Acting High Commission of Canada to PNG, Manon Dumas, said that they are excited and proud to be part of the Tree Kangaroo Conservation Programme. “The comprehensive approach that is adopted by the programme is exemplary.” She said Canada shares PNG’s commitment to biodiversity and they are looking forward to seeing the impact this project will make. Tree Kangaroo Conservation Programme conducted an extensive research for community dialogue and engagement throughout the Yus conservation area to gather feedbacks, recommendations and ideas with regards to the management of Yus conservation area with local communities and landowners. The One Health Programme aims to empower remote communities such as Yus with knowledge, resources, skills and leadership to address health concerns such as nutrition, others in alignment with the Department of Health and in partnership with the provincial health authority.

Title: District in Hela launches K5 million worth of projects
Content: HELA’s Koroba-Kopiago recently witnessed the launching of K5 million worth of facilities at Lake Kopiago. The facilities included a new council chamber, fencing and terminal building for the airstrip. The facilities were built through a partnership between the national government, district development authority and the local level government. The launching ceremony, held at the government station last weekend, was attended by Coffee Minister and local MP William Wai Bando, provincial administrator Marago Dagoba and Lake Kopiago local level government (LLG) president Steven Andrew. “Our people are fortunate to receive such facilities that will change the face of the district. “This shows our commitment to ensure that everyone receives important government services regardless of their political choices or affiliations. “It is important for us as leaders to be fair and equal to everyone,” said Minister Bando. He urged the people to look after the services and pledged his ongoing support towards the development and progress of Koroba-Kopiago. LLG president Steven Andrew acknowledged the support and said this was the first of its kind for this part of the district.

Title: Jacquinot Bay airstrip undergoes upgrade
Content: EARLY construction works have begun last month to upgrade the Jacquinot Bay Airstrip at Pomio’s Palmalmal government station in East New Britain. The airstrip, once serviced by Tropic Air through Kokopo’s Tokua Airport, has not had flights since Sept 2023. This was after the Tokua Airport terminal was vandalised and looted by criminals, destroying computers, which in turn forced the suspension of flights to Jacquinot Bay. Before its closure, charter flights from Tokua landed at Jacquinot Bay three times a week. Pomio MP Elias Kapavore toldThe Nationalthat since the incident at Tokua, the people of Pomio had faced many challenges. “From Tokua to here is 45 minutes,” he said. “In the past, it was easier and faster to travel to Pomio, by plane.Now we only travel here by ship.” Kapavore said that the district had to compromise by buying two ships to help people travel. Travel delays also affected public servants, prompting the district to buy a 500-horsepower boat to make trips faster. Kapavore said the upgraded Jacquinot Bay Airstrip runway will be 1.7km long. The airstrip, previously managed by the Rural Airstrip Agency (RAA) would now operate under the National Airports Corporation (NAC). The contractor for the project is Niugini Engineering and Procurement Services (NEPS) Construction and K1.4 million from provincial services improvement programme (PSIP) funds was released for early work, with more support expected from the national government under the Civil Aviation Development Improvement Programme (Cadip 2). Kapavore said the Pomio development authority (DDA) had approved and allocated K1. 5 million for the upgrading of the Jacquinot Bay Airstrip. The K1.5 million funding comes from the Pomio services improvement programme (DSIP) funds. “Pomio will make available K1.5 million and it will be presented to the company,” Kapavore said. He noted that the upgrade would allow bigger planes to use the runway. “Generally, this place will be sealed up to pavement, right across the runaway and even the carpark area, and the terminal will be upgraded,” he said. Kapavore said that Pomio had more than four airstrips. Two had already been opened, and work will continue with RAA to upgrade and maintain all of them. He acknowledged the government and the ENB Government for their contributions and support to developments in Pomio. Kapavore was confident that by Dec 12, this year, the airstrip would be ready for larger aircraft.

Title: Unity is the key
Content: AS we stand on the brink of a historic milestone – 50 years of independence – we must pause, reflect, and acknowledge the journey our beautiful nation has traversed. Papua New Guinea, with its rich cultural heritage, diverse traditions, and abundant natural resources, has indeed come a long way. However, like any country, our journey has not been without its trials. Today, as we celebrate half a century of independence, we are reminded of both the achievements and the challenges that have shaped our nation’s story. Over the past five decades, Papua New Guinea has made significant strides in development. From advancements in education and healthcare to improvements in infrastructure, our nation has risen from the ashes of colonial rule to establish its own identity. Yet, we cannot ignore the shadows that linger in the form of corruption, social inequality, and a system that at times feels disconnected from the needs of the people. These challenges – some deeply ingrained in our society – have hindered progress, slowed economic growth and created division among us. But this is not the time to dwell solely on the negatives. It is the time to look forward with hope and resolve. It is the time to recognise that change starts with us. Every citizen, every community, every individual has a role to play in building a better future for PNG. We must be united in our vision for the future. While our nation’s problems are complex, they are not insurmountable – Unity is the key. Our diverse cultures, languages, and traditions are not a barrier, but rather a strength that sets us apart from the world. We must celebrate this diversity and harness it as a tool for progress. It is time for all of us to come together – not as individuals or political parties, but as one united nation, driven by a shared vision of a prosperous future. We must reject corruption. Corruption has plagued our institutions for far too long. It has robbed us of opportunities, trust, and the future we deserve. But change is possible, and it starts with us holding ourselves accountable. By demanding transparency and integrity, by choosing leaders who prioritise the people over personal gain, we can begin to reclaim our nation’s future. We must invest in education and the youth. The next 50 years will be defined by the generations we nurture today. Our youth are our most precious resource, and it is crucial that we invest in their education, skills and aspirations. They are the builders of tomorrow, the ones who will carry forward the mantle of leadership. Let us ensure they have the tools they need to succeed – be it through access to quality education, opportunities for employment, or platforms for their voices to be heard. We must protect our environment. Our land, our seas, our resources – Papua New Guinea’s natural beauty is unparalleled. But with this beauty comes a responsibility to protect and preserve it for future generations. Sustainable development is the only path forward. We must balance progress with preservation, ensuring that our environment remains a source of prosperity for all. As we celebrate 50 years of independence, let us also pledge to work together for a better tomorrow. The road ahead may be challenging, but we are resilient. We are capable. And we are united in our love for this land we call home. Papua New Guinea is not defined by its past; it is defined by what we choose to make of its future. Let this 50th anniversary be a moment of awakening, a moment of action, and a moment of unity. We all have a role to play in the story of PNG – let us write it with integrity, hope, and a shared commitment to a brighter future for all. Happy 50th Independence Day, Papua New Guinea! Let us celebrate the strength, resilience and potential that lies within us all. John Wadidika

Title: Handshakes, trade and Palestine as PM takes world stage
Content: Canberra: Australia has used a United Nations meeting to try to revive a long-stalled major trade deal, after formally recognising Palestine as a state. Anthony Albanese met with French President Emmanuel Macron on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly for a 40-minute sit-down in New York on Tuesday, Australian time. In an address to the summit of world leaders, the prime minister reiterated Australia’s support for an end to the war between Israel and Hamas, and a two-state solution. Albanese compared the plight of Palestinians to that of the Jews before the creation of Israel. “In recognising Palestine, Australia recognises the legitimate and long-held aspirations of the Palestinian people,” he said. “It means real hope for a place they can call home. “This is the same hope that sustained generations of Jewish people.” Albanese and Macron also discussed progress on the previously stalled free trade agreement negotiations with the EU, and Australia’s bid to jointly co-host the COP31 climate conference with Pacific countries. The pair also talked about their nations’ co-operation on issues including support for Ukraine, the renewable energy transition and the Indo-Pacific. The prime minister met with other leaders including his Canadian counterpart Mark Carney, UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres and European Council President Antonio Costa. During the two-state solution conference at the UN, Albanese urged the Israeli government to “accept its share of responsibility” for the humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza. France was among a swathe of other countries that used the UN General Assembly session to recognise Palestine including the UK, Canada, Portugal, Malta and Andorra. More than 150 UN states, or more than three-quarters of the global body’s membership now recognise Palestinian statehood. But Australia faces pushback from 25 US Republicans who suggest “punitive measures” could be imposed on countries that have moved forward with recognition. The grouping of Israel supporters, including former presidential candidate Ted Cruz, said countries choosing to recognise Palestine were “rewarding terrorism”. Source: AAP

Title: Trump calls climate change the ‘greatest con job’
Content: New York City: President Donald Trump dismissed climate change as “the greatest con job” in the world during his address to the United Nations General Assembly, doubling down on his scepticism of global environmental initiatives and multilateral institutions. Scientists say climate change is real, mostly caused by humans, and getting worse. They point to rising temperatures, stronger storms, and melting ice as clear signs. Groups like the UN have warned that waiting too long to act could cause serious damage to the planet and people. Trump spoke for several minutes out of his near-hour speech on Tuesday on climate change during his address to the United Nations General Assembly, criticising the European Union for reducing its carbon footprint, which he claimed has taken a toll on its economy, and warning countries that have invested heavily in renewable energy that their economies will suffer. “It’s the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world, in my opinion,” Trump told the General Assembly. “All of these predictions made by the United Nations and many others, often for bad reasons, were wrong.” He added: “They were made by stupid people that have cost their country’s fortunes and given those same countries no chance for success.” Once Trump took office in January, the US submitted its withdrawal for a second time from the Paris Agreement, a 2015 pact agreed by 195 countries to strive to keep global temperatures from rising beyond 1.5 C, leaving it in the company of only Yemen, Iran and Libya. His administration is carrying out an “energy dominance” agenda that focuses on producing and exporting oil, gas and coal, as well as nuclear, while sidelining renewable energy, which has become cost-competitive. “We have the most oil of any nation anywhere, oil and gas in the world, and if you add coal, we have the most of any nation in the world,” he said. His remarks come a day before UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres hosts a climate summit at the UN that will focus on countries’ new climate action plans. Guterres has tried to keep the world focused on continuing a global transition away from fossil fuels towards clean energy. “Just follow the money,” Guterres said in June, adding that US$2 trillion (about K8 trillion) flowed into clean energy last year, US$800 billion (about K3.3 trillion) more than fossil fuels and up almost 70 per cent in a decade. Source: Reuters

Title: Super Typhoon Ragasa lashes HK, 14 dead in Taiwan
Content: Hong Kong: Super Typhoon Ragasa, the world’s most powerful tropical cyclone this year, is lashing Hong Kong with hurricane-force winds and torrential rain, while heavy downpours in Taiwan resulted in the deaths of 14 people. A barrier lake in Taiwan’s eastern Hualien county overflowed and sent a wall of water into a town, as heavy rains from Ragasa battered the island, the Taiwan fire department said on Wednesday. Since Monday, Taiwan has been hit by the outer rim of Ragasa, which has brought torrential rains to the island. In Hong Kong, roads were deserted as authorities instructed people to stay indoors and surging waves crashed over parts of the Asian financial hub’s eastern and southern shoreline. “Areas which were previously sheltered may become exposed … seas will be phenomenal with swells,” the observatory said. Ragasa, packing winds of up to 200km/h, will be closest to the city in the next few hours, around 100km south of the densely populated territory. It is expected to maintain super typhoon intensity as it moves toward the coast of China’s Guangdong province, home to more than 125 million people, where it is expected to make landfall from midday to late on Wednesday. Ragasa swept through the northern Philippines on Monday and Taiwan on Tuesday. The typhoon sparked panic buying this week in Hong Kong, with people crowding into supermarkets, leaving little on the shelves and in some cases queuing for hours to purchase goods amid fears that shops could be closed for two days. As the typhoon approached, residents taped their windows in the hope of reducing the risk of injury from shattered glass. Hong Kong issued the typhoon signal 10, its highest warning, early on Wednesday, which urges businesses and transport services to shut down. Authorities also issued the Amber rainstorm signal, as heavy rain was expected to continue, with some streets already partially flooded, according to the South China Morning Post. Authorities have warned of rising sea levels, saying they could be similar to those seen during Typhoon Hato in 2017 and Typhoon Mangkhut in 2018, both of which caused billions of dollars in damage. “The water level will reach the maximum around noon (2pm AEST),” generally to around four metres,” the observatory said. A woman and her five-year-old son were swept into the ocean on Tuesday after watching the typhoon from the waterfront, according to the SCMP, which said they were now in intensive care after being rescued. The government said it had opened 49 temporary shelters in various districts and 727 people have sought refuge at the shelters. Hong Kong’s Stock Exchange will remain open. It changed its policy late last year to continue trading whatever the weather. Guangdong authorities have evacuated over 770,000 people, state broadcaster CCTV said. In the gambling hub of Macau next to Hong Kong, authorities also issued the No. 10 warning signal early on Wednesday. Source: Reuters

Title: NATO warns Russia to stop ‘escalatory’ actions
Content: Brussels: Nato has warned Russia it will use “all necessary military and non-military tools” to defend itself as it condemned Moscow for violating Estonian airspace in a “pattern of increasingly irresponsible behaviour”. The warning came after Estonia said on Friday that three Russian MiG-31 fighter jets violated its airspace for 12 minutes before Nato Italian fighter jets escorted them out. The week before, some 20 Russian drones entered Polish airspace, prompting Nato jets to shoot some of them down and the alliance to beef up the defence of Europe’s eastern flank. US President Donald Trump appeared to come out in favour of a robust Nato response to any future incursions as he spoke to reporters at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. Asked whether Nato countries should shoot down Russian aircraft that enter their airspace, he told reporters: “Yes, I do”. The Nato statement followed a meeting of the North Atlantic Council, made up of ambassadors from the alliance’s 32 member countries, which was called after Estonia invoked Article 4 of Nato’s founding treaty. Pentagon chief Pete Hegseth held a call with Estonian Defence Minister Hanno Pevkur on Tuesday and told him that Washington “stands with all Nato allies and that any incursion into Nato airspace is unacceptable”, the Pentagon said in a statement. Hegseth “commended the quick response by European allies’ air defences”, the Pentagon said, adding he told his Estonian counterpart that Washington was closely tracking the situation. “Russia bears full responsibility for these actions, which are escalatory, risk miscalculation and endanger lives. They must stop,” the council said in a statement. Source: Reuters

Title: Who stopped the UN escalator? Likely a Trump staffer
Content: UNITED NATIONS: The United Nations believes it has solved the mystery of why an escalator abruptly stopped shortly after US President Donald Trump stepped onto it – his videographer may have accidentally triggered a safety mechanism. Trump jokingly complained about the incident during his speech to world leaders earlier on Tuesday after the teleprompter also didn’t work. “These are the two things I got from the United Nations – a bad escalator and a bad teleprompter,” he told the 193-member assembly, to some laughter. However, White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt wasn’t so lighthearted about it. “If someone at the UN intentionally stopped the escalator as the President and First Lady were stepping on, they need to be fired and investigated immediately,” she posted on X after the incident. UN spokesperson Stephane Dujarric said a readout of the escalator’s central processing unit indicated it “had stopped after a built-in safety mechanism on the comb step was triggered at the top of the escalator”. He said Trump’s videographer had been travelling backwards up the escalator to capture his arrival with First Lady Melania Trump. “The videographer may have inadvertently triggered the safety function,” Dujarric said in a statement. “The safety mechanism is designed to prevent people or objects accidentally being caught and stuck in or pulled into the gearing.” The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the UN findings. On the teleprompter, Trump told the General Assembly: “I can only say that whoever’s operating this teleprompter is in big trouble.” However, a UN official said the White House had operated its own teleprompter. After Trump finished speaking, UN General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock said: “The UN teleprompters are working perfectly”. Source: Reuters

Title: Trump unleashes at UN, countries are ‘going to hell’
Content: New York City: President Donald Trump has castigated the United Nations as a feckless institution in a speech to world leaders, praising America under his leadership while warning Europe will be ruined if it doesn’t turn away from a “double-tailed monster” of ill-conceived migration and green energy policies. His roughly hour-long speech before the UN General Assembly on Tuesday was both grievance-filled and self-congratulatory as he used the platform to applaud his second-term achievements and lament that some of his fellow world leaders’ countries were “going to hell”. The address was the latest reminder for US allies and foes that the United States has returned to an unapologetically “America First” posture with an antagonistic view toward the United Nations. Trump also sharply criticised the global body for inaction, saying it was filled with “empty words” that “don’t solve wars”. “What is the purpose of the United Nations?” Trump asked. “The UN has such tremendous potential. I’ve always said it. It has such tremendous, tremendous potential. But it’s not even coming close to living up to that potential.” Afterward, Trump attempted to assuage fears from some diplomats by assuring the top UN leader that the US remained “100 per cent” supportive of the global body despite his earlier criticism. “I may disagree with it sometimes, but I am so behind it because the potential for peace at this institution is great,” Trump told Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. It was another about-face after Trump offered a weave of jarring juxtapositions in his address to the assembly. He trumpeted himself as a peacemaker and enumerated successes of his administration’s efforts in several hotspots around the globe. At the same time, Trump heralded his decisions to order the US military to carry out strikes on Iran and more recently against alleged drug smugglers from Venezuela and argued that “globalists” are on the verge of destroying successful nations. Trump touted his administration’s policies allowing for expanded drilling for oil and natural gas and aggressively cracking down on illegal immigration. He warned that European nations that have more welcoming migration policies and commit to expensive energy projects aimed at reducing their carbon footprint were causing irreparable harm to their economies and cultures. “I’m telling you that if you don’t get away from the ‘green energy’ scam, your country is going to fail,” Trump said. “If you don’t stop people that you’ve never seen before that you have nothing in common with, your country is going to fail. “I love the people of Europe, and I hate to see it being devastated by energy and immigration. This double-tailed monster destroys everything in its wake, and they cannot let that happen any longer.” Trump also addressed Russia’s war in Ukraine, once again threatening to hit Moscow with “a very strong round of powerful tariffs” if Russian President Vladimir Putin didn’t end the war. After the speech he met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, to announce a dramatic shift in his position on the war: He said he now believes Ukraine, with the help of NATO, can win back all territory lost to Russia. Source: AP

Title: Asylum seeker jailed in case that sparked UK protests
Content: London: An Ethiopian asylum seeker, whose arrest in July sparked angry protests outside the hotel near London where he and other migrants were being housed, has been jailed for 12 months for sexually assaulting a woman and a teenage girl. The protests outside the Bell Hotel in Epping, 30km north of the British capital, became a touchpaper for a string of country-wide demonstrations amid rising tensions over immigration. Hadush Gerberslasie Kebatu was convicted at Chelmsford Magistrates Court earlier in September of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl and a woman, attempting to sexually assault the girl, inciting her to engage in sexual activity and one count of harassment. Kebatu had acknowledged that he was aware of the unrest his offending had caused and that other law-abiding asylum seekers had been affected by it as it drew a response from the public not just in Epping but across the country, Judge Christopher Williams told him. “It resulted in mass demonstrations and the fear that children in the United Kingdom are not safe,” the judge said on Tuesday. Immigration has become the dominant political issue in Britain, eclipsing concerns over a faltering economy, as the country faces both a record number of asylum claims and arrivals by migrants in small boats across the Channel. Kebatu, who had arrived in Britain on a small boat and only moved to the Bell Hotel about a week before the incident, had denied all the accusations, saying he was “not a wild animal”. Just more than 32,000 migrants are housed in hotels across the country, according to figures up to the end of June. The government plans to stop the practice by the next election, due in 2029. Source: Reuters

Title: Sudan cholera rate rising at ‘alarming’ rate, says UN
Content: Khartoum: The number of reported cholera cases is increasing in Darfur and more than 3,000 people across all of Sudan have died from the illness over the last 14 months of civil war, the UN health agency said. The current outbreak of the bacterial infection caused by contaminated food or water has spread to all 18 states in the war-torn country after erupting in Kassala in July last year, the World Health Organisation (WHO) said. Hala Khudari, its deputy representative in Sudan, said the WHO has launched a vaccination campaign targeting 406,000 people in the state of North Darfur that comes “as cholera cases in Darfur continue to rise at an alarming rate – at an alarming fatality rate, to be specific”. As of Sunday, some 12,739 cases and 358 deaths have been reported in more than half of Darfur localities, she said. The outbreak reached Darfur in western Sudan in May. “Reported cases in Darfur continue to increase amid severe access constraints that are impeding the required scale of response,” Khudari told reporters in Geneva by video from Port Sudan. The conflict between the Sudanese military and the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary group erupted in April 2023 in Khartoum before spreading across the country. The civil war has killed at least 40,000 people and displaced as many as 12 million others, UN officials have said. Both sides have been accused of committing atrocities such as ethnic cleansing, extrajudicial killings and sexual violence against civilians, including children. Meanwhile, many people across Sudan have been pushed to the brink of famine. The conflict and increased movements of people who have fled the fighting have limited access to basic services such as clean water, food and healthcare. Overall, more than 113,600 cases and more than 3000 deaths have been reported from across the country, reaching a fatality ratio of 2.7 per cent, well above the one per cent target threshold, Khudari said. Source: PA

Title: Suspended KPHL managing director Sonk seeks relief in court
Content: SUSPENDED Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) managing director Wapu Sonk has filed cases in the National Court in Waigani challenging his suspension. National Court Judge Collin Makail yesterday heard the preliminary issues raised by parties and told the lawyers to ensure that peace and good order was maintained until the matter returned on Friday. “What is critical is for parties to respect the rule of law,” Judge Makail said. “Servants, agents and associates of the parties in the case should respect the rule of law and follow the due court process in order for the issue to be duly resolved,” he told representatives of both sides. Sonk filed the case against Registrar of Companies David Kil, recently-appointed KPHL board chairman Gerea Aopi and members Jacob Anga, George Gware and Sundaram Srinivasan. The amended originating summons was filed on Saturday. Sonk was represented by lawyers from Baniyamai Lawyers and Jonathan Holingu from Holingu Lawyers. Judge Makail said that the case was urgent but lawyers involved in the case should advise their clients, agents, associates and servants to respect the rule of law and maintain good order until the case was heard. “Any application for joinder shall be filed by Sept 24 and served to parties,” he said. Meanwhile, lawyer Dane Mel from Mel and Henry’s Lawyers also told the court that Prime Minister James Marape, in his capacity as the KPHL trustee, needed to be named as a party in the proceeding. Lawyer Robert Bradshaw representing chairman Aopi and the KPHL board told the court that Sonk was suspended on full pay and the court should consider not granting the relief sought in the interim after the leave was granted. Sonk is seeking a declaration that Kil has no power under the Companies Act to alter or amend the records of KPHL in the Companies Register with the Investment Promotion Authority (IPA), unless and until it is authorised to do so by the management of the company or its board secretary, and that the following decisions and actions of Kil are null and void and of no-effect. He is also asking the court to declare that Aopi, Anga, Gware and Srinivasan are not directors of the KPHL board.

Title: Mirisim pushes for Frieda to start sooner
Content: ONE government minister is adamant that the Frieda River Copper and Gold project gets under way soonest. Telefomin MP and Works and Highways Minister Solan Mirisim says the project would drive development and progress for his remote district. “This is a major opportunity to overcome Telefomin’s long-standing isolation and with the town plan in place, the new roads and airport will connect the remote district to the northern coastal area, allowing for greater public transport and business activities for the people,” he said. He said landowner communities will also benefit from statutory payments such as royalties and compensation. Mirisim said he put this proposal to Prime Minister James Marape when launching the Telefomin township plan and the Tabubil to Telefomin highway on Sept 12. The township plan includes a new business development centre, a new runway for the Telefomin air strip, sealing of roads, introduction of postal services, building of office complex, new police office and public servants housing. This plan is set to cater for future investment opportunities should the government take on resource development, such as the Frieda project. Telefomin is bordered along the Hindenburg ridge which divides the OK Tedi mine along the star mountains of Western and Telefomin district. Mirisim said as parts of the mountain range had shown rich mineralization, it stood to reason to drive further exploration in the area. A 2018 feasibility study projected a long mine life of over 30 years for the Frieda river project. This facilitates a broader regional development for the Sepik region in bringing in the much-needed services and infrastructure to isolated communities, he said. PanAust Ltd acquired the project from Highylands Pacific in 2014 and proposes to operate the mine through its subsidiary Frieda River Ltd (FRL). It is a open cast mine and associated infrastructure will straddle both Sandaun and East Sepik provinces. “The project will establish infrastructure for power transmission, potentially providing electricity and fiber optic cable access to communities. “The people will benefit from direct and indirect employment opportunities, providing income and opportunities for skills development for local residents and improved access to markets via new infrastructure,” Mirisim said. He said this would foster the growth of local businesses, trading, and cash cropping.

Title: PNG elected to Interpol Asia committee
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has joined the International Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol) Asian region committee following an election held at Singapore last week bringing together 49 countries. Police Commissioner David Manning said the discussions included cybercrime, fugitive tracking and child exploitation. “As the largest Pacific Island Police Force, it was recognised that PNG provides significant input into regional security and combatting cross-border crime,” Manning said. “PNG’s priority is to harness the power of regional collaboration to meet criminal threats.” He said this increased engagement would enhance capacity to intercept international criminals trying to exploit our country, while providing valuable input to Asia-Pacific law enforcement. “The increased trafficking of drugs and weapons, and the laundering of money, pose a significant threat to the safety of communities across the Pacific and Asia,” he added. “The ﬁght against cyber-enabled child exploitation and other online criminal activity is another rising threat to our people.” Manning also said that PNG was the bridge between Asia and the Paciﬁc, positioned to foster deeper enhanced regional policing cooperation to target these criminals. He said assistant police commissioner (crimes) Hodges Ette who commanded complex investigations into transnational narcotic syndicates, money laundering, and child exploitation would represent PNG at the forum. PNG is joined on the committee by Fiji, Australia, China, India, United Arab Emirates, Korea and the Philippines. Interpol’s secretary-general Valdecy Urquiza highlighted the importance of regional police co-operation to combat changing cross-border criminal activities.

Title: Peter ToRot to be canonised next month
Content: THE Catholic Church is expected to canonise Blessed Peter ToRot next month, making him Papua New Guinea’s first saint. According to a recent edition of the Vatican News, Fr Tomas Ravaioli, IVE, an Argentine missionary and the vice postulator of the canonisation of Peter ToRot, serving in PNG for 15 years, said the people of PNG were “very excited”. “It all happened so fast it feels like a gift, the last present of Pope Francis to our beloved country,” he said. Pope Francis visited PNG in September 2024 and expressed his desire to canonize Peter ToRot. In March 2025, he signed the decree, paving the way for the October ceremony in Rome. “This canonisation is not only new but also historic,” Ravaioli explained. “Papua New Guinea has never had a canonised saint. “Next month, we will have our first.” Peter ToRot was born in 1912, the son of a village chief. He was a husband and father of three children, a humble catechist, living an ordinary life deeply rooted in faith. Trained as a catechist, he assumed pastoral responsibilities when missionaries were imprisoned during World War II. Despite Japanese restrictions on Christian practices, he secretly organised catechism classes, prepared couples for marriage, taught children, visited the sick, and distributed Holy Communion across villages, often walking for five to six hours to reach them. He offered himself for the service of the church, and in 1945, he was arrested and martyred for opposing polygamy, following an order executed by the Japanese authorities that wanted to reintroduce the practice. His defense of Christian marriage and morality cost him his life at just 33 years old. “ToRot was like John the Baptist,” Ravioli said. “He openly told people that it was not lawful to take multiple wives. For this, he was imprisoned and eventually killed. He defended the sanctity of marriage and died for the truth.”

Title: Artificial intelligence to drive the future of governance: PM
Content: THE Government plans to drive efficiency, accountability, and fairness in decision-making through the use of artificial intelligence (AI), Prime Minister James Marape says. “The Government is looking at artificial intelligence as a platform to build a merit-based society,” he said. “A meritocracy means appointments, contracts, and Government decisions are made on ability and qualification—not on tribe, family ties, or favouritism. “I don’t care where you come from, what religion you practise, or what orientation you hold. “If you have the best qualifications and experience for the job, you will get the job.” Marape revealed that the Government is already engaging with international partners such as the Queensland University of Technology and Israeli experts to design an AI-powered information and communication technology (ICT) system. He said that AI would be introduced in: Marape said that these reforms were part of the Government’s commitment to reset governance for the future. “Technology is here to be used. In the next two years, we will mature these reforms so that by 2027, AI and ICT fuel efficiency, transparency, and accountability in our country. “This will be our 50th anniversary legacy.” He added that AI will help overcome the negative aspects of the “wantok” system, which, while valuable for community life, has undermined governance when applied to public service. “Thewantoksystem has its good side, but in Government it breeds inefficiency and corruption. “We must tidy this space so that our children inherit a system where merit and fairness prevail,” he said.

Title: PNGDF officers reunite with Australian colleague
Content: FOUR officers of the PNG Defence Force reunited in Port Moresby with a colleague from the Royal Australian Navy after four years of studying together at the Australian Defence Force Academy. Sub-Lieutenant Patrick Cabot met Lt Steven Ali, Lt Lawrence David, Lt Jeremeel Gabby and Second Lt Trevor Tanabi during the recent Defence Week in Port Moresby. The four PNGDF officers attended the academy and the Royal Military College as part of a programme where members of the international militaries attend training alongside junior Australian Defence Force officers. Cabot and Ali met as members of the same division and as neighbours in the academy housing. They studied, trained and played together in the academy’s Taipans touch footy club. Cabot met David, Gabby and Trevor there. The group remained close friends during their studies and stayed in touch as the PNGDF members transferred to the Royal Military College at Duntroon to further their military education. Cabot, now an Assistant Weapons Electrical Engineering Officer on theHMAS Choules, was part of the ADF support for PNG’s 50th year of independence celebrations. His four PNGDF counterparts had the opportunity to join Cabot for a tour ofHMAS Choulesand catch up ahead of Ali’s ceremonial role in the presentation of colours event at Murray Barracks last week. Ali said: “It was great getting to see Patrick again and to tour his ship. “It feels like yesterday that we were in Canberra and now he is helping us with our Independence Day celebrations.” Cabot said it was a bit surreal seeing them again. “I’m so grateful to get to see them in person again – and with such a significant milestone to celebrate.”

Title: Usino-Bundi runner-up challenges election result
Content: USINO-BUNDI by-election runner-up Donald Uguro is challenging the election victory of MP Vincent Ambane Kumura in the Court of Disputed Returns. Uguro, the son of the late Usino-Bundi MP Jimmy Uguro, through lawyer Tony Waisi, filed the election petition in the National Court in Waigani on Sept 12. The petition is challenging the 278 votes which Kumura won by – 14,649 votes to 14,416. Included in the petition are allegations of “significant errors and omissions” by polling officials in villages in wards six, seven and eight of the Usino local level government. The petition claims that the presiding officer failed to use the official ward roll to verify the voters’ identities. Instead of calling names from the roll, officials allegedly instructed voters to form two separate lines, one for men and one for women, and distributed around 3,600 ballot papers without proper checks. Uguro argued that it allowed for a voting process that violated constitutional and electoral requirements. The number of ballots allegedly cast without proper verification of 3,600 was larger than the final vote margin. Uguro’s petition does not seek a new by-election but instead asks the court to order a recount of all votes while excluding the two ballot boxes from the wards where the alleged irregularities occurred. The Usino-Bundi by-election writ was issued on April 24. It was conducted under the Limited Preferential Voting (LPV) system where a voter picked three candidates in the order of first, second and third. The absolute majority required (50 per cent plus one) to win the election was 14,556.

Title: Road to Wau being paved
Content: GARAINA Station in Wau Waria, Morobe will be revived once road connection from Wau town reaches it, says MP Marsh Narawec. Narawec said the station, when Garaina Valley Tea was still in production in the late ‘80s, was the home of Garaina Tea and during its production, many people from around the country lived and worked there. A pilot track has been cut through the Garaina Valley and has reached the station but Narawec said more work was still needed to make the road accessible by vehicles. Wau Waria district development is now setting its roadwork machines on this Northern Highway which will link Wau, Biaru, Waria, Garaina Valley and on to some parts of Sohe district in Northern. Narawec estimated that by the end of this year or early next year, the road reaching Garaina Station should be ready. For many villages in the valley, establishment of a road network has been their dream for the past 50 years. Many have died while waiting for this vital service to reach them until Wau Waria DDA, under the chairmanship of MP Narawec, decided to give priority to the road link. Speaking to people in the valley at Garaina Station, Narawec told them to take ownership and help the district Works division to ensure the track is upgraded well. “When this road link is completed, it will make way for other services to reach you people,” he told them. “This Garaina Station will then be revived and we are also looking at reviving the Garaina Tea Plantation as well.” Narawec urged community leaders, youths and the people in Garaina Valley to look after public servants serving at the station as well as schools and health posts. “Look after these public servants as they sacrifice their lives, their families, time and resources to come here and serve you people in the Waria local level government,” he said. Narawec also urged the public servants in the LLG to serve the people diligently and work in partnership to revive Garaina Station to what it was like in the past. He added that the DDA will give its best to build a police station and other government facilities once better roads reaching the station are upgraded.

Title: Researcher calls for PNG-Bougainville pact
Content: THE Papua New Guinea and Bougainville governments should consider framing both governments’ relationship into the future as a new item in the Joint Supervisory Body agenda, according to a researcher. Lowy Institute senior researcher Oliver Nobetau, in his September edition, titled Bougainville’s future, drew a roadmap for development proposes actionable reforms to be undertaken by both governments for socio-economic development. “A separate agreement should be drawn up to provide certainty on development,” he said. “The Bougainville Peace Agreement’s ambiguity on the post-referendum process extends to what the PNG and Bougainville relationship will look like following the ratification vote in Parliament.” Nobetau said despite the Melanesian agreement where both governments committed to maintaining a close, peaceful and enduring relationship, the new agreement should focus on a partnership that states how PNG can also benefit in Bougainville’s development. The recommendations laid out include: “The idea to create a special purposes authority is not new as in 2006, Bougainville’s House of Representatives passed legislation for the creation of a Bougainville Restoration and Development Authority (BRDA), repealed in 2012,” Nobetau said. “Similarly, in 2021 a review of the National Coordination Office of Bougainville Affairs recommended the establishment of an authority responsible for the management and delivery of projects agreed by both governments. “Ideally, such an undertaking should be made prior to the PNG parliament’s vote on ratification of the Bougainville referendum and the 2027 independence deadline set by Bougainville leaders. “The timing for this proposal is also fitting with Bougainville and PNG at political and generational crossroads. “With PNG celebrating its 50th anniversary, and half of Bougainville’s population born post-conflict, the scene is set for a revitalisation and rebranding of the relationship.” Nobetau said with the political and parliamentary deadlines of 2027 fast approaching, proposed reforms should be undertaken by both governments sooner.

Title: Sulka tribe celebrates World Indigenous Day
Content: THE Sulkas, an indigenous tribe in Kokopo’s Bitapaka local level government (LLG) area in East New Britain, celebrated the World Indigenous Day with tribes from other parts of the world on Sept 11. The four wards in Bitapaka LLG belong to the Sulka tribe. They are Ganai, Mope, Watwat and Vunabaur. People from the wards gathered at Ganai to commemorate the day. Ward member for Ganai, Augustine Alois, said they celebrated Sept 11 as an affiliate to the World Indigenous Convention Organisation. Alois said this was the second time they had celebrated the World Indigenous Day. The first was last year and they planned to celebrate every year from here on. He said World Indigenous had given them certain requirements and once they meet all of them, they will be certified as an indigenous tribe in ENB. Alois said the requirements include: Alois said the Sulka tribe existed more than 300 years. He said white men came into contact with them in the 1500s and they have records of all this information. “In this province we have different ethnic groups and we the Sulka tribe are one of those marginalised ethnic groups,” he said. “The ENB provincial government has been suppressing some of our rights. “Our land rights, our development and services. “These lack of services and development are obvious when you travel down. “You can see that the good part of the road ends where the Tolais are, the electricity ends where they are, the water supply ends where they are and the good communication network ends where they are. “So, if we have existed for this long, what makes us different from the rest of ENB? “We deserve a fair treatment as well, fair distribution of developments and services. “We contributed so much to the economy of this province as well as into the nation’s purse, because most of the coconut and cocoa plantations were established by the white men on Sulka tribe’s land. “But in return, we get nothing. So, 50 years’ celebrations mean nothing to us.”

Title: Woman freed from murder charge
Content: THE National Court in Minj has freed a woman who was charged with the murder of her husband three years ago, upholding her no case to answer application. National Court Judge Joseph Crowley when handing down his decision in the case of Janet Kund Malu, from North Waghi’s Kuspa village in Jiwaka, said the State produced no evidence on elements necessary to provide a charge of murder. “Therefore, I uphold the application of the defence and declare Malu has no case to answer and she is discharged in relation to indictment 2127 of 2023,” he said. The court heard that on June 17, 2022, between 8am and 9am, Malu and her husband, Gilma Kolngo were allegedly fighting inside their house. During the fight, she allegedly used a tree branch to hit her husband. The State further alleged that she struck him on the right side of his neck which resulted in his death. However, when the trial started, the prosecutor informed the court that three of the four prosecution witnesses were not in court and police were unable to locate them. The prosecutor said the family of the accused had paid compensation to the family and as such the witnesses (who were from the same village) were reluctant to give evidence. On the first day, only one witness gave evidence and on the second day, only one other could be located and brought to court. Two of those witnesses were not called because they were not required for cross examination or their statements were tendered by consent.

Title: Warding off spirits. Bridge opened with ritual
Content: A PIG’s head was cut off and thrown into the Tolo river in East New Britain’s Pomio in a traditional gesture to ward off the spirits of the river as a 204-meter bridge was unveiled on Sept 17. The new Tolo Bridge connects villages in Pomio’s Mamusi-Yana local level government (LLG) area to Palmalmal government station, and locals with access to services from Pomio’s main commercial hub. The bridge is the result of a collaborative effort between Gilford Limited and the Pomio administration. Construction was carried out by Gilford’s subsidiary company, Vision Engineering and Construction Limited. After six months of work, the bridge is now complete and is expected to last longer than the two previous bridges that were washed away by the Tolo River. General Manager of Gilford Limited, Mok-Chow Kheng, said the teamwork had created something durable that would improve the lives of the people. “The bridge will make travel and business easier, especially during the rainy season, when theriver was once a big problem,” he said. Pomio MP Elias Kapavore, speaking at the opening, praised the company for the timely completion of the bridge. Kapavore said the opening of the bridge also marked the beginning of the country’s 50th year of independence. “Today is the first day of our 50th year as an independent nation,” he said. “This bridge took only six months to complete. “It was constructed on time and within budget.” Kapavore urged the people to make good use of the bridge and other services available to them. “We have two ships,” he said. “It was my responsibility to buy the ships, and it is now your responsibility to fill them with cocoa, copra, and coffee. “I challenge you today, you have roads now. Make sure you work the land and get your cash crops to the market.” Kapavore also highlighted the importance of respecting cultural traditions. He performed a customary ritual, which, according to local belief, would safeguard the people from spiritual threats when using the bridge.

Title: PNG has special significance for New Zealand army colonel George Duncan
Content: PAPUA New Guinea holds a special place in the heart of New Zealand army Col Duncan George, who recently oversaw a successful PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) celebration of the country’s 50th anniversary of independence. George was born in Christchurch and attended Riccarton High School, but for three years from the age of eight, he lived in PNG, learning the language and experiencing the nation’s rich culture. His father, Squadron Leader (Rtd) Chris George was posted as one of the New Zealand Defence Force instructors to the local defence academy and the family lived in Igam Barracks in Lae. In February, George was appointed the Joint Task Force Commander to plan and support the week-long anniversary celebrations. This included a military tattoo attended by military bands from Australia, Fiji, France, India, Japan, New Zealand, Tonga, United Kingdom, United States and Vanuatu. There was also a fleet review of Navy vessels, an air shows over Ela Beach and a static display of visiting and PNG aircraft. “I’m relieved that it went well, but also very proud of PNG, the PNG Defence Force and of course, the New Zealand and Australian Defence Forces that helped out,” George said. The week also provided opportunities for visiting aircraft from Australia, France and New Zealand to deliver supplies such as medical equipment, books and mosquito netting, to remote areas around the country. “There were a whole bunch of countries that came over to help celebrate, which was fantastic and it was great the majority of them were from around the Pacific region,” George said. George has been embedded in the PNGDF since December 2023 as the Deputy Chief of Staff, so has a unique insight into why this celebration was so significant for the country. “PNG is the most populous nation in Oceania. From a strategic geographic point of view, it straddles Southeast Asia and the Pacific. It’s a leading nation within the Pacific Islands Forum in terms of its size, geography and natural resources,” he said. “It was important to reflect on the positive aspects of the country, because all too often governance, the economy and law and order were the focal point from international observers. “PNG is a proud nation with uninterrupted parliamentary democracy, a growing middle class, and it’s a nation that has a big voice in the Pacific.” George’s family ties to the area remain to this day. His father was known for his professional skills but also his ability to train, mentor and encourage young Papua New Guinean aviators. Last month, George’s father Chris was presented with a commendation by PNGDF deputy chief Brig-Gen Lari Opa. “The great memories I have of being in PNG during the 80s were so strong that I always wanted to come back, I just wasn’t sure when or how. Having three kids (two teenagers) meant that I was a little hesitant to do it so late in my career, but my wife told me that it was now or never, so we took the plunge,” he said. George is the sixth deputy chief of staff to come from the NZDF since the appointment was created in 2009. “PNG and the PNGDF can be challenging places to live and work, but the people are the key to being here. They have different ways of doing things, but I’m lucky in the sense that I grew up here for a while, I’ve retained much of my Tok Pisin (Pidgin) and I feel comfortable and accepted here as one of the Defence Force’s own. “My wife has taken to scuba diving and my children are having a great experience at their respective schools,” he said. George, who finishes his posting in December, said he saw PNG as becoming increasingly important for New Zealand in the coming years. “I encourage anyone who is passionate about the Pacific and our place in it to consider a posting here. You need an adventurous spirit, but serving here will be a highlight in anyone’s career.”

Title: Deputy secretary of state Landau commends US-PNG partnership
Content: THE United States (US) has congratulated Papua New Guinea on its 50th Independence anniversary, marking five decades of partnership and shared progress. Deputy secretary of state Christopher Landau and Admiral Samuel Paparo, commander of the US Indo-Pacific Command, visited Port Moresby to commemorate this historic milestone, reaffirming the continuous relationship between the two countries. During the visit, Landau emphasised the US’ commitment to strengthening economic ties, enhancing infrastructure development, and deepening defence cooperation with PNG. Prime Minister James Marape and Landau signed a framework for strategic cooperation, formalising mutual priorities for the future of the bilateral relationship. The framework encompasses economic, commercial and digital collaboration, as well as critical minerals and infrastructure development. At the same time, the framework reaffirms existing mechanisms, like the Strategic Partnership Dialogue and the 2023 Defence Cooperation Agreement. “US engagement in the Pacific is broad,” Deputy Secretary Landau said. “From unexploded ordnance remediation programmes in PNG, to recent capacity building, infrastructure, and security programmes across the region,” he added. The visit also included key events such as the groundbreaking of DGCI’s US$498 million (about K2.08 billion) US-funded fuel storage facility, facilitated through the 2023 Defence Cooperation Agreement. These initiatives underscore the US’s commitment to supporting PNG’s economic growth, resilience, and regional security.
