USINDOPACOM’s Centre for Excellence in Disaster Management and Humanitarian Assistance (CFE-DM) has updated its disaster management handbook to mark 50 years of US-PNG relations on Sept 16. The handbook builds local crisis response capacity, fosters civil-military relationships, provides a vital tool for US-PNG cooperation during a crisis, strengthens the resilience of PNG, and supports US’s shared vision for a secure and open Indo-Pacific. The US Department of State is using US$11 million (about K46 million) in foreign military financing to enhance PNG’s capabilities in humanitarian assistance and disaster relief, maritime security, maritime domain awareness, and military professionalisation is underway. The PNGDF participated in the multilateral exercise Talisman Sabre alongside the US and Australia and hosted its first-ever component outside of Australia earlier this year. The US Department of State’s Bureau of International Narcotics and Law Enforcement Affairs intends to provide a resident adviser from the Department of Homeland Security Federal Law Enforcement Training Centres to support law enforcement development in PNG.

Title: ‘Capable operator’ flew drones at Copenhagen Airport
Content: Copenhagen: Drones that shut the Denmark’s main airport appear to have been flown by “a capable operator”, police say, adding that no suspects have been identified. The airports in Copenhagen and Oslo, the two busiest in the Nordic region, were shut for hours after drones were observed in their airspace late on Monday, leaving tens of thousands of passengers stranded as flights were diverted. “We have concluded that this was what we would call a capable operator,” Danish police Chief Superintendent Jens Jespersen told reporters on Tuesday, referring to the drones observed in Copenhagen. “It’s an actor who has the capabilities, the will and the tools to show off in this way,” Jespersen said, adding it was too early to say if the incidents in Denmark and Norway were linked. Copenhagen Airport was closed for four hours when two or three large drones were seen flying in its immediate vicinity, officials said, while the Oslo Airport was closed for three hours following two sightings, according to local police. Jespersen said the drones in Denmark came from several different directions, turning their lights on and off, before eventually disappearing after several hours. Copenhagen diverted 31 flights to other airports, causing ripple effects that delayed or cancelled around 100 flights and affected some 20,000 passengers, a spokesperson told reporters on Tuesday. The airport shutdowns came after a string of disruptions at European airports in recent days. A cyberattack last Friday knocked out check-in and boarding systems supplied by Collins Aerospace, a unit of RTX, affecting operations at London’s Heathrow and the Berlin and Brussels airports. At the weekend and into Monday, the fallout continued to snarl travel across the region. Source: Reuters

Title: Trump targets antifa as a ‘terrorist organisation’
Content: Washington: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order calling the antifa movement a “terrorist organisation”, the White House says, after promising actions targeting left-wing groups following Charlie Kirk’s assassination. Kirk, a prominent conservative activist with close ties to Trump, was assassinated on Sept 10 while speaking on a college campus in Utah. A 22-year-old technical college student has been charged with Kirk’s murder. Investigators are still looking for a motive and have not said the suspect operated in concert with any groups. But the Trump administration has used the killing as a pretext to revive years-old plans to target left-wing groups they regard as being hostile to conservative views. Antifa, short for anti-fascist, is a “decentralised, leaderless movement composed of loose collections of groups, networks and individuals”, according to the Anti-Defamation League, which tracks extremists. “While some extreme actors who claim to be affiliated with antifa do engage in violence or vandalism at rallies and events, this is not the norm,” it says on its website. Trump’s 370-word executive order on Monday directs “all relevant executive departments and agencies” to “investigate, disrupt, and dismantle any and all illegal operations” conducted by antifa or anyone who funds such actions, according to the White House. “Individuals associated with and acting on behalf of Antifa further co-ordinate with other organisations and entities for the purpose of spreading, fomenting, and advancing political violence and suppressing lawful political speech.” Federal law enforcement officials already investigate violent and organised crime associated with a variety of hate groups and ideological movements. The US government does not officially designate solely domestic groups as terrorist organisations in large part because of constitutional protections. But a Justice Department official with knowledge of discussions on the issue said Trump’s order would unlock expansive investigative and surveillance authorities and powers. The person, who declined to be named, said the designation would allow the US government to more closely track the finances and movements of US citizens and to investigate any foreign ties of the loose network of groups and non-profits the Trump administration views as antifa. It was not clear which individuals would be the target of such a probe. Critics of the administration have warned it might pursue an attack on free speech and opponents of the Republican president. Political violence experts and US law enforcement officials have previously identified far-right attacks as the leading source of domestic violent extremism. Trump administration officials have sought to portray left-wing groups as the main drivers of political violence in their remarks since Kirk’s death. Legal experts have said the domestic terrorism designation might be legally and constitutionally dubious, hard to execute and raise free-speech concerns, given that subscription to an ideology is not generally considered criminal under US law. During the first Trump administration there were at least two failed efforts to designate antifa a terrorist organisation. Source: Reuters

Title: ICC charges Duterte with crimes against humanity
Content: The Hague: Former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte has been charged with crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court (ICC). The 80-year-old is accused of being criminally responsible for dozens of murders that allegedly took place as part of his so-called war on drugs, during which thousands of small-time drug dealers, users and others were killed without trial. Duterte is the first Asian former head of state to be indicted by the ICC. ICC deputy prosecutor Mame Mandiaye Niang said Duterte was an “indirect co-perpetrator” in the killings, which the court alleges were carried out by others, including police. A redacted version of the ICC’s charge sheet was only made public on Tuesday. The first count against Duterte relates to his alleged indirect co-perpetration in the murders of 19 people between 2013 and 2016 when he was mayor of Davao City. It was in this southern stronghold, which Duterte ruled for decades, that he tested his war on drugs, which he later implemented nationwide during his presidency from 2016 to 2022. “During the mayoral period, Duterte, [redacted] and the above-mentioned law enforcement officials used police from Davao City and non-police hitmen (together, the DDS) to kill alleged criminals,” the document said, without revealing the names of the former president’s accomplices. It added the former president headed the so-called Davao Death Squad (DDS). The other two counts relate to the murders of 57 people. Fourteen of them were classified by the ICC as “high-value targets,” some of whom appeared on a list that offered financial incentives to police officers. These 57 murders took place from the beginning of Duterte’s presidency in 2016 until 2019, when he withdrew the Philippines from the Rome Statute that governs the ICC, fearing prosecution. “Duterte and his co-perpetrators shared a common plan or agreement to ‘neutralise’ alleged criminals in the Philippines (including those perceived or alleged to be associated with drug use, sale or production) through violent crimes including murder,” the document said. The ICC ordered Duterte’s arrest in March, accusing him of murder as a crime against humanity in the context of his war on drugs which, during his term, killed some 6000 people, police say. NGOs put the figure at around 30,000. He surrendered to the ICC on March 12 in response to the arrest warrant, and appeared before the judges in The Hague for the first time two days later. Duterte’s supporters allege the ICC is being used as a political tool by the Philippines’ current president Ferdinand Marcos, who had publicly fallen out with the powerful Duterte family. The ICC effectively has no power to arrest people without the co-operation of the countries they are in, which is most often refused – and Marcos had previously dismissed the idea of co-operating with the ICC. With agencies

Title: Palestine statehood a ‘point of contention’ in US ties
Content: Sydney: Australia has been urged not to ignore threats of “punitive measures” from top Republicans, as the prime minister lands in the US for one of his most important diplomatic ventures. Anthony Albanese arrived in New York City on Sunday morning Australian time ahead of a long-awaited United Nations General Assembly meeting where Australia, Canada, France and the UK will recognise the state of Palestine. But hours before touchdown, a group of top Republican congress members and allies of Donald Trump issued an open letter to the leaders of those nations warning recognition “may invite punitive measures”. “This is something that very well could be a point of contention between the Albanese government and the Trump administration,” United States Studies Centre director Jared Mondschein told AAP. “It should not be ignored.” But that doesn’t mean Australia cannot stand its ground. The UK’s foreign policy – like Australia’s – has begun to diverge from the US after decades of generally moving in lock step with the world power. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer has been able to work through his differences with the US president. “I would not be surprised if Prime Minister Albanese and President Trump are able to overcome their differences of opinion on this matter too,” Mondschein said. Albanese is hoping to secure his first face-to-face meeting with Trump, though talks have not yet been scheduled. Some speculated the two could hold discussions on the weekend before the UN event, but this was dispelled when the president announced he would attend the funeral of right-wing American commentator Charlie Kirk on Sunday in Arizona. The prime minister was due to meet with the US president in June during the G7 summit, but was left wanting when Trump departed the event early to intervene in escalating Middle East violence. In the months since, a bilateral meeting has arguably become a lesser priority for Albanese. The US in August spared Australian goods from a tariff hike, leaving its products at the baseline 10 per cent – which is the lowest rate levied against any American trading partner. But there is still much to discuss that extends beyond the bilateral US-Australia relationship, like the security environment and strategic competition in the Pacific. “If Australia and the United States – who are the closest of allies – are able to get aligned on this, then that will give momentum to other allies in the region,” Mondschein said. Stepping onto the tarmac at John F Kennedy International Airport in New York, Albanese emphasised the importance of Australia’s role on the world stage. “What we want to see is increased peace and security and stability around the world,” he told reporters. “We are a country that play a positive role in our region, in the Pacific, as well as of course … our traditional allies such as our Five-Eyes partners including the United States and the United Kingdom.” Source: AAP

Title: Vanuatu flags China policing deal after Australia snub
Content: Canberra: Australia’s attempt to net a security pact with Vanuatu has hit a major snag as one of the Pacific nation’s ministers flags expanded policing co-operation with China. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and his Vanuatu counterpart Jotham Napat were scheduled to sign a transformational security deal ahead of Pacific leaders meeting in the Solomon Islands this month. The AU$500 million (about K1.4b) deal – the second attempt by Albanese to formalise an agreement with Port Vila – fell over at the last minute after Vanuatu raised concerns it could inhibit assistance from third nations. Napat said there were issues around it potentially blocking other nations being able to fund the nation’s critical infrastructure projects. Australia has been working to sign exclusivity agreements across the Pacific to lock China out of critical infrastructure and security, and has struck similar deals with Tuvalu, Nauru and Papua New Guinea. But Vanuatu has effectively been playing Australia and China off against each other to bolster its own aid. China donated policing equipment including drones to Vanuatu after Chinese State Councillor and Minister of Public Security Wang Xiaohong met with Internal Affairs Minister Andrew Solomon Napuat. The Vanuatu Daily Post reported Napuat said Vanuatu had already finalised memorandums of understanding and co-operation agreements with other nations like Australia, and China was the only nation with which it still needed to formalise a pact. “Our two governments wish to formalise a police MoU similar to existing MoUs with Australia, New Zealand, France, the UK, and PNG, to better co-ordinate and manage different areas of partnership in the policing sector with all of our partners,” he is quoted as saying. He said the agreement was not the same as the Nakamal security agreement being negotiated with Australia. The Nakamal agreement is the pact under which Australia seeks to bolster Vanuatu’s economic and developmental needs in exchange for security co-operation. While the text hasn’t been made public, similar agreements Australia has struck include an effective veto of third nations providing assistance for security or critical infrastructure. Napuat said international media had exaggerated and misrepresented discussions about its security partnerships “which have very specific meanings in Vanuatu’s context”. Vanuatu’s interest wasn’t in militarisation but on security issues such as climate change, crime and general policing, he said. “This is why we must define our own security challenges and determine our security and policing needs,” he said. “Climate change is the biggest security threat in Vanuatu.” Prior to this month’s stalled deal, Australia and Vanuatu agreed a security agreement in 2022 that expressed a “family first approach to peace and security in our region”. The rhetoric is used by the Australian government to denote that security needs should be met by Pacific nations and not outside countries, namely China which is working to secure its only foothold in the region. The 2022 pact – Albanese’s first attempt at deal-making after coming to office – was never ratified by Vanuatu’s parliament due to concerns it breached the nation’s non-alignment foreign policy and had greater implications for its sovereignty. Source: AAP

Title: France joins Western allies in recognising Palestine
Content: UNITED NATIONS: France has recognised a Palestinian state at a world summit in New York, nearly two years into the war in Gaza, joining Western allies such as Britain and Australia, which already made the same historic move and were rebuked by Israel. “We must pave the way for peace,” the summit host, French President Emmanuel Macron, said on Monday. “Today, France, recognises the state of Palestine.” While the event, convened by France and Saudi Arabia, could boost the morale of Palestinians in their long search for statehood, it is not expected to deliver change on the ground. The most far-right government in Israel’s history has declared there will be no Palestinian state as it pushes on with its fight against militant group Hamas in Gaza following the Oct 7, 2023, attack on Israel that killed some 1200 people. Israel has become increasingly isolated and drawn global condemnation over its military conduct in Gaza, where more than 65,000 Palestinians have been killed, according to local health authorities. In recent weeks, Israel has begun a long-threatened ground assault on Gaza City with few prospects for a ceasefire. Andorra, Belgium, Luxembourg and San Marino were also expected to recognise a Palestinian state on Monday ahead of this week’s UN General Assembly, after Canada, Portugal and others did so at the weekend. Malta made the announcement earlier on Monday. Israel has said such moves will undermine the prospects of a peaceful ending to the conflict in Gaza. The two-state solution was the bedrock of the US-backed peace process ushered in by the 1993 Oslo Accords. The process suffered heavy pushback from both sides and has all but died. No such negotiations over a two-state solution have been held since 2014. The United States and Israel boycotted Monday’s meeting. Israel’s UN Ambassador Danny Danon said Israel would discuss what action to take in response to the announcements of recognition after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu returns to Israel next week. “Those issues were supposed to be negotiated between Israel and the Palestinians in the future,” he told reporters ahead of the meeting. The United States has told other countries that Palestinian recognition will create more problems, Secretary of State Marco Rubio said earlier this month. Amid Israel’s intensified Gaza offensive and escalating violence by Israeli settlers in the West Bank, there is a growing sense of urgency among some nations to act now before the idea of a two-state solution vanishes forever. France has driven the move, hoping that Macron’s announcement in July that he would recognise a Palestinian state would give greater momentum to a movement hitherto dominated by smaller nations that are generally more critical of Israel. A delegation representing the State of Palestine has observer status at the United Nations – but no voting rights. No matter how many countries recognise Palestinian independence, full UN membership would require approval by the Security Council, where the US has a veto. Source: Reuters

Title: ‘Bring it home’: PM’s diplomatic fight for climate meet
Content: Canberra: Australia has been urged not to cower in its fight for hosting rights of a major climate summit as the prime minister prepares to make his case for a rival bidder to stand down. Canberra has teamed up with the Pacific countries in a proposal to jointly hold the 2026 United Nations Climate Change Conference, known as COP31. Turkey has also expressed an interest in hosting the summit and neither bidder has so far backed away from the chance to hold the talks on home soil. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is preparing to meet with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the sidelines of the UN general assembly in New York to try to convince the leader to withdraw Ankara’s bid. Albanese said he would advocate for Australia’s case in good faith, and he had already held discussions with Turkey’s leaders. “It’s a joint bid and there’ll be a range of Pacific leaders here this week who will be advocating as well,” he told reporters on Monday. “If we’re going to see our way through to a common position, it is highly likely there will be a need to be compromise.” The prime minister will be hoping to emerge from the UN with a diplomatic victory on the world stage after failing to land formal deals with Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea in his last two overseas trips. Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young said Australia “shouldn’t be cowering and letting Turkey win this battle”. “Adelaide should be the host city and we should get on with showing leadership around the world,” she said. “If the prime minister doesn’t bring COP home … that’ll be a fail.” The conference will be held in the German city of Bonn under COP rules if an agreement can’t be reached between the two bidders. The impasse must be solved before the latest climate conference, in Brazil, concludes in November. The negotiations follow the federal government’s announcement of its 2035 emissions reduction target on Thursday. Greenhouse gas emissions would need to be reduced by between 62 and 70 per cent from 2005 levels to reach the goal. Source: AAP

Title: Race to save Solomons’ history as radio reigns supreme
Content: Honiara: The historical soundtrack of one of Australia’s near-neighbours is at risk of being forever lost. In a small room lined with shelves brimming with chronicles and recordings at the rear of the Solomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation in Honiara, sits Salei Rukasi. She has been working there since 1984. The veteran archivist is painstakingly undertaking the digitisation of thousands of hours of audio tapes to ensure the Pacific nation’s unique legacy lives on as time begins to ravage some of the material. The process, as it applies to the most extensive audio archive in the Solomons, began in the early 2000s in a tiny studio and with a single reel-to-reel machine. However the equipment is now faulty and the tapes are being sent to Australia to be converted as part of the Pacific Media Assistance Scheme managed by the ABC and supported by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Solomon Islanders still rely heavily on radio given the remoteness of some of its communities, which are scattered across an archipelago of almost a thousand volcanic islands and low-lying coral atolls to Queensland’s northeast. “It is very important because that’s the only audio you can have of them,” Rukasi recently told AAP in Honiara about the families that routinely visit her studio in search of recordings documenting the lives of their loved ones. “Maybe they’re published in books and all that but to hear somebody’s voice … actually, I think that is very important. “It can be maybe be traditional chants or things like that,” she explained. The archives include recordings, interviews and speeches from the Solomons’ long fight for independence granted in 1978. Periods of national upheaval which followed and other major political moments, as well as cultural events and local music from the station’s old recording studio, also feature. Relatives, children and even grandchildren have come searching for links to their forebears, Rukasi said. The Solomon Islands has been through tribulation and turbulence aplenty since gaining self government in 1976. Ethnic conflict between 1998 and 2003 tore apart the nation and collapsed its economy. However a regional peacekeeping force spearheaded by Australia arrived in 2003 to help restore peace and order. For better or worse, the Solomon Islands Broadcasting Corporation has been there through all of it following its creation by one of the nation’s first acts of parliament upon severing administrative ties with Britain. It now proudly broadcasts across more than 28,000 square kilometres, reaching the archipelago’s far flung corners. Video may have killed the radio star but hasn’t yet caught up with Rukasi. Source: AAP

Title: Pacific snags could follow Albanese to Trump meeting
Content: Darwin: Anthony Albanese is being accused of prioritising “photo ops” over diplomacy after his failure to seal two major deals with Pacific nations risked derailing an upcoming meeting with Donald Trump. Opposition Leader Sussan Ley said the prime minister had misrepresented the status of defence agreements with Papua New Guinea and Vanuatu by saying they were done deals before returning home empty-handed. Albanese left Port Moresby on Wednesday without a hoped-for defence pact with PNG after its prime minister, James Marape, failed to convene his cabinet to sign off on the landmark agreement in time. Instead, the leaders only managed to put their signatures to a communique laying out the key tenets of the pact, which Marape insists will be approved by cabinet shortly. “With every piece of diplomacy, agreement making, you just have to do the work. And clearly that hasn’t been done because he announced that it was all achieved and when he got there it clearly wasn’t,” Ley told Nine’s Today programme. Albanese insists the delay in signing the defence treaty has “no downside”, brushing aside claims it’s an embarrassment for the government. But the delay comes just more than a week after Albanese also returned empty-handed from a visit to Vanuatu, failing to land an AU$500 million (about 1.4b) deal that would have given Australia veto power over Chinese investment in critical infrastructure. “For the prime minister to rush over there and to use this just as a photo op, I think tells us that he isn’t doing the work, and it’s a real foreign policy failure, not just with PNG but with the $500 million deal with Vanuatu,” Ley said. The timing is unfortunate, given Albanese is preparing to visit the United States this week for an expected first face-to-face meeting with Trump on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly. The Albanese government risks being seen as having dropped the ball in Australia’s role as the US’s deputy sheriff in the Pacific. The Trump administration has been leaning on Australia to boost its security presence as a bulwark against Chinese influence in the region. The US expected Australia to maintain a strong security presence in the Pacific and the failure of its PNG and Vanuatu deals meant missed potential, Lowy Institute research fellow Oliver Nobetau told AAP. “This could have demonstrated that Australia and Papua New Guinea – it sees itself as a big brother – can maintain regional stability within the Pacific,” he said. The stalled agreements were probably going to reinforce US perceptions that Australia could do more when it came to security in the Pacific, Nobetau said. The government needed to go back to the drawing board to find a different diplomatic approach to instil confidence, especially among Melanesian nations, to sign on to such agreements, Nobetau said. Source: AAP

Title: New Zealand loosens path to residency for some migrants
Content: Wellington: The New Zealand government says it is introducing two new pathways for migrants to gain residency as part of their efforts to boost the country’s economy. Economic Growth Minister Nicola Willis said in the statement that skilled and experienced migrants play an important role in plugging workforce gaps, and in turn help businesses to grow. “Businesses told us it was too hard for some migrants to gain residence, even when they had crucial skills and significant experience that was not available in the existing workforce. We’re fixing it,” she said. The new pathways are for skilled workers and tradespeople and technicians, and require them to have relevant experience both overseas and in New Zealand and to meet salary thresholds, the statement said. New Zealand’s economy has been struggling having seen negative growth in three of the last five quarters and the government has been introducing a number of policies aimed at supporting it, including boosting foreign investment. While the Pacific nation’s net migration has remained positive, it has come off the highs seen following the reopening of the borders in 2022 as a historically high number of New Zealanders leave. Government coalition partner New Zealand First said it does not support the policy. Source: Reuters

Title: Tongan royal visit a return to familiar territory
Content: Canberra: While not quite a homecoming, Tongan royalty has returned to familiar territory on a visit to Australia’s bush capital. King Tupou VI and Queen Nanasipau’u have been welcomed by Governor-General Sam Mostyn and the Federation Guard with a smoking ceremony at Government House in Canberra on Friday. The royals are also due to visit Sydney as part of their week-long trip – the first official visit by a Tongan head of state to Australia in 46 years. The king’s welcome to Government House included a signing ceremony between Australia and Tonga for a statement of intent to lift the countries’ bilateral relationship. The statement committed to lifting the partnership with an agreement known as Kaume’a Ofi, which means close friends. Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the visit would strengthen bonds between Australia and Tonga. “Their majesties’ visit to Australia demonstrates the importance of our bilateral relationship and depth of the cultural and personal connections between our two countries spanning 200 years,” she said in a statement. “The visit will celebrate our strong defence ties, scientific innovation in heath and rich connections across faith.” The ceremonial visit is not the first time Tonga’s head of state has been in Canberra on official business. King Tupou VI became Tonga’s first high commissioner to Australia in 2008 and lived in Canberra for four years before ascending to the throne upon the death of his elder brother, King Tupou V. The king’s daughter, Princess Angelika Latufuipeka Tuku’aho, then held the role until 2023, when she stood down to complete doctoral studies at the Australian National University’s Department of Pacific Affairs. The Tongan royals will take part in an investiture ceremony in Sydney for Tongans living in Australia who assisted in the aftermath of the 2022 Hunga Ha’apai volcano disaster. It will be followed by a church service on Sunday, with members of the Tongan diaspora invited to attend. The Pacific nation will celebrate 150 years as a constitutional monarchy in November. Source: AAP

Title: Enforce new minimum wage, chamber tells department
Content: THE Department of Labour and Industrial Relations must ensure stringent and effective enforcement of the new minimum wage rates, according to the PNG Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Chamber president Ian Tarutia has welcomed the recently approved rate from K3.50 to K5 per hour from January next year, to K5.25 from January 2027, and K5.50 per hour from January 2028, as determined by the Minimum Wages Board. “Given the current economic conditions and rising cost of living, this adjustment is both timely and necessary,” Tarutia said. “Although many of our business members already pay above the minimum wage, we strongly urge all organisations and businesses to comply with the new minimum wage rates. “More importantly, this increase will enhance the earning and purchasing power of our workers, allowing them to live sustainably.” Minimum Wage Board chairman Beverly Doiwa said: “We are confident this new rate will provide relief for workers and their families, ensuring a fair and just wage reflecting economic realities, while mindful of business sustainability.” Meanwhile, a report has revealed that the PNG minimum wage rate is among the lowest in the Asia-Pacific region. The report was compiled by Stephen Howes of the Australian National University, and Kingtau Mambon and Kelly Samof of the University of PNG.

Title: Grounded PNGDF aircraft under recovery programme
Content: AFTER eight years of being grounded, the Papua New Guinea Defence Force aircraft CASA 235 has its engines restarted under the CASA recovery programme. Defence minister Dr Billy Joseph confirmed that phase two of the programme would start when the first phase was completed. “The completion of phase one is at an 85-90 per cent stage,” he said. “Once it’s completed, the aircraft will be flown to Bandu in Indonesia (where) they will do a full overhaul and c-service.” The Defence Force received the 30-year-old aircraft in 1994 which could carry 52 passengers including pilots, engineers and load masters. It was grounded in 2017. Joseph said that they planned to use the aircraft to transport troops and cargo around the country. He said that defence council planned to fix air capability and capacity not only for the air transport wing but also for the force. Joseph thanked the Australian Government for the flight excellence programme that gave three PAC 750 to be used fortraining. He said that after Phase Two, they planned to fix the other CASA 235 aircraft.

Title: Power outage in Port Moresby due to substation fire: PPL
Content: PARTS of Port Moresby experienced power outages over the weekend following a fire at the Konedobu substation on Friday night. A PNG Power Limited statement said that the fire severely damaged the 12-year-old 11kv control panel and burnt out insulation on several feeder cables. The affected areas included Down Town, parts of Korobosea, Hohola and Waigani. The statement said: “The damaged equipment requires a replacement that must be sourced from overseas. “In the interim, our engineers are executing a careful strategy to transfer your power supply to other operational substations. “This is a complex and dangerous process. We must balance the electrical load precisely to avoid overloading other feeders and causing further outages.” PPL urged consumers in the affected Kone feeders to be patient. “Our teams are handling high-voltage equipment and managing loads to ensure the safety of our personnel and the integrity of the entire grid. Rushing this process could risk further extended outages,” it said. Meanwhile parts of Port Moresby were without water on Saturday. The Water PNG Limited management said that a mechanical issue with its pump at the Bomana water supply intake caused the disruption. Water was restored to most parts of the city by 6pm on Saturday.

Title: Funding disruption delays work on Port Moresby’s cancer centre
Content: THE Comprehensive Cancer Centre at the Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH) faced disruptions due to funding and procurement delays, but persistent efforts have brought it close to completion, an official says. Hospital chief executive officer Dr Paki Molumi said during the World Patient Safety Day on Friday that Prime Minister James Marape had earlier this year said that the centre would be opened on Sept 16. But because of the non-availability of bulk funding, the project had to be phased to accommodate annual budget allocations. Molumi said that phase one and phase two had been completed. He said phase three is 80 per cent complete and Phase Four had just started. “The facility was being constructed to international standards under the guidance of global experts in oncology infrastructure,” he said. Molumi said that it would have advanced technoloy to deliver world-class cancer care. “While the project has experienced intermittent disruptions due to funding and procurement delays, persistent efforts have brought it close to completion.” Molumi said to align with available funding, human resource capacity, and technical support, services would begin from next year. “This facility is designed to serve as a one-stop cancer center, and will support excellence in cancer care for the next 50 years,” he said. Molumi said that once fully commissioned, the center would be the most advanced cancer treatment facility in the country, offering a full spectrum of diagnostic and therapeutic services under one roof. “This one-stop-shop approach will eliminate the need for overseas referrals, ensuring that Papua New Guineans receive world-class care at home,” he added.

Title: O’Neill cautions government about meddling with state agencies
Content: IALIBU-Pangia MP and former prime minister Peter O’Neill has warned the Government to stop interfering with important public institutions. In a Facebook post, O’Neill claimed that the recent interference in public institutions by the James Marape-led Government was a deliberate attempt to access public funds without the transparency and accountability needed. “The lack of transparency and accountability promotes corruption and allows politicians with dirty fingers to access billions of Kina. “This is eroding public trust,” he said. O’Neill claimed that the Government seems to be moving its focus from public accounts in Treasury and Finance to State-owned entities and public institutions such as the Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited and the National Banking Corporation. “Where is the respect for the constitutions of public institutions to protect them from political interference?” O’Neill said. He said that it was clear (Prime Minister Marape) had no commercial acumen or business experience to manage these important public institutions. “As a result, over the last six years, we have gone from one Marape-made mistake to another followed by more false promises,” he added. “Marape is calling for public officials to be tested by the courts but he and many in his government refuse to submit themselves to the same process. “We cannot blame the citizens for smelling a rat.” In response yesterday, Marape described O’Neill’s sentiments as “misleading, hypocritical, and unworthy of someone who presided over the worst era of economic mismanagement” in the nation’s history. “It baffles me that Mr O’Neill can talk about transparency and accountability when his own record speaks volumes of the opposite,” Marape said. “As an accountant and self-styled economic manager, he should recall the disastrous state in which he left this country when his government collapsed in 2019.”

Title: Undialu urges leaders to stop people blocking highway
Content: HELA Governor Philip Undialu has urged the leaders of Southern Highlands to stop people from blocking the Highlands Highway in protest over the suspension of Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) managing director Wapu Sonk. “I want to remind the people of Semin and Nipa that Sonk has deep roots in Hela, having been educated there and maintaining strong friendships and networks with Hela leaders and youths,” Undialu said. “This decision was made by the newly appointed KPHL board chaired by Gerea Aopi, and people should understand.” He said that it made little sense that the highway blockade was affecting the people in Hela supporting Sonk. “Although Prime Minister James Marape is from Hela and Southern Highlands, some of his decisions have not always favoured us. “But as leader of the country, he has the constitutional responsibility to appoint boards, including that of KPHL trustee shareholder. “We resolved to respect the Prime Minister’s decision and work with whichever Board he appoints and what has followed since is an internal matter that provincial leaders have no control over,” he said. “People need to act with responsibility and restraint. Sonk is a highly respected professional, known locally and internationally and any actions such as roadblocks, kidnappings, destruction or harassment in his name will only tarnish his reputation. “He has not been terminated, but merely suspended to respond to allegations – a normal process that any managing director, chief executive officer or department head may go through.”

Title: Meganesia concert goes well despite wet weather
Content: THE rain over Port Moresby on Saturday night did not stop city residents from attending the Meganesia concert at the Sir John Guise Stadium. The landmark event brought together an all-Papua New Guinea lineup of artists, featuring the nation’s most celebrated performers including Sprigga Mek, Ragga Siai, Tarvin Toune, Saii Kay, Mal Meninga Kuri, Anslom, DJ Tripple-X, Justin Wellington and Wan Squad. The Meganesia concert was held to celebrate the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. It also brought an end to the national week of celebrations and the start of the country’s 50th year, through the spirit, rhythm, passion and patriotism for Papua New Guinea. Unfortunately, international artist, Nigerian-American singer-songwriter Davido, who was enroute to support and perform alongside the local talent, could not attend due to unforeseen circumstances. Regardless, the energy and enthusiasm of the very best of what PNG’s talent had to offer took to the stage as they were cheered on by the crowd. The eight-hour long show delivered PNG’s signature blend of traditional and contemporary music, showcasing the diversity and vibrancy that defines the nation’s rich cultural landscape. A spectacular display of fireworks ended the night’s peaceful celebrations. All proceeding from the event will go toward heart and cancer centres throughout the country.

Title: ‘Friends to all’ policy remains: Marape
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s “friends to all, enemies to none” foreign policy still remains at the core of the country’s relations with others, Prime Minister James Marape says. “While we have security relations with some countries, we have economic trade with others,” he said. “We can differ in political world views, but humanity must remain as one in unity. “Our governments may be different but every government is there for the betterment of the people. “So in line with our foreign policy, we will remain as friends to all and enemies to none “That is the foundation that sits within the structure of all our foreign relations.” Marape made these remarks at a reception hosted by the Chinese embassy in Port Moresby on Friday. The reception, attended by government officials and members of the diplomatic corps, was held to commemorate the 76th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic of China. Marape congratulated China on such a momentous occasion, stating that relations between the countries were more focused on mutual economic prosperity. He said PNG’s foreign policy was crucial for the development of economic trade and investment with China. “Whilst we have security relations elsewhere, our relations with China remains with trade and businesses. “There have been many generations of Chinese people doing business in PNG. “Looking into the future, we will work more with China in the economic space because when China’s economy prospers, the world will prosper as well,” he said. Ambassador Yang Xiaoguang said China’s aid to PNG over the years has been based on mutual trust with “no political strings attached”.

Title: China issues statement on security agreement
Content: PAPUA New Guinea is tangled up over a security agreement with its closest neighbour Australia as China warned that the agreement should not restrict third parties and undermine the sovereignty of PNG. The Chinese Embassy in Port Moresby said that the Joint Communiqué between Papua New Guinea and Australia on a Mutual Defence Treaty should not be exclusive in nature, nor should it restrict or prevent a sovereign country from cooperating with a third party for any reason. It said that the Chinese side adheres to the principle of non-interference in other countries’ internal affairs, and respect PNG’s right to conclude a bilateral treaty with other countries on a voluntary basis. However, such a treaty should also refrain from targeting any third party or undermining its legitimate rights and interests. China is hoping that the government would continue to uphold independence and self-reliance, properly handle issues bearing on its sovereignty and long-term interests, and work with China to maintain the sound development of China-PNG relations and mutually beneficial cooperation. Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian on Wednesday said that the treaty was seen as strengthening Canberra’s push to curb China’s influence in the region. “Pacific Island countries (PICs), including Papua New Guinea, face top challenges of tackling climate change and accelerating development. China welcomes closer cooperation between PICs and other countries,” he said. “We actively help PICs grow the economy and deliver better lives for their people. “That being said, we believe that cooperation between PICs and any country should put the independence and development of PICs first, uphold openness and inclusiveness, and not target any third party.”

Title: Government commended for
Content: A RETIRED senior public servant and diplomat Joshua Kalinoe has commended the Government for coming up with innovative ideas to strengthen and deepen the defence capabilities of the country, including the proposed cooperation arrangements with Australia through the Pukpuk Treaty. Kalinoe said given the vast land and sea areas, security of PNG’s borders and threats against illegal cross-border activities and cybersecurity as well as the potential of domestic and international terrorism need to be stepped up. He warned, however, that the Government needs to ensure that the purpose and intent of the proposed Defence Treaty is clearly defined and is aligned to PNG’s foreign policy. Further, Papua New Guinea’s national interests and international obligations must be given priority, consideration and context. Kalinoe said the Government recently completed a review of PNG’s foreign policy and the status of the document is not yet known. “Currently, however, the basic thrust of the PNG Foreign Policy is based on the general principle of friends to all and enemy to none which was adopted at independence in 1975,” he said. “This policy thrust was later harmonised to Selective Engagement.” He said if the Pukpuk Defence Treaty is based on the current foreign policy of selective engagement then the proposed treaty is consistent with this policy. “However, given the potential impact the treaty will have on PNG’s national interests and international obligations, it should follow a thorough domestic review and consultative process, including for consistency and compliance with the national Constitution and Parliamentary procedures.”

Title: Deputy Prime Minister Rosso welcomes 166 new citizens
Content: MORE than 160 individuals were presented their citizenships by Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso in Port Moresby on Friday. Of the 166 new citizens, 62 were issued citizenship through naturalisation, while others received dual citizenship from the Immigration and Citizenship Services Authority (ICSA). Rosso, also the Immigration and Border Security Minister in charge of the ICSA, congratulated them for their decision to call PNG home. “You are all Papua New Guineans now,” he said. “As the country recently celebrated its 50th Independence anniversary, we are proud to welcome you all to be a part of our family. “But being a Papua New Guinean citizen also comes with responsibilities that you all must abide by and contribute to the betterment of the country. “I trust that you will all commit yourselves to our country’s values, cultures and Constitution.” Rosso said there was a backlog of citizenship applications that had to be cleared over the last two years, commending the ICSA and citizenship advisory committee for their efforts in awarding the citizenship certificates to the recipients. “The wait has been long for some of you and this event is the final part. “We tried to ensure that the process is stringent but fair, that every person who applied for citizenship was given a fair go at becoming a PNG citizen. “I commend the efforts of the advisory committee in clearing the backlog of applications to ensure that these people receive their certificates,” he said. On behalf of the recipients, Stan Joyce thanked the Government for gifting them such a privilege to be called Papua New Guineans. Joyce, also the City Pharmacy Limited Group chairman, said that as citizens, they each had a responsibility to contribute to the development of the country. He also urged business owners to employ more Papua New Guinean workers as a way of giving back to the country. “This is a great privilege and we all are very humbled to have received our citizenship. “By being granted citizens, we all have made a commitment to the development of this country, especially for the rights and development of the people. “I challenge us all to give the first priority to Papua New Guineans in our jobs and in everything that we do by adopting a PNG-first policy,” he said.

Title: Arob counting extended to October 5
Content: THE counting of votes for the 2025 Autonomous Regiomn of Bougainville (Arob) general election has been extended to Oct 5, with writs to be returned the day after. Counting was originally scheduled to end yesterday and writs would have been returned today. Bougainville Electoral Commissioner Desmond Tsianai said counting had started late due to logistical issues with the transportation of ballot boxes after polling ended on Sept 8. “After polling, ballot boxes were securely transported to the four counting centres, with police providing constant security,” he said. “Due to logistical issues, counting began three days later than expected on September 12 and continues to progress steadily. “This has been a transparent and peaceful election process. “Together, with the patience and commitment of all involved, we will bring this election to a successful conclusion.” Tsianai said that in accordance with sections 146 and 147 of the Bougainville Elections Act, it was necessary to extend the date for the return of writs until Oct 6, allowing the counting of votes to continue until then. He reaffirmed the commitment of his office to completing the counting process transparently and as soon possible. He also extended his gratitude to all electoral officials for their resilience, to candidates and scrutineers for their engagement, and to observers and media for their oversight. Meanwhile, counting for the 38 representative seats for each of the constituencies across the region continues. Counting is yet to start for the regional women representatives and the regional ex-combatants’ representatives for North, South and Central Bougainville seats, including the presidential seat. As of 5pm yesterday, those declared as the members-elect for the constituency seats are Robin Wilson (Barawa), Martin Avoata (Rotokas), Albert Punghau (Motuna Huyono Tokunutui), Fabian Epota Saleu (Torokina), Justine Bonai (Bolave), Melvin Wilolopa (Lato), Lawrence Namusi (Baba), Jason Baranangko (Rau), Lucas Bierepi (Kereaka), Ezekiel Masat (Tonsu), Clarence Dency (Eivo Torau), Junior Tumare (Makis), David Vatavi (Taonita Tinputz), Didymus Napto (Nissan), John Bobby (Baubake), Naphtali Veoriva (Taonita Teop), David Miringtoro (Ioro), Amanda Masono (Atolls), Philip Singkai (Lule), Henry Potabu (North Nasioi) and Luke Karaston (Suir).

Title: Only two mourning houses for late Wenge
Content: DEPUTY Prime Minister John Rosso says there are only two recognisedhauskrais(mourning houses) for the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge in the province, his residence in Hobu and at Sir Igantius Kilage Stadium Indoor complex from today. Rosso said the immediate family has set-up ahauskraiat Hobu, Nawaeb just outside Lae, and the official one would be at the Sir Igantius Kilage Stadium Indoor complex. He said a committee was put together on Thursday to oversee arrangements to ensure that the late leader would be put to rest with the utmost respect. He said no final date had yet been set to bring the governor’s body back to the province. He added that the late Wenge’s body would be in parliament and would be handed over to the provincial government and administration. Rosso said he will be buried at his village in Bainduong, Nawaeb. “It was his wish and we will do everything in our capacity to honour his wish,” he said. “Bainduong is only accessible by air so our first order of business now is to ensure we get materials there to start work on his burial site.” Rosso warned opportunists using the death to scam people and businesses for money. He said they had received reports from various businesses houses of people pretending to be the deputy prime minister and asking forhauskraimoney. Rosso clarified that any information regardinghauskraiand funeral arrangements will be relayed only through his office or provincial administrator Max Bruten’s office. He appealed to the people to respect their leader.

Title: Caution over importation of explosives
Content: POLICE commissioner David Manning has issued a caution to any person or business seeking to import fireworks, flares and other explosive items without required legal clearance. Manning said police, working with the Papua New Guinea Customs Service, has received numerous applications for the import and movement of explosive items that could potentially be misused if not properly controlled and safeguarded. “If not professionally transported, stored and managed, fireworks pose a risk to public safety, and in the wrong hands can be used to kill people or attack property,” Manning said in a statement. “The number of applications to import fireworks, flares and other explosive devices has increased substantially over the past year. “Police will not rubberstamp applications for civilian explosives that can easily end up in tribal conflicts and criminal activities. “There are also issues of overall public safety in the way that these explosives are safely transported and stored so as to reduce risk to public safety and potential theft. “We cannot run the risk of explosives being transported improperly through public spaces, or stored in where they could incidentally be set off or stolen.” Manning has provided standardised policy guidance for applicants seeking endorsement to import pyrotechnics (fireworks). “To enhance public safety and ensure pyrotechnics are imported for appropriate purposes only, and are properly handled, a heightened level of due diligence is in effect. “To ensure efficient consideration, applicants are advised to have the right documentation submitted for consideration,” Manning said. “There must be a fully completed import application form submitted before the explosives arrive in the country. “We must have copies of necessary licences and permits issued in accordance with the Explosives Act. “Information must be provided with details as to whether pyrotechnics are intended for a specific event or programme, and details of that event. “Further, there must be evidence of training for the applicant or their staff in the safe handling and use of pyrotechnics, and suitable insurance arrangements in place. “The provision of complete documentation will assist in the assessment of applications. “Upon receipt of completed request information, applications will be reviewed for endorsement by the RPNGC and PNG Customs. “The bottom line is that fireworks are explosive devices, and should only be managed by properly trained individuals in the interests of public safety.”

Title: Police get assets funded through special infrastructure initiatives
Content: DEPUTY police commissioner (special operations) Donald Yamasombi yesterday received keys to two houses and an armoury from Arepesh Construction for the Dog Unit at Bomana. Yamasombi said for the houses it was a token of appreciation from the contractor who has worked alongside the force. “Over the years and in many projects that we have in the organisation, we don’t have people who come forward with such token of appreciation. “It’s something that will stay with us for years to come,” Yamasombi said. He said the constabulary had a programme called the Special Police Assistance programme (Spap) which caters for funding for police infrastructure. The two houses were renovated at a cost of K150,000 by the contractor. The fencing and armoury were funded under the Spap. He said so far they have rolled out some programmes at the outside centres to rehabilitate infrastructure for the police force. “For the National Capital District in 2023, the police headquarters gave funding for the fencing to secure the barracks, but out of their own pockets, the contractor changed the design of the fencing and did a better one. “It’s costly and it’s secure. With the fencing comes the armoury. “We have the firearms and ammunition we carry around but we don’t secure them properly.” Yamasombi said the dog unit is privileged to have such assets which also includes three new vehicles that were recently presented to them. “Look after these assets, they don’t come easy,” he said. “Receive the things with a good heart and take good care of them.”

Title: Patient safety is everyone’s business: WHO
Content: PATIENT safety is the business of everyone in the health practice and should begin at birth and continue every step of the way, an official says. World Health Organisation (WHO) PNG acting representative Dr Josaia Tiko said this during the Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH) Independence celebrations in conjunction with World Patient Safety Day in Port Moresby on Friday. “Children are some of the most vulnerable patients in any health system as their small bodies developing immune systems and complete dependency on adults, mean that any small mistake in care can have devastating consequences as you observe from day to day,” he said. “We also know that social factors such as poverty, lack of education or living in remote areas can increase the risks children face in getting safe and timely care.” Tiko said unfortunately adverse events still happen far too often in patient care. He said these events include diagnostic errors, medication mistakes, delays in treatment and breakdown in communication between providers and families. “Therefore, WHO calls on all of us, governments, policy makers, health care workers, facility managers, parents and teachers to take action in terms of patient care,” he said. Tiko added that the same attention and resources must also be given to those children and adults living with disabilities. He stressed that these challenges must be addressed if everyone is serious about achieving equitable and safe healthcare for all and also healthy nation. Deputy chairman of the PMGH board Katherine Johnson, the PMGH staff that   commemorated the country’s 50th independence anniversary, they must also raise the standard in health in the hospital. “Our nation is only as strong as the health of its people, and patient safety is not just a medical concern, it is a national imperative,” she added. Johnson acknowledged all the staff and management of PMGH and their work and make patients’ safety a culture and part of their daily decision. She also challenged them to speak up for safety, encourage patients to ask questions, share concerns and be active partner on in their care.

Title: Prince Edward says robust judiciary crucial
Content: PRINCE Edward, the Duke of Edinburgh, who visited the new Waigani National Court Complex on the country’s 50th Independence Day, described the building as a “splendid replacement”. “It is quite appropriate standing here today, marking 50 years of this nation’s independence, in front of the judiciary, because an independent and robust judiciary is important in a thriving democracy,” Prince Edward said. “It is a pleasure to see the development that has taken place here with the new courts and following in my mother’s footsteps with the old court building,” he said. He told those who attended to witness him unveil a plaque that the roles of those that went before and those that were to come after were incredibly important. He said that the building and the courts were used for the purposes that they were designed for and nothing else. As part of his royal visit to the country, he was asked to visit the court complex to unveil the plaque. He said he was not sure what the plaque would signify. “The thing is, the unveiling of a plaque is not necessarily the most exciting thing that has happened in our lives. It may not signify the opening of the building but would signify something quite important,” he said. He was escorted by Governor General Sir Bob Dadae and Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika, who took him on a tour inside the new court complex. Prince Edward wished all lawyers, judges, and court users to use the building with their best.

Title: Understand constitution, public told
Content: PAPUA New Guineans have been reminded to turn to the Constitution to address much of the development challenges that have been affecting the country. Constitutional and Law Reform Commission (CLRC) secretary Dr Mange Matui said the Constitution needed to be better understood as it was the compass for all law-making, governance and national development. “The challenges ahead for the country are immense, from globalisation, climate change, digital transformation, overpopulation and cultural changes, we all have to face these collectively as one people,” he said. “Our Independence in 1975 was not merely a political event; it was a profound act of faith. “It was a declaration that the people of Papua New Guinea had the wisdom, courage, and capacity to govern ourselves. “These values were so noble, pure and timeless that, they were what guided the creation of the Constitution and they permeated throughout the Constitution. “Today, the Constitution guides government bodies, including the CLRC, to implement their activities in alignment with the requirements of the National Goals and Directive Principles, serving as a moral and policy compass for law-making, governance, and national development,” Matui said. He made these remarks during the CLRC’s gala dinner to commemorate the country’s 50th Independence Anniversary in Port Moresby on Monday. A picture book of the commission, highlighting its achievements since its establishment in 2004, was also launched. Matui said the CLRC played an integral part in nation-building, adding that their work was similar to that of doctors saving the lives of people. “When a medical doctor begins with a patient, the first thing he or she does is feel the pulse,” he said. “From that simple act, they can tell whether the body is healthy or in need of care. “In the same way, the CLRC performs that critical role of finding the pulse of our society. “Where the law is weak, outdated or unresponsive, we prescribe treatment through reforms that restore relevance, fairness, and justice. “We will continue to feel the pulse of our society, diagnosing its needs, and prescribing reforms that keep our democracy healthy.”

Title: Markham unveils plaque to celebrate 50th independence anniversary
Content: MARKHAM unveiled a 50th anniversary memory stone during its Sept 16 celebrations at Mutzing Station on Tuesday. Markham MP Koni Iguan unveiled the memory stone as a reminder to the upcoming generation to break free from poverty and laziness. “Let’s break free Markham, break away from laziness and our continuous complaints about governmental services,” Iguan said. “We have a rich land and the national highway running through our hearts.” He urged the people to do things for themselves and their families and not wait for the government. “You must tell yourself that, I can do it, if the government cannot do it, I can do it for myself and my family. “Let’s change for the next 50 years as Wednesday is the first day of our next 50 years’ journey. “Go home to your wife and family and tell them that you will break free from the past, poverty and laziness,” Iguan said. He said Markham has had a significant contribution in the road to independence and afterwards through its leaders. “The first Chief Minister was Tom Leah and he was the member for Markham that time,” Iguan said. “We can see how far we have come and many more opportunities being available to us that this country can advance into the future.” Iguan said that the problem we had in our country was holding back due to our past which was a hindrance to our prosperous future. “Now going forward for the next 50 years, we have to break free from the mentality of waiting for free handouts and laziness and start doing some things for ourselves and our families. He said that the memory stone unveiled at the Mutzing station arena had the pictures of all 10 serving members of Markham district and the founding father of our country, Sir Michael Somare. Markham district commemorated the 50th Independence anniversary with a three-day show consisting of all Christian denominations, schools and the four regions of PNG under the theme: break free.

Title: PM thanks leaders, representatives for joining in celebrations
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape thanked international leaders, delegations, and diplomatic partners who travelled to Papua New Guinea to share in the nation’s 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations. He said the overwhelming support demonstrated PNG’s growing role as a nation of global significance. “Never before in our history have so many foreign leaders and dignitaries gathered with us to celebrate our independence. This was the biggest number of international delegates since 1975, and I thank each and every one of our partners for standing with PNG as we marked this historic milestone,” Marape said. He highlighted the presence of United Nations secretary-General António Guterres, who spent four days in Port Moresby, as a symbol of PNG’s rising international profile. He noted that leaders from across the Pacific, Asia, Australia, New Zealand, Europe, and other regions attended the golden jubilee celebrations, underscoring PNG’s strong and diverse network of friendships. Marape said these partnerships were not only political, but also economic and people-centred as indicated in the following. “Foreign relations for me are not just about diplomacy. At their heart must be commerce and trade. Every nation we engage with must also be a partner in growing our economy and opening doors for our people,” he said.

Title: Unity during Independence celebrations impresses Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has expressed heartfelt gratitude to everyone for coming together in unity to celebrate the nation’s 50th Independence Anniversary, describing the occasion as one of the most joyous moments of his life. Reflecting on the week’s Golden Jubilee celebrations, he said he was moved to witness Papua New Guineans rallying under one flag. “I’ve lived the last 50 years and witnessed every Independence day since 1975. But this year, marking our 50th, was different,” he said. “The joy came from deep within my heart as I saw our people, everywhere, celebrating under one flag – the PNG flag. This truly consolidates our identity as one nation, one people, one country,” he said. He noted that unlike previous celebrations, there was no display of provincial flags during this year’s milestone commemoration. “For the first time, there was no evidence of other provincial flags. “Our people came together under the national flag, which gave me renewed hope for our future,” he said. He highlighted the symbolic performance by children from Bougainville, who sang songs of forgiveness, healing, and togetherness, as a powerful reminder of the higher calling of unity that the nation must embrace. He urged Papua New Guineans not to confine their sense of patriotism to Independence Day alone. “There is always a Sept 17, Sept 18, and all the days that follow. Independence is not just about the 16th – it is about what we do afterwards.”

Title: Marape urges Sonk to clear his name from allegations of financial dealings with a law firm
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has urged suspended Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited managing director Wapu Sonk to clear his name following serious allegations of financial dealings with a law firm levelled against him. Marape said the allegations were brought up by the board which resulted in Sonk’s suspension. He said the allegations include financial dealings with a law firm representing the former board, using company resources in legal matters against the current board and trustee shareholder (Marape), and ongoing allegations reported in international media. “These matters must be addressed openly and properly,” Marape said. “I respect the professional contributions of Sonk over the years. This is just a due process and if he rises above this and proves his innocence by suing the media organisation that revealed impropriety against him, then I am sure the board will consider his innocence, but he must take the responsibility to prove his innocence. “The integrity of the company is bigger than any individual, including myself and I can understand why the board took this position. “It is now incumbent upon him to clear his name and respond to these allegations. He said the board was appointed to look at the company, and the managing director has been in the company for a long time, so he has nothing to fear if he is totally innocent. “This process will help him clear his name once and for all as a professional son of the country,” Marape said. Marape reiterated his confidence in the independence of the board and the rule of law. “The board has done its job, and now it is up to the suspended managing director to do his part by clearing these allegations. “My government will always respect the rule of law and the independence of boards to carry out their functions. “We will never compromise governance for politics. Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited belongs to the people of Papua New Guinea, and it must always serve them with integrity, transparency, and accountability.” Marape said KPHL should operate with integrity and in line with the laws of the country. “Kumul Petroleum is not a family company, not a tribal company, and not a provincial company. It is a company that belongs to the people of Papua New Guinea, for the benefit of every citizen,” Marape said. “As the trustee shareholder on behalf of the people, my role is to ensure that proper governance and legal processes are followed at all times.”

Title: Police, PNGDF send reinforcement into Nipa following unrest over Sonk’s suspension
Content: POLICE and the Papua New Guinea Defence Force have sent personnel into Nipa-Kutubu in Southern Highlands, to reinforce security following an unrest over the suspension of Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited managing director Wapu Sonk. Police Commissioner David Manning said about 70 Mobile Squad personnel from Port Moresby and an additional manpower from the Papua New Guinea Defence Force based in Tari, Hela were on the way to Nipa to provide security. This follows the disruption of services on Friday in Nipa by people supporting Sonk. Manning said Sonk was a citizen who had access to the justice system but that access should be done in a responsible manner. “I understand we have tribes, communities and families but no one is above the law,” Manning said. “What is a decision that affects an individual should not compel tribesmen or relatives to take matters into their own hands, basically breaking the law.” Manning said the unrest in Nipa was under investigation.

Title: Police give Sonk deadline to pick suspension notice following death threats
Content: POLICE commissioner David Manning have given suspended managing director of Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited Wapu Sonk until 4pm Friday to pick up his suspension notice from the board or police will step in. Manning said police have been engaged following security threats issued against the board and acting managing director Luke Liria “The board were not about to sit by and have those threats being issued,” Manning said. Manning said police were investigating death threats against the board following Sonk’s suspension. He said police were also investigating the spill-over effects in Southern Highlands with reports of protests and destruction to properties. KPHL board chairman Gerea Aopi said the board decision on Friday allowed Sonk space to ‘address his personal issues’. “As a new board we look forward to working with the KPHL management but the cloud of allegations hanging over managing director, Wapu Sonk, must be cleared transparently and expeditiously, hence the board resolution. Meanwhile, Southern Highlands Governor William Powi said Sonk’s suspension was an insult to the people Nipa-Kutubu and Southern Highlands. He warned that the people of Southern Highlands would not take this matter lightly. “As Governor of Southern Highlands Province, I find this decision unacceptable. It disrespects the contributions of our province to the nation’s economy,” Powi said. Sonk was appointed managing director of the National Petroleum Company of PNG in January 2013. He held onto his position when the company was renamed to Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited in 2015. Sonk has occupied numerous leadership roles in the Petroleum Industry of PNG since beginning his career with Chevron Niugini in 1997. Some notable roles include the Director – PNG LNG Project – IPBC in 2012 and chairperson of Society of Petroleum Engineers (PNG Section) in 2011.

Title: Powi says Sonk’s suspension is an ‘insult to the people of Southern Highlands’
Content: THE suspension of Wapu Sonk as Kumul Petroleum Holdings Limited (KPHL) managing director is an insult to the people of Southern Highlands, Governor William Powi says. Powi warned that the people of Southern Highlands would not take this matter lightly. KPHL chairman Gerea Aopi said the board suspended Sonk on Friday to protect the integrity of the board and management. “As a new board we look forward to working with the KPHL management but the cloud of allegations hanging over managing director, Wapu Sonk, must be cleared transparently and expeditiously, hence the board resolution,” Aopi said. KPHL’s executive general manager external affairs Luke Liria has been appointed acting managing director. Powi said the decision was not only unjust but cruel. “Sonk is a faithful and loyal servant of the State, a distinguished professional, and one of the finest chief executive officers this country has produced,” he said. “He is a proud son of Nipa-Kutubu and a Southern Highlands man who has diligently served the interests of both the government and the people of Papua New Guinea,” Powi said. Powi said the decision was a direct insult to the people of Southern Highlands, particularly those from Nipa-Kutubu, who played a pivotal role in the success of the PNG LNG Project. “As Governor of Southern Highlands Province, I find this decision unacceptable. It disrespects the contributions of our province to the nation’s economy and undermines the role of our people who, through our Provincial Government and landowner entities, hold a 4.27 percent Kroton Equity stake in the PNG LNG Project,” he said.

Title: Wages to rise. Minimum-wage earners expect pay rise from K3.50 to K5.50
Content: MINIMUM-WAGE earners can expect a pay increase with a new rate of K5 per hour to come into effect from Jan 1 next year. Minimum Wages Board chairman Beverly Doiwa said in a statement that the increase from the current K3.50 per hour, in force since 2014, was the outcome of a nationwide consultation which started last year to address the challenges facing the country’s workforce. “The board has determined a new minimum wage of K5 per hour from the date of gazettal, to come into force by Jan 1, 2026 – from the previous rate of K3.50,” she said. “The rate will be implemented through a staggered increase – rising to K5.25 in January 2027, and then to K5.50 in January 2028. “This phased approach is designed to ease the transition for employers. “We’re confident this new rate will provide relief for workers and their families, ensuring a fair and just wage reflecting economic realities, while mindful of business sustainability. “This decision was a result of a comprehensive review and a balancing act of various factors as outlined in the Minimum Wages Board’s terms of reference (TOR).” The TOR were to: Doiwa said the board’s inquiry found that the 2014 minimum wage was insufficient to sustain workers against the rising cost of living. “We received compelling submissions from workers, civil society, and unions detailing the daily struggles faced by low-income families to afford basic necessities,” she said. “We also heard from employers, particularly small-to-medium enterprises, about the economic pressures they face, including a stagnant economy and rising operational costs.” Doiwa said the grey economy was growing where some employers were taking advantage of regulatory gap caused by weak enforcement and oversight.

Title: Betraying Sir Mekere: Trade union says transferring public accounts will betray Sir Mek’s reforms
Content: THE Government’s decision to transfer all public accounts from the Bank South Pacific Financial Group Limited (BSP) to the National Banking Corporation (NBC) should be discussed further, according to a trade union. Papua New Guinea Banks and Financial Institutions Workers Union president Killie Sapu-Keari described the Government’s move as an attack on the integrity of PNG’s financial sector and a betrayal of the reforms instituted by the late Sir Mekere Morauta. “(They were) reforms that strengthened the economy, protected workers’ superannuation funds, and shielded the nation’s wealth from political exploitation,” she said. “This reckless move will have far-reaching consequences, with a direct impact on dividends for Nasfund shareholders, plus thousands of ordinary Papua New Guinean workers who rely on these funds for their retirement security. “The Government appears to have no appreciation of the economic and social fallout of its decision. “Rather than building financial stability, private sector growth, and employment creation, this action undermines investor confidence and jeopardises the health of PNG’s financial ecosystem.” Sapu-Keari said that BSP, through its rural banking network and community-based agents, had already taken steps to reach the unbanked population. “The claim that this decision will solve issues of financial inclusion and high fees is a dangerous pretence. “Instead of empowering SMEs – the backbone of job creation – government policies have imposed excessive IPA fees, uncompetitive tax regimes, and burdensome compliance costs that actively discourage entrepreneurship. “The very manufacturers and businesses employing Papua New Guineans are also being squeezed, threatening jobs and economic growth.” Sapu-Keari said investor confidence had already been shaken when PNG faced the possibility of being grey-listed due to its lack of effective and technical compliance with international Anti-Money Laundering (AML) and Counter-Terrorism Financing (CTF) standards. “If the Government is serious about financial reform, it must strengthen the policing framework for existing AML/CTF policies and begin holding people to account. “Policies that look good on paper but lack enforcement will not protect the nation. Until there is a demonstrated commitment to compliance and governance, the government is not ready to run its own bank.”

Title: Bertha Somare urges cultural pride at 50th anniversary
Content: THE late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare’s dream of a united Papua New Guinea is evident today as people from different cultures live with others in provinces around the country, says Bertha Somare. The eldest daughter of Sir Michael was the chief guest at the 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations in Kimbe, West New Britain on Tuesday. She said that her father always believed that people must always be proud of their cultures. “My father was always proud of his culture and also saw the beauty in all the diverse cultures of the country,” she said. “Every time he went back to his home in East Sepik, he would always honour his traditions. “His traditional customs and beliefs kept him grounded.
