It taught him humility and respect. “This is why we must protect our culture as we are living in a time of rapid change.” Somare urged the people to follow the footsteps of Sir Michael and other founding fathers. “The independence and freedom we have today was given to us because of our forefathers,” she said. “But this also comes with responsibilities. “We must follow the ways they lived as the rights they have given us ensure that we make the country a better place for one another.” West New Britain Governor Sasindran Muthuvel called on the people to change their attitudes. “Fifty years ago, our forefathers stood with hope as the PNG flag was raised for the first time,” he said. “Today, we stand on their shoulders and our children will stand on ours.”

Title: Bougainville counting continuing with several winners declared
Content: THE counting of votes for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government general election has started with several winners being declared. Counting is expected to end on Sunday (Sept 21) and writs will be returned on Monday (Sept 22). Bougainville Electoral Commissioner Desmond Tsianai said counting started on Thursday at three centres in the region. Counting has started for the 38 representative seats for each of the constituencies in the region. Counting is yet to start for the regional women representatives and the regional ex-combatants’ representatives for North, South and Central Bougainville respectively, plus the presidential seat. As of 5pm yesterday, those declared as the members-elect for their constituency seats are Robin Wilson (Barawa), Martin Avoata (Rotokas), Albert Punghau (Motuna Huyono Tokunutui), Fabian Epota Saleu (Torokina), Justine Bonai (Bolave), Melvin Wilolopa (Lato), Lawrence Namusi (Baba), Jason Baranangko (Rau), Lucas Bierepi (Kereaka), and Ezekiel Masat (Tonsu). “The presidential ballots will be counted at the centre in Buka, while the other seats will be counted at regional counting centres in North, Central, and South Bougainville,” Tsianai said. “The Office of the Bougainville Electoral Commissioner aims to complete counting and return the writs by Sept 22. “Observers, scrutineers, and the media will be able to observe counting, in line with protocols. This election is a milestone for Bougainville as we elect our fifth Parliament. It shows how deeply Bougainvilleans care about our democracy. “We should be proud of how far we’ve come, and in unity and respect, we will continue building a stronger democratic future.”

Title: Sepik peace cyclists celebrate independence in Port Moresby
Content: SIXTEEN cyclists from East Sepik on a mission to promote peace have arrived in Port Moresby in time for the 50th Independence anniversary celebrations. The members of the East Sepik Cycling Movement arrived on Monday after travelling through 11 provinces. Club president Jethro Ani said that their six-week journey was to promote peaceful celebrations and national unity. “We traveled to also celebrate the legacies by founding father Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare and others for uniting the nation by traveling through 11 provinces in the Highlands, Momase and Southern,” he said “It was a tough journey through rugged terrain, but we had a purpose which brought us this far. “Some of the bikers fell sick, our bikes broke down along the way, but we managed to get help, fix our bikes, and reached Port Moresby.” Ani said they used to travel around East Sepik and West Sepik and Madang conducting awareness on law and order issues and sports. He urged young people in Wewak to refrain from illegal activities and be productive. “One of our own was behind independence, so we need to change our attitude, be united, and be a good example to others,” he said. They hope to also talk to the PNG Sports Federation to recognise cycling as a sports in PNG.

Title: International RnB superstar Akon urges PNG to dream big
Content: AMERICAN singer, RnB rapper and song writer Aliaune Thiam, famously known as Akon, took to the stage at the Sir John Guise Stadium on Wednesday in an unforgettable performance. The stadium packed to its capacity as Akon sang his first song Beautiful Day. During his bridge into one of his songs, he said they celebrated 50 years of independence in Senegal, West Africa in May. “But I want to tell you in that journey it’s going to take a lot more unity to be in the next level,” he said. “It’s going to take the next generation to take us to the next level and I want you to know in the process you will make mistakes but it’s all about how you deal with it and I know I was one of those kids that trouble followed me but I never stopped trying. “So you feel my pain and you will never stop trying. I remember coming from Africa to America chasing a dream. We have a long road.” Some of the songs he sang wereSmack That, Don’t Matter, Beautiful, Dangerous, Danza Kuduro, I Tried So Hard, Sorry, Blame It On Me, I Just Had Sex, Lonely, I Wanna Love You, It’s Been So Long, Right Now, Be with YouandFreedomthat had everyone reliving childhood memories from primary school days. He was later joined on stage by female artist Amirror. Local artists who performed before him were DadiiGii, DeSiZ and his crew and Mereani Masani. All proceedings to the all heart and cancer centres through the country. Akon departed Port Moresby yesterday.

Title: Wau-Waria prioritises road, communication and land access
Content: WAU Waria development authority (DDA) is setting its focus on road network, communication and land access to ensure basic services are delivered to the people, says an official. Adding onto those areas, MP Marsh Narawec said the other important areas are electricity and law and order. The DDA is targeting road links where rehabilitation and building of roads started two-and-a-half years ago. “With the district Works division on hand now, we are working on road links to rural areas in the district as only through this initiative, can the people have access to other services,” Narawec said. He said in terms of communication, the DDA is committed to ensuring that all communities in the rural areas of the district are connected with effective, fast and reliable mobile networks. Currently, a multi-purpose communication tower has been erected at a location at Biaru, and is fully equipped with necessary communication systems which will be launched in the near future. “We are confident to erect the same communication towers in the other two LLGs as well to make communication easier in remote locations in the district,” Narawec said. With regard to land accessibility for development purposes, Narawec said the DDA is planning to assist landowners with the registration of incorporated land groups (ILGs) for the district so that local people can take part effectively in development aspects. “We want to as much as possible protect the rights of landowners to their land and at the same time assist them to effectively participate in any development taking place in their respective locations.” Narawec further mentioned that what the DDA is looking at now is aimed at getting the people effectively involved in their own developmental and economical aspects.

Title: Exciting Bulolo Show livens up crowd
Content: BULOLO hosted its fourth cultural show this past week at St Steven’s Primary School, in line with Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary. Local MP Sam Basil Jr said the 2025 Bulolo Show was not only a highlight of the district’s calendar but also an opportunity to showcase Bulolo’s identity and development potential. “This show was like a mini Morobe Show where we had skydivers jump off a chopper with the PNG and Bulolo flag and fireworks display during the night on Tuesday,” he said. Show committee chairman Yemon Bisa said the event went beyond entertainment. “It celebrated the district’s legacy in gold mining, forestry, coffee and tea production, while also providing a platform for emerging industries such as apiculture and coffee processing,” he said. “The Bulolo Show was more than just an event. It was a celebration of our people, our achievements and our future. “We showcased the talent, culture and enterprise of our communities while inspiring the next generation to contribute to the district’s growth.” The two-day show, which was hosted on Sept 16-17, featured cultural dances, agricultural displays, exhibitions and sporting activities. It also promoted small businesses, tourism, and the district’s campaign to declare Bulolo town a national heritage site. One of the highlights came on day two when the Royal Engineering Battalion from Igam Barracks staged a dramatic mock battle. The soldiers demonstrated tactical skills, discipline and teamwork in a simulated battlefield scenario that thrilled the crowd while also educating them on the vital role of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force in maintaining security. According to Bisa, more than 500 people participated in the show. Basil added that the show was a chance for Bulolo to reflect on its proud history while also looking forward to future development.

Title: Tomuriesa raises concerns over Australia-PNG defence treaty
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa raised concerns about sovereignty, constitutionality, indemnities, law and order, and how a defence treaty between PNG and Australia agreement will be governed in practice. Tomuriesa, in a statement on Wednesday, said: “Any arrangement that allows foreign forces to operate on PNG soil, recruit our citizens, or integrate closely with our Defence Force has potential sovereignty implications. “Sovereignty is not just symbolic: it concerns who exercises legal authority, who is accountable when things go wrong, and whether PNG’s right to make independent decisions is preserved.” Tomuriesa said these questions must be addressed transparently and in line with PNG’s Constitution and the oversight roles of Parliament and the judiciary. “Recent coverage indicates the agreement will deepen integration and offers pathways for PNG nationals to serve in the Australian Defence Force – which makes these sovereignty questions urgent,” he said. Tomuriesa also said treaties that affect defence and domestic security raised constitutional issues. “For legitimacy and public confidence, the treaty should be tabled in Parliament, debated publicly, and if necessary referred to the Supreme Court for any constitutional questions,” he said. “We should also require clear implementing legislation so responsibilities and limits are spelled out in PNG law, not left solely to executive agreements.” Treaties sometimes create special status provisions for foreign soldiers, Tomuriesa added. “If personnel are given immunity from local prosecution, victims can be denied justice – as happened in other countries’ disputes over visiting forces arrangements,” he said. “The treaty must not create blanket immunities that undermine PNG’s criminal jurisdiction. “Examples show that immunity or unclear status arrangements can become major political flashpoints. “PNG needs strong partnerships, but not at the cost of our constitutional authority, legal protections for our citizens, or independent decision-making. “I would welcome cooperation that strengthens our Defence Force, but only with binding safeguards.”

Title: Police post burning mars celebrations
Content: CELEBRATIONS of the 50th independence anniversary in Kainantu, Eastern Highlands were marred by the burning of a police post and looting of two shops. Eastern Highlands provincial police commander Chief Supt John Kale said members of the public went on a rampage and burnt the police post near the Kainantu – Aiyura junction and broke into and looted two Asian shops on Wednesday. He said some opportunists who had differences with police attacked the police post amid public frustration over the funding of the staging the anniversary celebrations in Kainantu. “The Kainantu District Development Authority was accused by the public for not supporting them to stage independence celebrations and went on a rampage, causing destruction to the police post and looting of the shops,” Supt Kale said. He appealed to leaders in Kainantu to surrender suspects of the rampage. Kale said any public funding from the Government must be used to help people celebrate and enjoy the special anniversary. “I condemned the actions of the public and urged those with political interests to put aside their differences. “If you want to contest in the election, the 2027 election is around the corner, wait instead of using such situations to disturb peace and harmony,” Kale said. “Apart from these incidents, other districts had peaceful celebrations including the Goroka Show event that coincided with the independence anniversary.” Meanwhile, Kainantu MP William Hagauno said the peaceful independence anniversary celebrations in Kainantu were disturbed by drunk members of the public. “The 50th anniversary celebrations in Kainantu districts were done in village communities where the people are found most of the time, it went smoothly and ended peacefully,” he said. Hagauno said the people enjoyed the celebrations hosted by district organising committee using the money the Government allocated. “The organising committee shared the money equally to every corner of the district, they hosted peaceful celebrations like every district in PNG. “It was around 4.30pm when I came back from Ayanontu Primary School in Bilimoia area of Agarabi local level government when a fight broke out in Kainantu,” he said. Hagahauno said he waited at Three Mile near Kainantu until tensions eased before he came into town. He was assisted by the police. He said police could not do much because they were outnumbered, the rampage in town triggered at the music concert by drunken men that led to the burning of the police post and the break-in and looting of the Asian shops. He said there were two separate celebrations hosted in Kainantu town, the main programme at the Peace Park was peaceful until someone with political interest hosted a music show that attracted drunken public to caused nuisance. Hagauno named the person behind the musical concert and blamed him for being responsible for causing the mayhem. “I earlier told the police to stop the man from hosting the concert but they failed,” Hagauno said. “The violence was caused by drunken men, drug addicts and people with political intentions to disrupt the celebrations and paint a bad image of me,” he said.

Title: SDP partners NBC to boost radio coverage in Western
Content: THE PNG Sustainable Development Programme (SDP) has partnered the National Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) to restore radio transmission across Western following an agreement signing. SDP will provide K1.8 million support for the restoration of NBC’s radio equipment in Daru to extend transmission to other parts of South and Delta Fly using its relay towers, aiming to re-establish FM radio services in the province to deliver information to remote communities after this service ceased in 2016. NBC will provide engineering support by installing equipment on the SDP towers, after which the equipment will be fully owned by NBC once the total project cost is repaid through allocated radio airtime to SDP. SDP chief executive Lesieli Taviri said the partnership marked a major step forward in revitalising public broadcasting services in Western to ensure that every community can be informed. “SDP’s priorities in health, education and livelihoods all have a communication element which will be supported with this partnership once radio service is re-established in Western,” she said. “This investment by SDP also complements a priority of the provincial government of ensuring communication to the entire province.” NBC managing director Kora Nou said the tower-sharing arrangement would re-establish and extend NBC’s radio coverage throughout the province with plans for digital television.

Title: Sealing begins in Telefomin
Content: ROAD sealing started on 50th annivesary day for the Telefomin Station. Works and Highways Minister and Telefomin MP Solan Mirisim said this signified the start of the township plan launched by Prime Minister James Marape on Friday. The road-sealing started from the administration office and will go 9km around the station. The construction is by China Railway Construction and will take until the month’s end for completion. “This is a way forward for the next 50 years,” Mirisim said. “We will have to (extend) infrastructure development into the next 50 years. “It starts today (Sept 16), where Telefomin seeks to be a model district in Papua New Guinea. “This shows that we are serious about bringing change to the people and a start to thetownship plan in the next few years. “By 2027, we should have all services in place and an extension in business and professional engagement to the district.” Mirisim encouraged the people to take make use and protect infrastructure in the district.

Title: Increasing youth population threatening stability, says Kapavore
Content: EAST New Britain’s Pomio MP and Minister for Health Elias Kapavore has stressed that the increasing youth population remains one of the biggest challenges facing the Government. “One of the biggest challenges for our country today is the youth bulge,” he said. “Over 60 per cent of Papua New Guinea’s population is made up of people below the age of 25, placing immense pressure on the government to provide education and employment opportunities. “This is a serious problem for us.” Kapavore noted that the Government was working to find ways to cater for the fast-growing youth population. “Not everyone will make it into tertiary institutions. That’s why we need to look for alternatives,” he said. Kapavore announced that plans are underway to build a technical school in Pomio to help address the issue. He also reminded people of Pomio about development plans for the district, particularly at Palmalmal Station. He warned illegal settlers to vacate State land marked for development. “Under the law, you cannot build your house on someone else’s land,” he said. “You must obey the law.” Kapavore urged the people to respect authority and uphold good citizenship. “Obedience and respect have always been a part of us. Let us go back to those ways,” he said. The Pomio MP further appealed to leaders to be responsible with their use of social media, noting that certain content could provoke negative reactions among young people. “We must lead our youths in the right manner,” he said.

Title: Walium police get new vehicle
Content: POLICE operations in Walium have received a boost with the arrival of a new patrol vehicle aimed at improving law and order in Usino-Bundi. The vehicle was first presented by Northern commander, assistant police commissioner Peter Guinness, in Lae on Sept 12. It was handed over to Walium Police Station Commander Chief Sgt James Kewas on Saturday by new MP Vincent Kumura. Kumura stressed on his administration’s commitment to tackling crime and strengthening law enforcement as a top priority. “This vehicle will help police respond faster, patrol the Usino-Bundi Highway and improve community safety,” Kumura said. He noted Walium headquarters’ strategic location which connects Ramu Nickel Mine, Ramu Agri Industries and the highway into Madang. He said however, law-and-order issues had discouraged tourism and investment in the district. “We are working to restore confidence so that business and tourism can grow again,” he said. Kumura also appealed to the community to work closely with police and respect the law, while emphasising that the vehicle be used responsibly. “It is taxpayer-funded and cannot be used for personal purposes – no alcohol, no tinted windows, and no misuse will be allowed,” Kumura warned, echoing Guinness’ earlier instructions. Kewas added that the vehicle would strengthen police mobility and visibility; community leaders at the ceremony said they hoped the new vehicle would mark the start of more regular police patrols and a stronger partnership between residents and law enforcement. Earlier that week, Kumura was sworn in by Magistrate Stanley Bino in front of his people at the district headquarters in Walium. He was accompanied by Madang rural commander Chief Insp Peter Gorek. Kumura appealed to his constituents to strive for unity, maintain humility, and have shared responsibility. He convened a special district meeting to talk to his sector heads and community leaders. “We will walk together, plan together, and build together,” Kumura said.

Title: Kairuku marks independence, LLGs celebrate
Content: YULE Island in Central’s Kairuku became the location for the district’s main independence celebrations. Clusters from all three local level government (LLG) areas of Kairuku, Mekeo and Kuni converged on the island, taking part in marching, traditional singsings, live band performances and more. Yule Island is also the place on which the country’s flag was designed. Hence, making the event more special, a first-of-its-kind flag festival was launched. During the launch, Kairuku MP Peter Isoaimo said it was only fitting for the flag festival and the 50th independence celebrations to be held on Yule Island. Isoaimo said that he cut the ribbon on behalf of the Minister for Arts, Culture and Tourism Belden Namah. “Today marks the beginning of the Papua New Guinea flag festival. It is going to be a tourism product for Kairuku district. “It will be held annually with funding support from the Tourism Promotion Authority. “We commemorate the festival today here because of the significance of the golden jubilee anniversary and that it is the rightful birthplace of the flag back in 1972 by students of the OLSH technical school,” Isoaimo said. “The flag festival in the future will bring many tourism and economic benefits to Yule Island and the people of Kairuku.” Isoaimo announced that in the following years, the plan is to host it on July 3 every year to coincide with the next day July 4 which is the pilgrimage mass to commemorate the anniversary of the first missionaries who arrived in 1885.

Title: Boera villagers re-enact Hiri trade
Content: AS the custodians and founders of the Hiri trade, the people of Boera village in Central celebrated the 50th Independence anniversary with the re-enactment of the Hiri trade. Students from Boera Primary School played out the story of Edai Siabo, the legendary figure from Boera, who was credited for initiating the Hiri trade cycle. According to oral tradition, Siabo was taught the principles of the trade by a giant eel spirit, which he then used to build the very first lagatoi (a large canoe) named Bogebada and embarked on the inaugural Hiri voyage to the Gulf of Papua. The students on a lagatoi through dance and storytelling played out how Siabo and his friends sailed off the cost of Central with the lagatoi and journeyed to the Gulf of Papua with clay pots to trade for sago and staple food. The play ended with mothers welcoming the Bogebada (sea-eagle) with dancing and hitting of sticks on the ground and the shouting “Edihoroha Bogebada”. The Hiri trade is believed to be an event which revolutionised Motuan society. After many generations, this trade is a significant traditional event that identifies the Boera people and remains a celebrated part of their culture.

Title: Huon Gulf celebrates with baton march
Content: MOROBE’S Huon Gulf marked its golden jubilee independence anniversary with a baton march led by students across its three local level governments (LLGs). The baton contained the written history of the district and its three LLGs, Morobe, Salamua and Wampar. The march started at Morobe where the baton was brought and due to unfavourable weather conditions and high tides, it rested at Lababiya and arrived on Saturday evening. It was received by Morobe High School students. Students from Morobe High School walked with the baton and passed it on to Koiari Primary School and later to Morobe Primary School and delivered to LLG officials. The baton was later released back to the students of Morobe High School, where they took it to Lababiya on Sunday. The school officials got the baton and passed it to students of Lababiya Primary School students who sailed with it through pristine waters to Salamua High School students. They later took the baton to Buakap Primary for the celebrations and rested for the night. On Monday, it was brought to Labu Butu, the first ward for Wampar LLG. It was later delivered to Markham Bridge Primary School, they then passed it on to Bubia Primary. Bubia students passed it on to Sagaring Primary School. Sagaring students later delivered it to Muya Primary students where they gave it to Munum Primary who joined the convoy with PX Huon Gulf float and delivered it to Nasuapun Primary School. The march was completed with the handover of the baton to Seventh-day Adventist Primary School and stayed for the night. On Tuesday, the march continued and the baton was delivered to Zifasing High School students and teachers who marched with it to the main arena at Mongkeng, Nadzab. The end of the march coincided with the raising of the flag, staging of a guard of honour, a mock battle by PNG Defence Force soldiers, awarding of medals and performances ofsingsinggroups. District education secretary Sammy Geseng said: “This is about the history for the past 50 years so in the next 50 years, this generation of students will it take on, that is why we engage them so that they will know about it. “One of the main challenges is the bad weather and the time, otherwise were able to complete the march successfully.”

Title: ENB recognises 30-plus with awards
Content: MORE than 30 persons were recognised with awards on Tuesday night, in the last part of East New Britain’s (ENB) commemorative programme for the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. A cocktail party was hosted to give recognition to individuals who had contributed one way or the other to build up various sectors of the ENB society. Among the local awardees was one of the soldiers who lowered the Australian flag 50 years ago in Port Moresby. Douglas Eremas Vuru, from Gazelle’s Rapitok village, was given the honour of raising the national flag in the earlier part of the programme at Rabaul’s Rapindik where a monument of Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare stood. The majority of awardees were in the business industry and had been around since pre-eruption in 1994 and continued to serve the communities there. Speaking at the occasion, Gazelle MP and Fisheries and Marine Resources Minister Jelta Wong said that 50 years was a long time for the country. “We have come 50 years, another couple of years and we will make it happen. I guarantee you that,” Wong said. He said despite the challenges faced in the province, the ENB government and its administration were doing what they could to resolve ongoing power blackouts and law and order issues. “We need to think positive and change the mindset, especially of the young people,” Wong said. Governor Michael Marum said the medals given were the start of a getting recognition at a national level. “This concept is from a collective decision by the provincial government and its administration, where you get this ENB golden award and the next qualification is to come under the ML award that will be progressed next year and so forth,” Marum said. Marum said they were looking at 50 awards, but names from Pomio and Gazelle were not submitted on time. He said the awards were a recognition given on behalf of the people of ENB. Meanwhile, the Papa Graun Cultural Show opened its three-day event on Sept 12 to commemorate the 50th Independence anniversary, bringing together people mainly from Kokopo’s Raluana. The event ended on Sunday. Day one featured a float from Malapau to Raburua and back, followed by a procession of guests into the arena, a flag-raising ceremony, and performances by church groups and cultural groups. There were live performances from local bands and artistes. Stalls were set up for small-to-medium enterprises (SMEs) and corporate houses, along with information booths for those who had registered. The event provided people with an opportunity to market their items while enjoying performances from various groups. Kokopo MP Ereman ToBaining Jr acknowledged the Malapau Beachfront organising committee for initiating the show. What began as a small but significant gathering in Malapau, with only one or two cultural dances, had now grown into a larger event involving the wider Raluana community. ToBaining said he wanted a lead-up event to the anniversary celebrations, which inspired him to host the Papa Graun Cultural Show to ignite the independence spirit. He highlighted the tireless efforts of East New Britain’s former leaders and the strong working relationship between the sitting MPs and Marum in striving to improve the province despite its challenges. “We accept those critics and challenges, so that we can bring development,” ToBaining said. Marum acknowledged the significance of the show and described it as a powerful expression of unity. “Our traditional songs, dances, and rituals remind us that we are the custodians of a living heritage,” he said. “Culture is what keeps us connected to our ancestors, grounded in our identity, and inspires us to build a stronger future.”

Title: Pomio locals celebrate over three days
Content: THE people of East New Britain’s Pomio came together at Palmalmal government station on Monday to open their three-day independence celebrations. The programme began with a float from the district field at Palmalmal Station to Malop Bridge and Manginuna Cemetery, before returning to the district office. Day one of the event saw groups from villages across Pomio showcasing their unique dances. There was also cultural representation from groups outside of East New Britain. Speaking at the opening ceremony, district administrator John Liskia reminded the people of the importance of celebrating and acknowledged the services that had been delivered, especially road connectivity. “Today, you can drive three hours to villages, which would normally take three days, 10 years ago, when there were no roads and bridges,” he said. “This gives us every reason to start celebrating today.” Liskia thanked past leaders for their contributions to developing Pomio, and acknowledged the current district administration team for their efforts in bringing development. Present for the event to celebrate with his people was Pomio MP and Health Minister Elias Kapavore. “We have gone miles in terms of development, and we must applaud this District Development Authority (DDA) board led by Elias Kapavore,” Liskia said. He urged the people to participate meaningfully in the celebrations. “Let us show our joy and pride as citizens of this country,” he said.

Title: ‘Strategic blunder’: Singirok says defence treaty a minefield for PNG
Content: THE proposed Mutual Defence Treaty between Australia and Papua New Guinea (Pukpuk Treaty) is not just a diplomatic milestone, but a potential Constitution legal and strategic minefield for PNG, says retired major-general Jerry Singirok. “In short, it being designed by Canberra to forge Australia’s interest over PNG sovereignty, is a strategic blunder,” Singirok said in a statement yesterday. “PNG is not for sale,” he said. He said PNG’s Constitution does not provide for military integration with a foreign power. He said the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) is mandated to serve the sovereign interests of PNG and any arrangement that embeds PNGDF personnel within the Australian Defence Force (ADF) or aligns PNG’s military doctrine with Australia’s could be seen as: “If the treaty is signed without Constitutional amendments or broad public consultation, it could be challenged in court or spark political backlash,” he said. He said the treaty promised interoperability, shared logistics, and even recruitment pathways for PNG citizens into the ADF. While this might modernise PNG’s defence capabilities, he said it also risked: He said if Australia wanted to “lure” PNG’s cabinet into signing, it might offer: “But unless PNG’s legal framework is updated and public trust is earned, this treaty could remain stalled—or worse, signed under pressure and later unravel led,” he said.

Title: Duke hands over King’s Colour
Content: PRINCE Edward, the Duke of Edinburgh, handed over the King’s Colour to the First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (1RPIR) at Murray Barracks, representing the sovereign’s authority over it, and the unit’s loyalty to the monarch. 1RPIR Commanding Officer Lt-Col Ezron Dekaetavara said the colour was a symbol of history, duty and unbroken service to the Crown. Prince Edward also handed over the Regimental Colour. Lt-Col Dekaetavara said: “They embodied the spirit of those who served before us, stood steadfast in battle and upheld the traditions of courage, loyalty and sacrifice. “They are a reminder of the sacred bond between the regiment and the sovereign – a bond we hold with the highest pride and responsibility.” Dekaetavara said the colours would be placed in the Officers’ Mess and used only for guards of honour staged for a member of the royal family or the Governor-General. The old colours will be kept at the Murray Barracks chapel. “The 1RPIR is proud of its distinguished heritage forged in the Second World War and carried forward for decades of service to our nation,” Dekaetavara said. On July 4, 1956, the Queen’s and Regimental Colours were presented to the Pacific Islands Regiment by then Governor-General, Field Marshal Sir William Slim, embodying the history, spirit and tradition of the unit to which they belonged. It was last used in a parade in 2023. It has now been changed to the King’s Colour after the passing of Queen Elizabeth II in 2022. “The colours will stand as a source of inspiration and pride during times of trial and symbolises unity in times of peace,” he added.

Title: King Charles praises PNG’s development
Content: KING Charles III has praised Papua New Guinea for its development and progress, saying the country’s story stretches back further than 50 years. “The story of Papua New Guinea stretches back further than the past five decades,” King Charles said in a message on its 50th independence anniversary. “One need only witnesses the immense diversity of peoples, languages, and cultures. Not to mention the abundant flora and fauna throughout the nation to appreciate the richness and complexity of its heritage which will also shape its future in generations to come. “Though the journey has not always been an easy one, modern Papua New Guinea stands as a proud symbol of its citizens’ perseverance, resilience, and tireless commitment to democracy and unity.” In his message relayed by video during the celebrations at the Sir John Guise stadium in Port Moresby on Tuesday night, King Charles said PNG had made great strides in development, public health, infrastructure and diplomacy. He said: “Today (Tuesday) is a big day for Papua New Guinea and I am happy to send my greetings from the bottom of my heart to you all to mark your 50 years of independence. “On this day of celebration, I reflect back on my first visit where Papua New Guinea’s flag was hoisted up on Independence Hill. I was there at that time. “On that day (Sept 16, 1975) we were looking at the future with hope and belief that the country will grow and become strong. “As a mature and established voice in the Pacific and on the world stage, I am immensely proud that Papua New Guinea is such a deeply valued and respected member of our Commonwealth family.”

Title: Prince Edward re-introduces award for youth in PNG
Content: PRINCE Edward, the Duke of Edinburgh, says that the Duke of Edinburgh international award will re-introduced in Papua New Guinea. The award was first introduced in England in 1956 and was made available to 130 countries. Papua New Guineans have been eligible for the awards, but was not used. Therefore, it is now being reintroduced by Prince Edward. The award is a non-formal education and learning framework available to those between the ages of 14 and 24, helping young people to build resilience, confidence, leadership, teamwork, community engagement, time management and responsibility. Successful applicants get an internationally recognised certificate, a boost to their university and job applications, build lifelong friendships and networks, encourage growth and social responsibility and offer adventure while learning. Prince Edward made this known during a non-formal education discussion attended by Governor-General Grand Chief Sir Bob Dadae, Prime Minister James Marape, Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko, UK High Commissioner to PNG Anne Macro and education representatives.
People: Bob Dadae, James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko

Title: Future lies in the past, O’Neill says
Content: IALIBU-Pangia MP and former prime minister Peter O’Neill has urged the nation to strengthen traditional ways of leadership and systems in the next 50 years of independence. “What I know is that our traditional ways are giving way to a western system that has not worked for us,” he said. “I also know that while we have our sovereignty, we are not self-determining and barely independent with our border and economy heavily propped up by outsiders. “I believe firmly that our bright future lies in the fingerprints of our tribal past, and not in blindly following the ways of Western societies.” O’Neill said the answers to the country’s challenges “lie with our ancestors”. “Our strengths have come from thousands of years of practices and that has been frayed in just a few decades,” he said. “But they remain and with just a few shakes, can be awakened to rise to meet today’s challenges. “Our ancestors were tribal, but they were notkanakas. “They not only survived but thrived in all areas of our country. “They were incredible navigators of the sea; fisherman; hunters; gatherers; farmers; traders; canoe and ship builders and border controllers. Our ancestors were successful people who developed orderly societies and elected leaders and conducted judicial functions such as village-based dispute resolution practices. “Traditional health care was administered, and disease was infrequent due to PNG’s isolation from other societies. “They kept our land as ours, our seas plentiful with food and managed the environment sustainably.” O’Neill said that births, marriages, deaths, conflicts, environmental disasters, invasions, and food security were all managed through an ancient system of governing. “Yes, we might have had big chiefs who ruled but they had to navigate internal borders and achieve harmony to survive as a collective of tribes,” he said. “In other words, we were an ancient nation with tribes interdependent on one other for success. “And successful we were. “A standout success that was valuable to other nations. “Our ancestors were not a failed state who needed rescuing. “We were colonised because we had valuable resources the world wanted.”

Title: PM reaffirms commitment to Bougainville
Content: THE Government remains committed to working with the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) towards a future that is good for Bougainville and Papua New Guinea, says Prime Minister James Marape. Marape in a message at Independence Hill in Port Moresby on Independence Day said to “our brothers and sisters in Bougainville: We hear you. We respect your voices”. “Our shared history has not been without its trials, but it is also a story of resilience, reconciliation, and hope,” he said. “As we look ahead, let dialogue, understanding, and unity guide us. “Whatever pathway we take, it must be one that honours the aspirations of Bougainville while preserving the spirit of one people, one nation, one country.” The Bougainville referendum, held in November-December 2019 saw a 97.7 per cent votein favour of independence over the alternative of greater autonomy. The referendum, sanctioned by the Constitution, was conducted to the highest standards, and certified to have been free and fair by international observers. Since then, the two governments had been engaging in consultations as required under the terms of the Bougainville Peace Agreement and the PNG Constitution. The leaders of PNG and Bougainville recently held talks in New Zealand to discuss Bougainville’s path to independence.

Title: Royal Family proud of PNG: Prince Edward
Content: THE Royal Family takes great interest in the fortunes of this country, says Prince Edward. Speaking during the Independence celebrations at Sir John Guise stadium on Tuesday evening, he said: “It is a very great pleasure to be able to join you here on your 50th anniversary of your independence and nationhood. “Thank you for the wonderful welcome that I received over the last few days. “It has been very special. “It has taken me so long to get here and why all the rest of my family have wanted to come here first. Because you have always shown them what a fabulous country this is. And you have always given us a great welcome. “As His Majesty (King Charles) said, ‘Mi liklik brata bilong King(I am the King’s younger brother)’. “What has struck me over the last few days is the enthusiasm you have for the monarchy and your loyalty to King Charles.” Prince Edward said the Royal Family was ‘very proud’ of what PNG has achieved in the last 50 years. “I am delighted that so many other realms and members of the Commonwealth Pacific have joined you here for these celebrations,” he said. “It means a great deal to all of us that you are here as a family.” Prince Edward, who enjoyed the cultural performances, said: “Thank you to all the performers and all the work that has gone on this evening. “It is spectacular and a real show of what a diverse country this is. “I look forward to being able to come back again.” Prime Minister James Marape, who also attended the celebrations, urged the people to work together. The celebrations at the Sir John Guise stadium started as early as 4pm with a fly over of aircraft which included the two Royal Australian Air Force F35A Combat Fighter Jets. This was later followed by various cultural performances. A reenactment of the Hiri Trade, followed by a Runway and Fashion show depicting an array of traditionally inspired wear. Music artists such as Sir George Telek, Betty Toea, Sanguma Band, and Sprigga Mek also performed on the night. The night also featured a drone light show which illustrated the PNG flag, and the Bird of Paradise, which illuminated the city sky. A fireworks display capped of a night of celebrations.

Title: Australia and PNG sign defence communique
Content: PAPUA New Guinea and Australia have agreed on the text of a Mutual Defence Treaty, which will be signed following cabinet processes in both countries. The joint communique of the Mutual Defence Treaty also known as the Pukpuk Treaty is intended to elevate defence relationship between the two countries to an alliance. Prime Minister James Marape and his Australian counterpart Anthony Albanese in a joint press conference yesterday said the treaty will include a mutual defence alliance which recognised that an armed attack on Australia or PNG would be a danger to the peace and security of both countries: According to Australian Associated Press, the deal may not be as snappy as Albanese hopes because of a holdup in gaining PNG cabinet approval for the pact. Marape said the communique signed was to establish core principles of the treaty after proper process are done by both cabinets as this is a military and not a dictatorship. “Australia has a big area of huge ocean and air space and PNG is part of the land mass in those spaces, it is in our interest to have a defence focus that is mutual for two nations,” he said. “50 years on the prime minister or commander cannot defend the over 4,000sqkm of land the ocean space we have in this security is priority. This is foresight that not just secures Australia but PNG. It was upon PNG’s proposal.” Albanese added that the treaty will elevate the status to an alliance. It will be Australia’s first new alliance in more than 70 years. “The treaty will build on 50 years of cooperation between the two countries, including the defence cooperation,” he said. “Our new alliance will reflect our true commitment to each other and to a region that is peaceful, stable and prosperous. “ He said the alliance will be grounded in 50 years of cooperation as equal partners. It will build on our unique security relationship, the foundation of which is the kinship between generations of our defence personnel. “It will recognise the sacrifices our peoples have made for each other and the cause of peace and our nations’ enduring commitment to the principles of democracy and sovereignty.”

Title: Albanese announces funding of new Parliament wing
Content: AUSTRALIA’S Prime Minister Anthony Albanese yesterday announced that they will be funding the new ministerial wing for the Papua New Guinea’s Parliament House as part of the 50th celebrations. Construction will follow a PNG-led design and consultation process, and draw on local craftsmanship and expertise. “Our support for the expansion of Parliament House is an investment in Papua New Guinea’s democracy and sovereignty that will benefit future generations,” he said. This gift recognises the common understanding of the democratic principles that underpin the modern Australia-PNG relationship, and the role of our parliaments in reflecting the voices of our people. He said the mutual recognition reflected the shared democratic values and warm friendship between Australia and PNG, which continued to grow after he addressed Parliament in 2023 and Marape, the first Pacific leader to address senators and members in Australia’s parliament. “At a ceremony held in Port Moresby on the day of independence in 1975, Australia’s then-Prime Minister Gough Whitlam observed ours is ‘a relationship of equals, based on mutual respect, understanding and trust,” Albanese said. “As close neighbours and warm friends, the future prosperity of our two nations are bound together.” He added that it will look like the Bird of Paradise, a signal from Australia that they valued PNG’s democracy.

Title: US, PNG sign cooperation pact for next 50 years
Content: THE United States (US) and Papua New Guinea signed a Strategic Cooperation Framework for mutual cooperation and priorities for the next 50 years, including economic, commercial, and digital collaboration, as well as critical minerals and infrastructure development. Deputy Secretary of State Christopher Landau and Prime Minister James Marape signed the framework yesterday, a day after the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. The framework underscores “mutual priorities for the next 50 years of the US – PNG bilateral relationship” according to the US Embassy. US ambassador Ann Marie Yastishock said the signing of this framework reflected the enduring partnership between the two nations and highlights the wide range of sectors for collaboration. “The US has stood with PNG since day one, in 1975,” said US Ambassador Yastishock. “This framework builds on five decades of cooperation based on shared values and a shared vision of the future,” she added. Meanwhile, the US had also acknowledged its private sector investment in the extractives sector. According to the US Embassy, the framework highlighted cooperation in critical minerals extraction and processing, with a focus on sustainable development, investment competitiveness, and practices to benefit the local communities in which companies operate. Furthermore, the embassy said that existing US companies could contribute to PNG’s overall development, as the framework states both nations will work together to increase US investment in PNG, and collaborate on policies aimed to attract greater US investment, including an increased focus on the use of trusted technology and strengthened cyber-security practices. Part of the focus of the framework is to allow for research and exploration into deep sea or seabed minerals. The US is supporting advancement of deep sea science that can be used to inform seabed mineral development and responsible mining activities in the Pacific to secure access to reliable supplies of critical minerals for strategic industries, which will benefit the US industry and the region. The document reaffirmed US’s commitments, including the 2023 Defence Cooperation and Ship-rider Agreements, the reoccurring Strategic Partnership Dialogue which was first held in Washington, DC, in 2024, and existing defence, maritime security and law enforcement capacity building and training programmes. Landau said: “This Framework for Strategic Cooperation reflects the United States’ commitment to a comprehensive partnership with PNG.” “It not only strengthens our defence ties but also fosters economic growth, innovation, and shared prosperity.”

Title: Governor-General urges self-reflection, patriotism
Content: PAPUA New Guinea reaffirms its commitment to be a friend to all, enemy to none as we navigate global developments and uncertainties together, says Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae. Speaking during the flag lowering ceremony at Sir Hubert Murray Stadium in Port Moresby on Tuesday, he said: “We appreciate our regional and bilateral partners – represented here by the diplomatic missions, and our friends and allies from across the world. “I extend a warm welcome to you all. Papua New Guinea has benefited from these alliances, and we are grateful for your contribution to our nation’s development.” In his message to Papua New Guineans, Sir Bob said: “I urge us to self-reflect and identify where we can improve and better ourselves. “Our attitude, our mindset. Let us bring back the spirit of patriotism, our culture of generosity, kindness and coherence in our communities. “Let us work at building strong, safe and secure communities for our families, our citizens and the future generations of this country. “Let us prove to ourselves, to our fellowmen and the world over, that we are capable of achieving greatness for our country, and we can do it!” Prince Edward, the Duke of Edinburgh, also attended flag lowering ceremony. Sir Bob acknowledged the Royal Family for sending Prince Edward to witness PNG’s celebrations. “His Majesty the King (Charles) has been gracious, and as a nation, sharing this special occasion in your presence, is significant to our 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations. “Papua New Guinea has over the last five decades, grown and evolved. We have our challenges, for sure. “But, as a nation of diverse cultures, 800 plus languages and unique traditions, we have stood together united as one nation, one country, one people,” Sir Bob said. “It was a proud moment for us on Sept 16, 1975, under the stewardship of our founding father Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare, when our nation Papua New Guinea came into being. “His Majesty the King, then Prince Charles, was present here in this very stadium on that momentous occasion. “At the birth of our country, we chose Constitutional Monarchy as our system of Government, to be part of the Commonwealth, specifically as a Realm nation. “We chose to have Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II as our Head of State.”

Title: PNG has not done enough: Bureaucrat
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has not done enough in the past 50 years in its commitments to trade compliance and market access, a senior bureaucrat has said. Joshua Kalinoe, former chief secretary, department head and diplomat, told a gala dinner hosted by the Commerce and Industry Department on Sept 15 that while the country had done well in providing a strong democracy and institutions that continued to protect justice, prosperity and progress, much needed to be done on the trade front to grow the economy. He also considered as “alarming” certain imbalances between economic stimulus and consumption financing. Kalinoe, who once served as commerce and industry department secretary observed that ever since independence, PNG had signed only three free trade agreements. Kalinoe said: “Since the PNG LNG project over 10 years ago, no foreign direct investment (FDI) or a trade agreement were signed with international partners. “This is a disappointing performance. Cross-border export trade and FDI are important to stimulate and facilitate sustainable domestic economic growth.” The veteran bureaucrat said both developing and developed nations were today pursuing aggressive cross-border export trade and FDI strategies. Countries in Africa, the Middle East and Asia were spending more time, money and human capital in trade and investment. Kalinoe urged PNG to adopt similar aggressive strategies and to begin by complying with the rules-based multilateral trading agreement (Bali Agreement) which imposes significant commitments for compliance and implementation. PNG also needed to coordinate implementation at political and bureaucratic levels which remain obstacles today,” he said. “Therefore, there is a pressing desire now for a realignment and harmonisation of some of our implementation mechanisms. “Such reforms should be performance and result based,” he said. On economic stimulus and consumption financing, Kalinoe said PNG had been borrowing heavily in the last five years from international financial institutions to fund its consumption budget. He said: “No economic stimulus intervention frameworks have been announced or formulated by the government. “Nothing wrong with borrowing so long as the funds are applied to value adding economic and social projects. “However, consumption borrowing to support the goods and services budget is a problem. “The debt will have be paid back by taxpayers at the expense of declining provisions for health and education services. “Further, the debt burden in the future will be paid by the coming young generations and instead of improving their standards of living, they will remain poorer. “So instead of borrowing more, the country should introduce strategic economic stimulus frameworks to facilitate domestic economic growth.  Such an approach should be based on a string of sectoral programmes and coordinated by a relevant agency of Government. “The epicenters of such a strategy should be to support existing businesses to expand as well as to facilitate increased FDI and cross-border export trade.”

Title: Land titles for department staff
Content: PERHAPS the best present any department got for its hardworking staff at the 50th Independence Anniversary was the securing of 320 land titles for the Commerce and Industry Department. Commerce and Industry Minister Win Daki made the happy announcement at a gala night hosted by the department at the Hilton Hotel on Sept 15, ending a week of celebration and events on the night. Daki said he was a proud man to be able to make such a gift to staff of a department that contributed much to the economic development of the country. “You do the work,” he said. “I do the presentation. I take the glory.” It is understood the land tiles are for a plot of land at what is commonly referred to as Duran Farm behind Eight-Mile outside Port Moresby. The Lands Department earlier last week presented the titles to the department. The gala dinner was interspaced with music, song and drama. Long-serving department employees who had clocked 15 years and over were given gifts and certificates. A drama by children of employees showcased the advent of independence and the way the country has come, likening it to a ship sailing on destiny’s tempestuous seas and reaching land. Secretary David Ganaii acknowledged the efforts of the country’s founding fathers in working through trials and tribulations to deliver the country’s independence. He said the department had come a long way and was now stabilised with permanent officers.

Title: Kasu wins Morobe pageant
Content: GEORGINA Kasu, 24, was crowned the Morobe cultural ambassador in the Miss Bird of Paradise Pageant ’25. She was among four pioneer contestants trying out for Miss Morobe. “I grew up in Port Moresby, and have always felt disconnected to my people and home,” she said. “Taking part in this pageant was my way of bridging that gap. “I didn’t really expect to be the inaugural Miss Morobe as there were other strong contestants.” Kasu, from Huon Gulf’s Labu Tale, works for Spectrum Holdings Limited’s accounts division in Port Moresby. She sponsored herself to pursue the interest, paying for her own ticket to Lae and back for try-outs, successfully landing a spot in the provincial pageant. She was voted as Miss Morobe on Wednesday night; her crowing witnessed by Lae business community chairman Anna Bais and reigning Miss Bird of Paradise May Hasola. “I look forward to be based here in Lae, working together with business houses, community and people to create more awareness on inclusive education for children with disability and representing Morobe in the Miss Bird of Paradise Pageant,” she said. “I’ll find a way around things to juggle work and represent my people and province. “I ask for the support of my people and the business community as I enter the national pageant in Port Moresby in December.” Kasu promotes her culture with pride, she’s an advocate of traditional language – Yabim and Kotec – and children living with disabilities, especially in rural communities. “Everybody deserves a right to life and service accessibility,” she said. “I call on all girls across the district to join this journey for a worthy cause.” Mother Lucy, who encouraged her daughter to join the pageant, said she never doubted her. “It’s a new experience, but we will be with her all the way to the national pageant,” she said. Bais said Morobe was the third province to crown their provincial queen.

Title: Arts exhibition expresses soul of country
Content: A NATIONAL arts exhibition was held in Port Moresby to mark Papua New Guinea’s 50th anniversary. Tourism, Arts and Culture Minister Belden Namah said that for half a century this exhibition had been more than just a gathering of artists, it had been a national stage where PNG’s soul had been expressed in colours, cravings, weavings, melodies and stories. “It is a mirror of who we are, a people bound by more than 800 languages, diverse traditions and countless expression, yet united by one spirit, one heritage and one nation,” Namah said. National Cultural Commission (NCC) exhibition curator Hillary Miria said that under the theme “unbroken lines: past, present and future of PNG contemporary arts”, the exhibition celebrated the resilience, creativity and cultural vision of its pioneering and contemporary artists. “From the monumental works that helped define nationhood at independence to the vibrant expression of today’s generation, these artworks speak to the journey of a country still shaping its identity through art. “This exhibition brings together pioneers, career artists and emerging voices who carry the threads of tradition into contemporary practice. “It honours the early visionaries whose works in Parliament House and public spaces gave form to a new nation, while also showcasing the experimental, critical and boundary-pushing creativity of today,” Miria said. He said that the exhibition invited everyone to walk these lines, reflected on history and saw how artists continued to shape the spirit of PNG for generations to come.

Title: Certain provisions of constitution needs changing, says Kwa
Content: JUSTICE and Attorney-General Department Secretary Dr Eric Kwa says certain provisions of the Constitution need to change with the times to allow for more development in the country. Kwa said the Constitution, including other relevant laws, needed to be subject to change through proper vetting processes. He said at least 50 amendments have been made to the Constitution since it was first adopted on Aug 15, 1975, by the Constituent Assembly and effective on Sept 16 the same year, coinciding with Independence Day. “The amendments are bound to happen,” he said. “When we look at the founding fathers and the constitution planning committee, they were developing the Constitution from an age of colonial oppression. “What was envisioned then and what we are experiencing now are very different. “Therefore, we must expect changes. “Changes are necessary to remain relevant but we must keep the foundation of the Constitution intact “Changes are necessary and there will be more in the future to sustain us as and ensure that we continue to exist a sovereign nation. “Beyond certain amendments, all the others were just to fix the edges of some of the provisions.” Kwa said constitutional amendments in 1995 which introduced the Organic Law on Provincial and Local Level Government was one example of the Constitution being changed during a time when the then-leaders saw fit to do so. “However, that was one of the biggest mistakes made,” he said. “Over the years, we have seen the demise of rural service delivery being sucked back to Waigani.” Kwa added that he supported the need for reforms to me made to allow for more decentralisation of powers and functions back to the provinces. Meanwhile, Kwa said all citizens needed to appreciate the freedom granted by the Constitution since 1975. “We may not have all the roads, bridges and all the other services but we are still free in our own country,” he said. “This is a reason to celebrate. “We must honour this freedom. “Even after 50 years, we are still one country.”

Title: Namani: Lawyers must defend the rule of law
Content: AS Papua New Guinea marks 50 years of independence, Papua New Guinea Law Society president Hubert Namani has proposed to lawyers to lead the nation in upholding the Constitution and the rule of law. Namani said during the opening of the new National and Supreme Court Complex in Port Moresby last week as a symbol of national progress and a reminder of the critical role lawyers played in defending justice, integrity and accountability. “While this milestone is a source of pride, it is also a call to action,” he said. “As lawyers, we must confront the challenges of corruption, lawlessness and weak governance. “We have a responsibility to speak truth to power and guide our nation toward a future worthy of its promise.” Namani encouraged all members of the legal profession to reflect on their role as guardians of justice and leaders of positive change, committing to strengthen the legal system and ensure that the next 50 years see PNG thrive under the rule of law. “Happy 50th Independence Anniversary,” he said. “Let us uphold our professional duties and lead by example.”

Title: Cultural finery on display at annual Morobe Show
Content: THE annual Morobe Agricultural Show ended on Sunday in Lae with a spectacular display of Papua New Guinean culture. Lae MP John Rosso, who was present during the show, said: “From the colourful cultural dances, to the powerful livestock displays, to the bustling stalls of SMEs, the Morobe Show has become a true reflection of our nation’s creativity, Morobe province’s creativity, resilience and potential.” He said for 62 years, the Morobe Show had brought people together from all corners of PNG and beyond. “It has been a place of exchange, knowledge, culture and commerce “It has provided opportunities for farmers to learn new methods and interact. “That is why the Morobe Show is not just an event. It is part of the social and economic fabric of Lae, Morobe province.” For the first time in years, a float parade wound through the city, showcasing local communities, businesses, and cultural groups. Traditional performances, modern farming displays, and interactive exhibits provided a unique platform for families and visitors to experience Morobe’s rich cultural and economic heritage. Apart from Rosso, important guest, Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae, graced the show with his presence. They engaged with participants and emphasised on the vital role of agriculture, innovation, and local enterprise in national development. A moment of silence was observed to honour the late Morobe Governor Luther Wenge, who passed away on Saturday. They paid tribute to his contributions to the province The show’s highlights included displays of local businesses who used the platform to showcase products and services, boosting trade and entrepreneurship in the province. Children and families enjoyed dedicated entertainment zones featuring games, rides, and cultural demonstrations, making the event inclusive and fun for all ages. MPAS president Hans Mehl expressed his gratitude to sponsors, participants, and the public. He said this year’s show has been a resounding success and has promoted innovation, strengthened community bonds and celebrated Morobe’s cultural and economic achievements as the country heads into celebrating the country’s 50th anniversary.
People: Bob Dadae, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: Wau basks in country’s jubilee celebration
Content: THE main highlights of 50th independence anniversary celebrations in Wau, Morobe, were the mock war game by PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) and the awarding of long service medals. Other minor highlights were the releasing of balloons in colours of the national flag, greasy pole, live band performances and speeches with police and PNGDF parades. People from Wau Urban, Wau Rural and Waria local level government as well as other districts and provinces, turned up in the PNG colours to celebrate this significant event. The mock war game by the PNGDF personnel was the main attraction where citizens were taken through drills performed by soldiers when coming into contact with enemies. Wau-Waria was lucky to have two units from the PNGDF. One unit was sent to Garaina station while the other took part in the celebration at Wau town. District chief executive officer John Orebut acknowledged the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare and his colleague leaders who stood up for freedom of this country 50 years ago. He said without their strives, determination, courage and strong leadership then, PNG would not have come this far. MP Marsh Narawec acknowledged mothers and women, saying they had contributed much to the development of the country. He said churches and other development partners had all helped in shaping PNG. While speaking of late Morobe Governor Luther Wenger, Narawec told the people that the governor was instrumental in ensuring that their new district prospered into the future. He said Wenge had contributed funding and machineries towards road links in the district. Narewec further urged his people to enter the next 50 years with changed mindsets and approaches.
People: Luther Wenge, Marsh Narawec, Michael Somare

Title: Commitment vital, says Kombra
Content: TEACHERS and education personnel throughout the country have been reminded that the country’s freedom is built on the foundation of an educated and empowered population as they celebrate the country’s independence. Education secretary Dr Uke Kombra sounded this reminder last Thursday as the Department of Education begun its two-day pre-independence celebration at Butuka Academy in Port Moresby. The celebrations ended on Friday. Thursday’s event began with flag raising witnessed by Education Minister Lucas Dekena, Higher Education Minister Kinoka Feo, Education secretary Dr Uke Kombra and education staff from both the Education Department and the Higher Education Department. Education Sector Development Plan (ESDP) 2023-2027 was also launched on the same day. Kombra reminded the teachers and department officials that as they celebrated the nation’s 50th independence day, they must remember that the country’s freedom was built on the foundation of an educated and empowered population. “The future of our community is in our hands, and it begins with our commitment to education and so let us celebrate our shared history and be inspired to create an even better future for our nation,” he urged. “For the past 50 years, the Ministry of Education has been the cornerstone of our nation’s journey since getting independence in 1975. “We were tasked with a difficult challenge and that was to unite the nation of 1,000 tribes and cultures and languages through the universal language of learning. “We built schools in remote villages and on distant islands, trained generations of local teachers and throughout the curriculum that honour our traditions and prepare our youth for a modern world.” Kombra said despite the many challenges they faced, this anniversary was a testament to the hard work and the tireless dedication of the countless teachers, administrative staff, and those who had side-shaped the lives of generations, nurtured minds that had gone on to lead government, industries, societies and communities. He highlighted that ESDP was a collaborative effort of five key agencies and aimed to provide an overarching view of our country’s development plan for education. “This is the first time ever since 1975 that we have witnessed a plan that unites the whole education sector,” he said. Kombra said the main goal of the ESDP was to implement the investment programme outlined in the Medium Term Development Plan Four (MTDP4). “The ESDP’s investment programme are linked to the key deliberate interventions programme from MTDP 4, including early childhood education, basic quality primary and secondary education, tertiary education, technical and vocation education training.”

Title: Kokopo Business College students celebrate two milestones
Content: The East New Britain’s Kokopo Business College (KBC) is hosting a double celebration – the college’s 25th silver jubilee and Papua New Guinea’s 50th anniversary. The two-day event, held at the college grounds in Kenabot, is celebrated under the theme “celebrating our silver journey and golden freedom, empowering minds and inspiring growth in education”. Events coordinator Janet Magaga said the occasion reflected the college’s long history and contribution to education in Papua New Guinea. “It’s a double celebration. It has been 25 years of existence here and of service to Papua New Guinea,” she said. KBC traces its roots to 1960 when it was established in Tavui as a secretarial college offering training for Grade 8 students. In 1975, it was moved to Rabaul but was later closed due to volcanic activity. It reopened in 1985 before being transferred to Kokopo Business College in 2000 through support from Australian Aid and the Gazelle Restoration Programme. Magaga said day one of the programme featured cultural performances, traditional food, stalls from students, alumni, SMEs, and corporate houses, as well as speeches, cake cutting, and a song competition. Day two continued with more regional and provincial performances, fun games, sales of merchandise and a fashion show to crown Mr and Miss 25th Silver Jubilee. KBC student representative council vice-president Janelle Sialis highlighted the role of student discipline and leadership in making the celebration possible. “So early in March, we the SRC decided to keep the students occupied when we have term breaks, we have mini games so that they feel involved and they avoid going out drinking or making nuisance,” she said. Sialis added that because of the students’ good behaviour and cooperation, the principal had approved the college’s graduation to be held at the end of this year rather than the following year. “I think the event is just turning out great. Everyone’s enjoying themselves,” she said. Meanwhile, Magaga has reminded KBC of its vital role in shaping future leaders. “I think KBC has contributed to nation building by educating a lot of students from all across Papua New Guinea,” she said. She added that graduates must use their skills to create opportunities. She said if they did not find employment, they should create employment from the skills that they had learned from the school. Magaga encouraged young people to be proactive. She said the school wanted to see young people doing something good for themselves. “They can create employment opportunities instead of waiting for a job offer,” she said. Magaga also explained why fundraising was part of the celebration and that was to raise funds to help the school with a lot of things that needed support. “That’s why we have put a registration fee for small table markets and SME stalls for K200, corporate stores for K250,” she said.

Title: Prince Edward presented flag symbolising the beginning of a new era
Content: ON THE morning of Sept 16, 1975, the Australian flag at the Sir Hubert Murray Stadium in Port Moresby was lowered, and in its place, Papua New Guinea’s own was raised for the first time as an independent nation. In commemoration of the country’s 50th Independence anniversary on Tuesday, a flag-lowering ceremony was held at the same venue to not only end the day’s celebrations but to also symbolise the beginning of a new era. Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Edward, was presented the flag after it was lowered, followed by an address from Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae to the people. “On the occasion of Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary, Your Royal Highness, we are deeply honoured by your presence with us today, ”Sir Bob said. “His Majesty, the King has been gracious, and as a nation, sharing this special occasion in your presence, is significant to our 50th Independence anniversary celebrations. “Papua New Guinea has over the last five decades, grown and evolved. “We have our challenges, for sure. But, as a nation of diverse cultures, 800 plus languages and unique traditions, we have stood together united as one nation, one country, one people.” Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, in a post on Facebook, said both countries shared a deep history. “Fifty years ago, on this very ground in Port Moresby, (former Australia PM) Gough Whitlam stood side by side with Papua New Guinea’s first Prime Minister, Sir Michael Somare to mark the birth of PNG as an independent country,” he said. “Now, the Papua New Guinea flag proudly flies on these grounds. “Today we honour the rich history and the deep ties between our nations – built on shared history, values and an enduring bond.”

Title: Celebration Raod link an independence gift for Wau-Waria
Content: A ROAD linking Wau and Garaina Station in the Waria LLG is an independence present for the Wau-Waria district, local MP Marsh Narawec says. Narawec said the road was a special gift by the government to the people at the eve of the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. “The best gift for us today is that in the last three days, a pilot road link connected Wau town to Garaina Station in Waria local level government,” Narawec said during independence celebrations in Wau on Tuesday. He said though the people have been neglected over the years, vehicles arriving at Garaina Station on the eve of independence showed that development was coming. “It’s a gift for us all in the district to have achieved this significant road link that will once again connect the famous Garaina Valley and the colonial era Garaina tea plantation. Narawec said the Garaina tea plantation would be rehabilitated in the coming years. Meanwhile, 100 long service personnel in Wau-Waria were given awards by the district administration as part of the independence celebrations in Wau. The awardees were those that have retired or are still in active in the public and private sectors. They were presented with long service medals, an appreciation certificate and K250 shopping vouchers. The district administration thanked them for their hard work and contribution towards developments in the district over the years.

Title: Carol slashes blouse prices after reaching independence target
Content: A SMALL business owner in Lae has thanked the city authority for allowing small businesses to operate freely in the city, leading up to the country’s 50th independence celebrations. Carol Ahi’s Butibam Indigenous Women Association acquired her vending license from the Lae City Authority four years ago and started selling items next to the state cemetery. Knowing that the 50th Independence anniversary would be a big event this year, she started restocking her items in June. Ahi set a target of K20,000 for her independence sales which began three weeks ago. She passed her goal on Sunday, making K22,000, and decided to drop the prices of her blouses from K100 to K50 on Monday, as a sign of goodwill to her customers. “I want to see that everyone is clothed in PNG colours on Sept 16,” she said. “I want to thank the government in Morobe, especially in Lae for giving us a fair chance to make money. “From youths selling flags to mothers like us who set up stalls – this was a golden opportunity for really good money and we did. “At least youths have money in their pockets so they didn’t have to go disturb others or mothers were kept busy and not gambling or go clubbing.”

Title: Administration Morobe urges people to pray for late Songang Wenge’s family
Content: THE Morobe administration has appealed to its people to pray for the immediate family and loved ones of the late Governor Luther Akisawa Wenge who are mourning his loss on this independence eve. Human Resource manager Kusak Meluk said the provincial government suspended a planned programme for the staff on Monday at the provincial headquarters in honour of their leader.Staff were asked to celebrate at home or attend the official independence programme at the Sir Ignatius Kilagi Stadium on Tuesday. “As we celebrate our country’s 50 years’ independence with joy and jubilant, we also mourn our great loss,” Meluk said.“All administration staff are hereby required to observe and pay respect to our great Kumul bilong Morobe by way of dressing in mourning colour as sign of respect. “I appeal to my public servants and clients to stand together to ensure we give our utmost respect to our governor leader, papa, grandfather, uncle and mighty kwila and sitting Governor who untimely passed on. “I urge all to pray for peace for his immediate family and loved ones and Morobe administration and Morobe Province that may the God of peace be with all now until we lay our leader to final rest.” Meluk said administration would scale down operations on Thursday as they plan details to receive the late Wenge. A funeral arrangement committee has been tasked to release formal announcements by Wednesday.

Title: ’50 years doesn’t happen twice’: Marape urges citizens to unite as country celebrates 50 years
Content: IN the eve of the country’s 50th Independence anniversary, Prime Minister James Marape is calling on all Papua New Guineans to stand united to see the country’s flag being hosted up for the 50th time. “I want to say to the children of Papua New Guinea, the generation that is alive today, 50 years of our nationhood, don’t happen twice,” he said. “The 50 years of a nationhood happens only once, and we are privileged to be the generation that is witnessing our nation pass through 50 years. “Never forget children of this country.
