There was once upon a time, certain parts of this country mostly were labeled ‘No to dogs and natives’.” He said it was against this backdrop that the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare’s generation all gravitate towards the idea that PNG can be a nation now. “We can be administrators of our own, we can run country on our own, and they moved mountains to achieve independence much faster than many would have envisioned or thought.” Marape told people to lay aside their differences in tribal, political differences, or any other issues they have in society and turn their attention towards the national flag, national anthem, and pledge tomorrow.

Title: From back blocks to top job: Marape’s story
Content: IT is a crisp September morning in Port Moresby. The streets are adorned with red, black and gold flags as Papua New Guinea counts down the hours to celebrate its 50th year of independence. From his office, the Parliament House and a monument of the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare are visible. Prime Minister James Marape watches the new Courthouse complex which his Government had allocated K401 million to complete. Marape is in his office, busy even on a Sunday, but he has made time for a chat. His story is of a young boy growing up in one of the remotest parts of the country, far from Port Moresby or the trappings of high office. That boy was born in 1971 in the rugged interior of Hela before moving to rural Western province. His journey from remote villages to the nation’s highest political office mirrors the story of PNG itself – resilience, hope and the belief that tomorrow can be better than today. Marape was only four years old when his missionary parents were stationed at Nomad in Western. The country was just weeks into independence in September 1975, but for families like the Marapes, daily realities had changed little. Remote areas with no roads and health facilities. Barefoot walking long distances to school, and often wearing traditional clothes were Marape’s lifestyle. Tragedy came early. His parents lost their first-born child to malaria, a wound that never fully healed and which gave young James a first-hand understanding of the fragility of life in rural PNG. “All my life I was educated in some of the remotest schools – from Western to West Sepik to Enga and the Eastern Highlands,” he recalls. “At 12, I became a boarding student at Paglum in remote Western Highlands, and that was when I first met students from all over PNG.” The Marape household revolved around hard work. His mother tilled the land, baked scones, and sewed clothes which James sold. “My mother was my first employer,” he said with a laugh. “I sold her products every school holiday. Whatever I earned went towards my school fees. Children today won’t understand the hardship we faced then.” Politics entered his life early. Campaign houses were part of community life in the Highlands, and by age 11, Marape was sitting cross-legged on the ground, listening to speeches and debates at the Anganmul village in Minj. “Seeing my mother’s struggle, I told myself that one day I would be a Member of Parliament,” he said. It was not bravado but a child’s vow born of hardship and observation. Like many young men of that era, he briefly considered a tradesman’s path – the promise of wages and tools was tempting. His parents refused. They saw in him the capacity to go further and insisted that he finished school. “Seeing their commitment, I buried myself in books,” Marape recalls. After Grade 10, he won a place in Grades 11 and 12 at a reduced fee of K80 – a blessing that made higher education possible. In 1990, the University of Papua New Guinea accepted him into its programme. For his tribe in Tari, it was a milestone worth celebrating. Education was still a rarity. “Attending UPNG made me the contemporary PNG man I am today. It opened my eyes to the whole country.” It was at the Waigani campus in 1991 that his ambition sharpened. Student debates, policy papers, the clash of ideas – all cemented his conviction that politics could be a vehicle for change. Marape first stood for election in 2002 for the Tari Open seat, finishing second. He returned to Port Moresby and worked as a principal research officer at the Department of Personnel Management, gaining a close-up view of how the machinery of government functioned. Yet the pull of politics did not fade. In 2007, Marape resigned from the public service to contest again. This time the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare travelled to Tari to campaign for him. It was more than political endorsement; it was a beginning of a mentorship that would shape Marape’s approach to leadership. “My loyalty lies with Sir Michael,” Marape said. He won and in 2008, Somare appointed him Minister for Education. Marape joined the Peter O’Neill Government in 2012 and rose through the ranks, serving in various ministerial posts. But in April 2019, he broke away over differences in policy and governance, a decision that set off a chain of events leading to his election as Prime Minister in May, 2019. During the tense days at the Laguna camp, when MPs huddled in hotels and alliances shifted hourly, Sir Michael paid him a visit. Marape still smiles at the memory. “He was glad when I announced my membership of Pangu Pati. Little did I know Pangu would be in power and leadership until now.” With leadership came heavy responsibilities. “What saddens me most is having to bury four former Prime Ministers while at the helm – Sir Mekere in 2020, Sir Michael Somare in 2021, Sir Rabbie Namaliu in 2023 and Sir Julius Chan in 2025. “As a child of the 70s, I had the hardest task of burying all the heavyweights.” He still remembers Sir Michael’s last words about his Karau village in the Murik Lakes, Angoram, 11 days before he passed on in 2021. Such moments remind him that the nation’s founding leaders governed with ethics and service at the forefront. “At this 50th anniversary, those of us here now must ask ourselves, what we can give or do for this great nation.” As the anniversary celebrations draws near, Marape’s speech carries both pride and urgency. “Much work remains to be done in health, education, law and order, and growing the economy. I cannot do it alone. We have not achieved all. Let’s work together. Our customs, Bible and Constitution are our guides. Leadership starts at home.” For Marape, that last point is more than a slogan. His upbringing taught him that leadership begins with discipline and care for family. It is a message he repeats to young Papua New Guineans who crowd around him at events. From the barefoot boy selling scone on dusty Highlands roads, to the man steering a complex and youthful nation, James Marape’s story is inseparable from Papua New Guinea’s own. Both are still work in progress, still grappling with distance and diversity, still seeking unity and development. As the national anthem swells at lead-up events and flags flutter, Marape turns to wave at the crowd. Somewhere in the stands, a young boy from a remote village might be watching, dreaming his own improbable dream.
People: James Marape, Julius Chan, Michael Somare, Sir Julius Chan

Title: Former CJ on leadership: Constant changes have brought instability
Content: FORMER chief justice Sir Arnold Amet has highlighted the constant change in national leadership as an impediment to the country’s development. Sir Arnold said Papua New Guinea has seen the election of 10 prime ministers since 1975, adding that political instability has ensued when prime ministers were removed by a vote of no confidence (VoNC) or resignation due to the threat of one. He said that Section 145 of the Constitution, which governs the process for a VoNC, has caused much of the political instability faced by the country’s leadership at the national level. “In 50 years, we have elected 10 prime ministers following the first national general election in 1977, with seven changes of prime ministers between the elections,” he said. “We have had 10 elections, 10 prime ministers, and in between the elections, an additional seven changes of prime ministership. “Altogether, we have had 17 prime ministers during the 50 years of independence which averages out to 2.9 years of active service per prime minister. “So the critical challenges these facts raise is the apparent and considerable political instability in government as a result of far too many frequent VoNCs under Section 145 of the Constitution or threats of VoNCs resulting in resignations. “With less than three years of a national leadership turnover and changes of executive leadership, is that the formula for the development of a nation? “This leads to inconsistencies in the implementation of policies, including constant changes in priorities.” He added that too many political parties were also to blame for the instability seen in governments over the years. “There are too many political parties with at least 22 in Parliament right now of the 56 registered. “This is not a formula for consistent government and leadership.” Sir Arnold said that the country needed good governance and not more politicisation of government and leadership. He urged all Papua New Guineans to learn and understand the meaning of five National Goals and Directive Principles outlined in the Constitution. They are: “These wordings are critical and are not just mere rhetoric,” he said. “We must bring back the National Goals and Directive Principles into the conversation for practical application, policy formulation and decision-making.”

Title: Three generations, one journey
Content: ON Sept 16, 1975, my mother, with thousands of Papua New Guineans, not in Port Moresby, heard of the raising of our new flag for the first time. She was pregnant with me then — just four months from bringing me out into a country that, like me, was still waiting to take its first tentative steps. She and my late father were in Lorengau, Manus, that day. There was music and tears, dancing and speeches, but above all there was a sense of hope – hope for a fresh start, hope for unity, and hope for a better life for the next generation. I was one of that next generation, not yet born, but already belonging to the story of an independent Papua New Guinea. I was born in January, 1976. My life commenced in the first chapter of PNG’s life as a Sovereign State. In some ways, my course has resembled hers, one of dreams, tribulations, lessons learned and growth. Coming of age in a new nation, I was raised as a child in a nation in the process of finding itself. The early days of independence were hopeful and fraught. We were an eclectic people that learned to walk together, considering development of the modern as well as the ancient traditions with us. I remember the slow, simple days, pre-smartphone, pre-instant communication, when I was getting letters written by hand, listening to the transistor, walking the dusty roads. But I also remember the strength of families, the strength of community and the determination to be part of something better. PNG was young, and so was I. Eventually, I found my path in the media industry — a career that has now spanned 26 years. It has been one of the great privileges of my life to tell the story of this country, to give voice to its challenges, its accomplishments and its people. In the course of my career, I have seen history being made. I’ve seen governments come and go, policies fought and protested, roads constructed, protests and celebrations held. I’ve encountered everyday Papua New Guineans involved in extraordinary acts during their daily lives, and I’ve witnessed the indomitable spirit that pushes us along, even when progress seems slow. But I’ve also witnessed the difficulties – corruption, inequality and missed opportunities. Along with many Papua New Guineans, I have asked why such a richly blessed nation with resources and talent has not yet realized its full potential. But even in the midst of these frustrations, I am hopeful — because I have seen what we can do when we are united. In parallel with PNG’s 50th independence, I’ve been doing some personal reflection about my own pending milestone. I’m 49 years old and have almost experienced every second of this nation’s story — growing, changing, learning and discovering her strength right beside her. And now, I look at my 20-year-old daughter, who will reach that milestone in December — a mere three months after our nation hits half a century. Her life embodies the future my mother hoped for on that Independence Day in 1975. I hold the same hopes for my daughter today — that she may grow up in a country where her dreams can come true, that opportunities are broader, that her generation can lead with courage, wisdom and compassion. Turning 50 is more than a number — for me and for Papua New Guinea. It’s a time to step back, take stock and decide what sort of future we want to build. What I’m hoping is simple: That the dreams of 1975, the dreams my mother harbored and the dreams I harbor today, will at long last become reality for my daughter’s generation. That we invest in our people, protect our cultures and embrace unity while we celebrate diversity. That we are responsible for our leaders, and that we – as citizens – own how we come to our collective fate. My country and I, we have travelled a long and windy road together – and we both hear the clock strike midnight on our fourth decade, I’m more convinced than ever that my country’s most exciting chapters are ahead. For just as with the child my mother bore on Independence Day, Papua New Guinea carries something valuable still — the potential. I will think of my daughter as an entering young adult and the road my daughter’s generation has ahead of its. And I will whisper the promise my mother held in her heart: “We are still here. We are still growing. And we’re just getting started.”

Title: Safety first during celebrations: Ambulance
Content: SAFETY and responsibility must be at the heart of our celebrations, says National St John Ambulance interim chief executive Dr Arabella Koliwan. “Our data shows that the number of emergencies our ambulance service team responds to doubles on Independence Day,” she said in a statement on Friday. “I urge everyone to celebrate safely and responsibly.” Koliwan provided important guidelines for a safe and memorable celebration which are: If you see anyone in distress or requiring urgent help, call the toll-free 111, Koliwan said. She said: “Our ‘green angels will be on the ground throughout the celebrations. “Please don’t hesitate to visit our emergency tents and stations if you need help. “As we celebrate Independence, National St John reaffirms its commitment to saving lives, providing critical emergencymedical assistance, and delivering compassionate care. “We remain dedicated to serving communities across our nation with courage and compassion, just as we have done for generations. “While we embrace this momentous occasion, safety and responsibility must be at the heart of our celebrations.”

Title: Business houses donate to NCD, Central police
Content: MORE than five business houses in Port Moresby on Wednesday presented food and cash worth more than K30,000 to police in the National Capital District (NCD) and Central to support operations in the city. Assistant police commissioner (NCD and Central) Benjamin Turi thanked the four nightclubs and a food company for their donations. He said this is a way forward to strengthen the idea of police and communities working together. “The four nightclubs – Night Club Breeze, Kundu Club, V8 Club and Chili Club – donated food and cash worth more than K15,000, of which K10,000 was given in cash to support them with fuel,” Turi said Turi said PNG Premium Food Industries donated food worth more than K14,000, which will be distributed to all police stations and the specialist sections to use during operations. He thanked the business houses and is looking forward to more support from other business houses so that police operations will be successful.

Title: Untrained public service served well: Former kiap
Content: A RETIRED public servant who served as akiapin the early 1970s has described how Papua New Guinea gained its independence on Sept 16, 1975. Anton Naseph Wulia, 76, of the Sulka people of Ganaii i n Kokopo’s Bitapaka, shared his experience. Wulia joined as akiapin 1971 when he was only 20 years old and was serving in Southern Highlands. When planter Jack Emmanuel was murdered at Gazelle’s Kabaira in 1971, Gough Whitlam became Prime Minister in 1975, the same year PNG gained its independence. Wulia said during Whitlam’s term as prime minister, he fast-tracked the independence for PNG and extracted all Australia senior public servants serving, leaving behind a big vacuum in all structures of the public service. “I am not afraid to say this and this is the truth, the Australians – cheated us,” Wulia said. “During my time, I was almost everything you can think about in terms of public service. “I was a policeman and also a magistrate because of the shortage of manpower in the rural areas. I exercised a public service role as akiap. “One of the things I realised as mystery is there is a letter written to all the Australian public servants to leave the country and anyone who wanted to stay back will lose their gratuity payment. “They threatened all Australian public servants leaving behind under-trained national staff,” Wulia said. He claims that the education level today is very low or poor compared with the past, before independence. As akiap, Wulia served in Southern Highlands, Manus and in his home province ENB. He resigned from public service after 22 years of service. After leaving public service, Wulia started his own consultancy service in land matters. “I am very happy that I am still around to celebrate and witness this 50 years’ anniversary, my only regret is our generation now are not prepared to take this nation forward,” he said.

Title: Bali-Witu enjoy safe celebrations
Content: THE two-days pre-independence celebrations on Witu Island of Talasea’s Bali-Witu, West New Britain concluded in a safe and peaceful manner, drawing widespread community participation and support. WNB tourism officer Gilton Tagara toldThe Nationalthat the occasion was honoured by the presence of Governor Sasindran Mutuvel, Talasea MP Freddie Kumai and community members. Tagara said two leaders highlighted the importance of unity, cultural pride and reflection as Papua New Guineans prepared to celebrate its 50th Independence Anniversary tomorrow. Tagara said the two leaders’ engagement with the local community signified strong leadership and commitment to the ongoing journey of nationhood. Tagara explained that the celebration featured traditional dances, cultural performances and community showcases that not only reflected the rich heritage of Witu Island but also demonstrated the resilience and togetherness of its people. “These cultural expressions reaffirm the enduring values that have sustained communities since independence in 1975, while also inspiring younger generations to uphold and preserve their traditions,” Tagara said. “As the nation looks forward to the Golden Jubilee of Independence, this milestone event on Witu Island served as a reminder of the collective responsibility to protect cultural identity, foster development, and strengthen unity across all levels of society.” He said the people of the island have set a strong example of how local celebration contribute to the national spirit.

Title: Moving into the next 50 years
Content: PARENTS, teachers, lecturers and everyone have been told to invest well in education as the country moved into the next 50 years. Higher Education Minister Kinoka Feo made this announcement on Thursday during the launching of the Education Sector Development Plan (ESDP) 2023-2027 for the Education Department. “Fifty years ago, our fathers rose to their feet and declared, we are one people, one nation, under God, free and independent,” he said. “Today, we do not just look back, we look forward and we ask what will the next 50 years look like?” Feo said the answer is clear, the future will be written in classrooms, the lecture halls, the workshops and the research labs of Papua New Guinea, the future will be written in the minds of the children. He said the plan that was launched was not just any plan but a national contract with the future. “This plan carries K4.19 billion of investment where it invests in early childhood education because the child who starts well, finishes strong. “It strengthens primary and secondary schools because literacy and numeracy are the foundation and cornerstones of every nation,” Feo said. “It expands technical and vocational training because not every child must wear a tie but every child must have a skill.” He said this plan raises the standard in teacher training and accreditation because a teacher who is empowered would empower a generation.” “The plan also builds the bridges to universities, to science, to research, to innovation because this is the age of knowledge and knowledge is power, therefore this plan needs support from everyone to make it work,” Feo said. He stressed that a plan cannot teach a child, cannot inspire a classroom and cannot raise a nation. “It is only when we together, government, teachers, churches, parents, private sector, students, development partners – only when we rise together and implement this plan, then and only then will it become life and light to Papua New Guinea,” Feo said. “Teachers, you must teach with passion, not just for a salary but for the soul of a nation, parents must value your child’s education and we leaders must resource this plan, not just promise, but we must deliver.”

Title: Morobe prepares to receive governor’s casket
Content: MOROBE has begun planning and preparations to receive its leader Governor Luther Akisawa Wenge who died in Port Moresby after a short illness. Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso had an emergency meeting yesterday with the provincial administration and northern command Assistant Police Commissioner Peter Guinness following the confirmation of Wenge’s passing on Saturday morning. “I came to inform the administration and plan on how we will be able to work towards receiving this body for State burial,” Rosso said. “I will take charge of preparations, liaising with provincial and national government to ensure that we receive our governor’s body with the greatest respect he deserves. “We will make that announcement in an official press statement on Wednesday,” he said. Rosso said meantime, 50th independence anniversary celebrations in Lae and the province will continue. “It is impossible to hold-off as celebrations are already midway,” he said. “This is a national event and planned before the tragic news. “But make no mistake, Morobe is mourning, there will be appropriate arrangements made to honour his legacy.”

Title: Joint forces march to mark 50th anniversary
Content: ONE-HUNDRED-AND-FIFTY-ONE joint forces members marched in a show of strength from town to Eriku in Lae on Friday to mark the 50th independence anniversary. The forces included 23 members of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF), 36 cadets, 30 Joint Forces Academy (JFA) members, 37 Correctional Institute Services (CIS) per personnel, five Australian Defence Force members with pipes and drums, 25 Police band members, Lae City Authority with 35 pipes and drums trainees, and 34 scouts. The show of strength march started at Second Street in town with formation and inspection. The forces later marched to Eriku oval to complete the programme. Northern Assistant Commander Peter Guinness addressed the parade, stating that he was honoured to be part of the milestone that marked half century of the independence of Papua New Guinea (PNG). “It is fitting to host the parade in Lae to signify what we are here to celebrate,” he said. “It is not just an ordinary celebration, this year marks 50 years of freedom and sovereignty, and perseverance for the people of PNG. “We as responsible citizens must stand together in unity to preserve and promote our democratic values and that’s the reason why countries have the armed forces because they are the pride of the nation. “For us, we have the Defence Force, Police Force and the Correctional Services. “It’s something we are proud of. And I am proud to say that I have served the country for 50 consecutive years with distinction and unblemished record.” Guinness said that during his years of being in the disciplinary force, he had not faced any disciplinary charge, and he was still standing and would gracefully retire from the RPNG service. “Therefore, we must serve and guard the sovereign right of PNG by upholding our respective codes of ethics in our respective organisations,” he said. “We all have code of ethics and we have to live by them. “They are the directing principles that guides us.”

Title: Give more powers to provinces
Content: PAPUA New Guinea has spent nearly 50 years talking about giving power to the people. The problem is, it rarely follows through. Decentralisation wasn’t a policy bolt-on – it was baked into the country’s founding logic. But the way it’s been handled since independence? That’s a different story. One of hesitation, sabotage, and a slow bleed of local agency. That drift must end. Decentralisation shouldn’t just be an idea to be tossed around or mulled over in every other Parliament sitting. It is an urgent necessity. Before independence, the Constitutional Planning Committee (CPC) laid out a vision. In its 1973 interim reports, the CPC made it clear: most people wanted district governments with real teeth. Bougainville, already pushing for autonomy, submitted its own draft model. The CPC responded by proposing a three-way meeting – national leaders, CPC members, Bougainville reps – to hash out interim arrangements. These weren’t vague aspirations. They were structural demands, laid out before the ink dried on the Constitution. The CPC didn’t want decentralisation to be a bureaucratic gesture. It wanted political decentralisation – actual legislative and executive power at the local level. That vision led to the 1976 Organic Law on Provincial Government. Provinces got elected assemblies, premiers, and control over education, health, infrastructure. It looked promising. But it didn’t last. Assemblies were underfunded, lacked capacity, and couldn’t deliver. Public trust eroded. Between 1983 and 1995, most provincial governments were suspended for “non-performance”. The national government kept the power to intervene, and it used it. In the early ’90s, the 1995 Organic Law on Provincial Governments and Local-Level Governments (OLPGLLG) changed everything. Direct provincial elections were gone. Governors became national MPs. Assemblies were filled with Open MPs, LLG reps, and appointed members. LLGs – over 300 of them – were formally recognised, but their powers were limited. It looks like power-sharing, but it’s not. Since then, PNG has tried autonomy in patches. Bougainville, after a decade-long war, got autonomous status in 2001 under the Bougainville Peace Agreement. Its government controls policing, education, taxation. It’s the most advanced model in PNG, but it’s fragile – dependent on national funding and political goodwill. The 2019 referendum, where 97.7 per cent voted for independence, still hangs in limbo. Other provinces – East New Britain, Enga, New Ireland – have pushed for more autonomy under the OLPGLLG. But the national government has been slow to respond. Legal ambiguities persist The CLRC’s 2014 review of the OLPGLLG said it plainly: the law doesn’t clearly define who does what. A centralised government allows for uniform policy implementation across all provinces, like a one-size-fits-all deal, but some of these policies don’t work everywhere. Provinces are not developing at the same rate – some lag behind but would not have to if all provinces managed their own finances and affairs. And where centralised financial control may reduce mismanagement at sub-national levels, that only depends on enforcement and transparency. If there is no transparency, the risk of misuse goes up. Meanwhile, the provinces, districts and LLGs remain under or unevenly funded, which leads to service delivery breakdown, eroded trust and political alienation. Bougainville’s referendum wasn’t symbolic; it was a direct response to decades of neglect. New Ireland, under former Governor Late Sir Julius Chan, was making strides in their push for autonomy with their efforts to be a self-sufficient province. But here’s the thing: decentralisation was never optional for PNG. With over 800 languages and communities scattered across mountains and islands, centralised governance isn’t just inefficient, it’s impossible. Local governments aren’t just closer to the people. They’re the only ones who can respond to their needs. When they’re underfunded, undertrained, and politically neutered, the consequences are obvious: broken clinics, failing schools and roads that vanish in the wet season. This is even more so when provinces are met with natural disasters. In the time the national government takes to consolidate its resources to help, local leadership could be able to step up. The stakes couldn’t be higher. Decentralisation could bring political stability, especially in places like Bougainville. It could also unlock development solutions tailored to local realities. But that takes more than lip service. It demands legal clarity, financial transparency, and a real commitment to sharing power. The OLPGLLG needs fixing. Revenue-sharing must be streamlined. Local officials need training, resources, and authority. And national leaders need to stop treating local governance like a threat, and start treating it like the foundation it was meant to be. Right now, PNG’s decentralisation is a half-kept promise. The structures are there. The substance isn’t. If the country wants to move forward, it needs to stop pretending power has been devolved and start making it real. Power was supposed to flow outward. Time to unblock the pipes.

Title: Vanimo Primary School celebrates with cultural dances
Content: VANIMO Primary School (VPS) in West Sepik kicked off Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations on Wednesday, thrilling the crowd with vibrant student cultural dances. The opening gathering drew key figures including Vanimo-Green MP Belden Namah and acting provincial administrator Eric Sakin, sparking joy among the school community. Namah donated K20,000 to the school to support the anniversary programmes, paving the way for a series of memorable events. VPS headmaster Paul Pohu welcomed the guests and thanked them for the backing that made the programmes possible. “Our students are thrilled to showcase PNG’s diverse traditions,” he said. “These activities build their understanding of our hard-won independence.” Young dancers, adorned in grass skirts and feathers, moved to traditional tunes representing cultures from across the nation. Families and locals watched in delight as the performers twirled and stomped in perfect rhythm. Namah stressed education’s key role in building the country and also calling for greater community engagement. “We need to support our schools for a brighter PNG,” he told parents and everyone who gathered there. Sakin supported the message, applauding the school’s push for unity. Other notable guests included Miss Bird of Paradise of Sandaun Carol Hwena and West Sepik acting police commander Senior Insp Silas Kuaino, who were also part of the programme. The celebrations had set the tone for a week of fun and education, building up to anniversary day tomorrow. Vanimo Primary, a longstanding pillar in the province, marks this golden jubilee as a proud highlight for staff and students. The West Sepik authorities were encouraging locals to join upcoming activities and reflect on PNG’s progress since 1975.

Title: Fun and games from 50 years ago
Content: SMALL boys missed a few opportunities for play 50 years ago. Shrieks of laughter and shouting would often reveal the whereabouts of a group of small boys sliding down a steep slope on a section of banana-stem or cardboard carton. Pig bladders became “soccer balls”, and games were soon underway between groups of small boys, while waiting for food to cook during feasts. Children in coastal areas had the sea as their playground. Beautifully made model sailing boats were also raced by children from many coastal villages. Girls had much less time to play. At an early age, they had their energy channelled into practical activities. Tiny girls were often given miniature digging sticks to play with. Older girls became responsible for looking after younger children and family piglets. However, many girls were able to turn that work into play. In some parts of Papua New Guinea, older girls and women entertained themselves and others during their limited leisure times with almost endless numbers of string-figure patterns, often accompanied by stories. Not all games were “just for fun”. Some traditional boy’s games developed skills that would be needed in adulthood, such as quick reflexes required to dodge arrows in tribal battles. Others were to encourage crop growth. For a few weeks each year, ritual spinning-top games were played by men and boys in both the highlands and lowland parts of Papua New Guinea. In the Highlands, the games were played to encourage the development of karuka nuts. In lowland areas, where yams were an important crop, such as the Sepik, spinning-top games were played to encourage the growth of large tubers. Traditionally, with each spin of a top, special words were said to encourage crop growth. Various wheeled toys, wilkas (wheel-cars), that were pushed by a stick or pulled on a string were popular in many parts of Papua New Guinea 50 years ago. The range of ‘wheels’ was almost infinite from cotton-reels to truck tyres, and included discs cut from tree-trunks and fig-fruit. One type resembled a modern grand prix racing car. It was made by attaching between four and eight fig-fruit wheels to a section of banana-leaf midrib. The midrib had a notch cut into it to receive the combined steering and pushing stick. Wheeled toys that were pushed and steered by a stick or length of pitpit cane were most common. As excited small boys pushed them along narrow winding footpaths, they were often accompanied by realistic sounds of a truck double-declutching (‘double-im’) and changing gears. Wheeled toys that were pulled along by string were less common than ‘pusher’ types. Another ‘wheel’ variation was a hoop that could be an old bicycle wheel-rim or cane bent to form a circle that was pushed and steered by hitting with a ‘paddle’, often made from the base of a palm leaf. A ‘game’ that was definitely not for children were greasy-pole competitions. They generally took place at non-traditional gatherings; often to celebrate the completion of a project. Young men formed teams in an attempt to get one of their members to the top of the pole and collect the prizes. The prizes often included money, cooking utensils and tools. Greasy-pole competitions were a great spectator sport. In addition to rugby league, many games were introduced to Papua New Guinea by Australians. Local versions of volleyball, soccer, basketball and cards (‘laki’) were played throughout the country. One of those games, Trobriand cricket, has become truly New Guinean and bears little resemblance to the original.

Title: ‘Unseen’ hands that built a nation
Content: FOR 50 years, the stitches and the stone, Were set by hands that worked to build a home. Not just of bricks, but of a nation’s soul, A quiet strength that made the different parts whole. They faced the shadows, the anger, and the pain, Weathered the storm and the silent, falling rain. They stood their ground through all the violence they knew, Their spirits brave, and resolute, and true. The bird of paradise, with wings of red and gold, Soared over hills from which of no turning back. A future painted on a tapa, With hopeful yellow and the white of things to last. They learned to wear trousers and the grass skirts too, A testament to what their hands could do. They built a nation from a blend of lands,tok plesand cultures, With courage in their hearts and in their hands. With skilful hands, they’d sew and weave a newbilum, For the silent victories they carry in it. They roll the dough and lovingly knead, And pick the harvest to sow the future’s seed. They carry burdens and they learned to drive, They massage weary souls and keep them strong. In quiet moments, there were tears and kisses too, And moments filled with laughter, bold and new. The stop and cry for all the hopes they’d lost, But carried on, no matter what the cost. From the womb, held the nation’s future child, Their backbone strong, their spirits light. They bore the weight upon their sturdy shoulders, The silent architects, the nation’s steadfast holders. With shells and tusks, and feathers bright and grand, They sang the stories of the troubled land. The rhythm of thekundu, a sacred beat, The mightykumul, rising from defeat. With folded hands and bowed heads in quiet prayers, They found the strength to bear their heavy cares. The pages of the Bible, worn and thin, Held the quiet faith that helped the work begin. They rocked the babies, holding futures in their arms, The hands gave voice to the silent. They cared for health, with skill and mind. In every humble kitchen, warm and bright, They stirred the soup and worked from day to night. And in the morning, brewed the steaming coffee strong, For all the ones who needed to belong. They wove the strongest baskets from the vine, A symbol of a sacred, shared design. Their work, a quiet fire, burning ever deep, The promises their generations had to keep. The bedrock built on quiet, endless love, A nation lifted by the strength of the hands. Their legacy is etched against the stars in the sky, The nation-builders whose work will never end. They were the bedrock, steadfast, strong, and true, The nation-builders in the background, you.

Title: The Somare legacy: Leave PNG in a better state than when you received it
Content: SIR Michael led Papua New Guin­ea, together with many eminent and many more unnamed and faceless Papua New Guineans from across the country, to lay the foun­dations of our political independ­ence. They gave us the opportunity to use our immeasurable resources to sustain our sovereignty. It was a time when the winds of political change were sweeping across the South Pacific, South­east Asia, and the Indochina re­gion. Across our wider region, the forces of socialism, communism, and military rule were also rising, shaping and influencing nations in profound ways. Papua New Guinea, however, gained independence without bloodshed or military domination. Our forefathers guided this country into nationhood while protecting our cultural identity and indig­enous rights, embedding those rights firmly within our Constitu­tion. Our Constitution became the framework that created and shaped the laws which regulate and man­age life in our society. In less than 50 years – stretch­ing across four generations – my grandfather, my father, myself and now my son, have each lived under this system. Each generation has been ex­posed to a foreign framework of governance and society, adapting and contributing something new to Papua New Guinea’s growth. The knowledge and wisdom car­ried from one generation to the next have multiplied, strengthen­ing the foundation for the future. Today, I am standing in my son’s generation, just as my father once stood before mine. The knowledge and experiences I have gathered; I will pass on to him. My expectation, just as my fathers was of me, is that each gen­eration should leave Papua New Guinea in a better state than when we inherited it. This is the legacy that I bring to you, the legacy of Sir Michael So­mare, my father. I want to share my reflections about his patience, wisdom, and vision, and why I believe he left Papua New Guinea a better place, filled with opportunities for my generation. It is also why I feel obligated to ensure that my own children in­herit a country where they can live with dignity, hope and pride. The story of Sir Michael stretches across these four generations. He lived for 86 years, and his presence, leadership and values have pro­foundly shaped the chapters of our nation’s journey. I have cited publicly available data from independent institutions that have observed Papua New Guinea’s development over three of these four generations. The World BankFigure 1(below) from Trade Economics, provide a glimpse of Papua New Guinea’s growth. I have taken this opportunity to superimpose Sir Michael’s final nine-year tenure as Prime Minis­ter to show that he did leave PNG, in an economic sense, far better off than when he entered in 2002. Figure 1below shows the GDP of Papua New Guinea, courtesy of Trade Economics, (link pro­vided) I have not plotted his time­line on the graph but you can follow from his political life as I have summarised here. Sir Michael Somare served as Papua New Guinea’s Chief Minister from 1972 (when self-government began) until independence in 1975, then became the nation’s first Prime Minister from 1975 to 1980. He returned as Prime Minister from 1982 to 1985 and again from 2002 to 2011. His official retirement from poli­tics was in 2017, and he spent a total of 17 years as Prime Minister across these separate terms. Sir Michael played a pivotal role through eras of major change, leading PNG to political independ­ence and guiding its political devel­opment over multiple generations. But, he did more than that, he prepared PNG for economic inde­pendence as well, as seen inFig­ure 1where 2002 to 2011 showed the largest GDP growth ever achieved by a government under a single Prime Minister. Figure 2, below (BPNG Data, link provided) shows the external pub­lic debt, andFigure 3, (BPNG Data, link provided) the domestic public debt andFigure 4, the combined data for external and domestic debt. 2002 saw the highest level of debt seen by PNG, Sir Michael took ownership and designed the eco­nomic solutions, reduced level of external debt and borrowing. The economic turnaround was immediate and sustained as debt was curtailed and he designed gov­ernment policy that spurred on the largest wave of investor confidence PNG has ever seen. We have had two successive Gov­ernments that we can now meas­ure and compare how government policy initiatives, legislative and fiscal stability and resource utilisa­tion has impacted the economy. Figure 3 shows the maintenance of legislative and fiscal policy stability and the separation of responsibilities with BPNG management of monetary policy reflecting sustained linear growth in domestic debt under Sir Michael’s political leadership. 2011 to 2019 saw record exponential growth in both domestic and external public debt being achieved and that carried forward past 2019 to today. Figure 4is plotted from data from the Bank of PNG from “the Quarterly Economic Bulletin” (QEB). The QEB provides a very interesting read including data and provides Papua New Guineas the visibility to make an independent assessment of economic conditions. Sir Michael’s journey encapsulates this theme of leaving our country in better stead than what we inherited is best depicted in the first graph, “PNG GDP” this is best read, keeping in mind that he did not stay for consecutive terms until 2002 where he was Prime Minister for just short of two terms. He envisaged the “Sovereign Wealth Fund” for PNG that was tied to the development of the largest resource projects PNG has ever seen PNG LNG and paved the way forward for economic expansion. In 2014, the first gas from PNG LNG left PNG shores and now, 11 years have passed with two successive governments and proceeds from PNG LNG have not entered the Sovereign Wealth Fund. Figure 5(below) is a challenge to Papua New Guineans to take ownership of what we inherit reflect on it and find the solutions for us to leave a better future for our children to grow up in. In summary, the blue line was our economic trajectory under leadership of Sir Michael; the purple line represents where we are today and the green line is Papua New Guinea back on track for economic prosperity. The challenge for us today is to raise the purple curve back to the green curve to get Papua New Guinea back on track for a prosperous nation for our future generations.

Title: The little known story of Kina
Content: WHEN a team from the Central Bank of Papua New Guinea looked into redesigning some of the banknotes to commemorate the golden jubilee of the Kina and Toea, PNG’s national currency, they traced back history and stumbled upon Kagua, Southern Highlands. Much is known about Southern Highlands but little is known about Porane village in the Kagua local level government where Kina, Papua New Guinea’s upper unit of its national currency, was born. The story of Kina began with Sir Yano Belo on Saturday, April 19, 1975. Sir Yano was the member for Kagua-Erave and minister for works in the Michael Somare government in the soon-to-be Independent State of Papua New Guinea. During the first cabinet meeting on April 19, 1975, when names for PNG’s currency were proposed and tossed around, Sir Yano threw in the name “Kina”, for the higher denomination, and surprisingly it was unanimously accepted. Finance minister Sir Julius Chan proposed Toea, for the lower denomination. The rest, like they say, is history. But when reflecting on the birth of the currency, Sir Yano recalls that the names proposed and came to cabinet were chosen with careful deliberation, embodying the spirit, identity and dignity of the people. To make this legacy personal, Sir Yano revealed that, the Kina and Toea were also names given to his and Sir Julius’ respective sons, linking the family’s identity to that of the nation itself. Initially, “kina” is the name of the shell money from the coast which people hung around their necks as something valuable. Back then, it was highly valued and respected widely in the Highlands. According toThe National, the word “kina” means, according to a language of Western Highlands, “a store of wealth”. Kina, and of course Toea, as medium of exchange among our people dates back to prehistory and resembles a colourful aesthetic in unity in the transition from prehistory to colonialism as these valuables shells exchanges hands from the villages in the coast to highlands in time. The emergence of the Kina and Toea on the morning after independence came with its own jurisdiction defined and sanctioned primarily by the appearance of our national sovereignty, says Dr Andrew Moutu in his articleMore than a medium of exchange(The National, Sept 20, 2024). Kina and Toea are defined by jurisdiction and legitimised existence meaning it is an authority on its own. On Aug 28, 2025, Prime Minister James Marape unveiled the new K50 note and 50 toea coin at the currency commemorative launching at the Stanley Hotel & Suites in Port Moresby. Sir Yano was invited as a guest of honour at this historic event, which also announced the upcoming new K100 note, set for release on Jan 30, 2026, to commemorate the late Sir Julius Chan, whose vision had shaped the financial destiny of Papua New Guinea. When called up to speak at the event, Sir Yano paid homage to the late Sir Michael Somare, Sir Julius, and all founding fathers and stressed that the strength of a nation lay not only in its institutions but also in the character, integrity and vision of its leaders. He called upon all Papua New Guineans to respect the law, uphold the Constitution and protect the values instilled by the forefathers, reminding the audience that the blueprint of sovereignty, prosperity and divine destiny is embedded in the Constitution. Sir Yano concluded by declaring that the true power of the Kina and Toea would be realised through authentic leadership – leaders who serve, protect and honour the Constitution. The Kina and Toea continue to serve as a poignant reminder of the nation’s journey, its leaders’ vision, and the enduring spirit of Papua New Guineans as they celebrate 50 years of freedom and sovereignty. While Sir Julius, whose image may appear on the new K100 note, and immortalised across generations to come the story of Sir Yano Belo and Kina may hatch in the living memory of every Papua New Guinea.
People: James Marape, Julius Chan, Michael Somare, Sir Julius Chan

Title: A personal recollection: PNG’s 50 years
Content: ON the eve of celebrating Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary, I wish to reflect on the challenges, experiences, and hopes that shaped our nation’s journey – particularly from the early 1970s leading up to that historic day on Sept 16, 1975. Beginnings: Education and early career Looking back 55 years ago, in 1970, I had just completed Form 4 (Grade 10) at Bugandi High School in Lae. After spending an extended holiday in my home village of Lelefiru, Gulf, I unfortunately missed the opportunity to continue further education at Sogeri National High School. What seemed like a setback at the time turned into an opportunity. In 1971, I secured employment with Trans Australian Airlines (TAA). Back story: I walked in dressed rugged and the expatriate said to me, young man, go get cleaned up, long white socks and come back. Long story short, I quickly cleaned myself up and went back the next day, and there began my career as a trainee traffic officer in Lae at the age of 17. After three weeks of in-house training and three months of practical work in Port Moresby, I was well prepared to join Air Niugini when it began operations on Nov 1, 1973. Growing with Air Niugini From those beginnings, my career grew with the airline. Over 23 years, I held several key management positions in Mt Hagen, Rabaul, Popondetta, Madang, and later internationally in Singapore and Manila. I served as airport manager in Port Moresby, then as commercial director/marketing manager, and ultimately deputy general manager until my early retirement in 1996 due to medical reasons. During this period, Air Niugini became not just an airline, but a symbol of PNG’s identity. It established a training centre to upskill Papua New Guineans, replacing expatriates as their contracts expired. Many of us were sent overseas for specialised training, equipping us with the knowledge to lead in aviation and management. Mood before Independence – the excitement, the uncertainty… In the early 1970s, under the foresight and vision of our founding leaders – most notably the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare – PNG moved toward self-government in 1973. This laid the foundation for truly national institutions: Air Niugini, the PNG Banking Corporation, the Bank of PNG, theNational Broadcasting Corporation, and many others. There was, however, a sense of uncertainty. Many Australians working alongside us were leaving, convinced independence would bring chaos and bloodshed. Yet others stayed, and together we proved those fears unfounded. Sept 16, 1975: A nation is born I will never forget the day at Sir Hubert Murray Stadium when the Australian flag was lowered and the PNG flag was raised in its place. On Sept 16, 1975, independence was declared – and the world saw a young nation stand tall. There was no chaos. No bloodshed. Instead, there was joy, pride, and a deep sense of belonging. For me, the celebrations continued as I marked my 21st birthday the following month, on Oct 24, 1975, at the old Four-Mile Social Club in Port Moresby. A nation at 50 Fifty years on, I remain proud to have witnessed our country’s journey from colony to independent nation. I am proud to have played a small part in building Air Niugini into one of the Pacific’s most successful airlines, which itself celebrated its 50th anniversary in November 2023. Most of all, I am proud to be a Papua New Guinean. Congratulations, PNG, on your 50th Independence anniversary!

Title: Queensland’s PNG community marks 50 years of independence
Content: Thousands of members of Queensland’s Papua New Guinean community have celebrated half a century of the country’s independence with traditional music, dancing, art, and food. PNG was an Australian territory until Sept 16, 1975, when the country gained independence. To mark the country’s globally significant milestone, the PNG community in Queensland hosted a major festival on Saturday in Logan, south of Brisbane. About 5,000 persons were expected to attend the event, with people travelling from across Queensland, interstate and PNG. Papua New Guinea Federation Queensland Incorporated’s Veronica Henderson said the day was a celebration of culture and independence. She said there had been an “overwhelming response” from the community wanting to participate in this year’s annual event. “We’ve had to assist some of our provincial community groups because they’ve needed to bring people from PNG, not just people also the traditional wear that they needed to bring,” she said. Shanea Fletcher had a stall with handmade grass skirts and flower crowns at the event and said she was proud to share the colourful side of her culture. “The flower crowns are a statement piece,” she said. “They help us feel beautiful. “Independence is a celebration of my country, a coming together. “It’s a lovely warm community and just a wonderful celebration.” Henderson said Queensland also had a bigger PNG population than other states in Australia. The latest census data, from 2021, showed that 17,085 persons in Queensland said they were born in Papua New Guinea. PNG is made up of many different provinces that speak more than 800 languages. Henderson said the festival celebrated each group and their cultural identity through dance, and said they needed to add an extra stage to this year’s event to accommodate performers. “We haven’t turned anyone away,” she said. “We decided that we’d let everyone participate, and we created two stages.” The festival featured around 130 stalls, with a diverse array of traditional food on offer. “Food and celebration of the culture goes together,” Henderson said. “That’s what a lot of Papua New Guineans look forward to – eating food that has been cooked reminds them of home. “It taps into that sense of belonging to PNG.” Michael William Gorogo, from Central, was cooking traditional dishes and said the day meant celebrating his culture in his home away from home. “We’re never going to see this (anniversary) again, so for me 50 years is big,” he said. “We miss everything back home, so the food and dance means a lot to us.” Stall holder Emilia Taatu said it was a special celebration. “It means a lot to me and PNG has come a long way since 1975,” she said. “There’s a wonderful feeling of unity and oneness, we all live in different suburbs and this event brings us together.” – ABC

Title: Morobe government initiate planning to honour late governor Wenge
Content: THE Morobe Government has begun planning to receive its leader, late Governor Luther Akisawa Wenge, who died at the Port Moresby General Hospital after a short illness on Saturday. Deputy Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso called an emergency meeting with the provincial administration and Northern Command Assistant Police Commissioner Peter Guinness following the confirmation of Wenge’s passing. “I came to inform the administration and plan on how we will be able to work towards receiving his body for state burial,” Rosso said. “I will take charge of preparations, liaising with the provincial and national government to ensure that we receive our governor’s body with the greatest respect he deserves. “We will make that announcement in an official press statement on Wednesday.” Rosso said in the meantime, celebrations for the country’s 50th Independence anniversary in Lae and the province would continue as planned. “It is impossible to hold-off as celebrations are already midway,” Rosso said. “This is a national event and planned prior before the tragic news. “But make no mistake, Morobe is mourning; there will be appropriate arrangements made to honour his legacy.”

Title: ‘Unapologetic’, ‘fearless’ and ‘defender of the constitution’: Condolences pouring in on the passing of late ‘Songang’ Wenge.
Content: CONDOLENCE messages are pouring in for late Songang and Morobe Governor Luther Wenge, who passed away on Saturday morning at the Port Moresby General Hospital. Prime Minister James Marape confirmed Wenge’s passing after battling a short illness. The US Embassy in Port Moresby described Wenge as a visionary leader and extended their condolences to his family, the people of Morobe, and Papua New Guinea. East Sepik Governor Allan Bird paid tribute to Wenge as a strong, unapologetic voice, offering condolences to his family, tribe, and the people of Morobe. “We have lost a strong, unapologetic voice,” Bird said. “On behalf of the Sepik people, in recognition of our common cause: I offer our deepest condolences. Thank you for your service to our nation.” Tewai-Siassi MP Dr. Kobby Bomareo expressed deep sadness at the sudden passing of Morobe’s governor.Kobby described Wenge as outspoken, exuberant, a strong defender of the constitution. He said Wenge was a dedicated advocate for Morobe’s cause, whose voice would be missed in Parliament and the church.“Tewai-Siassi people share in the grief with the people of Morobe and the country, praying for peace during this time of sorrow,” Kobby said.Bougainville Regional member Peter Tsiamalili Jnr described Wenge as a courageous advocate for justice, a principled voice in national debates, and a true friend to Bougainville.“His fearless defense of fairness, unity, and respect, as well as his unwavering support during Bougainville’s most difficult times, will be remembered with deep gratitude,” Tsiamalili said.“Governor Wenge’s legacy lives on in Parliament, in the courts, and in the hearts of those who heard him speak truth to power.”Tsiamalili said as Papua New Guinea marked 50 years of independence, Wenge’s absence was deeply felt across the nation.He said Wenge’s life and memory remain a source of moral clarity and strength for Papua New Guineans. “The people of Bougainville join Morobe and the Wenge family in grief, honoring his contribution to democracy, peace, and self-determination,” Tsiamalili said. Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jnr also expressed his condolences on the passing of Wenge, saying his departure was a tremendous loss not only for his family but Morobe and the entire nation. “Governor Wenge was a formidable leader, he was bold, eloquent, and never afraid to speak the truth in Parliament,” Basil said. “When he spoke, he made us listen. He carried the voice of Morobe, its valleys, its mountains, its tribes, and his presence stretched from the highlands to the islands.” Basil said Wenge’s courage, his legal mind, and his faith were guiding lights in his service. He said Wenge believed in justice, in equity, and in the promise of a better Morobe and Papua New Guinea.
People: Allan Bird, James Marape, Kobby Bomareo, Luther Wenge, Sam Basil

Title: Morobe Governor Luther Wenge passes on
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape and Deputy Prime Minister John Rosso this morning announced the passing of Morobe Governor Luther Wenge at Port Moresby General Hospital. Both described Wenge’s passing as tragic and a great loss for the province but the nation. Rosso, who is also Lae MP, said it was a shock for the people of Morobe and for Papua New Guinea on the eve of our country’s 50th Independence celebrations. Wenge, a seasoned lawyer, dedicated his life to serving the people of Morobe as a three-term governor from 1997 to 2012 and in his current tenure since 2022. Rosso said this was marked by an unwavering commitment to justice, development, and the wellbeing of the province. Rosso said Wenge’s voice was always bold and uncompromising when it came to protecting the rights of our people. “My sincere condolences go to the Wenge family, his relatives, the people of Samangzing village, the people of Nawae, and the people of Morobe during this time of grief.” Marape said Wenge had undergone an urgent surgery to stop internal bleeding. “Despite the tireless efforts of our best medical professionals, and with arrangements being made for further treatment, complications arose due to underlying diabetic conditions. “His vital organs collapsed, and after several hours of resuscitation attempts, he was placed on life support. “At around 4am (this morning), doctors confirmed that he had not recovered, and he remained on life support only by machine assistance. “After giving time for his family to be present, medical staff have now withdrawn support, and we confirm with sadness that our senior leader has passed on.” Marape acknowledge the doctors and medical staff who did everything humanly possible and to thank the Leader of Government Business for coordinating emergency care. Marape said Wenge served the people, of Morobe and PNG,with great distinction and courage over many years.
People: James Marape, John Rosso, Luther Wenge

Title: People will be biggest losers: O’Neill
Content: FORMER Prime Minister, Peter O’Neill says Papua New Guineans will be the “biggest losers” in regards to the Government’s decision to switch banks. O’Neill said: “The decision by Government to switch its banking arrangements from a publicly-owned, dual stock exchange-listed, and well-known bank established in PNG for nearly 70 years, to a government-controlled, freshly-formed bank licenced only eight months ago, is having a devastating impact on Papua New Guineans. “86 per cent of all shares in Bank South Pacific are owned by Papua New Guineans. “Yesterday the value of these shares was wiped out as the sensitive markets, already on high alert due to PNG’s massive corruption and certain grey-listing, reacted negatively to the news the Government was moving all government accounts to the National Banking Corporation. “The workers, retirees, landowners and everyday Papua New Guineans have been dealt a cruel blow. “Papua New Guineans own 86 per cent of BSP and thus, with the stroke of his pen, Marape has cost Papua New Guineans over two billion Kina (K2, 236,000,000) in one single day. “Markets will continue to punish the BSP share price in coming days as the full fallout from the government meddling is felt.” O’Neill said the impact of the decision on landowners would be “massive and unjustified” with Mineral Resources Development Company (MRDC) owning 15 per cent of all BSP shares. Just two months ago, MRDC, an institution mandated to invest landowners’ equity, an institution with the Prime Minister acting as the sole trustee shareholder, confirmed they had purchased 70 per cent of the BSP shares held by MVIL taking MRDCs total shareholding to 15 per cent of BSP, making MRDC the second largest shareholder. The MRDC managing director rightly said on July 18, 2025: “BSP is the best performing blue-chip company and recognised financial institution in the Pacific region, providing consistent shareholder returns.” “The landowner companies stated by MRDC as having bought the shares, namely Gobe, Moran, Kutubu, Gigira, Hides No.4, Juha; Angore, PNG LNG Pipeline, PNG LNG Plant Site, and three landowner companies from Ok Tedi, must be absolutely horrified and angry at what the Marape government has done to the value of their recent investment. “The Government would have known at the time that the MVIL shares were sold to these landowners that the value would be wiped out in less than two months. “This is a massive breach of trust and most likely insider-trading to deliberately bring down the value of BSP. “Workers and retirees – the holders of superannuation funds – have seen their investments crumble. “Our Pacific neighbours – the workers of the Solomon Island Islands and Fiji – have also suffered the same fate with their own super funds having invested in BSP has a safe, prudent company. “The timing of this decision could not be worse as PNG faces the tightening grip of the IMF; the Kina slides; jobs evaporate; public debt climbs, and the grey listing seems certain. “The negative impact on our country’s reputation is going to take decades to restore.”

Title: Kina Securities says potential impact of change immaterial
Content: KINA Securities Limited says the company is aware of the Papua New Guinea Government’s decision to transfer its accounts from commercial banks to the National Banking Corporation Limited. The company stated that it was also aware of the potential financial impact of the accounts transfer. In a market release, Kina Securities stated that they were aware of a recent announcement regarding a decision by the Government through the National Executive Council to instruct a number of Government departments and State-owned Enterprises to transfer accounts from commercial banks to the National Banking Corporation Limited. “Kina has conducted an initial assessment of our diversified portfolio, indicating that if these changes are fully implemented, the potential impact on Net Profit After Tax (NPAT) from transferring these accounts from the government sector is not material,” the Company said. “Kina will continue to inform the market in line with its continuous disclosure obligations.”

Title: Competition in banking is essential for growth, prosperity, says Minister
Content: STATE Enterprises Minister William Duma has welcomed the completion of the first tranche of the private equity raising by the National Banking Corporation (NBC). Duma said that the Government had backed the development of NBC so that the country could have real competition in the local banking system. “As our economy grows, competition between leading banks is essential,” Duma said. “The media have been talking about BSP, but the NEC decision is very clear in that there was absolutely no mention of BSP. “If BSP had consulted its biggest shareholder, Kumul Consolidated Holdings about the impact of the NEC decision prior to releasing its statement to the stock exchange, these issues would have been managed better. “But BSP, unfortunately, did not do so. “Having competition might not sit well with some who have had it good for too long, but that is the reality of economy becoming stronger.” He described the comments by the former prime minister Peter O’Neill on the matter as “mostly incorrect and reflect misunderstanding of the facts”. “This alarmist rhetoric can undermine investor confidence in Papua New Guinea, and ultimately deprive workers of their incomes, if we are not careful,” Duma said. “BSP is one of the most important business institutions in our country and around the Pacific, and this does not change. “As a businessman, (O’Neill) knows that competition is healthy for the economy, and this is what is happening. “So he should get behind positive change instead of talking it down. “Look at our neighbours like Australia. “There is real competition between banks (which) is a good thing. “Our PNG is one of the largest depositors of funds, so it is in the interests of our people and our Government to have options, because with competition, the customer can expect better value when it comes to banks handling money.” Duma said the private equity raising was part of plans to reduce Government ownership of the bank after the initial public offering when NBC was listed on the Port Moresby Stock Exchange. He added: “When BPNG granted a commercial banking license in December 2024 to NBC, one of the conditions was for the Government to reduce its ownership from 100 per cent to a minority stake. “This is underway with more than 50 PNG-owned businesses and citizens investing K100 million in the National Banking Corporation. “We anticipate that NBC will raise of up to K300 million, further diluting the Government’s share.” He said that the other large banks in PNG were dominated by foreign shareholders. “NBC is the people’s bank in PNG, and shares will be sold to Papua New Guineans.”

Title: We hope to be the bank of choice, says Thornton
Content: MORE than 50 Papua New Guinea citizens and/or PNG Companies have become shareholders of the State-owned National Banking Corporation (NBC), says chief executive officer Paul Thornton. “A further K150 million to K200 million equity will be raised in the coming months to further broaden our shareholder base,” he said. “This will further dilute Government ownership in NBC. “An initial public offering to list NBC on the PNG Stock Exchange is planned for 2027 at which time, all Papua New Guineans will have the opportunity to hold shares in NBC.” Thornton said initially, it was anticipated that a number of Government Trust accounts would be moved to NBC. “This is a relatively small part of the Government’s Bank accounts,” he said. “With regard to timing and extent of the transfer of government accounts to NBC, any movement of banking arrangements will be done in an orderly fashion. “We know that many SOEs have long standing banking relationships with various commercial banks. We wish to be an additional banker to the SOEs (State-owned enterprises) and over time by providing good customer service and product delivery, we hope to be their bank of choice.” “One of the reasons for additional banking licences being issued last year was to create competition. “Sometimes competition can look to be chaotic, but in the end, competition provides customers with genuine choice. “NBC is looking to provide the people of Papua New Guinea with that choice.”

Title: Sir Michael’s wisdom ‘came from experience’
Content: THE late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare not only achieved the once-impossible dream of independence but also listened to wise counsel, establishing foundations that lifted Papua New Guineans from the colonial shadows tosovereignty. Dulciana Somare-Brash, the youngest daughter of Sir Michael who spoke yesterday during a seminar hosted by the Somare Institute of Leadership and Governance (Silag) in Port Moresby, said her father was unmoved by external pressures forged a hit with decisions grounded in deep cultural understanding, refusing to let outside voices drown out the wisdom of his own experiences. “Half a century on, we find ourselves at a crossroads where tradition and progress collide, villages in Port Moresby stand proudly in their original forms yet now they are flanked by rising modern buildings,” she said. Somare-Brash said these transformation and technology advancement marked the regeneration of highly-educated Papua New Guineans “bridging the wisdom of our ancestors with the promising of the future”. “We’re standing at the crossroads, beneficiaries and extraordinary transformation over just five decades and as we reflect our progress, and we must grasp the weight of this moment and boldly shape our future, honouring the legacy of those who came before us while forging a destiny worthy of our aspirations,” she added. Somare-Brash said against the backdrop of 50 years of nationhood, PNG is the living testament to the resilience and adaptability of her father and founding fathers and mothers of this nation. She also mentioned that the recent civil unrest and conflict cast a shadow over the country’s progress, underscoring the urgent need for unity as country the moved forward, “Now, more than ever, there is an urgent need for robust commercial study and principal negotiations that reflect PNG’s dynamic landscape and ensure truly equitable outcomes for our people,” she said. “Recognising the urgency of transformative change is imperative that we prioritise bold, macroeconomic reforms alongside microeconomic strategies that directly enhance household incomes, especially in the informal sectors, SMEs, and MSME.” Somare-Brash added that time has come to demand transparent access to the nation’s vast resources and to renegotiate terms that empower communities and secure economic future. She further urged Papua New Guineans to unite in protecting the country’s environment, culture and heritage, warning that climate change and environmental degradation are already threatening lives, traditions and security.

Title: Importance of respect emphasised to students
Content: IN a powerful pre-independence sermon at East New Britain’s LionHeart Christian Academy (LCA), school chairman Graham Ndrou delivered a passionate message to students emphasising the importance of respecting leaders and understanding God’s role in nation-building. Ndrou told the students that regardless of political challenges, citizens must respect their leaders, believing that such reverence ultimately honoured God. He highlighted that Papua New Guinea’s true foundation lies not in political figures but in divine guidance. “You must always respect your leaders. You need to understand when you respect them, God will honour you,” he said. “God is the God of our nation. It is not our prime minister; it is not all the members.” Ndrou noted that God establishes and dismantles kingdoms according to His divine will. He encouraged students to discipline themselves, pray daily and remain faithful, asserting that God is the ultimate architect of nations. “Your job is to discipline yourself, study every day and let God take care of you,” he said. The daily events, which included a devotion discussion on leadership, a quiz, fun games and a symbolic cake-cutting ceremony celebrating the birth of PNG as an independent nation, provided a vibrant backdrop to thechairman’s inspirational message. Ndrou’s message resonated with a powerful call to youth to respect leadership, seek God’s vision and maintain personal discipline, they can become future nation-builders who honoured both their country and their faith. “PNG belongs to God. You want to be great in life, you go to God first and God will bless you in Heaven,” he said.

Title: Marape rejoins PIF leaders
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has re-joined his 14 counterparts of the Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) at the PIF Leaders’ meeting to sign the Pacific Resilience Treaty. The treaty is a first of such arrangement established by PIF-member countries and is a commitment from them to create a financial institution that will operate as a sustainable “superfund”. This innovative approach is designed to provide a more efficient, community-centred and accessible mechanism for funding vital climate adaptation, disaster preparedness and loss and damage projects across the region. Key details about the Pacific Resilience Facility treaty are: It is a “first for the Pacific established by the Pacific”; The facility is designed to provide grants or loans without negatively impacting their credit ratings. The facility is built around two main pillars: The signing of this treaty marks a significant step toward regional self-reliance in managing climate resilience and security. It is a demonstration of the seriousness of the region’s commitment to its people and the support of its partners.

Title: Pacific media barred from Albanese’s press conference
Content: AUSTRALIAN officials barred all Pacific Island media to cover the press conference by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on the sidelines of the 54th Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting in Honiara, the Solomon Islands, on Wednesday. Albanese arrived in Honiara on Wednesday with all the Australian media reporting on issues surrounding geopolitics between China and Australia in the Solomon and the Pacific in recent days. Solomon Islands media personnel were so disappointed and called on their Media Association of Solomon Islands (Masi) and the PIF Secretariat to say something about the blunder. During a closed-door session inside the media centre at the Solomon Islands National Stadium, Albanese addressed Australian media with strict protocols by Australian officials not to allow any other journalists withinthe Pacific to attend and pose questions which included New Zealand media. All the Pacific Island media personnel felt intimidated and were curious to know what the “secret agenda” Albanese had to raise that he did not want to address and include Pacific Island media in the presser. When Albanese was asked by an Australian journalist about why Pacific journalists were barred from attending the presser, he said: “I don’t know what you are talking about mate.” Albanese then joined the 18-member PIF Leaders to sign the Blue Pacific as Ocean of Peace Declaration.

Title: Chief Justice launches Public Solicitor Mamu’s seventh book
Content: CHIEF Justice Sir Gibbs Salika launched Public Solicitor Leslie Mamu’s seventh book on Tuesday. The book titled, “Judicial Review in Papua New Guinea”, covers judicial review and administrative law in PNG, providing insights into these challenging areas. Sir Gibbs congratulated Mamu who worked hard and tirelessly despite his busy schedules to put this piece together. “I know for sure that this book would be very helpful, especially to students studying law,” he said. “I congratulate you for finding time in your busy schedules to put all these together.” Sir Gibbs said the book would be a valuable reference for those in the legal fraternity and the public. He urged those interested in knowing more about the judicial process in PNG to buy a copy. Mamu, from Nonga village in East New Britain’s Rabaul, has been practicing law for 17 years now. His seventh book covers topics like judicial review, leave to apply for judicial review, application for judicial review, remedies in judicial review, and judicial review appeal. Mamu said book writing took time and great effort to completing one. He challenged those that attended to translate their experience into books so that it would guide the upcoming ones who want to follow a similar path in life.

Title: K125 million European Union budget support
Content: THE European Union (EU) and Papua New Guinea, through the National Planning and Monitoring department, have signed on a K125 million budget support programme. The financing agreement is for the PNG State and Resilience Building Contract programme. It is part of the cooperation between PNG and EU through the Medium-term Development Plan Four. The EU investment will support forestry, water management, sanitation, and governance, according to EU Commissioner Jozef Sikela. Sikela had recently returned from EU-Pacific Investment Conference in Suva, Fiji, where EU announced a K1.5 billion climate action budget support for the Pacific Island countries. Last year the EU launched a K273 million similar programme support on forestry, climate, and biodiversity. He said that the support was part of EU’s Global Gateway initiative, a strategy to invest in sustainable development around the world. “PNG is a great partner to the EU and much of the work that PNG is doing to fighting climate change is commendable by the EU nations,” he said. “The first disbursement of one million Euro is already on its way, clear proof of Europe’s reliability as a partner. “The programme (that EU is supporting) will create a more predictable environment for investment and private sector growth in PNG. Meaning jobs, business opportunities, and long-term prosperity,”Sikela said. He said that EU and PNG could work together to create tangible benefits to local communities by boosting sustainable economic growth and bolstering their capacity to tackle climate challenges.
