The beneficiaries of the new budget support include the people of PNG through the line agencies: The budget support from EU follows the successful implementation and progress made by PNG within the frameworks of the ongoing budget support programme in good governance. Planning Minister Sir Ano Pala said the budget support on the eve of PNG’s 50th independence anniversary demonstrated a “maturity in the partnership” between PNG and EU.

Title: NZ army delivers food, medical gear to rural PNG
Content: A NEW Zealand Defence Force C-130J Hercules and two NH90 helicopters have delivered equipment, medical gear and clothing to remote areas of Papua New Guinea. The flights took place over two weeks, while the nation was celebrating its 50th anniversary of independence. Among No.40 Squadron’s C-130J deliveries were first aid equipment, clothing and books. The squadron’s liaison officer for the C-130J, Flight Lieutenant Mick Wansink, said the PNG deployment wasn’t one they had the opportunity to do very often. “It’s great being able to fly around these islands for the crew. “The flying has provided plenty of challenges manoeuvring into smaller airfields that are not used as often by aircraft of this size. “Operating in new environments adds elements that we don’t typically have to deal with back in New Zealand,” Wansink said. The NH90s travelled to small remote areas throughout the country where fixed-wing aircraft are unable to land. They delivered about 2,000kg of mosquito nets Malaria is a concern in PNG with roughly 90 per cent of the population living in high risk areas. Rotarians Against Malaria operations officer Scholastica Rim joined one of the flights to a remote village in the country’s highlands. “The mosquito nets are going to protect the locals in their communities,” Rim added. “The regions are so remote that the only means to bring the nets in is by aircraft.” The NH90s also moved an 800kg mini-excavator to workers in remote farmland in the Kiru to Keapara in Rigo, Central. The equipment needed to be moved 4km and across a lagoon if the NH90 had not been available. No.3 Squadron Flight Commander, Flight Lieut Paul Robinson said it was rewarding to be able to help communities that wouldn’t be able to achieve the tasks without their support and capability.

Title: PNG art on display in Cairns
Content: ARTWORK Papua New Guinea and Australia will be on display at the Cairns Regional Council’s Mulgrave Gallery in Australia from today as part of PNG’s 50th anniversary celebrations. The art exhibition titled “The Invisible Line: Stories, Legends and Past Connections” will be launched by Australia’s Assistant Minister for Pacific Island Affairs Senator Nita Green, and Australia’s ambassador for First Nations People Justin Mohamed today. According to the Australian High Commission, four PNG-based and four Australia-based artists have been working on the art project for the past six months, following workshops in Port Moresby in March. The Invisible Line highlights the ancestral and continued connections between PNG and Australia through art and stories. These stories celebrate Australian First Nation and PNG cultures, as well as contemporary expression and PNG diaspora voices in Australia. The multi-disciplinary artists taking part in the exhibition include Leonard Tebegetu (metal work), Gazellah Bruder (printmaking, painting and metal work), Pax Jukapa (painting), Morgan Lavapo (painting), Jimmy K Thaiday (sculpture, painting, print/etching), Charlie Street (painting and graphics), Wendy Mocke (multimedia, acting, writing), and Bernadette Killin (visual arts and educator). Renowned PNG artist Lesley Wengembo and acting curator of the Mulgrave Gallery in Cairns, Sally Brown, have curated the exhibition. “It’s so good to see all eight artists of both countries come together, especially the moment they all met during their visit in Port Moresby – it was almost like they all knew each other.”

Title: Police ready to provide security for Independence celebrations
Content: POLICE in the National Capital District (NCD) stand ready to provide security during the independence celebrations. Metropolitan Supt Warrick Simatab said they have partnered with the National Events Council (NEC) to provide security during American singer Akon’s music concert at the Sir John Guise Stadium on Wednesday. Police were out in force at yesterday’s opening of the Waigani National Court Complex also. Attempts to get a comment from the NEC to confirm the list were unsuccessful, however, artiste Naked Koala and Nigerian singer-songwriter Burna Boy are understood to have posted on their social media pages. “For NCD we’ll be focusing on the Unity Parade on Friday and the arts and musical festival at Ela Beach including the cultural show at Unagi Oval,” Simatab said. “We’ll also be covering the Festival of a Thousand Tribes ay Murray Barracks. We are working closely with NEC for major events like the music concert.” Simatab added that police are also on standby for other events like the combined church services just to monitor people’s movement. He said their operations started two months ago with the removal of road side markets, cleaning up certain places and enforcing the NCD Commission’s directives on animal control and safety. “We started our operation two months ago cracking down on liquor, unroadworthy vehicles, and ethnic clashes. “Protecting our women and children,” he said. Simatab said with the launch of the close circuit television command and control centre it will help the more than 2,000 police officers from Bomana, Water Police, Mobile Squads, K9 unit, band members and the reservists to protect the city.

Title: Ramu NiCo worker celebrates PNG at 50
Content: WHILE growing up on outskirts of her hometown, Madang, Benna Taltal never thought that she would one day work for a big company like Ramu NiCo. So as the float parade crawled passed, she felt a deep sense of gratitude as an occupant of the Ramu NiCo float alongside her work colleagues. The Ramu NiCo float was part of a parade during the launch of the 50th anniversary celebration in Madang on Friday, Aug 29, 2025. The event was filled with laughter and joy. Ramu NiCo staff at the head office were all in their full work uniforms. They carried small PNG flags as they prepared to join the parade. Two vehicles were provided, a 25-seater Coaster bus and a truck. Taltal chose to ride on the truck. As the parade set off from the town’s Laiwaden Oval, Taltal, who had the PNG flag design painted on her face, was swept up with the excitement, screaming “Happy 50th Independence” to the people on the roadsides. She tossed small flags and balloons to the children cheering at the float parade, completely absorbed in the pride of her country. She also reflecting on the theme of the 50th anniversary celebration – “Celebrate our history, inspire our future”. “I work for a world-class mine that has brought significant development to project impact areas, and I have all the right to celebrate to the fullest,” she spoke to her friend next to her, who was also shouting, “Happy Independence”. Ramu NiCo has constructed the huge Banu Bridge, built classrooms and aid posts, supported health and education programmes, sponsored students to tertiary institutions and developed agriculture projects for future sustainability. These were the reasons Taltal felt proud to celebrate as a Ramu NiCo worker. She believed that with companies like Ramu NiCo and the determination of the people, the future of Papua New Guinea was bright and full of promise.

Title: Local organisations get law and justice grants
Content: FIVE local organisations received funding support through grants awarded under the Australia-Papua New Guinea Law and Justice Partnership’s Community Justice Fund (CJF) to continue addressing justice issues in the country. Grants of up to K250,000 were made available to the organisations to tackle law and order issues in rural areas across PNG. Since its launch in November last year, the fund has supported a growing number of community-based organisations and frontline service providers. Speaking at the presentation of the grants in Port Moresby, Australian attorney-general Michelle Rowland said the CJF was established to support organisations on the grounds that were directly involved in helping people in rural areas. “The Community Justice Fund grants show what partnership in action looks like, supporting our Pacific community leaders to drive real change in their communities,” she said. “Australia and Papua New Guinea’s relationship is based on our common history, our close geography and our shared values. “Together, we are working to achieve a more accessible, more inclusive and more responsive system of justice. “I’m proud that we’ve taken another step together by supporting communities in PNG that drive change.” Rowland said the funding support to the organisations were based on Australia and PNG’s longstanding partnership throughout the years, adding that her government was committed to support other sectors as well. “This fund is part of a broader and enduring partnership between our two great nations. “Our collaboration extends beyond justice, into security, governance and human rights, including initiatives that respond to local needs and build long-term resilience.” Justice Minister and Attorney-General Pila Niningi commended the Australian government for its continued support, particularly in its effort to strengthen PNG’s law and justice sector.

Title: Police warn youths to stop illegal trade along border
Content: YOUTHS in Telefomin have been warned to refrain from drinking and selling alcohol and drugs along the borders. Telefomin Police Station Commander Chief Sergeant Terry Dap said most youths were caught along the borders of Western, Hela, Enga and Indonesia. There is a liquor ban in place covering Western. Telefomin and surrounding areas. “With limited resources and manpower, policing is very difficult as all crimes are committed at the outskirts and to get in there, attend to the suspects, bring them to the station, process them and further bring to the nearest courthouse in Kiunga or Vanimo is another hurdle,” he said. Established in 2010, the station currently has seven regular police officers and 30 reservists attending to police matters in the district. The reservists are from the Telefomin, Oksapmin, Yapsie, and Namea. They graduated in July. When suspects are processed, they are sent for court in Kiunga and Vanimo. Training was made possible by Telefomin MP Solam Mirisim and other provincial government officials. “We are fortunate with the highways being built because it makes it easier to take suspects to Kiunga. “But still, there are challenges we face. “Though we are in West Sepik and should refer to Vanimo Courts, it is cheaper to go to Kiunga,” he said. He said with the increased manpower, he hopes to see more improvements in law and order in the district.

Title: Rebutting doubts on sovereignty
Content: AS Papua New Guinea prepares to mark its 50th Independence Jubilee on Sept16, a troubling flare of doubt has emerged—questioning the legality and authenticity of our nationhood. This skepticism is fuelled by a curious coalition: Segments of civil society, fringe academics, and the usual chorus of Australian media voices. Among them is Martin Korokan Lomeyari, a former senior civil servant with the Department of Prime Minister and NEC. Korokan’s academic journey spans Sopas School of Nursing (now Innovative University of Enga), Divine Word University, Peking University in Beijing, and currently, a PhD candidacy at Deakin University, Melbourne. He hails from Yaramanda Village, Ambum LLG, Enga. Korokan positions himself as a provocative legal and cultural revisionist—challenging the foundational narrative of PNG’s independence through constitutional law, ancestral heritage, and historical oversight. Here’s a more nuanced breakdown of his stance: I respectfully differ. Let us dissect and rebut each claim with precision and pride. Claim 1: PNG’s independence breached Section 128 of the Australian Constitution.Rebuttal: Claim 2: PNG’s separation lacked indigenous consent and erased Aboriginal sovereignty.Rebuttal: Claim 3: PNG’s independence violated international norms of decolonisation.Rebuttal: Claim 4: PNG’s independence erased ancestral unity and indigenous justice.Rebuttal: – Nationhood is not defined by colonial cartography but by the moral will of a people to govern themselves. PNG chose freedom—not fragmentation. Claim 5: PNG’s separation disrupted shared spiritual cosmologies.Rebuttal: Dignity, legitimacy, and civic soul The anti-PNG critique may be intellectually provocative, but it is legally and morally flawed. Our independence was lawful, consultative, and internationally endorsed. It did not sever ancestral ties—it empowered them. It did not erase justice—it fulfilled it. Let us not allow revisionist nostalgia to undermine the dignity of our nationhood. PNG’s civic soul was born not in breach, but in boldness. And it continues to rise.

Title: Florists to showcase their products at National Orchid and Flower Show
Content: Two men will be among a group of 20 florists from the Highlands region who will participate at the National Orchid and Flower Show this weekend. Organiser of the Highlands floral displays and National Capital District, Keryn Hargreaves said it would be a first for the florists from Eastern Highlands, Chimbu, Jiwaka and Western Highlands provinces to participate in the show. “We will be bringing a plane full of flowers, all the different orchids from Mt Hagen as well as from Jiwaka, Chimbu, the Everlasting Daisies from Mt Wilhelm, interims, bird of paradise, and all the lilies,” she said. “We will feature flower dresses which will all be assembled to feature statue made out of flowers. The Bird of Paradise will be featured in our arrangements.” Hargreaves said their main aim was to expose the floriculture industry of Goroka. “Goroka is known as the flower town so the highlight would be promoting the floriculture of Goroka, the Highlands and PNG,” she said. “The different flowers and the potential of the floriculture industry needs to be harnessed and promoted so being there is the highlight for us.” Hargreaves said the floriculture industry was a sleeping giant because most of the focus was on food and agriculture. “It needs to get out there and be marketed and promoted as part of the Small to Medium Enterprise providing employment in the floriculture industry,” she said. “A lot of these florists are single parents and it’s their form of income to sustain their livelihood. “Some of them supply their flowers as far as Buka, Kimbe and Port Moresby.” “Most of the floral displays in Port Moresby are from Goroka and Mt Wilhelm.” “I thank the National Orchid and Flower Show for inviting us to represent the highlands region.” “We look forward to be part of this special occasion and to celebrate the 50th independence with PNG as well during the National Orchid and Flower show.”

Title: Institute renames building after Dr John Momis
Content: THE Somare Institute of Leadership and Governance (Silag) has renamed one of its building after Dr John Momis, a founding father of Papua New Guinea. Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology Minister Kinoka Feo and Momis unveiled the plaque at the Silag campus in Port Moresby yesterday. Feo said the renaming of the building was not only an honour but also a symbol and reminder to every student who walked through the institution that leadership was about vision, intellect and importantly the courage to design a future larger than oneself. “As we celebrate our 50th anniversary, we also honor one of the towering figures of our nation’s history, Grand Chief Dr John Momis,” he said. He added that Silag was more than a building and an institution. “It is a living reminder that leadership is not about power, wealth, fame, or privileges but more about vision, courage, and sacrifice,” he said. “It reminds us that our past must not be forgetten, but celebrated because it is the root of our identity and the compass about our journey ahead.” He said Momis was remembered as the architect of the PNG Constitution who crafted the guiding framework that has held the country together as a democracy for half a century. “But the constitution he shaped was not a borrowed document, it was rooted in our traditions, our communal beliefs, and our aspirations as a Melanesian people.”

Title: Karkar Island villagers paddle to Madang for showcase
Content: A FLOTILLA of 22 canoes powered by padallers from Patilo in Karkar Island, Madang arrived at Siar village yesterday on their way to Kranget island near Madang town. The paddlers began their voyage from Karkar, traveling through Rempi, Kananam, Malmal and Riwo before reaching Siar. They are expected to continue paddling to Kranget island today before heading to Tusbab Beach for the showcase on Sept 13. Spokesperson Darius Suari explained that the journey was not just about paddling. “We also do outreach programmes. “In every village we stop, we hold a small prayer night with the community before leaving.” The 22 canoes will be repainted before their final journey to Tusbab Beach, where they will be displayed to the public. Suari said Madang residents interested in owning canoes could buy them when the villagers arrived.

Title: Sir Bob praises new courthouse complex
Content: GOVERNOR-GENERAL Grand Chief Sir Bob Dadae has described the new K600 million courthouse complex as the “institutional heart of justice” in the country. “It is the institutional heart of justice in Papua New Guinea,” he said. “Within its walls resides the hopes of our people for fairness, redress, resolution, and for protection under the law.” Sir Bob opened the complex yesterday in the presence of Prime Minister James Marape, Acting Speaker Casmiro Aia, Minister for Justice and Attorney-General Pila Niningi, and Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika. He said that the building was more than just bricks, mortar, and architectural excellence. “The complex houses 15 modern courtrooms, judges’ chambers, providing infrastructure to support the increasing demand of the growing and enduring justice system,” he said Sir Bob added that the court’s new structure, with the separation of the National Court and Supreme Court, the addition of the Appeals Court, and the increased number of judges, was a tangible sign of judges’ roles as stewards of the Constitution. “The building belongs to no one, no man or woman. It belongs to the public,” Sir Bob said “It is your right to exercise that cause. It is your right to expect justice, to redress, to seek redress and to have your voices heard. This is the house where those rights are protected.” The opening ceremony was witnessed by members of the public and students in their school uniforms. There were cultural performances by dance groups from Western and Central.
People: Bob Dadae, Casmiro Aia, James Marape, Pila Niningi

Title: O’Neill pleased with new court complex
Content: FORMER Prime Minister Peter O’Neill described the new Waigani National Court Complex as “more than bricks and mortar”. O’Neill and his Government started the project back in 2016. Prime Minister James Marape when speaking yesterday also acknowledged the former O’Neill Government for providing the initial funding. Attending its opening yesterday, O’Neill said: “It is an impressive building befitting the cornerstone role our courts play in upholding order and fairness in our society. “In 2016 when the project was approved, it was done so as to acknowledge the fundamental need to not just give lip service to justice but as a Government we needed to invest to ensure our people could expect the most modern, efficient, secure and practical court facilities and our judges and court workers had an excellent work environment to carry out their mandated duties. “The new court complex is fully digitised with up to the minute technology making it easier and accessible for allcourt users, not just those in our capital. “I am pleased with the outcome that I saw today and reiterate my congratulations to all involved.”

Title: Nawaeb MP Pelgen prioritises road restoration in electorate
Content: EMERGENCY restoration of road network in the Nabak local level government, Nawaeb in Morobe, has begun as work starts on the Tusulu-Tuzing road, according to an official. Nawaeb MP Theo Pelgen in a statement said the district development authority had activated emergency road restoration in the LLG to connect the 14 wards to vital government services. “Nabak LLG is also a rugged area in the province and we are trying our best at the district level to ensure people are connected so that service providers like the government and non-government organisations can bring services to the people,” he said. Currently earth-moving machines are on site as work started to upgrade the main Nabak Highway which will end at Bambok to provide access to wards close to Saruwaged Range. Pelgen said the road link will allow accessibility of cash crops such as coffee, cocoa and garden produce, which the people of Nabak, have been producing over the years. Despite funding shortages, the DDA is doing emergency road repairs to access roads as well as the main LLG road link. Pelgen said the Bambok health post which serves a population of over 5,000 people has never been serving the people since it was built under previous MP Kennedy Wenge. “Plans and funds have been earmarked to ensure the Bambok Health Post is up and running. I am concerned after learning that mothers died during childbirth and babies also died while transporting them to Lae.” Pelgen said the health facility should be in operation with a health extension officer stationed there towards the end of the year.

Title: Marape backs deferral of talks
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape yesterday announced his full support for the Solomon Islands’ decision to postpone the Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) Development Partners Dialogue. The Solomon Islands, as the current PIF chair, will defer the event until the Forum’s framework review is finalised. Marape said the PIF family needed to stand together amid growing geopolitical competition in the region. “There are clear signs of outside influence attempting to pressure Pacific nations to take sides,” he said. “The PIF must remain strong and united for a free and peaceful Pacific.” He emphasised that Papua New Guinea’s foreign policy, “Friend to All, Enemy to None” allows PNG to maintain relations with nations without compromising its democratic values or its free market economy. He called on larger nations to respect the autonomy of PIF countries. “I urge all large countries to respect our right to decide our own relationships and not create disunity within the PIF,” he added. He believes the ongoing review of the PIF’s framework will provide a guide for how the region can engage with development partners and civil society. Marape highlighted key regional priorities, stating, “Our focus should be on action in climate change, climate financing, and marine resources. Together, we can be a powerful force in controlling our fisheries and marine as- sets.”

Title: Oxfam urges Pacific leaders to honour commitment
Content: AS Pacific leaders gather in Honiara, they must respond to the growing calls from communities across the region to uphold their commitment to building an “ocean of peace”, a vision that cannot be realised without confronting the intersecting crisis of human rights violations, climate injustice and environmental exploitation. The ongoing human rights crisis in West Papua, marked by rising numbers of internally displaced people and increasing violence against civilians, demand urgent attention. Oxfam in the Pacific calls on Pacific leaders to support the appeal for the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights to be granted unimpeded access to investigate these concerns. “There is precedent for these calls,” said Oxfam in the Pacific executive director Eunice Wotene. “Pacific Island Forum leaders have previously committed to fact-finding missions into West Papua, but accountability for this has been lacking,” she said. “It’s time to honour those commitments and to carry them out with full accountability and transparency.” At the same time, the climate crisis continues to devastate frontline communities across the Pacific. Rising seas, extreme weather and loss of livelihoods are compounding people’s vulnerabilities – particularly in places where human rights are already under threat. Oxfam urged Australia, as a major polluter, to take accountability and increase their share of climate finance to the region, ensuring that Pacific communities have the resources they need to adapt, particularly as Australia bids to host COP31 in partnership with the Pacific.

Title: Civil society watches over Pacific leadership: PM Manele
Content: THE civil society continues to be a watchdog that holds political leadership accountable and fosters transparency in the Pacific, says Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) chairman Jeremiah Manele. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manele said this during the leaders’ dialogue with the civil society in Honiara on Tuesday. “The civil society plays an integral role in the region as both a partner who ensures our regional commitments are translated into tangible actions and impact at the community level.” Manele said civil society organisations were not only partners but co-architects in communities and society. “Your voices amplify those often unheard and bring to the table practical, innovative solutions that governments alone cannot achieve,” he said. “This dialogue is an opportunity to listen to perspectives – we may not always agree but we must always be respectful of each other’s views and continue to find a way to work together in the interest of our Pacific people. “The true measure of our progress is best seen not only in the decisions made by governments, but in the lived realities of our people. “The Pacific’s future is not something to be decided in isolation, it is ours to shape, together with courage, wisdom and unity,” Manele said. The Council of Regional Organisations in the Pacific (CROP) plays an important role in implementing the decisions of leaders in the PIF, Manele said. He acknowledged the work of CROP agencies in aligning the collective 2050 strategy. “Our regional system must always be, first and foremost, centered on our people and the membership that it serves. “I encourage us to engage with openness and the spirit of solidarity that defines our Blue Pacific Continent.”

Title: Minister challenges men to ensure order in homes
Content: POLICE Minister Peter Tsiamalili Jnr has urged all men to rise up to ensure there is order in homes. Tsiamalili made the call while acknowledging the partnership with the Jiwaka provincial government in the construction of 40 police houses that opened in Minj on Tuesday. The minister said the houses were 50 years’ independence anniversary gift to the Jiwaka police. While acknowledging Governor Simon Kaiwi with the funding of more than K6 million for the houses that took six months to build, including the building of police infrastructure in the districts, Tsiamalili said the problems facing the country now related to order. “There is no problem with the law, the problem is with order. And, clearly there is a breakdown of order in families that spill onto the streets, thus affecting communities,” he said. He said men were the ones causing fear and insecurity to women, and that must stop. He urged everyone to go back to the culture of discipline and order, and consult the Bible that emphasised more on order. Tsiamalili also acknowledged the challenges Jiwaka police were being faced with which were highlighted by the provincial police commander Chief Insp Laimo Asi, and assured that the department would be notified. He said the Government was investing in police through recruitment, officer cadet training, logistics and partnership with the Australian Federal Police to build up local police capacity. Insp Asi said his manpower strength of 93 officers had reduced almost by half as 50 officers were suspended on disciplinary grounds while another six would be retrenched next week. “I have just around 50 officers available to do police work in the province of about 400,000 people,” he said. “The police ratio is one to 4,000 people,” he told Minister Tsiamalili. Asi requested the minister to take it up with the department for five additional buildings to house the commissioned officers including himself. He also requested the minister to take it up at cabinet level on the need to establish the Jiwaka provincial police command.

Title: Justice Department sponsors staff to pageant in Western
Content: The Department of Justice and Attorney General (DJAG) has for the first time sponsored one of its female officers to take part in the Miss Bird of Paradise Pageant. The event took place last Saturday (Sept 6) in Daru, Western. Kimberley Rulete, an officer from Western, entered the inaugural Miss Bird of Paradise Western Pageant. She was sponsored by DJAG through the Child Nutrition and Social Protection (CNSP) Project. Rulete was recently recruited by the department as a provincial liaison officer for Western. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in Journalism and Public Relations from the University of Papua New Guinea. The Miss Bird of Paradise chairperson, Anna Bias, said the Miss Bird of Paradise Pageant is a national programme that is not only about a beauty contest. It is a programme that helps young women become leaders, cultural ambassadors, and advocates of positive change in their communities. It was founded in 2023. Miss Rulete used the programme to raise awareness on child nutrition and social protection issues in Western. She contested for the crowning of Miss Bird of Paradise Western Province and finished in third place. “I want to help my people and contribute meaningfully to the community,” Rulete said. She thanked the Department of Justice and Attorney General for the sponsorship and support, saying the pageant gave her a chance to inspire other women and girls in her province.

Title: New hospital to serve 80,000
Content: AFTER years of waiting, about 80,000 persons of West New Britain’s Cape Gloucester can now access medical services at a recently opened K32 million rural hospital. The local people, who used to travel long distances by sea to receive help in other districts due the remoteness of Kandrian-Gloucester, rejoiced at the sight of their largest health infrastructure, which was brought closer to home by the Australian government, Asian Development Bank (ADB), Health Department and provincial health authority. Authority chairman Dr Mathias Sapuri said the new 22-bed health facility includes a general adult ward, children’s ward, post-natal ward, and a tuberculosis isolation ward. It also has a waiting house for expectant mothers, amenities for guardians, and 12 houses for staff members. Sapuri said the construction of the hospital was part of the authority’s plan to improve healthcare in the province. “We finally completed the Cape Gloucester Rural Hospital for the local people in two-and-a-half years in one of the most remote places of the province. “The hospital will serve up to 80,000 persons in the area. “It will change the health services within the district, it will help with patient transfer from the district to Kimbe Provincial Hospital. “The plan is to expand the hospital to level four, with another operation theatre, additional 20 patient beds and 10 more staff houses, including a duplex accommodation for medical students and registered medical officers on rotations. “I will lead the first full team of specialist doctors to perform all specialist surgeries there, starting early November (this year),” he said. Sapuri, also the National Health Board chairman, thanked all the development partners and relevant authorities that helped to build the hospital. “Our most sincere thanks and gratitude to the Australian government, ADB, Health Department staff and technical team with the Government, the authority board, management and staff, provincial government and the contractor and builder, PNG Forest Limited. “Our most sincere thanks to the Health Minister Elias Kapavore for opening this facility with Governor Sasindran Muthuvel, Nakanai MP Francis Maneke and Talasea MP Freddie Kumai. “The people of Cape Gloucester have expressed their sincerest thanks to all who helped.”
People: Elias Kapavore, Francis Maneke, Sasindran Muthuvel

Title: Infrastructure upgrade part of town development
Content: NOMAD in Middle Fly, Western, will have its infrastructure upgraded, says a governor. Western Governor Taboi Awi Yoto said this was part of the town development plan and the design was approved by Lands and Physical Planning this week. “While the name Middle Fly is the name of the existing electorate, it’s just the name that’s old, but it does not have the current infrastructure to support a district headquarters. “The infrastructure that used to support the district is now in the Delta Fly headquarters,” he said. He said this project now paves the way for work to start on the district headquarters. Under the project, the Western government has procured 25 prefabricated staff houses, 10 container single accommodation units, a level-four hospital infrastructure, and a police station with three police staff houses. The Middle Fly Development Authority has procured the district headquarters office complex and three more staff houses. “These are infrastructure ready to be installed as materials reach the construction sites from Kiunga. “We would not go ahead without the approval of landowners for making available their customary land for the town development,” he said. He thanked the government for making the necessary funds available for land mobilisation, physical planning work and technical assistance.

Title: Senior European official to visit PNG
Content: EUROPEAN Commissioner for International Partnerships Jozef Síkela is visiting the country today and tomorrow to advance the European Union’s (EU) long-standing partnership with Papua New Guinea, a relationship that stretches back to 1977. During his visit, Síkela and National Planning Minister Ano Pala are expected to sign a new EU budget support programme for State buildings and resilience in PNG. The €25.6-million (about K125 million) programme aims to enhance sustainable forest management, address challenges posed by climate change, improve access to clean water, and strengthen governance so that institutions can serve citizens more effectively and provide better access to justice. In addition,Síkela announced the last €1-million (about K4.9 million) disbursement of the ongoing budget support programme for good governance. Síkela said: “I am honoured to visit PNG to celebrate with you the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. “The cooperation between PNG and the EU has been an important part of these past decades. “And I believe that the newly-signed budget support to enhance forest conservation, climate change responses, and water and governance in PNG will allow us to make our partnership grow even stronger under the EU’s Global Gateway investment strategy. “Together, we can create tangible benefits to local communities by boosting sustainable economic growth and bolstering their capacity to tackle climate challenges.” Síkela is visiting PNG following his participation in the first EU-Pacific Business Forum in Fiji, where he announced a nearly €300-million (about K1.4 billion) investment package between the EU and the Pacific, including PNG. During his visit, Síkela is meeting with leading representatives of the Government to strengthen the EU-PNG partnership through the EU Global Gateway strategy, particularly by mobilising investments in transport connectivity and climate-resilient infrastructure. The discussions will follow up on progress in the investment projects in water sector and the Rabaul port rehabilitation after the visit of European representatives, including the European Investment Bank, in July. The implementation of both projects will enable PNG to leverage European expertise and resources to drive sustainable development and improve infrastructure, in line with both local and regional goals Delegation of the European Union to PNG. The EU is represented by the Delegation of the EU to PNG. Ambassador-designate Erika Hasznos is head of the delegation in Port Moresby. The union has 27-member states, including France, which is represented in PNG. Within the EU, the European External Action Service (EEAS) is the EU’s body for Foreign Affairs and Security. The European Commission is the EU’s executive body. The EU has been a vital development ally for PNG, focusing on important sectors such as forestry, climate change and biodiversity; water and sanitation (WaSH); good governance; and economic development. Adding to this, trade relations between the EU and PNG are robust and grounded in the interim Economic Partnership Agreement, with PNG as one of its pioneering signatories.

Title: Marape expects more arrests after installation of CCTVs
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has asked police commissioner David Manning to speak with Correctional Services commissioner Bernard Nepo to find land to build new cells for prisoners at a cost of K20 million. Marape said with closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras installed in Port Moresby, more suspects were to be arrested and cells would be full. He said they would amend laws to give police the power to arrest and penalise offenders effectively. “Everyone from petty criminals to traffic offenders must know that their actions have consequences,” he said. Marape said this during the launching of the CCTV control centre at Four-Mile on Tuesday. “We are good people, but pockets among us still fall into lawlessness. Those who refuse to live peacefully will be dealt with once and for all,” he said. Marape said his government’s long-term vision was to expand the police force to 10,000 officers by 2035, supported by information, communication science, artificial intelligence, and modern investigative tools. He also revealed plans for a national police hotline linked to the CCTV centre, allowing citizens to report crimes instantly, with cases registered online and distributed to relevant stations for immediate response. “I want Port Moresby to be safe so that my daughters and all our children can live freely and securely,” Marape said. Marape urged Manning to get out and arrest people where and when crimes were happening as the country deserved safety. Manning said Port Moresby should not only be a place of work and residency but a place of pride. He said the CCTVs would add value to all who called the city home and for the future generation. “This is one step to bettering the safety and security of the people in the city. There are ongoing discussions on how best we can ensure that we have the appropriate legislations in place,” Manning said.

Title: Magistrate suggests death penalty for sex predators
Content: A MAGISTRATE says the law should be changed to allow sexual predators to face the death penalty. Committal Court Magistrate Paul Puri Nii made his comment while presiding over a case involving a 64-year-old man charged with sexually abusing his biological nine-year-old daughter. Said Nii: “It is about time the Government should amend the current maximum penalty of sexual penetration from 25 years to death penalty and let all the child sexual predators die and rot in hell. “If evidence suggests that the victim was harassed by her own dad then any other male relatives are not to be trusted. “ “The society is rotten causing of people’s attitude and minds to act abnormally, hence the defendant in this case.” The no-nonsense magistrate, while ruling on sufficiency of evidence, said every young female should be loved and taken good care of at all times and should not be sexually abused by someone they look up to for help and shelter. Police alleged that between 2021 to Aug 2023, at Mautana settlement in Port Moresby’s NCD, the accused, of Nondugul village in Jiwaka’s North Waghi, had allegedly engaged in the act of sexual penetration with his daughter who was nine at that time. The accused denied the allegation in court and said that everything was being fabricated by his daughter and her mother to defame his character and reputation. He submitted that the charge was defective as there was no evidence in the police file, and asked the court to dismiss the case. The court assessed the accused’s submissions and the police evidence and found that the alleged victim’s own statement is destructive (damaging) and intact and the evidence was overwhelming. “In my conclusion, it is my view that police evidence and facts connects the defendant to the charge. “The allegation should be sustained.” he said The accused was remanded in custody. He will return to court next week for a section 96 (declaration) statement.

Title: 72 more CCTV cameras installed in nation’s capital
Content: THE National Capital District Commission has installed 72 more close circuit television (CCTV) cameras in 80 sites covering hotspots in the city. It takes the number of cameras to around 200 which included those used during the Apec Leaders’ Summit in 2018. City Manager Ravu Frank said that it was to create the backbone of a modern surveillance and rapid response system, “one that will help us prevent crime, manage traffic, and respond swiftly when incidents occur”. “The command and control at the Four-Mile tarpot will be the nerve centre of our operations equipped with advanced servers, a giant video wall, and intelligence software capable of real-time monitoring, facial and vehicle recognition, and automated alerts. It is the city’s new eyes and ears,” he said. The project is being delivered in partnership with Maigata Limited, Dahua Technologies, and XT Décor, with Tsalach Engineering as project manager. “We are rolling out 72 advanced TiOC WizSense Pan-Tilt-Zoom cameras at key intersections and high-risk locations,” he said. In addition, 31 automatic number plate recognition cameras are being installed around the city. Frank said that these cameras would automatically record vehicle number plates, helping officers detect stolen or unregistered vehicles, monitor traffic flow, and support police investigations with the help of the Motor Vehicles Insurance Limited and Road Traffic Authority. With these upgraded cameras, power restoration, and the control centre, the total project value now stands at around K16mil. “The Government committed K20mil of which K15 million has already been released,” he said.

Title: PM says extra cameras will help fight lawlessness
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has welcomed the installation of more closed circuit television (CCTV) cameras around Port Moresby to arrest lawbreakers. “We are good people, but pockets among us still fall into lawlessness,” he said. “Those who refuse to live peacefully will be dealt with once and for all.” Marape said during the launching of the CCTV control centre at Four-Mile yesterday that the CCTV cameras would lead to more suspects being arrested. “Everyone from petty criminals to traffic offenders must know that their actions have consequences,” he said. Marape added that the Government long-term plan was to expand the police force to 10,000 officers by 2035, to be supported by information communication science, artificial intelligence, and modern investigative tools. There are also plans for a national police hotline linked to the CCTV centre for citizens to report crimes instantly, with cases registered online and distributed to relevant stations for immediate response. “I want Port Moresby to be safe, so that daughters and children can live freely and securely,” Marape said. He urged Police Commissioner David Manning to arrest all lawbreakers because the people deserved safety and security. Manning said Port Moresby should only be for those with jobs – a place of employment not of residency. “There are ongoing discussions on how best we can ensure that we have the appropriate legislations where you will see that NCD would have it separate laws that govern how we reside, work and who travels in and out.”

Title: Early pay for public servants
Content: PUBLIC Servants can access their pay one week early to enjoy Independence anniversary celebrations. The Finance Department has moved the pay date for pay 19 of public servants forward to the end of this week because of independence anniversary celebrations. Finance Secretary Samuel Penias toldThe Nationalthat this was not additional pay or bonus but frontloading of pay for the next pay period. He said that this was done in accordance with National Gazette No. G827, which had declared Sep 15, 16, and 17 as pubic holidays for the independence celebration. “Yes due to the public holiday coming up next week when the banking system would have closed for business until Thursday, it is proper that pays are sorted out now for the public service to use to commemorate the 50th years of independence celebrations,” he said. “The actual pay date falls on the public holiday Sept 17, 2025, but we are unable to process the pay during that time. “All staff are requested to take note of these changes and make necessary personal and administrative arrangements,” Penias said. The department launched its 50th Independence anniversary celebrations recently. Finance Minister Thomas Opa also said that this was a defining moment for every citizen, every institution, and every generation. “Fifty years ago, these great men believed in our people — that we could govern ourselves, build our economy, and preserve our unique cultures and values,” Opa said. “We honour their legacy and all who have carried the burden of nation-building since that historic moment.” He urged all public servants and decision-makers to use the jubilee not only to celebrate, but to reflect on the nation’s progress and recommit to its future. “This 50th Anniversary is not just about looking back. “It is a call to reflect, to reawaken, and to renew our commitment. As we celebrate, we must also prepare to modernise, reform, and lead,” he added.

Title: Marape hails importance of civil society groups
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has described civil society organisations as the “eyes and ears” on the ground, connecting government policies to the communities they are meant to serve. He told the Pacific Island Forum leaders’ dialogue with the civil society in Honiara, Solomon Islands, that “you are the innovators, advocates, and front-line responders”. “You can help us identify where our regional architecture is working and, more importantly, where it falls short,” Marape said. “Your insights into the systemic challenges we face – whether in governance, resource management, or the delivery of services – are crucial for strengthening our collective impact. “Our role extends far beyond providing feedback. You are co-creators of our future. “We must find ways to deepen your engagement, from policy formulation to project implementation. “By working hand-in-hand, we can ensure that our efforts are not just technically sound but are also culturally sensitive, community-driven, and truly reflective of the diverse aspirations of our Pacific family.” Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele said that Pacific island nations must continue to invest in regional organisations. “I look forward to discussing the opportunities of working towards stronger intergovernment organisations that embrace the spirit and purpose of international law,” he said. Manele, chairing the 54th Pacific Islands Forum in Honiara, said the highlight for this week would be the endorsement of two key regional initiatives reaffirming the leadership of the region globally: “Taken together, it will be a strong political recommitment to resilience and peace across our Blue Pacific continent,” Manele said. “In the spirit of dialogue and perspectives, a key element of this week will also be the opportunity to talk to heads of our Council of Regional Organisations in the Pacific, the private sector and civil society, who represent the perspectives and views of our communities and continue to play an important role in accountability and monitoring of political decisions.”

Title: Pacific Islands strongest when standing as one, forum told
Content: THE Pacific is at its strongest when nations stand together, says Pacific Islands Forum Secretary-general Baron Divavesi Waqa. He said during the opening of the 54th forum meeting in Honiara, Solomon Islands, on Monday that the forum was a testament to the vision of the founding leaders who, more than five decades ago, recognised that the Pacific “is at its strongest when we stand together – united as one”. “As with all families, there are moments of challenge and there are moments of celebration. “What is important throughout is a consistent will to navigate these issues together,” Waqa said. “Yes, we operate in a very fluid geostrategic environment, but we must hold fast to our commitment to our forum family. “Let us draw strength from our cultures, our shared ocean, and from the spirit of solidarity that has always defined our Blue Pacific,” he said. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele said that the Pacific island people were on the frontline of climate change and global shocks. “Climate action is urgent,” Manele said. “The Pacific has shown, through the Climate Champions initiative, that political advocacy can elevate our priorities on the world stage,” he added. “As we approach Cop30, it is essential that we empower a new cohort of champions to carry forward our collective call for climate justice. “At the same time, we must seize every opportunity to advance this call and reaffirm our firm resolve to bring Cop31 to our shores, in partnership with Australia.” He thanked the Pacific islands leaders for attending the Pacific ACP leaders meeting in Honiara. “The signing of the Samoa Agreement in 2023 set a renewed framework with our European partners. We advanced Pacific climate diplomacy at Cop28 and Cop29, ensuring our survival agenda remained at the heart of global discussions.”

Title: Culture and traditions come alive at school’s independence event
Content: GOLDIE River Primary School students in Central’s Hiri-Koiari displayed their traditional and cultural way of life during the school’s pre-independence celebrations on Thursday to preserve and promote country’s history. Head teacher Jasper Matiabe said more than 1,200 students from grade three to eight as well as ace students (grades one and two) participated along with their 31 teachers and surrounding communities, including Goldie Barracks’ residents, before going for their term three break. “Our students formed five main groups according to their places of origin representing Momase, Southern, New Guinea Islands and lower and upper Highlands with each group displaying their cultural way of life through songs and dances,” he said. “They also defined and explained the meaning of samples, designs and colours on each provincial flags to inspire their peers and younger generations in a way to promote country’s history as part of the pre-celebration leading up the 50th Golden Jubilee of PNG’s independence on Sept 16,” Matiabe said the event was the first of its type hosted by the school despite no funding assistance from business houses or the Government. “However, we are using our own funding from TFF to ensure the event was successful as we do not want to let the students’ morale down, especially with the country’s 50th independence Golden Jubilee coming up on Sept 16,” he said. He said the participants came in as early as 9.30am to sing the National Anthem and raise the PNG flag before they continued with traditional dances and other programmes until 3pm. “We have seen a great display of our traditions and culture with pride through these young men and women who will take our places in future and continue to lead this country forward. “It was a spectacular event indeed as other students wore PNG colours of gold, red and black to show unity and freedom as their peers participated in traditional dances.”

Title: Dr Ambi’s corruption-related charges dismissed
Content: A COMMITTAL Court has dismissed the case of Dr Umadevi Ambihaipahar, better known as Dr Ambi, for failure by police to produce evidence in court. Committal Court Magistrate Paul Puri Nii, in Waigani yesterday, dismissed the case after prosecutor Sgt Sandra Holland informed the court that the arresting officer had not been communicating with her on the progress of the case since Ambi’s arrest. The prosecution asked for an adjournment. Ambi’s lawyer, Jerry Siki, objected and made a verbal application to have the matter dismissed for want of police files. The court refused the prosecution’s application on the basis that police did not show interest in the case. “In my view, although there is no time computation devoted to Section 37(3) of the Constitution on the commonly used phrase ‘reasonable time’, all matters should be dealt with distinctively on their own merit and on a case-by-case basis,” Magistrate Nii said. He said there was also no evidence based documentation explaining the progress of the case and the need for an adjournment if there were any investigations underway. Magistrate Nii said this drew the court into confusion on what the prospects and guarantee would be if the matter was adjourned for police to corroborate the charge. The court upheld the Ambi’s application. She was discharged of the allegations of misappropriation, abuse of office, official corruption, and dealing with criminal property. Ambi toldThe Nationaloutside court that she was happy with the court’s decision. Police alleged that between 2021 and 2023, Ambi – former acting director of the Directorate of Social Change and Mental Health Services – had allegedly abused and misused funds belonging to the Mental Health Hospital worth K1,355,393.08.

Title: Unity Parade to kick off NCD celebrations
Content: NATIONAL Capital District (NCD) events to commemorate 50 years of independence will begin with a Unity Parade on Friday from 5.30am to 10am from Murray Barracks to Ela Beach. After the walk, a week-long Art and Music Festival will be launched. NCD Governor Powes Parkop said over the weekend they have planned for a Pasin Tumbuna Festival and a church service on Sunday from 6am to 9am. Other events include tree-planting by world leaders at Parliament House, flag-raising at the Independence Hill on Sept 16, PNG 50 mass choir and 50 formation at the Independence Boulevard, Festival of a Thousand Tribes, University of Papua New Guinea and Pacific Adventist University festivals and a PNG50 spectacular concert at Sir Hubert Murray Stadium. “We are just six days away,” Parkop said. “This is a special time for us to think about our journey, how far we have come, our heritage, where we are. “And for the next 50 years, how we should elevate the lives of people and improve the city. “I urge everyone to leave their differences aside. “Let’s come together to mark this time and event. “It’s an important moment for us to celebrate our journey and achievements. “We have our flaws, but that’s our story. “We can learn from the past and get better hereon.” Parkop said events will start on Friday and run through till Sept 17. “Some of the events that we have put together are events that we have been having in the recent years,” he said. “There will be a lot of guests coming in to share the moment with us. “On Saturday, leaders attending the Pacific Islands Forum will fly to Port Moresby. “Everyone must be on their best behaviour.”

Title: Buimo remandees raise concern over hearing delays
Content: REMANDEES at Buimo Correctional Service (CS) outside Lae have raised concern over prolonged delay in their court hearings, saying justice is being denied. Alfred Lua Manak, for example, has been on remand for seven years and says it feels like he’s serving sentence. Speaking on behalf of the remanded, Manak said many prisoners similarly have waiting for years without trial, creating a heavy burden on both inmates and the facility. “I am wearing a blue uniform which means I am still waiting for court,” Manak said. “We have not yet been convicted, but for me, being in here for seven years now feels like I am already serving a sentence. For us, delaying justice means our justice has been denied.” He explained that the long wait has left many remandees in limbo, uncertain about their future while separated from their families. Buimo CS commander, Chief Superintendent Michael Wundia, confirmed the concerns, and pointed out that several detainees had been waiting for extended periods. “Four remandees have been in custody for over four years now,” he said. “The others are new, waiting for court or their hearing, but only four have waited for over five years.” He added that the backlog of cases places significant strain on the prison. “Delayed hearing also puts pressure on us in the facility given that the number of prisoners keeps growing every year,” he said. “We try to provide for their shelter and food rations, which is hard. “Keeping them in here for too long without being convicted is indeed unjust.” The remandees are calling on the courts to fast-track hearings to ensure that remandees are given timely access to justice. Their plea reflects the growing challenge in the justice system, where overcrowding, resource constraints, and case backlogs continue to test the country’s commitment to fair and efficient trials.

Title: Opposition leader fires barbs at PM and Government
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa has slammed the Government over alleged widespread corruption, a lackluster economic performance the breakdown in rule of law and public service failures. “The state of the country under the six-year regime of Prime Minister James Marape and his Pangu-led Government has progressively gone backwards,” he said in a statement yesterday. Tomuriesa said daily we see, hear and read stories about: “The Pangu-led Government of Prime Minister James Marape must shoulder all the blame for a failed government that has miserably failed to halt rapid downward trend towards a failed state,” Tomuriesa said.

Title: Australia attorney-general here for court complex opening
Content: AUSTRALIA’S attorney-general Michelle Rowland has arrived in Papua New Guinea to attend the opening of the New Waigani National Court Complex today. “This visit to Papua New Guinea is an opportunity to reflect on our shared histories and to celebrate the strong partnership that has developed between our countries, courts and legal institutions,” she said in a statement yesterday. “Together, we are committed to supporting a justice system that serves all fairly and effectively. “This visit reaffirms Australia’s commitment to work with PNG to advance justice, equality and the rule of law.” During the visit, Rowland will meet with her counterpart, Minister for Justice and Attorney-General Pila Niningi MP, and Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika. The visiting AG will also offer her congratulations on PNG’s independence and connect with the future leaders and community groups who are shaping the future of law and justice in PNG, including graduates and alumni of the University of Papua New Guinea, the Legal Training Institute and the Business Coalition for Women’s Senior Executive Women’s Leadership Programme and recipients of the Australia-PNG Law and Justice Partnership’s Community Justice Fund grants.

Title: Taraka youth leaders call for justice
Content: MORE than 5000 citizens living at West Taraka in Lae, Morobe are urging the authorities for justice to be done on the two youths that were killed and eight others hospitalised since last Saturday. The West Taraka community also asked for an outside independent investigation team to investigate what transpired on Sept 6 when two youths were shot and killed and eight others injured allegedly by members of the PNG Defence Force from the Engineering Battalion at Igam Barracks. Community youth leader Ismael Paindo Serum while speaking on behalf of the citizens at West Taraka said the people were asking if the Government could explain to the people why they were being attacked allegedly by the soldiers. “The way they attacked us that fateful morning when everyone were still asleep is like they were trying to attack their enemies in wartime,” Serum said. He said the three disciplinary forces of the Government were meant to protect lives and properties but why did they use arms against the armless citizens when there was no threats leveled at them at that time. “Now, we want nothing but justice to be done by the authorities in relation to the deaths, the injured and the properties that were lost in the fire and by theft,” she said. The community claimed that they knew nothing about the death of a soldier (also on Saturday), and were innocent but were allegedly targeted by the PNGDF personnel. Mother of a student at a primary school that was shot and killed, Kayline Kesna, said she struggled over the years to look after the child only to find her child being shot recklessly with no reason. The tearful mother said that her child was a primary school student who was innocently and brutally killed. John Michael who had one of his sons killed while another was hospitalised said he did not know how one of his sons died and another was badly injured. “At that morning, sounds of gunfire woke us up from bed. This problem was not for West Taraka but started at Igam block and dragged us in,” said Michael.

Title: Woman wants K500,000 for damaged properties
Content: A VICTIM of the incident at West Taraka in Lae has claimed that her properties worth more than K500, 000 were allegedly destroyed by members of PNG Defence Force personnel last Saturday. The victim, Julie Sine said all her properties including a trade store, a family house and two other houses used by the family for business purposes, were all burnt to the ground. “I am living with a huge family here, together with my husband, children, in-laws, their kids and together we are 31 of us living here,” she said. “Now, we have lost everything, the only thing we had were the clothes on our bodies.” Julie was also stabbed on her left leg allegedly by a member of the PNGDF as she claimed that entered her premises at that fateful morning of Sept 6, 2025. She claimed that when the man entered her premises, he was fully masked and she thought it was a rascal who wanted to rob her. Julie explained that she was injured on the left leg and also on the left side of her head, while witnessing her properties being damaged. She said the alleged PNGDF members chased them off their premises and then they damaged properties, broke into some of them and later set them on fire. She said the approach by the alleged members of the PNGDF were like criminals trying to steal from people. Meanwhile her husband, Robert Sine, said the family was never given the chance to remove any of their belongings. “Sixty cartoons of beer, 25 hard stuff, 17 Coke cartoons, 15 inners of cigarettes of different types and K7,000 in cash were stolen at that time,” he said. Robert said other items like chainsaw, cement bags, sewing machine, mechanical tools, a generator set, two deep freezers, television screens and other properties were taken from his house. “They also killed my chickens and a pig and brought them with them,” he added. Robert said after chasing his family members away and ransacking his home, they set fire to it. He said that the family now had nothing left and were asking for complete justice to be done to their loss and the injuries sustained by his wife Julie. Police commissioner David Manning in a statement on Sept 7, 2025, said that initial investigations had revealed that those involved in an attack on West Taraka residents were military personnel and it was related to a personal dispute. Manning said some of the offenders were alleged to have been in military uniforms and used PNGDF vehicles.

Title: Lae school receives biggest furniture donation
Content: LAE’S Bowali Primary School received its biggest furniture donation yesterday – a total of 1,786 desks and tables to enable a comfortable learning for students. Head teacher Andrew Nasongan said the school had been facing overcrowding, lack of furniture and poor infrastructure. “With almost 50 students per class, four or five students would use one desk,” he said. “Our Tuition Fee Free grant is not much, usually around K32,000-K39,000. “We could only do single purchases upon specific request by teachers depending on their priority.” Nasongan said schools had become dependent on donations from business houses to ease their burden. He participated in a survey questionnaire by the City Pharmacy Limited Group of Companies, landing Bowali as a lucky recipient of the donation, made possible through a partnership with the Swire Shipping. “We only wanted furniture for grades one to three but they’ve given us enough to cater for all grades, even the library and staff room,” he said. “Our students returning from their holidays can now sit on good chairs in term four.” Nasongan said Bowali was a pre-independence school, established in 1963 and received its primary status in 1966. He said some classrooms built then were still being used today. “A school this old should already been transformed to a different level by now,” he said. “We have a big landmass that’s unused, the school still looks the same.” Nasongan said they had a 4-in-1 classroom, water tank and fence built through a donation from the National Fisheries. He said Lae City Authority will be building an 8-in-1 classroom and Wafi Golpu Joint Venture has also promised to build an 8-in-1 classroom and a multi-purpose hall. He said the school still needed staff housing, student ablution block and a proper administration office.

Title: Materials for LLG elections sent to provinces, says Sinai
Content: MATERIALS for the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections have been sent to most provinces in preparation for polling to start on Sept 27, according to Electoral Commissioner Simon Sinai. “Logistics operations on the movement of election materials throughout the country has started with the shipment of most containers to the provinces,” he said in a statement yesterday. “All election materials, which includes ballot boxes, ballot papers, polling kits and voting compartments have been dispatched and most of the provinces have confirmed receiving their containers,” he said. “We have a few more to go but the bulk of the work is done and we are ready and set for polling.” Sinai confirmed that polling for the LLG elections would proceed as per the revised schedule, after it was deferred from the initial date on July 12 due to administrative issues, particularly the alignment of 500-plus newly created wards and 41 LLGs in 14 provinces. He said eligible voters had been identified from existing rolls and separated to create new rolls for the new wards and LLGs which were ready for the polling period which will end on Oct 10. Counting starts on Oct 11 and writs will be returned by Oct 17. “This was the main cause of the delay. “Though it is not the responsibility of the PNG Electoral Commission staff, I am happy that most of the realignment work is complete with the rolls being printed and ready for polling,” Sinai said. He apologised to the people, especially the 30,000-plus candidates who have had to endure the long delay, urging the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs to ensure that requests for the new ward and LLG proclamations be done before the elections. He added that certain wards and LLGs that did not meet the legal requirements, including the voter population needed, have had their writs withdrawn.

Title: Miss Morobe beauty pageant to declare winner
Content: THE first Miss Bird of Paradise Morobe will be crowned tonight in Lae. Committee chairperson Jennifer Baing said MBPPNG Morobe 2025 was a movement for inclusivity, empowerment, and cultural pride. “The pageant is a platform to empower young women to be voices for positive change in our province, while raising awareness and support for inclusive education for children living with disabilities,” Baing said. “Beauty is part of it, yes, but the heart of this programme is about leadership, culture, and giving back to the community with a focus on inclusive education for children living with disabilities.” She confirmed four contestants this year as Georgina Kasu, Viola Benson, Rhahellah Bora-Menemo and Salome Yaling. She said the focus was on The Inclusive Education Resource Centre (IERC) in Lae. The school needs a dedicated transport for students and trained teachers in inclusive education. Baing said without this support, children with disabilities risked being excluded from education and opportunity. Baing said this message will be brought to the national stage of the Miss Bird of Paradise PNG, where the crowned MBPPNG Morobe will compete against 21 other provincial entrants. “Tonight, we will present the aim and vision of the Miss Bird of Paradise Morobe to the Lae and Morobe business community and leaders, to support the crowned Miss Bird of Paradise Morobe with the entrance fee to the Miss Bird of Paradise PNG of K100,000 and to support, her and the in the three months leading up to the National Pageant in Vanimo,” she said. “Support this honourable cause to empower young women to become changemakers in their communities and to also promote the culture and beauty of Morobe province.” Baing said it was necessary that the provincial pageant contestants had cultural links to Morobe. “This is the first year so we were only able to cater for four contestants due to funding and time constraints, but next year and onwards, we will have contestants from all the 10 districts of Morobe,” Baing said. She thanked the initial sponsors – Lonestar International Agency – who has committed support for the next three years doing hair, makeup and wardrobe of the Miss Bird of Paradise Morobe Pageant, Deputy Prime Minster and Lae MP John Rosso for a commitment of K100,000 towards the launching and crowning and the support of Sir Bob Sinclair and the Lae International Hotel. “By uniting as the Lae business community, we can ensure Morobe’s children living with disabilities are supported, and our province shines proudly at the first-ever 22-Province Miss Bird of Paradise PNG Pageant,” Baing said.

Title: Bishop calls for united effort
Content: A CHURCH leader says that the challenges faced in Papua New Guinea today demands strong partnership and collaboration between the government, churches and the civil society. Evangelical Lutheran Church of PNG’s Head Bishop Dr Jack Urame said these grouping should not be partners only in name but in real dialogue, cooperation and collective action. Urame said: “As we celebrate 50 years, a mother is in labor pain behind the mountains where there is no health center; a father is walking for days to come into town; a child is begging on the street because there is no food, no home, no love and care; a youth is knocking on the door to find a job; a girl is sexually assaulted; a family is under threat due to violence; a community is robbed of their peace due to ethnic conflict; a mother cannot feed her children well because there is no food; a family cannot afford school fee because it is so expensive; a patient iswaiting in pain to die because there is no medicine; and, the list goes on. “Our challenges have accumulated over the years.” Urame stressed collaboration and collective effort, taking little practical steps through discipline, honesty, humility and service for the people. “50 years must not be years of lost opportunities, lost resources, lost generations, lost vision and lost dreams for our nation,” he said. “It must be 50 years of great lessons. “What we have seen, experienced, and felt in the last 50 years must become our motivation to move into the future with determination, conviction, aspirations and hope. “To build a better PNG, our leaders must manage the recourse of this country well, be honest with the way they handle public money, and make wise decisions to lead this country. “Churches must continue to inspire people with the Gospel of peace, reconciliation and unity. “Civil society must take positive actions and move in a positive direction. “Together, we can build a better PNG. “We must aim to build a future filled with peace, justice and harmony; not a gloomy and fragmented one, but a brighter future, with thriving communities, flourishing families, blooming society and a prosperous and progressive nation. “To create that future it requires our collective will, determination, discipline and positive action. “With a united front, we can build the future we desire today.”

Title: Daveona selling 60 cakes for cancer ward
Content: A WOMAN in Lae is celebrating her 60th birthday this September by raising funds for the national cancer ward at Angau Memorial Provincial Hospital. Eunice Daveona who wants to make her “60s truly count” commended her “60 cakes for 60 years” journey on Sept 1, through her small business Darituma’s Delights & Accessories. “This initiative is part of my ongoing personal commitment to give back to the community,” she said. “Each year, I try to contribute to a charitable cause. “I’ve chosen to support those bravely facing cancer this year.” Daveona said choosing to give to cancer came easy since she had lost loved ones and very close friends to this top lifestyle killer. “Last year, I did a fundraising for the cancer ward, but I realised that one market day could not raise enough for me to donate,” she said. “I had to continue raising a little at a time and by the time valentine’s day came, I had enough to make my little gift packs to donate 30 gift bags and a few trays of cupcakes. “This year, as I prepare to celebrate my 60th birthday on Sept 24, I am launching a fundraising drive to mark this milestone with purpose and generosity.” Daveona said all proceeds would be handed over to a representative of the cancer ward during Pinktober, on the 18th and 19th of October, as part of the Incubator Hub Information Market. “Making cake is my business and from that I feel comfortable enough to make money to help others,” she said. “So far, I have sold 13 cakes and have 47 more to reach my target of 60.” “If you would like to support by purchasing a cake, making a donation, or helping spread the word, your kindness and generosity will make a real difference in the lives of patients and their families.” Daveona’s involvement in charity work began with the “All nations women’s group” in Port Moresby – formed mainly by expatriate women who come and live as spouses. “I started my charity work in my forties (40),” she said. “Since coming to Lae eight years ago, I have donated cakes and cupcakes for churches, schools, and individuals for their fundraising activities.”

Title: There is reason to celebrate independence despite challenges
Content: STUDENTS of Tauran Primary School in East New Britain were reminded that there is still much to celebrate despite the challenges facing Papua New Guinea today. East New Britain administrator, Levi Mano, delivered the 50th anniversary encouragement to students during the school’s pre-Independence Day commemorative program held last week. Mano acknowledged the criticism surrounding the golden jubilee but encouraged the younger generation to look beyond negativity and appreciate the nation’s achievements. “We are still a united country, free, with no wars, and an abundance of food sources,” he said. “Other countries envy the freedom that we enjoy here. “PNG has not only survived for 50 years but its has also maintained its sovereignty as an independent state. It’s an achievement that the people should be proud of.” As a native of Viviran village, Mano described it as an honour to return to his home community and encourage them to celebrate the milestone with pride. The school holds national significance as the alma mater of the late Grand Chief Sir Paulias Matane, former governor-general, who was also buried near the school.

Title: K20 million for Jiwaka’s Waghi Mek plantation rehabilitaion work
Content: JIWAKA’s Waghi Mek Plantation (WMP) rehabilitation programme has a cash infusion of K20.5 million from the Government. The fund was presented on Monday by the Minister for Coffee William Bando and the provincial Governor Simon Kaiwi to the new board and administration in Banz. The K20.5 million was allocated three years ago for the rehabilitation of the Waghi Mek Plantation by the Marape government. The money has been sitting in the provincial government account until last week. Bando, on behalf of the Coffee Industry Corporation (CIC), presented K500,000 as seed capital to WMP. Kaiwi told the capacity crowd in Banz, the five directors of the board, CIC officials and the Minister that he released the K20 million which was in the provincial account for three years. Kaiwi said it took him that long because the process of getting Waghi Mek back meant it had to go through the process of re-registrations, meeting tax compliance processes, reorganising shareholders, appointing directors, putting in the board and getting the management in place. He said now that the processes are being met and satisfactory for WMP to operate as a company, the fund was deposited into the company’s account. WMP account now as a start-up capital of K20.5 million. In response, WMP chairman Gabriel Tai presented a 10-year work plan for WMP to Kaiwi. Tai said part of the plan was to rehabilitate the 13 plantations on the 600 hectares of land. The shareholders of the revamped WMP are the four local level government councils, North and South Waghi, Nondugul and Minj, and businessman Henry Hogan. It was made known earlier that 25 years ago, WMP generated K15-K20 million a year.

Title: Aviation centre a gift of friendship
Content: THE Aviation Heritage Centre that was opened yesterday at the National Museum and Art Gallery (NMAG) was a “gift of friendship”, Australian Chief of Air Force Air Marshall Stephen Chappell said. The centre, funded by the Royal Australian Air Force, was first established two years after independence in 1977 and stands today as the living testament to the two countries’ close relationship. But really the aircraft involves a triangle because a third country is included in the saga. The Douglas A-20 Havoc bomber belonged to the United States Air Force. The opening of the building starts with the aircraft, nicknamed Hell’N Pelican II. “During World War Two, it was in service in Papua New Guinea with 388th bomber squadron before it crash-landed in Madang 81 years ago when it found itself in the firing lines of Japanese Zeros,” Chappell said In 2022, then Air Marshall Mel Hupfeld set the wheels in motion to make sure the aircraft in PNG has a home.
