Construction of the centre started in April 2023 Chappell said the defence treaty between PNG and Australia, once signed, will further elevate the partnership, and serve to strengthen strategic trust and people to people links fostered between the two countries. “The three qualities that we share are the shared history or experiences, showing up for each other, and mutual respect.” NMAG president Terence Moka said it was conceived through the foresight of the founding father and first prime minister, the late grand chief sir Michael Somare who recognised that PNG’s rich culture and traditions were the existence of the people.

Title: Country’s literacy rate improving, says Kombra
Content: EDUCATION Department Secretary Dr Uke Kombra says literacy rate in the country has improved over the years, from 56 per cent in 2000 to 67 per cent in 2010. Kombra said the gains reflected efforts made through formal education as well as non-formal education programmes, run in partnership with churches, non-governmental organisations and Correctional Services. With the release of the 2024 census results soon, the country will then have a clearer picture of the current literacy levels, he said. But Kombra said there was still much to do. “With 2.7 million children in school today, we want to make sure that everyone going to school is able to read and write,” he said. “But those who miss school for one reason or another, we must also reach them through different modes of education,” he said. The secretary called for renewed national commitment to literacy as Papua New Guinea had launched National Literacy Week in Lae this week. He stressed that every citizen must be given the chance to read and write as the country goes into celebrating its 50th anniversary. Kombra reminded the nation that literacy is not only about children in schools but also about adults and young people who missed out on formal education. “Non-formal education is a very important part of our system where we advocate for those who are not literate to be literate,” he said. “We work in partnership with churches, Correctional Services, and non-governmental organisations to make sure no one is left behind in terms of learning how to read and write.” He said literacy remained both a challenge and a national responsibility. “The challenge is still there for us. In the next 50 years, as our education system grows, we must ensure literacy reaches every corner of Papua New Guinea,” he said.

Title: Eliminate illiteracy. Minister says 2.3 million remain illiterate in PNG
Content: EDUCATION Minister Lucas Dekena says 4.9 million Papua New Guineans can read and write, while 2.3 million remain illiterate out of a population of 7.3 million. The statistics are based on the 2000-2010 national census. Dekena made the statement during the launch of the 30th National Literacy Week in Lae on Monday. He said although 11 provinces had already reached the 70 per cent literacy target, millions of adults and more than 600,000 children still lack basic reading, writing, and numeracy skills. “Tackling illiteracy and innumeracy is a collective responsibility,’ he said. “It is crucial that we support the over 2 million adults and more than 600,000 children in Papua New Guinea who lack these skills. Dekena said the country has set its sights on eliminating illiteracy within the next 50 years. As part of this, the government has declared free education from early childhood to Grade 12 and is creating alternative pathways for adults who missed out on schooling. He said the Government had introduced direct interventions through policy reforms. “If school fees are a problem that keeps our children away from going to school, the government is making education free from elementary, early childhood, all the way to Grade 12. “From now, going into the future, there is no reason for our children not to go to school. Parents, it is your responsibility to ensure that your kids attend because you are not paying any school fees at all.” He noted that the national literacy rate had improved from 56.2 percent in 1980 to 67.6 percent by 2010, representing 4.9 million literate people out of a population of 7.3 million. “The way forward in literacy is to reduce poverty, combat social issues, and improve living standards. Reading is essential to gaining knowledge, which enables us to make informed choices and decisions. The government is also strengthening adult education through the Flexible Open and Distance Education programme, which has no age limit and allows learners to pursue a Grade 12 certificate at any stage of life.

Title: Defence Week ends with airshow
Content: PART of the static air display at the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) Air Transport Wing (ATW) at Eight-Mile was to inspire the younger generation to become pilots and aircraft engineers. ATW commanding officer Lt Col Douglas Vavar said they will need to retire and rest at some point. “We won’t be here for too long, and among the crowd I hope there are children inspired to become pilots and engineers,” he said. The airshow was open to the public between 9am and 3pm on Sunday. The aircraft on display were from  the United States Air Force, Royal Australian Air Force, New Zealand, King Air 350 from Australia’s 32 squadron, C27J Spartan from Australia’s 35 squadron, and PNGDF helicopter Bell 412 that is contracted  under the defence cooperation programme to support operations and three PAC 750 and two CASA aircraft. Vavar said France CASA CN-235 left on Saturday afternoon. “We are the people’s defence force, so we’re very happy that we have given the opportunity for the public to come out here to see the aircraft,” he said. Air movement commanding officer Lt Masonga Yapsie said New Zealand and Australia personnel displayed disaster rescue operations as well as capabilities for conduct of elections. He said during the week they were busy moving cargoes to provinces outside the National Capital District as part of the Planti Balus operation. “We’ve reached about 18 to 20 provinces, moving educational, medical and building materials. Most of the celebration is in the city, but through the operation, we reached other centres of the country,” he said. The display concluded all activities for the PNGDF Week. National flag carrier, Air Niugini, also participated in the spectacular airshow in Port Moresby on Saturday as part of the historic celebrations marking PNG’s 50th Independence anniversary. It joined the PNGDF and international partners in presenting a memorable showcase of aviation skill, pride and unity. Its Boeing 767, P2-PXW, bearing the national colours, was operated by three Papua New Guinean pilots – Captain Maurice Rondeau, Captain Esmond Yasi, and Captain Samiu Taufa. Flying under the call sign Niugini 8050, the aircraft performed controlled manoeuvres, including spectacular “go-around” to the delight of thousands of citizens watching from Ela Beach. Taufa, who is also Air Niugini’s officer-in-charge and acting chief operating officer, expressed his pride in the airline’s participation. “This was more than just a flyover – it was a proud moment for our nation,” he said. “To have Papua New Guinean pilots at the controls of our own national airline’s aircraft, flying over our capital city on such an important milestone, is deeply symbolic. “We thank the PNG Defence Force for including Air Niugini in this historic airshow, and we dedicate this participation to the people of PNG. The people saw their own sons in the cockpit, representing the skills, dreams, and pride of our country.”

Title: Pano ousted. Court orders by-election for Kagua-Erave
Content: THE National Court has ordered a by-election for the Kagua-Erave seat in Southern Highlands after finding that MP Maina Pano’s victory in the 2022 General Election was null and void. Judge Colin Makail yesterday upheld the petition filed by Emmanuel Loma Pamea who claimed allegations of illegal practices at polling and hijacking of ballot boxes. Pamea filed the petition based on the allegations claiming that the total number of votes were affected by the illegal practices more than the winning margin. Pano and the Electoral Commission had argued that Pamea’s arguments grounds be dismissed for being incompetent. The court dismissed them on errors at polling and grounds on errors at counting. But it ruled that the grounds on illegal practices at polling (hijacking and stuffing of ballot-boxes) were valid. The court heard that 17 ballot boxes were excluded from counting by the Returning Officer because they were hijacked and contained ballot papers that were not marked by voters. The court found that during the trial, the respondents did not cross-examine the witnesses’ accounts in relation to the hijacking and stuffing of these ballot boxes for the 17 wards in the Erave LLG. “I am satisfied that the total number of votes affected by the illegal practices is 13,561, representing 11,097 votes from the 17 hijacked ballot boxes, and 2,464 votes from two ballot boxes set on fire at the Kagua police station, as the winning margin was 4,550 votes. “The total number of votes affected was more than the winning margin. I am further satisfied that the result of the election was likely to be affected.” He also ordered that the people engaged in the illegal practices be referred to the police for further investigation and prosecution for hijacking and stuffing of ballot boxes with illegally marked ballot papers.

Title: Wingti recalls last DC 3 aircraft to come out of the sky
Content: HERE is former prime minister Paias Wingti under that landmark at Seven-Mile on the outskirts of Jackson International Airport, Port Moresby. But he is not there posing for a photograph because he wants some publicity. If you look at the plaque under the DC3 aircraft, it mentions that the aircraft was hoisted onto its pedestal on Feb 23, 1979, by Paias Wingti, then the Minister for Transport under the Somare government. Wingti said of that occasion: “This was the last DC 3 to come off the sky. “I asked Air Niugini to put that aircraft up for young Papua New Guineans to know of the history of this hard-working DC 3s. “We bought the first F28s from Nauru Airlines in 1979. “We slowly replaced all TAA and Anett small Fokkers and the DC3s. “Bruce Jeffcott was the first transport minister. I was the second. Okuk was the third.” Their tenure in office was rudely interrupted in March 1980 when Sir Julius Chan overthrew the government in the first successful motion of no confidence. Chan would move on to successfully nominate Paias Wingti as Prime Minister in November 1985 in another motion of no confidence.
People: Julius Chan, Paias Wingti, Sir Julius Chan

Title: Prime Minister appeals to fathers: Serve the nation
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has urged men and boys of Papua New Guinea, to “arise and serve the nation” as the country approaches its 50th Independence Anniversary on Sept 16. In his Father’s Day message, Marape paid tribute to the invaluable role that fathers and male figures play in shaping strong families, resilient communities and a united nation. “Our National Anthem begins with the powerful call, ‘O arise all you sons of this land’,” he said. “This is not just a lyric – it is a national responsibility. “As we prepare to celebrate 50 years of Independence, I urge every man and father in Papua New Guinea to arise, take your rightful place in society, and be the role models our children can look up to.” Marape emphasised that the call to arise is more than physical. It is a spiritual and moral duty, rooted in faith, integrity and service. “We must live according to God’s Word,” Marape said. “We must lead by example in our homes, communities, churches, and workplaces. “The country needs men who are grounded in faith, strong in character and respectful in conduct.” Marape also appealed for respect and protection of women and girls, saying that the strength of the nation depends on the well-being and safety of all its people. “To the fathers and men of Papua New Guinea: We are called not just to lead, but to serve with humility, to protect with courage and to love with compassion,” he said. “Let us teach our sons to honour women and girls. “Let us build a culture where respect is the foundation of every relationship.” As the country counts down to its Golden Jubilee of Independence, Marape stated that the future of Papua New Guinea lies in the hands of its families – and the fathers who lead them. “A strong nation is built on strong families. And strong families are built by responsible fathers,” he said. “Let us rise to the occasion, build up our homes, guide our children, and work together for a better and brighter future.” Marape thanked all fathers, grandfathers, uncles, brothers, and male mentors who are standing tall in their communities. “On this Father’s Day, I honour all the men who are doing their part, quietly and faithfully, to raise good children, support their partners, and make a difference,” he said. “Your role is sacred. “You are needed now more than ever. “Happy Father’s Day to all the Fathers in our country today. “May God bless you all and may God bless Papua New Guinea.”

Title: Leave a will so ‘family can have a fair share of your assets’, says Niningi
Content: PAPUA New Guineans have been urged to prepare a will for their next of kin to reduce the burden of an unfair inheritance by family members. Justice Minister and Attorney-General Pila Niningi said that many people died without leaving a will, which left their families fighting over their assets through the Office of Public Trustee. He said the Office of Public Trustee, an independent statutory body that acts as the custodian of a deceased person without a will, had come across many cases of people dying without leaving a will on how their assets should be distributed among family members. “This is a very important office that all citizens must know about,” he said. “It is our responsibility to educate the people because many people have left properties without saying anything in a will. “Therefore, I call upon Papua New Guineans to ensure their will expressly states how their properties and assets will be distributed after their death. “No matter how small it may be, there must be a will to ensure that your family can have a fair share of your assets. ‘This will make it easier for the Office of Public Trustee to administrate.” Niningi was at the launching of the Office of Public Trustee’s website in Port Moresby on Friday. “The new website promotes awareness, transparency and efficiency of the Office of Public Trustee services to the people,” Niningi said. “This launch is far more than a simple technical upgrade; it is about our commitment to good governance, transparency, decentralisation and the connecting with our people.”

Title: Climate change, development among agenda for Pacific leaders forum
Content: CLIMATE change and development issues affecting Papua New Guinea and the region will be discussed at the 54th Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) in Honiara, Solomon Islands, this week, according to Prime Minister James Marape. “Melanesia, Polynesia and Micronesia, are a family that speaks as one voice on common issues that affect all of us,” he said. “All leaders of the Pacific are expected to attend, including the prime ministers of Australia and New Zealand, and presidents and prime ministers of the other island nations. “This is an important moment in the face of many global issues, including the existential threat of climate change and the increasing pressure from bigger nations seeking our allegiance. “There are many common challenges right across the Pacific so we want to address them and preserve our own policy and sovereign preferences.” He said that the PIF was an important platform to raise concerns affecting the country and other Pacific island nations, particularly climate change and geo-politics. Papua New Guinea will stress that the Pacific nations must remain together. “We want to tell those who are coming into the Pacific to divide us to take your division elsewhere. “We stand as one family in the Pacific,” he said. Marape said Pacific Island leaders would travel to Port Moresby after the meeting. “After our meeting here in Honiara, they will travel to Port Moresby on a Solomon Islands–assisted charter this Saturday, and will remain with us until Sept 17 before departing for their respective countries or onward to the United Nations General Assembly. “Their presence is a great privilege for us and a profound show of solidarity with Papua New Guinea,” he said. Marape returns to the country today and will go back to Honiara on Thursday for a leaders’ retreat.

Title: UN Secretary-General failed to address issues, says Opposition leader
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa says the United Nations (UN) General Secretary Antonio Guterres did not address issues affecting the nation and region during his visit last week. Tomuriesa said: “While we (Opposition) all appreciate the visit by the UN General-Secretary, we the Opposition are concerned that the highest ranking official of the United Nations has totally failed to address some of the major issues affecting the nation and the region. Abuse of our woman and girls and ordinary men and women on the streets. The UN General-Secretary should address the issues affecting our closest neighbours while being in the country. During a farewell event in Port Moresby on Friday, Marape remained confident that UN had PNG covered after offering it a glimpse into the county’s bio-diversity and culture in the true Melanesian way. Marape said: “What a four days with the United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. “He arrived four days ago, addressed our people’s house, met all including giving respect to late Sir Michael Somare in Wewak, visiting rural PNG in Nuku and spent his third night in a mountain lodge outside of Mt Hagen in Western Highlands. “I had said farewell to him at the door of the plane (Air Niugini) on Friday afternoon and knew not that the great man was ‘there watching my back’ as I left. What a picture of humility, gratitude and service the senior teaches. Instead of taking his seat, he stood watching me leave!” he said. Guterres’ visit to the country was at the invitation of Marape and coincided with Papua New Guinea’s 50th golden jubilee celebrations. PNG has been a member of the United Nations since Oct 10, 1975. In his farewell speech, Guterres said: “I express my deep admiration, gratitude and solitude in relation to the role PNG plays to the world and its extraordinary role to this country to address the issues of climate change.”

Title: UN chief impressed with Hagen agriculture
Content: UNITED Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres was amazed when he looked down from the plane as it hovered above Western Highlands and noticed land being ploughed and rows of garden produce being planted. Governor Wai Rapa when welcoming Guterres and a delegation at Mt Hagen on Thursday, briefed him of the local’s way of life, including political administration, governance, business, agriculture and the position of the province in the regional growth. Guterres said: “I was amazed by the fields (farms), high productivity farming and agriculture. “Many people in the world think that past farming was done in Egypt or Mesopotamia. “But I learned that agriculture was born here in Western Highlands. “You have such a high-quality agriculture production in your province.” Guterres’ reference to agriculture in Western Highlands refers to scientific verification that Kuk Swamp saws evidence that agriculture existed for nearly 10,000 years, making it one of the oldest sites known to man. Rapa noted that the provincial economy was based on agriculture, and given the climate and the land, Western Highlands remains the food basket of the country. He thanked the United Nations through its agencies and partners that have supported communities through many interventions and resilient programmes, including livelihood projects.

Title: Teenage pregnancy a factor in school dropouts: Study
Content: A NEW national study has identified pregnancy as a significant factor causing girls to leave school early in PNG, highlighting a critical need for targeted sexual and reproductive health and support services for the country’s massive youth population. The 2024 National Youth Baseline Study, conducted by the Papua New Guinea National Research Institute (PNGNRI), reveals the challenges facing a demographic where young people under 25 make up about 60 per cent of the population—about 7.3 million people. This group is projected to grow rapidly, with the national population expected to reach 13 million by 2032. The study, which surveyed 9,029 youths, found a critically high education dropout rate, with six out of every 10 youths having left the education system prematurely. This aligns with the country’s low literacy rate, where only one in three children complete their basic education. Among the key reasons for discontinuing education, the study found that pregnancy accounted for 4.6 per cent of all dropouts. This figure, representing 309 individuals in the study sample, highlights a specific barrier to education faced by young women and is consistent with data showing that one in six women in PNG gives birth to her first child before the age of 18. The research also indicates that broader family instability directly impacts school attendance. The data shows that 3.7 per cent of youths left school due to their parents splitting up, which often places additional domestic and financial burdens on young women. The consequences of dropping out are severe and contribute to a cycle of disadvantage. The study found that 86 per cent of youths are unemployed, with a lack of qualifications being a primary barrier. This situation is exacerbated by inadequate access to formal education, a lack of job training opportunities and a high unemployment rate, which often leaves young people disengaged and can lead to increased vulnerability and social issues. Furthermore, the environment for young people is challenging. Children and youths in PNG are exposed to the highest rate of violence in the East Asia and Pacific Region, with a large number suffering physical, verbal and sexual abuse. The formal justice system remains inaccessible to most, with less than 20 per cent of child victims having access to courts. The study’s findings point to the necessity of integrated policy interventions. Addressing barriers specific to girls, such as pregnancy through sexual and reproductive health education and family planning, is essential. More broadly, investments in the health, education and employability of this large youth cohort are not just a social imperative but an economic one. Without these investments, the potential of this generation to contribute positively to the nation’s future will not be realised.

Title: Bougainville election counting expected to start on Thursday
Content: COUNTING of votes for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government general election is expected to start on Thursday after polling ended yesterday. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai said that although a one-day polling period was conducted as scheduled on Friday, polling had to be extended in selected locations in the region and other provinces because the names of some voters were not on the electoral roll. He said polling was extended for Bougainvilleans living in the National Capital District (NCD), East New Britain, Morobe and Madang for Central Bougainville voters only. Bougainvilleans in Eastern Highlands also cast their votes for North, Central and South Bougainville. Tsianai said that the extension of the polling period in selected locations was made to ensure that all Bougainvilleans living outside the region would be able to participate in the election. Writs are expected to be returned the 22nd of this month. Meanwhile, assistant returning officer Bordger Semoso toldThe Nationalthat polling for Central Bougainville voters in NCD was completed yesterday. He clarified that only North Bougainville and South Bougainville voters were able to cast their ballots on Friday. “The polling on Friday was only for North and South Bougainville voters,” he said. “It did not include Central Bougainville because the ballot papers for the ex-combatant seat didn’t arrive on time. We’re conducting the election for Central Bougainville and should complete polling. While this is being done in NCD, the same is being done in Goroka, Madang, Kokopo and Lae.”

Title: Ombudsman directs MPs to acquit district funds
Content: THE Ombudsman Commission (OC) has directed all MPs to submit their outstanding service improvement programme acquittals in compliance with the Organic Law on the Duties and Responsibilities of Leadership. In a notice dated July 15, 2025 published in this paper yesterday, the OC said it was “alarming” that some MPs were yet to submit their district service improvement programme (DSIP) and provincial service improvement programme (PSIP) acquittals to the commission’s head office in Port Moresby, even after a similar notice was issued in February. Chief Ombudsman Richard Pagen, Ombudsman Tabitha Suwae and acting Ombudsman Kevin Kepore said in a joint statement: “The Ombudsman Commission calls on all Members of Parliament to submit all outstanding acquittal reports for the PSIP and DSIP within six weeks from the date of this publication. “Therefore. the Ombudsman Commission unequivocally demands that all outstanding PSIP and DSIP acquittal reports be submitted to the Department of Implementation and Rural Development within six weeks from today. “This final notice applies to all unacquitted PSIP and DSIP funds from previous years, including the submission of all 2024 reports. “Failure to comply with the existing laws and policies guiding the requirements for acquittals constitutes a breach and can prompt an enquiry under the Leadership Code. “Copies of the acquittals must be sent to the Ombudsman Commission through its regional offices and its head office in Port Moresby before the deadline. “It is important that this directive is complied with as non-compliance will result in charges of misconduct in office under Section 23 of the Organic Law of the Duties and Responsibilities of Leadership.”

Title: Police launch probe into Lae deaths
Content: INDEPENDENT investigators will be sent to Lae to investigate the killing of two youths and injuring of six others at West Taraka on Saturday, police say. According to Police Commissioner David Manning, investigations will be carried out and members of the PNG Defence Force who were alleged to have been involved, will be dealt with accordingly. Manning, in a report released on Sunday, stated that what happened on Saturday morning was unacceptable. The report states that initial investigations confirmed that those involved in the attack at West Taraka were military personnel. Lae metropolitan commander Chief Supt Chris Kunyanban also confirmed that an independent team of investigators would be in Lae to investigate the incident. “At the moment, no arrests have been done, but once investigation is on, suspects will be identified and they will be dealt with under appropriate laws,” Kunyanban said. He said only through investigation, those identified will be brought before the law and they can prove their innocence in the court of law. While comparing the recent Kapiak Street incident resulting in people being killed and now the West Taraka incident, Chief Supt Kunyanban said it showed that people were not allowing police to do their job. In these two incidents, people were taking the laws into their own hands which had made the situation serious and complicated as well. “Police are here to solve such issues lawfully and people have to report such incidents and let police deal with them to avoid such complicated situations from happening in the future,” Kunyanban said. The call for an independent investigation was made following the killing of two youths and injuring of another six, as well as destruction and burning of properties allegedly by members of the PNGDF at Igam Barracks in Lae following the killing of a soldier at Kids Kona, early on Saturday.

Title: Officers graduate in data processing, management
Content: TWENTY police officers from Western Highlands’ Mt Hagen have graduated in data processing and management from a two-week course offered by the Somare Institute of Leadership and Governance (Silag) last Friday. Provincial police commander (PPC) Chief Supt John Sagom thanked the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) for funding the upskilling of the 20 police officers, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) for setting up the information and communication technology centre at Kimininga Barracks and the police human resource division for facilitating the training. He also acknowledged Silag for conducting the training. Sagom said the training was important because police officers needed to collate, analyse and submit reports to make police work efficient. He said a few had computer skills and spread sheet experiences while the others were taught the skills in basic computing and the use of the Excel spreadsheet. One of the graduates, sector response unit commander, Insp Jacob Kumin, said during his 25-year career with the RPNGC, he had never done data processing using the spread sheet. “Today the world is going paperless, most of us when it comes to court files, complaints, we are doing them on paper and record keeping and updating are outdated,” he said. He said the course would help them to efficiently manage information and data. Rebecca Gonapa, Silag’s director for learning development, research and innovation, thanked the RPNGC for engaging the institute to do the training.

Title: Madang cops warn against disruptions
Content: MADANG police have warned the public not to engage in illegal activities to disrupt the 50th Independence anniversary celebrations as police will not hesitate to arrest those involved. Provincial police commander acting Supt Robert Baim issued the warning after rumours on social media that disruptions were expected during the celebrations nationwide. “Social media had it that youths would disrupt the event,” he said. “The rumours are baseless. “People should not believe this as police will be on high alert during the celebrations. “If it does happen, police will come down hard on those involved.” Baim said police in Madang were on alert and were monitoring the movement of people in hotspots to ensure this did not happen. “If we see any such actions or movements likely to disrupt the celebrations, we will respond immediately and swiftly as public safety is paramount,” he said. Baim said if there were grievances with the Government or anyone else, there were lawful channels that the one could go through peacefully to solve their issues and not through violent means. “The public in Madang is urged not to ever think of doing any nasty thing that might cause disruptions to the independence celebrations,” Baim said. “Police will give their best to ensure that public safety is upheld and properties are safe.” The celebrations should encourage unity, reflection and oneness among people from all walks of life despite coming from different cultural backgrounds, he added. “Over the last 50 years, the country has gone through numerous challenges to have come this far,” Baim said. “So people have to take ownership of these celebrations and make it a memorable one. “After this, we can plan for the better into the next 50 years.” Baim said people should promote cultural diversity.

Title: Rosso and top cop hail commitment of Lae police
Content: DEPUTY Prime Minister and Lae MP John Rosso has joined Lae metropolitan police commander Chief Superintendent Chris Kunyanban in applauding Lae police for managing crime in Lae. In relation to a recent chain of criminal activities in and around the city, Rosso said police have handled situations well. “It also shows that crime does not pay. Lae police have dealt with all these incidents and continue to lead the way in making Lae safe,” he said. Rosso said there was no major increase in crime “as sensationalised by media”. “We are a city of nearly 4,000 persons, and there will still be some incidents of crime,” he said. “Compared with other provinces and cities, there have been one or two robberies, but our police have responded and dealt with them. “It’s not a spike in crime, that’s just social media sensationalising it, resulting in everyone thinking Lae has a surge in crime. “Lae police have dealt with them all in a professional manner.” Kunyanban thanked the Lae City Authority (LCA) for helping police through a reserve programme. He said Lae police had been challenged by a population boom, which had put a strain on their manpower and response. Kunyanban said the programme over the last two years had seen the inception of foot patrols around Eriku and the main market area, reducing criminal activities in these hotspots. “I applaud our MP John Rosso for this vision,” he said. “We use the operational aspect of things – meaning that they come to work, we tell them where to work, conduct foot beat or what to do for the day while administration purposes – their uniform and allowances – are being paid by LCA. “This an agreement which the commissioner has put in place to cater for the numerical strength for each province.”

Title: Show helps raise funds for kids in need
Content: A FASHION show was held in Port Moresby on Thursday evening to raise funds for the Gateway Children’s Fund – a charity focused on improving the lives of children in need. Gateway Children’s Fund founding chairman and chief executive officer Rick Paynter said they could not carry out its functions without the “awesome amount of support and goodwill”. He thankedThe National, Sir Brian Bell Foundation, Hilton Port Moresby Hotel and Residences and Sylvia Pascoe for supporting the fashion runway. “My church in Melbourne pays for all the administration. We have no big offices here, just the school. “All of the money goes straight to the primary school for food, education and paying of teachers,” Paynter said. “At Gateway Children’s Fund, our motto is to be an outpost of hope.” Australian television presenter and media commentator Kendall Gilding was host and special guest. Quoting statistics from the United Nations Children’s Fund, Paynter said: “In PNG, there are over 10,000 paediatric deaths every year, that is a child who dies under five. And the chief causes – malnutrition, malaria, dysentery, dehydration and the flu – are preventable. That drives our work at Gateway Children’s Fund to try to push back against those terrible statistics. “Our school has been running since 2012. “Since 2012, we have not one child die in our programme from preventable diseases. We provide education from kinder to Grade Six. “Within that programme, all the children are getting nutrition and medical care, and it’s free for them. “Most of these children would not go to school if it were not for a school like ours.” Paynter said its main site was at Moitaka in Port Moresby where its school is located. The other site is in Goroka, Eastern Highlands. “Of all the children who enter our programme, particularly our school, 84 per cent graduate (from) Grade Six,” Paynter said. He said the remaining 16 per cent of children did not complete the programme mainly due to parents moving away.

Title: School stages cultural show to raise funds
Content: Laloki Secondary School in Central’s Hiri-Koiari held a cultural show to raise funds for the school while commemorating the country’s golden jubilee anniversary. School principal Carol Tsinabi, while opening the cultural show, said the show was to raise funds for the school to address the 2023-2025 School Learning Improvement Plan (Slip). She said although tuition fee free funding was allocated, it was only suitable for school operations and no external projects to improve school infrastructure. “There are 34 teachers and 1,087 students,” Tsinabi said. “Only 17 teachers reside in the school and only 432 are boarding students.” She highlighted this to portray a picture of the need to build teachers’ houses and boarding accommodation for students. “We are hoping that the event will help us with some funds so that we can build one of two houses as well as other focus areas of the Slip which are yet to be implemented,” Tsinabi said. She urged former students, Central leaders and individuals to contribute towards the fundraising drive. “We appreciate our founding fathers, Sir Michael Somare, Sir Julius Chan and all who fought for our Independence,” Tsinabi said.
People: Julius Chan, Michael Somare, Sir Julius Chan

Title: 54th Pacific Islands Forum starts in Honiara
Content: THE 54th Pacific Islands Forum Leaders Meeting (PIFLM) begins today in Honiara, Solomon Islands with all delegates from the 18-member country participating in discussions and decisions from Sept 8-12. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele said that they were ready and happy to host the 54th PIFLM in Honiara and to share not only the forum but our culture, our stories and our hospitality. “Hosting the forum for the third time after 1979 and 1992 reflects our commitment to Pacific solidarity and to the values of unity and corporation that lies at the hearts of our Pacific way,” he said Manele said the theme of this year’s forum, “Umi Tugeda: Act now for an integrated blue Pacific continent”, was both a reflection of who we are and a call to where we must go. “‘Umi tugeda – we are together’, these words speak directly to our identity as Pacific people,” he said. “In Solomon Islands, the words reflect our custom, wantok system, traditions that honor kinship, neutral support and collective responsibilities. “These are not just cultural expressions; they are the foundations of our regionalism.” Manele said the Pacific island nations needed to act now. He said our challenges demanded urgent actions whether it was the impact of climate change on our shores, the sustainable management of our resources or the resilience of our economies, the time for plans and discussions as passed. “Now is the time for decisions and actions and an integrated blue Pacific continent,” he said.

Title: O’Neill: IMF now admits true state of economy
Content: FORMER prime minister Peter O’Neill says that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in a recent report admitted that the country’s economy is 20 per cent smaller than it should be. “The IMF’s resident representative Sohrab Rafiq has handed down his organisation’s latest economic update plainly admitting (that) the economy is essentially 20 percent smaller than it otherwise would have been if it had continued to grow at its pre-Covid, pre-2019 trend,” the Ialibu-Pangia MP said in a statement. “Despite all the talking from this Government and their proxy controllers of Treasury, the IMF, it is quite something to see this backhanded compliment from the head of the IMF that the heavily criticised economic management under my watch has been recognised as not too bad after all. “The headline numbers cannot be denied – the facts are that in 2011 the total Gross Domestic Product was just under K30 billion and in 2019, when the leadership changed to (James) Marape, the economy was nearly three times bigger at K85 billion. “Gold price, a major influence on PNG’s GDP, was on average US$1,250 (about K5,922) per ounce during my term, compared to US$2,500 (about K11,845) from 2019 to 2025 during the Marape government.” O’Neill said that in simple terms, Marape and Treasurer Ian Ling-Stuckey “and their friends at the IMF have enjoyed the benefits of a doubling of the average gold price and yet have failed to translate these upswings in the economy to improvements in our peoples’ lives”. “Instead, we are much worse off with rampant crime and corruption and a cost-of-living crisis, over indebtedness and a chronic shortage of medicines, sliding currency and a drought on jobs,” he said. “It was not perfect during my leadership, but even the IMF now admits the economy would be 20 per cent bigger today if our strategy of managing the economy had continued.” O’Neill, the leader of the People’s National Congress Party said that he did not hold the IMF up as a shining light of economic truth-telling or expertise. “(I) prefer to assess our economy based on how families are getting on, how businesses are investing and how many young people are in good jobs,” he said.

Title: ‘Teach our children their cultures’: School celebrates two milestones
Content: CHILDREN should be taught their cultures to give them a sense of identity so they can meaningfully contribute to nation-building, a school administrator says. Virtues Early Child Care and Education director Shalanta Boli said Papua New Guinea’s culture had been “our moral compass”. “A child can only know who he or she is if they understand their identity,” Boli said. The school on Friday celebrated the country’s 50th Independence anniversary and the school’s 15th anniversary. “No matter how culturally diverse we are, how mixed we are, we must teach our children their cultures to give them their sense of identity and in that, they can find their strength to meaningfully contribute to nation building,” Boli said. The celebration also honoured the legacy of school founder Theresa Aria Boli. The organisation has held on to the principles of being just and fair, to weigh things thoroughly, and has never been self-serving. Boli added: “More importantly, we have held on to hope. “The hope and faith of being a propelling positive catalyst towards nation-building by contributing ethical morally-just individuals who can and will lead our nation into a future that we all can be proud of. “The foundation and building blocks of this organisation has been built on pure love and affection for wanting better for our children.”

Title: Bougainville extends polling
Content: POLLING for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government general election has been extended in selected locations in the region and other provinces because some names were missing from the electoral roll. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai said that after a one-day polling period was conducted as scheduled on Friday, an extension was necessary because some voters could not find their names on the electoral roll. “The long queues we saw in some places were a challenge, but they were also a reflection of something we should celebrate – Bougainvilleans’ commitment to democracy and their determination to make their voices heard,” Tsianai said. “High turnout is a strength of our democracy. “Listening to voters and learning from their experiences will help us build an even better electoral process for the future.” He commended the people for ensuring that polling was conducted peacefully on Friday, following polling in the Atolls constituency on Thursday. Polling will be held today (Sept 8) for Bougainvilleans living in the National Capital District, East New Britain, Morobe and Madang for Central Bougainville voters only. Bougainvilleans in Eastern Highlands will also be casting their votes for North, Central and South Bougainville. He said that the decision was made to ensure that all Bougainvilleans living outside the region would be able to participate in the election. “I urge all Bougainvilleans living and working in the five provinces to take note of the announcement and participate in the polling on Monday (today),” he said.

Title: PNGDF airshow highlights service of women in military
Content: THE participation of women joining the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) Air Transport Wing (ATW) is minimal, says director Air Preparations Lt Col Nancy Wii. Wii said there have not been many women in the force and so far they have 300 females but in three different sections. “At ATW we have about 15 females in areas of aircraft engineering, movement personnel and our support staff as for female pilots I am the only one at the moment and we would like to see more women join the rank and file,” she said. Port Moresby residents turned out over the weekend to witness aircraft flying over Ela Beach as part of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force Week Air Show. Alongside PNGDF’s PAC750 aircraft, was Australia’s C-27J the Spartan has frequently supported operations into PNG’s remote areas and rugged airstrips. Other aircraft included New Zealand’s NH90, France’s CASA CN235, Hercules C-130J, Australia’s King Air 350, PNGDF’s Bell412 that flew the PNG flag, United States KC135 and Air Niugini A220. “We have been grounded and we revived ourselves with the Royal Australian Air Force through our partnership in 2020 and so far have three PAC 750 aircraft,” Wii said. “Through the flight of excellence programme we have trained pilots, load masters, movement personnel. The PAC 750 are just the foundation; they are used to train our pilots to build the air force of PNGDF.” Wii has been with the PNGDF for 20 years since she joined 2005 when there was a requirement for pilots. She was flying for Air Lines PNG at that time. “I did my flight training in New Zealand, self- sponsored and I’ve been doing other training in Australia,” she added. She noted that dropping down from the PAC 750 with parachutes was a first for them and was a capability they were building. Australian Air Force Wing Commander Dianne Bell and captain of the C-130J added that they were excited to be here and supporting PNGDF and all the activities that have happened. “It is really good for the younger generations who aspire to become pilots.”

Title: Guterres appeals for PNG during Nuku visit
Content: THE weapon we have against climate change is the forest, says United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. “I am here to bring a hug, a big hug from the people of the world to the people of Nuku, and the people of the mountains,” Guterres told the Nuku people during his visit there on Thursday. “And I have two messages from the world to you. First message, a message of gratitude. We are extremely grateful because of the forest that you are preserving for the world. Such a beautiful group of people in such a beautiful landscape, keeping this forest that benefits the whole world. “You have heard about climate change. You know the temperatures are rising. And in the Pacific, there are islands that are sinking. There are droughts that are making life impossible for farmers. There are floods that destroy houses and properties. All this because of climate change. So, thank you very much in the name of the world for the way you preserve this beautiful forest.” Guterres said. Guterres in his second message spoke about solidarity. “I spoke with the Prime Minister (James Marape). He has great plans for this country. To have much more roads, to have much more schools, to have much more health centres. But this is a huge country, full of mountains with certain remote areas. “It’s a very difficult job that he has. And I want to express here a very strong appeal, an appeal to the international community to support the Government and the people of Papua New Guinea, for the people and the Government of Papua New Guinea to be able to accelerate the progress in roads, the progress in schools, the progress in health centres to the benefit of everybody. And the United Nations will be at your side, and will be loud and clear, telling the international community that these beautiful people deserve solidarity, because you are giving the world an enormous gift with your forest. It’s time for the world to pay back, Guterres said. He said international communities around the world that receive enormous benefits from PNG’s forests and oceans and should support the country and its development. “So I want to launch an appeal for international communities to accept the climate justice and countries like PNG must have all the support it was promised. “This is so the country is able to address the needs of adaptation to build resilience and protect its people and country against devastating impacts of climate change and also justice in the way international financial institutions address the problems of development of this country,” he said. Guterres said the international finance architecture created in 1975 was outdated. Those institutions with benefit from the presence of PNG when created and therefore there is a need for reforms in international Financial system for country’s like PNG to have a stronger voice and make the right decisions and a much higher access to resources that are essential to the development of country. “PNG has enormous challenges but because it is a middle income country has no access to concessional funding. “This is injustice that must be corrected and therefore international communities must respond to the generosity of PNG and its contribution to fight climate change from its wonderful forests and oceans. “PNG does not contribute to climate change, it has a negative emission record, therefore it needs all the support it can get,” he said. He said international communities must be able to understand the importance of supporting PNG for a modern society.

Title: UN Secretery-General Guterres praises PNG’s democracy
Content: UNITED Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres expressed admiration for Papua New Guinea’s 50 years of uninterrupted democracy and commitment to peace. “Papua New Guinea is a country with 50 years of uninterrupted democracy … a remarkable example in today’s world, and I want to pay tribute to that and to express my deep admiration,” he said. He also highlighted Papua New Guinea’s crucial role in the global fight against climate change. “Papua New Guinea does not contribute to climate change. Papua New Guinea has a negative emissions record … And the same international community that receives the enormous benefit of Papua New Guinea’s forests and oceans must pay back. Calling for climate justice and reforms in international financing, the Secretary-General emphasised that middle-income developing nations such as Papua New Guinea should have access to concessional funding to support resilience and sustainable development. “This is an injustice that must be corrected,” he stressed. On Thursday Guterres honoured the memory of founding father Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare by visiting Somare’s final resting place in Wewak, East Sepik before travelling with Marape to Nuku in West Sepik on the same day. There he interacted warmly with citizens, shaking hands with mothers, elders and children, and viewing community-based UN programmes in action. He later travelled to Mt Hagen, Western Highlands, where he met with beneficiaries of UN initiatives in peace-building, gender-based violence response, maternal health, youth development and education, staying late into the night to engage in dialogue.

Title: UN visit a milestone for us, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has described the visit by United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres as a “milestone moment” for the nation, coinciding with its 50th Independence Anniversary and strengthening PNG’s partnership with the UN. “He was not just in Port Moresby as head of the UN family; he is responsible for all citizens of planet Earth in terms of a moral voice, the advocacy, a pointer to directions. He stepped out of Port Moresby with me … into rural Nuku (West Sepik) that depicts the 85 per cent of our people who still are living in the rural pockets of our country,” Marape said. Marape praised the Secretary-General’s humility and dedication, saying: “You have certainly inspired us to lift our game as far as working to ‘leave no child behind and no place behind’. You have entrenched our relationship … and more importantly our subscription to leaving no place and no child behind.” Marape thanked Guterres on behalf of the people of Papua New Guinea for his visit and leadership, noting that it had further anchored the UN–PNG partnership at a pivotal moment in the country’s history. Marape noted that Guterres also highlighted the importance of Papua New Guinea’s vast forests, biodiversity, and carbon reserves to the global climate agenda. Marape said this acknowledgment was timely as PNG continues to advocate for sustainable development, climate financing, and eco-tourism opportunities that benefit its people. “Guterres reminded the world that nations with big carbon footprints must support countries like PNG, whose intact forests and ecosystems serve as lungs of the planet. “His vision resonates with our national priorities to turn ecological wealth into sustainable economic opportunities for our citizens,” Marape said He further recalled that the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare was instrumental in shaping the global climate framework, with Papua New Guinea’s leadership securing the inclusion of REDD+ as Article 5 of the Paris Agreement in 2015.

Title: Police will prosecute soldiers allegedly involved in death of two people
Content: POLICE Commissioner, David Manning, has assured the public in Lae that soldiers allegedly involved in the death of two people and injuries to six others in West Taraka, Morobe, will be prosecuted to the full extent of the law. Commissioner Manning said an incident on Saturday morning, (Sept 6), was unacceptable and the public expects much more from disciplined personnel. “Initial investigations have confirmed those involved in an attack on West Taraka residents were military personnel and the incident was related to a personal dispute,” Manning said in a statement yesterday. “Some of the offenders are alleged to have been wearing military uniforms and travelled in PNGDF vehicles.  Police are working with the PNGDF hierarchy to ensure the matter is properly investigated and prosecuted,” Manning said. “While the PNGDF will deal with this tragic indecent through their internal disciplinary processes, this is a criminal investigation and that is how the case will be pursued through legal processes. “We are in the process of identifying all individuals involved and charges will be laid. “The country expects more from those who serve our nation in uniform, and all must honour the oaths they swore. “I know the PNGDF Commander has made significant progress in instilling discipline in personnel, as we are doing in the RPNGC, and there is zero tolerance for violent and reckless behaviour. “This is senseless violence that has resulted in the death of two people, injuries to six others, and significant theft and property damage. “The people of Morobe can rest assured that those involved are being confined to barracks while investigations are underway. Charges will be laid, and those responsible will face the law to answer for their actions. “With charges being laid and prosecutions sought before the court, police are limited in some of the detail that can be released. “However, as charges are made against individuals, this will be made public. “Police have increased patrols in the area to further reassure the public that the incident has concluded.”

Title: Lutherans celebrate 50th independence anniversary
Content: THE Evangelical Lutheran Church of Papua New Guinea joined the nation in commemorating its 50 years with a two-day pre-independence celebration event over the weekend in Lae. The event started with a float around the city. The faith-based community then congregated at Martin Luther Seminary where various information booths were set up, complemented by traditional and contemporary dances and songs over Friday and Saturday. Head Bishop Dr Jack Urame said the Lutheran Church among many other churches were forerunners of development and nation building, transforming lives of many Papu New Guineans through the Gospel of Christ and through social services like education, health care, community empowerment in agriculture, economic and infrastructure. “We became an autonomous local church in 1956, almost two decades ahead of the country’s independence,” he said. “We were leading the way on the path to localisation, self-determination, self-governing and local responsibility and ownership, becoming the model of our nation in many things.” Today, the church has a membership of two million people with 17 districts and many more circuits, parishes and congregations spreading across the country. Urame said this celebration was not for those achievements, but for their contribution to nation building. “Churches worked independently from the government and laid the foundation for social and economic development of the country, many of which are still standing today through church schools and church heath facilities, airstrips, roads and other infrastructures built by the churches,” he said.  “The churches contributed immensely to the human resource capacity of the country and continue to do so, creating an enabling environment for character formation and disciplined life, forming, molding, shaping and grooming Christian citizens and Christian leaders for this country.”

Title: Everything is electronic inside the new courthouse, says Sir Gibbs
Content: CHIEF Justice Sir Gibbs Salika says everything is electronic inside the new courthouse. The courthouse is expected to be opened on Wednesday this week. Sir Gibbs said after the swearing-in ceremony of Justice Graham Ellis at the Government House that this was a technological improvement. “I am expecting a lot of improvement in the judicial time because at the moment, there are judges waiting to have their turn to go into courtrooms,” he said. “We have to wait for other judges to finish presiding over their cases and would be told by their associates to go in once they were done.” Sir Gibbs said that this would no longer be an issue as with the new technological improvement, everyone would be sitting all at the same time. He said there would be less paper and he expected improvements in the performance of the judges’ work. It was announced earlier that case backlogs had drastically increased and doubled from the time the country got its independence. “There are indicators that will assist us to know whether we are performing or not,” Sir Gibbs said. “But I believe there is room for the judiciary to improve in case dispositions. “To invest in the judiciary in that kind of court setting, we are lifting the profile of the legal profession from the judiciary up to the lawyers themselves.” Sir Gibbs has urged all judges and lawyers to join hands in working together to professionally attend to the legal needs of the people, so that they can be properly assisted.

Title: PNGDF expected to be stronger in the next 50 years: Minister
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) is expected to be a much stronger force in the next 50 years, says Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph. Joseph said this during a ceremonial event on Friday to thank the land and support units that facilitated or took part in exercise Antap Long Ol. “I’m very proud of the achievement including all the commanding officers of the units. Like the Chief of PNGDF Rear Admiral Philip Polewara said, PNGDF would not have existed if that walk didn’t happen,” he said. “That walk 50 years ago was not to show solidarity to Government but also to convince the Government that PNG needed a defence force.” Joseph said in the Southwest Pacific, PNG was one of the three countries to have a defence force apart from Fiji and Tonga. “It is really important we have a defence force,” he added. “A defence force that is capable and ready to respond to any challenges either domestically, internally and within the region.” Joseph said they were working to build the force capability to have in place the white paper 2013, the defence act and all other activities that will strengthen air, land, marine and cyberspace. National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop said they took this exercise seriously in terms of the messages and the impact. “We are here to show our appreciation to the different units who participated,” he said. “We should not lose focus of our customs to appreciate the contributions of our people. “Without the security personnel and safety provided by soldiers that is needed for economic and social development to take place, things won’t work out.” Both Parkop and Joseph along with their team presented 10 pigs, store items and garden food as an appreciation towards the land units. PNGDF’s new chief force preparations Col Michael Banda thanked both leaders and said the walk was important in the sense that the messages contained independence goodwill messages to inform the Government that was going to be formed that the force was going to be committed.

Title: Teacher urges schools to teach cultural pride
Content: SCHOOLS have a responsibility to instil cultural pride in young children, says a teacher. Barbara Mogu, founder and head teacher of Barby’s Early Childhood School in Lae, said  schools were a second home to children, and naturally should enable positive learning in all aspects of a child’s life. The Nationalobserved many schools in Lae braving the rain to host their pre-independence celebrations on Wednesday. Barby’s held its event on the school premises, displaying cultural dances and re-enacting the history of civilizationand PNG’s journey to independence. Their drama depicted Western influence and the introduction of religion and its impact on culture and tradition. Mogu said teaching the children about the country’s history should be included as animportant aspect of school curriculums.

Title: Nine on UK’s Chevening Scholarship off to study for masters
Content: AS the country prepares to celebrate its 50th Independence anniversary, nine Papua New Guineans will be travelling to the United Kingdom (UK) to do various Masters programmes through the UK government’s Chevening Scholarship Programme. The Chevening Scholarship Programme is a prestigious, fully-funded Master’s scholarship offered to international students with leadership potential aimed at providing them with a world-class education, global network and confidence. Speaking at the farewell reception in Port Moresby on Saturday, British High Commissioner Anne Macro said these talented young men and women would soon be embarking on a life-changing experience. “These men and women are our 2025 achievement cohorts who will be going for a 12-month Masters study programme,”she said “This gathering is basically for a pre-departure briefing. This is when we tell them all about what London is like, what they need to take for the cold weather and how important their studies are and all that.” She explained that another type of scholarship called the Commonwealth Scholarship which aims to support faculty development in line with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, is also offered by the UK. UK Minister for the Indo-Pacific at the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO), Catherine West in her address said that this was a special moment for the country as it celebrated its 50 years of independence.  “We are about to embark on a journey to a changing future, and soon you will join a global community of scholars from over 100 countries, meeting experts, peers and challenges “What better way to honour the milestones than by investing in the next generation of our wonderful students. Today is not just a farewell, but the celebration of beginnings.” she said West told the students that the UK is excited to see how they would grow and becoming agents of change in their country.

Title: UK minister West pays courtesy call on PM
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape on Friday met United Kingdom’s Minister for Indo-Pacific Region Catherine West in a courtesy call paid on Marape at his office at Melanesian House in Waigani. Among the matters discussed was the visit by the Duke of Edinburgh, Prince Edward to Papua New Guinea for the county’s 50th Independence anniversary where he will officiate the formal handover of the King’s colours and regimental colours to the PNG Defence Force. He will also preside over the opening of the court complex. While in Port Moresby, the Minister is signing two Memoranda of Understanding (MOU). They include a MOU on Development Cooperation and a Shiprider Agreement. Marape thanked West for her visit to PNG while highlighting long-standing relations between PNG and the UK. “PNG always values its relations with the United Kingdom, and we thank the UK government for elevating this relationship through these latest MOUs, as well as the recently-signed Status of Force Agreement,” Marape said. “Our ties keep on getting stronger as seen in the participation of the UK Defence personnel in the Military Week, the programme that is part of our 50th Independence anniversary celebrations. This also signifies a stronger working relationship between our two defence forces which paves the way for future co-operation in the security space.” Marape also noted West’s participation at an event in Port Moresby associated with UK-funded programmes in areas of climate change, nature, clean energy and forests. “PNG is similarly focused on climate change, climate action and mitigation, as we host the third largest tropical rainforest in the world and up to seven per cent of the world’s biodiversity.”

Title: Buimo inmates celebrate independence
Content: BUIMO Prison inmates held a five-day programme to commemorate the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. Buimo Correctional Services officer Sgt Arnold Jiwai said the five-day event was organised by prisoners and overseen by warders and the prison administration. “This event was unlike previous years where we only hosted sporting events for pre-independence programme just for less than three days,” he said. He said for this year, the Aug 8-29 pre-independence programme started with a week-long sporting event at the prison. “This year’s pre-independence programme is the biggest we had with the prisoners compared to last year’s celebrations. “This is the fourth day and so far the turnout of the programmes have been very positive as we can see changes here,” he said. He said that everything was organised by the prisoners themselves including security, the setup and the events included in the programme. Peter Wagu, Buimo Prison inmate and organising committee for the pre-independence programme, said that the pre-independence event was organised under the welfare office through its rehabilitation programme. “This five days’ programme consists of both physical and spiritual activities such as the gospel concert and the arts and crafts showcase.” He said that the arts and crafts displayed by the prisoners from the female block and male blocks will be judged, and winners will receive prizes and a trophy. “This event is part of our rehabilitation programme to show that we have changed and showcased what we can do as this is not just a prison but a place for learning as well,” he said. He acknowledged Maison Mai and others who had been part of the five days’ event as judges and provided prizes to be won. The celebration ended on Sept 5, but another independence event will be held on Sept 15.

Title: Chuave submits DSIP implementation report
Content: CHIMBU’s Chuave has always been spot on with the compilation of it District Services Improvement Programme (DSIP) implementation report, according to the Implementation and Rural Development Department. James Datt, assistant secretary to Highlands One zone, hailed the district administration for always furnishing the report on time, upon receiving this year’s first and second quarter reports in Port Moresby recently. Datt acknowledged the efforts put in by the Chuave district administrator Francis Aiwa with his finance manager Michael Agua, for being compliant as required by law. He also assured the Chuave administration team that the Bilum Platform, digital reporting, will soon be rolled out to the Highlands region to replace manual reporting which was cumbersome, costly, and time consuming. District administrator Aiwa thanked Datt for the assurance to roll out the Bilum Platform in the Highlands. He said the Bilum Platform would save cost, time, and allow for efficiency. Aiwa said furnishing the report on a timely basis was mandatory, and Chuave district as a constitutional office, had always been prompt under the leadership of MP, James Nomane. However, Aiwa raised that not all of DSIP and District Support Grants for the first and second quarter, had been received. “And, now we are progressing into the third quarter. Without the required level of funding received by the district, development intervention programmes have been stalled as well administrative functions have been affected,” he said. He said Chuave, like districts in Chimbu, was difficult, given its remoteness and rugged terrain.

Title: New Zealand army provides support
Content: It has been a busy period for the Kiwi contingent in Papua New Guinea, says New Zealand Defence Force (NZDF) Chief of Army Major General Rose King. A Royal New Zealand Air Force (RNZAF) C-130J Super Hercules, a Boeing B757, two NH90 helicopters and more than 40 NZDF and Air Force personnel had deployed alongside 10 militaries from the Pacific and around the world to participate in a number of ceremonial and public events. The NZDF band was among those that performed in the military tattoo held over the weekend alongside other international military bands. The NZ army also participated in anniversary events. The Hercules and NH90 helicopters had been involved in a multi-national air logistics support operation, transporting stores and equipment across the country and to outlying islands. “We are pleased to be here, not only to celebrate Papua New Guinea’s independence with our Pacific neighbours, but also work with them in a significant air logistics support operation that has moved cargo to hard-to-reach areas,” King said. “We are proud to stand alongside our partners, reinforcing our partnerships, helping out where we can and celebrating this important milestone.” The Hercules also delivered a range of medical, building and humanitarian supplies around PNG, in support of the country’s government and a range of non-governmental organisations. The NH90s delivered 2000kg of mosquito nets to remote villages, where fixed wing aircraft were unable to land. They also transported an 800kg mini excavator to rural farmland by an underslung load. The No.3 Squadron aircrew also notched up a milestone in the helicopters, travelling for the first time from one country to another, flying more than 450 nautical miles from Australia to Port Moresby. The celebrations also included an air show with RNZAF aircraft performing fly-pasts and a winching display by an NH90 at Ela Beach on Saturday, and a static air display featuring the NH90s yesterday. The NZDF contingent also included two Royal New Zealand Navy catering support staff, a chef and a steward, working on board Australia’sHMAS Choules. The NZDF’s Papua New Guinea Defence adviser Lt-Col Haden Dempsey said it was impressive to see the NZDF and other militaries taking part in the celebrations and working together by flying equipment and aid to remote areas of the country. “The Pacific is our neighbourhood,” he said. “We aim to make a valued contribution to the region and Pacific communities.”

Title: 45 Kiwi soldiers join PNGDF celebrations
Content: ABOUT 45 New Zealand Defence Force (NZDF) soldiers arrived in Port Moresby to help support the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) Week celebrations last week, in the lead-up to the country’s 50th anniversary. NZDF chief Major General Rose King said the team also took part in the military tattoo with other armies at the Sir Hubert Murray Stadium. Other partners in the tattoo were the United States, Tonga, Fiji, Vanuatu, Japan, India and the United Kingdom. “We are privileged to be here and help and be part of Papua New Guinea Defence Force Week and 50th (anniversary) celebrations,” King said. “The 45 persons includes the New Zealand army band that has members from the air force and the Navy. “They will be participating in the military tattoo.” King said they had a C130J Super Hercules aircraft and two NH90 helicopters that were to provide air force support in regards to supplies to a number of parts across PNG, whether it’s medical, educational, or building supplies. The military tattoo consisted of the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment pipes and drums that was raised in 1952. To open the tattoo, Australian Defence Force parachute school personnel and the bands led the event. PNGDF deputy chief Brig-Gen Lari Opa said the New Zealand government, through the NZDF, had over the years been responsive to PNG’s request for help in many of its special occasions and this particular event was no different. “We’re grateful for their helicopters that have done a lot of air movement during the week,” he said.

Title: Military tattoo ends with fireworks
Content: THE two- day military tattoo event ended with fireworks last night at the Sir Hubert Murray Stadium in Port Moresby. The tattoo was part of the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) Week celebrations that featured partners from nine different countries. PNGDF’s chief warrant officer Donald Yalom said military tattoos came together to perform only for special occasions like this. “For PNG, we are about to or have started celebrating the 50th jubilee anniversary and that’s why we have the band performing,” he said. “Most of them are brass bands and pipes and drums including our own pipes and drums of PNGDF.” Australian army band music director Major Ben Bonney whose role was to bring together all the bands for rehearsals, said the show included two guards, one from the PNGDF and one from Australia. “The procession into the arena included four cultural groups from PNG and it’s really been an adventure in the last few days, bringing everyone together to do rehearsals and putting on a show for everyone,” he said. Bonney said preparations were always challenging when you have to bring together nearly 500 performers, especially from different cultures where there were always difficulties with language, understanding each other and the heat. “But all in all, we got the show done and we’re all proud, he said.” It’s a great honour and opportunity to lead and international group like this. “The Australian band has 20 members but the band sizes for other countries varies.” The smallest band is from India with 13 members and the largest was the PNGDF with 35 band members.” The bands that took part were the Royal Pacific Islands Regiments pipes and drums, Third battalion Royal Australian Regiment pipes and drums, First Battalion Scots Guard pipes and drums, Tonga, United States 25th infantry division, Indian Navy Band, Vanuatu Mobile Force Band, Australian Defence Force federation guard precision drill team, First battalion band from the Royal Australian Regiments, New Zealand army band, Fiji military forces band and Japan ground self-defence force central band.

Title: Delegates arrive in Honiara for Pacific Islands Forum
Content: DELEGATES from the Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) 18-member countries are slowing arriving into Honiara, Solomon Islands for the 54th PIF Leaders Meeting (PIFLM). The meeting starts on Monday and will end on Friday with discussions and decisions to be passed on issues surrounding climate change, the Kava declaration, the Pacific Resilience Facility and the Ocean of Peace treaty. Prime Minister James Marape is expected to arrive on Monday to visit the Marine School in Honiara and departs on Tuesday. Marape said the forum was an important platform to raise concerns on the effects of climate change affecting the county and the region. He said there was an immediate need for climate action in the Pacific and Papua New Guinea has to take the lead. Leaders from the Small Island States (SIS) – Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Federated States of Marshall Islands, Nauru, Palau, Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu and Vanuatu – met on Monday morning to discuss issues that would be raised during the meeting-proper on Wednesday when all leaders meet. Kiribati President and incoming SIS chairman Taneti Maamau said the group has been recognised by forum leaders for special attention as the most vulnerable members of the Pacific family, due to the unique characteristics of small size, isolation, limited transportation link and resources constraints. “SIS leaders acknowledged the economic, social and environmental challenges SIS face including the intensifying impact of climate change, food security due to limited agricultural potention and very small populations, connectivity challenges resulting from expensive and irregular transport links and diseconomies of scale,” Maamau said. PIF Secretariat secretary-general Baron Divavesi Waqa said the SIS group had a special place in the Forum family. “It is a calling for the expression of our solidarity as the smallest and vulnerable members” Waqa said. “It is also a reminder that our regional architecture must serve all people especially those of the least capacity.” He added that one of the agenda that would be raised in the SIS meeting was the expression of interest by Tonga government to join SIS as a member. “Relatively, there will be a review of the membership of SIS member countries to strengthen self-reliance and sovereignty in the heart of SIS,” he said

Title: Journos in the Solomon Islands to cover forum
Content: MORE than 30 Pacific islands journalists attended a three-day workshop in Honiara, Solomon Islands in preparation for the 54th Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) Leaders Forum coverage this week. Ten of the journalists were selected by the Pacific Islands News Association (Pina) in partnership with the PIF Secretariat to attend the training with Solomon Island journalists. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele said they were proud to host Pacific Islands leaders with shared visions for the future. “Your commitments in supporting the media across the Pacific strengthens our regionalism and ensures that the voices of our people may be heard,” he said. Manele said the 2025 Forum theme was a reminder of our heritage and a call to our collective responsibility. “In this journey, the media plays a vital role,” he said. “You are not here as observers. You are here as participants and partners in shaping the future of our region.” Manele said the forum would debate strategies and frameworks. “But our people will ask: What does this mean for me, my family or my community? “It is through your (media) work that these answers will be found. You will tell the stories and make the regional decisions meaningful for everyday Pacific Islanders. “I know your work is not easy as many of you operate with limited resources in small newsrooms often with little support.” Meanwhile, the Forum Secretary-general Baron Divavesi Waqa said media coverage in a truthful, fair, balance and accurate way would shape how the leader’s decisions were understood, debated and remembered by the Pacific people.

Title: Afghan quake survivors refuse to return to villages
