Content: MASUD: Haunted by fears of aftershocks bringing rocks crashing down from the mountains, the survivors of Afghan earthquakes are vowing not to return to destroyed villages but camp in fields and on riverbanks instead, even without tents to keep off the rain. “We have no shelter, not even a tent,” said 67-year-old farmer Adam Khan, leaning on a stick outside his ruined home in the village of Masud in Afghanistan’s eastern province of Kunar, devastated last week by earthquakes and subsequent aftershocks. “It rained last night, we had no place to take cover,” he added. “Our biggest fear is the big rocks that could come down at any moment.” Two earthquakes on Sept 1 killed more than 2,200 people and injured over 3,600 across the region, flattening thousands of homes, while aftershocks brought fresh landslides, leaving families trapped between unstable mountains and swollen rivers. Aid groups sped in food and supplies by helicopter, but survivors say help is patchy and slow. Afghanistan’s poverty and inadequate infrastructure maroon many villages hours from the nearest road, while most homes, build of mud and stone, crumbled instantly in the tremors. Families cluster in makeshift camps dotting the area. In the village of Shaheedan, farmer Shams-ur-Rahman, 40, said he lost six relatives and fled with his family of nine. Now they sit in the open beside a road, flanked by their few possessions. “The tents they gave us cannot even accommodate our children,” he said. “On the way down from the mountain, I had no shoes for my son, so I shared mine with him in turns as we walked down.” For some, the displacement looks set to be permanent. In the harsh glare of the sun Gul Ahmad, 51, stood beside his relatives, the women of his family crouched in the shade of a wall as their pop-up tents flapped in the dust nearby. “Even if there is no earthquake, a simple rainfall could bring rocks crashing down on us,” he said. “We will not go back. The government must provide us a place.” Without sufficient shelter, sanitation and food, the trauma will spread disease and poverty in one of the world’s poorest and most quake-prone nations, international aid agencies say. Some of the worst affected are children. Twelve-year-old Sadiq was pulled out alive after being trapped for 11 hours under rubble, in which his grandmother and a cousin were killed beside him. “I thought I would die,” he said, sitting quietly on a rope bed as cousins and uncles milled around the family’s shelter. “It felt like doomsday.” Source: Reuters

Title: China-Australia jockeying heightens Pacific forum mess
Content: Canberra: A Sino-Australian tit-for-tat in Honiara as the two nations try to diplomatically out-muscle one another in the lead-up to this year’s Pacific Islands Forum has been described as almost comical. Australia is providing 61 security vehicles, road upgrades, cybersecurity support and AU$3 million (about K8m) in budgetary aid for the annual gathering of regional leaders in the Solomon Islands capital. China, by comparison, has gifted 27 cars for logistics and basic policing equipment for this week’s summit but the expectation is that Beijing is manoeuvring to play up its part in the proceedings. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele insists the nation’s own law and order officers will have sole responsibility for everyone’s wellbeing. But echoing in his ears is Australia’s oft-repeated claim that there is no role for China in Pacific security. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese signed a deal with Manele in Canberra in December in which he pledged to fund local policing in the struggling archipelagic nation in exchange for a reduced Chinese security presence there. The Department of Foreign Affairs says consultations are continuing over the expansion of the Solomons’ civilian force but it isn’t willing to talk specifics about the implementation of the agreement. According to a spokesperson, “Australia is committed to supporting Solomon Islands’ evolving security priorities.” Chinese posturing in the region is meanwhile alive and well. It’s naval vessels circumnavigated Australia in February, staging a live-fire exercise in the Tasman Sea. Beijing has also registered 26 new Pacific coastguard vessels and in 2024 conducted its first intercontinental ballistic missile test in the Pacific since 1980. Lowy Institute Pacific Islands program director Mihai Sora says the Solomons policing issue is “a domestic political football that has been kicked around”. There has been “intense and almost comical support” from both Australia and China, he says. “Manele would be under quite a bit of pressure from his Chinese government stakeholders to resist or diminish Australian support for policing.” The former diplomat says he will be looking in Honiara next week for on-the-ground progress on a joint regional policing initiative agreed to at last year’s forum hosted by Tonga. This could include a new development site or upgrades, he says. “And more information from Pacific Islands nations about how it will be deployed or implemented. “Every country was supposed to report back for this meeting. I don’t know if its for a lack of progress or if it’s been overshadowed by more dramatic events.” A diplomatic stoush separate to Australia and China’s jockeying threatened to scuttle the 2025 forum before it got under way, with Beijing pressuring the Solomons to exclude Taiwan, which is a PIF development partner. Source: AAP

Title: Climate finance crunch time at Pacific leader talks
Content: Canberra: Pacific leaders are set for a more intimate gathering than usual at key annual talks, but excluding some heavyweight nations may prove counterproductive to goals of luring crucial funding for the region. As a major threat to the security and prosperity of small island states, climate change typically dominates the yearly Pacific Islands Forum and the 2025 affair hosted by Solomon Islands this week should be no different. Island nations have long been pushing wealthy, high-emitting countries to help them adapt to the climate problem they did little to create, but accessing global pools of green finance has proven logistically challenging. Pacific leaders have since set up a regional fund they say will be better suited to the smaller, community-scale adaptation projects favoured by the region. Australia, one of the 18-member bloc, has already committed AU$100 million (about K273mil) to the fledgling fund. Wesley Morgan, research associate at the Institute for Climate Risk and Response at UNSW, said the regional heavyweight would be expected to chip in more. “There’ll be an expectation that Australia contributes more and works to leverage that regional fund to attract support from other nations as well,” Morgan, also a Climate Council Fellow, told AAP. But the Solomon Islands’ decision to keep out dialogue partners, including countries such as China, United States, France and Japan, might limit such opportunities. Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele made the call following pressure from Beijing to exclude Taiwan, which is a development partner for the forum. Lowy Institute Pacific Islands program director Mihai Sora said the annual talks had recently become “congested with geopolitical intrigue”, leaving important regional issues, such as health crises, struggling for airtime. On the other hand, attracting foreign climate finance – a priority of many member states – could be challenging with a more closed-off conference. Progress towards a meaningful collective security agreement could also be more difficult in such a setting, the former diplomat said. Sora said the public focus of the 54th Pacific Islands Forum Leaders’ Meeting would be on celebrating unity and shared priorities but privately, real differences were starting to emerge on foreign policy. “Some Pacific leaders are leaning into western partners, others are stridently non-aligned, and others are leaning into China and accommodating China’s effective intrusion into the Pacific Islands Forum, an institution of which it’s not even a member,” he said. Sora did not expect this tension to present itself in the leaders statement issued at the end of the five-day event, a document that details key decisions and outcomes from the summit. Morgan said COP31 discussions would also be bubbling away in the background, with Australia yet to secure the rights to co-host the global climate talks with the Pacific in 2026 and muscle out a rival bid from Turkey. “The bid has not been secured, but Pacific countries want to see this happen,” he said. Source: AAP

Title: ‘PNGDF won’t comment’: Bougainville Government furious over ‘unauthorised’ Royal New Zealand Air Force flight to Buka as PNGDF remains silent
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Defence Force have refused to comment on a protocol blunder that has left the Autonomous Bougainville Government fuming over the recent ‘unauthorised entry’ of a New Zealand military aircraft into Bougainville airspace. On Thursday, a Royal New Zealand Air Force Hercules C-130J delivered humanitarian supplies to Bougainville under the ‘Operation Planti Balus’, which stemmed out of the PNG Military Week celebrations. The Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) Attorney General Ezekiel Masatt condemned the unauthorised entry saying the “New Zealand and PNG governments and their military apparatus should know better”. A senior PNGDF spokesperson gave a brief response when contacted for the military’s comment. “PNGDF won’t comment. Only PM (prime minister) and FA (Foreign Affairs),” he said. Masatt said this blunder was a serious breach of the Bougainville Peace Agreement (BPA). Under the BPA, the National Government will be able to send PNGDF personnel to Bougainville for purposes of search and rescue and assistance in natural disasters and other humanitarian emergencies in response to requests from the ABG, or by giving prior notice to agreed points of contact in Bougainville. “There was no prior consultation and nor authorisation given,” Masatt said. “At a sensitive time when Bougainville is going through elections, and when the high profile meeting with the UN Secretary General (Antonio Guterres) has just concluded, the unauthorised landing has caused suspicion and apprehension. “Whether the operation is for humanitarian purposes or not is irrelevant.” The Bougainville general election was conducted on Friday. The NZDF earlier said it had sent the Hercules C-130J, a Boeing B757, two NH90 helicopters and more than 40 personnel to participate in Papua New Guinea’s celebrations of its 50th anniversary. The New Zealand Defence Force have been contacted for comment. Humanitarian support to Bougainville The super hercules transported wheelchairs, library books, mathematics text books, dictionaries, first-aid kits and clothing to Buka, organised by non-government organisation, WeCare. The items would be delivered to Murua Primary School in Bana, South Bougainville, Paruparu Primary School in Pangua, Central Bougainville, Saposa Primary School in North Bougainville and Paruparu Health Centre. WeCare programme manager Cecilia Maiasa thanked PNGDF and the NZDF for airlifting the cargo to Buka under the ‘Operation Planti Balus’. “Thank you to PNG Defence Force who have asked us through the ‘Operation Planti Balus’ to commemorate PNG’s golden jubilee,” Maiasa said. The Papua New Guinea Defence Force’s air, land and sea regiments – with support from Australia, New Zealand and France defence forces – are taking part in the military week, celebrating the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. Maiasa said WeCare also airlifted similar cargo to Wewak and Mt Hagen on Wednesday as part of the operation. PNGDF’s Major Darius Kaule, who is the lead air planner for PNGDF Joint Task Force 50, said ‘Operation Planti Balus’ stemmed from the PNGDF Week.

Title: Soldier stabbed to death in Lae. Police probe death as solder’s comrades ordered back to Igam barracks
Content: THE Papua New Guinea Defence Force are working closely with police in Lae to apprehend a suspect involved in the death of a soldier on Saturday morning in Lae. Igam’s Military Police commander Colonel Michael Percy confirmed the death of the soldier who was stabbed in the earlier hours on Saturday while on his way back to Igam barracks. Marai assured the public that the security situation in Igam was under control. He said the Military Police was working with police to manage the situation, and all soldiers were ordered back into the barracks to avoid further escalation of the situation. “The situation is under control,” said Marai. “Lae police are working closely with military police, and all soldiers have been withdrawn back to the barracks.” The unrest has disrupted community activities in Lae, with the Morobe Rugby Union announcing the cancellation of its grand final match on Saturday, scheduled to be held at Igam Barracks oval. The union said the safety of players, officials, and fans was a priority and urged the public to stay away from the Igam area until further notice.

Title: Draw inspiration from founding father’s, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has urged Papua New Guineans to draw inspiration from the nation’s founding fathers as the country prepares to celebrate its 50th Independence anniversary. During the opening of the 50th Anniversary Exhibition in Port Moresby on Wednesday, Marape reminded public servants that the generation which delivered independence between 1972 and 1975 achieved monumental tasks in just three years, without the advantage of modern education or technology. “That generation moved mountains against all odds,” Marape said. “They worked quickly, they worked with dedication. And in just three years, they gave us self-government, a constitution, and independence. Their example must inspire us today.” Marape said the exhibition was a timely reminder that Papua New Guinea’s story did not begin in 1975 but stretched back thousands of years. He pointed to the Kuk Early Agricultural Site in Western Highlands, where evidence of organised agriculture dated back 7,000 to 10,000 years, and the Ambum Stone from Enga, carbon-dated to more than 4,000 years old. He also highlighted Pacific-wide cultural connections through Lapita pottery, the Hiri trade, and traditional shell money, all evidence that Papua New Guineans were part of an advanced civilisation long before modern statehood. “We are an ancient people, with history, culture, and knowledge systems that predate many parts of the world,” he said. “This exhibition must remind us of that heritage, and also inspire us to work hard for the future.”

Title: Over 200,000 to vote in Bougainville General Election one-day polling
Content: MORE than 200,000 Bougainvilleans will go to the polls today for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) general election to be held in the region and the five provinces. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai confirmed that polling would be done in one day for all eligible voters in Bougainville, plus those residing in the National Capital District, Morobe, East New Britain, Eastern Highlands, and Madang. Counting of votes is scheduled for Sept 9. Writs will be returned by Sept 22. There are 408 candidates contesting, with seven vying for the presidency. Voters will cast four ballot papers to elect members for the following seats: “Polling with go ahead (today) and every eligible voter will cast four ballots,” Tsianai said. “I ask everyone to respect the process and allow polling to take place in a peaceful and joyous atmosphere. “I thank the people for their patience and for standing with us as we safeguard Bougainville’s democracy.” He said that they faced inadequate funding “that compressed our timeline, and the late arrival of the final shipment of ballot papers”. “But we acted responsibly to address these issues so that we can deliver a credible election. “Yes, there has been a delay, but this reschedule protects the integrity of our democracy. “I would rather face frustration today than deny voters their voice tomorrow.” He commended voters who used the SMS roll look-up service and the public display period to check and correct their enrolment details on the electoral roll.

Title: Minister Duma refutes PNG Power bankrupt report
Content: STATE Enterprise Minister William Duma says reforms are being implemented to increase power generation so that more people have access to electricity. Duma, while refuting media reports of a bankrupt PNG Power, said there was no easy or quick process. “The figures in the (media) story are implausible, and PNG Power would have ceased to operate a long time ago if the claims were true,” he said. “No person or business wants to have blackouts, and we are reducing the occurrence. “The facts are that we are turning PNG Power around, generating more revenue, reducing costs and upgrading infrastructure. “In Port Moresby alone, revenue has increased by 16 per cent – thanks to revenue protection measures, feeder metering and investments in distribution network upgrades.” He said that the growing population, particularly in urban centres, placed additional pressure on the grid. But capacity was improving compared to a few years ago.

Title: New Zealand Defence Force delivers mosquito nets to Goilala
Content: FIVE remote health centres in Woitape and Goilala districts in Central received 174 bales of mosquito nets and medicine supplies – thanks to PNG Defence Force Planti Balus initiative that helped the Rotarians Against Malaria (RAM). RAM’s chief operating manager Lindsay Nesan said the bales contained 50 nets each. “As part of its national campaign, RAM distributes nearly four million long-lasting insecticidal nets per grant cycle, rapid diagnostic test kits, and provides artemisinin based combination therapies and other essential medicines,” he said. He said that with funding support from the Global Fund, RAM was implementing malaria prevention and elimination initiatives in 22 provinces. Nesan added that RAM also trained community malaria volunteers to test and treat patients in remote areas. In November last year, RAM supported by the PNGDF and the Australian Defence Force, delivered 68,000 mosquito nets and medicine to families in remote parts of Middle Ramu and Usino Bundi districts in Madang.  “We have requested to do the same this year to Woitape and Goilala districts in Central by the RNZAF NH90 helicopter,” Nesan said. PNGDF’s Joint Task Force lead air planner Major Darius Kaule added that the operation ran from Tuesday to yesterday supported by the Australian, New Zealand and French Air Force aircraft. “Even though we have an overwhelming requests coming in, a few were chosen based on the criteria that we had out in our notices,” he toldThe National.

Title: PNGDF chief urges pride, dedication from troops
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Defence Force Chief Rear Admiral Philip Polewara is urging all serving men and women to do their duty with pride and dedication. “Nobody else will come and do this job of service which you decided to take on for your country and people,” he told them. “Your duty is of sacrifice of service to people. Other people may see the glamour of the uniform, but it is a job we swore an oath to and we will die in line of duty serving the country. “We have come 50 years and so let’s journey together in unity and cooperation for the next 50 years to ensure the PNGDF serves it mandated duty to protect the country, its borders by land, air and sea and its people. “The PNGDF has stood as both shield and servant of the people, from defending our borders to delivering aid, from peacekeeping abroad to supporting communities at home. Our soldiers, sailors and airmen have carried the weight of duty with courage and pride,” he said. Polewara made reference to the troops of the first Pacific Islands Regiment Exercise walk “Antap lo ol” from Wewak in East Sepik to Morobe before reaching Central and Port Moresby last week. “This is a testament of strength and courage and knowing the purpose of why we are here to serve the country. History has helped shape us into a democratic nation. “I must commend all soldiers, both men and women, who are taking part in the PNGDF week and those who are are stationed back at home, we all work as a team. “The soldiers who walked to Port Moresby and all others here are working to ensure this week is a success, this is enforcing national morale. “This is something we must create among our people and despite PNG having all the riches, but when we don’t have the morale then we are wasting our time and that is what holds the military together,” he said. Polewara reminded all servicemen and women that it was important to practice ethical behaviour and be disciplined at all times, whether on or off duty.

Title: Special delivery for Bougainville schools and health centre
Content: THREE remote schools and a health centre in Bougainville will receive books, medical supplies and clothing as independence anniversary presents, thanks to the PNG Military Week. The Papua New Guinea Defence Force’s air, land and sea regiments – with support from Australia, New Zealand and France defence forces – are taking part in the military week, celebrating the country’s 50th Independence anniversary. A New Zealand Defence Force C-130J Super Hercules transported wheelchairs, library books, mathematics text books, dictionaries, first-aid kits and clothing to Buka yesterday. Organised by non-government organisation, WeCare, the items would be delivered to Murua Primary School in Bana, South Bougainville, Paruparu Primary School in Pangua, Central Bougainville, Saposa Primary School in North Bougainville and Paruparu Health Centre. WeCare programme manager Cecilia Maiasa thanked PNGDF and the NZDF for airlifting the cargo to Buka under the Operation Planti Balus. “Thank you to PNG Defence Force who have asked us through theOperation Planti Balusto commemorate PNG’s golden jubilee,” Maiasa said. “I am very happy as I am about to take about one tonne of my cargo to Buka to reach the marginalised women and children, especially those with no road access.” Maiasa said WeCare also airlifted similar cargo to Wewak and Mt Hagen on Wednesday as part of the operation. PNGDF’s Major Darius Kaule, who is the lead air planner for PNGDF Joint Task Force 50, saidOperation Planti Balusstemmed from the PNGDF Week. “PNGDF Week is a celebration of the air, land and sea elements,” Kaule said. “During theOperation Planti Balus, we have asked the NGOs and government departments to put in their request (for assistance to airlift cargo). “We vetted all these requests to airlift NGO cargo, medical supplies and books to other parts of the country, especially to the rural areas. “We’ve been doing that since Sept 2. “So far, we’ve had the Australians support, New Zealand’s support as well as the French. “We have flown to Wewak (East Sepik), Vanimo (West Sepik) and Momote (Manus) on the Australian and New Zealand aircraft.”

Title: PNG, Australia defence forces show unity, strength
Content: DEFENCE partnership has gone from strength to strength among foreign navies since independence, says Papua New Guinea Defence Force Chief Rear Admiral Philip Polewara. “We as members of the PNGDF are honoured to be able to celebrate our nation’s 50th anniversary of independence with other militaries, navies and defence forces from around the world. “These are comrades from Australia, New Zealand, the United States, United Kingdom, France, Japan, India, Tonga, Fiji and Vanuatu. “This is a show of strength, unity and international cooperation and a means of strengthening diplomatic ties with the navies. “Most of them have been with us and have supported us in our journey to being an independent state of PNG, their coming here was at no cost as they are here to support and further maintain our friendship and comradeship in the navy,” Polewara said. Yesterday morning, eight naval ships sailed out of Fairfax Harbour and southwards of the Apec Haus for a fleet review. All five visiting and three PNG Navy vessels passed by in general salute to Governor-General Sir Bob Dadae. As the ships sailed back into the harbour, a PNG flag suspended from a hired helicopter flew towards and past the Apec Haus while the national anthem was sung. This is part of the PNGDF week, celebrating what the navy represents to the nations which they serve. This event is a part of other PNGDF events as a lead-up to the county’s 50th anniversary. The fleet review is both a military and diplomatic tradition, showcasing a nations naval power, honouring members’ service and often significant national or historical events. This are nations from the Commonwealth. The vessels that participated areHMPNGS Ted Diro (PNG),HMPNGS Rochus Lokinap(PNG),HMPNGS Gilbert Toropo(PNG),HMPNGS Cape Gloucester(PNG),HMAS Choules(Australia),HMAS Childers (Australia),FNS Aguste Benebig(France),VOEA Ngahau Koula(Tonga) andINS Kadmatt India. “To demonstrate partnership by navies, I can confidently comment in regard to the Australian army, navy and military. We have several of our serving men and women assigned to the Australian Navy and vice-versa and since the 1980s,” Polewara said. “Despite our ships being small, as a democratic nation we choose not to be spectators as we share the same doctrine that comes under the British Royal Navy,” he said. He said this event coincided with the air show, two-day military tattoo as well as smaller events and formal and informal functions. Chief of the Australian Navy ship Mark Hammond said: “It is an absolute honour to be here standing alongside PNG to witness its 50th anniversary independence of PNG, in particular to stand alongside our shipmates of PNG Maritime. “It was a wonderful site and it’s great to see some other Pacific nations here celebrating alongside our shipmates from PNG. We are partner nations and neighbours. He said Australia, PNG and other nations can drive economic success from the sea, while maintaining national security.

Title: Marape supports stronger climate action
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape on Wednesday night gave his full assurance to United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres that Papua New Guinea supported his call for stronger climate action to keep the global temperature rise to below 1.5 degree Celsius. In a dinner hosted in Port Moresby by the Prime Minister in honour of the Guterres, Marape reminded the audience of the crucial role PNG plays as the custodian of the world’s third largest tropical rainforest (shared with Indonesia), and the world’s largest ocean (shared with other Pacific Island countries) – both of which contribute largely to keeping the global warming equilibrium. Wednesday night dinner also coincided with the launch of PNG’s National Prevention Strategy (2025-30). He said Guterres’ advocacy on climate action, as high-lighted in his address given earlier that day to Parliament, was fully supported by PNG. “You have come home to a forest nation, you have come home to a marine nation,” Marape said. “Together with the other Pacific Island nations, we host the biggest ocean space on the planet. “We may be small island states in land size and population, but our contribution to global upkeep is second to none. Together with the Amazon and the Congo basins, our forest resources are second to none. “Your address today in Parliament on Climate Resilience and Climate Justice is the correct advocacy. We stand behind you. “We stand in total solidarity with you as your advocate to the Global North and G20 nations, and I speak in front of many G20 ambassadors here tonight. Keep the earth’s temperature below 1.5-degree Celsius.” Marape added that PNG was following closely the United Nations Climate Change conferences (Conference of the Parties) and is paying special attention to COP30 in Brazil this year. Since taking office in 2019, Marape has become a voice on the global scene on Climate Action and Climate Justice, demanding that developed countries do much more to live up to the Paris Agreement of 2015 where 195 countries made the treaty to keep the global temperature below 1.5 degree Celsius. Marape has taken the fight further by demanding that developed countries compensate small island states, especially those in the Pacific who have minimal carbon footprints, for damages suffered as a result of climate change. Marape insisted that PNG should be rightfully compensated for hosting tropical forests which have high economic value for development. He backed that up by not attending the last COP meeting in Baku, Azerbaijan. Earlier this year, Marape also made an appeal to United States President Donald Trump to reconsider his decision when the president withdrew the US from the Paris Agreement and global climate talks.

Title: Country fell short of reaching development goals, says PM
Content: THE country has fallen short of its development goals but with the support of the United Nations, the people would prosper, says Prime Minister James Marape. He made this known in Parliament on Wednesday after UN secretary-general António Guterres presented his speech. “This year, I must admit that we have not fully met all our aspirations, especially for human development. “But one thing is certain, we know the distance that we have travelled and where we must go in as far as finding education, health, employment, safety and dignity for our women and girls,” Marape said. “We value the UN’s global leadership and advocacy which resonates with our national aspirations. “The Government will support and continue to strengthen institutions of accountability, policing, justice and oversight so the rights of every citizen are protected.” Marape said PNG’s partnership with the UN had been tested and strengthened in the moments of national importance. “For years, the UN systems have supported the national Government and the Autonomous Bougainville Government on referendum and post-referendum dialogue,” Marape said. “The UN has also been our partner in public health when polio re-emerged in 2018 and the Government, World Health Organisation, Unicef and other partners mobilised nationwide immunisation. “Last year and this year, the UN also supported us in the disaster response and protection of displaced communities in the Maip-Mulitaka landslide in Enga, helping to coordinate assistance, advocating safe and dignified relocations.”

Title: Judge Ellis returns to serve in Enga
Content: THE National Court and Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea now have a total of 46 judges, after a judge was sworn in at Government House in Port Moresby yesterday. Justice Graham Ellis, an Australian, will be serving a term of three years, following his re-appointment by Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika and Minister for Justice and Attorney-General Pila Niningi. Sir Gibbs said that Justice Ellis would serve in Enga for the second time. “Justice Ellis will be serving in Enga. The last time he was here, he served the people of Enga and from that reputation that he left behind, the Engans were coming for him again,” Sir Gibbs said. “They wanted him back as he was a good operator in dealing with bulldozing of cases of criminal and civil matters when he served during his previous term.” Sir Gibbs said that Justice Ellis graciously agreed to come back to serve our people and the people of Enga although he had earlier served seven years in the country. Justice Ellis said that he was looking forward to this journey. “I am looking forward to being able to return to Enga. I have received a total of 12 requests to come and serve in Papua New Guinea over the last 40 years so I am pleased to say yes to this one,” he said. Justice Ellis is not new to the PNG Judiciary. He has served as a judge in Rabaul between 1990 and 1992, and in Enga between 2009 and 2011. He said he was glad to be chosen by Sir Gibbs of all the judges to be based in Wabag. He will fly to Lae today and would travel by road to Goroka, Kundiawa, Mt Hagen, then to Wabag and is expected to start on Monday.

Title: Peace ceremony: Bulolo ethnic groups reconcile
Content: A PEACE ceremony was held in Bulolo, Morobe, on Monday between ethnic groups to reconcile ahead of the country’s Independence anniversary celebrations. This brought together ethnic groups to end years of violence, bad blood, and restore harmony in the township, said project coordinator Archie Yamgar. Also a peace officer, Yamgar added that the reconciliation involved communities from Garaina, Buang, Madang and Finschhafen, who have been in conflict since around 2019. He said according to reports, the clashes, which escalated over time, resulted in killings, property damage, and widespread fear among residents and businesses in Bulolo. Bulolo Urban mayor Jason Ata confirmed that the Bulolo Development Authority (DDA), under the leadership of MP Sam Basil Jr, provided K40,000 to support the reconciliation. “This conflict has been ongoing for years and has taken many lives. “Monday’s ceremony is about ending that cycle and moving forward together.” Basil issued a strong call for the groups to make this the final reconciliation. “The Bulolo DDA has already supported peace ceremonies before, and this must be the last,” Basil said. “Funds should be used to improve schools, health services and business opportunities, not repeatedly spent on reconciliation. “The people must truly stop fighting and live in peace.” The event was coordinated under the Peace and Good Order Committee, supported by the Department of Justice and Attorney-General’s Community Justice programme. Yamgar said the reconciliation was needed in rebuilding stability. “Real peace must come from the heart,” said Yamgar. “This step shows our people are ready to change, and we will continue to extend reconciliation to other groups still in conflict.” The peace ceremony comes as Bulolo prepares to host one of only two government-funded Golden Jubilee shows on Sept 16-17, alongside Port Moresby. The celebrations will feature traditional dances, cultural exhibitions and displays from surrounding local level governments, with joint police operations to ensure safety. Authorities said the goal was for Bulolo to celebrate its independence jubilee free of fear, marking the beginning of a more peaceful future.

Title: Special teams to boost ‘Safe City’ operation
Content: THE National Capital District metropolitan command has tightened up on its “Safe City” operations with the inclusion of special teams from within its ranks and file. NCD metropolitan commander Supt Warrick Simatab said yesterday the teams would this week focus on enforcing liquor laws to reduce alcohol-related incidents. “Over the past two weeks, we have partnered with the National Capital District Commission to clean up the city, remove illegal structures, and manage animal control,” he said in a statement. Support teams for the operations include members of the mobile squads, dog units, water police, Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary bands, personnel from police headquarters and police reservists. “They are now on the streets with our NCD officers to make sure the city is secure,” Simatab said. “Our Safe City operations started last month and will continue right through the Jubilee celebrations, Christmas, and the New Year.” He identified key areas for coverage as: “Police have tightened their security measures and will take action as needed to address any concerns,” Simatab said. “If you see something suspicious, report it to the nearest police officer or station right away. “Respect our officers, and celebrate our jubilee in a responsible way.”

Title: Pomio installs 10 TB testing machines
Content: INSTALLATION of a 10-colour GeneXpert instrument and commissioning of four new tuberculosis (TB) basic management units (BMUs) in Pomio marked a first in East New Britain and Papua New Guinea’s latest against TB. For the first time, Pomio being the first district in the country to have a 10-colour GeneXpert machine now has access to world-class TB diagnostic capacity according to the Health Department. They will be able to rapidly diagnose TB, including drug-resistant TB and genotypic drug sensitivity testing for common first and second-line drugs used in PNG, a capacity only available in provincial hospitals. This innovation and the establishment of BMUs at four health facilities, means that people in Pomio can now access timely, reliable and life-saving TB services closer to home. Last week, the Health Department presented the GeneXpert machine to East New Britain health authority chief executive officer Dr Ako Yap and Pomio administrator John Liskia to help address what may be a dormant health crisis in the district. These developments follow a recent declaration of war against TB by Health Minister and Pomio MP Elias Kapavore, which represented not only a turning point for Pomio, but also a model for scaling up TB response in other remote districts in PNG. The presentation was made by the department’s senior regional medical officer for TB Dr Margaret Kal, to Yap and Liskia in Palmalmal. The installation of the GeneXpert machine was done by a team from the department and East New Britain laboratory team. The installation and commissioning of four BMUs in Pomio was supported by Path — a partner in the fight to end TB in collaboration with the ENB health authority. While thanking the Health Department and acknowledging ongoing support from partners to improve health outcomes in the province, Yap urged health workers to work together to address challenges in the province. “Our people must work together to maximise use of resources. We need to integrate our programmes – government, churches – to serve our people,” Yap said. He acknowledged the work of the churches which ran almost 80 per cent of the rural health services programmes and has eight facilities in Pomio. “At the moment, we do not have good TB services, demonstrating burden of TB in Pomio. “We only have eight BMUs in Gazelle, and we need to work together to ensure we transfer skills to our health workers,” Yap said. The GeneXpert machine was procured with the support of World Bank-funded Coronavirus emergency response project implemented by the Health Department. The machine uses an automated system to perform rapid testing for various diseases, including TB, human immuno-deficiency virus, early infant diagnosis, human papilloma virus, and Covid-19, providing diagnostic results within less than two hours and detects TB with higher sensitivity — unlike traditional labortory tests. The national and provincial TB teams, including partners, visited three facilities as part of their assessment to establish BMUs in the district by next year. “Based on our visits and assessments at the facilities, there is a likelihood of significantly high caseloads, high transmission of TB, and possible accumulation of TB in the community,” Kal said.

Title: Prisons need more rehab programmes, says volunteer
Content: MORE rehabilitation programme are needed in prisons to address the increasing crime rates committed by reoffenders, according to a Buimo Prison reintegration volunteer. Maison Mai said the after-prison pathways was vital, but are not present at Buimo. “We need more life skills, trade skills and financial literacy trainings especially in book keeping, management and small-to-medium enterprises to be carried out in the prison cells.” “Most of the inmates are illiterate. They do not know how to read or write but can see and do things with their hands through trainings,” Mai said. “When they are released and without proper education or skills, they most likely will return to criminal activities just to sustain themselves.” He said the Morobe government should include a small portion of their budget towards such programmes. As a former inmate, Mai sees the need for prisoners to be given such assistance to contribute meaningfully back in their respective communities such as having life skills or other necessary skills to sustain themselves.

Title: Deputy Speaker Iguan hails democratic principles
Content: PAPUA New Guinea’s commitment to the democratic principles since gaining Independence in 1975 remains strong, says Deputy Speaker Koni Iguan. “Our Constitution supports the freedom of speech, associations and political expression while also respecting customary laws,” he said. “That means civil society, media and grass-root movements are vital in keeping our democracy alive. “Institutions such as Ombudsman Commission and the national judiciary are encouraged in promoting accountability and good governance. “We acknowledge our democracy faces challenges such as political instability, corruption and lack of services reaching rural services, however, our commitment to democracy is grounded,” he said. This, he addressed dignitaries and MPs, when welcoming United Nations (UN) secretary-general Antonio Guterres into the parliament at 10am on Wednesday to address Parliament. Guterres praised PNG for being a country of tremendous diversity, languages and traditions, and still when faced with conflicts, are champions in forming consensus through dialogue. Iguan said: “It is a rare and special honour the United Nations and PNG affirm on the core values of the UN central to PNG’s national goals of democracy. “PNG is recognised as the Pacific’s most vibrant democracy since getting independence in 1975, we have been guided by a strong constitution that protects our rights, supports the rule of law, and upholds a democratic governance. “One of the strengths of our democracy is the high level of political participation across our culturally diverse population with over 800 languages and strong community traditions. Our political system is both locally inclusive and grounded,” he said. Iguan said the UN’s visit to PNG is one that the country hopes will inspire and guide the country in its work.

Title: UN’s Guterres pays tribute to PNG’s Grand Chief Sir Michael
Content: UNITED Nations General Secretary Antonio Guterres says late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare’s wisdom and determination has allowed the nation to emerge as a vibrant democracy. Guterres visited Wewak, East Sepik, yesterday to pay his respects at the final resting place of the late Sir Michael at Kreer Heights yesterday. “I am extremely honored to pay tribute to the father of this nation,” he said. “His wisdom and his determination has allowed Papua New Guinea to emerge as a vibrant democracy that now celebrates 50 years.” Prime Minister James Marape thanked Guterres for choosing to visit the country and Wewak this month. “The month of September is synonymous with this man (Sir Michael),” he said. “He died leaving a legacy. His death united the nation.” Son, Arthur Somare on behalf of the family acknowledged both men saying: “It is our honour to have you (Guterres) and Prime Minister grace us with your presence to pay respects to my old man’s grave.” Guterres and Marape left Wewak for Nuku in West Sepik then onto Mt Hagen in Western Highlands later in the afternoon. Guterres is expected to travel out of Port Moresby today.

Title: Administrator in tears over remote school students’ performance
Content: REMOTE school students moved the district administrator to tears with their beautiful performances of Chimbu’s Sinasina-Yongomugl diverse arts and cultures during their pre-independence celebrations on Tuesday. Students from Silma Primary School in Keredu village, Suai LLG, staged the celebrations with their array of performances. District administrator Obert Waure, who officiated with other dignitaries, shed tears over the expert ability of the primary school students. Students represented the cultures of Kare Tabeh, Kere Korepuge, Hani Bee and Okama Masalai played string band music from the 1960s among many other performances. Waure said he had never seen such performances in Chimbu, describing them as distinct, powerful, and unknown to many in the province. He said the performances told stories and brought out realities that would impact future generations. “As we join the rest of PNG to celebrate the 50th anniversary, we must ask ourselves, what will we pass on to our next generation in the next 50 years?” he said.

Title: ‘Champion’ of Papua New Guinea soldiers
Content: MAJOR Jack Costelloe worked closely with Papua New Guinean soldiers, police and villagers throughout World War II. That included coordinating labour for the construction of airstrips, participating in civilian recovery operations, organising long-range reconnaissance activities and leading patrols into enemy occupied territory. He spoke highly of the skills and bravery of these soldiers and had been a strong advocate to improve their pay, conditions and status. He believed that they should have received recognition similar that of the much more famous Papuan ‘Fuzzy Wuzzy Angels’. Major Costelloe highlighted that approximately 3,500 Papuan and New Guinean volunteer soldiers, many former police, served during World War II and that members of the First Papuan Infantry Battalion were involved in the first clash with the Japanese on the Kokoda Track, on July 23, 1942. He suggested that ‘Owen guns in the hands of men who were effective fighters with bows and arrows, proved to be a deadly combination for the enemy’ but that often Papua New Guinean soldiers had not been used to their full potential by Australian officers. In 1925, as a 19-year-old, Jack Costelloe took a position as a treasury clerk at Rabaul, in the then Australian Mandated Territory of New Guinea. He later studied anthropology and became a patrol officer and worked in that capacity on Bougainville (Kieta), New Ireland (Namatanai), Morobe (Wau, Morobe and Salamaua), and in the Central Highlands of New Guinea (Chimbu/Kundiawa), until 1942. During World War II, Jack Costelloe was part of the Australian New Guinea Administrative Unit (Angau) that was responsible for civilian administration, and with ‘M’ Special Unit of the Allied Intelligence Bureau. ‘M’ Special Unit activities included intelligence-gathering and guerilla operations. They included Jack operating with small groups of New Guinean soldiers and police behind enemy lines. In February 1943, along with Bena Force, Costelloe assisted 90 ethnic Chinese residents of Wewak to safety, after Japanese bombing. They had fled to the Ramu Valley and were escorted into the Highlands and evacuated to Australia from Bena Bena airstrip. In June 1943, Costelloe’s long experience in New Guinea saw him carrying out the logistically complex and culturally sensitive task of recruiting and supporting several thousand villagers from the Chimbu area to assist in the maintenance of Bena Bena airstrip and the construction of an airstrip at nearby Goroka. Liaising with United States Marines to develop a strategy to help liberate New Guinea Major Costelloe’s local knowledge of much of Japanese-occupied north-eastern New Guinea, and its people, resulted in him being selected to work with the Americans and provide input to a strategy designed to liberate the area. In August 1943, he was sent to Guadalcanal in the British Solomon Islands – via Australia and New Caledonia – to liaise with the Americans. The strategy that was developed – called ‘island hopping’ – involved isolating Japanese forces in various locations and cutting their supply lines, rather than direct confrontation. The first task was to isolate the main base at Rabaul on New Britain. That would be achieved by establishing airstrips on Bougainville Island – within fighter range of Rabaul – to provide bomber protection during attacks on Japanese positions and shipping. Major Costelloe was appointed district officer of Bougainville to liaise between local residents and the Americans during the establishment of the base. On Nov 1, 1943, Major Costelloe landed along with 14,000 troops of the US Third Marine Division, First Marine Amphibious Corps, at Empress Augusta Bay on Bougainville; to establish a base and airstrips at Torokina. One of his roles as district officer was to organise long-range intelligence-gathering operations by New Guinean scouts. They reported on Japanese military installations and the results of US Fifth Air Force bombing raids. A famous long-range scout who worked with Major Costelloe wasTultulKasman. He operated behind enemy lines to locate enemy installations, assess the results of Allied bombing, and intercept Japanese runners. At times he also flew with US pilots to guide them to targets. Costelloe recommended him for a Loyal Service Medal. Its citation acknowledged that ‘without his assistance (pilots) would have had great difficulty in identifying’many targets. Major Costelloe also led patrols into enemy territory. Over 40 days, during July and August 1944, Major Costelloe led six Australian soldiers and 40 New Guinean soldiers and police from Torokina across the rugged Emperor Range of central Bougainville to attempt to liberate Sikh prisoners being held by the Japanese on the north-east coast. The patrol had several encounters with Japanese patrols on the way. New Guinean police eventually made contact with the Sikhs. However, the Sikh officers were afraid of retribution on those not fit enough to escape and declined the offer of liberation.  They sent Costelloe a note thanking him for his efforts. In July 1945, Major Costelloe was seconded to assist in the development of the newly established Pacific Islands Regiment (later Royal Pacific Islands Regiment). On the Japanese surrender in September 1945, he returned to Angau to assist with post-surrender arrangements in the Aitape area. He was then appointed to the War Crimes Commission as a Special Magistrate, which included dealing with New Guinean collaborators. He appreciated the difficult positions that they had been placed in and was lenient. In mid-1946, he returned to his pre-war role as assistant district officer at Kundiawa in the Central Highlands of New Guinea where he was responsible for the whole of what today is the densely populated Chimbu Province. He returned to Australia in 1949 to work for the NSW Housing Commission in Sydney to help coordinate the construction of thousands of houses required for returning Australian service personnel and their families.

Title: ‘No security risk’ in Wewak for UN head’s visit
Content: EAST Sepik police have dispelled rumours of proposed protest by West Papuans living in Wewak in light of a visit by the United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres today. Provincial police commander Supt Christopher Tamari toldThe Nationalthere is no such event happening nor any security threat when Guterres arrives. He added that police have managed to address a clash between two factions yesterday. The Secretary-General, together with Prime Minister James Marape are expected to travel to Kreer Heights to pay their respects at the tomb of our Founding Father, late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare. A team of 35 soldiers from Moem Barracks are assisting police maintain order by camping at the Nuigo junction bordering the two settlements. Meanwhile, East Sepik Governor Allan Bird says he will be away in Australia to attend commitments with Sepik people in Australia. Bird said that he was notified on Monday about the UN delegation’s visit but had already committed to attend the 50th independence anniversary celebrations by Papua New Guineans living in Perth, Western Australia. “Perth has the largest PNG community and a large proportion of them are Sepik people. They are meeting most of the expenses of this trip,” he said. “I will also use the opportunity to visit employers in Western Australia to secure opportunities for our young people to work there.” Guterres will be in Wewak to pay respect at the burial site of Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare at Kreer Heights. Bird said that Yangoru-Saussia MP Richard Maru with other MPs would welcome Guterres. Bird was responding to an invitation sent to him by Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko dated Aug 29. Tkatchenko stated in the letter that the purpose of the visit was of the highest significance. “The Secretary-General, together with Prime Minister James Marape will travel to Kreer Heights to pay their respect at the tomb of our Founding Father, late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare,” he said.
People: Allan Bird, James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko, Michael Somare, Richard Maru

Title: PNG leading bold climate action, says Guterres
Content: UNITED Nations (UN) secretary-general Antonio Guterres says that Papua New Guinea has no climate change issues and is leading a bold climate action. “Time and time again we have seen climate leadership flow not from countries with the most wealth and power, but fromthose who know the stakes well,” he said. “The Pacific islands are ground zero for the impacts of climate change and Papua New Guinea is home to two out three Pacific citizens.” Guterres said that PNG was also home to seven per cent of the world’s biodiversity and some of the largest coral reefs and rainforests on the planet.” His address to the PNG Parliament yesterday centered on economic management, human rights, women issues, peace building, the Bougainville peace agreement and climate changeissues. He said that the UN supported PNG on healthcare, sustainable agriculture, providing assistance to those impacted by landslides, collaboration on anti-corruption trainings for public servants and the judiciary. It is his first trip to the Pacific since the landmark advisory opinion of the International Court of Justice in which the Pacific played a central role. “Your voice will be integral again at the annual UN Climate conference in Brazil (in November),” he said. “This builds on your pioneering work on sea level rise as part of the Pacific Islands Forum.” Marape said that the UN and all its key agencies had been integral partners in the development of PNG in the past 50 years. “Our partnership with the United Nations has been tested and strengthened in the moments of national importance,” he said.

Title: State will not use proceeds of MVIL shares sale: Minister
Content: STATE Enterprises Minister William Duma says that the State does not own shares in the Motor Vehicles Insurance Limited (MVIL) and does not intend to use the proceeds from the sale of shares. Duma said that it was Kumul Consolidated Holdings which owned MVIL and not the state. Duma said this in response to a question by Sinasina-Yongomugl MP Kerenga Kua in a recent Parliament sitting that the proceeds of the sale would be used to rehabilitate failing state-owned enterprises (SOEs) such as PNG Power Limited and Water PNG Limited. Kua had said: “Can he (Duma) undertake to return the proceeds of the sales back to MVIL to be used for the benefit of the purpose for which this fund was established and that is to compensate victims of use of motor vehicles who are injured or who have died considering at the moment the maximum pa out is K150,000 that is too small.” Duma said:  “The motor vehicle premium funds are kept separately from other assets by MVIL to indemnify the motor vehicle owners, and these funds have not been used by MVIL or KCH. “The market value of the BSP shares held by MVIL were not part of the motor vehicle premium funds, and proceeds of the sale of BSP shares are not part of the motor vehicle insurance premium funds. “To comply with prudential requirements, MVIL always maintains and keeps a minimum of K200 million every day, to meet claims for deaths and injuries caused by the use of motor vehicles. “MVIL is currently not insolvent. “The maximum payout of K150,000 is a separate matter which is being reviewed to take into account the changing economic circumstances of PNG and subject to NEC approval, is likely to be increased for the benefit of the dependents of deceased third-party persons and injured persons.” Duma also urged media outlets to contact state owned entities (SOEs) for balance before publishing “negative or questionable claims” against SOEs.

Title: Bougainville Elections deferred to Friday
Content: THE one-day polling for the 2025 Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) general election has been rescheduled to tomorrow, according to Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai. This is to ensure that all ballot papers are sent to all parts of the region, except the Atolls constituency which will proceed with polling today. Polling for people from Bougainville living in the National Capital District, Morobe, East New Britain, Eastern Highlands, and Madang will also take place tomorrow. “Every eligible voter should have the opportunity to cast their ballots,” Tsianai said. “Rescheduling polling at this stage is the most responsible decision to ensure that all ballot papers are delivered, so that all Bougainvilleans can vote on the same day. “This step protects the rights of voters and upholds the integrity of the election.” He said the decision was necessary to ensure the proper conduct of the election given that the printing of ballot papers in Port Moresby was not completed on time. The final shipment of ballot papers, scheduled for delivery on Aug 23, only arrived on Sept 2 which did not allow for packing and distribution on time for polling to take place today. Tsianai said that the change to the polling date was made in the best interest of voters, candidates and stakeholders, to prevent any risk of disfranchisement – the practice of denying a person’s right to vote. “I ask for the understanding and cooperation of all Bougainvilleans as we take this necessary step to ensure that every voter has the opportunity to cast their ballots.” Meanwhile, counting of votes is scheduled for next Tuesday (Sept 9). The Writs will be returned on Sept 22.

Title: Crowds gather in nation’s capital to see PNGDF vessels
Content: PORT Moresby residents braved the heat yesterday to stand in long lines to visit Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) naval ships. The ships includedHMPNGS Cape Gloucester,HMPNGS Ted Diro,HMPNGS Gilbert Toropo,HMPNGS Rochus Lokinapand Tongan patrol vesselVoea Ngahau Koula. The other naval ships open for visit was India’sINS Kadmatt,HMAS Choulesand French patrol vesselAuguste Benebig. Chief Petty Officer and Chief Engineer Levi Palie said the primary purpose of HMPNGS Cape Gloucester was providing logistical support to the PNGDF. “We recently got the ship from Singapore in 2022. We normally carry cargoes or do logistics for the PNGDF,” he said. The vessel was commissioned in 2022 and had been on standby for operations in Milne Bay, Morobe and East New Britain waters. Palie said the vessel holds about 22 to 23 crew members and has sailed to Manus, East Sepik, West Sepik and Morobe. He added that in 2023 the patrol boat provided humanitarian assistance for the displaced at Mt Bagana in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville. A teacher from the Academy of Inclusive Learning Karolyn Peter said they need with children with special needs and were so happy to take their students out to the vessel for a visit, something they haven’t done before. “We have the early learning that consist of our babies from 18 months up to grade 2 then we have the home schoolers,” she said. Today will be the fleet review that will include all military vessels sailing past the APEC Haus.

Title: Juffa thanks department for improving service delivery
Content: NORTHERN Governor Gary Juffa has commended the Department of Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs (DPLGA) for improving provincial government systems, particularly in terms of service delivery and development. He told the provincial administrators and governors’ conference that it was a platform for them to assess progress, align priorities, and chart a way for improved service delivery and provincial development. “We appreciate the enormous efforts by the team of academics and technical experts led by Dr Thomas Webster, who have put together an in-depth review of the reforms and provided reports to assist decision making,” Juffa said. It aligns with the work of the bipartisan committee chaired by Governor Luther Wenge and the technical task team led by Webster who conducted a comprehensive three-phase review of PNG’s decentralisation journey. The review examined the 1977 Organic Law, the 1995 Organic Law, and the 2014 District Development Authority Act which spans decades of decentralisation efforts. The team identified systemic weaknesses in service delivery, role clarity, and institutional coordination. “The outcome of the Governor’s conference was a unanimous decision by all governors to return to the pre-1995 provincial government systems,” Juffa said. He added that functions once held at the provincial level will be restored. “The will to change has always been there,” he said. “All we needed was the systems to change.” The move is expected to empower provincial administrations, making them the “engine room of reforms”, aligning budgets with responsibilities, strengthening internal revenue generation and improving financial management. “Governors will remain in Parliament until the transition is complete to a satisfactory level,” he said. “This effort aims to build a provincial administration system that is truly responsive, resilient, and results-driven, ensuring that every Papua New Guinean, regardless of their location, has access to quality services, economic opportunity, and a dignified life, as envisioned by the conference.”

Title: Australians welcome locals aboard Navy ship
Content: JOINING the Papua New Guinea Defence Force fleet open day was Australia’s Bay Class landing vesselHMAS Choulesthat had more than 3,000 Port Moresby visitors. The fleet open day at the old cargo wharf gave people a chance to step aboard the ship and see daily naval life. Many came for their first look inside a major amphibious vessel. Papua New Guinea Defence Force’s Lt Col Moses Andreas (fromHMAS Tarangau) said the visit highlights how cooperation continues to grow between partners. “It’s good thatHMAS Choulesis here, we have only a few vessels alongside, so this cements our relationship,” he said. “It’s about celebrating 50 years, and looking ahead, step by step, hand in hand.” Visitors toured the vessel and the flight decks guided by Australian Defence Force personnel who explained the ship’s operations and daily life at sea. HMAS Chouleshas previously hosted PNGDF personnel at sea, supporting training and building mutual trust. This year, the ship will assist with ceremonial and accommodation activities of PNG50. Royal Australian Navy medic seaman Makayla Coulson said the day was about connecting with the community and showing the ship’s capabilities. “There were lots of friendly faces and photos. We showed the public how we keep fit on deck, demonstrated firefighting equipment and explained the role of the medical team at sea.”

Title: Judiciary is no subjected to suppression: Judge
Content: THE judiciary is not subjected to any suppression or interference from any politician as stated by the Commonwealth Latimer House principles, a judge says. Justice Dr Vergil Narokobi said this when presenting on the topic of Commonwealth Latimer House principles: the doctrine of separation of powers, parliamentary sovereignty and the independence of lawyers and the judiciary on Tuesday during the Continuing Legal Education (CLE) seminar in Port Moresby. “Parliamentarians are able to carry out the legislative and constitutional functions in accordance with the Constitution and free from unlawful interference and fear of criminal or defamation suit,” he said. He said an independent, impartial, honest and competent judiciary was integral in upholding the rule of law in maintaining public confidence and dispensing justice without interference by politicians. “Judicial appointments should be based on three identifying criteria, which should be equality of opportunities, eligibility to all to hold such office, appointment should be on merits and there should be gender equality,” he said. Narokobi said that the relationship between parliament and the judiciary should be governed by respect for parliament’s primary responsibility on the one hand and the respect for judiciary’s responsibility for the interpretation and application of the law as its functions. “They both play a critical role and the independence should be seen as complimentary and constructive and should not be compromised the independence of either one,” he said. He said the principle also talks about public officer holders which includes judges and parliamentarians. “Ministers, MPs, judicial officers and public office holders must always have appropriate guidelines for ethical conducts,” he said. Narokobi said the principle also speaks on the accountability mechanisms and the executive should be accountable to parliament and judicial review should be protected so that the decisions of government were subject of judicial scrutiny. “Government should give adequate time to examine proposed legislation and there should be public input into the legislative process before legislations are enacted,” he said.

Title: Law society encourages further legal education, mentoring
Content: THE PNG Law Society will make Continuing Legal Education (CLE) compulsory for all lawyers starting 2027, says president Hubert Namani. Namani said all lawyers in the country should engage in CLE for their professional growth and the society would ensure that was done in order for them to qualify to renew their practising certificates for the following year. “CLE is now in its initial trial period starting this year and next year all lawyers should take enrichment courses as it is a requirement by PNG Law Society,” he said. “In 2027, it will be a requirement for PNG lawyers in order to maintain their practising certificate, that they attend 10 hours of CLE each calendar year.” He also said that mentoring of young lawyers by senior lawyers was a necessary requirement to be taken into consideration by the society. “Mentoring is an important aspect of the legal fraternity as it is part of your contribution to the profession,” he said. “I will be reaching out to some of your senior lawyers asking you to be mentors to junior lawyers,” he said. Chief Justice Sir Gibbs Salika also said mentoring was an important part of the lawyering career as it helps to guide and shape young lawyers in their lawyering journey. “During my time, after my admission from the Legal Training Institute (LTI), I was practising as a probationary lawyer for six months under the mentorship and guidance of a senior lawyer until I could run a trial on my own and I was confirmed as a lawyer,” she said. He said the practise today was quite different with mentoring and career growth of a young graduate lawyer as they were just going into the court unprepared for “sharks like me waiting to attack”.

Title: United Kingdoms West to visit PNG
Content: UNITED Kingdom (UK) Minister for the Indo-Pacific Catherine West will arrive in the country tomorrow for a three-day visit to sign agreements aimed at improving cooperation. West’s visit will see the signing of a new shiprider agreement, including two new development agreements with the Government and an announcement of new grant funding for sustainable agriculture and biodiversity conservation projects to address climate change. She is also expected to meet Prime Minister James Marape and Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko to express the UK’s congratulations as Papua New Guinea marks 50 years of independence. “It is an honour to represent the UK at this significant milestone for Papua New Guinea, an important partner for us in the Pacific,” West said. “The UK is working in partnership with PNG to maintain regional security and stability and tackle the climate and nature crisis, in line with your priorities.” Her visit also coincides with PNG’s 50th anniversary celebrations during the Defence Force Week, aiming to strengthen UK-PNG defence and security ties. The minister will attend the 50th anniversary Military Tattoo, which will see the UK Pipe and Drum Majors from the First Battalion Scots Guards join the PNG and Australian Defence Force Pipes and Drums for a combined performance. She will also meet British Royal Navy personnel fromHMS Tamar, one of two Royal Navy vessels located in the region. Alongside Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph, Minister West is expected to sign a new “Shiprider” agreement which will allow PNG officials to travel on British Navy vessels and carry out law enforcement within the country’s maritime territory.
People: Billy Joseph, James Marape, Justin Tkatchenko

Title: EU commissioner tours Pacific
Content: A EUROPEAN Union (EU) envoy will visit three Pacific Island countries this month to strengthen partnership and collaboration with the region. European Commissioner for International Partnerships Jozef Síkela will visit Fiji, Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea from Sept 5-12 to deepen the EU-Pacific partnership and scale up Global Gateway – the EU’s investment strategy to boost jobs and sustainable economic growth. His visit will focus on the main Global Gateway areas in the Pacific such as resilience to climate change and digital connectivity, including mobilising sustainable investments in quality infrastructure. In addition to hard infrastructure – building ports or hydropower plants, the EU also invests in soft infrastructure, such as skill development, capacity building, and regulatory support, to add value on the ground. During his tour, Síkela will sign several bilateral and regional agreements, meet high-level government representatives and visit EU-funded projects, such as two schools in Vanuatu affected by the earthquake that will be reconstructed and upgraded to serve as emergency shelters for the wider population during natural disasters. “The Pacific region is an important partner for the European Union, and I look forward to my visit as an opportunity to strengthen our lasting political and economic ties,” he said. “Our partnership helps us advance shared priorities – resilience to climate change and sustainable economic growth – ultimately improving the quality of life for people in both regions. “The EU’s Global Gateway investment strategy and the first-ever EU-Pacific Business Forum will help turn those priorities into action.” Síkela will attend the EU-Pacific Business Forum to be held in Nadi, Fiji, Sept 4-5, a first of its kind event in the region which will bring together high-level EU and Pacific policymakers, private sector leaders, investors and development partners to unlock trade and investment opportunities, showcase concrete projects, and build lasting business partnerships. In Papua New Guinea, his visit will serve to celebrate the country’s 50th anniversary of independence. According to the EU, bilateral flagship projects in the PNG include the green rehabilitation of the Rabaul port in East New Britain and the water, sanitation and hygiene programme in the country’s local communities.

Title: Three killed in Jiwaka accident
Content: THREE persons died in a road accident near Wagi Bridge in Jiwaka on the Highlands Highway on Sunday afternoon, police said. Jiwaka police commander Chief Inspector Laimo Asi, confirming the deaths, said 10 other persons received injuries, some serious, and were hospitalised at the Kudzip Nazarene Hospital. Asi said the cause of the accident was yet to be established, however, he warned drivers to take extra care when driving and applying traffic rules at all times, and refrain from drink driving. He said police had started an operation to impound defective and unregistered vehicles, and monitor drinking in moving vehicles. “Defaulters will be charged and fined,” he said. Asi said it would be better if authorities banned liquor sales and consumption in the province until the Independence anniversary celebrations ended. The accident was reported to have occurred when a Coaster bus travelling behind a truck allegedly rammed into it.

Title: Madang set for golden jubilee operations
Content: POLICE in Madang will start their golden jubilee operations by Monday and want the public in the province to maintain their dignity and respect. Madang police commander Acting Superintendent Robert Baim said people have to celebrate in true spirit to fit the occasion of 50 years. “Police in the province will start the operations with or without support as this is our responsibility and will be boosted with manpower from Correctional Services officers at Beon Prison,” he said. Baim said that is why people in the province have to adhere to the laws and avoid unlawful behaviour. “Madang police will not tolerate rascals, loud music after 10pm, being disrespectful to others, and all celebrations must be peaceful,” he said. Baim said anyone found drunk and attending celebrations will be dealt with accordingly. It was also revealed that police have identified possible spots in the town and in urban villages where homebrew (steam) is being produced and will target those spots to ensure production of those illicit spirit is not available to people during celebrations. Baim said all community policing units in the province would be utilised and has asked business houses and other stakeholders to support police to ensure their presence is there. Baim thanked Madang Governor Ramsey Pariwa and Madang administrator Daniel Aloi for funding support.

Title: Authority donates solar kits to communities
Content: MADANG district communities received a donation from the National Energy Authority (NEA) that consists of solar panels, solar kits and solar lanterns to support the rural solar electrification and drive the energy solution programme in the province. The Madang Rural Development Foundation (MRDF) with their partner Terrax Global Solutions, extended their appreciation to NEA for their generous donation. MRDF managing director Kurere Matanzana said the solar products are the best energy solutions for the rural and marginalised communities, especially their aid posts and health and resource centres. “The solar kits will be supplied to the targeted communities in Transgogol and Ambenob. “Our sincere thanks also to the Madang Health Authority for their logistical support, ensuring this project reached those who need it most,” he said. “We commend the leadership of executive manager Conrad Kumul and managing director Ronald Meketa for championing sustainable energy initiatives that will transform the lives of many in rural communities.” Kumul commended the leadership and initiative taken by MRDF and Terrax Global Solutions to partner NEA to drive the energy solution programme in province. This collaboration marks the beginning of a strong partnership in driving development for the people in Madang. Sustainable initiatives are the way forward for PNG’s energy sector, he said. Kurere added: “Together, we can light up communities, improve service delivery, and build a brighter, greener future for all.”

Title: New course needed for Bougainville development
Content: Canberra: The sole focus of Bougainville’s leaders to secure independence from Papua New Guinea risks failing to improve the long-term wellbeing of its people, research warns. Almost 98 per cent of people in the Autonomous Region of Bougainville, located in the northeast of PNG’s territorial waters, voted for independence in 2019. The referendum was non-binding and must be ratified by PNG’s parliament. It was mandated by the Bougainville Peace Agreement, which was signed in 2001 and ended a decade of civil war between the region and PNG. Bougainville’s leaders have since committed to declaring independence from Sept 1, 2027. A Lowy Institute report by Oliver Nobetau says while the peace agreement laid the foundations for the transition from autonomy to independence, it failed to provide a road map for overcoming key challenges. These include making improvements to people’s quality of life, such as providing access to basic services, employment, infrastructure and governance. “A Bougainville that seeks to achieve independence without a meaningful foundation for development is at risk of replicating the conditions it is seeking to escape,” the report reads. It argues a new agreement is needed between Bougainville and PNG to support socio-economic development and redefine the relationship. It should focus on co-operative efforts for development, measuring improvement through quantifiable targets and outlining the roles and responsibilities of both parties in achieving them. The report says Bougainville’s public service remains “critically underdeveloped” with 400 employees spread thin across unstable and often temporary workspaces. Almost 70 per cent of Bougainville’s public servants believe their institutional set-up is ineffective to carry out mandated functions. The report notes while these issues are also found throughout PNG, they lead to a lack of overall government presence felt within society and prevent Bougainville from exercising its autonomy in any meaningful way while undermining its readiness for independence. “The roadmap for Bougainville’s future should not be singularly defined by independence but must be grounded in development and prosperity for its people,” the report says. Five years ago, former Bougainville Revolutionary Army commander Ishmael Toroama won the presidency for his region on a platform of delivering independence for its some 300,000 people. Bougainville will hold its fifth election for the house of representatives on Friday. Source: With AAP

Title: United Nations’ Guteress commends PNG and Bougainville governments for maintaining peace on Bougainville
Content: UNITED Nations (UN) Secretary General Antonio Guteress has commended the Government for maintaining peace on Bougainville by forging consensus through dialogue. For more than two decades, Papua New Guinea and Bougainville have stayed the course of peace by honouring the UN-backed Bougainville Peace Agreement (BPA). The UN’s Peacebuilding Fund has supported two pillars of the BPA – weapons disposal and the 2019 Bougainville Referendum – where 97.7 per cent of Bougainvilleans voted for independence. When the Government and the Autonomous Bougainville Government reached an impasse on a pathway to table the referendum result to Parliament for ratification, the UN stepped in to fund the work of independent moderator, Sir Jerry Mateparae, to chart a way forward. This resulted in the Melanesian Agreement signed in June which Guteress said exemplified both parties’ willingness to engage in the difficult conversations –– and the United Nations has been honoured to be a part of this process. “Last Saturday (Aug 30) marked the twenty-fourth anniversary of the Bougainville Peace Agreement. This conflict left deep scars,” Guteress said in his address to Parliament on Wednesday. “You have shown the world the path of healing –– through dialogue, perseverance and mutual respect.
