On Friday, Bougainvilleans will cast their votes in the fifth autonomous election since the agreement. “I would like to salute the President of Bougainville (Ishmael Toroama), the Vice President and Minister for Independence, who are with us here today,” Guteress said. “Thank you for your commitment to these noble efforts. “We are also proud to work in partnership with women, youth and civil society throughout Bougainville. “Your continued dialogue offers a model to other countries, and I am confident that the next phase will deliver a lasting resolution to the mutual benefit of all.” Meanwhile, Guteress said PNG offered a number of powerful lessons to the world despite the geopolitical tensions that has created a volatile new reality for countries around the world. “In the face of these storms, Papua New Guinea offers a number of powerful lessons to the world,” Guteress said. “The first, is the art of forging consensus through dialogue. “For the past half century, you have worked to weave a single nation out of many traditions, many islands, many tongues. “Of course, that task is not easy. But you are determined to move forward, step by step.”

Title: 10 nations join PNGDF to celebrate PNG’s 50th Independence anniversary
Content: PNG Defence Force Chief Rear-Admiral Philip Polewara has thanked the 10 partner nations who are in Port Moresby to take part in activities to celebrate the 50th Independence anniversary. “Your presence and support shall strengthen our bonds, enhance our capabilities, and continue to foster a spirit of cooperation,” he said. Soldiers numbering up to 750 are from Australia, United States, United Kingdom, New Zealand, France, India, Japan, Fiji, Tonga, and Vanuatu. They will take part in activities planned for the PNG Defence Force Week which started yesterday. They include an Open Day yesterday and today where people could visit the naval vessels. A fleet review of naval vessels from PNG and other countries will be held at Ela Beachtomorrow, followed by a military tattoo on Friday at the Sir Hubert Murray stadium, and an air show on Saturday plus an aircraft static display on Sunday. Polewara thanked the 10 nations for sending naval vessels and military bands. “We appreciate your contributions which promote goodwill and understanding between our nations,” Polewara said. “We look forward to continued collaboration and friendship. “Together, in the years to come, we will build a brighter future for our nations and our people. “I urge you all, where your programmes permit, take time to immerse yourself in our celebrations and experience our unique culture and tradition.”

Title: ‘We cannot make any more change’: Eoe says LLG polls begin this month
Content: POLLING for the 2025 Local Level Government (LLG) elections will start on Sept 27 – no more deferrals, says Provincial and Local Level Government Affairs Minister Soroi Eoe. “The time is coming as we have all been waiting for a while now,” he said. “This is the 11th hour so we cannot make any more changes. “We have already planned everything and the Electoral Commission is getting organised. “Ballot boxes and ballot papers are being finalised and have been delivered. “The people have already made up their mind that there should be no more deferrals. “The LLG elections will go ahead as planned.” Polling will end on Oct 10. Counting starts on Oct 11. Writs will be returned on Oct 17. He was responding in Parliament to Western Highlands Governor Wai Rapa yesterday who raised concerns over the timing of the LLG elections as there would be other national events such as the 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations and Grade 12 national examinations to be held soon. Rapa asked if the elections could be deferred once again. “LLGs are very important tiers of government because they are closest to the people,” he said. “I am concerned that the schedule for the LLG elections will affect other events such as the Independence celebrations which will happen days before polling starts. “There is also the national examinations coming up and the elections could affect the students. “All these have to be considered before the elections are conducted. We need to give a peace of mind to LLG leaders as well.” Eoe said that there would be no more deferrals.

Title: Stronger laws should be to imposed on election-related offences: Niningi
Content: JUSTICE Minister and Attorney-General Pila Niningi says that there is a need to strengthen laws to be imposed on perpetrators of election-related offences. Niningi said that those who committed election-related offences such as the hijacking of ballot boxes or destruction of counting centres must be charged and prosecuted. Kabwum MP Patrick Basa yesterday questioned if there were laws to deal with perpetrators of election-related offences. Basa also sought clarification on a provision of Section 175 of the Organic Law on National and Local Level Government elections which the Electoral Commission could make declarations on based on “special circumstances”. He said: “Under Section 175 of the Organic Law, the Electoral Commission has the power to declare winners on special circumstances, but that law is still not clear. The minister must look into this law. “There is also the issue during elections where government properties are destroyed, (such as) buildings and cars being burnt. “Aren’t these criminal offences? “Running elections costs a lot of (public) money, but these people always cause trouble and then run away to hide. “Whoever causes these problems must be held responsible. The laws need to be clarified and enforced so these practices can be stopped.” Niningi said he would direct his department to look into the issues. “We must straighten and strengthen the law,” he said. “The destruction of ballot boxes and prevention of the counting process are completely wrong and are criminal offences. “The matter of a special circumstances declaration needs to be clarified to ensure that it prevents any more such cases happening in the future. “Many people are taking the law into their own hands during elections and we have to prevent that from happening.”

Title: Masere under fire in Parliament over NID project
Content: ADMINISTRATIVE Services Minister Richard Masere came under fire in Parliament yesterday over matters relating to the National Identification (NID) project. Jiwaka Governor Simon Kaiwi said that many Papua New Guineans who had turned 18 years and eligible to vote in elections had not been registered. “Can the minister inform this house if we have an updated common roll for the 2027 general election? “Do we have some systems to use in the 2027 elections?” Masere said that they would ensure that everyone was registered by 2027. “We are looking at biometric and electronic voting come 2027,” he said. Hiri Koiari MP Keith Iduhu said that the NID programme had reached less than 10 per cent of the population. “NID is a failed project,” Iduhu added. Masere denied that it was a failed project. “When it (NID programme) was created in 2014, it was created out of political convenience, created outside of the Constitution,” he said. “As a result, we had two agencies duplicating work. “I had to correct the flaws created by the former Government and bring it in line so that it works within the Constitution.” He added that the past Government had not funded the programme apart from the K300 million allocated initially which he said was “misused” by that former government. Former prime minister and Ialibu Pangia MP Peter O’Neill interjected with a point of order saying that Masere’s statement about the alleged misuse of funds was incorrect. “He has to be specific. “Who misused the money? “Is it the (NID) staff or (political) leaders? “Some of those who created the issue are now with the Government. “So stop pointing fingers at everyone. “Admit your failures so that you can correct yourself and do the right thing for once.”
People: Keith Iduhu, Richard Masere, Simon Kaiwi

Title: NZDF helicopter carries escavator to Keapara in Central’s Rigo
Content: A ROYAL New Zealand Air Force (RNZAF) helicopter yesterday transported a mini excavator from Kiru to Keapara village in Rigo district, Central. Kiru is part of Keapara, Alukuni and Karawa in the Hood Lagoon. This week, the PNG Defence Force, Australian Defence Force, RNZAF and France will carry out the Planti Balus Operation, providing road and air transport in rural areas. Air lead planner Major Darius Kaule toldThe Nationalthat the aircraft used would include the C-130J Super Hercules, C-7 Spartans, CASA CN 235 and NH 90 helicopters, plus the PNGDF’s PAC 750 in the operation. They can land and take off from any provincial airport. The helicopters will operate across a radius of about 180km from Port Moresby. They will fly to villages and small grass airstrips in Central, Gulf and Milne Bay. Villagers could not take the excavator across because of the lagoon that separates Kiru from Keapara. Kaule said the planes would also transport school supplies, medical equipment and supplies, building materials andanything that would benefit the communities. RNZAF Flight Lieutenant Paul Robinson said that they arrived on Aug 31 and would assist in transporting mosquito nets in the next two days. “Three assisted the movement of an excavator to a small village (which) they couldn’t transport themselves,” he added. “The helicopter was perfect to do that. “The only means they had to shifting it was by boat but it was not feasible for this particular equipment.”

Title: Peace returns to Mt Hagen
Content: FIGHTING between two major tribes in Western Highlands’ Mt Hagen has stopped, returning the peace of Aug 18-19 back to the city and the Jika and Moge tribes. Acting provincial police commander Inspector Moses Kalandi said police are monitoring the progress of the ceasefire agreement reached last Friday. Kalandi said police have been working with the Jika and Moge tribes since Monday to get the people go into the peace processes as outlined in the agreement. The agreement was reached after police and security personnel, backed by four political leaders in the province and councilors, asked the young warriors to leave guns for peace, and bury their five dead, and allow normalcy. The agreement was signed between the Jika and Moge tribes at the Western Highlands government building in the presence of political leaders Governor Wai Rapa, Minister for State Owned Enterprises William Duma, Minister for Commerce and Trade Bakri Daki, and Vice Minister for Police Jacob Maki. Senior provincial magistrate Betty Jacobs and the police also witnessed the Jika Milakemb Kunka/Palga and the Moge Engimb Andaklimb tribes signing the agreement. Leaders on both sides showed their remorse, thanked their political leaders for fostering peace, and agreed to lay down their arms, and heal the wounds the two days’ fight had inflicted. Rapa said peace is a fragile commodity that needs to be protected, and the Jika and Moge, as traditional landowners of Mt Hagen city have done it right. Duma said the Jika and the Moge had a close traditional bondage through ancestral lineage which should be respected and passed on to the next generation. Duma thanked the two tribes for heeding his instruction to prevent further agitation and remained within their land boundaries after the fight cooled off last Wednesday. Mul Baiyer Lumusa MP Jacob Maki said he appreciated the young men for listening to their councillors and community leaders in ending the fight, after two days of intensive fire exchanges. Maki said police and the PNG Defence Force soldiers will remain in Mt Hagen during the peace-building period to the end of this week. Meanwhile, Kalandi praised the tribal leaders for showing leadership, maturity and a commitment to lasting peace by agreeing to the ceasefire. Among the agreement was that all gunmen be disbanded and withdrawn from conflict areas immediately.

Title: Graduate gets support to build laboratory for herbal medicine
Content: A RECENT graduate from the Pacific Adventist University (PAU) received K130,000 from two sources to set up a laboratory to make a heart herbal medicine. K100,000 came from the Markham Development Authority and local MP Koni Iguan gave K30,000 to Allan Thomson for his Raginam Herbal Medicine laboratory last week at Raginam in Umi Markham. Raginam Herbal Medicine is made largely from goose grass. Thomson, a chemistry and biology student, is the founder of Raginam Herbal Medicine. He said goose grass was part of his final-year research project. “After completing my studies I returned to the village where one of my uncles was suffering from a heart condition,” Thomson said. He said they brought him to a health facility and found that there was no medicine to treat him. “When we got back to the village, I decided to use my final research formula and finding to make a herbal medicine from goose grass to treat his symptoms. “After taking two 500ml bottle of goose grass herb for two days, we saw that he recovered very well and then word spread to others about the herbal medicine,” Thomson said. He said he only extracted compounds from the goose grass and separated the minerals then mix with water to make the medicine. “The herbal medicine is made upon request from patients through their medical history and has a shelf life of two weeks,” Thomson said. He said two 500mls of herbal medicine dosage was 125mls taken every six hours for two days. Thompson acknowledged support from Iguan and the Markham authority for the construction of his laboratory and hopes to serve his local community. But he isn’t sure whether he’ll need a licence or clearance from the medical authorities to manufacture the medicine to sell to the public. “This is just a small support from me to our young man to continue what he has been doing,” Iguan said “Since this is my first time here in Raginam village to see what he does, I will only support him with a small amount and see where it takes him.” Iguan said venturing into such scientific practice these days was hard and took a lot of effort, but wished him well in his endeavours. Markham health manager Veronica Waffi said: “During our ancestor’s days, bush or herbal remedies were used widely for all types of illnesses. “Our elders used bark from trees, their leaves that can be boiled and some medicinal grass were taken as medicine. “Even some leaves were heated and placed on swollen parts of the body to be healed. “Now after being educated and being introduced to medical drugs and injections, we forgot about our natural remedies,” Waffi said. She said everyone wanted to take Panadol or amoxicillin for every little illness. “What our young man is doing is good but he has to go through a lot of process in order to achieve that and needs support from everyone,” Waffi said. She said the Health Department had processes and tests that needs to be done in order to be certified as a herbal medicine and urged Thomson not to give-up Waffi added that she was aware that most health facilities were having medicine shortages and were only giving prescriptions for patients to buy medicine in stores that prompted locals to use natural remedies. The Raginam Herbal Medicine is located at Raginam in Umi local level government, Markham.

Title: Lae Metropolitan Supt says police ‘will not back down’ despite threats
Content: POLICE in Lae have responded to threats levelled against them regarding the two armed robberies that happened last Friday and Sunday in Lae. During the first incident at a shop at Eriku last Friday, six suspects were shot dead, allegedly by police, two were badly injured and three escaped. On Sunday around midday, armed robbers held up a shop at Limki. Police did not indicate the amount of money stolen but said two of the suspects were wounded while another six escaped. Lae metropolitan commander Chief Supt Chris Kunyanban said police will not back down on the threats issued on social media, allegedly in relation to the armed robberies. “We will not back off, if they want to issue threats, we will face them head-on as we are only performing our constitutional duties,” said Kunyanban. He said police personnel had a duty to protect lives and properties and they were only carrying it out so if criminals wanted to issue threats, police will not hesitate to face them. The threats were issued via social media and other mediums after the two armed robberies. Kunyanban warned the people who were issuing the threats to be careful as the threats were sure to cause panic among members of the public as well. “It is a common practice where when police get into a confrontation with criminals, people want to issue threats and now with social media, anybody who feels like making a stupid statement would do so without knowing that the statement is actually a threat,” he said. He said policemen or women were human beings just like everyone else but when their lives came under threat while executing their duties, they had laws that protected them when using firearms. Kunyanban said that what had happened was an unfortunate situation and asked people to stop issuing threats and work with police to keep Lae city peaceful for the 50th independence anniversary celebration. He said police were still investigating the robbery incidents.

Title: Tanam first primary school in Morobe to celebrate independence anniversary
Content: TANAM Primary School in Huon Gulf is one of the first primary schools in Morobe to celebrate the 50th independence anniversary by reciting the speech of Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare on Sept 16, 1975. The school came to live yesterday as soldiers from the Engineering Battalion at Igam in Lae together with representatives from the Seventh-day Adventist church and students took part by reenacting the events that took place then. During the celebration at the school premises, the Australian flag was lowered and PNG flag was raised, commemorating what happened at Independence Hill in Waigini, Port Moresby on Sept 16, 1975. A 10-year-old grade six student, Aaric Jonathan Bampaf from East Sepik was appointed by the student body to recite the speech by Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare. Bampaf was led to the stage to recite the speech. He said: “The day we all have been looking forward for so long has arrived. Today is Sept 16, 1975, we have talked about this day, planned for it and looked forward to it. This country and its people can now enter independence and sovereignty and we will be counted among the family of nations.” He also recited another line of the speech, saying: “We have been lucky as we have not shed blood to gain the independence.” He then recited another line which spoke of those that were involved in ensuring PNG gained its independence like Sir Peter Simogun, Matthias Toliman and many others. The celebrations also saw performances by a women’s group from the United Church in Lae and a mock battle performance by soldiers. Tanam Primary School head teacher Otnie Omali said the purpose of the celebration was to mark the 50th independence anniversary of the country and to inform the students of what actually happened on Sept 16, 1975. He described the celebration as commemorative and informative as many of the students in schools now together with their parents, were not present when the country gained its independence. After the speeches, the 50th anniversary sculpture was unveiled to make the event.

Title: Primary school in Markham benefits from Australia government funding support
Content: FUNDING support in K93,000 worth of essential infrastructure support from the Australian government will boost the learning of more than 300 students of Itsir Primary School in Morobe’s Markham. School board chairman John Gaif said desks, tables and bookshelves to be received today were funded through the Direct Aid Programme of the Australian High Commission, supported by Grow PNG and Australian Consulate General, Lae. He said these would unlock the potential of their community. “Markham Valley is in a strategic location for agriculture and all other developments,” he said. “Without proper education and supporting infrastructure to help our children’s learning, how sure are we that our upcoming generation is capable of sustaining farming and other business activities on our land and can impact the next generation,” he said. The school, which has only three grades, is the only school serving Itsir village and nearby hamlets of ward 14, Atzera local level government. In 2016, the community with the help of GrowPNG, a private sector partner in agriculture, initiated an early childhood school. Gaif said last year, under the 1-6-6 system, they introduced grade three and the next goal was to be formally recognised.

Title: Grey list being monitored: PM
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has reassured the Parliament that work is in progress to get the country out of being grey listed. Marape said an inter-departmental committee involving the Department of Justice and Attorney General (DJAG) and other state bodies have been directed to get the country out of the grey list if it does happen next year. Grey listing refers to a country being under increased monitoring by international Financail Action Task Force because of presumed money laundering activities, counter financing of terrorism and other monetary restrictions. Unlike black listing, grey listing means a country is actively aware and working to improve its situation but still faces issues. “The last time we were grey listed was a period between 2014 to 2016 and we got ourselves uplifted out of it and right now in the mutual evaluation programme it is indicated that we might be put back to the grey list next year,” he said. “I want to give assurance to the Parliament that each departmental and agency team has been working for two years to avert the possibility of us going to the grey list but in any case if it does happen in 2026 then I want to give full assurance to the country that just like in 2016 when we got out of the grey list we will do our best.” He said the committee that involves the DJAG, Central Bank, Financial Analysis and Supervision Unit, Finance, Treasury, Police and other agencies. He was answering to Deputy Opposition Leader James Donald queries on how serious the Government was taking the country’s grey listing. Marape said global consciousness on terrorism financing and money laundering had been elevated since the Sept 11, 2001 terrorist attack in New York.

Title: School to mark nation’s 50 years with reconciliation
Content: YOKUA primary school in remote Bulolo will mark 50 years with a reconciliation ceremony to be held this week. The School is in Watut local level government of Bulolo district, and will mark a double celebration this month as it commemorates its 50th anniversary alongside Papua New Guinea’s Golden Jubilee. The two-day programme will not only celebrate the school’s history but also feature a reconciliation ceremony between five landowner groups and key stakeholders. Community leaders believe this symbolic step is vital to restoring the school’s future after decades of struggles. Despite being one of the oldest schools in Morobe, Yokua Primary has faced continuous setbacks since its establishment. Poor infrastructure, lack of resources, and consistently low academic performance have hindered its progress. Local beliefs attribute some of these challenges to a “curse,” linked to the community’s past mistreatment of early missionaries and explorers. Senior teacher Lenny Immanuel said reconciliation is seen as the first step towards change. “For the past five decades, the school has not been operating well, which is reflected in the poor academic results of our children and the rundown state of classrooms and teachers’ houses,” he said. “We want to reconcile with our stakeholders to pave the way forward.” Immanuel has called on the Bulolo District Development Authority, Mineral Resources Authority, Hidden Valley mine, PNG Forest Products, and church partners to support the event. “We don’t have much, but this programme is important,” he said. “We invite our stakeholders to help us, whether in cash or kind, to make this celebration a success.” Yokua Primary is a level-five school and serves students from 10 surrounding villages in Ward 8 of Watut LLG.  With limited road access making it difficult to transport materials, most school buildings are semi-permanent structures. The school acknowledged Bulolo MP Sam Basil Jnr for giving K50,000 towards build a new two-in-one classroom.

Title: Madang parade kicks off festivities
Content: MADANG town saw the province’s biggest parade on Friday. It was the launching of the 50th Independence Anniversary celebration and Madang people showed up in numbers to give it a roaring start to golden jubilee. Locals and foreigners showed up at the town’s Laiwaden Oval, among them an attractive young Chinese woman. As soon as the white Ramu NiCo 25-seat white coaster bus pulled up beside the Raibus Truck which the company used to decorate for the Ramu NiCo float, Joy Deng and her friends hurried out and explored what different corporate businesses were showcasing. Joy has seen float parades in China, but not as creative as what was in front of her on Friday, she said. Even more exciting for her was the fact that her employer Ramu NiCo was the major sponsor of the event and she was actually a participant. Before joining Ramu NiCo, she used to be a spectator in similar parades in her humble Hunan province in South China. Joy was now fulfilling the meaning of her own name, “Joy”, and ventured into the crowd laughing and dancing as she was discovering the splendid display of each float at Laiwaden Oval. To the amazement of some Papua New Guineans, Joy was actually doing a two-step dance that many them were familiar with. She and her friends captured numerous photos for her fond memories PNG. When the float took off from Laiwaden Oval and hit the streets of Madang town for school children to see, Joy saw Madang town too. “I have a comprehensive view of Madang town, and I am very excited about this experience,” Joy said. She said people in Hunan are friendly and loving just like the Madang people, who promoted the friendly culture and expressed “Kagin” in the local Bel dialect. Joy said she’ll remember parade for some time, the huge shark from Talidig, PNG Power’s display, the amazing artwork of a Bird of Paradise by Madang Technical College, traditional costumes and dancing on Sigma float, Air Niugini plane, Spiderman on the police landcruiser open back and many other displays.

Title: UPNG law students society hosts annual Regal Runway pageant
Content: THE University of Papua New Guinea’s School of Law hosted the annual Regal Runway pageant over the weekend to mark the school’s 60th anniversary. The pageant was also the school’s event to celebrate the 50th Independence anniversary. Law student’s society social and events committee member Emmajoy Ramo said the pageant was one of the highlights of the school’s calendar. “The Regal Runway is about creating a platform for law students to express themselves outside of academics. “It’s about showcasing creativity, talent and confidence while building unity and team spirit,” Ramo said. Eight student contestants took part in the event, with two representatives from each cohort (year one to year four). The contestants were Roswita Takil and Ricksy Kaiglo (LLB1), Michelle Debela and Silas Wagambie (LLB2), Jasmine Kosi and Kolo Sokame (LLB3), and Cassey Bang and Lenzen Zeru (LLB4). After an eventful night, Wagambie and Kosi were crowned Mr and Miss School of Law 2025. Judges included the pageant’s first male winner Benjamin Yalehen, social entrepreneur and DFM Model Agency founder, Leilani Konjib, and law lecturer Brian Tom.

Title: Bougainville marks Patriotism Day
Content: BOUGAINVILLEANS showed up in colour and pride to commemorate Bougainville Independence Patriotism Day on Monday. The day began with a dawn service at the Hutjena Oval, the same location in Buka, North Bougainville, where the Bougainville flag was hoisted for the first time on Sept 1, 1975. The service, led by the Bougainville council of churches, paid tribute to Bougainville’s political journey and honoured the legacy of key Bougainville leaders. The day’s event was followed by a water taxi float on the Buka passage, and a vehicle float by local taxis and government vehicles in the vicinity of Buka, culminating at Hutjena where the main programme was held. Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) Minister for Community Development Morris Opeti in delivering the keynote address at Hutjena Oval, emphasised the importance of the day and the significant meaning it held for Bougainville. “Today, we honour the meaning behind what happened on the Sept 1, 50 years ago. That day, the Bougainville flag was raised for the first time, even ahead of PNG’s independence. It was the first Universal Declaration of Independence that Bougainville made. And even though it did not receive the recognition it deserved at the time, what it did was instill a spirit of resilience, unity and strength to keep fighting for our political destiny,” Opeti said. He urged Bougainvilleans, particularly the younger generation, to embrace the spirit of patriotism and carry forward the aspirations of past leaders. “That is the spirit that we continue to celebrate today and we must ensure that generations who will come after us, keep this resilience alive. “Patriotism means we must continue to fight, continue to believe in our political destiny, even when the journey is hard,”Opeti said. He acknowledged that while ABG builds by enhancing its capacity and resources, “our target remains clear – independence by 2027”.

Title: Government committed to connecting country
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has reaffirmed the Government’s commitment to connect every corner of the country by road, electricity, ports, and information and communication technology (ICT), saying the next 20 years will be focused on ending rural isolation and unlocking the country’s full economic potential. Over the weekend, Marape travelled through Central, Gulf, Morobe, and Milne Bay, meeting communities along the new road corridors. He described the trip as “a moving experience” that underscored why the Government must prioritise connectivity for the majority of Papua New Guineans living in rural areas. “From Kupiano all the way to Gadaisu in Milne Bay, I saw almost unanimous support for the missing road link – a 300km stretch that will finally connect isolated communities to the rest of the country,” Marape said. “For the first time, vehicles can now pass from Port Moresby into Central and onwards to Milne Bay. This symbolises our intention: no one must be left behind.” Marape said the road corridor had already revealed vast opportunities in agriculture. Communities in Aroma, Amazon Bay and elsewhere in Milne Bay spoke of more than 100,000ha of land available for oil palm, rubber, coffee, and cocoa. Many of these plantations were abandoned after 1975, but could now be revived. “These roads will pay for themselves. They open up land for agriculture, fisheries, and small-to-medium enterprises (SME). They give our people the chance to move from subsistence into the formal cash economy,” Marape said. He said beyond agriculture, the Port Moresby–Alotau route is poised to boost domestic and international tourism. “This is one of the most pristine environments in PNG, with some of the friendliest people and unique cultures. We want to see guesthouses, resorts and tourism services emerge along this corridor,” he said. Marape also revealed that he was developing a new policy from his office to ensure that rural landowners benefit directly from new road links. “Our people already own land and land is an asset. But it has not been translated into cash value. I am working on a policy to register customary land properly, so that it can be used as collateral for SMEs, housing loans, and agriculture projects,” he said. The policy will link with existing SME and credit facilities, enabling landowners to build decent houses, run small businesses, and invest in commercial agriculture. Marape stressed that the new roads will not only open up markets but also uplift law and order. Police posts will be stationed along highways while laws will be passed to prevent illegal land sales and settlements. The Government also intends to expand supporting infrastructure – including electricity, jetties, airstrips, and information and communications technology services – to ensure rural communities are fully integrated into the national economy. Marape said the road opening was just the beginning of a 20-year vision to transform PNG’s connectivity. “From our 50th Independence anniversary to the 70th, we will build kilometre by kilometre until every part of our country is connected. “Whether by road, sea, air, or ICT – our people must be linked to opportunities,” Marape declared. “When I drove into Alotau and saw boys, girls, men and women celebrating, it affirmed to me that our focus is correct.” He said the other new routes now allow vehicles to travel from Port Moresby through Gulf, Morobe, Lae, and onwards to Madang and the Highlands, something unthinkable a few years ago. “Our government owes it to the rest of the country – especially the rural majority – to unbundle the full economic potential of our land. We will not be distracted by detractors,” Marape said.

Title: Milne Bay man recalls historic walk
Content: ON Jan 19, 1973, an 18-year-old from Fergusson Island, Milne Bay, made a decision that would shape the rest of his life. Soape Josa was in Form Six at the time when he enlisted in the Papua New Guinea Defence Force, not knowing that within just two years, he would become part of history. By 1975, whispers of independence were everywhere. PNG was preparing to stand as its own nation, and questions were raised about whether its fledgling defence force was ready. “Our defence force was young at that time and there were talks if our defence force was fit or not,” Josa recalled. “They said we must walk first to prove that we are fit.” As a private in Delta Company based at Moem Barracks, Wewak, Josa was among those selected to join a symbolic march to Port Moresby. Soldiers from each company – A, B, C, D, support, and administration – were chosen. From Delta, Josa was one of the lucky few. “They kept us three months in training. After the training, some fell out, some went through, and then they made selections. Among the 16, I was selected,” he said. On May 19, 1975, the group of 16 men began their long march from Moem Barracks. For Josa, the journey came with added responsibility. He had been chosen as the batman, personal assistant and close companion to the commander of the group, Lieutenant Geoffrey Key. “As the batman, I cooked for him, made his tea, and followed him to a location when he wanted to send a message. I did all his work because he was an officer. He could have selected someone from A Company, but he chose me from Delta,” he said. The trek was not easy. Supplies were limited, and the men struggled with poor-quality footwear. “One of the challenges faced during the trekking at that time was we had no proper shoes. Our shoes were Asian made; Australia did not give us good shoes,” Josa added. “Walking through the Markham Valley was especially hard with no roads, just dust everywhere.” Yet, Josa brought more than physical strength to the group, he brought laughter. “I was the clown in the group. I cracked jokes so the soldiers would not miss their kids and families, but focus on the journey we were taking,” he said. Looking back, he shared a message for today’s soldiers: “Discipline is important. “Every Defence Force member must show good discipline to the nation. “There’s no other way to bring PNG up without discipline. “We must lead by example for the young people, including students.” After 21 years of service, Josa retired as a warrant officer. He returned to his community and helped establish the reserve police to continue promoting discipline and order. Today, he lives with his five children and five grandchildren. He will celebrate his 70th birthday next month. And though the years have passed, one nickname from that historic walk still follows him. “Lieutenant Key used to call me kindam, and I used to say, ‘Hey, I’m not a prawn!’ That name stuck with me ever since,” he laughed. From a young private carrying the hopes of a nation, to a grandfather passing wisdom to the next generation, Josa’s story is one of service, resilience, and humour which is a living reminder of the sacrifices behind PNG’s independence.

Title: Pacific taste of the Australian dream goes up in smoke
Content: Honiara: Waltera Foxsiamanu was convinced he had a gold ticket to a better future after obtaining work in a Queensland abattoir as part of the Pacific-Australia Labour Mobility scheme. But when tragedy struck and his family home burnt down, the 32-year-old had to quit the job he’d held in Biloela for most of 2023 and rush back to Honiara to look after his mother. Cutting his stay in Australia short now means his path to resume the lucrative employment opportunity is blocked by red tape. Pacific Islanders can apply for a visa under the Palm scheme for stays up to four years, working in industries struggling with staff shortages especially in the agriculture sector. Due the interruption to his working visit, though, Foxsiamanu is stuck in limbo 2,000km away. As a cab driver, he still lives more among the haves than the have-nots within a subsistence economy that continues to use Malaitan shell-money as its traditional currency. Yet without a way to make it back to Biloela, he wonders for how long. There is a clear contrast between Solomon Islanders who can afford to build larger houses for their families due to their four years in Australia and those who have to crowd into smaller and often dilapidated ones, he says. “It’s really helped to change their life,” he said. “It’s so sad to see people just living in a small, tiny house, yeah, with no rooms, no place for the family to have dinner. “They just use the house for sleep.” Climate change has also had a notable impact on housing affordability in the Solomons, with some coastal dwellers with no choice but to uproot their lives and rebuild on higher ground on the outskirts of Honiara as sea levels relentlessly rise. Improved living standards in the predominantly Melanesian archipelagic nation is about more than just housing, with extra income often allowing families to pay higher school fees and buy better books to advance the education of their children. Poorer parents can still send their kids off to class “but they won’t go far”, Foxsiamanu laments. The more fortunate among Palm scheme workers can eventually return to various of nine participating Pacific Islands along with Timor-Lest, which is just 700km northwest of Darwin, with enough money to build a second house as a rental investment. Most of the significantly higher wages earned participating in the Australian-based arrangement is often sent home to support needy families. Without the extra income Foxsiamanu accumulated while employed in Australia, he wouldn’t be able to complete his rebuild. He says he was able to send back about AU$1,000 (about K2,715) week after deductions while he was part of the scheme, an amount that usually takes a Honiara cabbie three months to earn. His quest for a second shot isn’t hopeless but is an unlikely one for now. “It’s quite difficult, I really want to get back so I can complete the home,” he says. “When we get to Australia life seems to be easy then when we come back in the Solomon Islands, everything is quite difficult.” Australia is using the Palm scheme to spruik a better life for Solomon Islanders as it tries to build stronger people-to-people ties with its near neighbour during an era of increasing Chinese interest in the Pacific. The Solomons per-capita GDP of AU$600 (about K1,629) means it is ranked among the world’s least developed countries. Australia is one of its principal donors. Large billboards throughout Honiara promote the relationship, noting that it helped locals get jobs and support their families. However apparently well-received it is on the ground, though, Palm isn’t without criticism. United Nations special rapporteur Tomoya Obokata has singled out the scheme following a visit to Australia, saying workers are susceptible to modern slavery conditions. Strict rules about visas being tied to a single workplace also make people susceptible to abuse, he says. Workers who disengage from the scheme, where they leave their employer, “face the most significant risks of exploitation and contemporary forms of slavery”, according to his report. “The main issue among those schemes is that they create a significant power imbalance between employers and workers.” The rapporteur says he “received credible information from numerous stakeholders, including from workers themselves, revealing alarming and sometimes severe patterns of exploitation by employers, labour hire companies and migration agents”. Exploitative practices include underpayments, withheld wages, changing contracts, excessive deductions, racial discrimination, hazardous working conditions, harassment, sexual violence and being fired because of pregnancy. A tranche of briefing materials prepared for former federal employment minister Murray Watt about the scheme also reveals concerns around worker safety and treatment. Three critical car crashes in Queensland that involved the death of Pacific Islands labourers in Australia were listed under “sensitivities” in a brief prepared for Senator Watt’s meeting with Pacific high commissioners in Australia in December 2024. Addressing the safety of the visa holders while driving is a major area of concern for nations involved in the scheme. Employment Minister Amanda Rishworth says she is working with them to expand Palm and tackle issues such as disengagement. “Broadly, I get very positive feedback around the Palm scheme but of course, we’re always looking at how we refine it and improve it,” she said on Thursday. “We are working in an ongoing way with our Pacific Island country representative to look at how we can improve the scheme. “We’ll keep looking at how we can make the operation work well for both countries but importantly for the workers.” Source: AAP

Title: Hundreds of former immigration detainees to be deported
Content: Canberra: Hundreds of former immigration detainees will be deported to Nauru under a controversial deal that has secured bipartisan support. The pact will cost Australian taxpayers more than AU$400 million (about K1 billion) up front and then AU$70 million (about K190m) ongoing each year. It will allow Australia to transfer about 280 former detainees including convicted criminals to the tiny Pacific island, which has a population of about 12,000. Human rights groups and the Greens have condemned the agreement, which was signed by Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke. The deal impacts several hundred people known as the NZYQ cohort, who were released from custody following a landmark High Court ruling on indefinite detention. Shadow attorney-general Julian Leeser said it was a “legitimate arrangement”. “This cohort of people have had ample opportunities to put their case,” he told the ABC on Sunday. “They have exhausted all appeal avenues and the question now is whether they can be removed to another country.” Greens immigration spokesman David Shoebridge condemned the agreement. “This is another secret deal,” he said. “This time a $400 million secret deal, that Labor signed with Nauru to literally turn Nauru into a 21st century prison colony.” The federal government must pass legislation to allow for the removals. Cabinet minister Murray Watt wants to make progress as soon as possible. “It’s not the intention to send the entire cohort in one group,” he told Sky News. “The plan is to scale the number up and allow Nauru to put in place the systems that allow for the number to increase over time.” Senator Watt rejected suggestions Australia was dumping unwanted people including criminals on Nauru. “Nauru is an independent sovereign nation,” he said. “It can make its own decisions about what it wants to do, and the fact that they have reached that agreement with Australia does solve this issue.” Source: AAP

Title: Polewara says PNGDF ‘exists today’ because of 1975 walk
Content: DEFENCE Force Chief Rear-Admiral Philip Polewara says that the 1,200km walk in 1975 by soldiers from Wewak to Port Moresby is the reason why a defence force exists today. “That walk was to justify why Papua New Guinea needed a defence force on the eve of independence in 1975,” he said. “The pride and the defenders of the PNG constitution as we are today, standing tall and firm in our service to God, King and country.” To re-enact that 1975 walk, soldiers took part in the Antap Long Ol exercise which ended yesterday in Port Moresby. It was to deliver messages, reinforce military coordination and promote unity among the people. Polewara said that it was not only a test of endurance, discipline and teamwork but also a reminder of the spirit of resilience that defined the force and the nation. Yesterday around 4am, 19 soldiers from the Second Royal Pacific Islands Regiment, 23 from Engineering Battalion, 20 from the Long Range Reconnaissance Unit and 15 from the First Royal Pacific Island Regiment cheered each other as they arrived at Unagi Oval for a Freedom of City march to Parliament. Polewara thanked the soldiers who took part in the walk for demonstrating courage and commitment, showing that their efforts were a reminder that the strength of the defence force lay not only in training and equipment but also in the determination and character of each soldier. “They walked 1,200km through Mandi, Tring, Marienberg, Bogia, Madang, Dumpu, Wau, Garaina, and Tapini before reaching Port Moresby,” Polewara added. The exercise re-enacts the courageous trek by 15 men led by Lt Geoff Key in 1975 who walked from Moem to Port Moresby to deliver messages to the Chief Minister Michael Somare and the defence council.

Title: Young men walk, cycle to Port Moresby
Content: TWO groups of young men from Wewak in East Sepik have reached Port Moresby after walking and conducting awareness along the way about violence. One is made up of 14 cyclists. Another consists of 33 men who staged a walkathon. Walkathon chairman Jimex Buke said that it took them a month to reach Port Moresby. “We came as a youth group from Wewak to Madang, and did some awareness in Lae and Wau, then walked along the Bulldog track,” he said. “When we entered Gulf, we caught up with the First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment soldiers in Bereina. “We came (together) to (Port Moresby). It’s a first time for all of us.” Buke said that they were conducting awareness in the villages they passed to get the Government to register youths in their wards. “We’re saying no to all violence like wife bashing, child abuse and others,” he said. Buke said some of the cyclists travelled on the Highlands Highway and should come to Gulf and get a boat from Kikori. Of the 14 cyclists, three made it into Port Moresby with Buke and his team. Eleven were somewhere in Mt Hagen. Buke added that along the way, they saw how villagers lacked services such as airstrips. He urged the Government to pay attention to the Wau people. “We were new to the road and some place were dangerous or very cold. But we are safe here now,” Buke added. They were given food and water by villagers along the way. They gave the villagers whatever gifts they brought from Wewak.

Title: PM urges health professionals to improve in country’s health services
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has urged health professionals to improve the delivery of health services on the anniversaries of 50 years of national independence and 60 years of the medical society’s symposium. Marape told the symposium in Port Moresby yesterday that if there was one group of professionals who had left an indelible fingerprint in the country, it was those in the medical profession. “From community health workers in the most remote villages to surgeons in our hospitals, you have carried our country for the last 50 years,” he said. Marape described healthcare as a “right, not a privilege”. He recalled his own childhood in rural PNG, where he witnessed families lose children due to a lack of health services and capacity. “As a child, I saw my parents, especially my mother, weep for the loss of her children because basic healthcare was not available,” he said. While reaffirming the Government’s commitment to strengthening basic healthcare, Marape highlighted recent breakthroughs in specialist medical services, the first successful kidney transplant and heart bypass operation. He stressed that these achievements were made possible by teamwork between doctors, anaesthetists, nurses, researchers and technicians. The Prime Minister acknowledged the high cost of delivering world-class healthcare, especially in a country with competing priorities in education, infrastructure, and law and order. Marape said the long-term solution to sustaining healthcare lies in expanding PNG’s economy. He paid tribute to the late Professor Michael Alpers, describing him as one of the great contributors to PNG’s medical research. He also acknowledged the lifelong service of senior medical leaders including Professor Sir Isi Kevau, Professor Nakapi Tefuarani, and others.

Title: Government to split Alotau district before 2027 election
Content: THE Government plans to have a second district in Alotau by 2027, according to Prime Minister James Marape. “I want to give my commitment that a new district will be created out of Rabaraba by 2027,” he said. “This is a big step for Milne Bay province and Alotau district, which has long been one of the largest and most remote in the country. “The population has grown, and the geographic challenges demand that we decentralise government functions to better serve our people.” Marape explained that the new district would be created out of the vast Alotau district which is administratively challenging to manage. It is part of a plan to create five new districts around country by 2027 to improve service delivery. “This is not only for the new Rabaraba district, but also for the other four new districts that will be created under our 2027 decentralisation efforts,” Marape said. “Bringing government presence to the most remote parts of our country is a key part of the Pangu-led vision to empower our people at the grassroots level.” Marape urged leaders to begin preparing for the transition. “As we allocate resources to these districts, I ask all leaders to ensure they are spread for the greater good and used wisely to truly impact the lives of our people,” the Prime Minister said.

Title: Central city dream takes step forward
Content: THE long-awaited dream of giving Central its own identity took a major step forward with the first drawdown of K10,000 from the Central City Trust Fund. Under the leadership of Central Governor Rufina Peter, it marks the beginning of the Central city project. Walis Imbal, the provincial finance manager, said: “For too long, Central has not had a face, and I want to leave a legacy where Central has a face.” Imbal recalled the history of the trust fund at a ceremony attended by public servants from Finance and Treasury. “Because the funds remained dormant and unused, a new trust deed had to be issued by Finance,” Imbal said. “We then worked with the acting provincial administrator, Governor and the Finance Department. “We are glad that the Finance secretary approved access of the K27 million specially for the Central city development.” Deputy Finance secretary Tom Tiki said that the two major projects for Central were the Central City and the Central Hospital. Acting provincial administrator Edward Kila called on the administration to rally behind the Governor. “Money has sat there for 15 years and nothing has resulted,” he said. “Let’s use the funds for the purpose intended,” Kila said. Governor Rufina Peter revealed that one of her first tasks upon taking office in 2022 was to investigate the status of Central City. “I knew from my days in National Planning that there was a trust account with funds parked there. When I came in, I wrote quickly to Planning because K300,000 was outstanding to Snowy Mountain Engineering (SME) Company for an independent assessment of the Bautama site. “Despite writing three times with no response, we eventually funded the payment through the provincial executive council (PEC). “Once paid, SME released the report.” The drawdown of the K10,000 is for stationery and represents not just the start of physical works.

Title: Hwena is Miss Bird of Paradise – Sandaun
Content: VANIMO town came alive on Sunday night when hundreds of residents gathered to witness the crowning of the inaugural Miss PNG Bird of Paradise-Sandaun. Miss Vanimo Free Trade Zone Limited Carol Hwena was crowned as the first Miss PNG Bird of Paradise-Sandaun 2025-2026 after 50years by local MP and Tourism, Arts and Culture, Minister Belden Namah and Miss Bird of Paradise 2024-2025 May Hasola. Namah said this was the first time for the province to participate in such a pageant and called on all the people of West Sepik to support Hwena in her journey. “I am happy with this event and I would like to thank all the working committee, history is now created in Vanimo, Sandaun and West Sepik,” he said. “Let us all support the inaugural Miss Bird of Paradise Sandaun to be the next Bird of Paradise, Papua New Guinea.” “Let us take it from here to the next level. “Why not from Sankamap now and the next Bird of Paradise from Sandaun, let us all do it and let us all give the Inaugural Miss Bird of Paradise Sandaun all the moral support that she will need to showcase Sandaun’s art and culture and the Sandaun way,” he said. “Let us prove to the nation that we (Sandaun) as how the late Pope Francis had declared that we are the little Garden of Eden.” Miss Bewani Palm Oil Development Ltd Kristina Konie was the first runner-up and also received awards from various categories and Miss Selewen Sio Building Construction, Annie-Rose Wouwou was named the second runner-up. The other two contestants who participated in the pageant were Miss Golden Medallion Hotel Tia Nalaik and Miss Telefomin Natasha Fulieng. Hwena her maiden speech said she was humbled to be crowned as the first Miss Bird of Paradise Sandaun and was looking forward to representing the people of Sandaun. Chairman and founder of the PNG Miss Bird of Paradise Pageant Anna Bais said Sandaun would always walk in the right path and never go wrong as they uplifted their women as priority for them to achieve their life’s dreams and making it a reality.

Title: ‘Protect people, property and life’: Safety of residents a priority: Parkop
Content: THE safety and security of city residents and visitors are critical at this time of celebrations, says National Capital District (NCD) Governor Powes Parkop. “Police at all costs must protect the people, property and life between now and the two weeks leading up the country’s 50th independence celebrations,” he said. He said Port Moresby is the epicentre of the celebrations where the main activities will happen. Parkop addressed a short parade by police members from the NCD and Central command. This is the start of a two-week security operation to independence. The parade consisted of 680 members from Special Services Division, general police, policewomen, traffic, police dogs, reserves, Crime and Investigations Division and the police band. “The responsibility of making sure everything goes well rests on your shoulders as we will be having international visitors in the country before and by independence dates. “We have over the past weeks encountered ethnic clashes in the city and other crimes in the suburbs and you will have to ensure you are working nonstop to ensure we maintain peace during this time. “We know police response is not easy at this time when manpower is down, and some of you policemen and women have paid with your lives and that is equally same for the defence and Correctional Service members as well. But we need your commitment to ensure there is order,” he said. Among other events are the preparations for the Pacific Police Tattoo which will host police personnel from seven Pacific nations. Today, the city will host the United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres who will be visiting for four days before independence anniversary and prior to the General Assembly meeting in mid-September. Parkop announced that 100-plus Artificial Intelligence generated cameras will be installed enabling facial and clear footage of public and police conducting their duties. Assistant Commissioner of Police NCD and Central Command Benjamin Turi gave his assurance that with the limited manpower and resources, the police can still deliver an operation for the city and country.

Title: Turi wants enthusiasm from officers over next two weeks
Content: POLICE Assistant Commissioner National Capital District and Central Benjamin Turi says he expects no laziness from officers assigned to security operations over the next two weeks to anniversary day. “Starting today, we will work with all police station commanders to make sure the city is safe for everyone during the celebrations,” Turi said. “Despite having manpower down and with only 680 policemen and women and reservists assigned to security operations, that will not deter us from carrying out our security operations.” The NCD and Central command has assigned police members to the operations with checkpoints set up at venues and random police checks along suburbs day and night until Sept 17. Following an alcohol ban by the alcohol committee chairman John Kaupa, instructions have been given to police to search men and women for possession of alcohol. People or stores found to be still selling alcohol will be referred to the committee along with a statement and police have been warned not to tamper with the items. “Alcohol has been banned for the two weeks, so when you are patrolling settlements, stop and ask people where they are purchasing beer and confiscate all their items,” Turi said. “Those who defy the orders, will be referred to police and their licence will be removed by the committee. “Operational officers will take care of the security in suburbs and around the city, making sure that any little noise from any corner, we will quickly respond and no one is hurt. “All our internal security is taken care of by our traffic and the Dog Unit and Special Services Division members are doing their part in internal security of dignitaries. “For reservists working in government offices, if you are on your days off, we encourage you to put on your uniform and give us a hand,” he said. He said it was important for everyone to cooperate to ensure the operations are smooth with fewer people getting hurt and properties destroyed.

Title: Mutzing to host Markham’s celebrations
Content: PEOPLE from Morobe’s Markham will be celebrating the country’s 50th independence anniversary at the Mutzing Station from Sept 15- 17. Under the theme “Break Free”, a slogan carried since the start of the year, MP Koni Iguan explained that the theme calls on people to free themselves from laziness and take ownership of their own future. “Papua New Guinea gained independence 50 years ago, and we should not be saying ‘why should we celebrate when we are not seeing government services?’ “If the government did not give you this freedom 50 years ago, you wouldn’t be here living free and making your own choices,” Iguan said. “You were given freedom 50 years ago, but some of you chose to be lazy, and so you are living that poor life. “For Markham, we are trying to make this celebration a memorable one for our people so that they will have something to look back on.” The three-day programme has been carefully planned to highlight unity through faith, education, and culture. On Sept 15, churches will lead a combined fellowship to give thanks to God for his blessings upon the people and the nation. The official Independence programme on Sept 16 will be led by schools, featuring parades, student activities, and an independence address Iguan. The final day, Sept 17, will focus on cultural displays where children will have the opportunity to learn about traditional practices. “This is to bring up our culture to remind our children of their roots,” Iguan said. To prepare students, all schools in Markham are hosting mini-celebrations this week. The district authority has allocated K151,000 to 44 schools, including high schools, primary and tertiary institutions, to support their activities, excluding elementary schools. A police vehicle was also presented to the local police on the day to boost policing in the district and to ensure a safe celebration during the three days’ celebrations of independence.

Title: Councillor calls for better service delivery
Content: THE East New Britain government (ENBPG) has been urged to deliver basic government services to the rural community, especially the Bainings through its proposed ENB free trade zone. Qaqet Stewardship Council chairman Nicholas Leo issued this call recently in Kokopo. He called on the ENBPG to ensure the proposed East New Britain free trade zone delivers tangible services and benefits to rural communities, particularly in the Baining area. Leo acknowledged the recognition given to local voices in shaping the free trade zone policy, saying the concept offered potential to improve long-standing service delivery challenges. “We are celebrating 50 years of independence based on being a free country, but in terms of road access and connectivity, we still struggle,” he said. “We hope that this free trade zone concept will provide us with connectivity through road access in the next three years.” Leo stressed that the Baining people wanted to be included in the development, noting that areas such as Open Bay and Lassul had potential to become tourist hubs if supported by proper policies. He said this could also help address issues such as drug trafficking by creating regulated opportunities. While initially questioning the free trade zone concept, Leo said he now understood that local communities could still retain ownership of their resources, especially land. However, he warned of risks to culture and traditional practices if development was not carefully managed. Leo also raised concerns about the slow progress in establishing Baining as an electorate, despite its legal recognition. He urged the provincial government to begin preparations for the 2027 elections by recruiting staff for administrative roles and investing in basic infrastructure. “We would like to deliver our political voice in 2027,” he said. “That is where the concept will eventuate, on our land.”

Title: Defence Force land units deliver batons to minister
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Defence Force land units’ yesterday presented batons containing a goodwill independence message to Defence Minister Dr Billy Joseph at Parliament House to honour the past and affirm their commitment to the future. The message emphasises the unity, service, and dedication of the force, reaffirming its pledge of loyalty and commitment to the nation’s people, leaders and the Government, to stand united for years to come. The message concluded with the invocation; to God, King and the Country. Joseph said this walk of more than 1,200km was more than just a test of endurance. It was a profound enduring symbol of the military’s original promise to the nation. “In 1975, when a team of soldiers walked from Wewak to Port Moresby, they presented a message of loyalty to our founding father, Grand Chief Michael Somare,” he said. “They affirmed that the new nation of PNG would have its own Defence Force ready to defend its sovereignty and serve its people.” He said for five decades the force had been the guardian of PNG’s sovereignty and a pillar of identity. Joseph said the force was a tool of statecraft through which the Government could achieve its goals, whether it was providing humanitarian assistance, securing borders, or representing PNG on international peacekeeping missions. Soldiers from the First and Second Royal Pacific Islands Regiment, Engineering Battalion and the Long Range Reconnaissance took part in a 45-day walk, called theAntap Long Olexercise, that started at Moem Barracks, East Sepik on July 9. Director (land force preparations), Lt Col Donald Aisuk said the walk across rugged mountains, rivers and jungles in the first phase from Wewak to Madang took 11 days, covering 388km. “The second phase from Madang to Lae in 15 days covered 329km. The third by long range was the most demanding 275km from Lae to Wau across the Bulldog Track,” he said. The last phase was from Malalaua Station to Port Moresby, covering 220km in 11 days.

Title: Australia partnership backs rural power access
Content: AUTRALIA’S partnership is supporting Papua New Guinea’s efforts to expand access to electricity in rural Western communities. As part of the initiative, household solar lighting kits are being distributed and installed across four local-level government (LLG) area in South Fly: Morehead, Forecoast Kiwai, Oriomo Bituri and Fly Kiwai. By early next year, the programme aims to deliver and install more than 8,000 kits across in the district’s four LLG areas. Between May and August this year, the first 1,100 kits were installed in 29 communities in Morehead. Each kit includes a solar panel, three light-emitting diode (LED) lights, and a battery unit equipped with USB charging ports. The introduction of solar energy has been warmly received by the remote communities, providing a cleaner, more affordable and sustainable source of lighting for areas that previously had limited or no access to reliable electricity. Community chief of Morehead Station and Morehead High School chairman Thomas Sumari said the kits do more than provide a source of electricity. “I am grateful that this service has been rendered to my people,” he said. “Seeing their homes light up at night is a reminder of the positive changes that are underway in our region. “With these lights installed in households, our day students can study more effectively at night in the comfort of their homes.” The rollout of household solar lighting kits in South Fly is the result of a collaborative effort involving the Western Province Partnership, the provincial administration, LLG leaders, South Fly Rangers and local communities. These stakeholders are represented in a local steering committee chaired by South Fly administrator Wasewa Saebi. The South Fly Rangers are responsible for on-the-ground delivery and community engagement. They play a key role in ensuring that the project’s distribution criteria and objectives are clearly communicated and understood by all stakeholders. Australia is proud to partner PNG in its rural electrification programme, which aims to enhance daily lives by improving health services, enhancing education outcomes, and expanding economic opportunities in rural and remote areas across the country.

Title: Firm does first shipment of plastic bottles
Content: COCA-COLA Europacific Partners (CCEP) Papua New Guinea, as part of its long-term commitment to packaging sustainability, recently marked the first first shipment of polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic bottles out of Lae. This achievement was made possible through the PET Collection Campaign, led by CCEP in collaboration with Branis Recycling PNG with support from Coca-Cola Asean South Pacific. CCEP PNG sales and commercial director Tim Solly said addressing plastic waste and recycling challenges require collaboration between the industry, public sector and civil society. “We are excited to have shipped our first container out of Lae, and would like to remind residents to help keep our city clean by returning their plastic bottles for recycling,” Solly said. In May, the collection campaign expanded from Port Moresby into Lae which now enables Branis Recycling to collect, process the beverage bottles into flakes, and export from Lae. Lae residents can collect any PET plastic beverage bottle and deliver to the Branis collection site at Karimata Street or at Limki Street, Speedway. For every 1 kilogram collected, K1 will be paid. CCEP PNG will work with different groups in Papua New Guinea to significantly increase the amount of PET plastic beverage bottles collected in Lae and Port Moresby.

Title: Australia Navy ship arrives in Port Moresby
Content: Royal Australian Navy shipHMASChoulesarrived in Port Moresby on Saturday. The ship brought Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel to join the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF)  in celebrating PNG’s 50th Independence anniversary. The ADF named their support Operation “Wantaim”, commemorating the strong defence relationship between PNG and Australia. Chouleswill remain in Port Moresby until mid-September, providing accommodation and real-life support for Pacific partners from Fiji, New Zealand, Tonga and Vanuatu who are taking part in PNGDF Week and 50th anniversary celebrations. Chouleswill be participating in the Public Open Day for ship visits today (Sept 2). A second Royal Australian Navy ship,HMAS Childers, will join in the Multinational Fleet Review on Thursday. Led by the PNGDF, the ADF will also contribute personnel from the Australian army and Royal Australian Air Force to ceremonial and celebratory events, including air shows, ceremonial drill and artillery displays and military bands. Lead maritime planner for the PNGDF’s Joint Taskforce (JTF-50), Lieutenant Commander Laijah Anthony, said the anniversary celebrations is important to the PNGDF and the people of the country. Commander of the ADF contingent, Australian Army Lieutenant Colonel Simon Frewin, said the ADF is honoured to be in Port Moresby and is ready to support. “Our contribution to the celebrations is testament to the deep friendship and partnership between our two militaries, which is constantly increasing in breadth and integration,” Frewin said. Led by the PNGDF, the ADF are supporting the planning and delivery of PNGDF Week events:

Title: Three more pilots complete training for new aircraft
Content: AIR Niugini announced that three more pilots have completed their Airbus A220 type rating training, bringing the total to seven. Air Niugini has taken a proactive and strategic approach to preparing its workforce for the arrival of the A220. Captains Joachim Ortlauf, Paul Lohia and first officer Alipate Vasutoga underwent the training at the world-class Airbus facility in Mirabel, Canada. A statement from the airline said two additional groups are undertaking their training in Montreal. They are expected to finish the training by the end of this month. With six more courses planned for the remainder of the year, Air Niugini anticipates having 25 fully trained A220 pilots by year-end. The training momentum will continue into next year, ensuring a robust pipeline of qualified pilots ready to operate the new fleet. Air Niugini officer-in-charge and acting chief operating officer, captain Samiu Taufa, said the A220 is more than just a new addition to the fleet. “It is our first new, next-generation jet and captures the spirit of our nation and our aspirations for the future,” Taufa said. The arrival of the first A220 aircraft, registered P2-PGA and affectionately dubbed the “People’s Balus”, is scheduled for Sept 15 – perfectly timed to coincide with Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary.

Title: Soldiers end walk with handover of batons in Port Moresby
Content: THE Antap Long Ol exercise will end today with a Freedom of Entry march into Port Moresby by all soldiers who took part in the walk to hand over the batons to the Government to show the force’s commitment for the next 50 years. Lt-Col Donald Aisuk said the teams would walk to Murray Barracks to be received by Defence Force Chief Rear-Admiral Philip Polewara to end the exercise and open Military Week. The walk which began at Moem Barracks in Wewak on July 9 is part of the force’s contribution to commemorating the 50th independence anniversary. “We will go through Nine-Mile, Erima, and Gordon then to Unagi where the teams will be escorted by the band to the big roundabout after Vision City,” he said. “Then we head to Parliament House for the ceremony. “After that, they will walk to Murray Barracks.” The walk began in Moem with 19 Second Royal Pacific Islands Regiment soldiers. They handed over the letters to the Engineering Battalion soldiers in Madang. In Lae, they passed them on to the Long Range Reconnaissance unit. The batons were handed to the First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (1RPIR) unit over the weekend in Gulf for the walk to Taurama. Aisuk explained that the team’s major challenges were the weather and clean drinking water.

Title: Six Lae robbery suspects shot dead, two injured
Content: SIX thugs died, two were seriously injured while three escaped in a robbery gone wrong at a shop in Lae on Friday, police have confirmed. Lae metropolitan commander Chief Superintendent Chris Kunyanban said that one of the two injured receiving medical attention at Angau Hospital escaped later. Kunyanban said before robbing the shop, about 12 men pretending to be passengers hopped on a 15-seater bus and forced the driver to take them along the Okuk Highway outside Lae. “They held up the driver and the crew of the bus and took the bus back to Eriku where they held up the shop assistants and took a substantial amount of money, phone cards and other properties yet to be confirmed,” Kunyanban said. He said the suspects were chased by the police as they drove to Bundi Camp. Six of them were shot dead, two were badly injured and three fled. Police were able to retrieve all the weapons used by the criminals. Kunyanban said police would not hesitate to use lethal force in such incidents. Meanwhile, two men were injured when they tried to rob a store at Limki in Lae yesterday. Kunyanban said that he was awaiting a full report on that incident.

Title: Icac ordered to pay damages to Hulahau for breaching his human rights
Content: THE National Court has ordered the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) to pay damages to former chief migration officer (CMO) Stanis Hulahau for a breach of human rights. Judge David Cannings in Port Moresby on Friday declared that Hulahau was denied full protection of the law under Section 37 (1) of the Constitution by the actions of deputy commissioner Daniel Baulch and the ICAC team at his office on Jan 31, 2024. “The defendant, ICAC, being responsible for the actions of deputy commissioner Baulch and the ICAC team shall pay damages under Section 58 (2) to the plaintiff,” Judge Cannings ordered “The parties shall forthwith discuss the amount of damages that should be awarded to the plaintiff and the issue of costs of these proceedings, with a view to settlement of those issues.” The court heard that on Jan 31, 2024, a team from the ICAC led by Baulch entered the premises of the PNG Immigration and Citizenship Services Authority (ICSA). They went to the office of Hulalau to investigate an alleged corrupt conduct by him. They produced a letter headed “Request for information and things under Section 58 of the Organic Law on the ICAC”. And acting under that authority, inspected Hulahau’s office and removed 42 documents, a laptop, two mobile phones and a desktop computer. They took the documents and items to the ICAC office; the items were returned months later. Hulahau had given his resignation notice as CMO shortly before the event but was still occupying the office at that time. He filed legal proceedings against ICAC arguing that they had conducted an unlawful search seizure of documents, breaching his constitutional and human rights. The matter will return to court on Sept 12 for mention.

Title: Joint chiefs of staff reaffirm alliance and defence support
Content: PAPUA New Guinea Defence Force’s (PNGDF) Rear Admiral Philip Polewara during a two-day Chiefs of Defence conference in Hua Hin, Thailand met up with the United States (US) chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Dan Caine and Admiral Samuel Paparo, Commander of United States Indo-Pacific Command (USINDOPACOM) to reaffirm strong defence ties between the two countries. Polewara said the two countries would maintain peace, stability and security in the Indo-Pacific region. In a statement, he said the US indicated its willingness and commitment to support Papua New Guinea under the Defence Cooperation Agreement (2023) to build and enhance PNGDF capabilities, acknowledging PNG as a leader in the Pacific. This year’s conference is co-hosted by the US Indo-Pacific Command and the Royal Thai Armed Forces, bringing together senior military leaders from 29 nations. The conference carried the theme “Peace through Strength – Ensuring Security and Prosperity in the Indo-Pacific”. “It highlighted the importance of collaboration to address complex and evolving security challenges across the region,” he said.

Title: Governor General suggests establishment of veterans department
Content: GOVERNOR-General Sir Bob Dadae suggests a Department for Veterans Affairs be established to oversee the welfare of Papua New Guinea veterans once they leave active duty in the regiment and defence force for civilian life. Addressing veterans in Port Moresby on Saturday, Sir Bob said: “I also call upon the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (RPIR) and the Defence Force to undertake documenting critical events that happened from 1975 to 2025, capturing the events that shaped our military history. From the Liberation of Espiritu Santo to the State of Emergency in Bougainville and our role in Regional Peacekeeping. It is a sacred duty to ensure that the deeds of our soldiers are remembered, revered and passed on to future generations. “As Governor-General and Honorary Colonel of the RPIR, I am immensely proud of the service of the men and women of the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment, First and Second, based in Taurama Barracks in Port Moresby and Moem Barracks in Wewak, East Sepik. “Despite the many challenges encountered over the years, you have continued to stay true to your service and duty as proud members of the Royal Pacific Islands Regiment. “Along the way, we are grateful to have received support from our regional friends and partners from Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Japan, China, United Kingdom and United States. “We can learn from them and adapt where necessary to improve our capabilities to be more effective in our response and operations. “Protecting and defending our people, in the name of God, king and country, you, the RPIR, have demonstrated that the military is also about humanity and compassion. “Wear your uniform with pride and respect and always maintain and stay true to the values of the Regiment and the PNGDF.”

Title: Pomaleu: Time to take stock of projects delivered by the government
