Content: CHIEF Secretary Ivan Pomaleu says leaders should take stock of what has been done over the last 50 years in terms of project delivery and its challenges. “There are so many government-initiated projects that are listed but funding delays and project acquittals have been a critical downfall. That is why alignment is necessary at this time to ensure we overcome some of the challenges faced,” he said. Pomaleu stressed that the Organic Law gives us powers to makes laws and further define our characteristics. “However, there are different levels that should be open for effective and efficient implementation and checks on programme and projects. “What else must we do? Reform is a lifeblood of progress around the world where successful governments and organisations continually adapt to changing realties. We, too, must look critically and ask, how do we represent our people in a changing world? “We need to watch duplications at different structures of government. Over the years, the government has invested in health, education, infrastructure, law and order and economic development,” he said. Pomaleu said it has been observed that the Government must still find alignment and empower. Since Independence in 1975, the country has experimented with difference forms of decentralisation and the proposal from the Constitutional Law Reform Commission (CLRC) that never made it into the Constitution from 1972 to 1974. The 1976 Organic Law looked at integrating autonomy to provinces but it was the 1995 organic law that re-centralised many powers back to Waigani. In 2014, the District Development Authorities Act shifted resources to districts but created new institutional imbalances which caused confusion, hence the call for alignment by leaders. “Despite reforms, the intended reason of empowering provinces has not been fully realised, excessive re-centralisation continues to slow down service delivery as shown in our 22 provinces,” Pomaleu said. “Our people expect fairness, thus the services. It is the leaders, who are collectively responsible to respond to our stakeholders’ expectations. “When national policies are designed far from local authority’s realities, the results cause delays, confusion and disappointment, and this is not a reflection on our people but the systems that we have,” he said.

Title: Gulf Governor Sir Chris blames agencies for land issues
Content: GULF Governor Sir Christopher Haiveta says government line agencies play a key role in addressing land and people issues in support of the provincial governors’ move on decentralisation. “Lines agencies that are responsible have not done their job. Let’s say Lands on customary land matters, what have they done so far? They have to come and advise us on what is being done so far? “This information among key agencies such as Finance, and other sectors also play a key role in achieving this process. Provincial heads are all together trying to get things done, but who is forgetting us in this system at the national level? “Looking at the agenda items, there is so much work in progress, so what is this? And who is going to address us on this. We should be focusing on the problems that we are facing now and that is the lack of funding from the Government,” he said. He said Gulf has not received funding for almost three months and has hindered so much development and work. The governor’s conference, held on Friday, convened a day after the provincial administrators’ conference. Much of the discussions fell on a proposed new provincial government and on previous three proposed organic laws and how line agencies play a part in contributing to a new system of governance. The current system used promotes less independence with provincial administration still being very dependent on government budgeted District Support Investment Programme (DSIP) and Provincial Service Improvement Programme (PSIP). “Don’t talk about bringing in another system, and just hope that it will fix our existing problems. We have a system that’s already in place and so let’s fix the system,” he said. Sir Haiveta made reference to Enga Governor Sir Peter Ipatas call for a check on what system was in place and focused on what was currently working to ensure decentralisation of powers and responsibility was achieved by the provincial governments.

Title: Kiwi recognised for outstanding service to PNG
Content: WHEN squadron leader Chris George of the Royal New Zealand Air Force (RNZAF) took up his posting to Papua New Guinea in 1986, he knew the mission would be unlike any other in his career. In recognition of his outstanding service and dedication, George was presented with a commendation award by the Deputy Chief of PNGDF Brig-Gen Lari Opa last week. He served for three years (1986-1989) with the PNG Air Transport Wing in Lae, Morobe, a role that demanded not only aviation expertise but also patience and an enduring commitment to partnership. George became known, not only for his professional skills but also his ability to train, mentor and encourage young Papua New Guinean airmen. His focus was always on capacity building: ensuring that the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) Air Transport Wing developed the capability to stand independently and serve the needs of its people. Looking back, George’s time in Lae highlights the often unseen side of military service; quiet, patient work that builds institutions, strengthens relationships and leaves lasting impacts long after deployments. For him, the posting was not just about aircraft or operations, it was about people, community and cooperation. “There is always a connection with the Christchurch residents and young people, including married Kiwi men who became involved in PNG projects, this involvement created a cultural association and change of experiences,” he said. George highlighted one of the most common skill exchange practices which they did every time apart from his normal aviation duties. “I recall, boat building activities, the focus is on creating boats which were significant both culturally and practically, skills imparted during this activity included traditional and modern boat building techniques,” he said. George also valued the part of storytelling while doing work. He recalled: “Story telling was an integral part of the learning process while building boats, these approach allowed skills to be shared and preserved between the traditional canoe and the more modern fiber glass boats.” Today, George RNZAF is remembered by his colleagues in PNG and New Zealand as a professional who gave his utmost in service of two nations’ shared interest. His commendation is a fitting tribute to a career marked by dedication, leadership and humility.

Title: NCDC to link up CCTV cameras at 80 sites around nation’s capital
Content: NINETEEN closed circuit television cameras (CCTV) have been connected around the city to cover 80 sites during the independence celebrations in the National Capital District (NCD). NCD Governor Powes Parkop said by Friday, they should have the other cameras connected to reach 96 cameras across the city. These cameras will create profiles using artificial intelligence (AI) of wanted persons in the city, making it easier for police to track them down at the command and control centre at Four-Mile. “Some of the hotspots will come on the screens that will be monitored by police and other specialists back up artificial intelligence,” Parkop said. “It has no full capacity yet but if there’s a need, we will have more screens. “These screens are enough, the AI will be watching all sites, shifting the cameras to the site that needs immediate attention for facial identification.” Parkop said these all were covered by the National Government funding of K15 million plus K5 million from NCD Commission to improve safety and security. He said that in addition to what they would be installing were cameras from the PNG China Association during the time of Assistant Police Commissioner Anthony Wagambie Jr. “There are a more than 100 cameras already covering Erima, Gordon, Waigani, Boroko, Sabama, Koki and some other parts of the city,” he said. “More than 100 were already in place but they did not have a command and control centre, we will link all of them before Sept 16. “We’re trying to fast track procuring process. “Procuring the cameras and the software and hardware from China and is taking a bit of time but the basic equipment are already here.” Since it’s powered, they (NCDC) are also looking for alternatives to have a standby generator or solar to support the screens when the power supply goes off. These initiative will be supported by a rapid response unit with six new vehicles recently donated by NCDC. Assistant Police Commissioner NCD and Central Benjamin Turi said that these cameras and what they were doing were for the people. “The number of regular police is about 600 and you minus 100 from that for administration and we’re left with 500,” he said. “There are 461 officers in the country that are about to retire and a quarter of that is in Port Moresby. “We’re planning on having all the police officers learn to drive and having every sector have a rapid response unit to respond to clashes in the city.”

Title: PM apologises to Karamui for road delays
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape has apologised to the people of Karamui, Chimbu, for delays in road development and reaffirmed the Government’s commitment to delivering road connectivity under the national Connect PNG programme. He acknowledged that despite previous allocations in 2020, 2021 and 2022, the Karamui road project had not progressed as expected. “We did allocate funds for your road in past years and I have now directed the Works and Highways Department to investigate what has happened to those allocations,” he said. Marape stressed that while other roads across the country had seen continued progress – including Kikori to Mt Hagen, Telefomin to Tabubil and the current drive from Port Moresby to Alotau – Karamui has faced setbacks due to disagreements over routing and competing priorities at provincial and district levels. “We have misfired on this road. “Different preferences on routes have caused delays. I have now instructed the Works and Highways Department to select the best and most direct route into Karamui without further interference. The Government will deliver this road,” Marape said. He emphasised his personal connection to remote communities, recalling his own childhood experiences. “As a child who grew up in remote Papua New Guinea, I understand the pain of isolation. I remember my own mother crying when she lost children in those difficult conditions, with no access to health services or roads. I was only six years old when I saw her bury my baby sibling at Oksapmin. “These experiences shaped me, and they remain with me to this day. “That is why I know the struggles of Karamui and other remote places — and why I give you my fullest commitment that Karamui will not be left behind,” he said. He said communities such as Karamui, Oksapmin, Middle Ramu, Simbai, Maramuni, Kabwum, Rai Coast, Kandrian, Kaintiba, and many others are among the remotest parts of the country still waiting for access, but Connect PNG is designed to change this. “Through Connect PNG we are fixing this. This programme is not just about my government, but about every government that will follow. “It is a 20-year programme, step-by-step, kilometre-by-kilometre — building roads, jetties, ports, and airstrips to connect the unconnected and reach the unreached. “Our mission is clear: no part of PNG remain cut off,” he said. He also pointed to progress at Kaintiba, recalling his earlier visit there in 2020 when the people cried and pleaded for a road. “Today, I am proud that heavy machines are already at Kaintiba, building the road. Just as Kaintiba has now been reached, just as Telefomin has been reached, and just as we can now drive from Port Moresby to Alotau, or from Kikori to Mount Hagen — so too will Karamui be reached,” he said. Marape further appealed to all leaders in Chimbu to allow the national Government to implement the main road corridor to Karamui, while supporting smaller feeder roads separately. “Enough is enough. “Let us work together for the people. Karamui must be unlocked and my government will not rest until that is achieved.

Title: Goroka traffic police get boost with new vehicle
Content: Goroka traffic police were presented with a new vehicle on Friday by the Goroka Development Authority. Goroka MP Aiye Tambua when presenting the vehicle, said the police traffic section had a big task, with the town facing an influx of taxis and defective vehicles. “With the new vehicle, officers can monitor and control traffic in the town and also outer areas in Goroka,” he said. He told police officers, including provincial police commander Chief Supt John Kale, that the authority had a plan to build a separate traffic office. “We are looking for land to set up the traffic unit to enable them to store impounded vehicles,” Tambua said. He also presented K80,000 to Goroka police for the 50th anniversary celebrations and Goroka Show special operations. Kale thanked Tambua and the authority for the continued support towards Goroka police. Officer-in-charge (traffic) Senior Insp Josephine Kumai, in her response, said: “Thank you for coming to our support with the new vehicle. “This puts an end to our days of requesting other sections of the police for vehicle support for us to attend to traffic cases.” She said 95 per cent of vehicles in Goroka are defective and not roadworthy, but tracking them had been difficult and a vehicle was what they needed. Kumai said the new vehicle will empower them to effectively pursue traffic offenders and make arrests.

Title: Islanders get copra weighbridge
Content: THE people of Rabaul’s Watom Island in East New Britain are set to benefit from a new copra weighbridge. The weighbridge is expected to ease the struggles they have long faced in transporting and selling their copra on the mainland. The facility, which also served as a cocoa buying point, was opened during the same event as the launch of the new Watom Island Beach Resort. For years, islanders have relied solely on boats to travel to the mainland to sell their copra, often risking their lives at sea and spending large sums on transport costs. The new facility now provides a safer and closer option for selling their produce. The weighbridge is owned by Daniel Tolulu and January Daniel, who said the initiative was driven by their desire to support their community. “We have a heart for our people. “Even though we struggle at times, we are doing this for the benefit of the people of Watom Island,” Daniel said. She explained that in the past, copra was weighed using a hanging scale, but with the upgrade to a weighbridge, farmers on the island now have access to more accurate and efficient measurements. Daniel also highlighted the difficulties previously faced by herself and her husband, including late travel by boat to the mainland. In some cases, they arrive late after the Coconut Products Limited (CPL) office had already closed, forcing them to sleep at the beach until the next day. Another common challenge was fuel shortages. When boats ran out of fuel and fuel stations were closed, they were often stranded overnight on the mainland. The weighbridge, located at Nabil village in Vunakabi, Watom, is the only one of its kind on the island.

Title: One-day polling for Bougainville and five provinces
Content: A ONE-DAY polling period will be held for the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (Arob) general election and five other provinces on Thursday. Bougainville electoral commissioner Desmond Tsianai said: “I would like to once again remind every eligible voter in Bougainville and those who are residing in the National Capital District, Morobe, East New Britain, Eastern Highlands, and Madang, that polling for the fifth Arob general election will be conducted on a single day, Thursday, Sept 4. “I also take this time to regrettably advise Bougainvilleans living and working in other provinces in Papua New Guinea apart from the five provinces that due to funding limitations, polling will not be conducted in other provinces of PNG. “We sincerely regret any inconvenience this may cause and encourage all eligible voters in the above-mentioned provinces and in Bougainville to participate actively in this important democratic process. “On that note, I urge all Bougainvilleans, both in the private and public sectors within the region, to adhere to the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) circular instruction dated, Aug 25, 2025, from the Office of the ABG Chief Secretary and make available sufficient time to participate in the polling process.” Meanwhile, Tsianai said his office had finalised a comprehensive electoral roll update to be used during the election. “Through months of careful work, Office od the Bougainville Electoral Commission has partnered with community governments, ward recorders, schools, and citizens to deliver what is now regarded as the most accurate and transparent roll in PNG. “Bougainvilleans should feel proud of this achievement, which sets a new standard for electoral preparedness. “This is the best electoral roll in PNG. “Every ward and community has had a chance to take ownership of their roll, check their names, and raise concerns.”

Title: K340 million port for WNB
Content: PNG Ports Corporation Limited (PNG Ports) will be delivering a ‘climate change resilient’ K340 million port to the people of West New Britain. This will also bring more than 300 immediate jobs, spin-off benefits for the locals, and multiple future business opportunities. During a ground-breaking ceremony on Friday, PNG Ports chairman Harvey Nii said this significant investment was for the people of West New Britain who housed Kimbe Port – PNG Ports’ third busiest port. Nii explained that the 16-month project would see the existing port undergo “major marine and land rehabilitation works” to increase cargo volumes and vessel traffic by 2027. He said upon completion, the upgraded port infrastructure will be climate resilient, with the incorporation of climate change, disaster resilience and social inclusion in the project design. The Kimbe Port is critical to the growth of the New Guinea Islands. Last year, 252 vessels were received at the port, with a throughput of over 450,000 revenue tonnages, much of this is attributed to the trade of crude oil palm, cocoa, vanilla, copra, fish and logging. State Enterprises Minister William Duma said this crucial project marked a “transformative chapter” for the province. “We must remind ourselves that we are not merely launching a construction project, we are laying the foundation for enhanced connectivity, stronger national unity, and sustainable prosperity for generations to come,” Duma said. “As our country marks 50 years of independence, it is a moment for all of us to reflect on our achievements, acknowledge all the obstacles we had to overcome over the years, and renew our commitment to building a new future for our children and our grandchildren.” The project is being funded by the Australian Government through the Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific (AIFFP). Australian high commissioner Ewen McDonald was also in the province to co-officiate during the event with Duma, witnessed by provincial parliamentary leaders, AIFFP head Jonathan Kenna, government departmental heads, and leaders of traditional landowner groups. McDonald said: “The PNG Australia relationship is a relationship between family. “Our modern day relationship is about supporting conditions for economic prosperity. “We’re investing in high quality, sustainable infrastructure. “Investments in roads, ports, power and telecommunications are all fundamental for creating an environment where businesses can thrive, and communities can prosper.” The project has been divided into the land and marine component, with Global Constructions Limited and Pacific Marine Group to carry these out respectively.

Title: ‘We walked to show our commitment’: Ex-sergeant Malulu recalls walk in 1975
Content: EXERCISE Antap Long Olfrom Moem Barracks to Taurama Barracks in Port Moresby in 1975 was to demonstrate the Papua New Guinea Defence Force’s commitment to serving and protecting the country and its people as it transitioned to Independence – and after. A group of 16 soldiers embarked on a 1,200km-walk led by Lt Geoffrey Key and took 64 days to arrive at Taurama. Private Kenny Malulu, then 24, from Northern’s Biage village in the Kokoda Local Level Government was part of that historic journey. Now 74, Malulu vividly recalls the journey. “We were given messages placed nicely in envelopes and were given clear instructions to pass it on,” he said. “We were told to live off the land. “We had no idea of the content. “At that time, it was approved that chief minister Michael Somare be the Prime Minister. “Our bosses at Moem wrote letters to support the decision. “We walked (carrying the) letters to show our commitment. “Announcements were made through the radio about the walk and people were asked to provide us rations along the way.” Malulu said that they went past Brandi then took a short-cut to Murik Lake and then to Angoram where they got on two dinghies to cross the Sepik River. They faced rugged terrain and unpredictable weather, but their camaraderie and determination kept them going. The team overnighted across the river and set off the next day to Ramu in Madang. They took on a canoe to take them across the river to Bogia. “We followed the beach all the way to Bogia station and overnighted at a school,” Malulu said. “In the morning, we left Bogia and walked the highway till we reached Madang town around 5.30am. “We went to the police barracks to rest.” They left Madang along the highway and rested for two nights. On the third night, they rested near the Highlands highway. Of the 15, three were married. Malulu and his other friends were single at that time. They were ready for such an adventure to prove that the country has a strong army. “It was lovely meeting people along the way who were so proud to see us and offered us shelter and food. One of the challenges was finding clean drinking water. Drivers along the highway offered to help but Key said no.” The name “Antap Long Ol” described how soldiers crossed provinces to get into Port Moresby. The team included Key, Sgt Guwa and Corporal Sisi all from Finschhafen in Morobe, Malulu, Cpl Meck from Western Highlands, Cpl Gabby Kamberan from Enga, Signaler, Cpl Angora from Northern, Private Josah, Private Hulana from Central, Assistant Signaler, Private Maru from Gulf, Private Andrew Tai from Western Highlands, Private Tobly, Private Yama from East Sepik, Private Mon from Morobe, Private Felix Wama from East Sepik and Private Diga Koai from Gulf who had an injury.

Title: Central bank launches commemorative banknote and coin
Content: THE Bank of Papua New Guinea (BPNG) yesterday marked a historic double milestone, the nation’s 50th Anniversary of Independence and 50 years of its own national currency, with the launch of a commemorative K50 banknote and 50t coin. BPNG Assistant Governor for Currency and branch operations Ron Sikar said 20 million pieces of the new K50 banknotes and 2.5 million pieces of the new 50t coin have already been received by the banks. Governor Elizabeth Genia led the ceremony in the presence of Prime Minister James Marape, Foreign Affairs Minister Justin Tkatchenko, members of the Government, representatives of the business and diplomatic communities, and family members of the nation’s founding leaders. “Papua New Guineans will see the new currency in circulation,” Genia said. “The K50 note retains Parliament House, continues to honour Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare and carries the golden 50th Anniversary emblem with the Raggiana Bird of Paradise in flight, symbolising the nation’s future. “The 50t coin keeps its iconic seven-sided shape and crest, now joined by a coloured inlay of the PNG flag, representing unity and progress.” Genia paid tribute to the late Grand Chief, describing his legacy as a guiding presence throughout the anniversary celebrations. She also acknowledged the late Sir Julius Chan, who as Finance Minister in 1975 drove the establishment of the Kina and Toea, and the late Sir Henry ToRobert, the nation’s first Central Bank Governor, who guided the transition with professionalism and authority. She said next year, the BPNG would issue a redesigned K100 note featuring Sir Julius. “The new design celebrates our currency history and trading spirit, a fitting recognition of Sir Julius as our first finance minister and as a nation-builder who placed PNG in the world.” Genia recalled that the introduction of the kina and toea in 1975 was a national education campaign in itself. Booklets and posters were distributed in English, Tok Pisin and Hiri Motu. Radio and press campaigns explained the denominations and designs. And banks trained their staff with specimen notes. To ease the transition, the Kina was set equal in value to the Australian dollar and both currencies circulated side by side until the end of 1975. Farmers and smallholders were initially cautious, but confidence grew quickly as the Kina and Toea became embedded in daily life. “Fifty years ago, the notes and coins represented the first heartbeats of our nation. Today they are the backbone of our economy,” Genia said. The names themselves – Kina (pearl shell) and Toea (small trade shell) – reflected ancient systems of value and exchange. “By choosing these names, our leaders embedded culture into the heart of our economy. Every Kina and Toea carries our heritage into the modern economy,” she said. Genia reaffirmed BPNG’s focus. “We will sustain price stability, manage exchange rates responsibly and expand access to financial services to all Papua New Guineans. “This is not just economic housekeeping. It is the unfinished business of independence. “From now on, may every Kina and Toea carry our pride and our promise.” The commemorative K50 note and 50t coin will circulate alongside existing designs for many years to come.
People: James Marape, Julius Chan, Justin Tkatchenko, Michael Somare, Sir Julius Chan

Title: K340 million Kimbe port upgrade to boost business, Duma says
Content: A K340 million Kimbe port upgrade is expected to boost economic activities and create additional job opportunities for locals in Oil Palm rich West New Britain. Governor Sasindran Muthuvel said the port “has long been under strain” due to increased agriculture and fisheries activities. State Enterprises Minister William Duma acknowledged the support of the Australian government. Duma said: “The rehabilitation of Kimbe Port will enable safer, more efficient shipping, reinforce critical industries like oil palm and fisheries and open doors for local entrepreneurs and communities. “We’re especially grateful to the government and Australian people whose partnership continues to lift our development. “This project is part of a broader A$621.4 million (K1.7 billion) investment from the Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific (AIFFP). “There are two components of the upgrade. The marine component will cost K260 million and the land component will cost K79 million – K339 million in total.” Duma told the project contractors, Pacific Marine Group and Global Constructions to deliver this project on time, to the highest standards and in harmony with local communities and the environment.

Title: Government still resisting push for decentralisation of powers: Minister
Content: THE Government continues to control funding and decision-making from Waigani, despite its intention for decentralisation, an official says. Local Level Government and Provincial Affairs Minister Soroe Eoe said the key issue is to do with the centralisation of powers, despite three prior proposals for decentralisation. “Provinces remain dependent on national MPs and on district (DSIP) and provincial service improvement programmes (PSIP) funding mechanism, undermining the independence of local governments,” he said. He said this at the 2025 provincial administrators’ conference yesterday in Port Moresby. The dialogue among all administrators was for greater power and functions transfer to the provinces in a bid to accelerate improved service delivery to the people. Eoe referenced three proposed organic laws: “This assessment provides a new task for a newlook provincial government system that aligns with national priorities and aspirations, so for now, where have we gone wrong and where do we want to be in the next 50 years?” Eoe said “Performing the 1995 organic law is critical for governance and development because the current system has significant weaknesses that hinder effective service delivery and accountability. “The proposed reform aimed to rebalance physical power and grant provinces physical autonomy to govern themselves “There is overlap and confusion in service delivery, with the creation of the district development authority Act. This has caused overlapping roles and confusion between national, province and local level governments, thus leading to inefficiencies and wasted resources,” he said. “Proposed reforms seek to clarify responsibilities and streamline government structures and change in development demands. “The population has grown rapidly and development challenges have become increasingly complex and the current organic law is inadequate to these modern realities. “Proposed reforms aim to empower provinces to grow their economies and meet the demands of development. “The reforms aren’t simply about shifting the powers on pages, we are about creating a culture of responsibility and shared leadership.” He said decentralisation was the way forward to empower provinces to grow their own economies, strengthen their institutions and build resilient communities.

Title: Marat emphasises importance of laws
Content: CONSTITUTIONAL amendments and law reforms for the country must be done with serious consideration and not on an ad hoc basis, Rabaul MP Dr Allan Marat says. Speaking at the Constitutional and Law Reform Commission (CLRC) open day at the University of Papua New Guinea in Port Moresby yesterday, Marat said laws were meant to be made for the benefit of the people and not for personal gain. “Making laws for the country is very important but a difficult process that needs to be carefully considered,” he said. “It is never a clear-cut matter as we cannot pick and choose which laws to change as changing one can lead to other inter-related issues. “That is why proper consultations and debates must be held before they can be legislated. “Debates can be held inside or outside Parliament so that we can all come to an agreement. “We must be able to talk about what has worked and what has failed in respect to the Constitution and other laws before any changes can be made. “That is healthy for our democracy to thrive,” he said. Marat, a five-term MP involved in various roles, including being a former CLRC chairman, said that the commission provided a platform for people to use if they ever needed to share their views on the country’s laws. He said that the people had a responsibility to the development of the nation and should not always depend on leaders to do so. “There are many problems in the country today. “Our forefathers intended and hoped for everyone in the country to be prosperous. “Sadly, we are still struggling to achieve those goals and objectives they had set out. “The people must make a commitment and effort to develop the country to become more prosperous,” Marat said. He urged Papua New Guineans to understand and follow the five national goals and directive principles in the Constitution so as to develop the country for the better. They are: “They are what we can use to develop the nation,” Marat said. “All we need to do is follow it for the next 50 years.”

Title: More incentives for doctors serving in rural areas
Content: DOCTORS who are serving the rural health centres and hospitals will now be able to receive the rural incentives for the first time. This was made possible through the signing of the memorandum of agreement (MoA) 2025 to 2027 for the Determination of Salaries & Allowances of Doctors between the Department of Personnel Management (DPM), National Department of Health and National Doctors Association yesterday in Port Moresby. DPM secretary Taies Sansan said the rural incentive allowance of K100, 000 per annum will be awarded to ensure national medical doctors were employed in rural hospitals and health facilities While acknowledging the doctors’ work in the health sector and their understanding and professionalism in terms of the MoA, Sansan said: “This MoA 2025-2027 is a reflection of the government shared commitment to advance the welfare of doctors and, by extension, to strengthen thehealth system in Papua New Guinea.” She added that this agreement outlined clear provisions for terms and conditions of employment and it also reaffirmed the responsibility of the State to support and resource the doctors so that they were better positioned to serve citizens. Sansan said through the MoA 2025-2027, doctors would see: Sansan said that for the first time, the rural incentives allowance had been inserted in the agreement as the recognition from the government acknowledging the challenges faced by doctors working in difficult environments with limited resources. She encouraged implementing agencies and provincial health authorities to support and implement this MoA.

Title: Former teacher returns to PNG, will attend a cultural event
Content: A FORMER teacher who has contributed more than 50 years to the success of St Ignatius Secondary School in West Sepik has returned to celebrate in a cultural event to be held next month. Frank Evans, 85, and from Brisbane in Australia, initially worked as a pharmacist before taking up missionary work in Aitape in West Sepik in 1974. He worked as an arts teacher. After being away for two years due to illness, he has returned to partake in the school’s event as part of celebrating the country’s golden jubilee. “Most students would probably remember that I was very strict and I think that’s one thing that added to the success of the school. “I did not accept anybody breaking rules and there was a notice as you enter St Ignatius, saying ‘no alcohol, no drugs and no boy girl relationships’, and when you broke all three or any one of them, you were automatically out and there was no second chance. “At the stage, there were 320 and 80 girls and we decided we were going to change that. When I came, there were 15 expatriate teachers and one national teacher. “Before independence came, there were a lot of changes and most of the expatriate teachers went home. I remained and became headmaster in 1978 and having graduated my ex-students in Dorothy Tekwie in 1975 from Grade 10. She was among one of the top 10 students who were all girls,” he said. Among those Evans mentored who became successful were late Bernadette Ove, Patrick Pruaitch, late Andrew Kumbakor, John Tekwie, Dorothy Tekwie, and Supreme Court Judge Collin Makail, among many others who became lawyers, doctors, teachers and other professionals. It was in 1984 that Evans decided to combine the boys and girls’ campus after St Ignatius Secondary topped the country, with Marianville in second place in 1983. “People could not believe this rural place was achieving so high and over the years, it has maintained that status of excellence. Today, there are more than 800 students. “There has been such an improvement over the years. “I am quite amazed at the progress the school has made and we got some really outstanding students who have shown their abilities such as getting scholarships and pursuing their studies,” he said. Evans flew to Wewak yesterday, and will travel by road to Aitape for the school event. He returns to Australia in November.

Title: Safe house managers identify strategies to support victims
Content: SAFE houses are vital community-based refuges offering temporary accommodation and recovery support for women and children. Through the Australia-Papua New Guinea Law and Justice Partnership, numerous safe houses in the country were given grants under the Community Justice Fund (APLJ CJF) to ensure continuity in their role in the referral pathways network of services that help survivors access justice and holistic care. As part of this support, a learning event was held recently in Port Moresby, bringing together safe house operators, civil society organisations, advocates, and the GBV Secretariat to identify practical strategies for improving support to survivors of GBV, including Sorcery Accusation-Related Violence (Sarv). Participants included safe house service providers from the National Capital District (NCD), Enga, Madang and representatives from the GBV Secretariat. Despite their importance, many safe houses operate under challenging conditions with limited resources. Presentations highlighted findings from the GBV Secretariat’s recent national mapping of safe house services and shared insights from three APLJ CJF grant partners trialling a rapid response fund for emergency and priority needs. Group discussions focused on: “This event gave us a space to talk openly about what’s working and where we face challenges,” said one safe house managers. “Meeting others working in this space reminded me that I am not alone.” The GBV Secretariat gave an update to participants on the efforts to develop minimum standards for safe houses, aiming to improve the quality and consistency of GBV support services. “The mapping exercise is a step forward,” the spokesperson said. “It encourages safe houses to adopt standard operating procedures and policies that strengthen their work. “Safe houses are the first and most important partner in the referral pathway.” This learning event is the first in a planned series designed to bring together frontline law and justice champions to co-create local solutions to local challenges. Participants from safe houses who attend the learning event.

Title: Sohe lacks infrastructure development, MP says
Content: SOHE MP Henry Amuli says service delivery, particularly infrastructure development, has been lacking for the people of his district for years. During a recent inspection of building materials in Port Moresby for four major infrastructure projects in the district, Amuli, the district development authority (DDA), of which he is chairman, would support them with K3.5 million. The building materials inspected were for the Kokoda High School four-in-one double classroom and administration office (K1 million), Kokoda Police Barracks and ablution block (K1 million), Magurie community health aid post (K500,000) and solar lights under the Sohe rural housing scheme (K1 million). Following the inspection, the payments would be made to the suppliers to prepare for the shipment of the materials to Oro Bay in Northern, and then onward to the respective project sites for construction. Amuli said that he was satisfied with the progress and reaffirmed his administration’s commitment of the projects with the use of the district services improvement programme (DSIP) funds of the DDA. “While the need for service delivery in Sohe is huge, the resources available to Government are limited,” he said. “The little DSIP funds we receive from the Government must be put to effective use to deliver maximum benefit for our people. “Sohe DDA is ensuring that every Kina is spent wisely to achieve value for money. “Our priority focus remains on critical services – schools, health, roads, and law and order – to improve the quality of life for our constituents.” Acting district chief executive officer Albert Bogembo commended the DDA board for approving the crucial infrastructure projects and assured that the administration team would have them completed.

Title: Training aims to help communities prevent violence
Content: THE Madang Archdiocese has taken a step in the fight against gender-based violence (GBV) and sorcery accusation-related violence (Sarv) by hosting a week-long workshop aimed at empowering local communities. Held at the Migiar Pastoral Centre, the event brought together nearly 50 representatives from Catholic parishes, alongside with members of the Foursquare church, village court magistrates and the community policing unit. A statement from the Melanesian Institute said the initiative, a collaboration between the archdiocese, its development arm Diocesan Caritas, and the Grassroots Community Advocacy (GCA) Sumkar team, provided a forum for participants to share experiences and discuss strategies on how to prevent violence. Attendees from the districts of Madang, Bogia, Sumkar and Usino-Bundi engaged in dynamic discussions, focusing on how to de-escalate conflicts before they turned violent. A key theme of the workshop was the integration of faith-based principles into conflict resolution. Participants were encouraged to prioritise spiritual values over emotional responses during family disputes, fostering a collective dedication to ensuring respect and safety for everyone in the community. The sessions were facilitated by the the Grassroots Community Advocacy, with support from the Centre of Hope Safe House and the Melanesian Institute. The workshop equipped attendees with practical knowledge and tools to take back to their communities and implement change. Organisers recognised Father Eugene Grengary, Sr Techla, and Leo Yat for their leadership. The collaborative effort highlighted a unified commitment to combating violence and promoting a culture of respect and safety throughout Madang.

Title: Miss Western contestant seeking sponsors
Content: A CONTESTANT of the Miss Bird of Paradise Western Pageant is seeking sponsorship to register for the pageant which will be held early next month. Sophie Yasa, 23, from Western, Gulf and Eastern Highlands, was selected to contest amongst nine other contestants for the title of Miss Western. The event will be held on Sept 6 in Daru. Campaign manager James Mapo said since the shortlist came out last month, his team was yet to put in a registration of K5,000. “So far, we have sent letters to business houses in Daru, but we are still waiting for their responses,” Mapo said. “We have less than two weeks before the contest.” So far, the owner of a local business called A&A consultants, Theresa Aia, had stepped in to help cover for the wardrobe and makeup for Yasa. Yasa, in her appeal, said she was born and raised in Daru, and it was education that brought her out to Port Moresby in 2022. “Joining a beauty pageant is not all about beauty or having some talent. “For me, it’s about using the platform to help address social issues that I have witnessed my whole life growing up on the island and in Western,” she said. “This is an opportunity for me to be a role model for other women in the province who are suppressed every day by social issues and culture norms also. We want people to see change in different views and one is through such events. “We are also encouraging tourism by promoting our culture and traditions, having the largest land mass and having a lot of great sites for tourists to visit,” Yasa said.

Title: Ok Tedi Mining will assist school provide hands-on training for students
Content: ABOUT 200 students attending the Morehead Vocational Centre in South Fly, Western, can now have access to more hands-on training with Ok Tedi Mining Limited. This follows the signing of a memorandum of agreement between the school and the mine on Aug 14. The agreement provides for on-the-job student training, addressing the challenge of students being unable to secure practical placements. Morehead Vocational Centre manager Ken Potang commended Ok Tedi for its support towards the educational development of students. “This collaboration marks a pivotal moment for Morehead Vocational Centre and a tremendous blessing to our 229 students and the broader South Fly community,” he said. “Ok Tedi is not just rescuing Morehead Vocational; it is also securing the future of our students. “Despite pursuing various courses, many of our students had previously struggled to find hands-on training opportunities.” Ok Tedi training department manager Ian Strachan said: “Through this agreement, Ok Tedi is dedicated to facilitating vocational training for our students, ensuring they acquire practical experience that equips them for their future careers. “Ok Tedi is committed to building Papua New Guinea’s workforce. “Our ongoing training initiatives – including preferred area development training, apprenticeship training, graduate development scheme, and industrial training –demonstrate our commitment. “Morehead is now the second school, apart from Kiunga Vocational School, we are onboarding in this commitment to develop the youths of Western.”

Title: A life in three worlds. Andrew records experience in memoir
Content: WHILE there are no official records, Andrew Menger Marubu believes that he was born in 1958, at Sol in the upper Mendi Valley. His father, Marubu Pon Mondo, had three wives and Andrew was the third born, and only son, of his second wife, Pim Payim Porom. He is one of a decreasing number of people who have experienced the ‘three worlds’ that have created modern Papua New Guinea. He has experienced traditional life, life during the Australian administration and life since Independence. He has undertaken the extremely difficult and time-consuming task of recording his experiences of living during this historic time in a draft personal memoir. There is a rapidly closing window of opportunity for those who have lived through this historic period to record their experiences and observations. During his career, Andrew has worked in many parts of Papua New Guinea in a range of strategic roles. His work has also taken him to Russia, China, Thailand, New Caledonia, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Western Samoa, Australia, New Zealand and even to the tiny isolated Pacific island of Niue. He explained that his parents would have rarely ventured beyond sight of the place where they were born, before the Australian Administration stopped tribal fighting in the Mendi Valley. Andrew’s wife is a nurse from the Eastern Highlands and the occupations and lives of their children – a lawyer and running her own law firm, a printer, a PNG Power worker, a nurse, a policeman and a medical student – would generally be quite unfamiliar to their grandparents. The people and governments of most nations have had centuries to navigate the politics and technologies of a globalised world, which Papua New Guinea has had to achieve in little more than one generation! Andrew has written of his experiences and observations of Papua New Guinea negotiating its place in the world over the past 50 years; a valuable record of successes and failures to inform future decision-making. He also describes the experiences and observations of the first 17 years of his life during the Australian Administration; especially his interactions with teachers, medical staff and missionaries. Finally, he identifies and explains valuable traditional models used in crisis management, conflict resolution, environmental management, and in community cooperation and regeneration that could be adapted to help address some current and future issues. Andrew highlights effective traditional knowledges used in agricultural, architectural and art practices, developed over centuries or millennia that should be celebrated and not forgotten. Those ideas align with a statement made by Sir Michael Somare in 1975, on the eve of Independence: Every nation must build its identity and future on the strengths of its own past. A nation’s strength is its past. A people’s successful future lies in pride in their past. Traditional life Andrew’s memoir includes detailed descriptions of the traditional lives of his parents and ancestors. While there was constant potential for tribal fighting, Andrew also describesSai haundanMok inkceremonies that contributed to cohesion within a group and also reaffirmed friendships with allies.Sai haundbegan with community members cooperating to buildhauslainsfor future guests andMok inkended with a huge pig-kill where pork was distributed to friends. He also described trade fortigassotree oil – used in singsings – with Foi people around Lake Kutubu and for salt obtained from Enga people near Surunki. Life during the Australian Administration The first Australian that Andrew came into contact with was a nurse at Mendi hospital following an accident. He was impaled on a stick that had an empty round meat tin nailed to it, to create a toy ‘truck’, when it hit a tree-root. Momei Pangial, the first president of the Upper Mendi Local Government Council, persuaded his parents to take him to Mendi hospital. In his very early teens, Momei had attached himself to a patrol and worked his way from assistant cook to eventually representing the people of Mendi in National Parliament. He was able to clearly present the objectives of the Australian Administration to his people, including the power of Western medicine and health care. Andrew suggests that for most villagers, the ability to safely travel as the result of stopping tribal fighting by the Australian Administration had the greatest immediate impact on their lives. Other influences included western medicines and health-care, standardised education and legal systems, the cash economy, and the introduction of Christianity. For the nation as a whole, the introduction of democratic government on three levels – local, provincial and national – and management models were important legacies. Andrew attended Bela Primary T’ School from 1964 and entered Mendi High School in 1971. He was an active member of the Mendi High School cultural activities group. A part of the programme included examining traditional activities such asTie Nolor ‘cassowary race’ that avoided open warfare andTimpceremonies where, after around a generation, all economic, social and spiritual debts were repaid and communities could have a new beginning free of ongoing discontent. The programme also included collaborating with villagers to construct a museum where aspects of the different cultures in the Southern Highlands could be displayed and discussed. The museum was modelled on the largest traditional building in the Mendi Valley – aPolunda –that in turn was an interpretation of a Foi (Lake Kutubu) men’s longhouse. It was supported by six huge posts that had to be extracted from surrounding mountain forests. Life since Independence After graduating from Mendi High School, Andrew attended Sogeri National High School. He entered the University of Papua New Guinea in 1977 and graduated with a degree in social work. That university course had a great influence on decisions and values over his lifetime. In 1980, he entered the public service with the Office of Information that took him to East Sepik and to Eastern Highlands, where he met his wife, Dorothy (nee Kasive), a nurse from Asaro. Next, Andrew was transferred to Daru to serve under the Department of Western Province where he reached the level of assistant secretary. This was followed by a position with the Department of Housing and Urbanisation in Port Moresby. He has also been first secretary to the Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and an advisor to provincial governors and members of parliament, including: The Governor for Southern Highlands; the Governor for Western; the Member for Kavieng and Minister for Defence; Member for Kandrian-Gloucester and Minister for Forests; and Member for South Fly and Minister for Sports. Memoirs such as Andrew’s, especially if well illustrated with contemporary photographs of the people, places and events that are discussed, will be extremely valuable historical records for future generations. They would complement Sir Albert Maori Kiki’s 1968 classic:‘Ten Thousand Years in a Lifetime’. If Andrew’s memoir can be edited and published it would serve as a key model for others to follow.

Title: Bishop Urame calls for real repentance
Content: A CHURCH leader says that it is a mockery to call for repentance without “genuine repentance”. PNG Evangelical Lutheran Church Head Bishop Dr Jack Urame, reflecting on Repentance Day celebrated annually on Aug 26 since 2007, said there had never been any genuine repentance. “PNG has been celebrating the event annually for the past 18 years, yet the reality of the brokenness of our society does not show that there is genuine repentance,” he said. “Repentance by words without actions is a deception of our claim as a Christian country and a denial of our Christian duty.” Urame supported the call by churches for “repentance, reconciliation and to reset the future of the nation”. “We can’t ignore or deny the brokenness which appears in different forms. “Issues of lack of basic services, law and order breakdown, unemployment, youth disorientation, drug, violence, lack of good health care, economic inequality and social injustice are signs of brokenness and suffering confronting our people. “National repentance day provides the time for us to reflect, change, heal and transform our nation. “Without genuine repentance, healing and restoration and future of our nation is not bright and promising.” He said prayer alone could not heal the country’s “brokenness” nor solve corruption, weak governance and ineffective management of the affairs of the country. “Prayer must go together with genuine repentance and real action to mend the brokenness of our nation, from our homes up to the high government offices,” he said. He said the political leaders must lead by example by providing honest leadership. “The Government is entrusted with the responsibility of care to mend the brokenness, heal our nation and give hope,” he added. “The future we want, after 50 years of our political journey, is one with social stability, economic progress, development progress, peace, justice, unity and harmony.”

Title: In strife-torn Enga, Kunalin tribe embraces peace
Content: IN strife-torn Enga province, the Kunalin clan at Sirunki has shown restraint worthy of praise and notice. Situated atop Sirunki where the river Lai has its headwaters – flowing south into the Gulf of Papua and north to the mighty Sepik and onto the Bismarch Sea – the Kunalin opted to throw away violence into the Lai and embrace peace. It did so last Thursday in the face of great aggression and intimidation from a neighboring Laiagam tribe. The tribe invaded Kunalin land, set fire to 13 houses, slaughtered pigs and cut down trees before withdrawing. All through this, Kunalin tribesmen watched from a distance, without a word or action raised in anger or retaliation. The Kunalin tribe live on the border of Enga’s Wabag and Laiagam districts. Their restraint has earned the praise of Jude Tukuliya, the managing director of Conservation and Environment Protection Authority (Cepa), who is from Sirunki. Tukuliya said such a gesture was unusual in Engan culture and particularly in one such as Kunalin, known for its violence and warrior spirit in recent times. It was a true testament to the people’s desire to turn away from violence and embrace peace, he said. The Kunalin from Sirunki station came together with six other tribes in the LLG, including Lakolam tribe from Wabag to launch the community peace programme on the National Repentance Day in Sirunki. The Kunalin clan was attacked on a wrong impression that the clan was responsible for the killing of a man from Laiagam. It was later confirmed that the deceased was being pursued by his enemy from Laiagam into Sirunki and murdered. Tukuliya said the Kunalin wanted to change the image of the region from ‘wild west’ to ‘peaceful west.’ He also acknowledged CARE International for preparing the community well in the last five months, conducting trainings, doing peace advocacy, and identifying livelihood projects for the communities to take on to sustain peace. Other speakers on the occasion, Nelson Leia, the provincial law and order director, with representatives from the provincial government, and Nathan Luso with Rodney Watanikam from Jacob Luke Charitable Foundation and Lyumban Foundation said it was about time clans from all parts of Enga learn to “turn the other cheek”. Sirunki LLG interim president Douglas Tamarua Sirunki, who is from Kunalin, said Sirunki was the gateway to west Enga; Laigam, Kandep and Porgera-Paiela districts, known for tribal fights. If the gateway could shut the door to violence and open it to peace, it was hoped that the same could be embraced by all throughout the west. Youths surrendered home-brewing equipment and marijuana, old and young with their leaders marched in solidarity with the conviction of establishing lasting peace in Sirunki and beyond. Michael Daniels, chairman of Sirunki Peace Foundation Advocacy Society and deputy principal of Sirunki Secondary School said the Kunalin and the rest of the tribes are ready to embrace and promote peace.

Title: All districts in Enga, except Wabag, declared fighting zone
Content: ALL districts in Enga – except Wabag – have been declared fighting zones as of last Thursday, according to Enga provincial administrator Sandis Tsaka. “The Enga provincial peace and good order committee convened an urgent meeting on Aug 21 and by virtue of powers conferred by Section4 of the Intergroup Fighting Act, resolved and declared that all districts of Enga with the exception of Wabag as fighting zones for three months,” he said. The districts affected are Wapenamanda, Lagaip, Porgera-Paiela, Kandep and Kompiam-Ambum. They will include an alcohol ban, restrictions on the movement of people and public gatherings. The three months began from last Thursday. “The declarations are necessary as the provincial government seeks to invoke emergency powers to enable government agencies to control the recent escalation in tribal conflicts and warfare posing serious and imminent public safety risks to our people and also impacting delivery and access to public services across the province,” he said. Tsaka said the declaration would enable government agencies to invoke emergency powers to restrict movement, conduct arbitrary checks, detain suspects, confiscate properties, enforce curfews and other emergency measures to address security threats and restore the rule of law. “An automatic liquor ban comes into effect in all declared fighting zone areas and the Liquor Commissioner and Commission are required to advise all authorised licenced premises of this ban,” he said. “The law enforcement agencies are to work with the commission to enforce the ban.” Tsaka said the movement of people and vehicles in and out of the declared fighting zones would be restricted to ensure public safety. “Public gatherings and assemblies in any public areas within the declared zones will be strictly restricted too,” he said. Tsaka said that all declared areas would undergo random searches and inspection by law enforcement agencies. “Individuals found carrying prohibited items or suspected of illegal activities will be subject to arrest, detainment and appropriate criminal charges would be laid and prosecuted,” he said.

Title: Political party rep says government has not paid them
Content: A POLITICAL party general secretary has called on the Registrar of Political Parties to pay registered party executives gratuities as was the practice before. Pangu Pati general secretary Morris Tovebae said it was “burning issue now”. “Those who came before us enjoyed privileges that included annual leave and repatriation funds,” Tovebae said. “Unfortunately, from my time to now, we are still struggling with this issue,” he said. The Pangu Party general secretray raised the issue of gratuities and the late payment of funds to political parties on behalf of all party executives during the disbursement of government grants to political parties on Monday. The Government through the Political Parties office paid a total of K3.4 million owed to political parties as annual state grants and monthly stipends for party presidents and treasurers since 2023. “Why giving us the run-around on this issue? “If the Personnel Management (department) wants to change this, refer to the Organic Law on Integral Political Parties and Candidates (OLIPPAC) and check on what we are entitled to,” he said. “It is ours. Give it to us as most of us are not from Port Moresby. “We have families, we have homes. “We want to go. “Unfortunately we cannot and so we need our entitlements to be back-paid.” He said that he would take the matters up with Prime Minister James Marape to look into. “Political parties want to work but one of the biggest challenges is that funding is delayed year in year out. “How do you expect us to work in the institutions?” he asked. However, Registrar of Political Parties Emmanuel Pok said that the State did not owe political parties any money but would look at the concern over the party executives’ gratuities raise by Tovebae on behalf of party officials.

Title: Tree Kangaroo programme providing scholarships for students
Content: FOR more than 20 years, the Tree Kangaroo Conservation Programme (TKCP) has operated in Morobe’s Huon Peninsula to establish and manage the country’s first conservation area. The programme has evolved from a species-specific conservation initiative focused on the ecology and status of the endangered Matschie’s tree kangaroo into a holistic programme that encompasses livelihoods, education, health and community-based natural resource management in partnership with local landowners in the Yopno-Uruwa-Som (YUS) area. TKCP associate director Modi Pontio has led the organisation in its most recent programmes which include educational outreach support and community-led conservation for a range of rare and threatened species and their habitats, as well as initiatives to access government services and empower local stewards. “For more than 20 years, TKCP has provided financial support for successful student candidates from YUS seeking teaching certificates through Balob Teachers’ College in Lae,” she said. “This programme started as a partnership with the YUS LLG and the landowners and since 2002, TKCP has awarded scholarships that have helped 33 students graduate as qualified teachers, who return to YUS to fill vacant teacher postings and promote environmental education. “Due to the success of the programme, primary schools throughout YUS have been adequately staffed and reopened, providing children in YUS with greater access to educational opportunities. “Teacher training days are also conducted regularly across YUS, which encompasses more than 50 villages and 18 wards. “Thousands of children have been given an education through this programme. “Because of the education programme, we have now introduced a community health worker scholarship. The first intake will be in 2026 for a two-year programme in Madang. “There are six aid posts in YUS but only two of them are staffed fulltime. “We are working with the provincial health authority to utilise our scholarship candidates to fill this gap.”

Title: 15-Mile police supported with vehicles, station renovation
Content: CENTRAL police officers were told yesterday to take care of vehicles costing K300,000 donated by the Hiri-Koiari Development Authority and the refurbished 15-Mile police station. Assistant police commissioner (National Capital District and Central) Benjamin Turi said anyone destroying buildings or recklessly damaging the vehicles would be dealt with. He said the vehicles were for the people to benefit from and not police officers. “The building itself, I came for inspection a month ago, we’re happy to have a local contractor do the renovations. It will support the prisoners instead of taking them all the way up to Sogeri,” he said. “These vehicles will not be tinted. Take care of them and no drinking and driving.” Turi said the incident scene at Barakau last month where a police vehicle crashed into a construction truck was not a good look when he did inspections. He also said they might need a prisoners’ van for easier transportation from 15-Mile to the court house. “To the public, you are our eyes. “If you see any misuse like carrying families in these vehicles take the number and video or pictures and report it to us.” MP Keith Iduhu said the police station renovation cost around K380,000 to serve people of 15-Mile, lower Sogeri and Hiri East. Iduhu said the areas required logistical support and was for this reason the district had arranged the delivery of two new vehicles. “We commit these vehicles into your care to support the policing needs of our community. “We trust that you will take care and maintain the good conditions of the building with pride and discipline,” he said. “Let us all commit ourselves to being better citizens and more effective public servants. Let us work towards building a better Papua New Guinea by focusing on getting the basics right from the bottom to the top level.”

Title: Court dismisses motion, rules in favour of Dr Ambi
Content: A COURT has dismissed a motion filed by Health Minister Elias Kapavore and Social Change and Mental Health Services (SCMHS) director Dr Nelson Mek seeking to dismiss Dr Umadevi Ambihaipahar’s proceeding for being an abuse of process. National Court judge Susan Purdon-Sully yesterday dismissed the notice of motion as the defendants had failed to rely on a specific provision for summary dismissal provided for in Order 16, a provision sufficient to address their complaint. The court heard that in 2017 Ambihaipahar (better known as Dr Uma or Dr Ambi) was appointed acting director of SCMHS by the then-health minister. On Jan 15, she was served a letter of suspension dated Jan 8 by Kapavore. She filed a judicial review proceedings styled OS (JR) No 5 of 2025 on Feb 10 seeking leave to review the decision of her suspension. On March 4, Kapavore served the plaintiff with a notice of revocation of her appointment and appointed Mek as the director, which was gazetted on Jan 29. The plaintiff withdrew her proceedings on April 3 and filed a fresh proceeding on April 28, seeking leave to review the decision to revoke her appointment. Leave was granted and Mek was added as a party to the proceedings. Kapavore and Mek filed the motion on June 10 to dismiss the plaintiff’s proceedings, arguing that it was incompetent and an abuse of process as she had failed to disclose a reasonable cause for action. The plaintiff raised grounds on competency and argued that the defendants relied on an incorrect jurisdictional basis for order for summary dismissal of the judicial review proceedings which renders the motion’s nullity. The court upheld the plaintiff’s objection as the defendants had invoked the same jurisdictional power in the National Court Rules, deeming an abuse of process. The substantive matter will return for a pre-trial conference on Sept 13.

Title: China brings gifts for veterans
Content: VETERANS of the Pacific Islands Regiment league on Monday were presented two flags, 200 ties and other items by the Chinese Embassy. The league led by president and retired Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) commander Jerry Singirok was established in May as a voice for soldiers from the First and Second battalion and veterans who have served in the regiment. Defence Attaché Senior Col Jiang Tuan said it was a pleasure to show respect to the new veteran’s league of the PNGDF. “We want to keep this good relation not only for the economic areas but also between the two forces and also between the two branches of veterans,” Tuan said. Singirok thanked China’s people’s liberation army for the gifts and said between 1995 and 1996, as commander, he sent the first lot of officers to China for short terms courses hoping that they would build a relationship on the basis that our Government has declared that Papua New Guinea is a friendly country and has no enermies. “This friendship is to the extent that we’d like to study the model in China because veterans in China came to PNG to see conditions and opportunities here in PNG and wed like this association to foster that relationship but more importantly look at the welfare of the veterans,” Singirok said. Other veterans at the event included Brig Gen Francis Agwi, Col Michael Daniels, Maj George Morris, Maj Moses Jenjet and Warrant Officer Chris Mora. Singirok said the veterans cover the first regiment at Taurama and the second regiment in Moem Barracks that was established in 1965 and this has been 60 years in existence with more than 3,000 members. He toldThe Nationalthat the league would be the mouthpiece for Veterans Affairs and for current members who cannot speak openly on matters of operations and administration for the Defence Force. “We hope the government will recognise the faithful work of the soldiers and honour them accordingly,” he said. He added the regiment traces its roots to the Papuan Infantry Battalion and the New Guinea Infantry Battalion — two heroic units during the Southwest Pacific Campaign World War II. “Since then the regiment has stood as the foundation of the PNGDF since 1951 and has served with honour across the region,” Singirok said.

Title: PNG is a failed democracy, former prime minister Peter O’Neill says
Content: FORMER Prime Minister, Peter O’Neill said on Monday that Papua New Guinea is a failed democracy in its 50th year of Independence. Quoting global democracy indexes such as V-Dem and the Global Democracy Index, O’Neill said the country was on a dangerous and accelerated slide towards autocracy. In a statement, O’Neill said the visit by the United Nations (UN) secretary-general next week was not celebratory but “the biggest indication yet of the peril our nation is facing”. O’Neill, who is Leader of the People’s National Congress Party in Opposition and Ialibu-Pangia MP said: “It should come as no surprise but still it is a massive embarrassment strategically timed to be delivered on the eve of our 50 years of independence in the hope we listen and act. “The 2022 National General Election was a diabolical disaster for democracy – less than 50 per cent of eligible voters were able to cast their votes and more than 100 election petitions were filed in the Court of Disputed Returns. “Local level government elections were not delivered last year and remain on a vague timeline and have not been delivered. “Elections are the bare minimum of any democracy. The stolen 2022 National General Election and the failure to deliver the 2024 Local Level Government elections is a testament to the failing democracy and accelerated slide towards autocracy. “There is no doubt that democracy is being denied in our country, not maintained or honoured. “The UN does not listen to corrupt political leaders but instead they base their view on facts such as the Economist Democracy Index; the Democracy Matrix and the V-Dem Institute. “The facts are that in every one of these global democracy indexes, our country is no longer considered a democracy. “The V-Dem Index of 2024 rates PNG as an electoral autocracy with elements of both a hard autocracy and moderate autocracy.”

Title: Muthuvel says all districts in WNB will host independence celebrations
Content: WEST New Britain will join in with the rest of the country as it prepares to celebrate the 50th Independence Anniversary, Governor Sasindran Muthuvel says. Muthuvel said the provincial government, with the support of the three districts, had allocated about K1 million toward the celebrations which would be held from Sept 11-16 with various invited guests to attend each day. “Despite much of the negativity in the country, this is the time for celebration and I encourage everyone to participate in this momentous occasion for PNG,” he said. “We will make sure to support all the districts and LLGs in the province so everyone can come and celebrate. “The main event and celebrations will be held in Kimbe but there will also be celebrations in the rural areas which we will support. “This is a milestone for the country and I encourage all our people to turn up in numbers and participate in this celebration.” Muthuvel made these remarks during the presentation of cheques from the provincial government worth K20,000 each to the Lakiemata Correctional Service and Hoskins School of Excellence in Kimbe on Friday. He also presented another cheque of K105,000 to Gosiagu Designs to provide the attire for provincial government officials, public servants, including teachers and students who would participate in the anniversary celebrations next month. “More than 20 schools and other important institutions will be given financial assistance to participate and host their own celebrations. “Each district will have their own plans and funding for the celebrations so we are happy about that. “We need to be proud of our history and what we have achieved. “That is why we should all celebrate during this year’s independence anniversary. “We must look forward to the next 50 years and expect better things to come for the country,” he said.

Title: Second student charged over girl’s harassment at Unitech; on K2,000 bail
Content: A SECOND University of Technology student appeared in court yesterday charged with one count of cybercrime causing emotional distress. Anthon Howard, 28 from Tari Pori’s Buli village in Hela was the second student to appear in court after Sean Rolpagarea, 21, from Pomio’s Malmal village in East New Britain who was charged with a count of sexual touching under Section 349(1)(a) of the PNG Criminal Code Act. Howard appeared from a police bail of K2,000 and was charged under Section 23 (1) (i) of the Cyber Crime Act 2016. Both Howard and Rolpagarea were charged separately by police following an incident at the Unitech premises on Aug 9, 2025 when a young lady of unstable mind was harassed by male student’s time and aired on social media. In the court yesterday before magistrate Grace Peu, police prosecutor First Constable Maureen Pohei submitted to court for an increase in bail for Howard from K2,000 to K5,000. The court granted the verbal submission and ordered that Howard pay an additional K1,000 while his two guarantors were to pay K1,000 each which will bring the total bail to K5,000. The court ordered Howard to keep with strict bail conditions; to appear in all court mention dates, not to leave Lae unless on leave of court, to reside at Unitech for the duration of his case and to report to police every second Tuesday. Police alleged that Howard on Aug 9, used an electronic device — a mobile phone — took screen shots of the sexual harassment of the young lady that was posted on Unitech Rugby League whatsapp group update. Police say, he then posted those screen shots to his own TikTok account when he was identified and reported to the university’s student representative senate president. Howard was then picked up by the university’s security personnel and handed over to police The court was told that after police interrogation, Howard confessed that six fifteen15-second videos were uploaded to TikTok account, however, he deleted those videos a few minutes after but others had already seen it. He will appear again on Oct 20.

Title: Court throws out man’s 15-year jail term for unlawful discharge of firearm
Content: A MAN’s 15-year jail term for unlawful discharge of firearm was thrown out the National Court in Kokopo. Graham Nohu, from Kavieng’s Meterangkasing village in New Ireland was jailed to 15 years by the District Court in Kokopo on July 24. Aggrieved by the District Court’s decision on sentence to be excessive, he filed his appeal through his lawyer Vincent Gonduon. National Court Judge George Manuhu, who heard the appeal last Monday in Kokopo, said the sentence of 15 years for discharging of firearms in public under Section 59 (1) of the Firearms Act was excessive. He ordered: “By virtue of section 155 (4) of the Constitution, the court declares and order that the sentence of 15 years is reduced to five years.” Judge Manuhu also ordered that one month was deducted for sentence already served. “The remainder of four years and 11 months is suspended on conditions that Nohu keeps peace and good behaviour for three years,” he said. Outside court, Gonduan toldThe Nationalthis was a landmark decision to guide the magistrate when exercising their summary jurisdiction and to mindful of imposing excessive penalties that were not within their powers.

Title: Solar power saves college’s poultry project
Content: THE self-sustained Christian Leaders’ Training College (CLTC) in Banz, Jiwaka, has owed Bank South Pacific Financial Group Limited K3.2 million from its poultry project since 2020. However, CLTC has recently commissioned a K1.4 million solar-generated electricity unit that would help to keep the poultry project and other income-generating projects operating to make money for the repayment of the debt. The solar power will also provide constant electricity for the learning institution. CLTC principal Dr Maxon Mani said the poultry project, which generated much money for the college was affected during the Coronavirus period, creating the huge debt which the college was now repaying. Mani said the poultry project, which chicken and chicks to the Highlands, was managed by Tablebirds from 2015-2019, and when that company left, Signature Poultry took over in 2020. However, Mani said Signature Poultry left during the Covid-19 period after the business was making a loss, resulting in the debt of K3.2 million. He said as a Christian organisation, CLTC took on the debt quietly, and was now repaying the loan. “We are slowly reviving the poultry project, selling 80 boxes of chicks per week. “Also, we are now selling 5,000 meat birds per week. Previously, we used to sell 180,000 –  200,000 birds in a week,” he said. He said CLTC did not have the capacity to rebuild the project to its full potential, however, an application had been put to the Department of Livestock and Agriculture for support to maximise production. He said egg production was being revitalised to meet the market demand. Commenting on the solar power project, Mani said: “Electricity supply is integrated into solar power, PNG Power supply, and generator set, whereby one electricity source is switched off, the other electricity is automatically connected and switched on. “The solar system uses 1,000 solar panels to charge the batteries, producing 700 kilowatts of energy per day.” He said the solar system was funded by New Zealand and Australian benefactors while the solar panels, batteries and accessories were bought in from Germany.

Title: Training centre celebrates 61st anniversary
Content: THE Christian Leaders’ Training College (CLTC) in Banz, Jiwaka, celebrated its 61st anniversary last week as a lead-up to the 50th Independence anniversary celebrations. Attended by few of the 2,000 alumnae who passed out from the centre since 1964, staff, students and the surrounding communities, the celebration was marked with a thanksgiving programme to God for His faithfulness in building leadership in the churches in the South Pacific.
