CLTC principal Dr Maxon Mani said the college with its two campuses in Lae and Port Moresby, was accredited by the Commission of Higher Education in 2010, with the first graduation for the Masters in Theology programme held in 2012. Mani said CLTC was looking forward to offering doctorate programme in bible and theology by 2030. He said a submission was made to the Department of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology three years ago, which was pending approval. The college had the capacity, and was placing the academic staff on doctorate programmes to qualify them for teaching as part of the preparatory stages, he said. Mani said master’s programme was offered in 2008 and degree in1979, five years after the college was incorporated as a national institution. Mani said the Evangelical Alliance Churches, Pentecostal and the mainline churches had their pastoral leaders trained in CLTC to serve the church, Government and community. He said there were three strands of study programmes — agriculture, technical trades, and bible and theology. But in 1995, agriculture and technical skills programmes were taken out because government schools were providing them. “However, we have seen the need to take on agriculture and technical trades, as we see more students coming out from Grade 12,” Mani said. He said apart from the bible and theology programmes, CLTC streamlined community transformation integrated programmes which included scripture study, farming, and business studies five years back.

Title: ‘I ask for forgiveness’: Marape says nation should anchor in God alone
Content: THE words of the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare echoed around Sir John Guise stadium yesterday as people celebrated National Prayer and Repentance Day. Prime Minister James Marape reminded everyone of what Sir Michael had declared in 1975, that no human wisdom could hold together the country’s thousand tribes and 800 languages without being anchored in God. “Sir Michael told us that no human wisdom can hold this land together,” Marape said. “He said this nation must be anchored in God, and God alone. “Today, standing at the threshold of our 50th year, I see the deep wisdom in his words.” The atmosphere at the stadium was filled with words of praise and worship songs by Christians of all denominations. There were live band performances by the gospel band P2UIF and African gospel singer Sinach. Marape urged all Papua New Guineans to seek forgiveness and reconciliation, and rededicate the nation to God. He also requested the people to forgive him for a “curse” he made during the 2019 Repentance Day, that corruption and those who practised it were holding Papua New Guinea back. He said yesterday that it was intended only for the corrupt public servants and politicians. “I remove the curse I made seven years ago as it is not for the nation, and I ask for forgiveness,” he said. “Repentance must go beyond words and be reflected in a real transformation of character. “Repentance is not lip service. “It must be anchored in true transformation – in our hearts, our families, our communities, and in the highest offices of this land.” Marape also held himself accountable. “If I, as your Prime Minister, am a stumbling block to our nation’s progress, I ask God to remove me and raise up someone better to lead Papua New Guinea,” he said.

Title: Seven warring Wabag tribes reconcile
Content: SEVEN warring tribes in Lagaip and at the western end of Wabag districts in Enga came together for a peace ceremony at the Surinki government station on Repentance Day yesterday. It came as tribal fights were reported in Mulitaka and Wapenamanda, and Mt Hagen in Western Highlands. The seven tribes, who sporadically attacked each other, sought forgiveness, and vowed not to take up arms for conflict resolutions. They instead elected to support family building through viable self-sustained projects, and build a peaceful Enga. Men, women and children from Lakolam, Aiyokolam, Leprapus, Apanda, Sirunki station, Kaipale, and Lyamala, marched into the station for the event organised by Care International in PNG and its partners, the Sirunki Peace Advocacy Society, the Surinki Peace Committee and churches. The initiative is a peace-building and livelihood support project to support changes in the western districts of Wabag and Lagaip, promoting a new identity grounded in peace, unity and community resilience. The project is supported by the Minderoo Foundation in Australia through Care International. Surinki local level government president Douglas Tamarua said the western end of Enga must promote peace. He said members of his Kuualin tribe demonstrated that by not retaliating against a tribe from Laigap which attacked them just two days before Repentance Day. Sirunki peace committee member Michael Danus said: “The people of Sirunki and Western Enga want change. We believe that through faith and collaborative efforts, we can restore the glory days of our land.” Care International in a statement said a training had empowered the people to identify the root causes of conflict and to develop their own solutions. The training led to the establishment of eight community peace committees and the creation of seven action plans to promote peace.

Title: Namani describes corruption as a ‘cancer killing our country’
Content: PNG Law Society president Hubert Namani has described corruption as the “cancer killing our country”, saying that it had affected much of the nation’s socio-economic development over the years. “Corruption is affecting almost all the sectors in the country,” he said. “When there is no medicine in the hospital, it is a sign of corruption. “Fifty years on and our mothers are giving birth on the floors of our hospitals. This means that something is very wrong with the country. “We really need good leadership to take the bull by the horn and deal with corruption which is destroying our country.” Namani told the 2025 PNG Update seminar last week that the systems to address corruption were already in place but strong leadership was lacking. He said that institutions such as the Ombudsman Commission, Auditor-General and the judiciary, needed to be empowered to hold those who practised corruption accountable. “These institutions need to be empowered and protected from any outside interference,” he said. “We have the laws in place to allow them to operate but there has been a low rate of prosecution of about 20 per cent in the country. That is unacceptable.” He added that adherence to the Constitution would not only address corrupt practices but also allow for greater socio-economic development of the country. He said: “The Constitution was born out of careful thought and we shouldn’t change it. Among other things, the Constitution also allows for economic development. Papua New Guinea is blessed with so many natural resources yet we cannot translate these blessings into economic development for the people. The Constitution provides for the systems for us to develop our country but we have to make it work.”

Title: Opposition wants Marape and Air Niugini to reinstate Seddon
Content: OPPOSITION Leader Douglas Tomuriesa wants Prime Minister James Marape and the Air Niugini board to reinstate Gary Seddon who was recently suspended. He said that he had never seen a chief executive of Air Niugini with his officers and the public in the terminals to ensure everything was in order, the queues were shorter and passengers served on time. “Under this CEO, we have seen new planes being ordered and what we are hearing is that in September, the planes will arrive in our country,” Tomuriesa said. Airline board chairman Karl Yalo said Seddon was suspended so that they could look into information on spare parts and other administrative issues. Seddon’s suspension came before the airline received its first Airbus A220 on Sept 15. Tomuriesa asked why should somebody come and do the hard work, use his wisdom to bring these planes into the country, and then somebody else comes and takes the credit? “I think this is nonsense,” he said. He urged the Government to look into this and act quickly as this was not in the public’s interest. Tomuriesa added that as the country looked to celebrate 50 years, people needed to be reassured of their safety in planes, who managed it and their leaders in Parliament to present them. “I’m calling on the prime minister to get the board to reinstate the CEO to his position.”

Title: ‘Prison taught us to repent’: Inmates sing gospel songs composed behind bars
Content: TEN low-risk prisoners from the Bomana Prison sang two self-composed songs during the Jubilee Reset Gospel Music festival in Port Moresby – saying that they were blessed to be part of it. Bomana Prison music ministry band leader Nathan Manikumbu from Maprik in East Sepik toldThe Nationalthat it was a blessing for him and his fellow inmates to participate in the festival. “Two of the original gospel songs that we sang are composed by us while in prison, and they are about resetting our mindset as prisoners and to look forward to come out of the prison as changed and reborn (Christians),” he said. He said he was happy that five Correctional Officers trusted him and the other low-risk prisoners and escorted them to perform at the Sir John Guise stadium music festival. “With ‘reset’ being the theme of the music festival, it is a blessing that we come to show our musical talents with other church ministries,” he said. “Staying in the prison has taught us to repent, reset our mindsets and be born again and come out a changed person.” Manikumbu said the titles of the two songs they composed were “Giving back to Jesus” and “Repent”. “The two songs are composed from our hearts and the words have a deep meaning, reflecting the theme of the jubilee year,” he said. “I reflect on the word of God in Leviticus 27 as I repent and ready to be released from the prison and be born again in the name of Jesus.”

Title: Political parties cautioned to comply with financial returns
Content: POLITICAL party executives have been cautioned to comply with financial returns or face grants being forfeited to the government. Registrar of Political Parties Emmanuel Pok said this when paying K3.4 million to 16 political parties with MP representatives for administrative use. Each registered party is expected to acquit an election report, due three months after an election, and the annual report due each year on March 31. Pok, referring to Section 88 of the Organic Law on Integral Political Parties and Candidates (OLIPPAC), said party executives who do not comply will be guilty of misconduct in office under the leadership code and will be referred to the Ombudsman Commission. The payment on Monday is state funding for 2023 and 2024. Each party will be paid K10,000 for each MP. “Though we face delayed funding situations, when the state pays, it backdates and pays in full. “As of today (Monday), the State does not owe any funds to political parties. “It is now for the executives to ensure they comply with the commission with their acquittals or they face penalties,” he said. Since 2001, when the OLIPPAC was introduced, the state invested over K85 million over the last 24 years. This includes fortnightly salaries and monthly stipends for political party executives. “If there is no reasonable justification for two consecutive years, party registrations will be cancelled,” he said. The commission has expended a sum of over K1 million in political party funding and K1 million in stipends for presidents and treasurers of political parties. From the K3.4 million paid by the State, over K3 million has been disbursed to the 16 political parties. The balance of K400,000 is from penalties paid by political parties.

Title: Police ready to provide security for independence celebrations
Content: POLICE in Madang, Morobe and East Highlands are set to provide security during the 50th independence celebrations next month, says Assistant Commissioner of Police Northern Command, Peter Guinness. “As far as I know, we do not have any budget for security operations to support the independence in my command but I can only assume that each respective province will make funding available for the celebrations,” he said. Guinness said this when responding to questions byThe Nationalon the budget for each command for security during the independence. He said for the 50th independence celebrations in Lae: “I was informed that the police cadets will be in Lae as the independence celebrations will coincide with the Morobe Show. “So we will have a fun-time in the three provinces under my command as I always get support from the respective provincial governments so I will ask for assistance in terms of providing security support during the Independence celebrations so that the people enjoy in peace,” he said. Meanwhile, Chief of Bougainville Police, Francis Tokura said they had a budget planned for the security operations but they were waiting for the Autonomous Bougainville Government (ABG) to release funding. “I have an independence committee in place with discussions on the programmes but we also have issues with the funding and hoping that the Bougainville MPs and the regional member would help us along with ABG,” he said. He said they had planned to have celebrations in all three regions with the main celebrations of the 50th independence anniversary at Hutjena Oval in Buka. “We are looking forward to have three-days of celebrations in Bougainville from Sept 12-16 with security personnel ready to provide security,” he said.

Title: Senior police officers sign new contracts
Content: TWENTY-FIVE senior officers from the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary signed their contracts before Police Commissioner David Manning in Port Moresby yesterday. Manning said the contracts for senior officers were done on merit basis and encouraged them to work effectively in their respective specialty areas. “I would like to congratulate the 25 senior officers including four provincial police commanders (PPCs) on your contract signing today and I wish you all the best in your careers,” he said. Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP), Human Resource, Gaiwary Tinga said for ACPs and Divisional Commanders’ positions who were acting, gazettes had been sent out already and once the Commissioner sighted them, they will be advertised. “As soon as the Commissioner appoints the new ACPs and divisional commanders, we will assist them with their contracts,” he said. The 25 senior officers who signed their contracts were: Deputy Commissioner of Police (DCP), Regional Operations, Samson Kua, DCP- Administration, Dr Philip Mitna; DCP- Chief of Bougainville Police, Francis Tokura; ACP-Crimes, Hodges Ette; ACP-Policy and Planning Divisions Rigga Neggi; ACP-Specialist Operations, Julius Tasion, Divisional Commander – Northern, Peter Guinness, ACP Traffic, John Kolopen, Divisional Commander- New Guinea Islands Naua Vanuwaru, ACP-Internal Affairs, Emil Alfa, Lae Metropolitan Superintendent Chris Kunyanban, Director Crimes Superintendent Joel Simatab, Director Special Services Division (SSD) Chief Superintendent Michael Tilae, Director Human Resource Management (HRM) Supt Paul Unupite, Director HRM and Training Supt Jackson Ambe, Director Logistics Publications, Supt Godwin Dukaduka, Director Corporate Services, Supt Steven Bunga, Director Regional and Provincial Training, Supt Paul Kipak, Director ABS, Supt Charlie Sare, FAS, Finance and Administration, Jerry Pais, Western Highlands Provincial Police Commander (PPC), Chief Supt John Sagom, PPC- Southern Highlands Supt Epenes Nili, PPC East Sepik, Supt Chris Tamari, Chimbu PPC, Supt Mazuc Rubiang and PPC Eastern Highlands, Chief Supt John Kale.

Title: Military walk passes through Agevairu
Content: THE 16-man team from the First Royal Pacific Islands Regiment (1RPIR) left Agevairu village around 2am yesterday after spending a night. The team led by Lt Desmond Avamor is expected to arrive at Laloki on Saturday after starting off at Malalaua in Gulf last Wednesday. Papua New Guinea Defence Force land units are reenacting a walk done by soldiers at the Moem Barracks, Wewak who in 1975, had walked 1,200km to Port Moresby to deliver independence messages. Deputy Chief of PNGDF Brig-Gen Lari Opa had said it was the PNGDF’s way of showing its commitment towards protecting its country andpeople. “The walk has attracted not only leaders but villagers and people as well along roadsides as they watch their PNGDF personnel walk by,” he said. “With soldiers making it before the given dates just shows how fit and ready they are and we’re happy for that.” Over the weekend, the team reached Eboa in Mekeo and passed Yule Island junction. They are expected to be met by their families and other soldiers at the Goldie River Training Depot when they arrive. 1RPIR commanding officer Lt Col Ezron Dekaetavara said this walk of pride, unity and patriotism had pushed the soldiers forward to meet the dates given. The messages in the batons will be presented at Independence Hill. One will be handed over to the PNGDF and one to the Government. Dekaetavara said the walk was not easy, it was tough, dangerous and long for the soldiers as they crossed rivers, swamps and climbed steep mountains, demonstrating their determination. He said the final phase would be where they would meet with all other units for a freedom of city match into Port Moresby on Monday to deliver the messages.

Title: MPs must develop country and not just ‘focus on securing funds’: Webstar
Content: A PROMINENT academic has urged people to understand that the role of MPs is more than just bringing service to their respective electorates. National Research Institute Professor research fellow Dr Thomas Webster told the 2025 PNG Update seminar last week that MPs had a responsibility for the development of the nation and not just of their own people. “People have developed a mind-set that MPs are meant to deliver on their needs and requests such as fixing infrastructure or paying for funeral expenses,” he said. “The focus of many MPs now is to secure funds for their electorates and provinces. “It is not about national issues or how best they can address them but about their electorate and how they are able to secure their funds.” Webster urged all MPs to understand the primary roles as legislators in Parliament, which was the representation of the country’s legislative arm of government. He said that MPs, through Parliament and parliamentary committees, needed to hold the executive government accountable to the people. “MPs, even though they have been elected by their people to be represented in Parliament, must make decisions in the best interest of the nation,” he said. “Parliament makes laws and elect the executive government and ensures accountability of the executive government. “Parliamentary committees, which are also empowered by the Constitution, must also be strengthened to provide oversight over the executive government. “These roles have been lacking as there has been a decline in the ability of Parliament to hold the executive government accountable.” Webster added that Papua New Guineans must also understand the roles and responsibilities of their elected leaders, stating that elections are one of the most important democratic processes for them. “People need to know about their role in the development of the country,” he said. “They are able to contribute through their elected leaders during elections every five years.

Title: Government’s poor fiscal plan leaves country in K65 billion debt, says Nomane
Content: CHUAVE MP James Nomane claims the Government’s fiscal consolidation plan has led to a national debt of K65 billion after borrowing K40 billion in the last seven years. Nomane said proper fiscal consolidation, a government policy aimed at reducing budget deficits and national debt by either cutting spending or increasing revenue to improve fiscal sustainability and investor confidence, was still left wanting ever since Prime Minister James Marape took office in 2019. “On the eve of Papua New Guinea’s 50th Independence anniversary, the 2025 national budget is on the brink of failing because of the Government’s failed fiscal consolidation,” he said in a statement on Monday. “After six years, we continue to miss revenue targets, and the prime minister is unable to make the tough decision to cut spending on Connect PNG and the public service. The latter takes up 33 per cent of the budget and crowds out development priorities. “From the 5.6 per cent legislated fund for Connect PNG programme, more than K8.5 billion has been spent on road infrastructure without any audits in the last six years. “This lack of transparency and governance is synonymous with crony capitalism and parochial politics.” Nomane said if the Government was focused on decreasing expenditure, the country would have stabilised debt, curbed inflation, reduced deficit, and created fiscal space for investments. “The Government defends itself by saying its borrowing is within the ambit of the Fiscal Responsibility Act and brags about a sustainable debt-to-GDP ratio of 52 per cent. “The sad reality is that gross domestic product (GDP) is artificially high because inflation is high, and the Kina is in depreciation. “GDP is not high because of high economic output,” Nomane said. “The current situation is that failed revenue has led to cash shortages, increasing arrears and putting pressure on debt repayments, and those districts that received only K3 million out of K20 million in 2025 will not receive 100 per cent appropriation. “The 2025 Budget will fail without an immediate supplementary budget to correct this budget blowout. The Government, under the guise of fiscal consolidation, has plummeted the country into unsustainable debt with no foreign direct investment in six years, no growth prospects, and wider inequality.”

Title: Better services for Chimbu hospital patients
Content: PATIENTS visiting Chimbu’s Mingende Hospital will now be able to access services such as general surgeries, laboratory outcomes, radiology and dental among others, according to Health Minister Elias Kapavore. The Pomio MP was recently in the province to present the level-four certificate of accreditation to Mingende hospital after 75 years of existence. The health facility was understood to be established as an aid post by Catholic missionaries on Aug 25, 1950. “It took 14 years to make their dream a reality to formally recognise and award them the district hospital status, making this facility the first district hospital in Chimbu,” Kapavore said. “Full commendation to (Kerowagi MP) Francis Siune, Governor Noah Kool and the Simbu Health Authority (PHA) board and management led by Dr Ken Kasi. “Following this accreditation, the Simbu PHA has recruited a surgeon to be based at Mingende for the first time. “Siune has committed to providing a vehicle for the surgeon. “I thank the local MP for providing six ambulances for the health centres in his district. “Such partnership is vital for the effective functioning of PHAs.” Kapavore said similar ratings (level four) have been awarded to East New Britain’s Vunapope Hospital and Gulf’s Kapuna Hospital. “A similar arrangement is underway for Raihu Hospital in West Sepik,” he said. “We thank the Catholic Church Health Services for being our special partner in healthcare pre-independence today and into the future.”

Title: Chinese ambassador congratulates PNG on golden jubilee
Content: CHINA’s ambassador Yang Xiaoguang has congratulated Papua New Guinea on its 50th Independence anniversary, highlighting the achievements of both countries since diplomatic ties were established in 1976. “In just over 20 days, PNG will celebrate its 50th anniversary of independence,” he said. “Next year will also mark the 50th anniversary of China-PNG diplomatic relations. “Building on past achievements and forging ahead into the future, our relations are at a critical stage. “This presents a significant opportunity for the development of bilateral relations and the deepening of cooperation in various fields, and will also create new opportunities for PNG. “We extend sincere congratulations to the PNG Government and people.” Yang added that Chinese ecology and environment minister and special envoy Huang Runqiu would attend the 50th Independence Anniversary celebrations in the country on behalf of the Chinese government. He also stated that even though PNG and China formally established diplomatic relations 49 years ago, both countries have more than a century’s worth of shared history. “More than 100 years ago, Chinese people came to PNG across the sea,” Yang said. “They settled down, worked hard and with integrity. “They learned the local language and culture, and gradually integrated into the local community, becoming an integral part of PNG’s society and culture. “Today, the Chinese community is the second largest foreign ethnic group in PNG. “They are important players in PNG’s economic and social development, promoters of China-PNG cultural exchange and friendship, and an important bridge and bond between our two countries.”

Title: PNG launches Human rights plan
Content: PAPUA New Guinea reached a significant milestone in the journey of protecting the rights and freedom of every citizen with the launch of the Human Rights Strategic Plan 2024-29. Justice and Attorney-General Department Secretary Dr Eric Kwa, during the launch last week, said the plan is a roadmap to strengthening governance, improve access to justice, and give voice to the most vulnerable. “Over the next five years, it will guide coordinated national action to advance human rights in Papua New Guinea,” he said. Kwa said this historic achievement drives a national agenda that had remained unresolved for more than 30 years, and thanked the Government for its strong commitment to enhancing human rights protections in the country. “Over the years, steps have been taken to in critical issues such as gender-based violence, sorcery accusation-related violence, family protection, child rights, gender equality and rights of persons living with disabilities. “This strategy builds on those efforts and places human rights at the heart of national priorities,” he said. Kwa said the strategic plan was aligned with the medium-term development plan, particularly strategic policy area five (law and justice), the strategy ensures greater access to justice for vulnerable groups, including women, children, persons with disabilities, people in rural areas, and those who are socially and economically disadvantage. “It also supports women’s empowerment, tackles gender violence, promotes family and social inclusions and complements strategic priority area 11 on good governance,” he said. Kwa said human rights can no longer be secondary, they require focused attention and concrete actions, and this strategy provides a clear and coordinated response.

Title: Wasi making busking known in Wewak
Content: STREET preachers speaking to passersby are common in Port Moresby and Wewak, East Sepik, among other centres. Musicians who busk, or perform on streets, are rare. You will find one or two at Boroko in Port Moresby. Musicians who busk on the streets or beside shopping malls are common in towns and cities in the western world. In Wewak, there is one musician who is bringing this rare practice to the sea-side town. Leo Wasi can be found busking beside the QP Trading shop, opposite the Tang Mow Plaza and hotel car park. The artiste, with his acoustic guitar, will be seen most days of the week, donned in white and sporting a nice hat as well. His favourite numbers are the golden oldies. He also sings with an accent that is more foreign than local. “I come here almost every day,” Wasi said. “I also do tutorials for those who want to play the guitar.” Wasi said he charges his students K25 for two-three hours. “I have roots in Chambri here in East Sepik, but I came from Lae, in Morobe,” he said. “I am here for a while. I do not know how long I will be staying.” In the meantime, the show goes on.

Title: ‘We were the youths of Independence’: Max Hufanen Rai recalls how student activism helped drive PNG’s push for nationhood
Content: IN the final years before independence, the University of Papua New Guinea (UPNG) was more than an academic institution – it was a political engine. Student leaders debated, campaigned, and confronted the doubts of a divided country. Max Rai was one of them. “I was one of the student leaders who always spoke pro-independence,” he said. “Because I was very close to the late Grand Chief Sir Michael Somare, I would stand up and argue against anyone who opposed independence.” Rai entered UPNG in 1974 after completing Form Four at Brandi High School. He was part of a cohort of Sepik students who had come through one of the country’s top secondary schools at that time. “Preliminary year is like combining Form Five and Form Six,” he said. “After that, I did a degree for three years.” But it wasn’t the academic structure that defined his time – it was the political climate. Rai became student president of the Pangu Pati branch and a regular speaker at the university forum. “Sometimes I chaired meetings. Other times, anything said about Somare or Pangu Pati, I would stand up against other people.” The forums were held at lunchtime, open to students and lecturers alike. “When there were elections, we would have forums,” Rai said. “I would be chairing the meeting promoting Pangu Pati. And I travelled around the country campaigning – in Madang, in Rabaul, and different places.” But not everyone was convinced that gaining independence was the right way to go. At least not yet. “Many in the Highlands thought they weren’t ready,” Rai said. “But we said: Let’s get independence and worry about your problems later. We told them the Australians weren’t going to build roads in the highlands. We have to become independent, find our own money, and build our own bridges and roads. “But the Australians supported our move for Independence and that made a big difference.” Rai said the Sepik students were especially vocal. “We were ready. Definitely,” he said. “Even though we had similar infrastructure problems, our councils were already building roads. “Most of the roads in our province were built by councils – not the national government.” The forums at the university weren’t just talk. They shaped public opinion. “We were promoting independence all the time,” Rai said. Rai’s connection to Sir Michael ran deep. His sister’s husband had worked with Sir Michael atRadio Wewak, and Rai had known him since he was young. “Those people who said negative things about Somare, I would stand up and confront them and then I would go and report all that to him,” he said. Sometimes, while Rai was in UPNG, Sir Michael would send for him directly. The UPNG administration at the time encouraged student involvement in the lead-up to independence. “They encouraged us to take part in independence – a historic event that would transform everything in PNG, including the university,” Rai said. “Some people did not because they were scared that something might happen. But nothing happened. “We celebrated independence (with) no problems.” On September 16, 1975, Rai and fellow student Gabriel Dusava attended the flag-raising ceremony at Sir Hubert Murray Stadium. “People arrived so early. The place was packed,” he said. “When Gabriel and I caught a bus and arrived, they said: ‘Place is full. Wait outside.’ So we had to stay on the roadside and watch the flag go up.” Rai remembers the moment vividly. “The Australian flag came down for the very last time,” he said. “A lot of people were crying. They were sorry that the Australians were leaving. Not necessarily overnight. The flag coming down meant that they were going to eventually leave. And our flag went up, and it’s been up there all these years.” Rai felt pride – not just in the country, but also in the role students had played. “We were the youths of independence. We pushed for it. We believed in it. And now we were seeing it happen,” he said. “In the early days, we had to nurture the country. You didn’t have to graduate from an Australian university to come and do miraculous things. You have to graduate from your own country and go through the experience.” During his time at UPNG, Rai also led demonstrations against government decisions he believed weren’t in the nation’s interest. “If you don’t agree with the government, you must,” he said. “We led many demonstrations. Not violent. But we made an impact.” Sir Michael knew Rai was involved. “He would tell the people to come and tell me to go up and talk to him,” he said. “I’d go up and brief him and say, we’re demonstrating for the public. We must make an impact for public support.” Rai believes student power was essential in those years. “Often the opposition parties were not very active,” he said. “In politics, you trade positions. Sometimes, some things that were not good for the country – you need student power to force the government to change.” Rai said the forums were the backbone of that movement. “Almost every day at the university forum, if we thought that something was not in the nation’s interest in the long run, we would debate.” After graduation, Rai joined the Department of Foreign Affairs and later studied at the Australian National University. But even outside of UPNG, he still did all he could for the country that he and many others of his generation were nurturing. He went on to be a United Nation’s diplomat and an ambassador to several countries, including China. He laid the ground work for Chinese investors to come to the country and for PNG students to study in China. Looking back, Rai credits Sir Michael’s cabinet strategy for PNG’s peaceful transition. “He put the right people in Cabinet to represent the whole country,” he said. “They went out and convinced everyone. That’s why we got independence without trouble.” Rai said he was proud of the country’s resilience since gaining independence. “There’s no country like PNG,” he said. “We have thousands of languages and yet our people still get along.” But he’s also clear-eyed about the risks and how fragile unity can be at times. “Any disintegration will be a disaster,” he said, adding that one province deciding to leave may lead to more pulling away. “At independence, many thought we’d fall apart, but we didn’t.” Rai said Sir Michael had always intended for provinces to gradually become autonomous so that the people would not have to rely on the Government or donors. “It came out in the Constitutional Planning Committee to ensure that it goes in the Constitution. That eventually, provinces should be autonomous to ensure that they take the lead in building their own provinces,” he said. Rai urges young Papua New Guineans to think nationally. “Don’t think about your province. Think PNG. Promote the country first, then your place of origin,” he said. Rai said in that way, everyone would be contributing to nation-building as it was everyone’s responsibility. “PNG will become a strong and powerful country. A competitor to Australia and New Zealand.” Rai is not just hopeful – he’s proud. “As somebody who was part of the youth of independence, I must say: I’m really proud of our country,” he said. “We’ve come a long way.”

Title: Deadly infectious diseases on Australia’s doorstep
Content: Adelaide: Australians have little knowledge of the threat on their doorstep from the world’s deadliest infectious diseases and it has a crucial role in fighting them, the head of a global health partnership says. Lady Ros Morauta, chair of the Global Fund to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, is visiting Australia this week to lobby MPs to increase our contribution to its work. “These diseases are a huge threat to Australia,” she told AAP. “HIV, for example – there are heaps of Australians who go to PNG and to Fiji, and the increase in HIV in those two countries in the last couple of years is extraordinary.” The Global Fund’s Indo-Pacific regional impact report, released on Monday, exposes the urgent health emergencies on Australia’s doorstep. Papua New Guinea recorded 11,000 new HIV cases in 2024 and declared a national HIV crisis in June, while Fiji declared an HIV outbreak in January after almost 1,600 new infections last year. TB remains PNG’s leading cause of death, with its health minister declaring “a war” on TB in June. Lady Ros, who has lived in PNG for 43 years and was the nation’s first lady from 1999 to 2002, said Global Fund’s impact as a multilateral funder of global health grants had been “amazing”. Over the last two decades, the Global Fund partnership has saved 65 million lives and cut the combined death rate from AIDS, TB and malaria by 61 per cent, she said. “It’s the most fantastic organisation, because it’s very much country-led, country-focused and performance-driven. It’s not the donor saying, ‘oh, you should do this’, she said. Funding is based on a national plan put forward by the nation, and implemented by government agencies and the private sector. “If you say you’re going to distribute half a million mosquito nets, you have to distribute them for the next lot of money to come,” Lady Ros said. There were still huge health challenges in the region, and Australia should support its neighbours by tackling them, she added. Australia pledged AU$266 million (about K720m) for 2023-2025, and the fund is now seeking AU$330 million (about K893m) for its next funding cycle. “Australia has been a donor to the Global Fund from the very beginning – and it’s in Australia’s interest, as well as being the right thing to do,” Lady Ros said. Australia is expected to announce its next pledge to the fund in 2025. Source: AAP

Title: Australia in the dark over China-Nauru development deal
Content: Canberra: Australia discovered a major deal between Nauru and a Chinese company through a press release, months after signing a pact that demands advanced notice of security and critical infrastructure agreements. Australia is providing Nauru AU$100 million (about K270m) in budget support and AU$40 million (about K108m) for policing in exchange for an effective veto of security and critical infrastructure agreements with third countries. The treaty, under which Australia has transferred $40 million in 2025, stipulates Canberra must be consulted on agreements affecting Nauru’s security and critical infrastructure. Any pact then needs to be mutually agreed upon before Nauru signs. Foreign Affairs Department officials revealed they found out about a AU$1 billion (about 2.7b) infrastructure investment proposal signed by Nauru and the China Rural Revitalisation and Development Corporation via a media release. First assistant secretary in the department’s Pacific division Mark Tattersall played down concerns when questioned at a public hearing on Monday, saying it was only a proposal that had not yet gone to Nauru’s cabinet. Any implementation or investment was “potentially some time off”, he added. Tattersall insisted the security pact was operating as planned despite saying Australia was “interested by the language” in the Chinese agreement. “When it was released by press release on the Nauruan government website, we noted language in the proposal that potentially triggers some elements of treaty provisions,” he told a parliamentary hearing into the treaty. “We’ve reached out to Nauru and counterparts to seek further details.” Australia has since received further details, Tattersall said. “We have agreed to continue any discussions with Nauruan counterparts to see if treaty provisions are indeed triggered by the proposal,” he said. Canberra has also reached out to Beijing. Tattersall admitted Australia had found “not a great deal” of detail about the Chinese company. “There does not appear to be a large body of internet presence for the entity in China,” he said. Liberal MP Henry Pike said it was “strange that it wasn’t flagged by the government of Nauru”. He questioned the rationale for calm after Tattersall referred to the agreement as “just … an investment proposal at this time”. “It seems strange to me that something … isn’t officially policy of the Nauruan government when you’ve got the minister for foreign affairs and trade and his deputy in Beijing signing a document,” Pike said. Officials from Australia and Nauru have formally met six times to discuss their treaty’s implementation. Department of Foreign Affairs assistant secretary Jeff Roach said the treaty ensured Pacific security issues would be tackled by Pacific nations, something Australia is championing as it tussles with Chinese influence in the region. Nauru ratified the treaty in February after it was signed by the two nations’ leaders in Canberra in December 2024 but it still needs to pass the Australian parliament. Tattersall said he hoped it would be ratified before Pacific island leaders meet for a regional forum in mid-September. Source: AAP

Title: Trump to chair Gaza meeting in Washington this week
Content: Gaza: US special envoy Steve Witkoff says President Donald Trump will chair a meeting on Gaza at the White House and added that Washington expects Israel’s war in the Palestinian territory to be settled by the end of the year. The meeting will be held on Wednesday. The US State Department separately said Secretary of State Marco Rubio will meet Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar in Washington the same day. Trump had promised a swift end to the war in Gaza during the 2024 US election campaign and after taking office in January, but almost seven months into his term, that stated goal remains elusive. An Israeli security official said on Tuesday that none of the five journalists were among the six Hamas targets killed. Israeli forces struck Nasser hospital in Khan Younis in the south of the enclave on Monday, killing at least 20 people including journalists who worked for Reuters, the Associated Press, al-Jazeera and other outlets. In its statement on Tuesday, the Israeli military said troops had identified what it said was a camera “positioned by Hamas” in the area to observe its forces. It said they operated to remove the threat by striking and dismantling the camera. The statement identified what it called “several gaps” that Israel’s Chief of the General Staff had instructed be further examined: “Firstly, a further examination of the authorisation process prior to the strike, including the ammunition approved for the strike and the timing of the authorisation. “Secondly, an examination of the decision-making process in the field.” The statement said the Chief of the General Staff had emphasised that the Israeli military directs its activities solely toward military targets. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office said on Monday that Israel deeply regretted what he called a “tragic mishap”. An Israeli military spokesman said on Tuesday that journalists working for Reuters and Associated Press were not a target of Israel’s strike on Nasser hospital. “We can confirm that the Reuters and AP journalists were not a target of the strike,” he said. On Monday, the Reuters live video feed from the hospital, which cameraman Hussam al-Masri, a Reuters contractor, had been operating, suddenly shut down at the moment of the initial strike. Masri was killed in the attack. Reuters and other news providers often deliver live video feeds to media outlets worldwide during major news events to show the scene from the ground in real time. Reuters has frequently broadcast a feed from Nasser hospital during the Gaza Strip war, and for the past several weeks had been delivering daily feeds from the hospital position that was hit. The journalists killed also included Mariam Abu Dagga, who freelanced for the Associated Press and other outlets, Mohammed Salama, who worked for Qatar-based broadcaster al-Jazeera, Moaz Abu Taha, a freelance journalist who worked with several news organisations including occasionally contributing to Reuters, and Ahmed Abu Aziz. Source: Reuters

Title: UN Secretary General Guterres to address Parliament during visit
Content: UNITED Nations (UN) Secretary-General António Guterres will address the Papua New Guinea Parliament during his visit next month, according to Prime Minister James Marape. “This is the first time that a UN Secretary-General has come to our country. And it is not just a fly-in, fly-out visit, but a four-day stay – something quite unprecedented for the Secretary-General in any single location globally,” Marape said. “This visit is a profound honour for our people. “His presence demonstrates recognition of Papua New Guinea’s consistent respect for democracy, individual freedoms, human rights, and peacebuilding since Independence.” Guterres will arrive on Sept 2 and leaves on Sept 5. He will address Parliament on Sept 3. He said that the visit would also acknowledge the Bougainville Peace Agreement of Aug 30, 2001, a landmark in peace and reconciliation, and Papua New Guinea’s role in maintaining peace and unity within its diverse communities. Guterres will call on the Governor-General Grand Chief Sir Bob Dadae. He will travel to Mt Hagen on Sept 4 to witness community peace initiatives and visit forest areas that showcase Papua New Guinea’s rich biodiversity. Marape said that Guterres was expected to speak on Papua New Guinea’s global significance as one of the world’s great biodiversity hubs, and to recognise the nation’s leadership in environmental stewardship and sustainable development. “As we celebrate 50 years of Independence, we are humbled that global leaders, including the UN Secretary-General and His Royal Highness Prince Edward, will join us. “Their presence affirms that Papua New Guinea is not isolated, but a respected member of the international community,” Marape said.

Title: Unitech student fined for obstructing police duty, locked up in Buimo
Content: A MAGISTRATE on Friday ordered a second year student of Papua New Guinea University of Technology in Lae, Morobe to pay K4,000 fine or face two years in jail at Buimo Prison. Ezekiel Kimbu, 26, from Goroka’s Kama village in Eastern Highlands, was convicted by magistrate Nasiling Bingtau after finding him guilty of one count of obstructing a lawful instruction from a member of the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary. The court fined Kimbu and ordered that his K300 bail be converted to court fine which leaves K3,700 to be paid before being released. Bingtau further ordered that three months be deducted from Kimbu’s two-year jail term, which means he will now serve one year and nine months in prison. He will be kept in custody at Buimo Prison until such time that his fine is paid in full. On Aug 9, 2025, Kimbu was at East Taraka in Lae, Morobe between 2am and 3am when police caught up with him. At that time, police noticed drunkards standing in front of a canteen and were drinking and making loud noises. The drunkards were cautioned by a member of the police to leave the place and the canteen keeper to close her store as it was into late hours. At that time, police took into consideration a fresh ethnic clash in Lae so such groupings in the odd hours was not tolerated. Kimbu then asked the police why they asked for the shop to close when nothing was happening there at that time. Police arrested Kimbu for disobeying and obstructing police duty, charged him and had him before the court where he was found guilty as charged and sentenced.

Title: Manele will return for independence celebrations, says Marape
Content: PRIME Minister James Marape says that his Solomon Islands counterpart Jeremiah Manele will return for the 50th Independence anniversary celebrations on Sept 16. Marape said that 15 Pacific leaders were expected in Port Moresby for the anniversary celebrations after attending the Pacific Islands Forum in Honiara from Sept 8 to 12. Marape emphasised the need to move “from aid to trade,” calling for deeper economic engagement between the two nations. He urged foreign missions to open embassies in the Solomon Islands, stressing that the country “deserves respect” as a sovereign partner. Marape also endorsed Manele’s initiative of “Melanesian Oceans”, a regional approach to harness the Pacific’s fisheries and marine resources sustainably. “Our oceans hold some of the world’s richest tuna stocks. “Together, Melanesia must shape our own destiny and ensure resources benefit our people,” Marape said. More than 60 Papua New Guinean businesses are registered in the Solomon Islands in telecommunications, oil palm, banking, and tourism. Marape said Papua New Guinea remained the largest foreign investor in the Solomon Islands. Marape praised Solomon Islands’ tourism potential, encouraging Papua New Guineans and the international community to visit. “PNG is still growing in tourism, but our cousins in the Solomon Islands will look after you well. “They are not an extension of PNG. They are a proud nation of their own,” Marape said. Manele departed for Australia on Friday.
